"New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pennsylvania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Laredo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Polynesia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6394589", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps update (06): USA (PA) outbreak update", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6394589", "date": "2019-03-05 18:58:32", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (03): USA (PENNSYLVANIA, TEXAS), EUROPE (IRELAND)\n***************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\nUSA\n---\n[1] USA summary\n[2] Pennsylvania\n[3] Texas\n\nEurope\n------\n[4] Ireland\n\n******\n[1] USA Summary\nDate: Wed 27 Feb 2019\nSource: Precision Vaccinations [abridged, edited]\nhttps://www.precisionvaccinations.com/58-mumps-cases-reported-cdc-and-28-cases-reported-ice-during-2019\n\n\nThe ongoing measles outbreak now has anti-vaxx competition from another vaccine-preventable disease, mumps. From 1-31 Jan 2019, mumps infections have been reported in 58 people from 18 states to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC).\n\nThis new data is good news when compared with 2018 when the CDC confirmed 2251 mumps cases. But, this CDC data may not include mumps cases reported by the U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) agency during 2019. So far, ICE facilities in Colorado and Texas have reported mumps cases.\n\nThe leading states reporting mumps cases during 2019 include, but are not limited to, the following:\n\n- Arkansas: The Department of Health said cases of the mumps have been confirmed on the campus of the University of Arkansas at Fayetteville. A total of 3 cases have been confirmed and there is another suspected case of the mumps at the university over the last few weeks.\n\n- Georgia: Nancy Nydam, Director of Communications for The Georgia Department of Public Health, wrote, \"An outbreak of mumps has been reported at the facility and the investigation is ongoing.\"\n\n- Illinois: 8 cases were reported in 2 locations; 6 at Crystal Lake church and 2 at the McHenry County Correctional Facility. Health officials are working to determine if the 2 locations are related.\n\n- Indiana: 2 confirmed cases of the mumps have been found at Indiana University in Bloomington, health officials said.\n\n- Montana: 3 cases of mumps are confirmed in children attending Bozeman public schools, and health officials are investigating other possible cases.\n\n- North Dakota: The North Dakota Department of Health has confirmed 5 cases of mumps statewide, 3 of them in Stark County and 2 in Williams County.\n\n- Pennsylvania: Officials at a Delaware County elementary school are warning parents after a student was diagnosed with mumps. Officials at Garrett-Ford Elementary in Drexel Hill sent an email to parents regarding the health concern.\n\n- Utah: Southern Utah health officials say they have a reported case of mumps that popped up at an elementary school in St. George earlier this month [February 2019]. However, they believe because of the long delay before symptoms show, there could be more cases.\n\n- Wisconsin: A Marquette University student has contracted mumps. In an email to students, the school said the infected student lives in one of the residence halls.\n\nInternationally, Ireland has reported a mumps outbreak during 2019. According to reporting by the Irish Times, there have been 278 mumps cases in the 1st 6 weeks of 2019, compared with 43 for the same time in 2018, according to the HSE's Health Protection Surveillance Centre. A total of 9 outbreaks were reported in school, university, community, and private home settings, with the majority of cases occurring among teenagers and young adults.\n\nA major factor contributing to mumps outbreaks is being in a crowded environment or living in a dormitory with a person who is infectious with mumps, says the CDC.\n\nOne mumps outbreak in Ireland forced the cancellation of a schools rugby match in south Dublin, while Trinity College, DCU, and schools in Co Louth have also been affected. During 2018, various colleges have reported mumps cases, such as Cincinnati, Emory, Harvard, James Madison University, Michigan, Northern Colorado, Northeastern University, Oklahoma University, Penn State, TCU, Texas State and Western Illinois University.\n\nAccording to the previous study, another potential cause of these mumps outbreaks is 'waning-immunization'. A previous study from the Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health found that vaccine-derived immune protection against mumps persists on average about 27 years, after the last administered dose.\n\nIn response to the expanding number of mumps outbreaks, the CDC released guidance in October 2017, regarding when the 3rd dose of mumps vaccine is appropriate. This new CDC guidance did not recommend a 3rd MMR dose outside of a 'confirmed mumps outbreak'.\n\nAnother reason for mumps outbreaks could be under-vaccinations by international travelers.\n\nThe mumps component of the MMR vaccine has reported being 88% effective when a person gets 2 vaccine doses.\n\n[Byline: Don Ward Hackett]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Pennsylvania: Temple University on alert after students test positive for mumps\nDate: Fri 1 Mar 2019\nSource: 6abc [abridged, edited]\nhttps://6abc.com/health/temple-on-alert-after-students-test-positive-for-mumps/5162886/\n\n\nStudents, faculty and staff at Temple University have been notified about cases of mumps on campus. Student Health Services says 4 Temple students have tested positive for the highly-infectious virus.\n\n[Fri 1 Mar 2019] was the last day before spring break and some Temple students were worried. \"Yeah, I'm a little concerned that means people aren't getting vaccinated,\" student Caroline Gugel said.\n\n[Byline: Bob Brooks]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[One big concern with Spring break is that students who do not yet know they are infected can spread the virus to susceptible unvaccinated individuals when they travel outside the university. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[3] Texas: immigration facilities\nDate: Fri 1 Mar 2019\nSource: KRGV [edited]\nhttps://protect2.fireeye.com/url?k=09d1b67e-55e910c3-09d34f4b-000babd9fa3f-5795fe99245699f6&u=https://www.krgv.com/news/group-of-migrants-in-immigration-facilities-sick-with-mumps/\n\n\nThe Texas Department of State Health Services confirmed there are 186 people with mumps at immigration facilities across the state; 5 of these people are employees.\n\nThe department reported there are no cases of mumps in the communities surrounding the facility.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[See Mumps update (01): USA 20190210.6307434 for further discussion on the situation in the ICE facility in Laredo, Texas and Mumps update (02): USA (CO, TX), Europe (Ireland) 20190221.6329434 for ICE in Houston, Texas. During initial medical checks on the migrants entering the country, it would be good practice to vaccinate them with MMR. Similarly, all personnel working at the ICE facilities should be vaccinated to protect them and their families, as well as the incarcerated community within the facility and everyone outside. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[4] Ireland: Outbreak of mumps hits universities\nDate: Wed 27 Feb 2019\nSource: The Times [abridged, edited]\nhttps://www.thetimes.co.uk/edition/ireland/outbreak-of-mumps-hits-universities-50vmfl2f8\n\n\nA total of 384 cases mumps have been reported this year [2019] from Irish Universities, HSE figures have shown.\n\nThere were 64 new cases reported last week, bringing the total to 384 since the start of the year [2019]. The number of cases has been rising steadily in recent weeks, with 278 in the 1st 6 weeks of the year. Last year [2018] there had been 52 cases by the end of February. There were 576 cases in total last year [2018].\n\n[Byline : Catherine Sanz]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Also see ProMED-mail Mumps update (02): USA (CO, TX), Europe (Ireland) 20190221.6329434 for more on the outbreak in Ireland. - Mod.LK]\n\n[\"Before the U.S. mumps vaccination program started in 1967, about 186 000 cases were reported each year, but the actual number of cases was likely much higher due to underreporting. Since the pre-vaccine era, there has been a more than 99% decrease in mumps cases in the United States. Since the 2-dose vaccination program was introduced in 1989, mumps cases have ranged year to year from a couple of hundred to several thousand. However, in recent years, there has been an increase in the number of reported cases, from 229 cases in 2012 to 6366 cases in 2016. The recent increase has been mainly due to multiple mumps outbreaks reported across the country in settings where people often have close contact with one another, like college campuses.\" CDC (https://www.cdc.gov/mumps/outbreaks.html). - Mod.LK\n\nHealthMap/ProMED maps available at:\nUnited States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106\nIreland: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/39]\nSee (WA,TX) 20170110.4753366\n.................................................sb/lk/ao/jh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6384687", "date": "2019-03-05 18:58:32", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (03): USA (PENNSYLVANIA, TEXAS), EUROPE (IRELAND)\n***************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\nUSA\n---\n[1] USA summary\n[2] Pennsylvania\n[3] Texas\n\nEurope\n------\n[4] Ireland\n\n******\n[1] USA Summary\nDate: Wed 27 Feb 2019\nSource: Precision Vaccinations [abridged, edited]\nhttps://www.precisionvaccinations.com/58-mumps-cases-reported-cdc-and-28-cases-reported-ice-during-2019\n\n\nThe ongoing measles outbreak now has anti-vaxx competition from another vaccine-preventable disease, mumps. From 1-31 Jan 2019, mumps infections have been reported in 58 people from 18 states to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC).\n\nThis new data is good news when compared with 2018 when the CDC confirmed 2251 mumps cases. But, this CDC data may not include mumps cases reported by the U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) agency during 2019. So far, ICE facilities in Colorado and Texas have reported mumps cases.\n\nThe leading states reporting mumps cases during 2019 include, but are not limited to, the following:\n\n- Arkansas: The Department of Health said cases of the mumps have been confirmed on the campus of the University of Arkansas at Fayetteville. A total of 3 cases have been confirmed and there is another suspected case of the mumps at the university over the last few weeks.\n\n- Georgia: Nancy Nydam, Director of Communications for The Georgia Department of Public Health, wrote, \"An outbreak of mumps has been reported at the facility and the investigation is ongoing.\"\n\n- Illinois: 8 cases were reported in 2 locations; 6 at Crystal Lake church and 2 at the McHenry County Correctional Facility. Health officials are working to determine if the 2 locations are related.\n\n- Indiana: 2 confirmed cases of the mumps have been found at Indiana University in Bloomington, health officials said.\n\n- Montana: 3 cases of mumps are confirmed in children attending Bozeman public schools, and health officials are investigating other possible cases.\n\n- North Dakota: The North Dakota Department of Health has confirmed 5 cases of mumps statewide, 3 of them in Stark County and 2 in Williams County.\n\n- Pennsylvania: Officials at a Delaware County elementary school are warning parents after a student was diagnosed with mumps. Officials at Garrett-Ford Elementary in Drexel Hill sent an email to parents regarding the health concern.\n\n- Utah: Southern Utah health officials say they have a reported case of mumps that popped up at an elementary school in St. George earlier this month [February 2019]. However, they believe because of the long delay before symptoms show, there could be more cases.\n\n- Wisconsin: A Marquette University student has contracted mumps. In an email to students, the school said the infected student lives in one of the residence halls.\n\nInternationally, Ireland has reported a mumps outbreak during 2019. According to reporting by the Irish Times, there have been 278 mumps cases in the 1st 6 weeks of 2019, compared with 43 for the same time in 2018, according to the HSE's Health Protection Surveillance Centre. A total of 9 outbreaks were reported in school, university, community, and private home settings, with the majority of cases occurring among teenagers and young adults.\n\nA major factor contributing to mumps outbreaks is being in a crowded environment or living in a dormitory with a person who is infectious with mumps, says the CDC.\n\nOne mumps outbreak in Ireland forced the cancellation of a schools rugby match in south Dublin, while Trinity College, DCU, and schools in Co Louth have also been affected. During 2018, various colleges have reported mumps cases, such as Cincinnati, Emory, Harvard, James Madison University, Michigan, Northern Colorado, Northeastern University, Oklahoma University, Penn State, TCU, Texas State and Western Illinois University.\n\nAccording to the previous study, another potential cause of these mumps outbreaks is 'waning-immunization'. A previous study from the Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health found that vaccine-derived immune protection against mumps persists on average about 27 years, after the last administered dose.\n\nIn response to the expanding number of mumps outbreaks, the CDC released guidance in October 2017, regarding when the 3rd dose of mumps vaccine is appropriate. This new CDC guidance did not recommend a 3rd MMR dose outside of a 'confirmed mumps outbreak'.\n\nAnother reason for mumps outbreaks could be under-vaccinations by international travelers.\n\nThe mumps component of the MMR vaccine has reported being 88% effective when a person gets 2 vaccine doses.\n\n[Byline: Don Ward Hackett]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Pennsylvania: Temple University on alert after students test positive for mumps\nDate: Fri 1 Mar 2019\nSource: 6abc [abridged, edited]\nhttps://6abc.com/health/temple-on-alert-after-students-test-positive-for-mumps/5162886/\n\n\nStudents, faculty and staff at Temple University have been notified about cases of mumps on campus. Student Health Services says 4 Temple students have tested positive for the highly-infectious virus.\n\n[Fri 1 Mar 2019] was the last day before spring break and some Temple students were worried. \"Yeah, I'm a little concerned that means people aren't getting vaccinated,\" student Caroline Gugel said.\n\n[Byline: Bob Brooks]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[One big concern with Spring break is that students who do not yet know they are infected can spread the virus to susceptible unvaccinated individuals when they travel outside the university. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[3] Texas: immigration facilities\nDate: Fri 1 Mar 2019\nSource: KRGV [edited]\nhttps://protect2.fireeye.com/url?k=09d1b67e-55e910c3-09d34f4b-000babd9fa3f-5795fe99245699f6&u=https://www.krgv.com/news/group-of-migrants-in-immigration-facilities-sick-with-mumps/\n\n\nThe Texas Department of State Health Services confirmed there are 186 people with mumps at immigration facilities across the state; 5 of these people are employees.\n\nThe department reported there are no cases of mumps in the communities surrounding the facility.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[See Mumps update (01): USA 20190210.6307434 for further discussion on the situation in the ICE facility in Laredo, Texas and Mumps update (02): USA (CO, TX), Europe (Ireland) 20190221.6329434 for ICE in Houston, Texas. During initial medical checks on the migrants entering the country, it would be good practice to vaccinate them with MMR. Similarly, all personnel working at the ICE facilities should be vaccinated to protect them and their families, as well as the incarcerated community within the facility and everyone outside. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[4] Ireland: Outbreak of mumps hits universities\nDate: Wed 27 Feb 2019\nSource: The Times [abridged, edited]\nhttps://www.thetimes.co.uk/edition/ireland/outbreak-of-mumps-hits-universities-50vmfl2f8\n\n\nA total of 384 cases mumps have been reported this year [2019] from Irish Universities, HSE figures have shown.\n\nThere were 64 new cases reported last week, bringing the total to 384 since the start of the year [2019]. The number of cases has been rising steadily in recent weeks, with 278 in the 1st 6 weeks of the year. Last year [2018] there had been 52 cases by the end of February. There were 576 cases in total last year [2018].\n\n[Byline : Catherine Sanz]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Also see ProMED-mail Mumps update (02): USA (CO, TX), Europe (Ireland) 20190221.6329434 for more on the outbreak in Ireland. - Mod.LK]\n\n[\"Before the U.S. mumps vaccination program started in 1967, about 186 000 cases were reported each year, but the actual number of cases was likely much higher due to underreporting. Since the pre-vaccine era, there has been a more than 99% decrease in mumps cases in the United States. Since the 2-dose vaccination program was introduced in 1989, mumps cases have ranged year to year from a couple of hundred to several thousand. However, in recent years, there has been an increase in the number of reported cases, from 229 cases in 2012 to 6366 cases in 2016. The recent increase has been mainly due to multiple mumps outbreaks reported across the country in settings where people often have close contact with one another, like college campuses.\" CDC (https://www.cdc.gov/mumps/outbreaks.html). - Mod.LK\n\nHealthMap/ProMED maps available at:\nUnited States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106\nIreland: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/39]\nSee (WA,TX) 20170110.4753366\n.................................................sb/lk/ao/jh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2001-01-31 20:19:00", "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2019-03-16 00:00:00", "2019-03-16 00:00:00", "2019-02-16 00:00:00", "2019-03-16 00:00:00", "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-10-16 00:00:00", "2019-03-16 00:00:00", "2019-03-16 00:00:00", "2019-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "1967-03-16 00:00:00", "1989-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Fayetteville", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bloomington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "VA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Delaware County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brazil", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Portugal", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Laredo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Polynesia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6379783", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps update (04): USA (PA) outbreak", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6379783", "date": "2019-03-05 18:58:32", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (03): USA (PENNSYLVANIA, TEXAS), EUROPE (IRELAND)\n***************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\nUSA\n---\n[1] USA summary\n[2] Pennsylvania\n[3] Texas\n\nEurope\n------\n[4] Ireland\n\n******\n[1] USA Summary\nDate: Wed 27 Feb 2019\nSource: Precision Vaccinations [abridged, edited]\nhttps://www.precisionvaccinations.com/58-mumps-cases-reported-cdc-and-28-cases-reported-ice-during-2019\n\n\nThe ongoing measles outbreak now has anti-vaxx competition from another vaccine-preventable disease, mumps. From 1-31 Jan 2019, mumps infections have been reported in 58 people from 18 states to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC).\n\nThis new data is good news when compared with 2018 when the CDC confirmed 2251 mumps cases. But, this CDC data may not include mumps cases reported by the U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) agency during 2019. So far, ICE facilities in Colorado and Texas have reported mumps cases.\n\nThe leading states reporting mumps cases during 2019 include, but are not limited to, the following:\n\n- Arkansas: The Department of Health said cases of the mumps have been confirmed on the campus of the University of Arkansas at Fayetteville. A total of 3 cases have been confirmed and there is another suspected case of the mumps at the university over the last few weeks.\n\n- Georgia: Nancy Nydam, Director of Communications for The Georgia Department of Public Health, wrote, \"An outbreak of mumps has been reported at the facility and the investigation is ongoing.\"\n\n- Illinois: 8 cases were reported in 2 locations; 6 at Crystal Lake church and 2 at the McHenry County Correctional Facility. Health officials are working to determine if the 2 locations are related.\n\n- Indiana: 2 confirmed cases of the mumps have been found at Indiana University in Bloomington, health officials said.\n\n- Montana: 3 cases of mumps are confirmed in children attending Bozeman public schools, and health officials are investigating other possible cases.\n\n- North Dakota: The North Dakota Department of Health has confirmed 5 cases of mumps statewide, 3 of them in Stark County and 2 in Williams County.\n\n- Pennsylvania: Officials at a Delaware County elementary school are warning parents after a student was diagnosed with mumps. Officials at Garrett-Ford Elementary in Drexel Hill sent an email to parents regarding the health concern.\n\n- Utah: Southern Utah health officials say they have a reported case of mumps that popped up at an elementary school in St. George earlier this month [February 2019]. However, they believe because of the long delay before symptoms show, there could be more cases.\n\n- Wisconsin: A Marquette University student has contracted mumps. In an email to students, the school said the infected student lives in one of the residence halls.\n\nInternationally, Ireland has reported a mumps outbreak during 2019. According to reporting by the Irish Times, there have been 278 mumps cases in the 1st 6 weeks of 2019, compared with 43 for the same time in 2018, according to the HSE's Health Protection Surveillance Centre. A total of 9 outbreaks were reported in school, university, community, and private home settings, with the majority of cases occurring among teenagers and young adults.\n\nA major factor contributing to mumps outbreaks is being in a crowded environment or living in a dormitory with a person who is infectious with mumps, says the CDC.\n\nOne mumps outbreak in Ireland forced the cancellation of a schools rugby match in south Dublin, while Trinity College, DCU, and schools in Co Louth have also been affected. During 2018, various colleges have reported mumps cases, such as Cincinnati, Emory, Harvard, James Madison University, Michigan, Northern Colorado, Northeastern University, Oklahoma University, Penn State, TCU, Texas State and Western Illinois University.\n\nAccording to the previous study, another potential cause of these mumps outbreaks is 'waning-immunization'. A previous study from the Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health found that vaccine-derived immune protection against mumps persists on average about 27 years, after the last administered dose.\n\nIn response to the expanding number of mumps outbreaks, the CDC released guidance in October 2017, regarding when the 3rd dose of mumps vaccine is appropriate. This new CDC guidance did not recommend a 3rd MMR dose outside of a 'confirmed mumps outbreak'.\n\nAnother reason for mumps outbreaks could be under-vaccinations by international travelers.\n\nThe mumps component of the MMR vaccine has reported being 88% effective when a person gets 2 vaccine doses.\n\n[Byline: Don Ward Hackett]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Pennsylvania: Temple University on alert after students test positive for mumps\nDate: Fri 1 Mar 2019\nSource: 6abc [abridged, edited]\nhttps://6abc.com/health/temple-on-alert-after-students-test-positive-for-mumps/5162886/\n\n\nStudents, faculty and staff at Temple University have been notified about cases of mumps on campus. Student Health Services says 4 Temple students have tested positive for the highly-infectious virus.\n\n[Fri 1 Mar 2019] was the last day before spring break and some Temple students were worried. \"Yeah, I'm a little concerned that means people aren't getting vaccinated,\" student Caroline Gugel said.\n\n[Byline: Bob Brooks]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[One big concern with Spring break is that students who do not yet know they are infected can spread the virus to susceptible unvaccinated individuals when they travel outside the university. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[3] Texas: immigration facilities\nDate: Fri 1 Mar 2019\nSource: KRGV [edited]\nhttps://protect2.fireeye.com/url?k=09d1b67e-55e910c3-09d34f4b-000babd9fa3f-5795fe99245699f6&u=https://www.krgv.com/news/group-of-migrants-in-immigration-facilities-sick-with-mumps/\n\n\nThe Texas Department of State Health Services confirmed there are 186 people with mumps at immigration facilities across the state; 5 of these people are employees.\n\nThe department reported there are no cases of mumps in the communities surrounding the facility.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[See Mumps update (01): USA 20190210.6307434 for further discussion on the situation in the ICE facility in Laredo, Texas and Mumps update (02): USA (CO, TX), Europe (Ireland) 20190221.6329434 for ICE in Houston, Texas. During initial medical checks on the migrants entering the country, it would be good practice to vaccinate them with MMR. Similarly, all personnel working at the ICE facilities should be vaccinated to protect them and their families, as well as the incarcerated community within the facility and everyone outside. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[4] Ireland: Outbreak of mumps hits universities\nDate: Wed 27 Feb 2019\nSource: The Times [abridged, edited]\nhttps://www.thetimes.co.uk/edition/ireland/outbreak-of-mumps-hits-universities-50vmfl2f8\n\n\nA total of 384 cases mumps have been reported this year [2019] from Irish Universities, HSE figures have shown.\n\nThere were 64 new cases reported last week, bringing the total to 384 since the start of the year [2019]. The number of cases has been rising steadily in recent weeks, with 278 in the 1st 6 weeks of the year. Last year [2018] there had been 52 cases by the end of February. There were 576 cases in total last year [2018].\n\n[Byline : Catherine Sanz]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Also see ProMED-mail Mumps update (02): USA (CO, TX), Europe (Ireland) 20190221.6329434 for more on the outbreak in Ireland. - Mod.LK]\n\n[\"Before the U.S. mumps vaccination program started in 1967, about 186 000 cases were reported each year, but the actual number of cases was likely much higher due to underreporting. Since the pre-vaccine era, there has been a more than 99% decrease in mumps cases in the United States. Since the 2-dose vaccination program was introduced in 1989, mumps cases have ranged year to year from a couple of hundred to several thousand. However, in recent years, there has been an increase in the number of reported cases, from 229 cases in 2012 to 6366 cases in 2016. The recent increase has been mainly due to multiple mumps outbreaks reported across the country in settings where people often have close contact with one another, like college campuses.\" CDC (https://www.cdc.gov/mumps/outbreaks.html). - Mod.LK\n\nHealthMap/ProMED maps available at:\nUnited States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106\nIreland: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/39]\nSee (Ireland)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6350670", "date": "2019-03-05 18:58:32", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (03): USA (PENNSYLVANIA, TEXAS), EUROPE (IRELAND)\n***************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\nUSA\n---\n[1] USA summary\n[2] Pennsylvania\n[3] Texas\n\nEurope\n------\n[4] Ireland\n\n******\n[1] USA Summary\nDate: Wed 27 Feb 2019\nSource: Precision Vaccinations [abridged, edited]\nhttps://www.precisionvaccinations.com/58-mumps-cases-reported-cdc-and-28-cases-reported-ice-during-2019\n\n\nThe ongoing measles outbreak now has anti-vaxx competition from another vaccine-preventable disease, mumps. From 1-31 Jan 2019, mumps infections have been reported in 58 people from 18 states to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC).\n\nThis new data is good news when compared with 2018 when the CDC confirmed 2251 mumps cases. But, this CDC data may not include mumps cases reported by the U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) agency during 2019. So far, ICE facilities in Colorado and Texas have reported mumps cases.\n\nThe leading states reporting mumps cases during 2019 include, but are not limited to, the following:\n\n- Arkansas: The Department of Health said cases of the mumps have been confirmed on the campus of the University of Arkansas at Fayetteville. A total of 3 cases have been confirmed and there is another suspected case of the mumps at the university over the last few weeks.\n\n- Georgia: Nancy Nydam, Director of Communications for The Georgia Department of Public Health, wrote, \"An outbreak of mumps has been reported at the facility and the investigation is ongoing.\"\n\n- Illinois: 8 cases were reported in 2 locations; 6 at Crystal Lake church and 2 at the McHenry County Correctional Facility. Health officials are working to determine if the 2 locations are related.\n\n- Indiana: 2 confirmed cases of the mumps have been found at Indiana University in Bloomington, health officials said.\n\n- Montana: 3 cases of mumps are confirmed in children attending Bozeman public schools, and health officials are investigating other possible cases.\n\n- North Dakota: The North Dakota Department of Health has confirmed 5 cases of mumps statewide, 3 of them in Stark County and 2 in Williams County.\n\n- Pennsylvania: Officials at a Delaware County elementary school are warning parents after a student was diagnosed with mumps. Officials at Garrett-Ford Elementary in Drexel Hill sent an email to parents regarding the health concern.\n\n- Utah: Southern Utah health officials say they have a reported case of mumps that popped up at an elementary school in St. George earlier this month [February 2019]. However, they believe because of the long delay before symptoms show, there could be more cases.\n\n- Wisconsin: A Marquette University student has contracted mumps. In an email to students, the school said the infected student lives in one of the residence halls.\n\nInternationally, Ireland has reported a mumps outbreak during 2019. According to reporting by the Irish Times, there have been 278 mumps cases in the 1st 6 weeks of 2019, compared with 43 for the same time in 2018, according to the HSE's Health Protection Surveillance Centre. A total of 9 outbreaks were reported in school, university, community, and private home settings, with the majority of cases occurring among teenagers and young adults.\n\nA major factor contributing to mumps outbreaks is being in a crowded environment or living in a dormitory with a person who is infectious with mumps, says the CDC.\n\nOne mumps outbreak in Ireland forced the cancellation of a schools rugby match in south Dublin, while Trinity College, DCU, and schools in Co Louth have also been affected. During 2018, various colleges have reported mumps cases, such as Cincinnati, Emory, Harvard, James Madison University, Michigan, Northern Colorado, Northeastern University, Oklahoma University, Penn State, TCU, Texas State and Western Illinois University.\n\nAccording to the previous study, another potential cause of these mumps outbreaks is 'waning-immunization'. A previous study from the Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health found that vaccine-derived immune protection against mumps persists on average about 27 years, after the last administered dose.\n\nIn response to the expanding number of mumps outbreaks, the CDC released guidance in October 2017, regarding when the 3rd dose of mumps vaccine is appropriate. This new CDC guidance did not recommend a 3rd MMR dose outside of a 'confirmed mumps outbreak'.\n\nAnother reason for mumps outbreaks could be under-vaccinations by international travelers.\n\nThe mumps component of the MMR vaccine has reported being 88% effective when a person gets 2 vaccine doses.\n\n[Byline: Don Ward Hackett]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Pennsylvania: Temple University on alert after students test positive for mumps\nDate: Fri 1 Mar 2019\nSource: 6abc [abridged, edited]\nhttps://6abc.com/health/temple-on-alert-after-students-test-positive-for-mumps/5162886/\n\n\nStudents, faculty and staff at Temple University have been notified about cases of mumps on campus. Student Health Services says 4 Temple students have tested positive for the highly-infectious virus.\n\n[Fri 1 Mar 2019] was the last day before spring break and some Temple students were worried. \"Yeah, I'm a little concerned that means people aren't getting vaccinated,\" student Caroline Gugel said.\n\n[Byline: Bob Brooks]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[One big concern with Spring break is that students who do not yet know they are infected can spread the virus to susceptible unvaccinated individuals when they travel outside the university. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[3] Texas: immigration facilities\nDate: Fri 1 Mar 2019\nSource: KRGV [edited]\nhttps://protect2.fireeye.com/url?k=09d1b67e-55e910c3-09d34f4b-000babd9fa3f-5795fe99245699f6&u=https://www.krgv.com/news/group-of-migrants-in-immigration-facilities-sick-with-mumps/\n\n\nThe Texas Department of State Health Services confirmed there are 186 people with mumps at immigration facilities across the state; 5 of these people are employees.\n\nThe department reported there are no cases of mumps in the communities surrounding the facility.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[See Mumps update (01): USA 20190210.6307434 for further discussion on the situation in the ICE facility in Laredo, Texas and Mumps update (02): USA (CO, TX), Europe (Ireland) 20190221.6329434 for ICE in Houston, Texas. During initial medical checks on the migrants entering the country, it would be good practice to vaccinate them with MMR. Similarly, all personnel working at the ICE facilities should be vaccinated to protect them and their families, as well as the incarcerated community within the facility and everyone outside. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[4] Ireland: Outbreak of mumps hits universities\nDate: Wed 27 Feb 2019\nSource: The Times [abridged, edited]\nhttps://www.thetimes.co.uk/edition/ireland/outbreak-of-mumps-hits-universities-50vmfl2f8\n\n\nA total of 384 cases mumps have been reported this year [2019] from Irish Universities, HSE figures have shown.\n\nThere were 64 new cases reported last week, bringing the total to 384 since the start of the year [2019]. The number of cases has been rising steadily in recent weeks, with 278 in the 1st 6 weeks of the year. Last year [2018] there had been 52 cases by the end of February. There were 576 cases in total last year [2018].\n\n[Byline : Catherine Sanz]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Also see ProMED-mail Mumps update (02): USA (CO, TX), Europe (Ireland) 20190221.6329434 for more on the outbreak in Ireland. - Mod.LK]\n\n[\"Before the U.S. mumps vaccination program started in 1967, about 186 000 cases were reported each year, but the actual number of cases was likely much higher due to underreporting. Since the pre-vaccine era, there has been a more than 99% decrease in mumps cases in the United States. Since the 2-dose vaccination program was introduced in 1989, mumps cases have ranged year to year from a couple of hundred to several thousand. However, in recent years, there has been an increase in the number of reported cases, from 229 cases in 2012 to 6366 cases in 2016. The recent increase has been mainly due to multiple mumps outbreaks reported across the country in settings where people often have close contact with one another, like college campuses.\" CDC (https://www.cdc.gov/mumps/outbreaks.html). - Mod.LK\n\nHealthMap/ProMED maps available at:\nUnited States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106\nIreland: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/39]\nSee {"location": "Laredo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Polynesia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6329434", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps update (02): USA (CO, TX), Europe (Ireland)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6329434", "date": "2018-04-27 11:46:59", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (03): MEXICO, USA (DELAWARE, VIRGINIA)\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Mexico\n[2] USA (Delaware)\n[3] USA (Virginia, William and Mary College)\n\n******\n[1] Mexico\nDate: Tue 24 Apr 2018\nSource: Excelsior [Google translated, edited]\nhttp://www.excelsior.com.mx/comunidad/advierten-sobre-brote-de-paperas-en-escuelas-de-la-cdmx/1234552\n\n\nA mumps outbreak is latent in universities in 7 states of the country. The outbreaks of greater risk have been located in student centers of the capital of the country, Sonora and Chihuahua.\n\nThe General Directorate of Epidemiology issued an epidemiological alert for the spread of cases of infectious parotitis in the country, which has mainly affected the student population.\n\nAccording to the epidemiological bulletin at week 16 of 2018, 2619 cases of infectious parotitis, known as mumps, have been reported.\n\nThe states with the highest number of cases are: Tamaulipas with 561, Nuevo Le\u00f3n with 302, Quintana Roo with 203, Jalisco with 189 and Chihuahua with 167.\n\nSince the beginning of 2018, cases and outbreaks of the disease have been reported in the United States.\n\nThe Ministry of Health emphasized that it was identified as affecting mainly university residents of the US center in Mexico.\n\nThe age groups most affected nationwide are adults aged 25-44 years, with 805, followed by the group of 20-24 years with 531 and children aged 5-9 years, with 388.\n\n[Byline: Ximena Mej\u00eda]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A HealthMap/ProMED-mail of Mexico can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/14.]\n\n******\n[2] USA (Delaware, New Castle County)\nDate: Tue 17 Apr 2018\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/delaware-reports-additional-mumps-cases-outbreak-total-now-15-74934/\n\n\nIn a follow-up on the mumps outbreak in New Castle County, Delaware, The Delaware Division of Public Health (DPH) is confirming 2 additional cases of the mumps as part of its ongoing investigation of an outbreak among attendees at 2 multi-cultural dances in New Castle County. This brings the total number of mumps cases to 15.\n\nAll of the individuals infected with mumps reside in New Castle County.\n\nNine of the 15 persons with mumps attended either the 10 Feb or 3 Mar 2018 social dance (Baile Mejicano) that took place at the Chase Center on the Riverfront in Wilmington. Two of the remaining 4 individuals live with someone who attended one of the dances, and the source of the mumps virus exposure for the remaining 4 individuals is still under investigation.\n\nMumps is an acute viral infection spread through saliva or mucus from the mouth, nose, or throat. An infected person can spread the virus by coughing, sneezing, talking, sharing items such as cups or eating utensils with others, and touching objects or surfaces with unwashed hands that are then touched by others.\n\nSymptoms typically start with a few days of fever, headache, muscle aches, tiredness, and loss of appetite, followed by swollen salivary glands, which results in puffy cheeks and a swollen jaw. Symptoms typically appear 16-18 days after infection, but can range from 12-25 days after infection. Some people with mumps may not have any symptoms. Most people with mumps recover completely in a few weeks. However, mumps can occasionally cause complications, especially in adults.\n\nPeople known or suspected to have mumps should stay away from school or work until 5 days after the onset of swollen salivary glands as there is no specific treatment for mumps.\n\nThe CDC recommends children get 2 doses of MMR vaccine, starting with the 1st dose at 12-15 months of age and the 2nd dose at 4-6 years of age. Teens and adults who did not get the recommended MMR vaccines per the above schedule should be vaccinated so they are up to date. During outbreaks, CDC also recommends that those at highest risk due to exposure to people with mumps should receive a 3rd dose of MMR.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As of 25 Apr 2018, cases number 19. All 19 individuals reside in New Castle County. The age ranges of adults with the mumps virus are 21-57 years old. Additionally, there was one child under the age of 5 infected. According to the Delaware News https://news.delaware.gov/2018/04/24/four-mumps-cases-identified-bringing-total-19/, this is the 1st time that more than 3 mumps cases have been recorded during any calendar year since at least 2005. - Mod.LK\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail of the United States can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106 and Delaware, United States at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/211.]\n\n******\n[3] Virginia, William and Mary College\nDate: Wed 25 Apr 2018\nSource: The Virginia Gazette [edited]\nhttp://www.vagazette.com/news/va-vg-wm-mumps-20180428-story.html\n\n\nThere has been a case of reported mumps at the College of William and Mary.\n\nThe announcement was sent out in an email by Virginia Wells, director of the student health center at William and Mary, and Virginia Ambler, vice president of student affairs, on 24 Apr 2018. The email said the Peninsula Health District identified a case of mumps, and the student has since been isolated. Larry Hill, a spokesman for the Peninsula Health District, said they are working with the college on this case. ...\n\nWells said in her email people known to have had contact with the sick student have been notified, but since college campuses are a close and compact environment, it's possible other students may have been exposed.\n\nIn Wells and Ambler's email, they recommended students to review their immunization status and contact their doctor to receive the vaccine as needed. This vaccine is usually to children at age 12 months and again between the ages of 4-6 years and is 88% effective in persons having received 2 doses. So, someone who received a full immunization may still develop mumps.\n\nThe Virginia Department of Health said people who are exposed to mumps may not show symptoms for 12-25 days, and those infected can transmit mumps to others 2 days before symptoms appear. The email from Wells and Ambler suggested contacting your doctor and self-isolating until your doctor directs otherwise if you begin to have mumps-like symptoms.\n\n\"The university has taken all appropriate and recommended steps, including sharing this information with the campus community,\" the email said. \"We will provide additional updates or recommendations if needed.\"\n\nUpdate April 26\n----------\nA new announcement from Wells and Ambler said more cases of mumps have been reported on campus. The students who contracted the virus have been isolated, as with the 1st case.\n\nWhile Hill said Peninsula Health could not release the exact number of students who contracted mumps, there were several cases reported.\n\n[Byline: Amelia Heymann]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n\n[HealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nVirginia, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/247]\nSee Also\nMumps update (02): USA (VA,DE) resurgence 20180323.5704564\nMumps update: USA 20180220.5638266\n2017\n-----\nMumps update (37): USA, New Zealand McGowan\nUSA 20171001.5352710\nMumps update (27): Pacific (New Zealand), USA (HI, AK) 20170925.5340444\nMumps update (26): USA (TX) Canada (MB,BC) 20170919.5325095\nMumps update (25): Hawai'i (Hawai'I "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pacific", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wilmington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "DC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Polynesia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6148920", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps update (08): Malaysia (SL) Ireland (GY)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6148920", "date": "2018-04-27 11:46:59", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (03): MEXICO, USA (DELAWARE, VIRGINIA)\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Mexico\n[2] USA (Delaware)\n[3] USA (Virginia, William and Mary College)\n\n******\n[1] Mexico\nDate: Tue 24 Apr 2018\nSource: Excelsior [Google translated, edited]\nhttp://www.excelsior.com.mx/comunidad/advierten-sobre-brote-de-paperas-en-escuelas-de-la-cdmx/1234552\n\n\nA mumps outbreak is latent in universities in 7 states of the country. The outbreaks of greater risk have been located in student centers of the capital of the country, Sonora and Chihuahua.\n\nThe General Directorate of Epidemiology issued an epidemiological alert for the spread of cases of infectious parotitis in the country, which has mainly affected the student population.\n\nAccording to the epidemiological bulletin at week 16 of 2018, 2619 cases of infectious parotitis, known as mumps, have been reported.\n\nThe states with the highest number of cases are: Tamaulipas with 561, Nuevo Le\u00f3n with 302, Quintana Roo with 203, Jalisco with 189 and Chihuahua with 167.\n\nSince the beginning of 2018, cases and outbreaks of the disease have been reported in the United States.\n\nThe Ministry of Health emphasized that it was identified as affecting mainly university residents of the US center in Mexico.\n\nThe age groups most affected nationwide are adults aged 25-44 years, with 805, followed by the group of 20-24 years with 531 and children aged 5-9 years, with 388.\n\n[Byline: Ximena Mej\u00eda]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A HealthMap/ProMED-mail of Mexico can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/14.]\n\n******\n[2] USA (Delaware, New Castle County)\nDate: Tue 17 Apr 2018\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/delaware-reports-additional-mumps-cases-outbreak-total-now-15-74934/\n\n\nIn a follow-up on the mumps outbreak in New Castle County, Delaware, The Delaware Division of Public Health (DPH) is confirming 2 additional cases of the mumps as part of its ongoing investigation of an outbreak among attendees at 2 multi-cultural dances in New Castle County. This brings the total number of mumps cases to 15.\n\nAll of the individuals infected with mumps reside in New Castle County.\n\nNine of the 15 persons with mumps attended either the 10 Feb or 3 Mar 2018 social dance (Baile Mejicano) that took place at the Chase Center on the Riverfront in Wilmington. Two of the remaining 4 individuals live with someone who attended one of the dances, and the source of the mumps virus exposure for the remaining 4 individuals is still under investigation.\n\nMumps is an acute viral infection spread through saliva or mucus from the mouth, nose, or throat. An infected person can spread the virus by coughing, sneezing, talking, sharing items such as cups or eating utensils with others, and touching objects or surfaces with unwashed hands that are then touched by others.\n\nSymptoms typically start with a few days of fever, headache, muscle aches, tiredness, and loss of appetite, followed by swollen salivary glands, which results in puffy cheeks and a swollen jaw. Symptoms typically appear 16-18 days after infection, but can range from 12-25 days after infection. Some people with mumps may not have any symptoms. Most people with mumps recover completely in a few weeks. However, mumps can occasionally cause complications, especially in adults.\n\nPeople known or suspected to have mumps should stay away from school or work until 5 days after the onset of swollen salivary glands as there is no specific treatment for mumps.\n\nThe CDC recommends children get 2 doses of MMR vaccine, starting with the 1st dose at 12-15 months of age and the 2nd dose at 4-6 years of age. Teens and adults who did not get the recommended MMR vaccines per the above schedule should be vaccinated so they are up to date. During outbreaks, CDC also recommends that those at highest risk due to exposure to people with mumps should receive a 3rd dose of MMR.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As of 25 Apr 2018, cases number 19. All 19 individuals reside in New Castle County. The age ranges of adults with the mumps virus are 21-57 years old. Additionally, there was one child under the age of 5 infected. According to the Delaware News https://news.delaware.gov/2018/04/24/four-mumps-cases-identified-bringing-total-19/, this is the 1st time that more than 3 mumps cases have been recorded during any calendar year since at least 2005. - Mod.LK\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail of the United States can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106 and Delaware, United States at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/211.]\n\n******\n[3] Virginia, William and Mary College\nDate: Wed 25 Apr 2018\nSource: The Virginia Gazette [edited]\nhttp://www.vagazette.com/news/va-vg-wm-mumps-20180428-story.html\n\n\nThere has been a case of reported mumps at the College of William and Mary.\n\nThe announcement was sent out in an email by Virginia Wells, director of the student health center at William and Mary, and Virginia Ambler, vice president of student affairs, on 24 Apr 2018. The email said the Peninsula Health District identified a case of mumps, and the student has since been isolated. Larry Hill, a spokesman for the Peninsula Health District, said they are working with the college on this case. ...\n\nWells said in her email people known to have had contact with the sick student have been notified, but since college campuses are a close and compact environment, it's possible other students may have been exposed.\n\nIn Wells and Ambler's email, they recommended students to review their immunization status and contact their doctor to receive the vaccine as needed. This vaccine is usually to children at age 12 months and again between the ages of 4-6 years and is 88% effective in persons having received 2 doses. So, someone who received a full immunization may still develop mumps.\n\nThe Virginia Department of Health said people who are exposed to mumps may not show symptoms for 12-25 days, and those infected can transmit mumps to others 2 days before symptoms appear. The email from Wells and Ambler suggested contacting your doctor and self-isolating until your doctor directs otherwise if you begin to have mumps-like symptoms.\n\n\"The university has taken all appropriate and recommended steps, including sharing this information with the campus community,\" the email said. \"We will provide additional updates or recommendations if needed.\"\n\nUpdate April 26\n----------\nA new announcement from Wells and Ambler said more cases of mumps have been reported on campus. The students who contracted the virus have been isolated, as with the 1st case.\n\nWhile Hill said Peninsula Health could not release the exact number of students who contracted mumps, there were several cases reported.\n\n[Byline: Amelia Heymann]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n\n[HealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nVirginia, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/247]\nSee Also\nMumps update (02): USA (VA,DE) resurgence 20180323.5704564\nMumps update: USA 20180220.5638266\n2017\n-----\nMumps update (37): USA, New Zealand translated, edited]\nhttp://www.excelsior.com.mx/comunidad/advierten-sobre-brote-de-paperas-en-escuelas-de-la-cdmx/1234552\n\n\nA mumps outbreak is latent in universities in 7 states of the country. The outbreaks of greater risk have been located in student centers of the capital of the country, Sonora and Chihuahua.\n\nThe General Directorate of Epidemiology issued an epidemiological alert for the spread of cases of infectious parotitis in the country, which has mainly affected the student population.\n\nAccording to the epidemiological bulletin at week 16 of 2018, 2619 cases of infectious parotitis, known as mumps, have been reported.\n\nThe states with the highest number of cases are: Tamaulipas with 561, Nuevo Le\u00f3n with 302, Quintana Roo with 203, Jalisco with 189 and Chihuahua with 167.\n\nSince the beginning of 2018, cases and outbreaks of the disease have been reported in the United States.\n\nThe Ministry of Health emphasized that it was identified as affecting mainly university residents of the US center in Mexico.\n\nThe age groups most affected nationwide are adults aged 25-44 years, with 805, followed by the group of 20-24 years with 531 and children aged 5-9 years, with 388.\n\n[Byline: Ximena Mej\u00eda]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A HealthMap/ProMED-mail of Mexico can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/14.]\n\n******\n[2] USA (Delaware, New Castle County)\nDate: Tue 17 Apr 2018\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/delaware-reports-additional-mumps-cases-outbreak-total-now-15-74934/\n\n\nIn a follow-up on the mumps outbreak in New Castle County, Delaware, The Delaware Division of Public Health (DPH) is confirming 2 additional cases of the mumps as part of its ongoing investigation of an outbreak among attendees at 2 multi-cultural dances in New Castle County. This brings the total number of mumps cases to 15.\n\nAll of the individuals infected with mumps reside in New Castle County.\n\nNine of the 15 persons with mumps attended either the 10 Feb or 3 Mar 2018 social dance (Baile Mejicano) that took place at the Chase Center on the Riverfront in Wilmington. Two of the remaining 4 individuals live with someone who attended one of the dances, and the source of the mumps virus exposure for the remaining 4 individuals is still under investigation.\n\nMumps is an acute viral infection spread through saliva or mucus from the mouth, nose, or throat. An infected person can spread the virus by coughing, sneezing, talking, sharing items such as cups or eating utensils with others, and touching objects or surfaces with unwashed hands that are then touched by others.\n\nSymptoms typically start with a few days of fever, headache, muscle aches, tiredness, and loss of appetite, followed by swollen salivary glands, which results in puffy cheeks and a swollen jaw. Symptoms typically appear 16-18 days after infection, but can range from 12-25 days after infection. Some people with mumps may not have any symptoms. Most people with mumps recover completely in a few weeks. However, mumps can occasionally cause complications, especially in adults.\n\nPeople known or suspected to have mumps should stay away from school or work until 5 days after the onset of swollen salivary glands as there is no specific treatment for mumps.\n\nThe CDC recommends children get 2 doses of MMR vaccine, starting with the 1st dose at 12-15 months of age and the 2nd dose at 4-6 years of age. Teens and adults who did not get the recommended MMR vaccines per the above schedule should be vaccinated so they are up to date. During outbreaks, CDC also recommends that those at highest risk due to exposure to people with mumps should receive a 3rd dose of MMR.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As of 25 Apr 2018, cases number 19. The email said the Peninsula Health District identified a case of mumps, and the student has since been isolated. Larry Hill, a spokesman for the Peninsula Health District, said they are working with the college on this case. ...\n\nWells said in her email people known to have had contact with the sick student have been notified, but since college campuses are a close and compact environment, it's possible other students may have been exposed.\n\nIn Wells and Ambler's email, they recommended students to review their immunization status and contact their doctor to receive the vaccine as needed. This vaccine is usually to children at age 12 months and again between the ages of 4-6 years and is 88% effective in persons having received 2 doses. So, someone who received a full immunization may still develop mumps.\n\nThe Virginia Department of Health said people who are exposed to mumps may not show symptoms for 12-25 days, and those infected can transmit mumps to others 2 days before symptoms appear. post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Mexico\n[2] USA (Delaware)\n[3] USA (Virginia, William and Mary College)\n\n******\n[1] Mexico\nDate: Tue 24 Apr 2018\nSource: Excelsior [Google translated, edited]\nhttp://www.excelsior.com.mx/comunidad/advierten-sobre-brote-de-paperas-en-escuelas-de-la-cdmx/1234552\n\n\nA mumps outbreak is latent in universities in 7 states of the country. The outbreaks of greater risk have been located in student centers of the capital of the country, Sonora and Chihuahua.\n\nThe General Directorate of Epidemiology issued an epidemiological alert for the spread of cases of infectious parotitis in the country, which has mainly affected the student population.\n\nAccording to the epidemiological bulletin at week 16 of 2018, 2619 cases of infectious parotitis, known as mumps, have been reported.\n\nThe states with the highest number of cases are: Tamaulipas with 561, Nuevo Le\u00f3n with 302, Quintana Roo with 203, Jalisco with 189 and Chihuahua with 167.\n\nSince the beginning of 2018, cases and outbreaks of the disease have been reported in the United States.\n\nThe Ministry of Health emphasized that it was identified as affecting mainly university residents of the US center in Mexico.\n\nThe age groups most affected nationwide are adults aged 25-44 years, with 805, followed by the group of 20-24 years with 531 and children aged 5-9 years, with 388.\n\n[Byline: Ximena Mej\u00eda]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A HealthMap/ProMED-mail of Mexico can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/14.]\n\n******\n[2] USA (Delaware, New Castle County)\nDate: Tue 17 Apr 2018\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/delaware-reports-additional-mumps-cases-outbreak-total-now-15-74934/\n\n\nIn a follow-up on the mumps outbreak in New Castle County, Delaware, The Delaware Division of Public Health (DPH) is confirming 2 additional cases of the mumps as part of its ongoing investigation of an outbreak among attendees at 2 multi-cultural dances in New Castle County. This brings the total number of mumps cases to 15.\n\nAll of the individuals infected with mumps reside in New Castle County.\n\nNine of the 15 persons with mumps attended either the 10 Feb or 3 Mar 2018 social dance (Baile Mejicano) that took place at the Chase Center on the Riverfront in Wilmington. Two of the remaining 4 individuals live with someone who attended one of the dances, and the source of the mumps virus exposure for the remaining 4 individuals is still under investigation.\n\nMumps is an acute viral infection spread through saliva or mucus from the mouth, nose, or throat. An infected person can spread the virus by coughing, sneezing, talking, sharing items such as cups or eating utensils with others, and touching objects or surfaces with unwashed hands that are then touched by others.\n\nSymptoms typically start with a few days of fever, headache, muscle aches, tiredness, and loss of appetite, followed by swollen salivary glands, which results in puffy cheeks and a swollen jaw. Symptoms typically appear 16-18 days after infection, but can range from 12-25 days after infection. Some people with mumps may not have any symptoms. Most people with mumps recover completely in a few weeks. However, mumps can occasionally cause complications, especially in adults.\n\nPeople known or suspected to have mumps should stay away from school or work until 5 days after the onset of swollen salivary glands as there is no specific treatment for mumps.\n\nThe CDC recommends children get 2 doses of MMR vaccine, starting with the 1st dose at 12-15 months of age and the 2nd dose at 4-6 years of age. Teens and adults who did not get the recommended MMR vaccines per the above schedule should be vaccinated so they are up to date. During outbreaks, CDC also recommends that those at highest risk due to exposure to people with mumps should receive a 3rd dose of MMR.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As of 25 Apr 2018, cases number 19. All 19 individuals reside in New Castle County. The age ranges of adults with the mumps virus are 21-57 years old. Additionally, there was one child under the age of 5 infected. According to the Delaware News https://news.delaware.gov/2018/04/24/four-mumps-cases-identified-bringing-total-19/, this is the 1st time that more than 3 mumps cases have been recorded during any calendar year since at least 2005. - Mod.LK\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail of the United States can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106 and Delaware, United States at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/211.]\n\n******\n[3] Virginia, William and Mary College\nDate: Wed 25 Apr 2018\nSource: The Virginia Gazette [edited]\nhttp://www.vagazette.com/news/va-vg-wm-mumps-20180428-story.html\n\n\nThere has been a case of reported mumps at the College of William and Mary.\n\nThe announcement was sent out in an email by Virginia Wells, director of the student health center at William and Mary, and Virginia Ambler, vice president of student affairs, on 24 Apr 2018. The email said the Peninsula Health District identified a case of mumps, and the student has since been isolated. Larry Hill, a spokesman for the Peninsula Health District, said they are working with the college on this case. ...\n\nWells said in her email people known to have had contact with the sick student have been notified, but since college campuses are a close and compact environment, it's possible other students may have been exposed.\n\nIn Wells and Ambler's email, they recommended students to review their immunization status and contact their doctor to receive the vaccine as needed. This vaccine is usually to children at age 12 months and again between the ages of 4-6 years and is 88% effective in persons having received 2 doses. So, someone who received a full immunization may still develop mumps.\n\nThe Virginia Department of Health said people who are exposed to mumps may not show symptoms for 12-25 days, and those infected can transmit mumps to others 2 days before symptoms appear. The email from Wells and Ambler suggested contacting your doctor and self-isolating until your doctor directs otherwise if you begin to have mumps-like symptoms.\n\n\"The university has taken all appropriate and recommended steps, including sharing this information with the campus community,\" the email said. \"We will provide additional updates or recommendations if needed.\"\n\nUpdate April 26\n----------\nA new announcement from Wells and Ambler said more cases of mumps have been reported on campus. The students who contracted the virus have been isolated, as with the 1st case.\n\nWhile Hill said Peninsula Health could not release the exact number of students who contracted mumps, there were several cases reported.\n\n[Byline: Amelia Heymann]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n\n[HealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nVirginia, United States: 20170110.4753366\n.................................................sb/lk/msp/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "mumps"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2619-03-16 00:00:00", "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "2021-04-26 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "VA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "VIRGINIA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brazil", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Portugal", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Jalisco", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Malaysia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Virginia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Delaware", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "DELAWARE", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pacific", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wilmington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Polynesia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5804230", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps update (05): USA (IL, VA), New Zealand (OT)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5804230", "date": "2018-04-27 11:46:59", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (03): MEXICO, USA (DELAWARE, VIRGINIA)\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Mexico\n[2] USA (Delaware)\n[3] USA (Virginia, William and Mary College)\n\n******\n[1] Mexico\nDate: Tue 24 Apr 2018\nSource: Excelsior [Google translated, edited]\nhttp://www.excelsior.com.mx/comunidad/advierten-sobre-brote-de-paperas-en-escuelas-de-la-cdmx/1234552\n\n\nA mumps outbreak is latent in universities in 7 states of the country. The outbreaks of greater risk have been located in student centers of the capital of the country, Sonora and Chihuahua.\n\nThe General Directorate of Epidemiology issued an epidemiological alert for the spread of cases of infectious parotitis in the country, which has mainly affected the student population.\n\nAccording to the epidemiological bulletin at week 16 of 2018, 2619 cases of infectious parotitis, known as mumps, have been reported.\n\nThe states with the highest number of cases are: Tamaulipas with 561, Nuevo Le\u00f3n with 302, Quintana Roo with 203, Jalisco with 189 and Chihuahua with 167.\n\nSince the beginning of 2018, cases and outbreaks of the disease have been reported in the United States.\n\nThe Ministry of Health emphasized that it was identified as affecting mainly university residents of the US center in Mexico.\n\nThe age groups most affected nationwide are adults aged 25-44 years, with 805, followed by the group of 20-24 years with 531 and children aged 5-9 years, with 388.\n\n[Byline: Ximena Mej\u00eda]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A HealthMap/ProMED-mail of Mexico can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/14.]\n\n******\n[2] USA (Delaware, New Castle County)\nDate: Tue 17 Apr 2018\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/delaware-reports-additional-mumps-cases-outbreak-total-now-15-74934/\n\n\nIn a follow-up on the mumps outbreak in New Castle County, Delaware, The Delaware Division of Public Health (DPH) is confirming 2 additional cases of the mumps as part of its ongoing investigation of an outbreak among attendees at 2 multi-cultural dances in New Castle County. This brings the total number of mumps cases to 15.\n\nAll of the individuals infected with mumps reside in New Castle County.\n\nNine of the 15 persons with mumps attended either the 10 Feb or 3 Mar 2018 social dance (Baile Mejicano) that took place at the Chase Center on the Riverfront in Wilmington. Two of the remaining 4 individuals live with someone who attended one of the dances, and the source of the mumps virus exposure for the remaining 4 individuals is still under investigation.\n\nMumps is an acute viral infection spread through saliva or mucus from the mouth, nose, or throat. An infected person can spread the virus by coughing, sneezing, talking, sharing items such as cups or eating utensils with others, and touching objects or surfaces with unwashed hands that are then touched by others.\n\nSymptoms typically start with a few days of fever, headache, muscle aches, tiredness, and loss of appetite, followed by swollen salivary glands, which results in puffy cheeks and a swollen jaw. Symptoms typically appear 16-18 days after infection, but can range from 12-25 days after infection. Some people with mumps may not have any symptoms. Most people with mumps recover completely in a few weeks. However, mumps can occasionally cause complications, especially in adults.\n\nPeople known or suspected to have mumps should stay away from school or work until 5 days after the onset of swollen salivary glands as there is no specific treatment for mumps.\n\nThe CDC recommends children get 2 doses of MMR vaccine, starting with the 1st dose at 12-15 months of age and the 2nd dose at 4-6 years of age. Teens and adults who did not get the recommended MMR vaccines per the above schedule should be vaccinated so they are up to date. During outbreaks, CDC also recommends that those at highest risk due to exposure to people with mumps should receive a 3rd dose of MMR.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As of 25 Apr 2018, cases number 19. All 19 individuals reside in New Castle County. The age ranges of adults with the mumps virus are 21-57 years old. Additionally, there was one child under the age of 5 infected. According to the Delaware News https://news.delaware.gov/2018/04/24/four-mumps-cases-identified-bringing-total-19/, this is the 1st time that more than 3 mumps cases have been recorded during any calendar year since at least 2005. - Mod.LK\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail of the United States can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106 and Delaware, United States at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/211.]\n\n******\n[3] Virginia, William and Mary College\nDate: Wed 25 Apr 2018\nSource: The Virginia Gazette [edited]\nhttp://www.vagazette.com/news/va-vg-wm-mumps-20180428-story.html\n\n\nThere has been a case of reported mumps at the College of William and Mary.\n\nThe announcement was sent out in an email by Virginia Wells, director of the student health center at William and Mary, and Virginia Ambler, vice president of student affairs, on 24 Apr 2018. The email said the Peninsula Health District identified a case of mumps, and the student has since been isolated. Larry Hill, a spokesman for the Peninsula Health District, said they are working with the college on this case. ...\n\nWells said in her email people known to have had contact with the sick student have been notified, but since college campuses are a close and compact environment, it's possible other students may have been exposed.\n\nIn Wells and Ambler's email, they recommended students to review their immunization status and contact their doctor to receive the vaccine as needed. This vaccine is usually to children at age 12 months and again between the ages of 4-6 years and is 88% effective in persons having received 2 doses. So, someone who received a full immunization may still develop mumps.\n\nThe Virginia Department of Health said people who are exposed to mumps may not show symptoms for 12-25 days, and those infected can transmit mumps to others 2 days before symptoms appear. The email from Wells and Ambler suggested contacting your doctor and self-isolating until your doctor directs otherwise if you begin to have mumps-like symptoms.\n\n\"The university has taken all appropriate and recommended steps, including sharing this information with the campus community,\" the email said. \"We will provide additional updates or recommendations if needed.\"\n\nUpdate April 26\n----------\nA new announcement from Wells and Ambler said more cases of mumps have been reported on campus. The students who contracted the virus have been isolated, as with the 1st case.\n\nWhile Hill said Peninsula Health could not release the exact number of students who contracted mumps, there were several cases reported.\n\n[Byline: Amelia Heymann]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n\n[HealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nVirginia, United States:
