"date": "2018-04-27 11:46:59", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (03): MEXICO, USA (DELAWARE, VIRGINIA)\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Mexico\n[2] USA (Delaware)\n[3] USA (Virginia, William and Mary College)\n\n******\n[1] Mexico\nDate: Tue 24 Apr 2018\nSource: Excelsior [Google translated, edited]\nhttp://www.excelsior.com.mx/comunidad/advierten-sobre-brote-de-paperas-en-escuelas-de-la-cdmx/1234552\n\n\nA mumps outbreak is latent in universities in 7 states of the country. The outbreaks of greater risk have been located in student centers of the capital of the country, Sonora and Chihuahua.\n\nThe General Directorate of Epidemiology issued an epidemiological alert for the spread of cases of infectious parotitis in the country, which has mainly affected the student population.\n\nAccording to the epidemiological bulletin at week 16 of 2018, 2619 cases of infectious parotitis, known as mumps, have been reported.\n\nThe states with the highest number of cases are: Tamaulipas with 561, Nuevo Le\u00f3n with 302, Quintana Roo with 203, Jalisco with 189 and Chihuahua with 167.\n\nSince the beginning of 2018, cases and outbreaks of the disease have been reported in the United States.\n\nThe Ministry of Health emphasized that it was identified as affecting mainly university residents of the US center in Mexico.\n\nThe age groups most affected nationwide are adults aged 25-44 years, with 805, followed by the group of 20-24 years with 531 and children aged 5-9 years, with 388.\n\n[Byline: Ximena Mej\u00eda]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A HealthMap/ProMED-mail of Mexico can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/14.]\n\n******\n[2] USA (Delaware, New Castle County)\nDate: Tue 17 Apr 2018\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/delaware-reports-additional-mumps-cases-outbreak-total-now-15-74934/\n\n\nIn a follow-up on the mumps outbreak in New Castle County, Delaware, The Delaware Division of Public Health (DPH) is confirming 2 additional cases of the mumps as part of its ongoing investigation of an outbreak among attendees at 2 multi-cultural dances in New Castle County. This brings the total number of mumps cases to 15.\n\nAll of the individuals infected with mumps reside in New Castle County.\n\nNine of the 15 persons with mumps attended either the 10 Feb or 3 Mar 2018 social dance (Baile Mejicano) that took place at the Chase Center on the Riverfront in Wilmington. Two of the remaining 4 individuals live with someone who attended one of the dances, and the source of the mumps virus exposure for the remaining 4 individuals is still under investigation.\n\nMumps is an acute viral infection spread through saliva or mucus from the mouth, nose, or throat. An infected person can spread the virus by coughing, sneezing, talking, sharing items such as cups or eating utensils with others, and touching objects or surfaces with unwashed hands that are then touched by others.\n\nSymptoms typically start with a few days of fever, headache, muscle aches, tiredness, and loss of appetite, followed by swollen salivary glands, which results in puffy cheeks and a swollen jaw. Symptoms typically appear 16-18 days after infection, but can range from 12-25 days after infection. Some people with mumps may not have any symptoms. Most people with mumps recover completely in a few weeks. However, mumps can occasionally cause complications, especially in adults.\n\nPeople known or suspected to have mumps should stay away from school or work until 5 days after the onset of swollen salivary glands as there is no specific treatment for mumps.\n\nThe CDC recommends children get 2 doses of MMR vaccine, starting with the 1st dose at 12-15 months of age and the 2nd dose at 4-6 years of age. Teens and adults who did not get the recommended MMR vaccines per the above schedule should be vaccinated so they are up to date. During outbreaks, CDC also recommends that those at highest risk due to exposure to people with mumps should receive a 3rd dose of MMR.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As of 25 Apr 2018, cases number 19. All 19 individuals reside in New Castle County. The age ranges of adults with the mumps virus are 21-57 years old. Additionally, there was one child under the age of 5 infected. According to the Delaware News https://news.delaware.gov/2018/04/24/four-mumps-cases-identified-bringing-total-19/, this is the 1st time that more than 3 mumps cases have been recorded during any calendar year since at least 2005. - Mod.LK\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail of the United States can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106 and Delaware, United States at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/211.]\n\n******\n[3] Virginia, William and Mary College\nDate: Wed 25 Apr 2018\nSource: The Virginia Gazette [edited]\nhttp://www.vagazette.com/news/va-vg-wm-mumps-20180428-story.html\n\n\nThere has been a case of reported mumps at the College of William and Mary.\n\nThe announcement was sent out in an email by Virginia Wells, director of the student health center at William and Mary, and Virginia Ambler, vice president of student affairs, on 24 Apr 2018. The email said the Peninsula Health District identified a case of mumps, and the student has since been isolated. Larry Hill, a spokesman for the Peninsula Health District, said they are working with the college on this case. ...\n\nWells said in her email people known to have had contact with the sick student have been notified, but since college campuses are a close and compact environment, it's possible other students may have been exposed.\n\nIn Wells and Ambler's email, they recommended students to review their immunization status and contact their doctor to receive the vaccine as needed. This vaccine is usually to children at age 12 months and again between the ages of 4-6 years and is 88% effective in persons having received 2 doses. So, someone who received a full immunization may still develop mumps.\n\nThe Virginia Department of Health said people who are exposed to mumps may not show symptoms for 12-25 days, and those infected can transmit mumps to others 2 days before symptoms appear. The email from Wells and Ambler suggested contacting your doctor and self-isolating until your doctor directs otherwise if you begin to have mumps-like symptoms.\n\n\"The university has taken all appropriate and recommended steps, including sharing this information with the campus community,\" the email said. \"We will provide additional updates or recommendations if needed.\"\n\nUpdate April 26\n----------\nA new announcement from Wells and Ambler said more cases of mumps have been reported on campus. The students who contracted the virus have been isolated, as with the 1st case.\n\nWhile Hill said Peninsula Health could not release the exact number of students who contracted mumps, there were several cases reported.\n\n[Byline: Amelia Heymann]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n\n[HealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nVirginia, United States: 00:00:00", "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "2021-04-26 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "VA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "VIRGINIA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brazil", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Portugal", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Jalisco", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Malaysia", "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5704564", "date": "2017-11-10 11:18:50", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (32): SOUTH AMERICA, USA, NEW ZEALAND\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] South America (Bolivia)\n[2] USA (Washington)\n[3] USA (District of Columbia)\n[4] New Zealand\n\n******\n[1] South America (Bolivia)\nDate: Wed 1 Nov 2017\nSource: Pagina Siete [in Spanish, trans. Mod.JG]\nhttp://www.paginasiete.bo/sociedad/2017/11/1/bolivia-registra-brote-inusitado-paperas-luego-cinco-anos-157841.html\n\n\nThis year [2017] Bolivia is experiencing an unusual outbreak of mumps. According to data from the Ministry of Health, the number of reported cases until now is 3 times higher compared to figures recorded 5 years ago.\n\n\"We've had an important outbreak of mumps this year [2017],\" pointed out Adolfo Zarate, Head of the Epidemiology area of the Ministry of Health, who also mentioned that during this year 2044 cases of mumps have been reported. This is 3 times the figure for 2013, when a similar outbreak took place, but only 776 cases were reported. Mr Zarate explained that this explosive condition is because of the change of season, and also because non-immunized people may gather, so this may generate the high number of cases.\n\nYesterday [31 Oct 2017], La Paz Health Service (SEDES, according to its Spanish initials) reported that the mumps vaccine, which is included within the MRM package (measles, rubella, and mumps) only confers 80 percent protection. The vaccine is administered to children between 12 and 24 months of age, and a booster dose is given when they are 4 years old.\n\nThe most affected departments are La Paz, 1698 cases; Santa Cruz, 221 cases, and Cochabamba. For this reason, Mr Zarate urged the (symptomatic) population to go to health centers in order to have timely therapy.\n\nIn La Paz city, SEDES reported last week that this is an alarming situation, since \"there is an explosive and persistent outbreak\".\n\nMumps is a viral disease that is transmitted from person to person through saliva (droplets). Affected persons most commonly present with the following symptoms: fever, sore throat, parotid gland enlargement (inflammation), and loss of appetite.\n\nMr Zarate also recommended that all affected persons must get rest if they develop symptoms, since male subjects may develop orchitis (testis inflammation) or ovaritis (ovarian inflammation), which may lead -- in a small percentage of cases -- to infertility.\n\nHe also advised that affected persons must use masks; they must also avoid sharing cutlery and dishes, and thoroughly wash their hands. It is also important to disinfect the household using detergents, in order to prevent transmission of the disease to other members of the family.\n\nMr Zarate also recommended that sanitary triage must be established in educational facilities, so that if parents, teachers, or school authorities find a symptomatic student, he/she must be immediately sent home and be isolated for at least 10 days.\n\nThe disease may occur at any age in a non-immunized person, but most commonly affected individuals are those less than 20 years of age.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Bolivia can be seen at http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/americas/bolivia_admin_2006.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/5. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[2] USA (Washington)\nDate: Thu 2 Nov 2017\nSource: iFIBER One News [edited]\nhttp://www.ifiberone.com/columbia_basin/mumps-and-whooping-cough-a-problem-in/youtube_71b3dcd4-c002-11e7-9a61-ff27becf4d65.html\n\n\nGrant County [Washington] saw an extraordinary amount of mumps cases this year [2017] with 45. The mumps outbreak was contained to the Columbia Basin Job Corps and the Ephrata School District. Grant County Health District's Theresa Atkinson says that was a fraction of the 888 cases reported statewide.\n\n\"The mumps outbreak was incredibly large for our area,\" said Adkinson Fortunately, no one currently has mumps in Grant County.\n\nThe same cannot be said about whooping cough with 78 current cases in the county. This year [2017], Moses Lake had 54 cases of pertussis, Ephrata had 22, Soap Lake 2 and both Royal City and Warden had 1.\n\n\"It's the largest pertussis outbreak we've ever experienced,\" said Adkinson.\n\nFor more on how to prevent these illnesses, go to http://granthealth.org.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Washington can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/248. Grant county can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/washington-county-map.gif. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n\n[3] USA (District of Columbia)\nDate: Mon 6 Nov 2017\nSource: Washington Post [edited]\nhttps://www.washingtonpost.com/news/grade-point/wp/2017/11/06/mumps-reported-at-catholic-university-georgetown/\n\n\nMumps, an infectious disease carried on a sneeze or a cup, appears to be spreading among DC [USA, District of Columbia] universities, with cases reported at 3 schools.\n\nThe Catholic University of America recently identified a cluster of illness, with 4 confirmed mumps cases and 3 more suspected cases under investigation, a school spokeswoman said [Mon 6 Nov 2017].\n\nOn [Fri 3 Nov 2017], a message sent to the Georgetown University community said 2 undergraduates had been diagnosed with the disease.\n\nThe cases at Georgetown have been confirmed, according to a letter from the DC Department of Health.\n\nAnd American University has 2 confirmed mumps cases, as well as 4 suspected cases, school spokesman Mark Story said [Mon 6 Nov 2017].\n\nThe mumps cases at DC universities appear to be connected, though officials are still investigating, DC Department of Health spokeswoman Jasmine Gossett said.\n\n\"We are monitoring them and are working with the universities and their student health centers, just to inform them and then educate those who may be at risk,\" Gossett said.\n\nAt Catholic, the school has adjusted Communion distribution during Mass to help combat the illness, university spokeswoman Elise Italiano said. \"Normally, we offer Communion through the host and what we call the chalice, or the cup with wine,\" Italiano said. \"And we suspended the 2nd practice . . . because of the possible spread through saliva. So, we've just taken that extra precaution.\"\n\nMumps spreads through saliva or mucus, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Symptoms include fever, headaches, and swollen and tender glands under the ears, the CDC's website notes.\n\nGeorgetown officials asked infected students to cloister themselves for 5 days after the appearance of initial symptoms, a note to the campus from Vince WinklerPrins, assistant vice president for student health, said.\n\n\"We will continue to monitor and support these students,\" WinklerPrins said.\n\nIn an email sent to its campus community, Catholic said residential students who had reported mumps symptoms have been moved to an unoccupied space, in an attempt to limit exposure.\n\n\"Students are able to return to rooms and classes after a 5-day period,\" the email stated.\n\nCatholic's students were also briefed on how someone infected with mumps can spread the virus: by coughing or sharing a drink, for example. They were advised to keep their hands clean and to not share their utensils.\n\nThe University of Virginia [U-Va] has also recently urged students to take precautions after 2 suspected cases were identified. A U-Va spokesman did not immediately return an email seeking an update [Mon 6 Nov 2017].\n\n[Byline: Sarah Larimer]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nAnn Zhang\nUniversity of Rochester\n<ayzhang24@gmail.com>\n\nProMED thanks Ann Zhang for alerting us to these cases.\n\n[Because of the rise in mumps outbreaks observed at US universities since 2006, a federal expert US panel has endorsed a 3rd vaccine dose in such outbreak situations. See http://wapo.st/2yoWDc1 for a report on this decision, as well as ProMED mail Mumps update (31): USA, MMR 3rd dose, Canada 20171027.5407525.\n\nWashington DC can be located on the maps at http://www.mapsofworld.com/usa/ and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/259. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[4] New Zealand (Auckland)\nDate: Mon 6 Nov 2017 1:17 PM NZDT\nSource: NZ Herald, Newstalk ZB [edited]\nhttp://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11940991\n\n\nPublic health service medical officer, Dr Josephine Herman, says NZ has a vulnerable population who have not been fully immunised.\n\nAuckland Regional Public Health Service has been notified of 740 cases of mumps since 1 Jan [2017]. Dr Herman, said this was the worst outbreak since 1994. \"This is quite a large outbreak, and something we're very concerned about, and trying our best to implement public health measures to try to contain,\" Herman said.\n\nShe said Auckland was essentially free of the viral disease even late last year [2016], but the outbreak began after being picked up overseas. Herman said it particularly came from the Pacific Islands -- mostly Fiji, and later Tonga -- where the mumps vaccine was not available.\n\nShe said there have also been \"massive\" outbreaks in the US and the UK, which has spread easily through universities, she said.\n\n\"In terms of where the mumps infection is occurring, it's actually all throughout the world. New Zealand has been immune to it until late last year [2016] and early this year. Because we've had a vulnerable population here who have not been fully immunised with the MMR vaccine, it's allowed community spread to be well established.\n\n\"We are importing mumps, as well as probably exporting it as well.\"\n\nHerman said it was not possible to know if the rates of the disease have peaked.\n\nBut she said if people have not received the MMR vaccine, to do so immediately. Other ways to combat the spread include washing hands, covering coughs and cleaning commonly used items.\n\nHerman says for most adults, it's a mild illness. However, a small proportion can develop complications including meningitis or encephalitis. Young children are more at risk of developing harmful outcomes.\n\n[Byline: Jordan Bond]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This outbreak is a consequence of introduction of mumps into a community with low vaccination coverage. More often, mumps outbreaks are the consequence of waning immunity in young adults. But the Auckland outbreak is a reminder that even with elimination of mumps (and measles) from a country, high immunization levels must be maintained.\n\nMaps of New Zealand can be seen at http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/dc/NZTerritorialAuthorities.png and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/606. - Mod.LK]\nSee Also\nMumps update (31): USA, MMR 3rd dose, Canada "2044-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "1698-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-01-01 00:00:00", "1994-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Washington DC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NEW ZEALAND", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Fiji", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brazil", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Portugal", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tonga", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NZ", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Malaysia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "La Paz", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Santa Cruz", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SOUTH AMERICA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Royal City", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "DC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bolivia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Grant County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "District of Columbia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5638266", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps update: USA", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5638266", "date": "2017-11-10 11:18:50", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (32): SOUTH AMERICA, USA, NEW ZEALAND\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] South America (Bolivia)\n[2] USA (Washington)\n[3] USA (District of Columbia)\n[4] New Zealand\n\n******\n[1] South America (Bolivia)\nDate: Wed 1 Nov 2017\nSource: Pagina Siete [in Spanish, trans. Mod.JG]\nhttp://www.paginasiete.bo/sociedad/2017/11/1/bolivia-registra-brote-inusitado-paperas-luego-cinco-anos-157841.html\n\n\nThis year [2017] Bolivia is experiencing an unusual outbreak of mumps. According to data from the Ministry of Health, the number of reported cases until now is 3 times higher compared to figures recorded 5 years ago.\n\n\"We've had an important outbreak of mumps this year [2017],\" pointed out Adolfo Zarate, Head of the Epidemiology area of the Ministry of Health, who also mentioned that during this year 2044 cases of mumps have been reported. This is 3 times the figure for 2013, when a similar outbreak took place, but only 776 cases were reported. Mr Zarate explained that this explosive condition is because of the change of season, and also because non-immunized people may gather, so this may generate the high number of cases.\n\nYesterday [31 Oct 2017], La Paz Health Service (SEDES, according to its Spanish initials) reported that the mumps vaccine, which is included within the MRM package (measles, rubella, and mumps) only confers 80 percent protection. The vaccine is administered to children between 12 and 24 months of age, and a booster dose is given when they are 4 years old.\n\nThe most affected departments are La Paz, 1698 cases; Santa Cruz, 221 cases, and Cochabamba. For this reason, Mr Zarate urged the (symptomatic) population to go to health centers in order to have timely therapy.\n\nIn La Paz city, SEDES reported last week that this is an alarming situation, since \"there is an explosive and persistent outbreak\".\n\nMumps is a viral disease that is transmitted from person to person through saliva (droplets). Affected persons most commonly present with the following symptoms: fever, sore throat, parotid gland enlargement (inflammation), and loss of appetite.\n\nMr Zarate also recommended that all affected persons must get rest if they develop symptoms, since male subjects may develop orchitis (testis inflammation) or ovaritis (ovarian inflammation), which may lead -- in a small percentage of cases -- to infertility.\n\nHe also advised that affected persons must use masks; they must also avoid sharing cutlery and dishes, and thoroughly wash their hands. It is also important to disinfect the household using detergents, in order to prevent transmission of the disease to other members of the family.\n\nMr Zarate also recommended that sanitary triage must be established in educational facilities, so that if parents, teachers, or school authorities find a symptomatic student, he/she must be immediately sent home and be isolated for at least 10 days.\n\nThe disease may occur at any age in a non-immunized person, but most commonly affected individuals are those less than 20 years of age.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Bolivia can be seen at http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/americas/bolivia_admin_2006.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/5. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[2] USA (Washington)\nDate: Thu 2 Nov 2017\nSource: iFIBER One News [edited]\nhttp://www.ifiberone.com/columbia_basin/mumps-and-whooping-cough-a-problem-in/youtube_71b3dcd4-c002-11e7-9a61-ff27becf4d65.html\n\n\nGrant County [Washington] saw an extraordinary amount of mumps cases this year [2017] with 45. The mumps outbreak was contained to the Columbia Basin Job Corps and the Ephrata School District. Grant County Health District's Theresa Atkinson says that was a fraction of the 888 cases reported statewide.\n\n\"The mumps outbreak was incredibly large for our area,\" said Adkinson Fortunately, no one currently has mumps in Grant County.\n\nThe same cannot be said about whooping cough with 78 current cases in the county. This year [2017], Moses Lake had 54 cases of pertussis, Ephrata had 22, Soap Lake 2 and both Royal City and Warden had 1.\n\n\"It's the largest pertussis outbreak we've ever experienced,\" said Adkinson.\n\nFor more on how to prevent these illnesses, go to http://granthealth.org.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Washington can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/248. Grant county can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/washington-county-map.gif. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n\n[3] USA (District of Columbia)\nDate: Mon 6 Nov 2017\nSource: Washington Post [edited]\nhttps://www.washingtonpost.com/news/grade-point/wp/2017/11/06/mumps-reported-at-catholic-university-georgetown/\n\n\nMumps, an infectious disease carried on a sneeze or a cup, appears to be spreading among DC [USA, District of Columbia] universities, with cases reported at 3 schools.\n\nThe Catholic University of America recently identified a cluster of illness, with 4 confirmed mumps cases and 3 more suspected cases under investigation, a school spokeswoman said [Mon 6 Nov 2017].\n\nOn [Fri 3 Nov 2017], a message sent to the Georgetown University community said 2 undergraduates had been diagnosed with the disease.\n\nThe cases at Georgetown have been confirmed, according to a letter from the DC Department of Health.\n\nAnd American University has 2 confirmed mumps cases, as well as 4 suspected cases, school spokesman Mark Story said [Mon 6 Nov 2017].\n\nThe mumps cases at DC universities appear to be connected, though officials are still investigating, DC Department of Health spokeswoman Jasmine Gossett said.\n\n\"We are monitoring them and are working with the universities and their student health centers, just to inform them and then educate those who may be at risk,\" Gossett said.\n\nAt Catholic, the school has adjusted Communion distribution during Mass to help combat the illness, university spokeswoman Elise Italiano said. \"Normally, we offer Communion through the host and what we call the chalice, or the cup with wine,\" Italiano said. \"And we suspended the 2nd practice . . . because of the possible spread through saliva. So, we've just taken that extra precaution.\"\n\nMumps spreads through saliva or mucus, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Symptoms include fever, headaches, and swollen and tender glands under the ears, the CDC's website notes.\n\nGeorgetown officials asked infected students to cloister themselves for 5 days after the appearance of initial symptoms, a note to the campus from Vince WinklerPrins, assistant vice president for student health, said.\n\n\"We will continue to monitor and support these students,\" WinklerPrins said.\n\nIn an email sent to its campus community, Catholic said residential students who had reported mumps symptoms have been moved to an unoccupied space, in an attempt to limit exposure.\n\n\"Students are able to return to rooms and classes after a 5-day period,\" the email stated.\n\nCatholic's students were also briefed on how someone infected with mumps can spread the virus: by coughing or sharing a drink, for example. They were advised to keep their hands clean and to not share their utensils.\n\nThe University of Virginia [U-Va] has also recently urged students to take precautions after 2 suspected cases were identified. A U-Va spokesman did not immediately return an email seeking an update [Mon 6 Nov 2017].\n\n[Byline: Sarah Larimer]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nAnn Zhang\nUniversity of Rochester\n<ayzhang24@gmail.com>\n\nProMED thanks Ann Zhang for alerting us to these cases.\n\n[Because of the rise in mumps outbreaks observed at US universities since 2006, a federal expert US panel has endorsed a 3rd vaccine dose in such outbreak situations. See http://wapo.st/2yoWDc1 for a report on this decision, as well as ProMED mail Mumps update (31): USA, MMR 3rd dose, Canada 20171027.5407525.\n\nWashington DC can be located on the maps at http://www.mapsofworld.com/usa/ and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/259. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[4] New Zealand (Auckland)\nDate: Mon 6 Nov 2017 1:17 PM NZDT\nSource: NZ Herald, Newstalk ZB [edited]\nhttp://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11940991\n\n\nPublic health service medical officer, Dr Josephine Herman, says NZ has a vulnerable population who have not been fully immunised.\n\nAuckland Regional Public Health Service has been notified of 740 cases of mumps since 1 Jan [2017]. Dr Herman, said this was the worst outbreak since 1994. \"This is quite a large outbreak, and something we're very concerned about, and trying our best to implement public health measures to try to contain,\" Herman said.\n\nShe said Auckland was essentially free of the viral disease even late last year [2016], but the outbreak began after being picked up overseas. Herman said it particularly came from the Pacific Islands -- mostly Fiji, and later Tonga -- where the mumps vaccine was not available.\n\nShe said there have also been \"massive\" outbreaks in the US and the UK, which has spread easily through universities, she said.\n\n\"In terms of where the mumps infection is occurring, it's actually all throughout the world. New Zealand has been immune to it until late last year [2016] and early this year. Because we've had a vulnerable population here who have not been fully immunised with the MMR vaccine, it's allowed community spread to be well established.\n\n\"We are importing mumps, as well as probably exporting it as well.\"\n\nHerman said it was not possible to know if the rates of the disease have peaked.\n\nBut she said if people have not received the MMR vaccine, to do so immediately. Other ways to combat the spread include washing hands, covering coughs and cleaning commonly used items.\n\nHerman says for most adults, it's a mild illness. However, a small proportion can develop complications including meningitis or encephalitis. Young children are more at risk of developing harmful outcomes.\n\n[Byline: Jordan Bond]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This outbreak is a consequence of introduction of mumps into a community with low vaccination coverage. More often, mumps outbreaks are the consequence of waning immunity in young adults. But the Auckland outbreak is a reminder that even with elimination of mumps (and measles) from a country, high immunization levels must be maintained.\n\nMaps of New Zealand can be seen at http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/dc/NZTerritorialAuthorities.png and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/606. - Mod.LK]\nSee Also\nMumps update (31): USA, MMR 3rd dose, Canada "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5528344", "date": "2017-11-10 11:18:50", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (32): SOUTH AMERICA, USA, NEW ZEALAND\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] South America (Bolivia)\n[2] Mod.JG]\nhttp://www.paginasiete.bo/sociedad/2017/11/1/bolivia-registra-brote-inusitado-paperas-luego-cinco-anos-157841.html\n\n\nThis year [2017] Bolivia is experiencing an unusual outbreak of mumps. According to data from the Ministry of Health, the number of reported cases until now is 3 times higher compared to figures recorded 5 years ago.\n\n\"We've had an important outbreak of mumps this year [2017],\" pointed out Adolfo Zarate, Head of the Epidemiology area of the Ministry of Health, who also mentioned that during this year 2044 cases of mumps have been reported. This is 3 times the figure for 2013, when a similar outbreak took place, but only 776 cases were reported. Mr Zarate explained that this explosive condition is because of the change of season, and also because non-immunized people may gather, so this may generate the high number of cases.\n\nYesterday [31 Oct 2017], La Paz Health Service (SEDES, according to its Spanish initials) reported that the mumps vaccine, which is included within the MRM package (measles, rubella, and mumps) only confers 80 percent protection. The vaccine is administered to children between 12 and 24 months of age, and a booster dose is given when they are 4 years old.\n\nThe most affected departments are La Paz, 1698 cases; Santa Cruz, 221 cases, and Cochabamba. For this reason, Mr Zarate urged the (symptomatic) population to go to health centers in order to have timely therapy.\n\nIn La Paz city, SEDES reported last week that this is an alarming situation, since \"there is an explosive and persistent outbreak\".\n\nMumps is a viral disease that is transmitted from person to person through saliva (droplets). Affected persons most commonly present with the following symptoms: fever, sore throat, parotid gland enlargement (inflammation), and loss of appetite.\n\nMr Zarate also recommended that all affected persons must get rest if they develop symptoms, since male subjects may develop orchitis (testis inflammation) or ovaritis (ovarian inflammation), which may lead -- in a small percentage of cases -- to infertility.\n\nHe also advised that affected persons must use masks; they must also avoid sharing cutlery and dishes, and thoroughly wash their hands. It is also important to disinfect the household using detergents, in order to prevent transmission of the disease to other members of the family.\n\nMr Zarate also recommended that sanitary triage must be established in educational facilities, so that if parents, teachers, or school authorities find a symptomatic student, he/she must be immediately sent home and be isolated for at least 10 days.\n\nThe disease may occur at any age in a non-immunized person, but most commonly affected individuals are those less than 20 years of age.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Bolivia can be seen at http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/americas/bolivia_admin_2006.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/5. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[2] USA (Washington)\nDate: Thu 2 Nov 2017\nSource: iFIBER One News [edited]\nhttp://www.ifiberone.com/columbia_basin/mumps-and-whooping-cough-a-problem-in/youtube_71b3dcd4-c002-11e7-9a61-ff27becf4d65.html\n\n\nGrant County [Washington] saw an extraordinary amount of mumps cases this year [2017] with 45. The mumps outbreak was contained to the Columbia Basin Job Corps and the Ephrata School District. Grant County Health District's Theresa Atkinson says that was a fraction of the 888 cases reported statewide.\n\n\"The mumps outbreak was incredibly large for our area,\" said Adkinson Fortunately, no one currently has mumps in Grant County.\n\nThe same cannot be said about whooping cough with 78 current cases in the county. This year [2017], Moses Lake had 54 cases of pertussis, Ephrata had 22, Soap Lake 2 and both Royal City and Warden had 1.\n\n\"It's the largest pertussis outbreak we've ever experienced,\" said Adkinson.\n\nFor more on how to prevent these illnesses, go to http://granthealth.org.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Washington can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/248. Grant county can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/washington-county-map.gif. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n\n[3] USA (District of Columbia)\nDate: Mon 6 Nov 2017\nSource: Washington Post [edited]\nhttps://www.washingtonpost.com/news/grade-point/wp/2017/11/06/mumps-reported-at-catholic-university-georgetown/\n\n\nMumps, an infectious disease carried on a sneeze or a cup, appears to be spreading among DC [USA, District of Columbia] universities, with cases reported at 3 schools.\n\nThe Catholic University of America recently identified a cluster of illness, with 4 confirmed mumps cases and 3 more suspected cases under investigation, a school spokeswoman said [Mon 6 Nov 2017].\n\nOn [Fri 3 Nov 2017], a message sent to the Georgetown University community said 2 undergraduates had been diagnosed with the disease.\n\nThe cases at Georgetown have been confirmed, according to a letter from the DC Department of Health.\n\nAnd American University has 2 confirmed mumps cases, as well as 4 suspected cases, school spokesman Mark Story said [Mon 6 Nov 2017].\n\nThe mumps cases at DC universities appear to be connected, though officials are still investigating, DC Department of Health spokeswoman Jasmine Gossett said.\n\n\"We are monitoring them and are working with the universities and their student health centers, just to inform them and then educate those who may be at risk,\" Gossett said.\n\nAt Catholic, the school has adjusted Communion distribution during Mass to help combat the illness, university spokeswoman Elise Italiano said. \"Normally, we offer Communion through the host and what we call the chalice, or the cup with wine,\" Italiano said. \"And we suspended the 2nd practice . . . because of the possible spread through saliva. So, we've just taken that extra precaution.\"\n\nMumps spreads through saliva or mucus, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Symptoms include fever, headaches, and swollen and tender glands under the ears, the CDC's website notes.\n\nGeorgetown officials asked infected students to cloister themselves for 5 days after the appearance of initial symptoms, a note to the campus from Vince WinklerPrins, assistant vice president for student health, said.\n\n\"We will continue to monitor and support these students,\" WinklerPrins said.\n\nIn an email sent to its campus community, Catholic said residential students who had reported mumps symptoms have been moved to an unoccupied space, in an attempt to limit exposure.\n\n\"Students are able to return to rooms and classes after a 5-day period,\" the email stated.\n\nCatholic's students were also briefed on how someone infected with mumps can spread the virus: by coughing or sharing a drink, for example. They were advised to keep their hands clean and to not share their utensils.\n\nThe University of Virginia [U-Va] has also recently urged students to take precautions after 2 suspected cases were identified. A U-Va spokesman did not immediately return an email seeking an update [Mon 6 Nov 2017].\n\n[Byline: Sarah Larimer]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nAnn Zhang\nUniversity of Rochester\n<ayzhang24@gmail.com>\n\nProMED thanks Ann Zhang for alerting us to these cases.\n\n[Because of the rise in mumps outbreaks observed at US universities since 2006, a federal expert US panel has endorsed a 3rd vaccine dose in such outbreak situations. See http://wapo.st/2yoWDc1 for a report on this decision, as well as ProMED mail Mumps update (31): USA, MMR 3rd dose, Canada 20171027.5407525.\n\nWashington DC can be located on the maps at http://www.mapsofworld.com/usa/ and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/259. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[4] New Zealand (Auckland)\nDate: Mon 6 Nov 2017 1:17 PM NZDT\nSource: NZ Herald, Newstalk ZB [edited]\nhttp://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11940991\n\n\nPublic health service medical officer, Dr Josephine Herman, says NZ has a vulnerable population who have not been fully immunised.\n\nAuckland Regional Public Health Service has been notified of 740 cases of mumps since 1 Jan [2017]. Dr Herman, said this was the worst outbreak since 1994. \"This is quite a large outbreak, and something we're very concerned about, and trying our best to implement public health measures to try to contain,\" Herman said.\n\nShe said Auckland was essentially free of the viral disease even late last year [2016], but the outbreak began after being picked up overseas. Herman said it particularly came from the Pacific Islands -- mostly Fiji, and later Tonga -- where the mumps vaccine was not available.\n\nShe said there have also been \"massive\" outbreaks in the US and the UK, which has spread easily through universities, she said.\n\n\"In terms of where the mumps infection is occurring, it's actually all throughout the world. New Zealand has been immune to it until late last year [2016] and early this year. Because we've had a vulnerable population here who have not been fully immunised with the MMR vaccine, it's allowed community spread to be well established.\n\n\"We are importing mumps, as well as probably exporting it as well.\"\n\nHerman said it was not possible to know if the rates of the disease have peaked.\n\nBut she said if people have not received the MMR vaccine, to do so immediately. Other ways to combat the spread include washing hands, covering coughs and cleaning commonly used items.\n\nHerman says for most adults, it's a mild illness. However, a small proportion can develop complications including meningitis or encephalitis. Young children are more at risk of developing harmful outcomes.\n\n[Byline: Jordan Bond]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This outbreak is a consequence of introduction of mumps into a community with low vaccination coverage. More often, mumps outbreaks are the consequence of waning immunity in young adults. But the Auckland outbreak is a reminder that even with elimination of mumps (and measles) from a country, high immunization levels must be maintained.\n\nMaps of New Zealand can be seen at "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "pertussis", "rubella", "encephalitis", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["2032-03-16 00:00:00", "2044-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "1698-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-01-01 00:00:00", "1994-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Washington DC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NEW ZEALAND", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Fiji", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brazil", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Portugal", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tonga", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NZ", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Malaysia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "La Paz", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Santa Cruz", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SOUTH AMERICA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Royal City", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "DC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "District of Columbia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5518587", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps update (36): USA (HI) school", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5518587", "date": "2017-11-10 11:18:50", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (32): SOUTH AMERICA, USA, NEW ZEALAND\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] South America (Bolivia)\n[2] USA (Washington)\n[3] USA (District of Columbia)\n[4] New Zealand\n\n******\n[1] South America (Bolivia)\nDate: Wed 1 Nov 2017\nSource: Pagina Siete [in Spanish, trans. Mod.JG]\nhttp://www.paginasiete.bo/sociedad/2017/11/1/bolivia-registra-brote-inusitado-paperas-luego-cinco-anos-157841.html\n\n\nThis year [2017] Bolivia is experiencing an unusual outbreak of mumps. According to data from the Ministry of Health, the number of reported cases until now is 3 times higher compared to figures recorded 5 years ago.\n\n\"We've had an important outbreak of mumps this year [2017],\" pointed out Adolfo Zarate, Head of the Epidemiology area of the Ministry of Health, who also mentioned that during this year 2044 cases of mumps have been reported. This is 3 times the figure for 2013, when a similar outbreak took place, but only 776 cases were reported. Mr Zarate explained that this explosive condition is because of the change of season, and also because non-immunized people may gather, so this may generate the high number of cases.\n\nYesterday [31 Oct 2017], La Paz Health Service (SEDES, according to its Spanish initials) reported that the mumps vaccine, which is included within the MRM package (measles, rubella, and mumps) only confers 80 percent protection. The vaccine is administered to children between 12 and 24 months of age, and a booster dose is given when they are 4 years old.\n\nThe most affected departments are La Paz, 1698 cases; Santa Cruz, 221 cases, and Cochabamba. For this reason, Mr Zarate urged the (symptomatic) population to go to health centers in order to have timely therapy.\n\nIn La Paz city, SEDES reported last week that this is an alarming situation, since \"there is an explosive and persistent outbreak\".\n\nMumps is a viral disease that is transmitted from person to person through saliva (droplets). Affected persons most commonly present with the following symptoms: fever, sore throat, parotid gland enlargement (inflammation), and loss of appetite.\n\nMr Zarate also recommended that all affected persons must get rest if they develop symptoms, since male subjects may develop orchitis (testis inflammation) or ovaritis (ovarian inflammation), which may lead -- in a small percentage of cases -- to infertility.\n\nHe also advised that affected persons must use masks; they must also avoid sharing cutlery and dishes, and thoroughly wash their hands. It is also important to disinfect the household using detergents, in order to prevent transmission of the disease to other members of the family.\n\nMr Zarate also recommended that sanitary triage must be established in educational facilities, so that if parents, teachers, or school authorities find a symptomatic student, he/she must be immediately sent home and be isolated for at least 10 days.\n\nThe disease may occur at any age in a non-immunized person, but most commonly affected individuals are those less than 20 years of age.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Bolivia can be seen at http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/americas/bolivia_admin_2006.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/5. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[2] USA (Washington)\nDate: Thu 2 Nov 2017\nSource: iFIBER One News [edited]\nhttp://www.ifiberone.com/columbia_basin/mumps-and-whooping-cough-a-problem-in/youtube_71b3dcd4-c002-11e7-9a61-ff27becf4d65.html\n\n\nGrant County [Washington] saw an extraordinary amount of mumps cases this year [2017] with 45. The mumps outbreak was contained to the Columbia Basin Job Corps and the Ephrata School District. Grant County Health District's Theresa Atkinson says that was a fraction of the 888 cases reported statewide.\n\n\"The mumps outbreak was incredibly large for our area,\" said Adkinson Fortunately, no one currently has mumps in Grant County.\n\nThe same cannot be said about whooping cough with 78 current cases in the county. This year [2017], Moses Lake had 54 cases of pertussis, Ephrata had 22, Soap Lake 2 and both Royal City and Warden had 1.\n\n\"It's the largest pertussis outbreak we've ever experienced,\" said Adkinson.\n\nFor more on how to prevent these illnesses, go to http://granthealth.org.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Washington can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/248. Grant county can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/washington-county-map.gif. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n\n[3] USA (District of Columbia)\nDate: Mon 6 Nov 2017\nSource: Washington Post [edited]\nhttps://www.washingtonpost.com/news/grade-point/wp/2017/11/06/mumps-reported-at-catholic-university-georgetown/\n\n\nMumps, an infectious disease carried on a sneeze or a cup, appears to be spreading among DC [USA, District of Columbia] universities, with cases reported at 3 schools.\n\nThe Catholic University of America recently identified a cluster of illness, with 4 confirmed mumps cases and 3 more suspected cases under investigation, a school spokeswoman said [Mon 6 Nov 2017].\n\nOn [Fri 3 Nov 2017], a message sent to the Georgetown University community said 2 undergraduates had been diagnosed with the disease.\n\nThe cases at Georgetown have been confirmed, according to a letter from the DC Department of Health.\n\nAnd American University has 2 confirmed mumps cases, as well as 4 suspected cases, school spokesman Mark Story said [Mon 6 Nov 2017].\n\nThe mumps cases at DC universities appear to be connected, though officials are still investigating, DC Department of Health spokeswoman Jasmine Gossett said.\n\n\"We are monitoring them and are working with the universities and their student health centers, just to inform them and then educate those who may be at risk,\" Gossett said.\n\nAt Catholic, the school has adjusted Communion distribution during Mass to help combat the illness, university spokeswoman Elise Italiano said. \"Normally, we offer Communion through the host and what we call the chalice, or the cup with wine,\" Italiano said. \"And we suspended the 2nd practice . . . because of the possible spread through saliva. So, we've just taken that extra precaution.\"\n\nMumps spreads through saliva or mucus, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Symptoms include fever, headaches, and swollen and tender glands under the ears, the CDC's website notes.\n\nGeorgetown officials asked infected students to cloister themselves for 5 days after the appearance of initial symptoms, a note to the campus from Vince WinklerPrins, assistant vice president for student health, said.\n\n\"We will continue to monitor and support these students,\" WinklerPrins said.\n\nIn an email sent to its campus community, Catholic said residential students who had reported mumps symptoms have been moved to an unoccupied space, in an attempt to limit exposure.\n\n\"Students are able to return to rooms and classes after a 5-day period,\" the email stated.\n\nCatholic's students were also briefed on how someone infected with mumps can spread the virus: by coughing or sharing a drink, for example. They were advised to keep their hands clean and to not share their utensils.\n\nThe University of Virginia [U-Va] has also recently urged students to take precautions after 2 suspected cases were identified. A U-Va spokesman did not immediately return an email seeking an update [Mon 6 Nov 2017].\n\n[Byline: Sarah Larimer]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nAnn Zhang\nUniversity of Rochester\n<ayzhang24@gmail.com>\n\nProMED thanks Ann Zhang for alerting us to these cases.\n\n[Because of the rise in mumps outbreaks observed at US universities since 2006, a federal expert US panel has endorsed a 3rd vaccine dose in such outbreak situations. See http://wapo.st/2yoWDc1 for a report on this decision, as well as ProMED mail Mumps update (31): USA, MMR 3rd dose, Canada 20171027.5407525.\n\nWashington DC can be located on the maps at http://www.mapsofworld.com/usa/ and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/259. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[4] New Zealand (Auckland)\nDate: Mon 6 Nov 2017 1:17 PM NZDT\nSource: NZ Herald, Newstalk ZB [edited]\nhttp://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11940991\n\n\nPublic health service medical officer, Dr Josephine Herman, says NZ has a vulnerable population who have not been fully immunised.\n\nAuckland Regional Public Health Service has been notified of 740 cases of mumps since 1 Jan [2017]. Dr Herman, said this was the worst outbreak since 1994. \"This is quite a large outbreak, and something we're very concerned about, and trying our best to implement public health measures to try to contain,\" Herman said.\n\nShe said Auckland was essentially free of the viral disease even late last year [2016], but the outbreak began after being picked up overseas. Herman said it particularly came from the Pacific Islands -- mostly Fiji, and later Tonga -- where the mumps vaccine was not available.\n\nShe said there have also been \"massive\" outbreaks in the US and the UK, which has spread easily through universities, she said.\n\n\"In terms of where the mumps infection is occurring, it's actually all throughout the world. New Zealand has been immune to it until late last year [2016] and early this year. Because we've had a vulnerable population here who have not been fully immunised with the MMR vaccine, it's allowed community spread to be well established.\n\n\"We are importing mumps, as well as probably exporting it as well.\"\n\nHerman said it was not possible to know if the rates of the disease have peaked.\n\nBut she said if people have not received the MMR vaccine, to do so immediately. Other ways to combat the spread include washing hands, covering coughs and cleaning commonly used items.\n\nHerman says for most adults, it's a mild illness. However, a small proportion can develop complications including meningitis or encephalitis. Young children are more at risk of developing harmful outcomes.\n\n[Byline: Jordan Bond]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This outbreak is a consequence of introduction of mumps into a community with low vaccination coverage. More often, mumps outbreaks are the consequence of waning immunity in young adults. But the Auckland outbreak is a reminder that even with elimination of mumps (and measles) from a country, high immunization levels must be maintained.\n\nMaps of New Zealand can be seen at http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/dc/NZTerritorialAuthorities.png and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/606. - Mod.LK]\nSee Also\nMumps update (31): USA, MMR 3rd dose, Canada According to data from the Ministry of Health, the number of reported cases until now is 3 times higher compared to figures recorded 5 years ago.\n\n\"We've had an important outbreak of mumps this year [2017],\" pointed out Adolfo Zarate, Head of the Epidemiology area of the Ministry of Health, who also mentioned that during this year 2044 cases of mumps have been reported. This is 3 times the figure for 2013, when a similar outbreak took place, but only 776 cases were reported. Mr Zarate explained that this explosive condition is because of the change of season, and also because non-immunized people may gather, so this may generate the high number of cases.\n\nYesterday [31 Oct 2017], La Paz Health Service (SEDES, according to its Spanish initials) reported that the mumps vaccine, which is included within the MRM package (measles, rubella, and mumps) only confers 80 percent protection. The vaccine is administered to children between 12 and 24 months of age, and a booster dose is given when they are 4 years old.\n\nThe most affected departments are La Paz, 1698 cases; Santa Cruz, 221 cases, and Cochabamba. For this reason, Mr Zarate urged the (symptomatic) population to go to health centers in order to have timely therapy.\n\nIn La Paz city, SEDES reported last week that this is an alarming situation, since \"there is an explosive and persistent outbreak\".\n\nMumps is a viral disease that is transmitted from person to person through saliva (droplets). Affected persons most commonly present with the following symptoms: fever, sore throat, parotid gland enlargement (inflammation), and loss of appetite.\n\nMr Zarate also recommended that all affected persons must get rest if they develop symptoms, since male subjects may develop orchitis (testis inflammation) or ovaritis (ovarian inflammation), which may lead -- in a small percentage of cases -- to infertility.\n\nHe also advised that affected persons must use masks; they must also avoid sharing cutlery and dishes, and thoroughly wash their hands. It is also important to disinfect the household using detergents, in order to prevent transmission of the disease to other members of the family.\n\nMr Zarate also recommended that sanitary triage must be established in educational facilities, so that if parents, teachers, or school authorities find a symptomatic student, he/she must be immediately sent home and be isolated for at least 10 days.\n\nThe disease may occur at any age in a non-immunized person, but most commonly affected individuals are those less than 20 years of age.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Bolivia can be seen at http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/americas/bolivia_admin_2006.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/5. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[2] USA (Washington)\nDate: Thu 2 Nov 2017\nSource: iFIBER One News [edited]\nhttp://www.ifiberone.com/columbia_basin/mumps-and-whooping-cough-a-problem-in/youtube_71b3dcd4-c002-11e7-9a61-ff27becf4d65.html\n\n\nGrant County [Washington] saw an extraordinary amount of mumps cases this year [2017] with 45. The mumps outbreak was contained to the Columbia Basin Job Corps and the Ephrata School District. Grant County Health District's Theresa Atkinson says that was a fraction of the 888 cases reported statewide.\n\n\"The mumps outbreak was incredibly large for our area,\" said Adkinson Fortunately, no one currently has mumps in Grant County.\n\nThe same cannot be said about whooping cough with 78 current cases in the county. This year [2017], Moses Lake had 54 cases of pertussis, Ephrata had 22, Soap Lake 2 and both Royal City and Warden had 1.\n\n\"It's the largest pertussis outbreak we've ever experienced,\" said Adkinson.\n\nFor more on how to prevent these illnesses, go to http://granthealth.org.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Washington can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/248. Grant county can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/washington-county-map.gif. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n\n[3] USA (District of Columbia)\nDate: Mon 6 Nov 2017\nSource: Washington Post [edited]\nhttps://www.washingtonpost.com/news/grade-point/wp/2017/11/06/mumps-reported-at-catholic-university-georgetown/\n\n\nMumps, an infectious disease carried on a sneeze or a cup, appears to be spreading among DC [USA, District of Columbia] universities, with cases reported at 3 schools.\n\nThe Catholic University of America recently identified a cluster of illness, with 4 confirmed mumps cases and 3 more suspected cases under investigation, a school spokeswoman said [Mon 6 Nov 2017].\n\nOn [Fri 3 Nov 2017], a message sent to the Georgetown University community said 2 undergraduates had been diagnosed with the disease.\n\nThe cases at Georgetown have been confirmed, according to a letter from the DC Department of Health.\n\nAnd American University has 2 confirmed mumps cases, as well as 4 suspected cases, school spokesman Mark Story said [Mon 6 Nov 2017].\n\nThe mumps cases at DC universities appear to be connected, though officials are still investigating, DC Department of Health spokeswoman Jasmine Gossett said.\n\n\"We are monitoring them and are working with the universities and their student health centers, just to inform them and then educate those who may be at risk,\" Gossett said.\n\nAt Catholic, the school has adjusted Communion distribution during Mass to help combat the illness, university spokeswoman Elise Italiano said. \"Normally, we offer Communion through the host and what we call the chalice, or the cup with wine,\" Italiano said. \"And we suspended the 2nd practice . . . because of the possible spread through saliva. So, we've just taken that extra precaution.\"\n\nMumps spreads through saliva or mucus, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Symptoms include fever, headaches, and swollen and tender glands under the ears, the CDC's website notes.\n\nGeorgetown officials asked infected students to cloister themselves for 5 days after the appearance of initial symptoms, a note to the campus from Vince WinklerPrins, assistant vice president for student health, said.\n\n\"We will continue to monitor and support these students,\" WinklerPrins said.\n\nIn an email sent to its campus community, Catholic said residential students who had reported mumps symptoms have been moved to an unoccupied space, in an attempt to limit exposure.\n\n\"Students are able to return to rooms and classes after a 5-day period,\" the email stated.\n\nCatholic's students were also briefed on how someone infected with mumps can spread the virus: by coughing or sharing a drink, for example. They were advised to keep their hands clean and to not share their utensils.\n\nThe University of Virginia [U-Va] has also recently urged students to take precautions after 2 suspected cases were identified. A U-Va spokesman did not immediately return an email seeking an update [Mon 6 Nov 2017].\n\n[Byline: Sarah Larimer]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nAnn Zhang\nUniversity of Rochester\n<ayzhang24@gmail.com>\n\nProMED thanks Ann Zhang for alerting us to these cases.\n\n[Because of the rise in mumps outbreaks observed at US universities since 2006, a federal expert US panel has endorsed a 3rd vaccine dose in such outbreak situations. See http://wapo.st/2yoWDc1 for a report on this decision, as well as ProMED mail Mumps update (31): USA, MMR 3rd dose, Canada 20171027.5407525.\n\nWashington DC can be located on the maps at http://www.mapsofworld.com/usa/ and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/259. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[4] New Zealand (Auckland)\nDate: Mon 6 Nov 2017 1:17 PM NZDT\nSource: NZ Herald, Newstalk ZB [edited]\nhttp://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11940991\n\n\nPublic health service medical officer, Dr Josephine Herman, says NZ has a vulnerable population who have not been fully immunised.\n\nAuckland Regional Public Health Service has been notified of 740 cases of mumps since 1 Jan [2017]. Dr Herman, said this was the worst outbreak since 1994. \"This is quite a large outbreak, and something we're very concerned about, and trying our best to implement public health measures to try to contain,\" Herman said.\n\nShe said Auckland was essentially free of the viral disease even late last year [2016], but the outbreak began after being picked up overseas. Herman said it particularly came from the Pacific Islands -- mostly Fiji, and later Tonga -- where the mumps vaccine was not available.\n\nShe said there have also been \"massive\" outbreaks in the US and the UK, which has spread easily through universities, she said.\n\n\"In terms of where the mumps infection is occurring, it's actually all throughout the world. New Zealand has been immune to it until late last year [2016] and early this year. Because we've had a vulnerable population here who have not been fully immunised with the MMR vaccine, it's allowed community spread to be well established.\n\n\"We are importing mumps, as well as probably exporting it as well.\"\n\nHerman said it was not possible to know if the rates of the disease have peaked.\n\nBut she said if people have not received the MMR vaccine, to do so immediately. Other ways to combat the spread include washing hands, covering coughs and cleaning commonly used items.\n\nHerman says for most adults, it's a mild illness. However, a small proportion can develop complications including meningitis or encephalitis. Young children are more at risk of developing harmful outcomes.\n\n[Byline: Jordan Bond]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This outbreak is a consequence of introduction of mumps into a community with low vaccination coverage. More often, mumps outbreaks are the consequence of waning immunity in young adults. But the Auckland outbreak is a reminder that even with elimination of mumps (and measles) from a country, high immunization levels must be maintained.\n\nMaps of New Zealand can be seen at 20170324.4922098\nMumps update (11): USA 20170319.4911532\nMumps update (10) 20170314.4900923\nMumps update (09) 20170312.4895943\nMumps update (08): Canada, USA, comment 20170305.4880865\nMumps update (07): Canada, USA 20170303.4875855\nMumps update (06): USA 20170227.4864176\nMumps update (05): USA (PA, MO - RFI), Canada (ON, AB) 20170223.4860461\nMumps update (04): USA (WA), New Zealand 20170211.4830961\nMumps - USA (03): (AR) 20170205.4817357\nMumps - USA (02) 20170129.4801141\nMumps - USA (01): (WA,TX) 20170110.4753366\n.................................................sb/lk/mj/jh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "pertussis", "rubella", "encephalitis", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["2032-03-16 00:00:00", "2044-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "1698-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-01-01 00:00:00", "1994-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Washington DC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NEW ZEALAND", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Fiji", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brazil", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Portugal", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tonga", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NZ", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Malaysia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "La Paz", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Santa Cruz", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SOUTH AMERICA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Royal City", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "DC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bolivia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Grant County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "District of Columbia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5464364", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps update (34): Canada, USA (AK,TX)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5464364", "date": "2017-11-10 11:18:50", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (32): SOUTH AMERICA, USA, NEW ZEALAND\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] South America (Bolivia)\n[2] USA (Washington)\n[3] USA (District of Columbia)\n[4] New Zealand\n\n******\n[1] South America (Bolivia)\nDate: Wed 1 Nov 2017\nSource: Pagina Siete [in Spanish, trans. Mod.JG]\nhttp://www.paginasiete.bo/sociedad/2017/11/1/bolivia-registra-brote-inusitado-paperas-luego-cinco-anos-157841.html\n\n\nThis year [2017] Bolivia is experiencing an unusual outbreak of mumps. According to data from the Ministry of Health, the number of reported cases until now is 3 times higher compared to figures recorded 5 years ago.\n\n\"We've had an important outbreak of mumps this year [2017],\" pointed out Adolfo Zarate, Head of the Epidemiology area of the Ministry of Health, who also mentioned that during this year 2044 cases of mumps have been reported. This is 3 times the figure for 2013, when a similar outbreak took place, but only 776 cases were reported. Mr Zarate explained that this explosive condition is because of the change of season, and also because non-immunized people may gather, so this may generate the high number of cases.\n\nYesterday [31 Oct 2017], La Paz Health Service (SEDES, according to its Spanish initials) reported that the mumps vaccine, which is included within the MRM package (measles, rubella, and mumps) only confers 80 percent protection. The vaccine is administered to children between 12 and 24 months of age, and a booster dose is given when they are 4 years old.\n\nThe most affected departments are La Paz, 1698 cases; Santa Cruz, 221 cases, and Cochabamba. For this reason, Mr Zarate urged the (symptomatic) population to go to health centers in order to have timely therapy.\n\nIn La Paz city, SEDES reported last week that this is an alarming situation, since \"there is an explosive and persistent outbreak\".\n\nMumps is a viral disease that is transmitted from person to person through saliva (droplets). Affected persons most commonly present with the following symptoms: fever, sore throat, parotid gland enlargement (inflammation), and loss of appetite.\n\nMr Zarate also recommended that all affected persons must get rest if they develop symptoms, since male subjects may develop orchitis (testis inflammation) or ovaritis (ovarian inflammation), which may lead -- in a small percentage of cases -- to infertility.\n\nHe also advised that affected persons must use masks; they must also avoid sharing cutlery and dishes, and thoroughly wash their hands. It is also important to disinfect the household using detergents, in order to prevent transmission of the disease to other members of the family.\n\nMr Zarate also recommended that sanitary triage must be established in educational facilities, so that if parents, teachers, or school authorities find a symptomatic student, he/she must be immediately sent home and be isolated for at least 10 days.\n\nThe disease may occur at any age in a non-immunized person, but most commonly affected individuals are those less than 20 years of age.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Bolivia can be seen at http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/americas/bolivia_admin_2006.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/5. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[2] USA (Washington)\nDate: Thu 2 Nov 2017\nSource: iFIBER One News [edited]\nhttp://www.ifiberone.com/columbia_basin/mumps-and-whooping-cough-a-problem-in/youtube_71b3dcd4-c002-11e7-9a61-ff27becf4d65.html\n\n\nGrant County [Washington] saw an extraordinary amount of mumps cases this year [2017] with 45. The mumps outbreak was contained to the Columbia Basin Job Corps and the Ephrata School District. Grant County Health District's Theresa Atkinson says that was a fraction of the 888 cases reported statewide.\n\n\"The mumps outbreak was incredibly large for our area,\" said Adkinson Fortunately, no one currently has mumps in Grant County.\n\nThe same cannot be said about whooping cough with 78 current cases in the county. This year [2017], Moses Lake had 54 cases of pertussis, Ephrata had 22, Soap Lake 2 and both Royal City and Warden had 1.\n\n\"It's the largest pertussis outbreak we've ever experienced,\" said Adkinson.\n\nFor more on how to prevent these illnesses, go to http://granthealth.org.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Washington can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/248. Grant county can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/washington-county-map.gif. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n\n[3] USA (District of Columbia)\nDate: Mon 6 Nov 2017\nSource: Washington Post [edited]\nhttps://www.washingtonpost.com/news/grade-point/wp/2017/11/06/mumps-reported-at-catholic-university-georgetown/\n\n\nMumps, an infectious disease carried on a sneeze or a cup, appears to be spreading among DC [USA, District of Columbia] universities, with cases reported at 3 schools.\n\nThe Catholic University of America recently identified a cluster of illness, with 4 confirmed mumps cases and 3 more suspected cases under investigation, a school spokeswoman said [Mon 6 Nov 2017].\n\nOn [Fri 3 Nov 2017], a message sent to the Georgetown University community said 2 undergraduates had been diagnosed with the disease.\n\nThe cases at Georgetown have been confirmed, according to a letter from the DC Department of Health.\n\nAnd American University has 2 confirmed mumps cases, as well as 4 suspected cases, school spokesman Mark Story said [Mon 6 Nov 2017].\n\nThe mumps cases at DC universities appear to be connected, though officials are still investigating, DC Department of Health spokeswoman Jasmine Gossett said.\n\n\"We are monitoring them and are working with the universities and their student health centers, just to inform them and then educate those who may be at risk,\" Gossett said.\n\nAt Catholic, the school has adjusted Communion distribution during Mass to help combat the illness, university spokeswoman Elise Italiano said. \"Normally, we offer Communion through the host and what we call the chalice, or the cup with wine,\" Italiano said. \"And we suspended the 2nd practice . . . because of the possible spread through saliva. So, we've just taken that extra precaution.\"\n\nMumps spreads through saliva or mucus, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Symptoms include fever, headaches, and swollen and tender glands under the ears, the CDC's website notes.\n\nGeorgetown officials asked infected students to cloister themselves for 5 days after the appearance of initial symptoms, a note to the campus from Vince WinklerPrins, assistant vice president for student health, said.\n\n\"We will continue to monitor and support these students,\" WinklerPrins said.\n\nIn an email sent to its campus community, Catholic said residential students who had reported mumps symptoms have been moved to an unoccupied space, in an attempt to limit exposure.\n\n\"Students are able to return to rooms and classes after a 5-day period,\" the email stated.\n\nCatholic's students were also briefed on how someone infected with mumps can spread the virus: by coughing or sharing a drink, for example. They were advised to keep their hands clean and to not share their utensils.\n\nThe University of Virginia [U-Va] has also recently urged students to take precautions after 2 suspected cases were identified. A U-Va spokesman did not immediately return an email seeking an update [Mon 6 Nov 2017].\n\n[Byline: Sarah Larimer]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nAnn Zhang\nUniversity of Rochester\n<ayzhang24@gmail.com>\n\nProMED thanks Ann Zhang for alerting us to these cases.\n\n[Because of the rise in mumps outbreaks observed at US universities since 2006, a federal expert US panel has endorsed a 3rd vaccine dose in such outbreak situations. See http://wapo.st/2yoWDc1 for a report on this decision, as well as ProMED mail Mumps update (31): USA, MMR 3rd dose, Canada 20171027.5407525.\n\nWashington DC can be located on the maps at http://www.mapsofworld.com/usa/ and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/259. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[4] New Zealand (Auckland)\nDate: Mon 6 Nov 2017 1:17 PM NZDT\nSource: NZ Herald, Newstalk ZB [edited]\nhttp://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11940991\n\n\nPublic health service medical officer, Dr Josephine Herman, says NZ has a vulnerable population who have not been fully immunised.\n\nAuckland Regional Public Health Service has been notified of 740 cases of mumps since 1 Jan [2017]. Dr Herman, said this was the worst outbreak since 1994. \"This is quite a large outbreak, and something we're very concerned about, and trying our best to implement public health measures to try to contain,\" Herman said.\n\nShe said Auckland was essentially free of the viral disease even late last year [2016], but the outbreak began after being picked up overseas. Herman said it particularly came from the Pacific Islands -- mostly Fiji, and later Tonga -- where the mumps vaccine was not available.\n\nShe said there have also been \"massive\" outbreaks in the US and the UK, which has spread easily through universities, she said.\n\n\"In terms of where the mumps infection is occurring, it's actually all throughout the world. New Zealand has been immune to it until late last year [2016] and early this year. Because we've had a vulnerable population here who have not been fully immunised with the MMR vaccine, it's allowed community spread to be well established.\n\n\"We are importing mumps, as well as probably exporting it as well.\"\n\nHerman said it was not possible to know if the rates of the disease have peaked.\n\nBut she said if people have not received the MMR vaccine, to do so immediately. Other ways to combat the spread include washing hands, covering coughs and cleaning commonly used items.\n\nHerman says for most adults, it's a mild illness. However, a small proportion can develop complications including meningitis or encephalitis. Young children are more at risk of developing harmful outcomes.\n\n[Byline: Jordan Bond]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This outbreak is a consequence of introduction of mumps into a community with low vaccination coverage. More often, mumps outbreaks are the consequence of waning immunity in young adults. But the Auckland outbreak is a reminder that even with elimination of mumps (and measles) from a country, high immunization levels must be maintained.\n\nMaps of New Zealand can be seen at http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/dc/NZTerritorialAuthorities.png and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/606. - Mod.LK]\nSee Also\nMumps update (31): USA, MMR 3rd dose, Canada
