According to data from the Ministry of Health, the number of reported cases until now is 3 times higher compared to figures recorded 5 years ago.\n\n\"We've had an important outbreak of mumps this year [2017],\" pointed out Adolfo Zarate, Head of the Epidemiology area of the Ministry of Health, who also mentioned that during this year 2044 cases of mumps have been reported. This is 3 times the figure for 2013, when a similar outbreak took place, but only 776 cases were reported. Mr Zarate explained that this explosive condition is because of the change of season, and also because non-immunized people may gather, so this may generate the high number of cases.\n\nYesterday [31 Oct 2017], La Paz Health Service (SEDES, according to its Spanish initials) reported that the mumps vaccine, which is included within the MRM package (measles, rubella, and mumps) only confers 80 percent protection. The vaccine is administered to children between 12 and 24 months of age, and a booster dose is given when they are 4 years old.\n\nThe most affected departments are La Paz, 1698 cases; Santa Cruz, 221 cases, and Cochabamba. For this reason, Mr Zarate urged the (symptomatic) population to go to health centers in order to have timely therapy.\n\nIn La Paz city, SEDES reported last week that this is an alarming situation, since \"there is an explosive and persistent outbreak\".\n\nMumps is a viral disease that is transmitted from person to person through saliva (droplets). Affected persons most commonly present with the following symptoms: fever, sore throat, parotid gland enlargement (inflammation), and loss of appetite.\n\nMr Zarate also recommended that all affected persons must get rest if they develop symptoms, since male subjects may develop orchitis (testis inflammation) or ovaritis (ovarian inflammation), which may lead -- in a small percentage of cases -- to infertility.\n\nHe also advised that affected persons must use masks; they must also avoid sharing cutlery and dishes, and thoroughly wash their hands. It is also important to disinfect the household using detergents, in order to prevent transmission of the disease to other members of the family.\n\nMr Zarate also recommended that sanitary triage must be established in educational facilities, so that if parents, teachers, or school authorities find a symptomatic student, he/she must be immediately sent home and be isolated for at least 10 days.\n\nThe disease may occur at any age in a non-immunized person, but most commonly affected individuals are those less than 20 years of age.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Bolivia can be seen at http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/americas/bolivia_admin_2006.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/5. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[2] USA (Washington)\nDate: Thu 2 Nov 2017\nSource: iFIBER One News [edited]\nhttp://www.ifiberone.com/columbia_basin/mumps-and-whooping-cough-a-problem-in/youtube_71b3dcd4-c002-11e7-9a61-ff27becf4d65.html\n\n\nGrant County [Washington] saw an extraordinary amount of mumps cases this year [2017] with 45. The mumps outbreak was contained to the Columbia Basin Job Corps and the Ephrata School District. Grant County Health District's Theresa Atkinson says that was a fraction of the 888 cases reported statewide.\n\n\"The mumps outbreak was incredibly large for our area,\" said Adkinson Fortunately, no one currently has mumps in Grant County.\n\nThe same cannot be said about whooping cough with 78 current cases in the county. This year [2017], Moses Lake had 54 cases of pertussis, Ephrata had 22, Soap Lake 2 and both Royal City and Warden had 1.\n\n\"It's the largest pertussis outbreak we've ever experienced,\" said Adkinson.\n\nFor more on how to prevent these illnesses, go to http://granthealth.org.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Washington can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/248. Grant county can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/washington-county-map.gif. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n\n[3] USA (District of Columbia)\nDate: Mon 6 Nov 2017\nSource: Washington Post [edited]\nhttps://www.washingtonpost.com/news/grade-point/wp/2017/11/06/mumps-reported-at-catholic-university-georgetown/\n\n\nMumps, an infectious disease carried on a sneeze or a cup, appears to be spreading among DC [USA, District of Columbia] universities, with cases reported at 3 schools.\n\nThe Catholic University of America recently identified a cluster of illness, with 4 confirmed mumps cases and 3 more suspected cases under investigation, a school spokeswoman said [Mon 6 Nov 2017].\n\nOn [Fri 3 Nov 2017], a message sent to the Georgetown University community said 2 undergraduates had been diagnosed with the disease.\n\nThe cases at Georgetown have been confirmed, according to a letter from the DC Department of Health.\n\nAnd American University has 2 confirmed mumps cases, as well as 4 suspected cases, school spokesman Mark Story said [Mon 6 Nov 2017].\n\nThe mumps cases at DC universities appear to be connected, though officials are still investigating, DC Department of Health spokeswoman Jasmine Gossett said.\n\n\"We are monitoring them and are working with the universities and their student health centers, just to inform them and then educate those who may be at risk,\" Gossett said.\n\nAt Catholic, the school has adjusted Communion distribution during Mass to help combat the illness, university spokeswoman Elise Italiano said. \"Normally, we offer Communion through the host and what we call the chalice, or the cup with wine,\" Italiano said. \"And we suspended the 2nd practice . . . because of the possible spread through saliva. So, we've just taken that extra precaution.\"\n\nMumps spreads through saliva or mucus, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Symptoms include fever, headaches, and swollen and tender glands under the ears, the CDC's website notes.\n\nGeorgetown officials asked infected students to cloister themselves for 5 days after the appearance of initial symptoms, a note to the campus from Vince WinklerPrins, assistant vice president for student health, said.\n\n\"We will continue to monitor and support these students,\" WinklerPrins said.\n\nIn an email sent to its campus community, Catholic said residential students who had reported mumps symptoms have been moved to an unoccupied space, in an attempt to limit exposure.\n\n\"Students are able to return to rooms and classes after a 5-day period,\" the email stated.\n\nCatholic's students were also briefed on how someone infected with mumps can spread the virus: by coughing or sharing a drink, for example. They were advised to keep their hands clean and to not share their utensils.\n\nThe University of Virginia [U-Va] has also recently urged students to take precautions after 2 suspected cases were identified. A U-Va spokesman did not immediately return an email seeking an update [Mon 6 Nov 2017].\n\n[Byline: Sarah Larimer]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nAnn Zhang\nUniversity of Rochester\n<ayzhang24@gmail.com>\n\nProMED thanks Ann Zhang for alerting us to these cases.\n\n[Because of the rise in mumps outbreaks observed at US universities since 2006, a federal expert US panel has endorsed a 3rd vaccine dose in such outbreak situations. See http://wapo.st/2yoWDc1 for a report on this decision, as well as ProMED mail Mumps update (31): USA, MMR 3rd dose, Canada 20171027.5407525.\n\nWashington DC can be located on the maps at http://www.mapsofworld.com/usa/ and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/259. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[4] New Zealand (Auckland)\nDate: Mon 6 Nov 2017 1:17 PM NZDT\nSource: NZ Herald, Newstalk ZB [edited]\nhttp://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11940991\n\n\nPublic health service medical officer, Dr Josephine Herman, says NZ has a vulnerable population who have not been fully immunised.\n\nAuckland Regional Public Health Service has been notified of 740 cases of mumps since 1 Jan [2017]. Dr Herman, said this was the worst outbreak since 1994. \"This is quite a large outbreak, and something we're very concerned about, and trying our best to implement public health measures to try to contain,\" Herman said.\n\nShe said Auckland was essentially free of the viral disease even late last year [2016], but the outbreak began after being picked up overseas. Herman said it particularly came from the Pacific Islands -- mostly Fiji, and later Tonga -- where the mumps vaccine was not available.\n\nShe said there have also been \"massive\" outbreaks in the US and the UK, which has spread easily through universities, she said.\n\n\"In terms of where the mumps infection is occurring, it's actually all throughout the world. New Zealand has been immune to it until late last year [2016] and early this year. Because we've had a vulnerable population here who have not been fully immunised with the MMR vaccine, it's allowed community spread to be well established.\n\n\"We are importing mumps, as well as probably exporting it as well.\"\n\nHerman said it was not possible to know if the rates of the disease have peaked.\n\nBut she said if people have not received the MMR vaccine, to do so immediately. Other ways to combat the spread include washing hands, covering coughs and cleaning commonly used items.\n\nHerman says for most adults, it's a mild illness. However, a small proportion can develop complications including meningitis or encephalitis. Young children are more at risk of developing harmful outcomes.\n\n[Byline: Jordan Bond]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This outbreak is a consequence of introduction of mumps into a community with low vaccination coverage. More often, mumps outbreaks are the consequence of waning immunity in young adults. But the Auckland outbreak is a reminder that even with elimination of mumps (and measles) from a country, high immunization levels must be maintained.\n\nMaps of New Zealand can be seen at "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "pertussis", "rubella", "encephalitis", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["2032-03-16 00:00:00", "2044-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "1698-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-01-01 00:00:00", "1994-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Washington DC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NEW ZEALAND", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Fiji", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brazil", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Portugal", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tonga", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NZ", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Malaysia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "La Paz", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "District of Columbia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5435146", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps update (32): South America, USA, New Zealand", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5435146", "date": "2017-11-10 11:18:50", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (32): SOUTH AMERICA, USA, NEW ZEALAND\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] South America (Bolivia)\n[2] USA (Washington)\n[3] USA (District of Columbia)\n[4] New Zealand\n\n******\n[1] South America (Bolivia)\nDate: Wed 1 Nov 2017\nSource: Pagina Siete [in Spanish, trans. Mod.JG]\nhttp://www.paginasiete.bo/sociedad/2017/11/1/bolivia-registra-brote-inusitado-paperas-luego-cinco-anos-157841.html\n\n\nThis year [2017] Bolivia is experiencing an unusual outbreak of mumps. According to data from the Ministry of Health, the number of reported cases until now is 3 times higher compared to figures recorded 5 years ago.\n\n\"We've had an important outbreak of mumps this year [2017],\" pointed out Adolfo Zarate, Head of the Epidemiology area of the Ministry of Health, who also mentioned that during this year 2044 cases of mumps have been reported. This is 3 times the figure for 2013, when a similar outbreak took place, but only 776 cases were reported. Mr Zarate explained that this explosive condition is because of the change of season, and also because non-immunized people may gather, so this may generate the high number of cases.\n\nYesterday [31 Oct 2017], La Paz Health Service (SEDES, according to its Spanish initials) reported that the mumps vaccine, which is included within the MRM package (measles, rubella, and mumps) only confers 80 percent protection. The vaccine is administered to children between 12 and 24 months of age, and a booster dose is given when they are 4 years old.\n\nThe most affected departments are La Paz, 1698 cases; Santa Cruz, 221 cases, and Cochabamba. For this reason, Mr Zarate urged the (symptomatic) population to go to health centers in order to have timely therapy.\n\nIn La Paz city, SEDES reported last week that this is an alarming situation, since \"there is an explosive and persistent outbreak\".\n\nMumps is a viral disease that is transmitted from person to person through saliva (droplets). Affected persons most commonly present with the following symptoms: fever, sore throat, parotid gland enlargement (inflammation), and loss of appetite.\n\nMr Zarate also recommended that all affected persons must get rest if they develop symptoms, since male subjects may develop orchitis (testis inflammation) or ovaritis (ovarian inflammation), which may lead -- in a small percentage of cases -- to infertility.\n\nHe also advised that affected persons must use masks; they must also avoid sharing cutlery and dishes, and thoroughly wash their hands. It is also important to disinfect the household using detergents, in order to prevent transmission of the disease to other members of the family.\n\nMr Zarate also recommended that sanitary triage must be established in educational facilities, so that if parents, teachers, or school authorities find a symptomatic student, he/she must be immediately sent home and be isolated for at least 10 days.\n\nThe disease may occur at any age in a non-immunized person, but most commonly affected individuals are those less than 20 years of age.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Bolivia can be seen at http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/americas/bolivia_admin_2006.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/5. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[2] USA (Washington)\nDate: Thu 2 Nov 2017\nSource: iFIBER One News [edited]\nhttp://www.ifiberone.com/columbia_basin/mumps-and-whooping-cough-a-problem-in/youtube_71b3dcd4-c002-11e7-9a61-ff27becf4d65.html\n\n\nGrant County [Washington] saw an extraordinary amount of mumps cases this year [2017] with 45. The mumps outbreak was contained to the Columbia Basin Job Corps and the Ephrata School District. Grant County Health District's Theresa Atkinson says that was a fraction of the 888 cases reported statewide.\n\n\"The mumps outbreak was incredibly large for our area,\" said Adkinson Fortunately, no one currently has mumps in Grant County.\n\nThe same cannot be said about whooping cough with 78 current cases in the county. This year [2017], Moses Lake had 54 cases of pertussis, Ephrata had 22, Soap Lake 2 and both Royal City and Warden had 1.\n\n\"It's the largest pertussis outbreak we've ever experienced,\" said Adkinson.\n\nFor more on how to prevent these illnesses, go to http://granthealth.org.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Washington can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/248. Grant county can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/washington-county-map.gif. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n\n[3] USA (District of Columbia)\nDate: Mon 6 Nov 2017\nSource: Washington Post [edited]\nhttps://www.washingtonpost.com/news/grade-point/wp/2017/11/06/mumps-reported-at-catholic-university-georgetown/\n\n\nMumps, an infectious disease carried on a sneeze or a cup, appears to be spreading among DC [USA, District of Columbia] universities, with cases reported at 3 schools.\n\nThe Catholic University of America recently identified a cluster of illness, with 4 confirmed mumps cases and 3 more suspected cases under investigation, a school spokeswoman said [Mon 6 Nov 2017].\n\nOn [Fri 3 Nov 2017], a message sent to the Georgetown University community said 2 undergraduates had been diagnosed with the disease.\n\nThe cases at Georgetown have been confirmed, according to a letter from the DC Department of Health.\n\nAnd American University has 2 confirmed mumps cases, as well as 4 suspected cases, school spokesman Mark Story said [Mon 6 Nov 2017].\n\nThe mumps cases at DC universities appear to be connected, though officials are still investigating, DC Department of Health spokeswoman Jasmine Gossett said.\n\n\"We are monitoring them and are working with the universities and their student health centers, just to inform them and then educate those who may be at risk,\" Gossett said.\n\nAt Catholic, the school has adjusted Communion distribution during Mass to help combat the illness, university spokeswoman Elise Italiano said. \"Normally, we offer Communion through the host and what we call the chalice, or the cup with wine,\" Italiano said. \"And we suspended the 2nd practice . . . because of the possible spread through saliva. So, we've just taken that extra precaution.\"\n\nMumps spreads through saliva or mucus, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Symptoms include fever, headaches, and swollen and tender glands under the ears, the CDC's website notes.\n\nGeorgetown officials asked infected students to cloister themselves for 5 days after the appearance of initial symptoms, a note to the campus from Vince WinklerPrins, assistant vice president for student health, said.\n\n\"We will continue to monitor and support these students,\" WinklerPrins said.\n\nIn an email sent to its campus community, Catholic said residential students who had reported mumps symptoms have been moved to an unoccupied space, in an attempt to limit exposure.\n\n\"Students are able to return to rooms and classes after a 5-day period,\" the email stated.\n\nCatholic's students were also briefed on how someone infected with mumps can spread the virus: by coughing or sharing a drink, for example. They were advised to keep their hands clean and to not share their utensils.\n\nThe University of Virginia [U-Va] has also recently urged students to take precautions after 2 suspected cases were identified. A U-Va spokesman did not immediately return an email seeking an update [Mon 6 Nov 2017].\n\n[Byline: Sarah Larimer]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nAnn Zhang\nUniversity of Rochester\n<ayzhang24@gmail.com>\n\nProMED thanks Ann Zhang for alerting us to these cases.\n\n[Because of the rise in mumps outbreaks observed at US universities since 2006, a federal expert US panel has endorsed a 3rd vaccine dose in such outbreak situations. See http://wapo.st/2yoWDc1 for a report on this decision, as well as ProMED mail Mumps update (31): USA, MMR 3rd dose, Canada 20171027.5407525.\n\nWashington DC can be located on the maps at http://www.mapsofworld.com/usa/ and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/259. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[4] New Zealand (Auckland)\nDate: Mon 6 Nov 2017 1:17 PM NZDT\nSource: NZ Herald, Newstalk ZB [edited]\nhttp://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11940991\n\n\nPublic health service medical officer, Dr Josephine Herman, says NZ has a vulnerable population who have not been fully immunised.\n\nAuckland Regional Public Health Service has been notified of 740 cases of mumps since 1 Jan [2017]. Dr Herman, said this was the worst outbreak since 1994. \"This is quite a large outbreak, and something we're very concerned about, and trying our best to implement public health measures to try to contain,\" Herman said.\n\nShe said Auckland was essentially free of the viral disease even late last year [2016], but the outbreak began after being picked up overseas. Herman said it particularly came from the Pacific Islands -- mostly Fiji, and later Tonga -- where the mumps vaccine was not available.\n\nShe said there have also been \"massive\" outbreaks in the US and the UK, which has spread easily through universities, she said.\n\n\"In terms of where the mumps infection is occurring, it's actually all throughout the world. New Zealand has been immune to it until late last year [2016] and early this year. Because we've had a vulnerable population here who have not been fully immunised with the MMR vaccine, it's allowed community spread to be well established.\n\n\"We are importing mumps, as well as probably exporting it as well.\"\n\nHerman said it was not possible to know if the rates of the disease have peaked.\n\nBut she said if people have not received the MMR vaccine, to do so immediately. Other ways to combat the spread include washing hands, covering coughs and cleaning commonly used items.\n\nHerman says for most adults, it's a mild illness. However, a small proportion can develop complications including meningitis or encephalitis. Young children are more at risk of developing harmful outcomes.\n\n[Byline: Jordan Bond]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This outbreak is a consequence of introduction of mumps into a community with low vaccination coverage. More often, mumps outbreaks are the consequence of waning immunity in young adults. But the Auckland outbreak is a reminder that even with elimination of mumps (and measles) from a country, high immunization levels must be maintained.\n\nMaps of New Zealand can be seen at http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/dc/NZTerritorialAuthorities.png and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/606. - Mod.LK]\nSee Also\nMumps update (31): USA, MMR 3rd dose, Canada "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "pertussis", "rubella", "encephalitis", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["2032-03-16 00:00:00", "2044-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "1698-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-01-01 00:00:00", "1994-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Washington DC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NEW ZEALAND", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Fiji", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brazil", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Portugal", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tonga", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "unknown"}, {"location": "District of Columbia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5407525", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps update (31): USA, MMR 3rd dose, Canada", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5407525", "date": "2017-08-20 09:44:05", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (24): AUSTRALIA (QUEENSLAND), NEW ZEALAND (OTAGO,) BRAZIL (AMAZONAS)\n*********************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Australia (Cairns, Queensland)\n[2] New Zealand (Dunedin, Otago)\n[3] Brazil (Manaus, Amazonas)\n\n******\n[1] Australia (Cairns, Queensland)\nDate: Fri 11 Aug 2017 9:00 PM AEST\nSource: The Cairns Post [edited]\nhttps://tinyurl.com/y9nepfk5\n\n\nFar North Queenslanders have been urged to vaccinate their children following a spike in mumps cases in Cairns. There have been 14 cases of the highly infectious disease identified by Queensland Health since [24 Jul 2017], compared to the yearly average of only one case in the Cairns and Hinterland health district.\n\nTropical Public Health director Dr Steven Donohue said the mumps outbreak had spilled over to Cairns from northwest Queensland and the Northern Territory's Top End.\n\n\"Outbreaks of mumps mainly occur because of low vaccination rates, missed doses in the past, waning immunity, or pressure of infection in overcrowded households,\" he said.\n\nHe said the viral illness was spread just like influenza, by coughing or sneezing near other people and through unwashed hands.\n\n\"Symptoms may occur around 2 weeks after exposure if the person is not immune,\" he said. \"The illness usually lasts between 5-9 days.\n\n\"One person in 3 who contracts mumps does not have any symptoms and doesn't realise they are sick, but they may still be contagious and infect may other people.\"\n\nNorthern Queensland Primary Health Network chief executive Robin Moore said immunisation was a simple, safe and highly effective way to protect children and adults from preventable diseases like mumps.\n\n\"This year's [2017] increase in the number of mumps cases in the Cairns region is a timely reminder to parents that immunisation is the best protection against preventable diseases such as these.\n\n\"We urge all members of the community to be fully vaccinated.\" ...\n\nThe disease is uncommon in developed countries, including Australia, because of the widespread use of the measles, mumps, rubella (MMR) vaccine.\n\nThis is given to children at 12 and 18 months, but free catch-up doses are available to anyone born after 1965 who may not have 2 recorded doses.\n\nOutbreaks of mumps mainly occur because of low vaccination rates, missed doses in the past, waning immunity, or pressure of infection in overcrowded households.\n\n[Byline: Daniel Bateman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Australia can be seen at http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/oceania/australia-political-map.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/2954. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n\n******\n[2] New Zealand (Dunedin, Otago)\nDate: Thu 17 Aug 2017 19:45 NZST\nSource: Stuff [edited]\nhttp://tinyurl.com/y7a56fv5\n\n\nUniversity of Otago students are being offered free booster shots after about 10 confirmed or suspected cases were reported in Dunedin [Otago, South Island].\n\nThree young people in Marlborough have contracted the contagious illness, with at least 1 case linked to an Auckland outbreak, while 2 have been confirmed in Nelson.\n\nNationally, an unusually high number of cases were reported from September 2016 to early 2017, and the Ministry of Health warned of \"an increased risk of further outbreaks\".\n\nAuckland reported 51 cases of mumps in the past month -- most aged 10 to 19 -- while several were recorded in Waikato earlier this year [2017].\n\nThe Auckland Regional Public Health Service said last month [July 2017] it was concerned not enough people were immunised in the face of the mumps outbreak.\n\nThe MMR vaccine is usually given in 2 doses, one at 15 months old and one at 4 years old.\n\nMost people recover from mumps, but it can have serious complications. The disease can cause inflammation of tissue surrounding the brain (meningitis), inflamed testicles or ovaries and deafness.\n\nMen hospitalised from the Auckland outbreak had pain and swelling in their testicles, known as orchitis, which in rare cases may lead to infertility.\n\nThe outbreak in Dunedin has prompted the Otago tertiary institution's student health team to offer free measles, mumps and rubella (MMR) booster shots to students who have not had two MMR vaccinations since 1990, or are unsure of their vaccination history.\n\nPro-vice-chancellor of health sciences Professor Peter Crampton, the convener of the university's pandemic planning group, said the group was \"determining our ongoing response as the situation develops.\"\n\nThe outbreak coincided with a large-scale boil water notice issued for parts of Dunedin, including the student quarter, after untreated water got into part of the town's drinking water supply on [Mon 14 Aug 2017].\n\nAll students and staff had been sent information about mumps. Information had been posted on social media.\n\nMarlborough medical officer of health Dr Andrew Lindsay said mumps is \"highly contagious\". It spreads through the air by breathing, coughing and sneezing, or through contact with infected saliva; by kissing or sharing food and drink. It usually takes 12-25 days before symptoms appear -- including pain in the jaw, fever, headache, and swollen glands around the face and body. People with mumps re infectious for 7 days before swelling starts and for 5 days after they cease.\n\nPersonal hygiene is essential to avoid catching mumps, including frequent hand washing, stopping coughs and sneezes in tissues, keeping at least 1 metre [3 ft] away from others and ensuring kitchens and bathrooms are clean.\n\nDr Jill Sherwood, public health physician with the ESR (the Institute of Environmental Science and Research), earlier said the MMR vaccine was not as effective in mumps as it was in measles and rubella. \"The mumps component is only about 85 per cent effective, whereas the measles component will most likely give you lifetime coverage,\" Sherwood said.\n\nThere have been no reported cases of mumps in Canterbury, a health board spokeswoman said.\n\n[Byline: Hamish Mcneilly, Jennifer Eder]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of New Zealand can be seen at http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/oceania/political-map-of-New-Zealan.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/738. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[3] Brazil (Manaus, Amazonas)\nDate: Fri 18 Aug 2017\nSource: Em Tempo [in Portuguese, trans. & summ., edited]\nhttp://www.emtempo.com.br/manaus-tem-surto-de-caxumba-com-230-casos/\n\n\nWith 230 cases of mumps in Manaus [Amazonas state] in 19 places, registered since April 2017, mainly in schools, the Municipal Health Department (Semsa) warns parents to keep the updated immunization booklet for children and adolescents.\n\nUp to 2016, there were no official mumps outbreak records in Manaus. In 2017, as of 18 Aug, there have been 230 cases reported from 19 localities, most of them in schools, which suggests low vaccination coverage in children and adolescents. The 1st outbreak was reported in April 2017 and the occurrence of cases is continuing until the month of August, according to the municipal health secretary. ...\n\n[Byline: Isac Sharlon]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nEmerson Capistrano\nEpidemiological Surveillance\nBoa Vista Health Service\nRoraima, Brazil\n<emerson.capistrano@gmail.com>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Emerson Capistrano for submitting this report. - Mod.LK\n\nMaps of Brazil can be seen at http://s13.postimg.org/jumnalk87/map_of_Brazil.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/10254. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\nMumps "event_date": ["2021-03-24 00:00:00", "1965-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-09-16 00:00:00", "2017-07-16 00:00:00", "1990-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-04-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-04-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2033-03-16 00:00:00", "2032-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00", "2021-03-28 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 {"archive_id": "5396070", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps update (30): USA, New Zealand", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5396070", "date": "2017-08-20 09:44:05", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (24): AUSTRALIA (QUEENSLAND), NEW ZEALAND (OTAGO,) BRAZIL (AMAZONAS)\n*********************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Australia (Cairns, Queensland)\n[2] New Zealand (Dunedin, Otago)\n[3] Brazil (Manaus, Amazonas)\n\n******\n[1] Australia (Cairns, Queensland)\nDate: Fri 11 Aug 2017 9:00 PM AEST\nSource: The Cairns Post [edited]\nhttps://tinyurl.com/y9nepfk5\n\n\nFar North Queenslanders have been urged to vaccinate their children following a spike in mumps cases in Cairns. There have been 14 cases of the highly infectious disease identified by Queensland Health since [24 Jul 2017], compared to the yearly average of only one case in the Cairns and Hinterland health district.\n\nTropical Public Health director Dr Steven Donohue said the mumps outbreak had spilled over to Cairns from northwest Queensland and the Northern Territory's Top End.\n\n\"Outbreaks of mumps mainly occur because of low vaccination rates, missed doses in the past, waning immunity, or pressure of infection in overcrowded households,\" he said.\n\nHe said the viral illness was spread just like influenza, by coughing or sneezing near other people and through unwashed hands.\n\n\"Symptoms may occur around 2 weeks after exposure if the person is not immune,\" he said. \"The illness usually lasts between 5-9 days.\n\n\"One person in 3 who contracts mumps does not have any symptoms and doesn't realise they are sick, but they may still be contagious and infect may other people.\"\n\nNorthern Queensland Primary Health Network chief executive Robin Moore said immunisation was a simple, safe and highly effective way to protect children and adults from preventable diseases like mumps.\n\n\"This year's [2017] increase in the number of mumps cases in the Cairns region is a timely reminder to parents that immunisation is the best protection against preventable diseases such as these.\n\n\"We urge all members of the community to be fully vaccinated.\" ...\n\nThe disease is uncommon in developed countries, including Australia, because of the widespread use of the measles, mumps, rubella (MMR) vaccine.\n\nThis is given to children at 12 and 18 months, but free catch-up doses are available to anyone born after 1965 who may not have 2 recorded doses.\n\nOutbreaks of mumps mainly occur because of low vaccination rates, missed doses in the past, waning immunity, or pressure of infection in overcrowded households.\n\n[Byline: Daniel Bateman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Australia can be seen at http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/oceania/australia-political-map.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/2954. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n\n******\n[2] New Zealand (Dunedin, Otago)\nDate: Thu 17 Aug 2017 19:45 NZST\nSource: Stuff [edited]\nhttp://tinyurl.com/y7a56fv5\n\n\nUniversity of Otago students are being offered free booster shots after about 10 confirmed or suspected cases were reported in Dunedin [Otago, South Island].\n\nThree young people in Marlborough have contracted the contagious illness, with at least 1 case linked to an Auckland outbreak, while 2 have been confirmed in Nelson.\n\nNationally, an unusually high number of cases were reported from September 2016 to early 2017, and the Ministry of Health warned of \"an increased risk of further outbreaks\".\n\nAuckland reported 51 cases of mumps in the past month -- most aged 10 to 19 -- while several were recorded in Waikato earlier this year [2017].\n\nThe Auckland Regional Public Health Service said last month [July 2017] it was concerned not enough people were immunised in the face of the mumps outbreak.\n\nThe MMR vaccine is usually given in 2 doses, one at 15 months old and one at 4 years old.\n\nMost people recover from mumps, but it can have serious complications. The disease can cause inflammation of tissue surrounding the brain (meningitis), inflamed testicles or ovaries and deafness.\n\nMen hospitalised from the Auckland outbreak had pain and swelling in their testicles, known as orchitis, which in rare cases may lead to infertility.\n\nThe outbreak in Dunedin has prompted the Otago tertiary institution's student health team to offer free measles, mumps and rubella (MMR) booster shots to students who have not had two MMR vaccinations since 1990, or are unsure of their vaccination history.\n\nPro-vice-chancellor of health sciences Professor Peter Crampton, the convener of the university's pandemic planning group, said the group was \"determining our ongoing response as the situation develops.\"\n\nThe outbreak coincided with a large-scale boil water notice issued for parts of Dunedin, including the student quarter, after untreated water got into part of the town's drinking water supply on [Mon 14 Aug 2017].\n\nAll students and staff had been sent information about mumps. Information had been posted on social media.\n\nMarlborough medical officer of health Dr Andrew Lindsay said mumps is \"highly contagious\". It spreads through the air by breathing, coughing and sneezing, or through contact with infected saliva; by kissing or sharing food and drink. It usually takes 12-25 days before symptoms appear -- including pain in the jaw, fever, headache, and swollen glands around the face and body. People with mumps re infectious for 7 days before swelling starts and for 5 days after they cease.\n\nPersonal hygiene is essential to avoid catching mumps, including frequent hand washing, stopping coughs and sneezes in tissues, keeping at least 1 metre [3 ft] away from others and ensuring kitchens and bathrooms are clean.\n\nDr Jill Sherwood, public health physician with the ESR (the Institute of Environmental Science and Research), earlier said the MMR vaccine was not as effective in mumps as it was in measles and rubella. \"The mumps component is only about 85 per cent effective, whereas the measles component will most likely give you lifetime coverage,\" Sherwood said.\n\nThere have been no reported cases of mumps in Canterbury, a health board spokeswoman said.\n\n[Byline: Hamish Mcneilly, Jennifer Eder]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of New Zealand can be seen at http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/oceania/political-map-of-New-Zealan.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/738. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[3] Brazil (Manaus, Amazonas)\nDate: Fri 18 Aug 2017\nSource: Em Tempo [in Portuguese, trans. & summ., edited]\nhttp://www.emtempo.com.br/manaus-tem-surto-de-caxumba-com-230-casos/\n\n\nWith 230 cases of mumps in Manaus [Amazonas state] in 19 places, registered since April 2017, mainly in schools, the Municipal Health Department (Semsa) warns parents to keep the updated immunization booklet for children and adolescents.\n\nUp to 2016, there were no official mumps outbreak records in Manaus. In 2017, as of 18 Aug, there have been 230 cases reported from 19 localities, most of them in schools, which suggests low vaccination coverage in children and adolescents. The 1st outbreak was reported in April 2017 and the occurrence of cases is continuing until the month of August, according to the municipal health secretary. ...\n\n[Byline: Isac Sharlon]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nEmerson Capistrano\nEpidemiological Surveillance\nBoa Vista Health Service\nRoraima, Brazil\n<emerson.capistrano@gmail.com>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Emerson Capistrano for submitting this report. - Mod.LK\n\nMaps of Brazil can be seen at http://s13.postimg.org/jumnalk87/map_of_Brazil.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/10254. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\nMumps Queensland)\n[2] New Zealand (Dunedin, Otago)\n[3] Brazil (Manaus, Amazonas)\n\n******\n[1] Australia (Cairns, Queensland)\nDate: Fri 11 Aug 2017 9:00 PM AEST\nSource: The Cairns Post [edited]\nhttps://tinyurl.com/y9nepfk5\n\n\nFar North Queenslanders have been urged to vaccinate their children following a spike in mumps cases in Cairns. There have been 14 cases of the highly infectious disease identified by Queensland Health since [24 Jul 2017], compared to the yearly average of only one case in the Cairns and Hinterland health district.\n\nTropical Public Health director Dr Steven Donohue said the mumps outbreak had spilled over to Cairns from northwest Queensland and the Northern Territory's Top End.\n\n\"Outbreaks of mumps mainly occur because of low vaccination rates, missed doses in the past, waning immunity, or pressure of infection in overcrowded households,\" he said.\n\nHe said the viral illness was spread just like influenza, by coughing or sneezing near other people and through unwashed hands.\n\n\"Symptoms may occur around 2 weeks after exposure if the person is not immune,\" he said. \"The illness usually lasts between 5-9 days.\n\n\"One person in 3 who contracts mumps does not have any symptoms and doesn't realise they are sick, but they may still be contagious and infect may other people.\"\n\nNorthern Queensland Primary Health Network chief executive Robin Moore said immunisation was a simple, safe and highly effective way to protect children and adults from preventable diseases like mumps.\n\n\"This year's [2017] increase in the number of mumps cases in the Cairns region is a timely reminder to parents that immunisation is the best protection against preventable diseases such as these.\n\n\"We urge all members of the community to be fully vaccinated.\" ...\n\nThe disease is uncommon in developed countries, including Australia, because of the widespread use of the measles, mumps, rubella (MMR) vaccine.\n\nThis is given to children at 12 and 18 months, but free catch-up doses are available to anyone born after 1965 who may not have 2 recorded doses.\n\nOutbreaks of mumps mainly occur because of low vaccination rates, missed doses in the past, waning immunity, or pressure of infection in overcrowded households.\n\n[Byline: Daniel Bateman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Australia can be seen at http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/oceania/australia-political-map.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/2954. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n\n******\n[2] New Zealand (Dunedin, Otago)\nDate: Thu 17 Aug 2017 19:45 NZST\nSource: Stuff [edited]\nhttp://tinyurl.com/y7a56fv5\n\n\nUniversity of Otago students are being offered free booster shots after about 10 confirmed or suspected cases were reported in Dunedin [Otago, South Island].\n\nThree young people in Marlborough have contracted the contagious illness, with at least 1 case linked to an Auckland outbreak, while 2 have been confirmed in Nelson.\n\nNationally, an unusually high number of cases were reported from September 2016 to early 2017, and the Ministry of Health warned of \"an increased risk of further outbreaks\".\n\nAuckland reported 51 cases of mumps in the past month -- most aged 10 to 19 -- while several were recorded in Waikato earlier this year [2017].\n\nThe Auckland Regional Public Health Service said last month [July 2017] it was concerned not enough people were immunised in the face of the mumps outbreak.\n\nThe MMR vaccine is usually given in 2 doses, one at 15 months old and one at 4 years old.\n\nMost people recover from mumps, but it can have serious complications. The disease can cause inflammation of tissue surrounding the brain (meningitis), inflamed testicles or ovaries and deafness.\n\nMen hospitalised from the Auckland outbreak had pain and swelling in their testicles, known as orchitis, which in rare cases may lead to infertility.\n\nThe outbreak in Dunedin has prompted the Otago tertiary institution's student health team to offer free measles, mumps and rubella (MMR) booster shots to students who have not had two MMR vaccinations since 1990, or are unsure of their vaccination history.\n\nPro-vice-chancellor of health sciences Professor Peter Crampton, the convener of the university's pandemic planning group, said the group was \"determining our ongoing response as the situation develops.\"\n\nThe outbreak coincided with a large-scale boil water notice issued for parts of Dunedin, including the student quarter, after untreated water got into part of the town's drinking water supply on [Mon 14 Aug 2017].\n\nAll students and staff had been sent information about mumps. Information had been posted on social media.\n\nMarlborough medical officer of health Dr Andrew Lindsay said mumps is \"highly contagious\". It spreads through the air by breathing, coughing and sneezing, or through contact with infected saliva; by kissing or sharing food and drink. It usually takes 12-25 days before symptoms appear -- including pain in the jaw, fever, headache, and swollen glands around the face and body. People with mumps re infectious for 7 days before swelling starts and for 5 days after they cease.\n\nPersonal hygiene is essential to avoid catching mumps, including frequent hand washing, stopping coughs and sneezes in tissues, keeping at least 1 metre [3 ft] away from others and ensuring kitchens and bathrooms are clean.\n\nDr Jill Sherwood, public health physician with the ESR (the Institute of Environmental Science and Research), earlier said the MMR vaccine was not as effective in mumps as it was in measles and rubella. \"The mumps component is only about 85 per cent effective, whereas the measles component will most likely give you lifetime coverage,\" Sherwood said.\n\nThere have been no reported cases of mumps in Canterbury, a health board spokeswoman said.\n\n[Byline: Hamish Mcneilly, Jennifer Eder]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of New Zealand can be seen at http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/oceania/political-map-of-New-Zealan.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/738. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[3] Brazil (Manaus, Amazonas)\nDate: Fri 18 Aug 2017\nSource: Em Tempo [in Portuguese, trans. & summ., edited]\nhttp://www.emtempo.com.br/manaus-tem-surto-de-caxumba-com-230-casos/\n\n\nWith 230 cases of mumps in Manaus [Amazonas state] in 19 places, registered since April 2017, mainly in schools, the Municipal Health Department (Semsa) warns parents to keep the updated immunization booklet for children and adolescents.\n\nUp to 2016, there were no official mumps outbreak records in Manaus. In 2017, as of 18 Aug, there have been 230 cases reported from 19 localities, most of them in schools, which suggests low vaccination coverage in children and adolescents. The 1st outbreak was reported in April 2017 and the occurrence of cases is continuing until the month of August, according to the municipal health secretary. ...\n\n[Byline: Isac "event_date": ["2021-03-24 00:00:00", "1965-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-09-16 00:00:00", "2017-07-16 00:00:00", "1990-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-04-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-04-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2033-03-16 00:00:00", "2032-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00", "2021-03-28 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 {"archive_id": "5352710", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps update (28): Canada, USA", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5352710", "date": "2017-08-20 09:44:05", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (24): AUSTRALIA (QUEENSLAND), NEW ZEALAND (OTAGO,) BRAZIL (AMAZONAS)\n*********************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Australia (Cairns, Queensland)\n[2] New Zealand (Dunedin, Otago)\n[3] Brazil (Manaus, Amazonas)\n\n******\n[1] Australia (Cairns, Queensland)\nDate: Fri 11 Aug 2017 9:00 PM AEST\nSource: The Cairns Post [edited]\nhttps://tinyurl.com/y9nepfk5\n\n\nFar North Queenslanders have been urged to vaccinate their children following a spike in mumps cases in Cairns. There have been 14 cases of the highly infectious disease identified by Queensland Health since [24 Jul 2017], compared to the yearly average of only one case in the Cairns and Hinterland health district.\n\nTropical Public Health director Dr Steven Donohue said the mumps outbreak had spilled over to Cairns from northwest Queensland and the Northern Territory's Top End.\n\n\"Outbreaks of mumps mainly occur because of low vaccination rates, missed doses in the past, waning immunity, or pressure of infection in overcrowded households,\" he said.\n\nHe said the viral illness was spread just like influenza, by coughing or sneezing near other people and through unwashed hands.\n\n\"Symptoms may occur around 2 weeks after exposure if the person is not immune,\" he said. \"The illness usually lasts between 5-9 days.\n\n\"One person in 3 who contracts mumps does not have any symptoms and doesn't realise they are sick, but they may still be contagious and infect may other people.\"\n\nNorthern Queensland Primary Health Network chief executive Robin Moore said immunisation was a simple, safe and highly effective way to protect children and adults from preventable diseases like mumps.\n\n\"This year's [2017] increase in the number of mumps cases in the Cairns region is a timely reminder to parents that immunisation is the best protection against preventable diseases such as these.\n\n\"We urge all members of the community to be fully vaccinated.\" ...\n\nThe disease is uncommon in developed countries, including Australia, because of the widespread use of the measles, mumps, rubella (MMR) vaccine.\n\nThis is given to children at 12 and 18 months, but free catch-up doses are available to anyone born after 1965 who may not have 2 recorded doses.\n\nOutbreaks of mumps mainly occur because of low vaccination rates, missed doses in the past, waning immunity, or pressure of infection in overcrowded households.\n\n[Byline: Daniel Bateman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Australia can be seen at http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/oceania/australia-political-map.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/2954. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n\n******\n[2] New Zealand (Dunedin, Otago)\nDate: Thu 17 Aug 2017 19:45 NZST\nSource: Stuff [edited]\nhttp://tinyurl.com/y7a56fv5\n\n\nUniversity of Otago students are being offered free booster shots after about 10 confirmed or suspected cases were reported in Dunedin [Otago, South Island].\n\nThree young people in Marlborough have contracted the contagious illness, with at least 1 case linked to an Auckland outbreak, while 2 have been confirmed in Nelson.\n\nNationally, an unusually high number of cases were reported from September 2016 to early 2017, and the Ministry of Health warned of \"an increased risk of further outbreaks\".\n\nAuckland reported 51 cases of mumps in the past month -- most aged 10 to 19 -- while several were recorded in Waikato earlier this year [2017].\n\nThe Auckland Regional Public Health Service said last month [July 2017] it was concerned not enough people were immunised in the face of the mumps outbreak.\n\nThe MMR vaccine is usually given in 2 doses, one at 15 months old and one at 4 years old.\n\nMost people recover from mumps, but it can have serious complications. The disease can cause inflammation of tissue surrounding the brain (meningitis), inflamed testicles or ovaries and deafness.\n\nMen hospitalised from the Auckland outbreak had pain and swelling in their testicles, known as orchitis, which in rare cases may lead to infertility.\n\nThe outbreak in Dunedin has prompted the Otago tertiary institution's student health team to offer free measles, mumps and rubella (MMR) booster shots to students who have not had two MMR vaccinations since 1990, or are unsure of their vaccination history.\n\nPro-vice-chancellor of health sciences Professor Peter Crampton, the convener of the university's pandemic planning group, said the group was \"determining our ongoing response as the situation develops.\"\n\nThe outbreak coincided with a large-scale boil water notice issued for parts of Dunedin, including the student quarter, after untreated water got into part of the town's drinking water supply on [Mon 14 Aug 2017].\n\nAll students and staff had been sent information about mumps. Information had been posted on social media.\n\nMarlborough medical officer of health Dr Andrew Lindsay said mumps is \"highly contagious\". It spreads through the air by breathing, coughing and sneezing, or through contact with infected saliva; by kissing or sharing food and drink. It usually takes 12-25 days before symptoms appear -- including pain in the jaw, fever, headache, and swollen glands around the face and body. People with mumps re infectious for 7 days before swelling starts and for 5 days after they cease.\n\nPersonal hygiene is essential to avoid catching mumps, including frequent hand washing, stopping coughs and sneezes in tissues, keeping at least 1 metre [3 ft] away from others and ensuring kitchens and bathrooms are clean.\n\nDr Jill Sherwood, public health physician with the ESR (the Institute of Environmental Science and Research), earlier said the MMR vaccine was not as effective in mumps as it was in measles and rubella. \"The mumps component is only about 85 per cent effective, whereas the measles component will most likely give you lifetime coverage,\" Sherwood said.\n\nThere have been no reported cases of mumps in Canterbury, a health board spokeswoman said.\n\n[Byline: Hamish Mcneilly, Jennifer Eder]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of New Zealand can be seen at http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/oceania/political-map-of-New-Zealan.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/738. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[3] Brazil (Manaus, Amazonas)\nDate: Fri 18 Aug 2017\nSource: Em Tempo [in Portuguese, trans. & summ., edited]\nhttp://www.emtempo.com.br/manaus-tem-surto-de-caxumba-com-230-casos/\n\n\nWith 230 cases of mumps in Manaus [Amazonas state] in 19 places, registered since April 2017, mainly in schools, the Municipal Health Department (Semsa) warns parents to keep the updated immunization booklet for children and adolescents.\n\nUp to 2016, there were no official mumps outbreak records in Manaus. In 2017, as of 18 Aug, there have been 230 cases reported from 19 localities, most of them in schools, which suggests low vaccination coverage in children and adolescents. The 1st outbreak was reported in April 2017 and the occurrence of cases is continuing until the month of August, according to the municipal health secretary. ...\n\n[Byline: Isac Sharlon]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nEmerson Capistrano\nEpidemiological Surveillance\nBoa Vista Health Service\nRoraima, Brazil\n<emerson.capistrano@gmail.com>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Emerson Capistrano for submitting this report. - Mod.LK\n\nMaps of Brazil can be seen at http://s13.postimg.org/jumnalk87/map_of_Brazil.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/10254. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\nMumps {"archive_id": "5340444", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps update (27): Pacific (New Zealand), USA (HI, AK)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5340444", "date": "2017-08-20 09:44:05", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (24): AUSTRALIA (QUEENSLAND), NEW ZEALAND (OTAGO,) BRAZIL (AMAZONAS)\n*********************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Australia (Cairns, Queensland)\n[2] New Zealand (Dunedin, Otago)\n[3] Brazil (Manaus, Amazonas)\n\n******\n[1] Australia (Cairns, Queensland)\nDate: Fri 11 Aug 2017 9:00 PM AEST\nSource: The Cairns Post [edited]\nhttps://tinyurl.com/y9nepfk5\n\n\nFar North Queenslanders have been urged to vaccinate their children following a spike in mumps cases in Cairns. There have been 14 cases of the highly infectious disease identified by Queensland Health since [24 Jul 2017], compared to the yearly average of only one case in the Cairns and Hinterland health district.\n\nTropical Public Health director Dr Steven Donohue said the mumps outbreak had spilled over to Cairns from northwest Queensland and the Northern Territory's Top End.\n\n\"Outbreaks of mumps mainly occur because of low vaccination rates, missed doses in the past, waning immunity, or pressure of infection in overcrowded households,\" he said.\n\nHe said the viral illness was spread just like influenza, by coughing or sneezing near other people and through unwashed hands.\n\n\"Symptoms may occur around 2 weeks after exposure if the person is not immune,\" he said. \"The illness usually lasts between 5-9 days.\n\n\"One person in 3 who contracts mumps does not have any symptoms and doesn't realise they are sick, but they may still be contagious and infect may other people.\"\n\nNorthern Queensland Primary Health Network chief executive Robin Moore said immunisation was a simple, safe and highly effective way to protect children and adults from preventable diseases like mumps.\n\n\"This year's [2017] increase in the number of mumps cases in the Cairns region is a timely reminder to parents that immunisation is the best protection against preventable diseases such as these.\n\n\"We urge all members of the community to be fully vaccinated.\" ...\n\nThe disease is uncommon in developed countries, including Australia, because of the widespread use of the measles, mumps, rubella (MMR) vaccine.\n\nThis is given to children at 12 and 18 months, but free catch-up doses are available to anyone born after 1965 who may not have 2 recorded doses.\n\nOutbreaks of mumps mainly occur because of low vaccination rates, missed doses in the past, waning immunity, or pressure of infection in overcrowded households.\n\n[Byline: Daniel Bateman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Australia can be seen at http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/oceania/australia-political-map.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/2954. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n\n******\n[2] New Zealand (Dunedin, Otago)\nDate: Thu 17 Aug 2017 19:45 NZST\nSource: Stuff [edited]\nhttp://tinyurl.com/y7a56fv5\n\n\nUniversity of Otago students are being offered free booster shots after about 10 confirmed or suspected cases were reported in Dunedin [Otago, South Island].\n\nThree young people in Marlborough have contracted the contagious illness, with at least 1 case linked to an Auckland outbreak, while 2 have been confirmed in Nelson.\n\nNationally, an unusually high number of cases were reported from September 2016 to early 2017, and the Ministry of Health warned of \"an increased risk of further outbreaks\".\n\nAuckland reported 51 cases of mumps in the past month -- most aged 10 to 19 -- while several were recorded in Waikato earlier this year [2017].\n\nThe Auckland Regional Public Health Service said last month [July 2017] it was concerned not enough people were immunised in the face of the mumps outbreak.\n\nThe MMR vaccine is usually given in 2 doses, one at 15 months old and one at 4 years old.\n\nMost people recover from mumps, but it can have serious complications. The disease can cause inflammation of tissue surrounding the brain (meningitis), inflamed testicles or ovaries and deafness.\n\nMen hospitalised from the Auckland outbreak had pain and swelling in their testicles, known as orchitis, which in rare cases may lead to infertility.\n\nThe outbreak in Dunedin has prompted the Otago tertiary institution's student health team to offer free measles, mumps and rubella (MMR) booster shots to students who have not had two MMR vaccinations since 1990, or are unsure of their vaccination history.\n\nPro-vice-chancellor of health sciences Professor Peter Crampton, the convener of the university's pandemic planning group, said the group was \"determining our ongoing response as the situation develops.\"\n\nThe outbreak coincided with a large-scale boil water notice issued for parts of Dunedin, including the student quarter, after untreated water got into part of the town's drinking water supply on [Mon 14 Aug 2017].\n\nAll students and staff had been sent information about mumps. Information had been posted on social media.\n\nMarlborough medical officer of health Dr Andrew Lindsay said mumps is \"highly contagious\". It spreads through the air by breathing, coughing and sneezing, or through contact with infected saliva; by kissing or sharing food and drink. It usually takes 12-25 days before symptoms appear -- including pain in the jaw, fever, headache, and swollen glands around the face and body. People with mumps re infectious for 7 days before swelling starts and for 5 days after they cease.\n\nPersonal hygiene is essential to avoid catching mumps, including frequent hand washing, stopping coughs and sneezes in tissues, keeping at least 1 metre [3 ft] away from others and ensuring kitchens and bathrooms are clean.\n\nDr Jill Sherwood, public health physician with the ESR (the Institute of Environmental Science and Research), earlier said the MMR vaccine was not as effective in mumps as it was in measles and rubella. \"The mumps component is only about 85 per cent effective, whereas the measles component will most likely give you lifetime coverage,\" Sherwood said.\n\nThere have been no reported cases of mumps in Canterbury, a health board spokeswoman said.\n\n[Byline: Hamish Mcneilly, Jennifer Eder]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of New Zealand can be seen at http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/oceania/political-map-of-New-Zealan.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/738. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[3] Brazil (Manaus, Amazonas)\nDate: Fri 18 Aug 2017\nSource: Em Tempo [in Portuguese, trans. & summ., edited]\nhttp://www.emtempo.com.br/manaus-tem-surto-de-caxumba-com-230-casos/\n\n\nWith 230 cases of mumps in Manaus [Amazonas state] in 19 places, registered since April 2017, mainly in schools, the Municipal Health Department (Semsa) warns parents to keep the updated immunization booklet for children and adolescents.\n\nUp to 2016, there were no official mumps outbreak records in Manaus. In 2017, as of 18 Aug, there have been 230 cases reported from 19 localities, most of them in schools, which suggests low vaccination coverage in children and adolescents. The 1st outbreak was reported in April 2017 and the occurrence of cases is continuing until the month of August, according to the municipal health secretary. ...\n\n[Byline: Isac 20160225.4050452\n.................................................sb/lk/mj/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-24 00:00:00", "1965-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-09-16 00:00:00", "2017-07-16 00:00:00", "1990-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-04-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-04-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2033-03-16 00:00:00", "2032-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00", "2021-03-28 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 {"archive_id": "5325095", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps update (26): USA (TX) Canada (MB,BC)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5325095", "date": "2017-08-20 09:44:05", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (24): AUSTRALIA (QUEENSLAND), NEW ZEALAND (OTAGO,) BRAZIL (AMAZONAS)\n*********************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Australia (Cairns, Queensland)\n[2] New Zealand (Dunedin, Otago)\n[3] Brazil (Manaus, Amazonas)\n\n******\n[1] Australia (Cairns, Queensland)\nDate: Fri 11 Aug 2017 9:00 PM AEST\nSource: The Cairns Post [edited]\nhttps://tinyurl.com/y9nepfk5\n\n\nFar North Queenslanders have been urged to vaccinate their children following a spike in mumps cases in Cairns. There have been 14 cases of the highly infectious disease identified by Queensland Health since [24 Jul 2017], compared to the yearly average of only one case in the Cairns and Hinterland health district.\n\nTropical Public Health director Dr Steven Donohue said the mumps outbreak had spilled over to Cairns from northwest Queensland and the Northern Territory's Top End.\n\n\"Outbreaks of mumps mainly occur because of low vaccination rates, missed doses in the past, waning immunity, or pressure of infection in overcrowded households,\" he said.\n\nHe said the viral illness was spread just like influenza, by coughing or sneezing near other people and through unwashed hands.\n\n\"Symptoms may occur around 2 weeks after exposure if the person is not immune,\" he said. \"The illness usually lasts between 5-9 days.\n\n\"One person in 3 who contracts mumps does not have any symptoms and doesn't realise they are sick, but they may still be contagious and infect may other people.\"\n\nNorthern Queensland Primary Health Network chief executive Robin Moore said immunisation was a simple, safe and highly effective way to protect children and adults from preventable diseases like mumps.\n\n\"This year's [2017] increase in the number of mumps cases in the Cairns region is a timely reminder to parents that immunisation is the best protection against preventable diseases such as these.\n\n\"We urge all members of the community to be fully vaccinated.\" ...\n\nThe disease is uncommon in developed countries, including Australia, because of the widespread use of the measles, mumps, rubella (MMR) vaccine.\n\nThis is given to children at 12 and 18 months, but free catch-up doses are available to anyone born after 1965 who may not have 2 recorded doses.\n\nOutbreaks of mumps mainly occur because of low vaccination rates, missed doses in the past, waning immunity, or pressure of infection in overcrowded households.\n\n[Byline: Daniel Bateman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Australia can be seen at http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/oceania/australia-political-map.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/2954. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n\n******\n[2] New Zealand (Dunedin, Otago)\nDate: Thu 17 Aug 2017 19:45 NZST\nSource: Stuff [edited]\nhttp://tinyurl.com/y7a56fv5\n\n\nUniversity of Otago students are being offered free booster shots after about 10 confirmed or suspected cases were reported in Dunedin [Otago, South Island].\n\nThree young people in Marlborough have contracted the contagious illness, with at least 1 case linked to an Auckland outbreak, while 2 have been confirmed in Nelson.\n\nNationally, an unusually high number of cases were reported from September 2016 to early 2017, and the Ministry of Health warned of \"an increased risk of further outbreaks\".\n\nAuckland reported 51 cases of mumps in the past month -- most aged 10 to 19 -- while several were recorded in Waikato earlier this year [2017].\n\nThe Auckland Regional Public Health Service said last month [July 2017] it was concerned not enough people were immunised in the face of the mumps outbreak.\n\nThe MMR vaccine is usually given in 2 doses, one at 15 months old and one at 4 years old.\n\nMost people recover from mumps, but it can have serious complications. The disease can cause inflammation of tissue surrounding the brain (meningitis), inflamed testicles or ovaries and deafness.\n\nMen hospitalised from the Auckland outbreak had pain and swelling in their testicles, known as orchitis, which in rare cases may lead to infertility.\n\nThe outbreak in Dunedin has prompted the Otago tertiary institution's student health team to offer free measles, mumps and rubella (MMR) booster shots to students who have not had two MMR vaccinations since 1990, or are unsure of their vaccination history.\n\nPro-vice-chancellor of health sciences Professor Peter Crampton, the convener of the university's pandemic planning group, said the group was \"determining our ongoing response as the situation develops.\"\n\nThe outbreak coincided with a large-scale boil water notice issued for parts of Dunedin, including the student quarter, after untreated water got into part of the town's drinking water supply on [Mon 14 Aug 2017].\n\nAll students and staff had been sent information about mumps. Information had been posted on social media.\n\nMarlborough medical officer of health Dr Andrew Lindsay said mumps is \"highly contagious\". It spreads through the air by breathing, coughing and sneezing, or through contact with infected saliva; by kissing or sharing food and drink. It usually takes 12-25 days before symptoms appear -- including pain in the jaw, fever, headache, and swollen glands around the face and body. People with mumps re infectious for 7 days before swelling starts and for 5 days after they cease.\n\nPersonal hygiene is essential to avoid catching mumps, including frequent hand washing, stopping coughs and sneezes in tissues, keeping at least 1 metre [3 ft] away from others and ensuring kitchens and bathrooms are clean.\n\nDr Jill Sherwood, public health physician with the ESR (the Institute of Environmental Science and Research), earlier said the MMR vaccine was not as effective in mumps as it was in measles and rubella. \"The mumps component is only about 85 per cent effective, whereas the measles component will most likely give you lifetime coverage,\" Sherwood said.\n\nThere have been no reported cases of mumps in Canterbury, a health board spokeswoman said.\n\n[Byline: Hamish Mcneilly, Jennifer Eder]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of New Zealand can be seen at http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/oceania/political-map-of-New-Zealan.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/738. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[3] Brazil (Manaus, Amazonas)\nDate: Fri 18 Aug 2017\nSource: Em Tempo [in Portuguese, trans. & summ., edited]\nhttp://www.emtempo.com.br/manaus-tem-surto-de-caxumba-com-230-casos/\n\n\nWith 230 cases of mumps in Manaus [Amazonas state] in 19 places, registered since April 2017, mainly in schools, the Municipal Health Department (Semsa) warns parents to keep the updated immunization booklet for children and adolescents.\n\nUp to 2016, there were no official mumps outbreak records in Manaus. In 2017, as of 18 Aug, there have been 230 cases reported from 19 localities, most of them in schools, which suggests low vaccination coverage in children and adolescents. The 1st outbreak was reported in April 2017 and the occurrence of cases is continuing until the month of August, according to the municipal health secretary. ...\n\n[Byline: Isac Sharlon]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nEmerson Capistrano\nEpidemiological Surveillance\nBoa Vista Health Service\nRoraima, Brazil\n<emerson.capistrano@gmail.com>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Emerson Capistrano for submitting this report. - Mod.LK\n\nMaps of Brazil can be seen at http://s13.postimg.org/jumnalk87/map_of_Brazil.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/10254. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\nMumps
