{"archive_id": "5300162", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps update (25): USA (Hawai'i Island) New Zealand (AU)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5300162", "date": "2017-08-20 09:44:05", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (24): AUSTRALIA (QUEENSLAND), NEW ZEALAND (OTAGO,) BRAZIL (AMAZONAS)\n*********************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Australia (Cairns, Queensland)\n[2] New Zealand (Dunedin, Otago)\n[3] Brazil (Manaus, Amazonas)\n\n******\n[1] Australia (Cairns, Queensland)\nDate: Fri 11 Aug 2017 9:00 PM AEST\nSource: The Cairns Post [edited]\nhttps://tinyurl.com/y9nepfk5\n\n\nFar North Queenslanders have been urged to vaccinate their children following a spike in mumps cases in Cairns. There have been 14 cases of the highly infectious disease identified by Queensland Health since [24 Jul 2017], compared to the yearly average of only one case in the Cairns and Hinterland health district.\n\nTropical Public Health director Dr Steven Donohue said the mumps outbreak had spilled over to Cairns from northwest Queensland and the Northern Territory's Top End.\n\n\"Outbreaks of mumps mainly occur because of low vaccination rates, missed doses in the past, waning immunity, or pressure of infection in overcrowded households,\" he said.\n\nHe said the viral illness was spread just like influenza, by coughing or sneezing near other people and through unwashed hands.\n\n\"Symptoms may occur around 2 weeks after exposure if the person is not immune,\" he said. \"The illness usually lasts between 5-9 days.\n\n\"One person in 3 who contracts mumps does not have any symptoms and doesn't realise they are sick, but they may still be contagious and infect may other people.\"\n\nNorthern Queensland Primary Health Network chief executive Robin Moore said immunisation was a simple, safe and highly effective way to protect children and adults from preventable diseases like mumps.\n\n\"This year's [2017] increase in the number of mumps cases in the Cairns region is a timely reminder to parents that immunisation is the best protection against preventable diseases such as these.\n\n\"We urge all members of the community to be fully vaccinated.\" ...\n\nThe disease is uncommon in developed countries, including Australia, because of the widespread use of the measles, mumps, rubella (MMR) vaccine.\n\nThis is given to children at 12 and 18 months, but free catch-up doses are available to anyone born after 1965 who may not have 2 recorded doses.\n\nOutbreaks of mumps mainly occur because of low vaccination rates, missed doses in the past, waning immunity, or pressure of infection in overcrowded households.\n\n[Byline: Daniel Bateman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Australia can be seen at http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/oceania/australia-political-map.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/2954. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n\n******\n[2] New Zealand (Dunedin, Otago)\nDate: Thu 17 Aug 2017 19:45 NZST\nSource: Stuff [edited]\nhttp://tinyurl.com/y7a56fv5\n\n\nUniversity of Otago students are being offered free booster shots after about 10 confirmed or suspected cases were reported in Dunedin [Otago, South Island].\n\nThree young people in Marlborough have contracted the contagious illness, with at least 1 case linked to an Auckland outbreak, while 2 have been confirmed in Nelson.\n\nNationally, an unusually high number of cases were reported from September 2016 to early 2017, and the Ministry of Health warned of \"an increased risk of further outbreaks\".\n\nAuckland reported 51 cases of mumps in the past month -- most aged 10 to 19 -- while several were recorded in Waikato earlier this year [2017].\n\nThe Auckland Regional Public Health Service said last month [July 2017] it was concerned not enough people were immunised in the face of the mumps outbreak.\n\nThe MMR vaccine is usually given in 2 doses, one at 15 months old and one at 4 years old.\n\nMost people recover from mumps, but it can have serious complications. The disease can cause inflammation of tissue surrounding the brain (meningitis), inflamed testicles or ovaries and deafness.\n\nMen hospitalised from the Auckland outbreak had pain and swelling in their testicles, known as orchitis, which in rare cases may lead to infertility.\n\nThe outbreak in Dunedin has prompted the Otago tertiary institution's student health team to offer free measles, mumps and rubella (MMR) booster shots to students who have not had two MMR vaccinations since 1990, or are unsure of their vaccination history.\n\nPro-vice-chancellor of health sciences Professor Peter Crampton, the convener of the university's pandemic planning group, said the group was \"determining our ongoing response as the situation develops.\"\n\nThe outbreak coincided with a large-scale boil water notice issued for parts of Dunedin, including the student quarter, after untreated water got into part of the town's drinking water supply on [Mon 14 Aug 2017].\n\nAll students and staff had been sent information about mumps. Information had been posted on social media.\n\nMarlborough medical officer of health Dr Andrew Lindsay said mumps is \"highly contagious\". It spreads through the air by breathing, coughing and sneezing, or through contact with infected saliva; by kissing or sharing food and drink. It usually takes 12-25 days before symptoms appear -- including pain in the jaw, fever, headache, and swollen glands around the face and body. People with mumps re infectious for 7 days before swelling starts and for 5 days after they cease.\n\nPersonal hygiene is essential to avoid catching mumps, including frequent hand washing, stopping coughs and sneezes in tissues, keeping at least 1 metre [3 ft] away from others and ensuring kitchens and bathrooms are clean.\n\nDr Jill Sherwood, public health physician with the ESR (the Institute of Environmental Science and Research), earlier said the MMR vaccine was not as effective in mumps as it was in measles and rubella. \"The mumps component is only about 85 per cent effective, whereas the measles component will most likely give you lifetime coverage,\" Sherwood said.\n\nThere have been no reported cases of mumps in Canterbury, a health board spokeswoman said.\n\n[Byline: Hamish Mcneilly, Jennifer Eder]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of New Zealand can be seen at http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/oceania/political-map-of-New-Zealan.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/738. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[3] Brazil (Manaus, Amazonas)\nDate: Fri 18 Aug 2017\nSource: Em Tempo [in Portuguese, trans. & summ., edited]\nhttp://www.emtempo.com.br/manaus-tem-surto-de-caxumba-com-230-casos/\n\n\nWith 230 cases of mumps in Manaus [Amazonas state] in 19 places, registered since April 2017, mainly in schools, the Municipal Health Department (Semsa) warns parents to keep the updated immunization booklet for children and adolescents.\n\nUp to 2016, there were no official mumps outbreak records in Manaus. In 2017, as of 18 Aug, there have been 230 cases reported from 19 localities, most of them in schools, which suggests low vaccination coverage in children and adolescents. The 1st outbreak was reported in April 2017 and the occurrence of cases is continuing until the month of August, according to the municipal health secretary. ...\n\n[Byline: Isac Sharlon]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nEmerson Capistrano\nEpidemiological Surveillance\nBoa Vista Health Service\nRoraima, Brazil\n<emerson.capistrano@gmail.com>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Emerson Capistrano for submitting this report. - Mod.LK\n\nMaps of Brazil can be seen at http://s13.postimg.org/jumnalk87/map_of_Brazil.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/10254. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\nMumps "event_date": ["2021-03-24 00:00:00", "1965-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-09-16 00:00:00", "2017-07-16 00:00:00", "1990-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-04-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-04-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2033-03-16 00:00:00", "2032-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00", "2021-03-28 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 {"archive_id": "5262239", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps update (24): Australia (QL), New Zealand (OT), Brazil (AM)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5262239", "date": "2017-08-20 09:44:05", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (24): AUSTRALIA (QUEENSLAND), NEW ZEALAND (OTAGO,) BRAZIL (AMAZONAS)\n*********************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Australia (Cairns, Queensland)\n[2] New Zealand (Dunedin, Otago)\n[3] Brazil (Manaus, Amazonas)\n\n******\n[1] Australia (Cairns, Queensland)\nDate: Fri 11 Aug 2017 9:00 PM AEST\nSource: The Cairns Post [edited]\nhttps://tinyurl.com/y9nepfk5\n\n\nFar North Queenslanders have been urged to vaccinate their children following a spike in mumps cases in Cairns. There have been 14 cases of the highly infectious disease identified by Queensland Health since [24 Jul 2017], compared to the yearly average of only one case in the Cairns and Hinterland health district.\n\nTropical Public Health director Dr Steven Donohue said the mumps outbreak had spilled over to Cairns from northwest Queensland and the Northern Territory's Top End.\n\n\"Outbreaks of mumps mainly occur because of low vaccination rates, missed doses in the past, waning immunity, or pressure of infection in overcrowded households,\" he said.\n\nHe said the viral illness was spread just like influenza, by coughing or sneezing near other people and through unwashed hands.\n\n\"Symptoms may occur around 2 weeks after exposure if the person is not immune,\" he said. \"The illness usually lasts between 5-9 days.\n\n\"One person in 3 who contracts mumps does not have any symptoms and doesn't realise they are sick, but they may still be contagious and infect may other people.\"\n\nNorthern Queensland Primary Health Network chief executive Robin Moore said immunisation was a simple, safe and highly effective way to protect children and adults from preventable diseases like mumps.\n\n\"This year's [2017] increase in the number of mumps cases in the Cairns region is a timely reminder to parents that immunisation is the best protection against preventable diseases such as these.\n\n\"We urge all members of the community to be fully vaccinated.\" ...\n\nThe disease is uncommon in developed countries, including Australia, because of the widespread use of the measles, mumps, rubella (MMR) vaccine.\n\nThis is given to children at 12 and 18 months, but free catch-up doses are available to anyone born after 1965 who may not have 2 recorded doses.\n\nOutbreaks of mumps mainly occur because of low vaccination rates, missed doses in the past, waning immunity, or pressure of infection in overcrowded households.\n\n[Byline: Daniel Bateman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Australia can be seen at http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/oceania/australia-political-map.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/2954. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n\n******\n[2] New Zealand (Dunedin, Otago)\nDate: Thu 17 Aug 2017 19:45 NZST\nSource: Stuff [edited]\nhttp://tinyurl.com/y7a56fv5\n\n\nUniversity of Otago students are being offered free booster shots after about 10 confirmed or suspected cases were reported in Dunedin [Otago, South Island].\n\nThree young people in Marlborough have contracted the contagious illness, with at least 1 case linked to an Auckland outbreak, while 2 have been confirmed in Nelson.\n\nNationally, an unusually high number of cases were reported from September 2016 to early 2017, and the Ministry of Health warned of \"an increased risk of further outbreaks\".\n\nAuckland reported 51 cases of mumps in the past month -- most aged 10 to 19 -- while several were recorded in Waikato earlier this year [2017].\n\nThe Auckland Regional Public Health Service said last month [July 2017] it was concerned not enough people were immunised in the face of the mumps outbreak.\n\nThe MMR vaccine is usually given in 2 doses, one at 15 months old and one at 4 years old.\n\nMost people recover from mumps, but it can have serious complications. The disease can cause inflammation of tissue surrounding the brain (meningitis), inflamed testicles or ovaries and deafness.\n\nMen hospitalised from the Auckland outbreak had pain and swelling in their testicles, known as orchitis, which in rare cases may lead to infertility.\n\nThe outbreak in Dunedin has prompted the Otago tertiary institution's student health team to offer free measles, mumps and rubella (MMR) booster shots to students who have not had two MMR vaccinations since 1990, or are unsure of their vaccination history.\n\nPro-vice-chancellor of health sciences Professor Peter Crampton, the convener of the university's pandemic planning group, said the group was \"determining our ongoing response as the situation develops.\"\n\nThe outbreak coincided with a large-scale boil water notice issued for parts of Dunedin, including the student quarter, after untreated water got into part of the town's drinking water supply on [Mon 14 Aug 2017].\n\nAll students and staff had been sent information about mumps. Information had been posted on social media.\n\nMarlborough medical officer of health Dr Andrew Lindsay said mumps is \"highly contagious\". It spreads through the air by breathing, coughing and sneezing, or through contact with infected saliva; by kissing or sharing food and drink. It usually takes 12-25 days before symptoms appear -- including pain in the jaw, fever, headache, and swollen glands around the face and body. People with mumps re infectious for 7 days before swelling starts and for 5 days after they cease.\n\nPersonal hygiene is essential to avoid catching mumps, including frequent hand washing, stopping coughs and sneezes in tissues, keeping at least 1 metre [3 ft] away from others and ensuring kitchens and bathrooms are clean.\n\nDr Jill Sherwood, public health physician with the ESR (the Institute of Environmental Science and Research), earlier said the MMR vaccine was not as effective in mumps as it was in measles and rubella. \"The mumps component is only about 85 per cent effective, whereas the measles component will most likely give you lifetime coverage,\" Sherwood said.\n\nThere have been no reported cases of mumps in Canterbury, a health board spokeswoman said.\n\n[Byline: Hamish Mcneilly, Jennifer Eder]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of New Zealand can be seen at http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/oceania/political-map-of-New-Zealan.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/738. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[3] Brazil (Manaus, Amazonas)\nDate: Fri 18 Aug 2017\nSource: Em Tempo [in Portuguese, trans. & summ., edited]\nhttp://www.emtempo.com.br/manaus-tem-surto-de-caxumba-com-230-casos/\n\n\nWith 230 cases of mumps in Manaus [Amazonas state] in 19 places, registered since April 2017, mainly in schools, the Municipal Health Department (Semsa) warns parents to keep the updated immunization booklet for children and adolescents.\n\nUp to 2016, there were no official mumps outbreak records in Manaus. In 2017, as of 18 Aug, there have been 230 cases reported from 19 localities, most of them in schools, which suggests low vaccination coverage in children and adolescents. The 1st outbreak was reported in April 2017 and the occurrence of cases is continuing until the month of August, according to the municipal health secretary. ...\n\n[Byline: Isac Sharlon]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nEmerson Capistrano\nEpidemiological Surveillance\nBoa Vista Health Service\nRoraima, Brazil\n<emerson.capistrano@gmail.com>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Emerson Capistrano for submitting this report. - Mod.LK\n\nMaps of Brazil can be seen at http://s13.postimg.org/jumnalk87/map_of_Brazil.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/10254. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\nMumps "event_date": ["2021-03-24 00:00:00", "1965-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-09-16 00:00:00", "2017-07-16 00:00:00", "1990-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-04-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-04-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2033-03-16 00:00:00", "2032-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 {"archive_id": "5197236", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps update (23): New Zealand (AU), USA (TX)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5197236", "date": "2017-04-23 08:21:48", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (16): USA (TEXAS, MINNESOTA)\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Texas\n[2] Texas, Dallas County\n[3] Minnesota\n\n******\n[1] Texas\nDate: Sat 15 April 2017\nSource: BABW News [edited]\nhttp://www.babwnews.com/2017/04/huge-disease-outbreak-in-u-s-sends-authorities-scrambling/\n\n\n[Mumps] has suddenly sprung up in the United States, and authorities are trying to figure out how to get a handle on the situation.\n\nA very unpleasant disease [mumps] has reared its ugly head in the United States, and authorities have been trying to understand why it's happening and how to stop it. Health department officials in Texas have announced that cases of mumps have surged to a 20-year high, and there may have been a bunch of exposures on South Padre Island where spring-breakers are celebrating.\n\nState health officials have reported 221 cases of mumps so far this year [2017], the most since 1994 when there were 234 cases. Mumps results in swollen salivary grands, swollen testicles, low fever, tiredness, and muscle aches, with symptoms emerging about 16 -- 18 days after exposure.\n\nInfections of mumps dived 99 percent since a vaccine was developed and released in 1967. The mumps vaccine protects 88 percent of people who are fully vaccinated, although some vaccinated people can still get sick if exposed.\n\n\"The Texas Department of State Health Services is advising health care providers to be on alert for mumps in their patients as the state experiences a 20-year high in mumps cases,\" states the THHS website \"State, regional and local health departments are currently investigating multiple outbreaks throughout the state, including one involving possible exposures on South Padre Island, a popular spring break destination for students from Texas and elsewhere in the United States. Texas has had 221 mumps cases this year [2017], the largest total since there were 234 cases in 1994.\"\n\n[Byline: Dan Taylor]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Texas, Dallas County\nDate: Wed 19 Apr 2017\nSource: FOX4News [edited]\nhttp://www.fox4news.com/news/249605964-story\n\n\nCedar Hill ISD officials held a forum [Wed 19 Apr 2017] night to provide more information to concerned parents about a severe mumps outbreak.\n\nDallas County Health and Human Services reports 84 mumps cases so far in 2017 [see [1] above, 221 cases total in state].\n\nUp to 64 of those cases are students and teachers in Cedar Hill ISD, with 3 more cases in DeSoto. Health officials have also identified 17 unrelated cases in Mesquite, Dallas and DeSoto.\n\nParents at the meeting submitted questions. Many wanted to know how the mumps is spreading and why.\n\n\"You heard about the chicken pox, you heard about the meningitis, but the mumps you haven't heard about in so long, so you're kind of concerned, like can it cause death?\" said parent [SA].\n\n[A] has a daughter at Cedar Hill High School. Her child is vaccinated, but [A] is still concerned about the mumps outbreak that started at her child's school.\n\n\"What are we doing about this mumps outbreak? Are we cleaning the building?\" [A] asked.\n\nDistrict officials said the outbreak started at Cedar Hill High School in February [2017].\n\nSince then, more cases have been found at 9th Grade Center, Collegiate High School, Permenter Middle School and High Pointe Elementary. \"When you get a bunch of kids all contained in small pockets of areas, like schools, the likelihood of spreading an airborne virus is gonna happen,\" said Cedar Hill ISD superintendent Orlando Riddick.\n\nOfficials don't know the source but said they're doing their best to keep the situation under control.\n\n\"We've started our cleaning processes and cleaning high touch areas,\" superintendent Riddick said. \"We began to disinfect schools with a misting machine.\"\n\nThe district has also hosted 4 vaccine booster clinics, saying more than 90 percent of their students are vaccinated.\n\nThe district's health director, Dr Michael Marshall, said infected people could be unknowingly spreading mumps.\n\n\"The problem is simply that people are coming to school who are infected with the mumps and they don't know it,\" said Dr Marshall.\n\nAccording to doctors, it can take up to 25 days until symptoms like fever, headache and loss of appetite show up. Some who are infected have no symptoms.\n\nParent [AG] said the district should be transparent about the outbreak. \"Just be transparent and make sure our building is clean and that it's safe for our children and teachers,\"[G] said.\n\nAccording to health officials, those without the mumps vaccine are most at risk. Doctors recommend at least 2 vaccines, and even a 3rd booster shot to increase protection. However, one can still get mumps even with the proper vaccines.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3] Minnesota\nDate: Fri 21 APR 2017 11:30 PM\nSource: CBS News [edited]\nhttp://www.cbsnews.com/news/mumps-outbreak-reported-at-university-of-minnesota/\n\n\nUniversity of Minnesota health officials are warning students about a mumps outbreak on campus, CBS Minnesota reports.\n\nSo far there have been 6 reported cases, campus health officials say.\n\nIt's considered highly contagious and the disease is spread by coughing, sneezing or sharing items that you eat or drink.\n\nThe symptoms are pretty clear -- puffy cheeks, a swollen jaw accompanied by a fever, headaches and loss of appetite.\n\n\"I've been at Boynton Health for 20 years and we have not had this situation before,\" said Dr Gary Christenson, the chief medical officer at the University of Minnesota.\n\nChristenson said students are required to be vaccinated for mumps before they come to school, with a few exceptions. But even then, it's still possible to contract the disease.\n\nUp to 6 reported cases of mumps so far at the University may not seem like a large number. But on a campus like this, Christenson said anything over 3 cases is considered an outbreak.\n\n\"One of the challenges of mumps is that for the 1st 2 days that someone has it, before they have symptoms, they are already shedding or can be exposing other people to it,\" said Christenson.\n\nA couple years ago, the Minnesota Wild got caught in a mumps outbreak. And in February, the mumps again briefly sidelined forwards [ZP] and [JP]. Students believe that if it can spread quickly on a hockey team, it can spread just as quickly on campus.\n\n\"If you are at the library or something, this is such a huge school, it's so hard for things not to be spread around,\" said senior Maddie Trenholm.\n\nThat's why health officials are asking students or faculty who has been diagnosed to stay away for 5 days.\n\n\"It's really hard to predict how long this will be an issue and how many cases we might have,\" said Christenson.\n\nAnd with finals coming up, they are hoping to keep this from spreading as much as possible. The cases the university has seen so far are considered mild.\n\nA US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention report in December 2016 shows that mumps are at a 10-year high -- and colleges seem to be especially hard hit by the contagious virus. The close quarters on campus make it easy for the disease to spread.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[From 1 Jan -- 25 Mar 2017, 42 states and the District of Columbia in the US reported 1965 cases of mumps to CDC.\n\nFrom year to year, mumps cases can range from roughly a couple hundred to a couple thousand. For example in 2016, there were approximately 5748 cases reported to CDC, and in 2012, there were 229. Before the US mumps vaccination program started in 1967, about 186 000 cases were reported each year, but the actual number of cases was likely much higher due to underreporting. Since the pre-vaccine era, there has been more than 99 percent decrease in mumps cases in the United States.\n\n(excerpted / edited from CDC.gov). - Mod.LK\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/354.]\nSee Also\nMumps update (15): New Zealand, USA 20170408.4958345\nMumps update (14): Australia (QL), USA 20170330.4935375\nMumps update (13): Portugal, 20160225.4050452\n.................................................sb/lk/ec/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "mumps", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-04-15 00:00:00", "1994-03-16 00:00:00", "1967-03-16 00:00:00", "1994-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-02-16 00:00:00", "2021-02-16 00:00:00", "2016-12-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "1965-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "1967-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2033-03-16 00:00:00", "2032-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00", "2021-03-28 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Dallas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Portugal", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MT", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MINNESOTA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "TEXAS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York City", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mesquite", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NE", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the District of Columbia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Parent", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Dallas County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5160387", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps update (22): New Zealand, USA", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5160387", "date": "2017-04-23 08:21:48", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (16): USA (TEXAS, MINNESOTA)\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Texas\n[2] Texas, Dallas County\n[3] Minnesota\n\n******\n[1] Texas\nDate: Sat 15 April 2017\nSource: BABW News [edited]\nhttp://www.babwnews.com/2017/04/huge-disease-outbreak-in-u-s-sends-authorities-scrambling/\n\n\n[Mumps] has suddenly sprung up in the United States, and authorities are trying to figure out how to get a handle on the situation.\n\nA very unpleasant disease [mumps] has reared its ugly head in the United States, and authorities have been trying to understand why it's happening and how to stop it. Health department officials in Texas have announced that cases of mumps have surged to a 20-year high, and there may have been a bunch of exposures on South Padre Island where spring-breakers are celebrating.\n\nState health officials have reported 221 cases of mumps so far this year [2017], the most since 1994 when there were 234 cases. Mumps results in swollen salivary grands, swollen testicles, low fever, tiredness, and muscle aches, with symptoms emerging about 16 -- 18 days after exposure.\n\nInfections of mumps dived 99 percent since a vaccine was developed and released in 1967. The mumps vaccine protects 88 percent of people who are fully vaccinated, although some vaccinated people can still get sick if exposed.\n\n\"The Texas Department of State Health Services is advising health care providers to be on alert for mumps in their patients as the state experiences a 20-year high in mumps cases,\" states the THHS website \"State, regional and local health departments are currently investigating multiple outbreaks throughout the state, including one involving possible exposures on South Padre Island, a popular spring break destination for students from Texas and elsewhere in the United States. Texas has had 221 mumps cases this year [2017], the largest total since there were 234 cases in 1994.\"\n\n[Byline: Dan Taylor]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Texas, Dallas County\nDate: Wed 19 Apr 2017\nSource: FOX4News [edited]\nhttp://www.fox4news.com/news/249605964-story\n\n\nCedar Hill ISD officials held a forum [Wed 19 Apr 2017] night to provide more information to concerned parents about a severe mumps outbreak.\n\nDallas County Health and Human Services reports 84 mumps cases so far in 2017 [see [1] above, 221 cases total in state].\n\nUp to 64 of those cases are students and teachers in Cedar Hill ISD, with 3 more cases in DeSoto. Health officials have also identified 17 unrelated cases in Mesquite, Dallas and DeSoto.\n\nParents at the meeting submitted questions. Many wanted to know how the mumps is spreading and why.\n\n\"You heard about the chicken pox, you heard about the meningitis, but the mumps you haven't heard about in so long, so you're kind of concerned, like can it cause death?\" said parent [SA].\n\n[A] has a daughter at Cedar Hill High School. Her child is vaccinated, but [A] is still concerned about the mumps outbreak that started at her child's school.\n\n\"What are we doing about this mumps outbreak? Are we cleaning the building?\" [A] asked.\n\nDistrict officials said the outbreak started at Cedar Hill High School in February [2017].\n\nSince then, more cases have been found at 9th Grade Center, Collegiate High School, Permenter Middle School and High Pointe Elementary. \"When you get a bunch of kids all contained in small pockets of areas, like schools, the likelihood of spreading an airborne virus is gonna happen,\" said Cedar Hill ISD superintendent Orlando Riddick.\n\nOfficials don't know the source but said they're doing their best to keep the situation under control.\n\n\"We've started our cleaning processes and cleaning high touch areas,\" superintendent Riddick said. \"We began to disinfect schools with a misting machine.\"\n\nThe district has also hosted 4 vaccine booster clinics, saying more than 90 percent of their students are vaccinated.\n\nThe district's health director, Dr Michael Marshall, said infected people could be unknowingly spreading mumps.\n\n\"The problem is simply that people are coming to school who are infected with the mumps and they don't know it,\" said Dr Marshall.\n\nAccording to doctors, it can take up to 25 days until symptoms like fever, headache and loss of appetite show up. Some who are infected have no symptoms.\n\nParent [AG] said the district should be transparent about the outbreak. \"Just be transparent and make sure our building is clean and that it's safe for our children and teachers,\"[G] said.\n\nAccording to health officials, those without the mumps vaccine are most at risk. Doctors recommend at least 2 vaccines, and even a 3rd booster shot to increase protection. However, one can still get mumps even with the proper vaccines.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3] Minnesota\nDate: Fri 21 APR 2017 11:30 PM\nSource: CBS News [edited]\nhttp://www.cbsnews.com/news/mumps-outbreak-reported-at-university-of-minnesota/\n\n\nUniversity of Minnesota health officials are warning students about a mumps outbreak on campus, CBS Minnesota reports.\n\nSo far there have been 6 reported cases, campus health officials say.\n\nIt's considered highly contagious and the disease is spread by coughing, sneezing or sharing items that you eat or drink.\n\nThe symptoms are pretty clear -- puffy cheeks, a swollen jaw accompanied by a fever, headaches and loss of appetite.\n\n\"I've been at Boynton Health for 20 years and we have not had this situation before,\" said Dr Gary Christenson, the chief medical officer at the University of Minnesota.\n\nChristenson said students are required to be vaccinated for mumps before they come to school, with a few exceptions. But even then, it's still possible to contract the disease.\n\nUp to 6 reported cases of mumps so far at the University may not seem like a large number. But on a campus like this, Christenson said anything over 3 cases is considered an outbreak.\n\n\"One of the challenges of mumps is that for the 1st 2 days that someone has it, before they have symptoms, they are already shedding or can be exposing other people to it,\" said Christenson.\n\nA couple years ago, the Minnesota Wild got caught in a mumps outbreak. And in February, the mumps again briefly sidelined forwards [ZP] and [JP]. Students believe that if it can spread quickly on a hockey team, it can spread just as quickly on campus.\n\n\"If you are at the library or something, this is such a huge school, it's so hard for things not to be spread around,\" said senior Maddie Trenholm.\n\nThat's why health officials are asking students or faculty who has been diagnosed to stay away for 5 days.\n\n\"It's really hard to predict how long this will be an issue and how many cases we might have,\" said Christenson.\n\nAnd with finals coming up, they are hoping to keep this from spreading as much as possible. The cases the university has seen so far are considered mild.\n\nA US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention report in December 2016 shows that mumps are at a 10-year high -- and colleges seem to be especially hard hit by the contagious virus. The close quarters on campus make it easy for the disease to spread.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[From 1 Jan -- 25 Mar 2017, 42 states and the District of Columbia in the US reported 1965 cases of mumps to CDC.\n\nFrom year to year, mumps cases can range from roughly a couple hundred to a couple thousand. For example in 2016, there were approximately 5748 cases reported to CDC, and in 2012, there were 229. Before the US mumps vaccination program started in 1967, about 186 000 cases were reported each year, but the actual number of cases was likely much higher due to underreporting. Since the pre-vaccine era, there has been more than 99 percent decrease in mumps cases in the United States.\n\n(excerpted / edited from CDC.gov). - Mod.LK\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/354.]\nSee Also\nMumps update (15): New Zealand, USA 20170408.4958345\nMumps update (14): Australia (QL), USA 20170330.4935375\nMumps update (13): Portugal, 20170312.4895943\nMumps update (08): Canada, USA, comment 20170305.4880865\nMumps update (07): Canada, USA 20170303.4875855\nMumps update (06): USA 20170227.4864176\nMumps update (05): USA (PA, MO - For example in 2016, there were approximately 5748 cases reported to CDC, and in 2012, there were 229. Before the US mumps vaccination program started in 1967, about 186 000 cases were reported each year, but the actual number of cases was likely much higher due to underreporting. Since the pre-vaccine era, there has been more than 99 percent decrease in mumps cases in the United States.\n\n(excerpted / edited from CDC.gov). - Mod.LK\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/354.]\nSee Also\nMumps update (15): New Zealand, USA 20170408.4958345\nMumps update (14): Australia (QL), USA 20170330.4935375\nMumps update (13): Portugal, 20161016.4562698\nMumps - USA (21) 20161001.4528777\nMumps - USA (20) 20161001.4528777\nMumps - USA (19) 20160917.4495932\nMumps - USA (18): (AR) 20160910.4478210\nMumps - USA (17): (AR) 20160225.4050452\n.................................................sb/lk/ec/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "mumps", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-04-15 00:00:00", "1994-03-16 00:00:00", "1967-03-16 00:00:00", "1994-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-02-16 00:00:00", "2021-02-16 00:00:00", "2016-12-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "1965-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "1967-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2033-03-16 00:00:00", "2032-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00", "2021-03-28 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Dallas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Portugal", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MT", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MINNESOTA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "TEXAS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York City", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mesquite", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NE", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the District of Columbia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Parent", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Dallas County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5095537", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps update (20): USA (IL, NY, MA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5095537", "date": "2017-04-23 08:21:48", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (16): USA (TEXAS, MINNESOTA)\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Texas\n[2] Texas, Dallas County\n[3] Minnesota\n\n******\n[1] Texas\nDate: Sat 15 April 2017\nSource: BABW News [edited]\nhttp://www.babwnews.com/2017/04/huge-disease-outbreak-in-u-s-sends-authorities-scrambling/\n\n\n[Mumps] has suddenly sprung up in the United States, and authorities are trying to figure out how to get a handle on the situation.\n\nA very unpleasant disease [mumps] has reared its ugly head in the United States, and authorities have been trying to understand why it's happening and how to stop it. Health department officials in Texas have announced that cases of mumps have surged to a 20-year high, and there may have been a bunch of exposures on South Padre Island where spring-breakers are celebrating.\n\nState health officials have reported 221 cases of mumps so far this year [2017], the most since 1994 when there were 234 cases. Mumps results in swollen salivary grands, swollen testicles, low fever, tiredness, and muscle aches, with symptoms emerging about 16 -- 18 days after exposure.\n\nInfections of mumps dived 99 percent since a vaccine was developed and released in 1967. The mumps vaccine protects 88 percent of people who are fully vaccinated, although some vaccinated people can still get sick if exposed.\n\n\"The Texas Department of State Health Services is advising health care providers to be on alert for mumps in their patients as the state experiences a 20-year high in mumps cases,\" states the THHS website \"State, regional and local health departments are currently investigating multiple outbreaks throughout the state, including one involving possible exposures on South Padre Island, a popular spring break destination for students from Texas and elsewhere in the United States. Texas has had 221 mumps cases this year [2017], the largest total since there were 234 cases in 1994.\"\n\n[Byline: Dan Taylor]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Texas, Dallas County\nDate: Wed 19 Apr 2017\nSource: FOX4News [edited]\nhttp://www.fox4news.com/news/249605964-story\n\n\nCedar Hill ISD officials held a forum [Wed 19 Apr 2017] night to provide more information to concerned parents about a severe mumps outbreak.\n\nDallas County Health and Human Services reports 84 mumps cases so far in 2017 [see [1] above, 221 cases total in state].\n\nUp to 64 of those cases are students and teachers in Cedar Hill ISD, with 3 more cases in DeSoto. Health officials have also identified 17 unrelated cases in Mesquite, Dallas and DeSoto.\n\nParents at the meeting submitted questions. Many wanted to know how the mumps is spreading and why.\n\n\"You heard about the chicken pox, you heard about the meningitis, but the mumps you haven't heard about in so long, so you're kind of concerned, like can it cause death?\" said parent [SA].\n\n[A] has a daughter at Cedar Hill High School. Her child is vaccinated, but [A] is still concerned about the mumps outbreak that started at her child's school.\n\n\"What are we doing about this mumps outbreak? Are we cleaning the building?\" [A] asked.\n\nDistrict officials said the outbreak started at Cedar Hill High School in February [2017].\n\nSince then, more cases have been found at 9th Grade Center, Collegiate High School, Permenter Middle School and High Pointe Elementary. \"When you get a bunch of kids all contained in small pockets of areas, like schools, the likelihood of spreading an airborne virus is gonna happen,\" said Cedar Hill ISD superintendent Orlando Riddick.\n\nOfficials don't know the source but said they're doing their best to keep the situation under control.\n\n\"We've started our cleaning processes and cleaning high touch areas,\" superintendent Riddick said. \"We began to disinfect schools with a misting machine.\"\n\nThe district has also hosted 4 vaccine booster clinics, saying more than 90 percent of their students are vaccinated.\n\nThe district's health director, Dr Michael Marshall, said infected people could be unknowingly spreading mumps.\n\n\"The problem is simply that people are coming to school who are infected with the mumps and they don't know it,\" said Dr Marshall.\n\nAccording to doctors, it can take up to 25 days until symptoms like fever, headache and loss of appetite show up. Some who are infected have no symptoms.\n\nParent [AG] said the district should be transparent about the outbreak. \"Just be transparent and make sure our building is clean and that it's safe for our children and teachers,\"[G] said.\n\nAccording to health officials, those without the mumps vaccine are most at risk. Doctors recommend at least 2 vaccines, and even a 3rd booster shot to increase protection. However, one can still get mumps even with the proper vaccines.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3] Minnesota\nDate: Fri 21 APR 2017 11:30 PM\nSource: CBS News [edited]\nhttp://www.cbsnews.com/news/mumps-outbreak-reported-at-university-of-minnesota/\n\n\nUniversity of Minnesota health officials are warning students about a mumps outbreak on campus, CBS Minnesota reports.\n\nSo far there have been 6 reported cases, campus health officials say.\n\nIt's considered highly contagious and the disease is spread by coughing, sneezing or sharing items that you eat or drink.\n\nThe symptoms are pretty clear -- puffy cheeks, a swollen jaw accompanied by a fever, headaches and loss of appetite.\n\n\"I've been at Boynton Health for 20 years and we have not had this situation before,\" said Dr Gary Christenson, the chief medical officer at the University of Minnesota.\n\nChristenson said students are required to be vaccinated for mumps before they come to school, with a few exceptions. But even then, it's still possible to contract the disease.\n\nUp to 6 reported cases of mumps so far at the University may not seem like a large number. But on a campus like this, Christenson said anything over 3 cases is considered an outbreak.\n\n\"One of the challenges of mumps is that for the 1st 2 days that someone has it, before they have symptoms, they are already shedding or can be exposing other people to it,\" said Christenson.\n\nA couple years ago, the Minnesota Wild got caught in a mumps outbreak. And in February, the mumps again briefly sidelined forwards [ZP] and [JP]. Students believe that if it can spread quickly on a hockey team, it can spread just as quickly on campus.\n\n\"If you are at the library or something, this is such a huge school, it's so hard for things not to be spread around,\" said senior Maddie Trenholm.\n\nThat's why health officials are asking students or faculty who has been diagnosed to stay away for 5 days.\n\n\"It's really hard to predict how long this will be an issue and how many cases we might have,\" said Christenson.\n\nAnd with finals coming up, they are hoping to keep this from spreading as much as possible. The cases the university has seen so far are considered mild.\n\nA US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention report in December 2016 shows that mumps are at a 10-year high -- and colleges seem to be especially hard hit by the contagious virus. The close quarters on campus make it easy for the disease to spread.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[From 1 Jan -- 25 Mar 2017, 42 states and the District of Columbia in the US reported 1965 cases of mumps to CDC.\n\nFrom year to year, mumps cases can range from roughly a couple hundred to a couple thousand. For example in 2016, there were approximately 5748 cases reported to CDC, and in 2012, there were 229. Before the US mumps vaccination program started in 1967, about 186 000 cases were reported each year, but the actual number of cases was likely much higher due to underreporting. Since the pre-vaccine era, there has been more than 99 percent decrease in mumps cases in the United States.\n\n(excerpted / edited from CDC.gov). - Mod.LK\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/354.]\nSee Also\nMumps update (15): New Zealand, USA 20170408.4958345\nMumps update (14): Australia (QL), USA 20170330.4935375\nMumps update (13): Portugal, accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/354.]\nSee Also\nMumps update (15): New Zealand, USA 20170408.4958345\nMumps update (14): Australia (QL), USA 20170330.4935375\nMumps update (13): Portugal, 20160225.4050452\n.................................................sb/lk/ec/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "mumps", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-04-15 00:00:00", "1994-03-16 00:00:00", "1967-03-16 00:00:00", "1994-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-02-16 00:00:00", "2021-02-16 00:00:00", "2016-12-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "1965-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "1967-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2033-03-16 00:00:00", "2032-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00", "2021-03-28 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Dallas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Portugal", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MT", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MINNESOTA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "TEXAS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York City", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mesquite", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NE", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the District of Columbia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Parent", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Dallas County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5049677", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps update (18): USA", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5049677", "date": "2017-04-23 08:21:48", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (16): USA (TEXAS, MINNESOTA)\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Texas\n[2] Texas, Dallas County\n[3] Minnesota\n\n******\n[1] Texas\nDate: Sat 15 April 2017\nSource: BABW News [edited]\nhttp://www.babwnews.com/2017/04/huge-disease-outbreak-in-u-s-sends-authorities-scrambling/\n\n\n[Mumps] has suddenly sprung up in the United States, and authorities are trying to figure out how to get a handle on the situation.\n\nA very unpleasant disease [mumps] has reared its ugly head in the United States, and authorities have been trying to understand why it's happening and how to stop it. Health department officials in Texas have announced that cases of mumps have surged to a 20-year high, and there may have been a bunch of exposures on South Padre Island where spring-breakers are celebrating.\n\nState health officials have reported 221 cases of mumps so far this year [2017], the most since 1994 when there were 234 cases. Mumps results in swollen salivary grands, swollen testicles, low fever, tiredness, and muscle aches, with symptoms emerging about 16 -- 18 days after exposure.\n\nInfections of mumps dived 99 percent since a vaccine was developed and released in 1967. The mumps vaccine protects 88 percent of people who are fully vaccinated, although some vaccinated people can still get sick if exposed.\n\n\"The Texas Department of State Health Services is advising health care providers to be on alert for mumps in their patients as the state experiences a 20-year high in mumps cases,\" states the THHS website \"State, regional and local health departments are currently investigating multiple outbreaks throughout the state, including one involving possible exposures on South Padre Island, a popular spring break destination for students from Texas and elsewhere in the United States. Texas has had 221 mumps cases this year [2017], the largest total since there were 234 cases in 1994.\"\n\n[Byline: Dan Taylor]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Texas, Dallas County\nDate: Wed 19 Apr 2017\nSource: FOX4News [edited]\nhttp://www.fox4news.com/news/249605964-story\n\n\nCedar Hill ISD officials held a forum [Wed 19 Apr 2017] night to provide more information to concerned parents about a severe mumps outbreak.\n\nDallas County Health and Human Services reports 84 mumps cases so far in 2017 [see [1] above, 221 cases total in state].\n\nUp to 64 of those cases are students and teachers in Cedar Hill ISD, with 3 more cases in DeSoto. Health officials have also identified 17 unrelated cases in Mesquite, Dallas and DeSoto.\n\nParents at the meeting submitted questions. Many wanted to know how the mumps is spreading and why.\n\n\"You heard about the chicken pox, you heard about the meningitis, but the mumps you haven't heard about in so long, so you're kind of concerned, like can it cause death?\" said parent [SA].\n\n[A] has a daughter at Cedar Hill High School. Her child is vaccinated, but [A] is still concerned about the mumps outbreak that started at her child's school.\n\n\"What are we doing about this mumps outbreak? Are we cleaning the building?\" [A] asked.\n\nDistrict officials said the outbreak started at Cedar Hill High School in February [2017].\n\nSince then, more cases have been found at 9th Grade Center, Collegiate High School, Permenter Middle School and High Pointe Elementary. \"When you get a bunch of kids all contained in small pockets of areas, like schools, the likelihood of spreading an airborne virus is gonna happen,\" said Cedar Hill ISD superintendent Orlando Riddick.\n\nOfficials don't know the source but said they're doing their best to keep the situation under control.\n\n\"We've started our cleaning processes and cleaning high touch areas,\" superintendent Riddick said. \"We began to disinfect schools with a misting machine.\"\n\nThe district has also hosted 4 vaccine booster clinics, saying more than 90 percent of their students are vaccinated.\n\nThe district's health director, Dr Michael Marshall, said infected people could be unknowingly spreading mumps.\n\n\"The problem is simply that people are coming to school who are infected with the mumps and they don't know it,\" said Dr Marshall.\n\nAccording to doctors, it can take up to 25 days until symptoms like fever, headache and loss of appetite show up. Some who are infected have no symptoms.\n\nParent [AG] said the district should be transparent about the outbreak. \"Just be transparent and make sure our building is clean and that it's safe for our children and teachers,\"[G] said.\n\nAccording to health officials, those without the mumps vaccine are most at risk. Doctors recommend at least 2 vaccines, and even a 3rd booster shot to increase protection. However, one can still get mumps even with the proper vaccines.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3] Minnesota\nDate: Fri 21 APR 2017 11:30 PM\nSource: CBS News [edited]\nhttp://www.cbsnews.com/news/mumps-outbreak-reported-at-university-of-minnesota/\n\n\nUniversity of Minnesota health officials are warning students about a mumps outbreak on campus, CBS Minnesota reports.\n\nSo far there have been 6 reported cases, campus health officials say.\n\nIt's considered highly contagious and the disease is spread by coughing, sneezing or sharing items that you eat or drink.\n\nThe symptoms are pretty clear -- puffy cheeks, a swollen jaw accompanied by a fever, headaches and loss of appetite.\n\n\"I've been at Boynton Health for 20 years and we have not had this situation before,\" said Dr Gary Christenson, the chief medical officer at the University of Minnesota.\n\nChristenson said students are required to be vaccinated for mumps before they come to school, with a few exceptions. But even then, it's still possible to contract the disease.\n\nUp to 6 reported cases of mumps so far at the University may not seem like a large number. But on a campus like this, Christenson said anything over 3 cases is considered an outbreak.\n\n\"One of the challenges of mumps is that for the 1st 2 days that someone has it, before they have symptoms, they are already shedding or can be exposing other people to it,\" said Christenson.\n\nA couple years ago, the Minnesota Wild got caught in a mumps outbreak. And in February, the mumps again briefly sidelined forwards [ZP] and [JP]. Students believe that if it can spread quickly on a hockey team, it can spread just as quickly on campus.\n\n\"If you are at the library or something, this is such a huge school, it's so hard for things not to be spread around,\" said senior Maddie Trenholm.\n\nThat's why health officials are asking students or faculty who has been diagnosed to stay away for 5 days.\n\n\"It's really hard to predict how long this will be an issue and how many cases we might have,\" said Christenson.\n\nAnd with finals coming up, they are hoping to keep this from spreading as much as possible. The cases the university has seen so far are considered mild.\n\nA US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention report in December 2016 shows that mumps are at a 10-year high -- and colleges seem to be especially hard hit by the contagious virus. The close quarters on campus make it easy for the disease to spread.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[From 1 Jan -- 25 Mar 2017, 42 states and the District of Columbia in the US reported 1965 cases of mumps to CDC.\n\nFrom year to year, mumps cases can range from roughly a couple hundred to a couple thousand. For example in 2016, there were approximately 5748 cases reported to CDC, and in 2012, there were 229. Before the US mumps vaccination program started in 1967, about 186 000 cases were reported each year, but the actual number of cases was likely much higher due to underreporting. Since the pre-vaccine era, there has been more than 99 percent decrease in mumps cases in the United States.\n\n(excerpted / edited from CDC.gov). - Mod.LK\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/354.]\nSee Also\nMumps update (15): New Zealand, USA 20170408.4958345\nMumps update (14): Australia (QL), USA 20170330.4935375\nMumps update (13): Portugal, Minnesota\n\n******\n[1] Texas\nDate: Sat 15 April 2017\nSource: BABW News [edited]\nhttp://www.babwnews.com/2017/04/huge-disease-outbreak-in-u-s-sends-authorities-scrambling/\n\n\n[Mumps] has suddenly sprung up in the United States, and authorities are trying to figure out how to get a handle on the situation.\n\nA very unpleasant disease [mumps] has reared its ugly head in the United States, and authorities have been trying to understand why it's happening and how to stop it. Health department officials in Texas have announced that cases of mumps have surged to a 20-year high, and there may have been a bunch of exposures on South Padre Island where spring-breakers are celebrating.\n\nState health officials have reported 221 cases of mumps so far this year [2017], the most since 1994 when there were 234 cases. The mumps vaccine protects 88 percent of people who are fully vaccinated, although some vaccinated people can still get sick if exposed.\n\n\"The Texas Department of State Health Services is advising health care providers to be on alert for mumps in their patients as the state experiences a 20-year high in mumps cases,\" states the THHS website \"State, regional and local health departments are currently investigating multiple outbreaks throughout the state, including one involving possible exposures on South Padre Island, a popular spring break destination for students from Texas and elsewhere in the United States. Health officials have also identified 17 unrelated cases in Mesquite, Dallas and DeSoto.\n\nParents at the meeting submitted questions. Many wanted to know how the mumps is spreading and why.\n\n\"You heard about the chicken pox, you heard about the meningitis, but the mumps you haven't heard about in so long, so you're kind of concerned, like can it cause death?\" said parent [SA].\n\n[A] has a daughter at Cedar Hill High School. Her child is vaccinated, but [A] is still concerned about the mumps outbreak that started at her child's school.\n\n\"What are we doing about this mumps outbreak? Are we cleaning the building?\" [A] asked.\n\nDistrict officials said the outbreak started at Cedar Hill High School in February [2017].\n\nSince then, more cases have been found at 9th Grade Center, Collegiate High School, Permenter Middle School and High Pointe Elementary. \"When you get a bunch of kids all contained in small pockets of areas, like schools, the likelihood of spreading an airborne virus is gonna happen,\" said Cedar Hill ISD superintendent Orlando Riddick.\n\nOfficials don't know the source but said they're doing their best to keep the situation under control.\n\n\"We've started our cleaning processes and cleaning high touch areas,\" superintendent Riddick said. \"We began to disinfect schools with a misting machine.\"\n\nThe district has also hosted 4 vaccine booster clinics, saying more than 90 percent of their students are vaccinated.\n\nThe district's health director, Dr Michael Marshall, said infected people could be unknowingly spreading mumps.\n\n\"The problem is simply that people are coming to school who are infected with the mumps and they don't know it,\" said Dr Marshall.\n\nAccording to doctors, it can take up to 25 days until symptoms like fever, headache and loss of appetite show up. Some who are infected have no symptoms.\n\nParent [AG] said the district should be transparent about the outbreak. \"Just be transparent and make sure our building is clean and that it's safe for our children and teachers,\"[G] said.\n\nAccording to health officials, those without the mumps vaccine are most at risk. Doctors recommend at least 2 vaccines, and even a 3rd booster shot to increase protection. However, one can still get mumps even with the proper vaccines.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3] Minnesota\nDate: Fri 21 APR 2017 11:30 PM\nSource: CBS News [edited]\nhttp://www.cbsnews.com/news/mumps-outbreak-reported-at-university-of-minnesota/\n\n\nUniversity of Minnesota health officials are warning students about a mumps outbreak on campus, CBS Minnesota reports.\n\nSo far there have been 6 reported cases, campus health officials say.\n\nIt's considered highly contagious and the disease is spread by coughing, sneezing or sharing items that you eat or drink.\n\nThe symptoms are pretty clear -- puffy cheeks, a swollen jaw accompanied by a fever, headaches and loss of appetite.\n\n\"I've been at Boynton Health for 20 years and we have not had this situation before,\" said Dr Gary Christenson, the chief medical officer at the University of Minnesota.\n\nChristenson said students are required to be vaccinated for mumps before they come to school, with a few exceptions. But even then, it's still possible to contract the disease.\n\nUp to 6 reported cases of mumps so far at the University may not seem like a large number. But on a campus like this, Christenson said anything over 3 cases is considered an outbreak.\n\n\"One of the challenges of mumps is that for the 1st 2 days that someone has it, before they have symptoms, they are already shedding or can be exposing other people to it,\" said Christenson.\n\nA couple years ago, the Minnesota Wild got caught in a mumps outbreak. And in February, the mumps again briefly sidelined forwards [ZP] and [JP]. Students believe that if it can spread quickly on a hockey team, it can spread just as quickly on campus.\n\n\"If you are at the library or something, this is such a huge school, it's so hard for things not to be spread around,\" said senior Maddie Trenholm.\n\nThat's why health officials are asking students or faculty who has been diagnosed to stay away for 5 days.\n\n\"It's really hard to predict how long this will be an issue and how many cases we might have,\" said Christenson.\n\nAnd with finals coming up, they are hoping to keep this from spreading as much as possible. The cases the university has seen so far are considered mild.\n\nA US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention report in December 2016 shows that mumps are at a 10-year high -- and colleges seem to be especially hard hit by the contagious virus. The close quarters on campus make it easy for the disease to spread.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[From 1 Jan -- 25 Mar 2017, 42 states and the District of Columbia in the US reported 1965 cases of mumps to CDC.\n\nFrom year to year, mumps cases can range from roughly a couple hundred to a couple thousand. For example in 2016, there were approximately 5748 cases reported to CDC, and in 2012, there were 229. Before the US mumps vaccination program started in 1967, about 186 000 cases were reported each year, but the actual number of cases was likely much higher due to underreporting. Since the pre-vaccine era, there has been more than 99 percent decrease in mumps cases in the United States.\n\n(excerpted / edited from CDC.gov). - Mod.LK\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/354.]\nSee Also\nMumps update (15): New Zealand, USA 20170408.4958345\nMumps update (14): Australia (QL), USA 20170330.4935375\nMumps update (13): Portugal, 20160225.4050452\n.................................................sb/lk/ec/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "mumps", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-04-15 00:00:00", "1994-03-16 00:00:00", "1967-03-16 00:00:00", "1994-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-02-16 00:00:00", "2021-02-16 00:00:00", "2016-12-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "1965-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "1967-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2033-03-16 00:00:00", "2032-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00", "2021-03-28 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 "Dallas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Portugal", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MT", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4988318", "date": "2017-04-23 08:21:48", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (16): USA (TEXAS, MINNESOTA)\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Texas\n[2] Texas, Dallas County\n[3] Minnesota\n\n******\n[1] Texas\nDate: Sat 15 April 2017\nSource: BABW News [edited]\nhttp://www.babwnews.com/2017/04/huge-disease-outbreak-in-u-s-sends-authorities-scrambling/\n\n\n[Mumps] has suddenly sprung up in the United States, and authorities are trying to figure out how to get a handle on the situation.\n\nA very unpleasant disease [mumps] has reared its ugly head in the United States, and authorities have been trying to understand why it's happening and how to stop it. Health department officials in Texas have announced that cases of mumps have surged to a 20-year high, and there may have been a bunch of exposures on South Padre Island where spring-breakers are celebrating.\n\nState health officials have reported 221 cases of mumps so far this year [2017], the most since 1994 when there were 234 cases. Mumps results in swollen salivary grands, swollen testicles, low fever, tiredness, and muscle aches, with symptoms emerging about 16 -- 18 days after exposure.\n\nInfections of mumps dived 99 percent since a vaccine was developed and released in 1967. The mumps vaccine protects 88 percent of people who are fully vaccinated, although some vaccinated people can still get sick if exposed.\n\n\"The Texas Department of State Health Services is advising health care providers to be on alert for mumps in their patients as the state experiences a 20-year high in mumps cases,\" states the THHS website \"State, regional and local health departments are currently investigating multiple outbreaks throughout the state, including one involving possible exposures on South Padre Island, a popular spring break destination for students from Texas and elsewhere in the United States. Texas has had 221 mumps cases this year [2017], the largest total since there were 234 cases in 1994.\"\n\n[Byline: Dan Taylor]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Texas, Dallas County\nDate: Wed 19 Apr 2017\nSource: FOX4News [edited]\nhttp://www.fox4news.com/news/249605964-story\n\n\nCedar Hill ISD officials held a forum [Wed 19 Apr 2017] night to provide more information to concerned parents about a severe mumps outbreak.\n\nDallas County Health and Human Services reports 84 mumps cases so far in 2017 [see [1] above, 221 cases total in state].\n\nUp to 64 of those cases are students and teachers in Cedar Hill ISD, with 3 more cases in DeSoto. Health officials have also identified 17 unrelated cases in Mesquite, Dallas and DeSoto.\n\nParents at the meeting submitted questions. Many wanted to know how the mumps is spreading and why.\n\n\"You heard about the chicken pox, you heard about the meningitis, but the mumps you haven't heard about in so long, so you're kind of concerned, like can it cause death?\" said parent [SA].\n\n[A] has a daughter at Cedar Hill High School. Her child is vaccinated, but [A] is still concerned about the mumps outbreak that started at her child's school.\n\n\"What are we doing about this mumps outbreak? Are we cleaning the building?\" [A] asked.\n\nDistrict officials said the outbreak started at Cedar Hill High School in February [2017].\n\nSince then, more cases have been found at 9th Grade Center, Collegiate High School, Permenter Middle School and High Pointe Elementary. \"When you get a bunch of kids all contained in small pockets of areas, like schools, the likelihood of spreading an airborne virus is gonna happen,\" said Cedar Hill ISD superintendent Orlando Riddick.\n\nOfficials don't know the source but said they're doing their best to keep the situation under control.\n\n\"We've started our cleaning processes and cleaning high touch areas,\" superintendent Riddick said. \"We began to disinfect schools with a misting machine.\"\n\nThe district has also hosted 4 vaccine booster clinics, saying more than 90 percent of their students are vaccinated.\n\nThe district's health director, Dr Michael Marshall, said infected people could be unknowingly spreading mumps.\n\n\"The problem is simply that people are coming to school who are infected with the mumps and they don't know it,\" said Dr Marshall.\n\nAccording to doctors, it can take up to 25 days until symptoms like fever, headache and loss of appetite show up. Some who are infected have no symptoms.\n\nParent [AG] said the district should be transparent about the outbreak. \"Just be transparent and make sure our building is clean and that it's safe for our children and teachers,\"[G] said.\n\nAccording to health officials, those without the mumps vaccine are most at risk. Doctors recommend at least 2 vaccines, and even a 3rd booster shot to increase protection. However, one can still get mumps even with the proper vaccines.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3] Minnesota\nDate: Fri 21 APR 2017 11:30 PM\nSource: CBS News [edited]\nhttp://www.cbsnews.com/news/mumps-outbreak-reported-at-university-of-minnesota/\n\n\nUniversity of Minnesota health officials are warning students about a mumps outbreak on campus, CBS Minnesota reports.\n\nSo far there have been 6 reported cases, campus health officials say.\n\nIt's considered highly contagious and the disease is spread by coughing, sneezing or sharing items that you eat or drink.\n\nThe symptoms are pretty clear -- puffy cheeks, a swollen jaw accompanied by a fever, headaches and loss of appetite.\n\n\"I've been at Boynton Health for 20 years and we have not had this situation before,\" said Dr Gary Christenson, the chief medical officer at the University of Minnesota.\n\nChristenson said students are required to be vaccinated for mumps before they come to school, with a few exceptions. But even then, it's still possible to contract the disease.\n\nUp to 6 reported cases of mumps so far at the University may not seem like a large number. But on a campus like this, Christenson said anything over 3 cases is considered an outbreak.\n\n\"One of the challenges of mumps is that for the 1st 2 days that someone has it, before they have symptoms, they are already shedding or can be exposing other people to it,\" said Christenson.\n\nA couple years ago, the Minnesota Wild got caught in a mumps outbreak. And in February, the mumps again briefly sidelined forwards [ZP] and [JP]. Students believe that if it can spread quickly on a hockey team, it can spread just as quickly on campus.\n\n\"If you are at the library or something, this is such a huge school, it's so hard for things not to be spread around,\" said senior Maddie Trenholm.\n\nThat's why health officials are asking students or faculty who has been diagnosed to stay away for 5 days.\n\n\"It's really hard to predict how long this will be an issue and how many cases we might have,\" said Christenson.\n\nAnd with finals coming up, they are hoping to keep this from spreading as much as possible. The cases the university has seen so far are considered mild.\n\nA US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention report in December 2016 shows that mumps are at a 10-year high -- and colleges seem to be especially hard hit by the contagious virus. The close quarters on campus make it easy for the disease to spread.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[From 1 Jan -- 25 Mar 2017, 42 states and the District of Columbia in the US reported 1965 cases of mumps to CDC.\n\nFrom year to year, mumps cases can range from roughly a couple hundred to a couple thousand. For example in 2016, there were approximately 5748 cases reported to CDC, and in 2012, there were 229. Before the US mumps vaccination program started in 1967, about 186 000 cases were reported each year, but the actual number of cases was likely much higher due to underreporting. Since the pre-vaccine era, there has been more than 99 percent decrease in mumps cases in the United States.\n\n(excerpted / edited from CDC.gov). - Mod.LK\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/354.]\nSee Also\nMumps update (15): New Zealand, USA 20170408.4958345\nMumps update (14): Australia (QL), USA 20170330.4935375\nMumps update (13): Portugal,
