{"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4895943", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps update (09)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4895943", "date": "2017-03-05 16:42:38", "main_text": "MUMPS UPDATE (08): CANADA, USA, COMMENT\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Canada (Ontario, Toronto)\n[2] Canada (New Brunswick, Alberta)\n[3] USA (Pennsylvania)\n[4] USA (Missouri)\n[5] Comment in response to RFI in ProMED posts Mumps update (05) & (06)\n\n******\n[1] Canada (Ontario, Toronto)\nDate: Thu 2 Mar 2017\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/toronto-mumps-outbreak-rises-18-54425/\n\n\nIn a follow-up on the mumps outbreak in Toronto, city health officials report 4 additional cases since the outbreak was 1st reported approximately one week ago.\n\nCurrently, there have been 18 confirmed cases of mumps in Toronto in 2017 as of 1 Mar 2017, according to Toronto Public Health.\n\nThe outbreak is primarily affecting young adults, 18 to 35 years of age. Earlier reports on the investigation note that many of these cases have frequented bars in the west downtown core of Toronto.\n\nThe mumps virus is found in saliva and respiratory droplets. It is spread from person to person through coughing, sneezing, and coming into contact with a person's saliva by sharing drinks or utensils, food or water bottles, or by kissing. A major factor contributing to outbreaks is being in a crowded environment, such as attending the same class, playing on the same sports team or living in a dormitory with a person who has the mumps.\n\n[Byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As of 4 Mar 2017, another 5 cases of mumps have been confirmed in Toronto, bringing the total to 22 this year (2017) in Toronto. Clusters of mumps cases have also emerged in the Prairies and Western Canada http://toronto.ctvnews.ca/toronto-mumps-outbreak-rises-to-22-cases-1.3309598. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[2] Canada (New Brunswick; Alberta)\nDate: Thu 2 Mar 2017\nSource: Global News [edited]\nhttp://globalnews.ca/news/3283698/new-brunswicks-top-doctor-stresses-importance-of-proper-vaccination-confirms-two-cases-of-mumps/\n\n\nThe province's acting chief medical officer of health is reminding people about the importance of ensuring that their vaccinations are up to date. Dr. Jennifer Russell said 2 cases of mumps have been confirmed in New Brunswick, along with an outbreak of whooping cough.\n\n\"Certainly, right now is the time to get checked to see if your vaccines are up to date for yourself and for your children,\" Russell said.\n\nThree more mumps cases have been confirmed in Edmonton; Alberta's total has risen to 21.\n\nRussell said it's \"concerning\" to have mumps in the province. According to the New Brunswick Department of Health's Routine Immunization Schedule, adults born after 1970 should have a 2nd booster vaccine to ensure they are protected.\n\n\"When we have a disease that has a vaccine that allows you to prevent it, we want people to get those vaccines because it's really, really important, not just for their own health or for their children's health, but also for the health of the people around them who either can't get immunized, or maybe the immunization didn't quite work as well for them,\" Russell said.\n\nShe said that the more people who get vaccinated, the safer everyone is in New Brunswick.\n\n\"I'm not able to disclose any demographic information at this time, but just to say that we do have 2 cases right now, and they are connected; there was some contact,\" Russell said.\n\nComplications from mumps can include meningitis, swollen testicles, and permanent deafness.\n\nRussell said there are no current cases of measles in New Brunswick but said it's something that can appear occasionally in the province.\n\nNew Brunswickers are encouraged to check with their health care provider or contact public health offices for more information on whether they need to update their vaccinations.\n\nDr. Russell said there is a current pertussis outbreak, more commonly known as whooping cough, in the Fredericton region.\n\nShe told Global News that the regional medical officer of health will be sending out a note to health care providers.\n\nRussell said there is a whooping cough vaccination given to children, but noted adults also require a booster shot. She said there can be complications from whooping cough that could result in death.\n\n[Byline: Adrienne South]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Whooping cough, or pertussis, is a serious disease that can cause babies to stop breathing. It is a vaccine-preventable disease that without vaccination is a very contagious disease that is most serious for babies. People with whooping cough usually spread the disease by coughing or sneezing while in close contact with others. Parents, older siblings, or other caregivers can give whooping cough to babies without even knowing they have the disease.\n\nYoung babies can get pneumonia (lung infection), and many have trouble breathing. About half of babies younger than one year old who get whooping cough end up in the hospital, and a few even die from the disease.\n\nBabies need protection because they can catch whooping cough from anyone around them, and it can make them very sick. Babies get protection from whooping cough vaccines in 3 important ways:\n- Through the Mother when she gets the whooping cough vaccine in the 3rd trimester of pregnancy.\n- By being surrounded with family members and caregivers who are up-to-date with their whooping cough vaccine.\n- By getting all doses of the whooping cough vaccine according to CDC's recommended schedule [excerpted and edited from CDC].\n\nA map of Canada showing the location of New Brunswick province can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/269. A map of Canada showing the location of Alberta can be found at https://binged.it/2m8sPen. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[3] USA (Pennsylvania)\nDate: Fri 3 Mar 2017\nSource: WJAC [edited]\nhttp://wjactv.com/news/local/possible-mumps-cases-at-penn-state-rises-to-27\n\n\nPenn State University is investigating a suspected outbreak of mumps after 27 \"suspected, probable or confirmed\" cases have been reported on campus.\n\nAccording to a news release from the school, 6 of the 27 cases have been confirmed by lab tests [Now, 12 cases have been confirmed (http://bit.ly/2m6zPZb). - Mod.LK].\n\nThe 1st case was diagnosed in late January [2017], and the school is now urging students and staff who are showing symptoms to remain isolated to help prevent the spread of the illness.\n\nPenn State said those infected should not immediately return to school following spring break.\n\nThe state's health department is continuing to monitor the situation alongside the school.\n\n[Byline: Lauren Petrelli]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map of the USA showing the location of Pennsylvania and Missouri can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/240.]\n\n******\n[4] USA (Missouri)\nDate: Sun 5 Mar 2017\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/southeast-missouri-state-university-reports-15-mumps-cases-vaccine-clinics-scheduled-next-week-16881/\n\n\nIn light of recent reports of 15 confirmed mumps cases on the Southeast Missouri State University campus, The Missouri Department of Health and Senior Services has updated its recommendation and is encouraging all Southeast Missouri State University students to consider getting a 3rd dose of the measles, mumps and rubella (MMR) vaccine in response to continued confirmed and suspected cases of mumps at the school.\n\nBecause the majority of those cases are within the fraternity and sorority community, the Cape Girardeau Public Health Center, with assistance from the Campus Health Clinic, will host a vaccination clinic for all members of the Greek Community, including those living on- and off-campus. ... This vaccination clinic is specifically for members of Southeast's Greek community, who health officials say have the greatest known risk factors and where the confirmed mumps cases are most concentrated.\n\nStudents who are not members of a fraternity or sorority can get a 3rd MMR dose by visiting the Campus Health Clinic. ... Students who are not part of the Greek community have a lower risk of contracting mumps based upon currently confirmed and suspected cases.\n\nThe reports at Southeast come on the heels of a mumps outbreak on the campus of the University of Missouri-Columbia reported this past fall [2016]. At the University of Missouri-Columbia, 350 confirmed and probable cases of mumps have been reported as of 23 Feb 2017.\n\nAccording to the Missouri Department of Health and Senior Services, the majority of cases continue to be reported among university students; 14 other colleges and universities across the State of Missouri have reported confirmed or suspected cases of mumps since August 2016.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[There has been an increasing number of reports of mumps cases on campuses in the US because of the lifestyle of students and their age, which reflects time since a 2nd vaccination with MMR (measles, mumps, rubella) vaccine. The mumps component of the MMR vaccine is about 88 percent effective when a person gets 2 doses. More than 5000 cases of mumps were reported last year, 2016, in the United States, of which 19 outbreaks occurred on college campuses. This is the most in a decade. But importantly, even with infection with the mumps virus, those who have been vaccinated have fewer severe complications. A 3rd vaccine dose is being considered as a preventative measure. There is some evidence that this additional dose may help control mumps outbreaks among populations with preexisting high 2-dose vaccine coverage. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[5] Comment in response to RFI in ProMED-mail posts Mumps update (05) & (06)\nDate: Sun 5 Mar 2017\nFrom: Kamran Kadkhoda <kamrankadkhoda@gmail.com> [edited]\n\n\n[Dr. Kadkhoda is responding to the RFI concerning the high incidence of mumps in previously vaccinated individuals, particularly young adults. From his response below, there clearly are a number of avenues to pursue to more fully understand the problem. ProMED-mail thanks Dr. Kadkhoda for his response. - Mod.LK]:\n\nThe best explanation so far is secondary vaccine failure/waning immunity: during the 1st decade or so after the vaccine, which uses genotype A strains, there's adequate cross-neutralization across different mumps genotypes, but after neutralization, capacity against non-A genotypes such as G wanes, then people may come down with clinical mumps. It'll be intriguing to see whether sub-neutralizing anti-mumps antibody levels help a new infection establish itself through antibody-dependent enhancement. It is also known that some HLA haplotypes play a role even in primary vaccine failure. All in all, significant pathogen inoculum should be another important factor on top of those mentioned above.\n\n--\nKamran Kadkhoda, Ph.D., D(ABMM), D(ABMLI)\nAssistant Professor - Clinical Microbiologist\nCadham Provincial Public Health Laboratory\nAdjunct Professor - Department of Immunology\nUniversity of Manitoba\nInvestigator at Children's Hospital Research Institute of Manitoba (CHRIM)\n<kamrankadkhoda@gmail.com>\nSee Also\nMumps update (07): Canada, USA 20170303.4875855\nMumps update (06): USA 20170227.4864176\nMumps update (05): USA (PA, MO - RFI), Canada (ON, AB) Brunswick, Alberta)\n[3] USA (Pennsylvania)\n[4] USA (Missouri)\n[5] Comment in response to RFI in ProMED posts Mumps update (05) & (06)\n\n******\n[1] Canada (Ontario, Toronto)\nDate: Thu 2 Mar 2017\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/toronto-mumps-outbreak-rises-18-54425/\n\n\nIn a follow-up on the mumps outbreak in Toronto, city health officials report 4 additional cases since the outbreak was 1st reported approximately one week ago.\n\nCurrently, there have been 18 confirmed cases of mumps in Toronto in 2017 as of 1 Mar 2017, according to Toronto Public Health.\n\nThe outbreak is primarily affecting young adults, 18 to 35 years of age. Earlier reports on the investigation note that many of these cases have frequented bars in the west downtown core of Toronto.\n\nThe mumps virus is found in saliva and respiratory droplets. It is spread from person to person through coughing, sneezing, and coming into contact with a person's saliva by sharing drinks or utensils, food or water bottles, or by kissing. A major factor contributing to outbreaks is being in a crowded environment, such as attending the same class, playing on the same sports team or living in a dormitory with a person who has the mumps.\n\n[Byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As of 4 Mar 2017, another 5 cases of mumps have been confirmed in Toronto, bringing the total to 22 this year (2017) in Toronto. Clusters of mumps cases have also emerged in the Prairies and Western Canada http://toronto.ctvnews.ca/toronto-mumps-outbreak-rises-to-22-cases-1.3309598. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[2] Canada (New Brunswick; Alberta)\nDate: Thu 2 Mar 2017\nSource: Global News [edited]\nhttp://globalnews.ca/news/3283698/new-brunswicks-top-doctor-stresses-importance-of-proper-vaccination-confirms-two-cases-of-mumps/\n\n\nThe province's acting chief medical officer of health is reminding people about the importance of ensuring that their vaccinations are up to date. Dr. Jennifer Russell said 2 cases of mumps have been confirmed in New Brunswick, along with an outbreak of whooping cough.\n\n\"Certainly, right now is the time to get checked to see if your vaccines are up to date for yourself and for your children,\" Russell said.\n\nThree more mumps cases have been confirmed in Edmonton; Alberta's total has risen to 21.\n\nRussell said it's \"concerning\" to have mumps in the province. According to the New Brunswick Department of Health's Routine Immunization Schedule, adults born after 1970 should have a 2nd booster vaccine to ensure they are protected.\n\n\"When we have a disease that has a vaccine that allows you to prevent it, we want people to get those vaccines because it's really, really important, not just for their own health or for their children's health, but also for the health of the people around them who either can't get immunized, or maybe the immunization didn't quite work as well for them,\" Russell said.\n\nShe said that the more people who get vaccinated, the safer everyone is in New Brunswick.\n\n\"I'm not able to disclose any demographic information at this time, but just to say that we do have 2 cases right now, and they are connected; there was some contact,\" Russell said.\n\nComplications from mumps can include meningitis, swollen testicles, and permanent deafness.\n\nRussell said there are no current cases of measles in New Brunswick but said it's something that can appear occasionally in the province.\n\nNew Brunswickers are encouraged to check with their health care provider or contact public health offices for more information on whether they need to update their vaccinations.\n\nDr. Russell said there is a current pertussis outbreak, more commonly known as whooping cough, in the Fredericton region.\n\nShe told Global News that the regional medical officer of health will be sending out a note to health care providers.\n\nRussell said there is a whooping cough vaccination given to children, but noted adults also require a booster shot. She said there can be complications from whooping cough that could result in death.\n\n[Byline: Adrienne South]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Whooping cough, or pertussis, is a serious disease that can cause babies to stop breathing. It is a vaccine-preventable disease that without vaccination is a very contagious disease that is most serious for babies. People with whooping cough usually spread the disease by coughing or sneezing while in close contact with others. Parents, older siblings, or other caregivers can give whooping cough to babies without even knowing they have the disease.\n\nYoung babies can get pneumonia (lung infection), and many have trouble breathing. About half of babies younger than one year old who get whooping cough end up in the hospital, and a few even die from the disease.\n\nBabies need protection because they can catch whooping cough from anyone around them, and it can make them very sick. Babies get protection from whooping cough vaccines in 3 important ways:\n- Through the Mother when she gets the whooping cough vaccine in the 3rd trimester of pregnancy.\n- By being surrounded with family members and caregivers who are up-to-date with their whooping cough vaccine.\n- By getting all doses of the whooping cough vaccine according to CDC's recommended schedule [excerpted and edited from CDC].\n\nA map of Canada showing the location of New Brunswick province can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/269. A map of Canada showing the location of Alberta can be found at https://binged.it/2m8sPen. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[3] USA (Pennsylvania)\nDate: Fri 3 Mar 2017\nSource: WJAC [edited]\nhttp://wjactv.com/news/local/possible-mumps-cases-at-penn-state-rises-to-27\n\n\nPenn State University is investigating a suspected outbreak of mumps after 27 \"suspected, probable or confirmed\" cases have been reported on campus.\n\nAccording to a news release from the school, 6 of the 27 cases have been confirmed by lab tests [Now, 12 cases have been confirmed (http://bit.ly/2m6zPZb). - Mod.LK].\n\nThe 1st case was diagnosed in late January [2017], and the school is now urging students and staff who are showing symptoms to remain isolated to help prevent the spread of the illness.\n\nPenn State said those infected should not immediately return to school following spring break.\n\nThe state's health department is continuing to monitor the situation alongside the school.\n\n[Byline: Lauren Petrelli]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map of the USA showing the location of Pennsylvania and Missouri can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/240.]\n\n******\n[4] USA (Missouri)\nDate: Sun 5 Mar 2017\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/southeast-missouri-state-university-reports-15-mumps-cases-vaccine-clinics-scheduled-next-week-16881/\n\n\nIn light of recent reports of 15 confirmed mumps cases on the Southeast Missouri State University campus, The Missouri Department of Health and Senior Services has updated its recommendation and is encouraging all Southeast Missouri State University students to consider getting a 3rd dose of the measles, mumps and rubella (MMR) vaccine in response to continued confirmed and suspected cases of mumps at the school.\n\nBecause the majority of those cases are within the fraternity and sorority community, the Cape Girardeau Public Health Center, with assistance from the Campus Health Clinic, will host a vaccination clinic for all members of the Greek Community, including those living on- and off-campus. ... This vaccination clinic is specifically for members of Southeast's Greek community, who health officials say have the greatest known risk factors and where the confirmed mumps cases are most concentrated.\n\nStudents who are not members of a fraternity or sorority can get a 3rd MMR dose by visiting the Campus Health Clinic. ... Students who are not part of the Greek community have a lower risk of contracting mumps based upon currently confirmed and suspected cases.\n\nThe reports at Southeast come on the heels of a mumps outbreak on the campus of the University of Missouri-Columbia reported this past fall [2016]. At the University of Missouri-Columbia, 350 confirmed and probable cases of mumps have been reported as of 23 Feb 2017.\n\nAccording to the Missouri Department of Health and Senior Services, the majority of cases continue to be reported among university students; 14 other colleges and universities across the State of Missouri have reported confirmed or suspected cases of mumps since August 2016.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[There has been an increasing number of reports of mumps cases on campuses in the US because of the lifestyle of students and their age, which reflects time since a 2nd vaccination with MMR (measles, mumps, rubella) vaccine. The mumps component of the MMR vaccine is about 88 percent effective when a person gets 2 doses. More than 5000 cases of mumps were reported last year, 2016, in the United States, of which 19 outbreaks occurred on college campuses. This is the most in a decade. But importantly, even with infection with the mumps virus, those who have been vaccinated have fewer severe complications. A 3rd vaccine dose is being considered as a preventative measure. There is some evidence that this additional dose may help control mumps outbreaks among populations with preexisting high 2-dose vaccine coverage. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[5] Comment in response to RFI in ProMED-mail posts Mumps update (05) & (06)\nDate: Sun 5 Mar 2017\nFrom: Kamran Kadkhoda <kamrankadkhoda@gmail.com> [edited]\n\n\n[Dr. Kadkhoda is responding to the RFI concerning the high incidence of mumps in previously vaccinated individuals, particularly young adults. From his response below, there clearly are a number of avenues to pursue to more fully understand the problem. ProMED-mail thanks Dr. Kadkhoda for his response. - Mod.LK]:\n\nThe best explanation so far is secondary vaccine failure/waning immunity: during the 1st decade or so after the vaccine, which uses genotype A strains, there's adequate cross-neutralization across different mumps genotypes, but after neutralization, capacity against non-A genotypes such as G wanes, then people may come down with clinical mumps. It'll be intriguing to see whether sub-neutralizing anti-mumps antibody levels help a new infection establish itself through antibody-dependent enhancement. It is also known that some HLA haplotypes play a role even in primary vaccine failure. All in all, significant pathogen inoculum should be another important factor on top of those mentioned above.\n\n--\nKamran Kadkhoda, Ph.D., D(ABMM), D(ABMLI)\nAssistant Professor - Clinical Microbiologist\nCadham Provincial Public Health Laboratory\nAdjunct Professor - Department of Immunology\nUniversity of Manitoba\nInvestigator at Children's Hospital Research Institute of Manitoba (CHRIM)\n<kamrankadkhoda@gmail.com>\nSee Also\nMumps update (07): Canada, USA 20170303.4875855\nMumps update (06): USA 20170227.4864176\nMumps update (05): USA (PA, MO - RFI), Canada (ON, AB) 20160225.4050452\n.................................................sb/lk/msp/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "pertussis", "rubella", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "1970-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-02-23 00:00:00", "2016-08-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2033-03-16 00:00:00", "2032-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00", "2021-03-28 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "wjac", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Alberta", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Toronto", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MT", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Brunswick", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ontario", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Missouri", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4875855", "date": "2016-12-26 10:43:43", "main_text": "MUMPS-USA (34): (ARKANSAS, TEXAS, MISSOURI)\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Arkansas (Marshallese)\n[2] Texas: cheerleading competitions\n[3] Missouri (Kansas City)\n\n******\n[1] Arkansas (Marshallese)\nDate: Fri 23 Dec 2016 5:12 PM EST\nSource: El Nuevo Herald, The Associated Press (AP) report [in Spanish, trans. Mod.LK, edited]\nhttp://www.elnuevoherald.com/vivir-mejor/salud/article122039909.html\n\n\nAccording to health officials, an epidemic of mumps is seriously affecting a community of citizens of the Marshall Islands residents of northwest Arkansas.\n\nCitizens of the Marshall Islands represent approximately 60 percent of the 2220 cases of mumps reported in the state through [Fri 23 Dec 2016]. The Arkansas Democrat-Gazette newspaper reported that the outbreak began in August 2016 (http://bit.ly/2hVVQYf).\n\nNate Smith, director of the State Health Department, said he doesn't know why so many people from the Marshall Islands are infected. Officials are investigating whether the vaccine is less effective for certain people. Smith said that the people of the Marshall Islands tend to live close to each other.\n\n\"It's a bit like a college dormitory in terms of intensity of exposure,\" he explained. Smith added that citizens of the Marshall Islands are involved in many community oriented events, where it is easy for transmission of infections.\n\nThe US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said that the epidemic in Arkansas is the largest since 2009 and 2010 when approximately 3000 people were infected in New York. Smith said that cases of mumps in Arkansas represent more than half of those reported this year [2016] at the national level.\n\nThe Department of Health had vaccinated almost 6600 people up to [Fri 23 Dec 2016]. Smith said that the efforts are showing results because only 12 cases were reported during the last 3 days of last week [week of 12 Dec 2016], \"which is really much less than we had for months.\"\n\nThe Marshall Islands are located in the Pacific Ocean, more than 3200 kilometers (2000 miles) southwest of Hawaii. About 12 000 of its citizens live in Northwest Arkansas.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-ESP\n<promed-esp@promedmail.org>\n\n[Mumps is a viral illness transmitted by the respiratory route, making dissemination possible in gatherings of people. The report does not specify the vaccination coverage of these citizens of the Marshall Islands who have developed the disease, which could be another factor contributing to this outbreak, apart from the possibility of lower effectiveness of the vaccine. It is necessary to investigate further in order to establish with certainty this behavior of the disease. - Mod.JG\n\nSee ProMED-mail Mumps - USA (21) 20161008.4545923 for reports of cases in other states in the United States -- Oklahoma and Washington -- and a discussion of the particular problem of providing protection to the Marshallese in Arkansas against vaccine-preventable diseases.\n\nA map showing the location of Arkansas in the United States can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/208 - Mod. LK]\n\n******\n[2] Texas: cheerleading competitions\nDate: Thu 22 Dec 2016 4:35 PM CST\nSource: KHOU-TV [edited]\nhttp://www.khou.com/news/health/dshs-investigating-two-north-texas-mumps-outbreaks/376855681\n\n\nState health officials are investigating 2 mumps outbreaks, one of which is connected to a series of cheerleading competitions in North Texas.\n\nThe Texas Department State Health Services [DSHS] is working with event organizers to notify those who attended 1 of 4 cheerleading competitions in November and December [2016] that they may have been exposed to mumps. DSHS said it has identified 11 mumps cases associated with this outbreak.\n\nA 2nd outbreak is being investigated in Johnson County, south of Fort Worth. Health officials have identified 72 cases in this outbreak, including 71 Johnson County residents and 1 Tarrant County resident. DSHS is working with school districts in the area to limit its spread since most of the cases are in students.\n\nMumps is spread by droplets of saliva or mucus from the mouth, nose, or throat of an infected person, usually when the infected person coughs, sneezes or talks. The virus can also be spread by sharing cups and utensils.\n\nSymptoms include swollen or tender salivary glands, low fever, tiredness and muscle aches. Men can also exhibit swollen or tender testicles.\n\nDSHS said people who are vaccinated can also contract the virus. The spread of mumps can be prevented or limited by covering coughs and sneezes, washing hands frequently with soap and water, and not sharing food or drinks.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map showing the location of Texas in the United States can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/245. A Texas county map can be found at http://geology.com/county-map/texas-county-map.gif.- Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[3] Missouri (Kansas City)\nDate: Sun 25 Dec 2016\nSource: The Monitor Daily [edited]\nhttp://www.themonitordaily.com/mumps/213109/\n\n\nIf you experience fever, headaches, muscle aches, tiredness, and loss of appetite, it is possible you have contracted mumps.\n\nThe mumps outbreak that has been sweeping through various regions across Missouri lately has spread to Kansas City, as well, according to health officials. At the moment, health agencies state that at least one case of an individual displaying mumps symptoms has been confirmed, says the Kansas City Health Department. As a consequence, an advisory has been issued on Thursday afternoon [22 Dec 2016].\n\nRex Archer, head of the Kansas City Health Department urges people who contracted the disease to stay inside, in order to contain the outbreak, via an official statement. In his plea, Mr Archer asks people to take several days off from either school or work-related duties for at least 5 days after the 1st symptoms emerge, such as the inflammation of the salivary glands. Rex Archer also says that individuals who came in contact with infected people could start displaying mumps symptoms anywhere in between 12 to 25 days after exposure to the virus. Ultimately, he recommends people who develop mumps symptoms to address their health care provider as soon as soon as possible. \"Questions about your immunity or vaccination status should be directed to your private physician\", says Rex Archer.\n\nAs of now, roughly 200 cases of infected individuals have been confirmed by the University of Missouri in Columbia. In order to contain the outbreak, Kansas City Health Department officials say that they are closely monitoring the progression of the local case. Not only this, but health officials also give out several tips that could prevent other individuals from contracting the disease.\n\nDoctors strongly recommend citizens to thoroughly wash their hands as often as possible, covering their mouths with anything other than their hands when sneezing, like tissues or elbow, and avoiding sharing spoons, forks, knives, or other eating utensils with infected subjects. Ultimately, the Health Department representatives also believe that one of the best ways for the population to stay mumps-free is by disinfecting surfaces that are frequently touched, such as doorknobs, counters, tables, and handles.\n\n[Byline: John Birks]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map showing the location of Missouri in the United States can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/4145. - Mod.LK]\nSee Also\nMumps - USA (33): (TX, AR) 20161221.4713166\nMumps - USA (32): (OK, MO, NY) 20161218.4704809\nMumps - USA (31): (TX) colleges (WA) 20161214.4699512\nMumps - USA (30): (WA, NY) 20161209.4688282\nMumps - USA (29): (TX, CT, WA) 20161203.4673013\nMumps - USA (28): (OR,MO) 20161126.4655765\nMumps - USA (27): (NY) 20161123.4648552\nMumps - USA (26): universities, schools 20161119.4639792\nMumps - USA (25): (AR,NY) 20161109.4616380\nMumps - Ireland: football players 20150223.3185969\nMumps - USA (02): (ID) university students 20150209.3153606\nMumps - UK: (Scotland) 20150204.3142750\nMumps - USA: (PA) professional hockey team players 20150109.3080644\n.................................................sb/lk/mj/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "mumps"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2034-03-16 00:00:00", "2220-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-08-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-12-16 00:00:00", "2016-12-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2016-12-16 00:00:00", "2033-03-16 00:00:00", "2032-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00", "2021-03-28 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "QC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Columbia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mumps - At the moment, health agencies state that at least one case of an individual displaying mumps symptoms has been confirmed, says the Kansas City Health Department. As a consequence, an advisory has been issued on Thursday afternoon [22 Dec 2016].\n\nRex Archer, head of the Kansas City Health Department urges people who contracted the disease to stay inside, in order to contain the outbreak, via an official statement. In his plea, Mr Archer asks people to take several days off from either school or work-related duties for at least 5 days after the 1st symptoms emerge, such as the inflammation of the salivary glands. Rex Archer also says that individuals who came in contact with infected people could start displaying mumps symptoms anywhere in between 12 to 25 days after exposure to the virus. Ultimately, he recommends people who develop mumps symptoms to address their health care provider as soon as soon as possible. \"Questions about your immunity or vaccination status should be directed to your private physician\", says Rex Archer.\n\nAs of now, roughly 200 cases of infected individuals have been confirmed by the University of Missouri in Columbia. In order to contain the outbreak, Kansas City Health Department officials say that they are closely monitoring the progression of the local case. Not only this, but health officials also give out several tips that could prevent other individuals from contracting the disease.\n\nDoctors strongly recommend citizens to thoroughly wash their hands as often as possible, covering their mouths with anything other than their hands when sneezing, like tissues or elbow, and avoiding sharing spoons, forks, knives, or other eating utensils with infected subjects. Ireland: football players 20150223.3185969\nMumps - USA (02): (ID) university students 20150209.3153606\nMumps - UK: (Scotland) 20150204.3142750\nMumps - USA: (PA) professional hockey team players 20150109.3080644\n.................................................sb/lk/mj/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "mumps"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2034-03-16 00:00:00", "2220-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-08-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-12-16 00:00:00", "2016-12-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2016-12-16 00:00:00", "2033-03-16 00:00:00", "2032-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00", "2021-03-28 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "QC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Columbia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mumps - Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hawaii", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arkansas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MISSOURI", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Fort Worth", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SF", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kansas City", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Marshall Islands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tarrant County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "TEXAS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Missouri", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York City", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NE", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oklahoma", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Johnson County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MT", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4860461", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps update (05): USA (PA, MO - RFI), Canada (ON, AB)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4860461", "date": "2016-12-26 10:43:43", "main_text": "MUMPS-USA (34): (ARKANSAS, TEXAS, MISSOURI)\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Arkansas (Marshallese)\n[2] Texas: cheerleading competitions\n[3] Missouri (Kansas City)\n\n******\n[1] Arkansas (Marshallese)\nDate: Fri 23 Dec 2016 5:12 PM EST\nSource: El Nuevo Herald, The Associated Press (AP) report [in Spanish, trans. Mod.LK, edited]\nhttp://www.elnuevoherald.com/vivir-mejor/salud/article122039909.html\n\n\nAccording to health officials, an epidemic of mumps is seriously affecting a community of citizens of the Marshall Islands residents of northwest Arkansas.\n\nCitizens of the Marshall Islands represent approximately 60 percent of the 2220 cases of mumps reported in the state through [Fri 23 Dec 2016]. The Arkansas Democrat-Gazette newspaper reported that the outbreak began in August 2016 (http://bit.ly/2hVVQYf).\n\nNate Smith, director of the State Health Department, said he doesn't know why so many people from the Marshall Islands are infected. Officials are investigating whether the vaccine is less effective for certain people. Smith said that the people of the Marshall Islands tend to live close to each other.\n\n\"It's a bit like a college dormitory in terms of intensity of exposure,\" he explained. Smith added that citizens of the Marshall Islands are involved in many community oriented events, where it is easy for transmission of infections.\n\nThe US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said that the epidemic in Arkansas is the largest since 2009 and 2010 when approximately 3000 people were infected in New York. Smith said that cases of mumps in Arkansas represent more than half of those reported this year [2016] at the national level.\n\nThe Department of Health had vaccinated almost 6600 people up to [Fri 23 Dec 2016]. Smith said that the efforts are showing results because only 12 cases were reported during the last 3 days of last week [week of 12 Dec 2016], \"which is really much less than we had for months.\"\n\nThe Marshall Islands are located in the Pacific Ocean, more than 3200 kilometers (2000 miles) southwest of Hawaii. About 12 000 of its citizens live in Northwest Arkansas.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-ESP\n<promed-esp@promedmail.org>\n\n[Mumps is a viral illness transmitted by the respiratory route, making dissemination possible in gatherings of people. The report does not specify the vaccination coverage of these citizens of the Marshall Islands who have developed the disease, which could be another factor contributing to this outbreak, apart from the possibility of lower effectiveness of the vaccine. It is necessary to investigate further in order to establish with certainty this behavior of the disease. - Mod.JG\n\nSee ProMED-mail Mumps - USA (21) 20161008.4545923 for reports of cases in other states in the United States -- Oklahoma and Washington -- and a discussion of the particular problem of providing protection to the Marshallese in Arkansas against vaccine-preventable diseases.\n\nA map showing the location of Arkansas in the United States can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/208 - Mod. LK]\n\n******\n[2] Texas: cheerleading competitions\nDate: Thu 22 Dec 2016 4:35 PM CST\nSource: KHOU-TV [edited]\nhttp://www.khou.com/news/health/dshs-investigating-two-north-texas-mumps-outbreaks/376855681\n\n\nState health officials are investigating 2 mumps outbreaks, one of which is connected to a series of cheerleading competitions in North Texas.\n\nThe Texas Department State Health Services [DSHS] is working with event organizers to notify those who attended 1 of 4 cheerleading competitions in November and December [2016] that they may have been exposed to mumps. DSHS said it has identified 11 mumps cases associated with this outbreak.\n\nA 2nd outbreak is being investigated in Johnson County, south of Fort Worth. Health officials have identified 72 cases in this outbreak, including 71 Johnson County residents and 1 Tarrant County resident. DSHS is working with school districts in the area to limit its spread since most of the cases are in students.\n\nMumps is spread by droplets of saliva or mucus from the mouth, nose, or throat of an infected person, usually when the infected person coughs, sneezes or talks. The virus can also be spread by sharing cups and utensils.\n\nSymptoms include swollen or tender salivary glands, low fever, tiredness and muscle aches. Men can also exhibit swollen or tender testicles.\n\nDSHS said people who are vaccinated can also contract the virus. The spread of mumps can be prevented or limited by covering coughs and sneezes, washing hands frequently with soap and water, and not sharing food or drinks.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map showing the location of Texas in the United States can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/245. A Texas county map can be found at http://geology.com/county-map/texas-county-map.gif.- Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[3] Missouri (Kansas City)\nDate: Sun 25 Dec 2016\nSource: The Monitor Daily [edited]\nhttp://www.themonitordaily.com/mumps/213109/\n\n\nIf you experience fever, headaches, muscle aches, tiredness, and loss of appetite, it is possible you have contracted mumps.\n\nThe mumps outbreak that has been sweeping through various regions across Missouri lately has spread to Kansas City, as well, according to health officials. At the moment, health agencies state that at least one case of an individual displaying mumps symptoms has been confirmed, says the Kansas City Health Department. As a consequence, an advisory has been issued on Thursday afternoon [22 Dec 2016].\n\nRex Archer, head of the Kansas City Health Department urges people who contracted the disease to stay inside, in order to contain the outbreak, via an official statement. In his plea, Mr Archer asks people to take several days off from either school or work-related duties for at least 5 days after the 1st symptoms emerge, such as the inflammation of the salivary glands. Rex Archer also says that individuals who came in contact with infected people could start displaying mumps symptoms anywhere in between 12 to 25 days after exposure to the virus. Ultimately, he recommends people who develop mumps symptoms to address their health care provider as soon as soon as possible. \"Questions about your immunity or vaccination status should be directed to your private physician\", says Rex Archer.\n\nAs of now, roughly 200 cases of infected individuals have been confirmed by the University of Missouri in Columbia. In order to contain the outbreak, Kansas City Health Department officials say that they are closely monitoring the progression of the local case. Not only this, but health officials also give out several tips that could prevent other individuals from contracting the disease.\n\nDoctors strongly recommend citizens to thoroughly wash their hands as often as possible, covering their mouths with anything other than their hands when sneezing, like tissues or elbow, and avoiding sharing spoons, forks, knives, or other eating utensils with infected subjects. Ultimately, the Health Department representatives also believe that one of the best ways for the population to stay mumps-free is by disinfecting surfaces that are frequently touched, such as doorknobs, counters, tables, and handles.\n\n[Byline: John Birks]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map showing the location of Missouri in the United States can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/4145. - Mod.LK]\nSee Also\nMumps - USA (33): (TX, AR) 20161221.4713166\nMumps - USA (32): (OK, MO, NY) 20161218.4704809\nMumps - USA (31): (TX) colleges (WA) 20161214.4699512\nMumps - USA (30): (WA, NY) 20161209.4688282\nMumps - LK]\n\n******\n[2] Texas: cheerleading competitions\nDate: Thu 22 Dec 2016 4:35 PM CST\nSource: KHOU-TV [edited]\nhttp://www.khou.com/news/health/dshs-investigating-two-north-texas-mumps-outbreaks/376855681\n\n\nState health officials are investigating 2 mumps outbreaks, one of which is connected to a series of cheerleading competitions in North Texas.\n\nThe Texas Department State Health Services [DSHS] is working with event organizers to notify those who attended 1 of 4 cheerleading competitions in November and December [2016] that they may have been exposed to mumps. DSHS said it has identified 11 mumps cases associated with this outbreak.\n\nA 2nd outbreak is being investigated in Johnson County, south of Fort Worth. Health officials have identified 72 cases in this outbreak, including 71 Johnson County residents and 1 Tarrant County resident. DSHS is working with school districts in the area to limit its spread since most of the cases are in students.\n\nMumps is spread by droplets of saliva or mucus from the mouth, nose, or throat of an infected person, usually when the infected person coughs, sneezes or talks. The virus can also be spread by sharing cups and utensils.\n\nSymptoms include swollen or tender salivary glands, low fever, tiredness and muscle aches. Men can also exhibit swollen or tender testicles.\n\nDSHS said people who are vaccinated can also contract the virus. The spread of mumps can be prevented or limited by covering coughs and sneezes, washing hands frequently with soap and water, and not sharing food or drinks.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map showing the location of Texas in the United States can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/245. A Texas county map can be found at http://geology.com/county-map/texas-county-map.gif.- Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[3] Missouri (Kansas City)\nDate: Sun 25 Dec 2016\nSource: The Monitor Daily [edited]\nhttp://www.themonitordaily.com/mumps/213109/\n\n\nIf you experience fever, headaches, muscle aches, tiredness, and loss of appetite, it is possible you have contracted mumps.\n\nThe mumps outbreak that has been sweeping through various regions across Missouri lately has spread to Kansas City, as well, according to health officials. At the moment, health agencies state that at least one case of an individual displaying mumps symptoms has been confirmed, says the Kansas City Health Department. As a consequence, an advisory has been issued on Thursday afternoon [22 Dec 2016].\n\nRex Archer, head of the Kansas City Health Department urges people who contracted the disease to stay inside, in order to contain the outbreak, via an official statement. In his plea, Mr Archer asks people to take several days off from either school or work-related duties for at least 5 days after the 1st symptoms emerge, such as the inflammation of the salivary glands. Rex Archer also says that individuals who came in contact with infected people could start displaying mumps symptoms anywhere in between 12 to 25 days after exposure to the virus. Ultimately, he recommends people who develop mumps symptoms to address their health care provider as soon as soon as possible. \"Questions about your immunity or vaccination status should be directed to your private physician\", says Rex Archer.\n\nAs of now, roughly 200 cases of infected individuals have been confirmed by the University of Missouri in Columbia. In order to contain the outbreak, Kansas City Health Department officials say that they are closely monitoring the progression of the local case. Not only this, but health officials also give out several tips that could prevent other individuals from contracting the disease.\n\nDoctors strongly recommend citizens to thoroughly wash their hands as often as possible, covering their mouths with anything other than their hands when sneezing, like tissues or elbow, and avoiding sharing spoons, forks, knives, or other eating utensils with infected subjects. Ultimately, the Health Department representatives also believe that one of the best ways for the population to stay mumps-free is by disinfecting surfaces that are frequently touched, such as doorknobs, counters, tables, and handles.\n\n[Byline: John Birks]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map showing the location of Missouri in the United States can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/4145. - Ireland: football players 20150223.3185969\nMumps - USA (02): (ID) university students 20150209.3153606\nMumps - UK: (Scotland) 20150204.3142750\nMumps - USA: (PA) professional hockey team players 20150109.3080644\n.................................................sb/lk/mj/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "mumps"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2034-03-16 00:00:00", "2220-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-08-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-12-16 00:00:00", "2016-12-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2016-12-16 00:00:00", "2033-03-16 00:00:00", "2032-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00", "2021-03-28 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "QC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Columbia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mumps - Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hawaii", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arkansas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MISSOURI", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Fort Worth", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SF", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kansas City", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Marshall Islands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tarrant County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "TEXAS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Missouri", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York City", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NE", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oklahoma", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Johnson County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MT", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4817357", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps update (03): USA (AR)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4817357", "date": "2016-12-26 10:43:43", "main_text": "MUMPS-USA (34): (ARKANSAS, TEXAS, MISSOURI)\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Arkansas (Marshallese)\n[2] Texas: cheerleading competitions\n[3] Missouri (Kansas City)\n\n******\n[1] Arkansas (Marshallese)\nDate: Fri 23 Dec 2016 5:12 PM EST\nSource: El Nuevo Herald, The Associated Press (AP) report [in Spanish, trans. Mod.LK, edited]\nhttp://www.elnuevoherald.com/vivir-mejor/salud/article122039909.html\n\n\nAccording to health officials, an epidemic of mumps is seriously affecting a community of citizens of the Marshall Islands residents of northwest Arkansas.\n\nCitizens of the Marshall Islands represent approximately 60 percent of the 2220 cases of mumps reported in the state through [Fri 23 Dec 2016]. The Arkansas Democrat-Gazette newspaper reported that the outbreak began in August 2016 (http://bit.ly/2hVVQYf).\n\nNate Smith, director of the State Health Department, said he doesn't know why so many people from the Marshall Islands are infected. Officials are investigating whether the vaccine is less effective for certain people. Smith said that the people of the Marshall Islands tend to live close to each other.\n\n\"It's a bit like a college dormitory in terms of intensity of exposure,\" he explained. Smith added that citizens of the Marshall Islands are involved in many community oriented events, where it is easy for transmission of infections.\n\nThe US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said that the epidemic in Arkansas is the largest since 2009 and 2010 when approximately 3000 people were infected in New York. Smith said that cases of mumps in Arkansas represent more than half of those reported this year [2016] at the national level.\n\nThe Department of Health had vaccinated almost 6600 people up to [Fri 23 Dec 2016]. Smith said that the efforts are showing results because only 12 cases were reported during the last 3 days of last week [week of 12 Dec 2016], \"which is really much less than we had for months.\"\n\nThe Marshall Islands are located in the Pacific Ocean, more than 3200 kilometers (2000 miles) southwest of Hawaii. About 12 000 of its citizens live in Northwest Arkansas.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-ESP\n<promed-esp@promedmail.org>\n\n[Mumps is a viral illness transmitted by the respiratory route, making dissemination possible in gatherings of people. The report does not specify the vaccination coverage of these citizens of the Marshall Islands who have developed the disease, which could be another factor contributing to this outbreak, apart from the possibility of lower effectiveness of the vaccine. It is necessary to investigate further in order to establish with certainty this behavior of the disease. - Mod.JG\n\nSee ProMED-mail Mumps - USA (21) 20161008.4545923 for reports of cases in other states in the United States -- Oklahoma and Washington -- and a discussion of the particular problem of providing protection to the Marshallese in Arkansas against vaccine-preventable diseases.\n\nA map showing the location of Arkansas in the United States can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/208 - Mod. LK]\n\n******\n[2] Texas: cheerleading competitions\nDate: Thu 22 Dec 2016 4:35 PM CST\nSource: KHOU-TV [edited]\nhttp://www.khou.com/news/health/dshs-investigating-two-north-texas-mumps-outbreaks/376855681\n\n\nState health officials are investigating 2 mumps outbreaks, one of which is connected to a series of cheerleading competitions in North Texas.\n\nThe Texas Department State Health Services [DSHS] is working with event organizers to notify those who attended 1 of 4 cheerleading competitions in November and December [2016] that they may have been exposed to mumps. DSHS said it has identified 11 mumps cases associated with this outbreak.\n\nA 2nd outbreak is being investigated in Johnson County, south of Fort Worth. Health officials have identified 72 cases in this outbreak, including 71 Johnson County residents and 1 Tarrant County resident. DSHS is working with school districts in the area to limit its spread since most of the cases are in students.\n\nMumps is spread by droplets of saliva or mucus from the mouth, nose, or throat of an infected person, usually when the infected person coughs, sneezes or talks. The virus can also be spread by sharing cups and utensils.\n\nSymptoms include swollen or tender salivary glands, low fever, tiredness and muscle aches. Men can also exhibit swollen or tender testicles.\n\nDSHS said people who are vaccinated can also contract the virus. The spread of mumps can be prevented or limited by covering coughs and sneezes, washing hands frequently with soap and water, and not sharing food or drinks.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map showing the location of Texas in the United States can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/245. A Texas county map can be found at http://geology.com/county-map/texas-county-map.gif.- Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[3] Missouri (Kansas City)\nDate: Sun 25 Dec 2016\nSource: The Monitor Daily [edited]\nhttp://www.themonitordaily.com/mumps/213109/\n\n\nIf you experience fever, headaches, muscle aches, tiredness, and loss of appetite, it is possible you have contracted mumps.\n\nThe mumps outbreak that has been sweeping through various regions across Missouri lately has spread to Kansas City, as well, according to health officials. At the moment, health agencies state that at least one case of an individual displaying mumps symptoms has been confirmed, says the Kansas City Health Department. As a consequence, an advisory has been issued on Thursday afternoon [22 Dec 2016].\n\nRex Archer, head of the Kansas City Health Department urges people who contracted the disease to stay inside, in order to contain the outbreak, via an official statement. In his plea, Mr Archer asks people to take several days off from either school or work-related duties for at least 5 days after the 1st symptoms emerge, such as the inflammation of the salivary glands. Rex Archer also says that individuals who came in contact with infected people could start displaying mumps symptoms anywhere in between 12 to 25 days after exposure to the virus. Ultimately, he recommends people who develop mumps symptoms to address their health care provider as soon as soon as possible. \"Questions about your immunity or vaccination status should be directed to your private physician\", says Rex Archer.\n\nAs of now, roughly 200 cases of infected individuals have been confirmed by the University of Missouri in Columbia. In order to contain the outbreak, Kansas City Health Department officials say that they are closely monitoring the progression of the local case. Not only this, but health officials also give out several tips that could prevent other individuals from contracting the disease.\n\nDoctors strongly recommend citizens to thoroughly wash their hands as often as possible, covering their mouths with anything other than their hands when sneezing, like tissues or elbow, and avoiding sharing spoons, forks, knives, or other eating utensils with infected subjects. Ultimately, the Health Department representatives also believe that one of the best ways for the population to stay mumps-free is by disinfecting surfaces that are frequently touched, such as doorknobs, counters, tables, and handles.\n\n[Byline: John Birks]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map showing the location of Missouri in the United States can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/4145. - Mod.LK]\nSee Also\nMumps - USA (33): (TX, AR) 20161221.4713166\nMumps - USA (32): (OK, MO, NY) 20161218.4704809\nMumps - USA (31): (TX) colleges (WA) 20161214.4699512\nMumps - USA (30): (WA, NY) 20161209.4688282\nMumps - Canada (02): (ON) school children 20150624.3462267\nMumps - Canada (QC): school children, correction (ON) 20150529.3396108\nMumps - Canada (QC): school children 20150529.3395573\nMumps Australia (WA) 20150426.33238\nMumps - Ireland: football players 20150223.3185969\nMumps - USA (02): (ID) university students 20150209.3153606\nMumps - UK: (Scotland) 20150204.3142750\nMumps - USA: (PA) professional hockey team players 20150109.3080644\n.................................................sb/lk/mj/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "mumps"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2034-03-16 00:00:00", "2220-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-08-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-12-16 00:00:00", "2016-12-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2016-12-16 00:00:00", "2033-03-16 00:00:00", "2032-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00", "2021-03-28 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "QC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Columbia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mumps - Officials are investigating whether the vaccine is less effective for certain people. LK]\n\n******\n[2] Texas: cheerleading competitions\nDate: Thu 22 Dec 2016 4:35 PM CST\nSource: KHOU-TV [edited]\nhttp://www.khou.com/news/health/dshs-investigating-two-north-texas-mumps-outbreaks/376855681\n\n\nState health officials are investigating 2 mumps outbreaks, one of which is connected to a series of cheerleading competitions in North Texas.\n\nThe Texas Department State Health Services [DSHS] is working with event organizers to notify those who attended 1 of 4 cheerleading competitions in November and December [2016] that they may have been exposed to mumps. DSHS said it has identified 11 mumps cases associated with this outbreak.\n\nA 2nd outbreak is being investigated in Johnson County, south of Fort Worth. Health officials have identified 72 cases in this outbreak, including 71 Johnson County residents and 1 Tarrant County resident. DSHS is working with school districts in the area to limit its spread since most of the cases are in students.\n\nMumps is spread by droplets of saliva or mucus from the mouth, nose, or throat of an infected person, usually when the infected person coughs, sneezes or talks. The virus can also be spread by sharing cups and utensils.\n\nSymptoms include swollen or tender salivary glands, low fever, tiredness and muscle aches. Men can also exhibit swollen or tender testicles.\n\nDSHS said people who are vaccinated can also contract the virus. The spread of mumps can be prevented or limited by covering coughs and sneezes, washing hands frequently with soap and water, and not sharing food or drinks.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map showing the location of Texas in the United States can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/245. A Texas county map can be found at http://geology.com/county-map/texas-county-map.gif.- Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[3] Missouri (Kansas City)\nDate: Sun 25 Dec 2016\nSource: The Monitor Daily [edited]\nhttp://www.themonitordaily.com/mumps/213109/\n\n\nIf you experience fever, headaches, muscle aches, tiredness, and loss of appetite, it is possible you have contracted mumps.\n\nThe mumps outbreak that has been sweeping through various regions across Missouri lately has spread to Kansas City, as well, according to health officials. At the moment, health agencies state that at least one case of an individual displaying mumps symptoms has been confirmed, says the Kansas City Health Department. As a consequence, an advisory has been issued on Thursday afternoon [22 Dec 2016].\n\nRex Archer, head of the Kansas City Health Department urges people who contracted the disease to stay inside, in order to contain the outbreak, via an official statement. In his plea, Mr Archer asks people to take several days off from either school or work-related duties for at least 5 days after the 1st symptoms emerge, such as the inflammation of the salivary glands. Rex Archer also says that individuals who came in contact with infected people could start displaying mumps symptoms anywhere in between 12 to 25 days after exposure to the virus. Ultimately, he recommends people who develop mumps symptoms to address their health care provider as soon as soon as possible. \"Questions about your immunity or vaccination status should be directed to your private physician\", says Rex Archer.\n\nAs of now, roughly 200 cases of infected individuals have been confirmed by the University of Missouri in Columbia. In order to contain the outbreak, Kansas City Health Department officials say that they are closely monitoring the progression of the local case. Not only this, but health officials also give out several tips that could prevent other individuals from contracting the disease.\n\nDoctors strongly recommend citizens to thoroughly wash their hands as often as possible, covering their mouths with anything other than their hands when sneezing, like tissues or elbow, and avoiding sharing spoons, forks, knives, or other eating utensils with infected subjects. Ultimately, the Health Department representatives also believe that one of the best ways for the population to stay mumps-free is by disinfecting surfaces that are frequently touched, such as doorknobs, counters, tables, and handles.\n\n[Byline: John Birks]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map showing the location of Missouri in the United States can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/4145. - Ireland: football players 20150223.3185969\nMumps - USA (02): (ID) university students 20150209.3153606\nMumps - UK: (Scotland) 20150204.3142750\nMumps - USA: (PA) professional hockey team players 20150109.3080644\n.................................................sb/lk/mj/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "mumps"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2034-03-16 00:00:00", "2220-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-08-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-12-16 00:00:00", "2016-12-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2016-12-16 00:00:00", "2033-03-16 00:00:00", "2032-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00", "2021-03-28 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "QC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Columbia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mumps - Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hawaii", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arkansas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MISSOURI", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Fort Worth", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SF", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kansas City", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Marshall Islands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tarrant County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "TEXAS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Missouri", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York City", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NE", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oklahoma", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Johnson County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MT", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4753366", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps update: USA (WA,TX)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4753366", "date": "2016-12-26 10:43:43", "main_text": "MUMPS-USA (34): (ARKANSAS, TEXAS, MISSOURI)\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Arkansas (Marshallese)\n[2] Texas: cheerleading competitions\n[3] Missouri (Kansas City)\n\n******\n[1] Arkansas (Marshallese)\nDate: Fri 23 Dec 2016 5:12 PM EST\nSource: El Nuevo Herald, The Associated Press (AP) report [in Spanish, trans. Mod.LK, edited]\nhttp://www.elnuevoherald.com/vivir-mejor/salud/article122039909.html\n\n\nAccording to health officials, an epidemic of mumps is seriously affecting a community of citizens of the Marshall Islands residents of northwest Arkansas.\n\nCitizens of the Marshall Islands represent approximately 60 percent of the 2220 cases of mumps reported in the state through [Fri 23 Dec 2016]. The Arkansas Democrat-Gazette newspaper reported that the outbreak began in August 2016 (http://bit.ly/2hVVQYf).\n\nNate Smith, director of the State Health Department, said he doesn't know why so many people from the Marshall Islands are infected. Officials are investigating whether the vaccine is less effective for certain people. Smith said that the people of the Marshall Islands tend to live close to each other.\n\n\"It's a bit like a college dormitory in terms of intensity of exposure,\" he explained. Smith added that citizens of the Marshall Islands are involved in many community oriented events, where it is easy for transmission of infections.\n\nThe US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said that the epidemic in Arkansas is the largest since 2009 and 2010 when approximately 3000 people were infected in New York. Smith said that cases of mumps in Arkansas represent more than half of those reported this year [2016] at the national level.\n\nThe Department of Health had vaccinated almost 6600 people up to [Fri 23 Dec 2016]. Smith said that the efforts are showing results because only 12 cases were reported during the last 3 days of last week [week of 12 Dec 2016], \"which is really much less than we had for months.\"\n\nThe Marshall Islands are located in the Pacific Ocean, more than 3200 kilometers (2000 miles) southwest of Hawaii. About 12 000 of its citizens live in Northwest Arkansas.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-ESP\n<promed-esp@promedmail.org>\n\n[Mumps is a viral illness transmitted by the respiratory route, making dissemination possible in gatherings of people. The report does not specify the vaccination coverage of these citizens of the Marshall Islands who have developed the disease, which could be another factor contributing to this outbreak, apart from the possibility of lower effectiveness of the vaccine. It is necessary to investigate further in order to establish with certainty this behavior of the disease. - Mod.JG\n\nSee ProMED-mail Mumps - USA (21) 20161008.4545923 for reports of cases in other states in the United States -- Oklahoma and Washington -- and a discussion of the particular problem of providing protection to the Marshallese in Arkansas against vaccine-preventable diseases.\n\nA map showing the location of Arkansas in the United States can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/208 - Mod. LK]\n\n******\n[2] Texas: cheerleading competitions\nDate: Thu 22 Dec 2016 4:35 PM CST\nSource: KHOU-TV [edited]\nhttp://www.khou.com/news/health/dshs-investigating-two-north-texas-mumps-outbreaks/376855681\n\n\nState health officials are investigating 2 mumps outbreaks, one of which is connected to a series of cheerleading competitions in North Texas.\n\nThe Texas Department State Health Services [DSHS] is working with event organizers to notify those who attended 1 of 4 cheerleading competitions in November and December [2016] that they may have been exposed to mumps. DSHS said it has identified 11 mumps cases associated with this outbreak.\n\nA 2nd outbreak is being investigated in Johnson County, south of Fort Worth. Health officials have identified 72 cases in this outbreak, including 71 Johnson County residents and 1 Tarrant County resident. DSHS is working with school districts in the area to limit its spread since most of the cases are in students.\n\nMumps is spread by droplets of saliva or mucus from the mouth, nose, or throat of an infected person, usually when the infected person coughs, sneezes or talks. The virus can also be spread by sharing cups and utensils.\n\nSymptoms include swollen or tender salivary glands, low fever, tiredness and muscle aches. Men can also exhibit swollen or tender testicles.\n\nDSHS said people who are vaccinated can also contract the virus. The spread of mumps can be prevented or limited by covering coughs and sneezes, washing hands frequently with soap and water, and not sharing food or drinks.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map showing the location of Texas in the United States can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/245. A Texas county map can be found at http://geology.com/county-map/texas-county-map.gif.- Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[3] Missouri (Kansas City)\nDate: Sun 25 Dec 2016\nSource: The Monitor Daily [edited]\nhttp://www.themonitordaily.com/mumps/213109/\n\n\nIf you experience fever, headaches, muscle aches, tiredness, and loss of appetite, it is possible you have contracted mumps.\n\nThe mumps outbreak that has been sweeping through various regions across Missouri lately has spread to Kansas City, as well, according to health officials. At the moment, health agencies state that at least one case of an individual displaying mumps symptoms has been confirmed, says the Kansas City Health Department. As a consequence, an advisory has been issued on Thursday afternoon [22 Dec 2016].\n\nRex Archer, head of the Kansas City Health Department urges people who contracted the disease to stay inside, in order to contain the outbreak, via an official statement. In his plea, Mr Archer asks people to take several days off from either school or work-related duties for at least 5 days after the 1st symptoms emerge, such as the inflammation of the salivary glands. Rex Archer also says that individuals who came in contact with infected people could start displaying mumps symptoms anywhere in between 12 to 25 days after exposure to the virus. Ultimately, he recommends people who develop mumps symptoms to address their health care provider as soon as soon as possible. \"Questions about your immunity or vaccination status should be directed to your private physician\", says Rex Archer.\n\nAs of now, roughly 200 cases of infected individuals have been confirmed by the University of Missouri in Columbia. In order to contain the outbreak, Kansas City Health Department officials say that they are closely monitoring the progression of the local case. Not only this, but health officials also give out several tips that could prevent other individuals from contracting the disease.\n\nDoctors strongly recommend citizens to thoroughly wash their hands as often as possible, covering their mouths with anything other than their hands when sneezing, like tissues or elbow, and avoiding sharing spoons, forks, knives, or other eating utensils with infected subjects. Ultimately, the Health Department representatives also believe that one of the best ways for the population to stay mumps-free is by disinfecting surfaces that are frequently touched, such as doorknobs, counters, tables, and handles.\n\n[Byline: John Birks]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map showing the location of Missouri in the United States can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/4145. - Mod.LK]\nSee Also\nMumps - USA (33): (TX, AR) 20161221.4713166\nMumps - USA (32): (OK, MO, NY) 20161218.4704809\nMumps - USA (31): (TX) colleges (WA) 20161214.4699512\nMumps - USA (30): (WA, NY) 20161209.4688282\nMumps -
