"unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4562698", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (22): (AR)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4562698", "date": "2016-09-17 18:29:12", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (19)\n****************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] USA (New York)\n[2] USA (Illinois): CDC guidance on MMR vaccine\n[3] USA (Oklahoma)\n[4] USA (New York)\n\n******\n[1] USA (New York)\nDate: Tue 13 Sep 2016\nSource: Newsday [edited]\nhttp://www.newsday.com/news/health/mumps-outbreak-in-long-beach-grows-to-nearly-50-cases-officials-say-1.12310605\n\n\nLong Beach [New York] mumps outbreak nears 50 cases, say officials\n--------------------------------------------------------------------\nThe mumps outbreak that has been evident this summer in Long Beach has continued to grow as health experts across the country have begun documenting an unrelated spate of cases in nearly every state, health officials said Tuesday [13 Sep 2016].\n\nLocally, the outbreak has remained concentrated in the barrier island region where multiple suspect cases are under investigation by the State Department of Health.\n\n[byline: Delthia Ricks]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] USA (Illinois): CDC guidance on MMR vaccine\nDate: September 2016\nSource: Healio Infectious Disease News [edited]\nhttp://www.healio.com/infectious-disease/vaccine-preventable-diseases/news/print/infectious-disease-news/%7Be12a2a27-d121-4dc0-b05a-bbf77f921fd1%7D/cdc-considers-guidance-on-third-mmr-dose-following-campus-outbreak\n\n\nCDC considers guidance on 3rd MMR dose following campus outbreak\n----------------------------------------------------------------\nThe Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recently offered guidance on a 3rd dose of the measles-mumps-rubella [MMR] vaccine for adolescents and young adults following a recent mumps outbreak at the University of Illinois.\n\n\"No formal recommendation for or against the use of a 3rd MMR dose has been issued by the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP),\" Justin P Albertson, MS, from the Illinois Department of Public Health, and colleagues wrote in a recent MMWR. \"However, CDC has provided guidelines for use of a 3rd dose as a control measure during mumps outbreaks in settings in which persons are in close contact with one another, where transmission is sustained despite high 2-dose MMR coverage, and when traditional control measures fail to slow transmission.\"\n\nThe Illinois Department of Public Health (IDPH) confirmed an outbreak of mumps at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign (C-UPHD) on 1 May 2015. Between April 2015 and May 2016, researchers identified 317 cases on campus. The university, IDPH and the university's McKinley Health Center recommended a 3rd MMR vaccination due to the seasonal trends and characteristics of the population at risk.\n\nAbout 50 000 students and staff members were targeted for 3rd-dose vaccination on C-UPHD campus. A total of 8200 doses of MMR were administered at multiple vaccination sites at the university between 6 and 27 Aug 2015 to determine if a 3rd dose of MMR would prevent further exposure of mumps to healthy staff and students. In addition, the C-UPHD center administered 3300 doses in the fall and spring semesters.\n\nEpidemiological analysis showed that all 317 cases of mumps were associated with the university. Cases in students totaled 278 (88 per cent), 3 (1 per cent) occurred in staff members and 36 (11 per cent) in people not associated with the university but who had contact with students or the campus grounds. Among those who were diagnosed at the time of parotitis onset, 50 patients had received 3 doses of MMR vaccine, 232 patients had received 2 doses, 12 patients had received 1 dose, 7 patients were unvaccinated and 16 patients were unaware if they had been vaccinated. 90 per cent of patients with a 3rd dose received it during the outbreak, and 10 per cent had received it previously independent of this outbreak, according to the researchers.\n\n\"In light of the recent increased incidence of mumps, CDC is gathering additional data to assess use of a 3rd dose of vaccine to inform decision-making during outbreak responses and potential changes in the recommendations,\" they wrote.\n\nReference:\nAlbertson JP, et al. MMWR Morb Mortal Wkly Rep. 2016;doi:10.15585/mmwr.mm62529a2.\n\n[byline: Kate Sherrer]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[While a 3rd dose of the vaccine sounds like it might be helpful in boosting immunity, it must be given sufficiently prior to exposure for the immunity to be boosted to be protective. As noted above, 50 patients (out of 317) had received 3 doses of MMR vaccine. One must assume they were not vaccinated with the 3rd dose in time to protect them.\n\nA 3rd vaccination appears to have been very effective in the following study: Ogbuanu IU, et al. Pediatrics 2012; 130(6)(http://pediatrics.aappublications.org/content/pediatrics/early/2012/10/30/peds.2012-0177.full.pdf). This study was conducted to assess the impact of a 3rd dose of MMR vaccine during an outbreak in 2009-2010 among school students in 6th-12th grade. The decline in incidence shortly after the intervention suggests that a 3rd dose of MMR vaccine may help control mumps outbreaks among populations with preexisting high 2-dose vaccine coverage. The results indicated that of 2265 eligible students, 2178 (96.2 per cent) provided documentation of having received 2 previous doses of MMR vaccine, and a high proportion (1755 or 80.6 per cent) chose to receive an additional vaccine dose. The overall attack rate for all 6th- to 12th-grade students declined from 4.93 per cent in the prevaccination period to 0.13 per cent after vaccination (P, .001). Villagewide, overall attack rate declined by 75.6 per cent after the intervention. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[3] USA (Oklahoma)\nDate: Thu 15 Sep 2016\nSource: Enid News & Eagle [edited]\nhttp://www.enidnews.com/news/local_news/update-some-in-suspected-mumps-outbreak-were-vaccinated/article_47c989a4-7b67-11e6-8e84-dffe3f42c206.html\n\n\nUpdate: Some in suspected mumps outbreak were vaccinated\n--------------------------------------------------------\nGarfield County Health Department has confirmed at least some of the individuals who have or are suspected of having mumps in Garfield County [Oklahoma] have been vaccinated against the disease.\n\n\"I don't have numbers on this just yet -- but it does look as though some were fully vaccinated with MMR,\" Carla Dionne, director of Garfield County Health Department, reported in an email to the Enid News & Eagle. She added that this particular vaccine -- measles, mumps and rubella -- \"is 88 per cent effective -- but not perfect. Individuals with 2 doses can still get mumps.\"\n\nEnid Public Schools [EPS] sent out a text message Wednesday [14 Sep 2016] evening reporting that Garfield County Health Department has confirmed multiple cases of mumps in the community, including at Longfellow Middle School and Enid High School.\n\nOklahoma Health Department later reported there have been 4 confirmed cases in Garfield County and at least 34 suspected cases.\n\nEPS requires students to be in compliance with Oklahoma vaccination laws, EPS Communications Director Amber Graham Fitzgerald said. \"Prior to (Wednesday's) events, the EPS Health Services Department established (Thursday) as the deadline for compliance,\" she said. \"Those not in compliance -- there are about 12 students who don't have the MMR vaccine -- will not be allowed to return to school until they are in compliance.\" This does not include students who have a religious or physical exemption from vaccinations, she said.\n\nLaurence Burnsed, an epidemiologist with the Acute Disease Service for the Oklahoma State Department of Health, confirmed that some of those who are suspected of contracting the disease in Enid have been vaccinated and that others have not been or do not know if they have been vaccinated. \"That's what you might expect in an outbreak situation,\" Burnsed said. \"If you have the recommended 2 doses of MMR, you're at an 88 per cent level of protection, so if 100 people were exposed, you would still have about 12 experiencing symptoms. The vaccine is not 100 per cent protective.\" In the health department's collaboration with school officials, Burnsed said there seems to be a good level of vaccinations.\n\nThe MMR vaccine is available at Garfield County Health Department.\n\nMumps is a virus spread though coughing, sneezing and direct contact with saliva through eating or drinking after an infected person, according to Garfield County Health Department. Symptoms can last 7-10 days and usually appear 12-25 days after infection.\n\nMumps is characterized by puffy cheeks and a swollen jaw, due to swollen salivary glands. Other symptoms include body aches, tiredness and fever, and males may experience swollen, painful testicles, according to the department. In order to prevent spreading mumps, children who exhibit such symptoms should not attend school or day care through 5 days after the illness begins, according to the department.\n\nBurnsed encouraged those who have not been vaccinated or who are behind on their vaccination schedule to get the MMR vaccine to help protect against the illness. Burnsed also said the state department is not ruling out that Enid's suspected outbreak could be related to a similar outbreak in Arkansas. \"It's certainly possible, considering the proximity,\" Burnsed said. \"But we are still gathering information.\"\n\nOn Monday [12 Sep 2016], the Arkansas Department of Health reported almost 100 cases of mumps have been confirmed in the state, with most being in Springdale, but some reported in Rogers and potential cases in Fayetteville, Huntsville and West Fork, according to the Arkansas Democrat Gazette.\n\n[byline: Sally Asher]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The cases in Oklahoma had been fully vaccinated with 2 doses, but still came down with measles. This suggests 3 doses may be more protective. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[4] USA (New York)\nDate: Thu 15 Sep 2016\nSource: New York Upstate [edited]\nhttp://www.newyorkupstate.com/news/2016/09/ny_warns_state_colleges_about_mumps_outbreak.html\n\n\nNew York warns state colleges about mumps outbreak\n--------------------------------------------------\nA mumps case at SUNY [State University of New York] Oswego may be linked to an outbreak of the contagious viral infection in the Long Beach area of Long Island [New York]. The State Health Department is warning colleges throughout the state the Long Beach outbreak could lead to other cases. The State Health Department said public health officials on Long Island have identified 45 mumps cases related to the Long Beach outbreak since July [2016].\n\nA SUNY Plattsburgh student also was recently diagnosed with mumps, but the source of that infection is still under investigation.\n\nBoth schools have notified unvaccinated students they will be barred from campus for 26 days after the last possible exposure if they do not get vaccinated. The health department said this step is being taken to avoid a large outbreak.\n\nMumps is characterized by fever, headache, swelling of the salivary glands, fatigue, muscle aches and loss of appetite. After a person is exposed to mumps, symptoms usually appear 16 to 18 days after infection. Mumps cannot be treated.\n\nTwo doses of the mumps vaccine provides the best protection against the disease, according to the health department.\n\nThe department offered these tips to prevent the spread of mumps:\n- do not share food, drinks, utensils or other personal items that may contain saliva;\n- wash hands frequently with soap and water or use an alcohol-based hand rub;\n- cover your mouth with a tissue when sneezing or coughing and discard the tissue;\n- clean and disinfect objects and surfaces that may be contaminated with germs.\n\nPeople with mumps should stay home away from public places for 5 days after the onset of symptoms and limit contact with others in their households.\n\nMumps is no longer common in the United States. As of 13 Aug [2016], 1786 cases nationwide had been reported to the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention [in 2016].\n\n[byline: James T Mulder]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Mumps may no longer be common in the US, but this year (2016) there appear to be a spate of cases throughout the country to the extent that CDC is considering a 3rd dose of the MMR vaccine in certain situations.\n\nA map of the US showing all states discussed can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106. - Mod.LK]\nSee Also\nMumps - USA [edited]\nhttp://www.newsday.com/news/health/mumps-outbreak-in-long-beach-grows-to-nearly-50-cases-officials-say-1.12310605\n\n\nLong Beach [New York] mumps outbreak nears 50 cases, say officials\n--------------------------------------------------------------------\nThe mumps outbreak that has been evident this summer in Long Beach has continued to grow as health experts across the Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] USA (Illinois): CDC guidance on MMR vaccine\nDate: September 2016\nSource: Healio Infectious Disease News [edited]\nhttp://www.healio.com/infectious-disease/vaccine-preventable-diseases/news/print/infectious-disease-news/%7Be12a2a27-d121-4dc0-b05a-bbf77f921fd1%7D/cdc-considers-guidance-on-third-mmr-dose-following-campus-outbreak\n\n\nCDC considers guidance on 3rd MMR dose following campus outbreak\n----------------------------------------------------------------\nThe Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recently offered guidance on a 3rd dose of the measles-mumps-rubella [MMR] vaccine for adolescents and young adults following a recent mumps outbreak at the University of Illinois.\n\n\"No formal recommendation for or against the use of a 3rd MMR dose has been issued by the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP),\" Justin P Albertson, MS, from the Illinois Department of Public Health, and colleagues wrote in a recent MMWR. \"However, CDC has provided guidelines for use of a 3rd dose as a control measure during mumps outbreaks in settings in which persons are in close contact with one another, where transmission is sustained despite high 2-dose MMR coverage, and when traditional control measures fail to slow transmission.\"\n\nThe Illinois Department of Public Health (IDPH) confirmed an outbreak of mumps at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign (C-UPHD) on 1 May 2015. Between April 2015 and May 2016, researchers identified 317 cases on campus. The university, IDPH and the university's McKinley Health Center recommended a 3rd MMR vaccination due to the seasonal trends and characteristics of the population at risk.\n\nAbout 50 000 students and staff members were targeted for 3rd-dose vaccination on C-UPHD campus. A total of 8200 doses of MMR were administered at multiple vaccination sites at the university between 6 and 27 Aug 2015 to determine if a 3rd dose of MMR would prevent further exposure of mumps to healthy staff and students. In addition, the C-UPHD center administered 3300 doses in the fall and spring semesters.\n\nEpidemiological analysis showed that all 317 cases of mumps were associated with the university. Cases in students totaled 278 (88 per cent), 3 (1 per cent) occurred in staff members and 36 (11 per cent) in people not associated with the university but who had contact with students or the campus grounds. Among those who were diagnosed at the time of parotitis onset, 50 patients had received 3 doses of MMR vaccine, 232 patients had received 2 doses, 12 patients had received 1 dose, 7 patients were unvaccinated and 16 patients were unaware if they had been vaccinated. 90 per cent of patients with a 3rd dose received it during the outbreak, and 10 per cent had received it previously independent of this outbreak, according to the researchers.\n\n\"In light of the recent increased incidence of mumps, CDC is gathering additional data to assess use of a 3rd dose of vaccine to inform decision-making during outbreak responses and potential changes in the recommendations,\" they wrote.\n\nReference:\nAlbertson JP, et al. MMWR Morb Mortal Wkly Rep. 2016;doi:10.15585/mmwr.mm62529a2.\n\n[byline: Kate Sherrer]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[While a 3rd dose of the vaccine sounds like it might be helpful in boosting immunity, it must be given sufficiently prior to exposure for the immunity to be boosted to be protective. As noted above, 50 patients (out of 317) had received 3 doses of MMR vaccine. One must assume they were not vaccinated with the 3rd dose in time to protect them.\n\nA 3rd vaccination appears to have been very effective in the following study: Ogbuanu IU, et al. Pediatrics 2012; 130(6)(http://pediatrics.aappublications.org/content/pediatrics/early/2012/10/30/peds.2012-0177.full.pdf). This study was conducted to assess the impact of a 3rd dose of MMR vaccine during an outbreak in 2009-2010 among school students in 6th-12th grade. The decline in incidence shortly after the intervention suggests that a 3rd dose of MMR vaccine may help control mumps outbreaks among populations with preexisting high 2-dose vaccine coverage. The results indicated that of 2265 eligible students, 2178 (96.2 per cent) provided documentation of having received 2 previous doses of MMR vaccine, and a high proportion (1755 or 80.6 per cent) chose to receive an additional vaccine dose. The overall attack rate for all 6th- to 12th-grade students declined from 4.93 per cent in the prevaccination period to 0.13 per cent after vaccination (P, .001). Villagewide, overall attack rate declined by 75.6 per cent after the intervention. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[3] USA (Oklahoma)\nDate: Thu 15 Sep 2016\nSource: Enid News & Eagle [edited]\nhttp://www.enidnews.com/news/local_news/update-some-in-suspected-mumps-outbreak-were-vaccinated/article_47c989a4-7b67-11e6-8e84-dffe3f42c206.html\n\n\nUpdate: Some in suspected mumps outbreak were vaccinated\n--------------------------------------------------------\nGarfield County Health Department has confirmed at least some of the individuals who have or are suspected of having mumps in Garfield County [Oklahoma] have been vaccinated against the disease.\n\n\"I don't have numbers on this just yet -- but it does look as though some were fully vaccinated with MMR,\" Carla Dionne, director of Garfield County Health Department, reported in an email to the Enid News & Eagle. She added that this particular vaccine -- measles, mumps and rubella -- \"is 88 per cent effective -- but not perfect. Individuals with 2 doses can still get mumps.\"\n\nEnid Public Schools [EPS] sent out a text message Wednesday [14 Sep 2016] evening reporting that Garfield County Health Department has confirmed multiple cases of mumps in the community, including at Longfellow Middle School and Enid High School.\n\nOklahoma Health Department later reported there have been 4 confirmed cases in Garfield County and at least 34 suspected cases.\n\nEPS requires students to be in compliance with Oklahoma vaccination laws, EPS Communications Director Amber Graham Fitzgerald said. \"Prior to (Wednesday's) events, the EPS Health Services Department established (Thursday) as the deadline for compliance,\" she said. \"Those not in compliance -- there are about 12 students who don't have the MMR vaccine -- will not be allowed to return to school until they are in compliance.\" This does not include students who have a religious or physical exemption from vaccinations, she said.\n\nLaurence Burnsed, an epidemiologist with the Acute Disease Service for the Oklahoma State Department of Health, confirmed that some of those who are suspected of contracting the disease in Enid have been vaccinated and that others have not been or do not know if they have been vaccinated. \"That's what you might expect in an outbreak situation,\" Burnsed said. \"If you have the recommended 2 doses of MMR, you're at an 88 per cent level of protection, so if 100 people were exposed, you would still have about 12 experiencing symptoms. The vaccine is not 100 per cent protective.\" In the health department's collaboration with school officials, Burnsed said there seems to be a good level of vaccinations.\n\nThe MMR vaccine is available at Garfield County Health Department.\n\nMumps is a virus spread though coughing, sneezing and direct contact with saliva through eating or drinking after an infected person, according to Garfield County Health Department. Symptoms can last 7-10 days and usually appear 12-25 days after infection.\n\nMumps is characterized by puffy cheeks and a swollen jaw, due to swollen salivary glands. Other symptoms include body aches, tiredness and fever, and males may experience swollen, painful testicles, according to the department. In order to prevent spreading mumps, children who exhibit such symptoms should not attend school or day care through 5 days after the illness begins, according to the department.\n\nBurnsed encouraged those who have not been vaccinated or who are behind on their vaccination schedule to get the MMR vaccine to help protect against the illness. Burnsed also said the state department is not ruling out that Enid's suspected outbreak could be related to a similar outbreak in Arkansas. \"It's certainly possible, considering the proximity,\" Burnsed said. \"But we are still gathering information.\"\n\nOn Monday [12 Sep 2016], the Arkansas Department of Health reported almost 100 cases of mumps have been confirmed in the state, with most being in Springdale, but some reported in Rogers and potential cases in Fayetteville, Huntsville and West Fork, according to the Arkansas Democrat Gazette.\n\n[byline: Sally Asher]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The cases in Oklahoma had been fully vaccinated with 2 doses, but still came down with measles. This suggests 3 doses may be more protective. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[4] USA (New York)\nDate: Thu 15 Sep 2016\nSource: New York Upstate [edited]\nhttp://www.newyorkupstate.com/news/2016/09/ny_warns_state_colleges_about_mumps_outbreak.html\n\n\nNew York warns state colleges about mumps outbreak\n--------------------------------------------------\nA mumps case at SUNY [State University of New York] Oswego may be linked to an outbreak of the contagious viral infection in the Long Beach area of Long Island [New York]. The State Health Department is warning colleges throughout the state the Long Beach outbreak could lead to other cases. The State Health Department said public health officials on Long Island have identified 45 mumps cases related to the Long Beach outbreak since July [2016].\n\nA SUNY Plattsburgh student also was recently diagnosed with mumps, but the source of that infection is still under investigation.\n\nBoth schools have notified unvaccinated students they will be barred from campus for 26 days after the last possible exposure if they do not get vaccinated. The health department said this step is being taken to avoid a large outbreak.\n\nMumps is characterized by fever, headache, swelling of the salivary glands, fatigue, muscle aches and loss of appetite. After a person is exposed to mumps, symptoms usually appear 16 to 18 days after infection. Mumps cannot be treated.\n\nTwo doses of the mumps vaccine provides the best protection against the disease, according to the health department.\n\nThe department offered these tips to prevent the spread of mumps:\n- do not share food, drinks, utensils or other personal items that may contain saliva;\n- wash hands frequently with soap and water or use an alcohol-based hand rub;\n- cover your mouth with a tissue when sneezing or coughing and discard the tissue;\n- clean and disinfect objects and surfaces that may be contaminated with germs.\n\nPeople with mumps should stay home away from public places for 5 days after the onset of symptoms and limit contact with others in their households.\n\nMumps is no longer common in the United States. As of 13 Aug [2016], 1786 cases nationwide had been reported to the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention [in 2016].\n\n[byline: James T Mulder]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Mumps may no longer be common in the US, but this year (2016) there appear to be a spate of cases throughout the country to the extent that CDC is considering a 3rd dose of the MMR vaccine in certain situations.\n\nA map of the US showing all states discussed can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106. - Mod.LK]\nSee Also\nMumps - USA "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4528777", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (20)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4528777", "date": "2016-09-17 18:29:12", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (19)\n****************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] USA (New York)\n[2] USA (Illinois): CDC guidance on MMR vaccine\n[3] USA (Oklahoma)\n[4] USA (New York)\n\n******\n[1] USA (New York)\nDate: Tue 13 Sep 2016\nSource: Newsday [edited]\nhttp://www.newsday.com/news/health/mumps-outbreak-in-long-beach-grows-to-nearly-50-cases-officials-say-1.12310605\n\n\nLong Beach [New York] mumps outbreak nears 50 cases, say officials\n--------------------------------------------------------------------\nThe mumps outbreak that has been evident this summer in Long Beach has continued to grow as health experts across the country have begun documenting an unrelated spate of cases in nearly every state, health officials said Tuesday [13 Sep 2016].\n\nLocally, the outbreak has remained concentrated in the barrier island region where multiple suspect cases are under investigation by the State Department of Health.\n\n[byline: Delthia Ricks]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] USA (Illinois): CDC guidance on MMR vaccine\nDate: September 2016\nSource: Healio Infectious Disease News [edited]\nhttp://www.healio.com/infectious-disease/vaccine-preventable-diseases/news/print/infectious-disease-news/%7Be12a2a27-d121-4dc0-b05a-bbf77f921fd1%7D/cdc-considers-guidance-on-third-mmr-dose-following-campus-outbreak\n\n\nCDC considers guidance on 3rd MMR dose following campus outbreak\n----------------------------------------------------------------\nThe Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recently offered guidance on a 3rd dose of the measles-mumps-rubella [MMR] vaccine for adolescents and young adults following a recent mumps outbreak at the University of Illinois.\n\n\"No formal recommendation for or against the use of a 3rd MMR dose has been issued by the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP),\" Justin P Albertson, MS, from the Illinois Department of Public Health, and colleagues wrote in a recent MMWR. \"However, CDC has provided guidelines for use of a 3rd dose as a control measure during mumps outbreaks in settings in which persons are in close contact with one another, where transmission is sustained despite high 2-dose MMR coverage, and when traditional control measures fail to slow transmission.\"\n\nThe Illinois Department of Public Health (IDPH) confirmed an outbreak of mumps at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign (C-UPHD) on 1 May 2015. Between April 2015 and May 2016, researchers identified 317 cases on campus. The university, IDPH and the university's McKinley Health Center recommended a 3rd MMR vaccination due to the seasonal trends and characteristics of the population at risk.\n\nAbout 50 000 students and staff members were targeted for 3rd-dose vaccination on C-UPHD campus. A total of 8200 doses of MMR were administered at multiple vaccination sites at the university between 6 and 27 Aug 2015 to determine if a 3rd dose of MMR would prevent further exposure of mumps to healthy staff and students. In addition, the C-UPHD center administered 3300 doses in the fall and spring semesters.\n\nEpidemiological analysis showed that all 317 cases of mumps were associated with the university. Cases in students totaled 278 (88 per cent), 3 (1 per cent) occurred in staff members and 36 (11 per cent) in people not associated with the university but who had contact with students or the campus grounds. Among those who were diagnosed at the time of parotitis onset, 50 patients had received 3 doses of MMR vaccine, 232 patients had received 2 doses, 12 patients had received 1 dose, 7 patients were unvaccinated and 16 patients were unaware if they had been vaccinated. 90 per cent of patients with a 3rd dose received it during the outbreak, and 10 per cent had received it previously independent of this outbreak, according to the researchers.\n\n\"In light of the recent increased incidence of mumps, CDC is gathering additional data to assess use of a 3rd dose of vaccine to inform decision-making during outbreak responses and potential changes in the recommendations,\" they wrote.\n\nReference:\nAlbertson JP, et al. MMWR Morb Mortal Wkly Rep. 2016;doi:10.15585/mmwr.mm62529a2.\n\n[byline: Kate Sherrer]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[While a 3rd dose of the vaccine sounds like it might be helpful in boosting immunity, it must be given sufficiently prior to exposure for the immunity to be boosted to be protective. As noted above, 50 patients (out of 317) had received 3 doses of MMR vaccine. One must assume they were not vaccinated with the 3rd dose in time to protect them.\n\nA 3rd vaccination appears to have been very effective in the following study: Ogbuanu IU, et al. Pediatrics 2012; 130(6)(http://pediatrics.aappublications.org/content/pediatrics/early/2012/10/30/peds.2012-0177.full.pdf). This study was conducted to assess the impact of a 3rd dose of MMR vaccine during an outbreak in 2009-2010 among school students in 6th-12th grade. The decline in incidence shortly after the intervention suggests that a 3rd dose of MMR vaccine may help control mumps outbreaks among populations with preexisting high 2-dose vaccine coverage. The results indicated that of 2265 eligible students, 2178 (96.2 per cent) provided documentation of having received 2 previous doses of MMR vaccine, and a high proportion (1755 or 80.6 per cent) chose to receive an additional vaccine dose. The overall attack rate for all 6th- to 12th-grade students declined from 4.93 per cent in the prevaccination period to 0.13 per cent after vaccination (P, .001). Villagewide, overall attack rate declined by 75.6 per cent after the intervention. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[3] USA (Oklahoma)\nDate: Thu 15 Sep 2016\nSource: Enid News & Eagle [edited]\nhttp://www.enidnews.com/news/local_news/update-some-in-suspected-mumps-outbreak-were-vaccinated/article_47c989a4-7b67-11e6-8e84-dffe3f42c206.html\n\n\nUpdate: Some in suspected mumps outbreak were vaccinated\n--------------------------------------------------------\nGarfield County Health Department has confirmed at least some of the individuals who have or are suspected of having mumps in Garfield County [Oklahoma] have been vaccinated against the disease.\n\n\"I don't have numbers on this just yet -- but it does look as though some were fully vaccinated with MMR,\" Carla Dionne, director of Garfield County Health Department, reported in an email to the Enid News & Eagle. She added that this particular vaccine -- measles, mumps and rubella -- \"is 88 per cent effective -- but not perfect. Individuals with 2 doses can still get mumps.\"\n\nEnid Public Schools [EPS] sent out a text message Wednesday [14 Sep 2016] evening reporting that Garfield County Health Department has confirmed multiple cases of mumps in the community, including at Longfellow Middle School and Enid High School.\n\nOklahoma Health Department later reported there have been 4 confirmed cases in Garfield County and at least 34 suspected cases.\n\nEPS requires students to be in compliance with Oklahoma vaccination laws, EPS Communications Director Amber Graham Fitzgerald said. \"Prior to (Wednesday's) events, the EPS Health Services Department established (Thursday) as the deadline for compliance,\" she said. \"Those not in compliance -- there are about 12 students who don't have the MMR vaccine -- will not be allowed to return to school until they are in compliance.\" This does not include students who have a religious or physical exemption from vaccinations, she said.\n\nLaurence Burnsed, an epidemiologist with the Acute Disease Service for the Oklahoma State Department of Health, confirmed that some of those who are suspected of contracting the disease in Enid have been vaccinated and that others have not been or do not know if they have been vaccinated. \"That's what you might expect in an outbreak situation,\" Burnsed said. \"If you have the recommended 2 doses of MMR, you're at an 88 per cent level of protection, so if 100 people were exposed, you would still have about 12 experiencing symptoms. The vaccine is not 100 per cent protective.\" In the health department's collaboration with school officials, Burnsed said there seems to be a good level of vaccinations.\n\nThe MMR vaccine is available at Garfield County Health Department.\n\nMumps is a virus spread though coughing, sneezing and direct contact with saliva through eating or drinking after an infected person, according to Garfield County Health Department. Symptoms can last 7-10 days and usually appear 12-25 days after infection.\n\nMumps is characterized by puffy cheeks and a swollen jaw, due to swollen salivary glands. Other symptoms include body aches, tiredness and fever, and males may experience swollen, painful testicles, according to the department. In order to prevent spreading mumps, children who exhibit such symptoms should not attend school or day care through 5 days after the illness begins, according to the department.\n\nBurnsed encouraged those who have not been vaccinated or who are behind on their vaccination schedule to get the MMR vaccine to help protect against the illness. Burnsed also said the state department is not ruling out that Enid's suspected outbreak could be related to a similar outbreak in Arkansas. \"It's certainly possible, considering the proximity,\" Burnsed said. \"But we are still gathering information.\"\n\nOn Monday [12 Sep 2016], the Arkansas Department of Health reported almost 100 cases of mumps have been confirmed in the state, with most being in Springdale, but some reported in Rogers and potential cases in Fayetteville, Huntsville and West Fork, according to the Arkansas Democrat Gazette.\n\n[byline: Sally Asher]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The cases in Oklahoma had been fully vaccinated with 2 doses, but still came down with measles. This suggests 3 doses may be more protective. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[4] USA (New York)\nDate: Thu 15 Sep 2016\nSource: New York Upstate [edited]\nhttp://www.newyorkupstate.com/news/2016/09/ny_warns_state_colleges_about_mumps_outbreak.html\n\n\nNew York warns state colleges about mumps outbreak\n--------------------------------------------------\nA mumps case at SUNY [State University of New York] Oswego may be linked to an outbreak of the contagious viral infection in the Long Beach area of Long Island [New York]. "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4495932", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (19)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4495932", "date": "2016-09-17 18:29:12", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (19)\n****************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] USA (New York)\n[2] USA (Illinois): CDC guidance on MMR vaccine\n[3] USA (Oklahoma)\n[4] USA (New York)\n\n******\n[1] USA (New York)\nDate: Tue 13 Sep 2016\nSource: Newsday [edited]\nhttp://www.newsday.com/news/health/mumps-outbreak-in-long-beach-grows-to-nearly-50-cases-officials-say-1.12310605\n\n\nLong Beach [New York] mumps outbreak nears 50 cases, say officials\n--------------------------------------------------------------------\nThe mumps outbreak that has been evident this summer in Long Beach has continued to grow as health experts across the country have begun documenting an unrelated spate of cases in nearly every state, health officials said Tuesday [13 Sep 2016].\n\nLocally, the outbreak has remained concentrated in the barrier island region where multiple suspect cases are under investigation by the State Department of Health.\n\n[byline: Delthia Ricks]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] USA (Illinois): CDC guidance on MMR vaccine\nDate: September 2016\nSource: Healio Infectious Disease News [edited]\nhttp://www.healio.com/infectious-disease/vaccine-preventable-diseases/news/print/infectious-disease-news/%7Be12a2a27-d121-4dc0-b05a-bbf77f921fd1%7D/cdc-considers-guidance-on-third-mmr-dose-following-campus-outbreak\n\n\nCDC considers guidance on 3rd MMR dose following campus outbreak\n----------------------------------------------------------------\nThe Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recently offered guidance on a 3rd dose of the measles-mumps-rubella [MMR] vaccine for adolescents and young adults following a recent mumps outbreak at the University of Illinois.\n\n\"No formal recommendation for or against the use of a 3rd MMR dose has been issued by the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP),\" Justin P Albertson, MS, from the Illinois Department of Public Health, and colleagues wrote in a recent MMWR. \"However, CDC has provided guidelines for use of a 3rd dose as a control measure during mumps outbreaks in settings in which persons are in close contact with one another, where transmission is sustained despite high 2-dose MMR coverage, and when traditional control measures fail to slow transmission.\"\n\nThe Illinois Department of Public Health (IDPH) confirmed an outbreak of mumps at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign (C-UPHD) on 1 May 2015. Between April 2015 and May 2016, researchers identified 317 cases on campus. The university, IDPH and the university's McKinley Health Center recommended a 3rd MMR vaccination due to the seasonal trends and characteristics of the population at risk.\n\nAbout 50 000 students and staff members were targeted for 3rd-dose vaccination on C-UPHD campus. A total of 8200 doses of MMR were administered at multiple vaccination sites at the university between 6 and 27 Aug 2015 to determine if a 3rd dose of MMR would prevent further exposure of mumps to healthy staff and students. In addition, the C-UPHD center administered 3300 doses in the fall and spring semesters.\n\nEpidemiological analysis showed that all 317 cases of mumps were associated with the university. Cases in students totaled 278 (88 per cent), 3 (1 per cent) occurred in staff members and 36 (11 per cent) in people not associated with the university but who had contact with students or the campus grounds. Among those who were diagnosed at the time of parotitis onset, 50 patients had received 3 doses of MMR vaccine, 232 patients had received 2 doses, 12 patients had received 1 dose, 7 patients were unvaccinated and 16 patients were unaware if they had been vaccinated. 90 per cent of patients with a 3rd dose received it during the outbreak, and 10 per cent had received it previously independent of this outbreak, according to the researchers.\n\n\"In light of the recent increased incidence of mumps, CDC is gathering additional data to assess use of a 3rd dose of vaccine to inform decision-making during outbreak responses and potential changes in the recommendations,\" they wrote.\n\nReference:\nAlbertson JP, et al. MMWR Morb Mortal Wkly Rep. 2016;doi:10.15585/mmwr.mm62529a2.\n\n[byline: Kate Sherrer]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[While a 3rd dose of the vaccine sounds like it might be helpful in boosting immunity, it must be given sufficiently prior to exposure for the immunity to be boosted to be protective. As noted above, 50 patients (out of 317) had received 3 doses of MMR vaccine. One must assume they were not vaccinated with the 3rd dose in time to protect them.\n\nA 3rd vaccination appears to have been very effective in the following study: Ogbuanu IU, et al. Pediatrics 2012; 130(6)(http://pediatrics.aappublications.org/content/pediatrics/early/2012/10/30/peds.2012-0177.full.pdf). This study was conducted to assess the impact of a 3rd dose of MMR vaccine during an outbreak in 2009-2010 among school students in 6th-12th grade. The decline in incidence shortly after the intervention suggests that a 3rd dose of MMR vaccine may help control mumps outbreaks among populations with preexisting high 2-dose vaccine coverage. The results indicated that of 2265 eligible students, 2178 (96.2 per cent) provided documentation of having received 2 previous doses of MMR vaccine, and a high proportion (1755 or 80.6 per cent) chose to receive an additional vaccine dose. The overall attack rate for all 6th- to 12th-grade students declined from 4.93 per cent in the prevaccination period to 0.13 per cent after vaccination (P, .001). Villagewide, overall attack rate declined by 75.6 per cent after the intervention. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[3] USA (Oklahoma)\nDate: Thu 15 Sep 2016\nSource: Enid News & Eagle [edited]\nhttp://www.enidnews.com/news/local_news/update-some-in-suspected-mumps-outbreak-were-vaccinated/article_47c989a4-7b67-11e6-8e84-dffe3f42c206.html\n\n\nUpdate: Some in suspected mumps outbreak were vaccinated\n--------------------------------------------------------\nGarfield County Health Department has confirmed at least some of the individuals who have or are suspected of having mumps in Garfield County [Oklahoma] have been vaccinated against the disease.\n\n\"I don't have numbers on this just yet -- but it does look as though some were fully vaccinated with MMR,\" Carla Dionne, director of Garfield County Health Department, reported in an email to the Enid News & Eagle. She added that this particular vaccine -- measles, mumps and rubella -- \"is 88 per cent effective -- but not perfect. Individuals with 2 doses can still get mumps.\"\n\nEnid Public Schools [EPS] sent out a text message Wednesday [14 Sep 2016] evening reporting that Garfield County Health Department has confirmed multiple cases of mumps in the community, including at Longfellow Middle School and Enid High School.\n\nOklahoma Health Department later reported there have been 4 confirmed cases in Garfield County and at least 34 suspected cases.\n\nEPS requires students to be in compliance with Oklahoma vaccination laws, EPS Communications Director Amber Graham Fitzgerald said. \"Prior to (Wednesday's) events, the EPS Health Services Department established (Thursday) as the deadline for compliance,\" she said. \"Those not in compliance -- there are about 12 students who don't have the MMR vaccine -- will not be allowed to return to school until they are in compliance.\" This does not include students who have a religious or physical exemption from vaccinations, she said.\n\nLaurence Burnsed, an epidemiologist with the Acute Disease Service for the Oklahoma State Department of Health, confirmed that some of those who are suspected of contracting the disease in Enid have been vaccinated and that others have not been or do not know if they have been vaccinated. \"That's what you might expect in an outbreak situation,\" Burnsed said. \"If you have the recommended 2 doses of MMR, you're at an 88 per cent level of protection, so if 100 people were exposed, you would still have about 12 experiencing symptoms. The vaccine is not 100 per cent protective.\" In the health department's collaboration with school officials, Burnsed said there seems to be a good level of vaccinations.\n\nThe MMR vaccine is available at Garfield County Health Department.\n\nMumps is a virus spread though coughing, sneezing and direct contact with saliva through eating or drinking after an infected person, according to Garfield County Health Department. Symptoms can last 7-10 days and usually appear 12-25 days after infection.\n\nMumps is characterized by puffy cheeks and a swollen jaw, due to swollen salivary glands. Other symptoms include body aches, tiredness and fever, and males may experience swollen, painful testicles, according to the department. In order to prevent spreading mumps, children who exhibit such symptoms should not attend school or day care through 5 days after the illness begins, according to the department.\n\nBurnsed encouraged those who have not been vaccinated or who are behind on their vaccination schedule to get the MMR vaccine to help protect against the illness. Burnsed also said the state department is not ruling out that Enid's suspected outbreak could be related to a similar outbreak in Arkansas. \"It's certainly possible, considering the proximity,\" Burnsed said. \"But we are still gathering information.\"\n\nOn Monday [12 Sep 2016], the Arkansas Department of Health reported almost 100 cases of mumps have been confirmed in the state, with most being in Springdale, but some reported in Rogers and potential cases in Fayetteville, Huntsville and West Fork, according to the Arkansas Democrat Gazette.\n\n[byline: Sally Asher]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The cases in Oklahoma had been fully vaccinated with 2 doses, but still came down with measles. This suggests 3 doses may be more protective. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[4] USA (New York)\nDate: Thu 15 Sep 2016\nSource: New York Upstate [edited]\nhttp://www.newyorkupstate.com/news/2016/09/ny_warns_state_colleges_about_mumps_outbreak.html\n\n\nNew York warns state colleges about mumps outbreak\n--------------------------------------------------\nA mumps case at SUNY [State University of New York] Oswego may be linked to an outbreak of the contagious viral infection in the Long Beach area of Long Island [New York]. The State Health Department is warning colleges throughout the state the Long Beach outbreak could lead to other cases. The State Health Department said public health officials on Long Island have identified 45 mumps cases related to the Long Beach outbreak since July [2016].\n\nA SUNY Plattsburgh student also was recently diagnosed with mumps, but the source of that infection is still under investigation.\n\nBoth schools have notified unvaccinated students they will be barred from campus for 26 days after the last possible exposure if they do not get vaccinated. The health department said this step is being taken to avoid a large outbreak.\n\nMumps is characterized by fever, headache, swelling of the salivary glands, fatigue, muscle aches and loss of appetite. After a person is exposed to mumps, symptoms usually appear 16 to 18 days after infection. Mumps cannot be treated.\n\nTwo doses of the mumps vaccine provides the best protection against the disease, according to the health department.\n\nThe department offered these tips to prevent the spread of mumps:\n- do not share food, drinks, utensils or other personal items that may contain saliva;\n- wash hands frequently with soap and water or use an alcohol-based hand rub;\n- cover your mouth with a tissue when sneezing or coughing and discard the tissue;\n- clean and disinfect objects and surfaces that may be contaminated with germs.\n\nPeople with mumps should stay home away from public places for 5 days after the onset of symptoms and limit contact with others in their households.\n\nMumps is no longer common in the United States. As of 13 Aug [2016], 1786 cases nationwide had been reported to the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention [in 2016].\n\n[byline: James T Mulder]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Mumps may no longer be common in the US, but this year (2016) there appear to be a spate of cases throughout the country to the extent that CDC is considering a 3rd dose of the MMR vaccine in certain situations.\n\nA map of the US showing all states discussed can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106. - USA (18): (AR)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4478210", "date": "2016-05-18 11:17:49", "main_text": "MUMPS - CANADA: (BRITISH COLUMBIA)\n**********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 13 May 2016\nSource: News Talk 980 CKNW [edited]\nhttp://www.cknw.com/2016/05/13/mumps-outbreak-among-young-adults-in-whistler/\n\n\nHealth officials are urging those living in Whistler [British Columbia] to make sure their mumps vaccinations are up to date after an outbreak among young adults.\n\nVancouver Coastal Health Medical Health Officer Dr Paul Martiquet says 11 cases of the mumps have been reported in Whistler, a tourist town populated by foreign workers.\n\n\"Some of them aren't up to date with their immunization status, as a result, we've had mumps outbreaks [the last one in] 2011. We are advising everyone who was born after 1970 to make sure they are immunized, and to make sure they've had 2 doses of the vaccine -- not just one.\"\n\nThe highly contagious viral infection causes fever and swelling of the salivary glands. It is spread through coughing, sneezing, or sharing cups or utensils touched by saliva or mucus [of an infected person].\n\n[Byline: Shelby Thom]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Canada can be seen at https://canadaalive.files.wordpress.com/2014/02/canada_political_map.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/11997. Whistler Blackcomb is a major ski resort located 121 km [75 mi] north of Vancouver, in British Columbia.\n\nOutbreaks of mumps continue to occur in Canada and the proportion of cases aged 20 years and older has increased. Complications such as orchitis (inflammation of the testicles) and oophoritis (inflammation of the ovaries) are relatively frequent; permanent sequelae like deafness are rare.\n\nMumps vaccine is available as measles-mumps-rubella (MMR) or measles-mumps-rubella-varicella (MMRV) vaccine. Mumps vaccine effectiveness has been estimated at 62 to 91 percent for 1 dose and at 76 to 95 percent for 2 doses. Reactions to MMR and MMRV vaccine are generally mild and transient and include pain and redness at the injection site, low-grade fever, and rash.\n\n(Excerpted from http://www.phac-aspc.gc.ca/publicat/cig-gci/p04-mump-orei-eng.php). - USA (17): (AR)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4459649", "date": "2016-05-18 11:17:49", "main_text": "MUMPS - CANADA: (BRITISH COLUMBIA)\n**********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 13 May 2016\nSource: News Talk 980 CKNW [edited]\nhttp://www.cknw.com/2016/05/13/mumps-outbreak-among-young-adults-in-whistler/\n\n\nHealth officials are urging those living in Whistler [British Columbia] to make sure their mumps vaccinations are up to date after an outbreak among young adults.\n\nVancouver Coastal Health Medical Health Officer Dr Paul Martiquet says 11 cases of the mumps have been reported in Whistler, a tourist town populated by foreign workers.\n\n\"Some of them aren't up to date with their immunization status, as a result, we've had mumps outbreaks [the last one in] 2011. We are advising everyone who was born after 1970 to make sure they are immunized, and to make sure they've had 2 doses of the vaccine -- not just one.\"\n\nThe highly contagious viral infection causes fever and swelling of the salivary glands. It is spread through coughing, sneezing, or sharing cups or utensils touched by saliva or mucus [of an infected person].\n\n[Byline: Shelby Thom]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Canada can be seen at https://canadaalive.files.wordpress.com/2014/02/canada_political_map.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/11997. Whistler Blackcomb is a major ski resort located 121 km [75 mi] north of Vancouver, in British Columbia.\n\nOutbreaks of mumps continue to occur in Canada and the proportion of cases aged 20 years and older has increased. Complications such as orchitis (inflammation of the testicles) and oophoritis (inflammation of the ovaries) are relatively frequent; permanent sequelae like deafness are rare.\n\nMumps vaccine is available as measles-mumps-rubella (MMR) or measles-mumps-rubella-varicella (MMRV) vaccine. Mumps vaccine effectiveness has been estimated at 62 to 91 percent for 1 dose and at 76 to 95 percent for 2 doses. Reactions to MMR and MMRV vaccine are generally mild and transient and include pain and redness at the injection site, low-grade fever, and rash.\n\n(Excerpted from http://www.phac-aspc.gc.ca/publicat/cig-gci/p04-mump-orei-eng.php). - Mod.LK]\nSee Also\nMumps - USA (11): (MA) student cases 20160429.4192049\nMumps - USA (10): (IN,MA) student cases 20160415.4162668\nMumps - USA (09): (MN,ND,IN) 20160409.4148390\nMumps - USA (08): (ND) 20160403.4136830\nMumps - USA (07): (MT) student cases 20160318.4104627\nMumps - USA (06): (CA, NY) student cases 20160315.4095024\nMumps - USA (05): (MA) student cases 20160312.4088535\nMumps - USA (04): (MA, MT) student cases 20160311.4084267\nMumps - USA (03): (MA) student cases 20160308.4078373\nMumps - USA (02): (NH) student cases, alert 20160229.4057550\nMumps - USA: (CO,KY) increased incidence 20160225.4050452\n2015\n----\nMumps - Norway: increased incidence 20151109.3776723\nMumps - USA (05): (IA) returning university students 20150821.3594465\nMumps - Ireland (02) 20150806.3563027\nMumps - USA (04): (IL, MO) university students 20150730.3546295\nMumps - USA (03): (IL) university students 20150616.3442934\nMumps - Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SF", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MT", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4446845", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (16): (NY)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4446845", "date": "2016-05-18 11:17:49", "main_text": "MUMPS - CANADA: (BRITISH COLUMBIA)\n**********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 13 May 2016\nSource: News Talk 980 CKNW [edited]\nhttp://www.cknw.com/2016/05/13/mumps-outbreak-among-young-adults-in-whistler/\n\n\nHealth officials are urging those living in Whistler [British Columbia] to make sure their mumps vaccinations are up to date after an outbreak among young adults.\n\nVancouver Coastal Health Medical Health Officer Dr Paul Martiquet says 11 cases of the mumps have been reported in Whistler, a tourist town populated by foreign workers.\n\n\"Some of them aren't up to date with their immunization status, as a result, we've had mumps outbreaks [the last one in] 2011. We are advising everyone who was born after 1970 to make sure they are immunized, and to make sure they've had 2 doses of the vaccine -- not just one.\"\n\nThe highly contagious viral infection causes fever and swelling of the salivary glands. It is spread through coughing, sneezing, or sharing cups or utensils touched by saliva or mucus [of an infected person].\n\n[Byline: Shelby Thom]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Canada can be seen at https://canadaalive.files.wordpress.com/2014/02/canada_political_map.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/11997. Whistler Blackcomb is a major ski resort located 121 km [75 mi] north of Vancouver, in British Columbia.\n\nOutbreaks of mumps continue to occur in Canada and the proportion of cases aged 20 years and older has increased. Complications such as orchitis (inflammation of the testicles) and oophoritis (inflammation of the ovaries) are relatively frequent; permanent sequelae like deafness are rare.\n\nMumps vaccine is available as measles-mumps-rubella (MMR) or measles-mumps-rubella-varicella (MMRV) vaccine. Mumps vaccine effectiveness has been estimated at 62 to 91 percent for 1 dose and at 76 to 95 percent for 2 doses. Reactions to MMR and MMRV vaccine are generally mild and transient and include pain and redness at the injection site, low-grade fever, and rash.\n\n(Excerpted from http://www.phac-aspc.gc.ca/publicat/cig-gci/p04-mump-orei-eng.php). - USA (12): (WI,NE,MA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4237258", "date": "2016-05-18 11:17:49", "main_text": "MUMPS - CANADA: (BRITISH COLUMBIA)\n**********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 13 May 2016\nSource: News Talk 980 CKNW [edited]\nhttp://www.cknw.com/2016/05/13/mumps-outbreak-among-young-adults-in-whistler/\n\n\nHealth officials are urging those living in Whistler [British Columbia] to make sure their mumps vaccinations are up to date after an outbreak among young adults.\n\nVancouver Coastal Health Medical Health Officer Dr Paul Martiquet says 11 cases of the mumps have been reported in Whistler, a tourist town populated by foreign workers.\n\n\"Some of them aren't up to date with their immunization status, as a result, we've had mumps outbreaks [the last one in] 2011. We are advising everyone who was born after 1970 to make sure they are immunized, and to make sure they've had 2 doses of the vaccine -- not just one.\"\n\nThe highly contagious viral infection causes fever and swelling of the salivary glands. It is spread through coughing, sneezing, or sharing cups or utensils touched by saliva or mucus [of an infected person].\n\n[Byline: Shelby Thom]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Canada can be seen at https://canadaalive.files.wordpress.com/2014/02/canada_political_map.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/11997. Whistler Blackcomb is a major ski resort located 121 km [75 mi] north of Vancouver, in British Columbia.\n\nOutbreaks of mumps continue to occur in Canada and the proportion of cases aged 20 years and older has increased. Complications such as orchitis (inflammation of the testicles) and oophoritis (inflammation of the ovaries) are relatively frequent; permanent sequelae like deafness are rare.\n\nMumps vaccine is available as measles-mumps-rubella (MMR) or measles-mumps-rubella-varicella (MMRV) vaccine. Mumps vaccine effectiveness has been estimated at 62 to 91 percent for 1 dose and at 76 to 95 percent for 2 doses. Reactions to MMR and MMRV vaccine are generally mild and transient and include pain and redness at the injection site, low-grade fever, and rash.\n\n(Excerpted from http://www.phac-aspc.gc.ca/publicat/cig-gci/p04-mump-orei-eng.php). - Ireland: football players 20150223.3185969\nMumps - USA (02): (ID) university students 20150209.3153606\nMumps - UK: (Scotland) 20150204.3142750\nMumps - USA: (PA) professional hockey team players 20150109.3080644\n.................................................sb/lk/mj/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["measles", "mumps", "rubella", "varicella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2016-05-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "1970-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Vancouver", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Whistler", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "QC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "British Columbia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mumps - Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SF", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MT", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4228383", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Canada: (BC)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4228383", "date": "2016-05-18 11:17:49", "main_text": "MUMPS - CANADA: (BRITISH COLUMBIA)\n**********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 13 May 2016\nSource: News Talk 980 CKNW [edited]\nhttp://www.cknw.com/2016/05/13/mumps-outbreak-among-young-adults-in-whistler/\n\n\nHealth officials are urging those living in Whistler [British Columbia] to make sure their mumps vaccinations are up to date after an outbreak among young adults.\n\nVancouver Coastal Health Medical Health Officer Dr Paul Martiquet says 11 cases of the mumps have been reported in Whistler, a tourist town populated by foreign workers.\n\n\"Some of them aren't up to date with their immunization status, as a result, we've had mumps outbreaks [the last one in] 2011. We are advising everyone who was born after 1970 to make sure they are immunized, and to make sure they've had 2 doses of the vaccine -- not just one.\"\n\nThe highly contagious viral infection causes fever and swelling of the salivary glands. It is spread through coughing, sneezing, or sharing cups or utensils touched by saliva or mucus [of an infected person].\n\n[Byline: Shelby Thom]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Canada can be seen at https://canadaalive.files.wordpress.com/2014/02/canada_political_map.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/11997. Whistler Blackcomb is a major ski resort located 121 km [75 mi] north of Vancouver, in British Columbia.\n\nOutbreaks of mumps continue to occur in Canada and the proportion of cases aged 20 years and older has increased. Complications such as orchitis (inflammation of the testicles) and oophoritis (inflammation of the ovaries) are relatively frequent; permanent sequelae like deafness are rare.\n\nMumps vaccine is available as measles-mumps-rubella (MMR) or measles-mumps-rubella-varicella (MMRV) vaccine. Mumps vaccine effectiveness has been estimated at 62 to 91 percent for 1 dose and at 76 to 95 percent for 2 doses. Reactions to MMR and MMRV vaccine are generally mild and transient and include pain and redness at the injection site, low-grade fever, and rash.\n\n(Excerpted from http://www.phac-aspc.gc.ca/publicat/cig-gci/p04-mump-orei-eng.php). - Mod.LK]\nSee Also\nMumps - USA (11): (MA) student cases 20160429.4192049\nMumps - USA (10): (IN,MA) student cases 20160415.4162668\nMumps - USA (09): (MN,ND,IN) 20160409.4148390\nMumps - USA (08): (ND) 20160403.4136830\nMumps - USA (07): (MT) student cases 20160318.4104627\nMumps - USA (06): (CA, NY) student cases 20160315.4095024\nMumps - USA (05): (MA) student cases 20160312.4088535\nMumps - USA (04): (MA, MT) student cases 20160311.4084267\nMumps - USA (03): (MA) student cases 20160308.4078373\nMumps - USA (02): (NH) student cases, alert 20160229.4057550\nMumps - USA: (CO,KY) increased incidence 20160225.4050452\n2015\n----\nMumps - Norway: increased incidence 20151109.3776723\nMumps - USA (05): (IA) returning university students 20150821.3594465\nMumps - Ireland (02) 20150806.3563027\nMumps - USA (04): (IL, MO) university students 20150730.3546295\nMumps - USA (03): (IL) university students 20150616.3442934\nMumps - Ireland: football players 20150223.3185969\nMumps - USA (02): (ID) university students 20150209.3153606\nMumps - UK: (Scotland) 20150204.3142750\nMumps - USA: (PA) professional hockey team players 20150109.3080644\n.................................................sb/lk/mj/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["measles", "mumps", "rubella", "varicella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2016-05-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "1970-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Vancouver", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Whistler", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "QC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "British Columbia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mumps - Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SF", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MT", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4192049", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (11): (MA) student cases", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4192049", "date": "2016-03-11 09:06:43", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (04): (MASSACHUSETTS, MONTANA) STUDENT CASES\n********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Massachusetts: University of Massachusetts students\n[2] Montana: Belgrade schools\n\n******\n[1] Massachusetts: University of Massachusetts students\nDate: Wed 9 Mar 2016\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/umass-boston-reports-2nd-mumps-case-99723/\n\n\nFollowing reports of the 1st case of mumps in a UMass [University of Massachusetts] Boston (UMB) last week [week of 1 Mar 2016], school officials announced [Tue 8 Mar 2016] a 2nd confirmed case of the contagious viral disease.\n\nThe 1st on campus case occurred on 20 Feb 2016 during the UMB Men's hockey team match against University of Southern Maine (USM), according to a University Health Services release.\n\nUSM has previously reported a confirmed mumps case last week.\n\nMumps is a contagious disease. The most common symptom is swelling of the cheeks and jaw due to inflammation of one or both of the saliva glands near the ear and back of the jaw. However, up to half of the people with mumps may not have enough swelling to show. Other symptoms include fever, headache, stiff neck, and loss of appetite.\n\nCurrently, there is no specific treatment for mumps. Supportive care should be given as needed. If someone becomes very ill, they should seek medical attention. If someone seeks medical attention, they should call their healthcare provider in advance so that they do not have to sit in the waiting room for a long time and possibly infect other people.\n\nUMB student health asks that you seek medical care if you experience any of the symptoms noted above in the next 2 weeks. Please call or come to see us, or visit your own healthcare provider. Please be sure to tell your provider that there was a confirmed case of mumps on campus.\n\n[Byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The report stated the University of Massachusetts Boston hockey team was matched against Southern Maine University (SMU), and in the next line stated \"USM has previously reported a confirmed mumps case last week.\" Since SMU is Southern Methodist University, but the report names the University as Southern Maine University, I have taken the liberty of changing the name to University of Southern Maine, USM, which I suspect is correct.\n\nPlease see comments about mumps activity in the United States following item [2] below. - Mod.LK\n\nThe state of Massachusetts can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/16731. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[2] Montana: Belgrade schools\nDate: Wed 9 Mar 2016\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/mumps-reported-in-belgrade-montana-students-70542/\n\n\nHealth officials in Gallatin County, Montana are reporting on 4 mumps cases among students in Belgrade schools. All of the confirmed cases attend Belgrade High School or Belgrade Middle School.\n\nMumps is a viral disease characterized by swelling of the parotid or salivary glands along the face, neck, and jaw. The swelling can last from 2 to 10 days. The incubation period, (time from when you were infected to when you have symptoms) is 12-25 days. Other symptoms, in addition to the swelling around the neck and jaw, include fever, malaise (tiredness), muscle aches, and headache. Up to 25% of people with mumps may have few or no symptoms.\n\nMumps is spread by droplets of saliva or mucus from the mouth, nose, or throat of an infected person. Saliva can pass from one person to another when they share straws, spoons, forks, cups, cans, bottles, and even lip gloss. Mumps is also commonly spread when an infected person coughs or sneezes, and a non-infected person inhales respiratory droplets that contain the virus.\n\nIf you do have mumps, you should avoid prolonged, close contact with other people until at least 5 days after your salivary glands begin to swell because you are contagious during this time.\n\nParents of children who may be most susceptible to mumps will be notified by staff from Gallatin City-County Health Department who will provide information and health care guidance. In most cases, students who are most susceptible to mumps are those who have not been vaccinated against the disease.\n\nThe good news is that guidance from the American Academy of Pediatrics and the Centers for Disease Control has determined that unimmunized students can return to school immediately if they are vaccinated against mumps.\n\nStudents who have religious or medical exemptions for the MMR [measles, mumps, rubella] vaccine may be excluded from school for 25 days or more, depending on the course of the outbreak. But again, if students are vaccinated with the MMR vaccine they can return to school immediately.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Montana can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/35926. Gallatin County, in southern Montana, can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/montana-county-map.gif.\n\nFrom 2000 through 2012, an average of 1135 mumps cases (range: 229 to 6584) were reported annually in the United States. Large outbreaks occurred in 2006 (6584 cases) and in 2009 and 2010 (approximately 3500 cases). Outbreaks occurred primarily among previously vaccinated persons in densely populated settings (colleges and religious communities). A provisional total of 438 mumps cases were reported in 2013.\n\nMMR vaccine is recommended routinely for all children age 12 through 15 months, with a 2nd dose at age 4 through 6 years. The 2nd dose is not a booster, but rather is intended to produce immunity in the small number of people who fail to respond to the 1st dose. 2-5% of people do not develop measles immunity after the 1st dose of vaccine. This occurs for a variety of reasons.\n\nTo protect against mumps, adults with no evidence of immunity should get 1 dose of MMR unless the adult is in a high-risk group. High-risk people need 2 doses and include healthcare personnel, international travelers, and students at post-high school educational institutions, among others (excerpted/edited from http://www.immunize.org/askexperts/experts_mmr.asp).\n\nMumps is no longer common in the United States, but periodic mumps outbreaks occur, particularly in winter and spring, and cases may still occur despite prior vaccination. Crowded environments, such as college classes, organized sports, or dormitories, are a major contributing factor to the spread of mumps if the virus is introduced.\n\n80 to 90% of vaccinees will be fully protected, but those who do become infected following vaccination tend to have milder disease when exposed to the virus. If a community maintains a high vaccination rate, the risk of exposure declines too. - Mod.LK]\nSee Also\nMumps - USA (03): (MA) student cases 20160308.4078373\nMumps - USA (02): (NH) student cases, alert 20160229.4057550\nMumps - USA: (CO,KY) increased incidence 20160225.4050452\n2015\n----\nMumps - Norway: increased incidence 20151109.3776723\nMumps - Argentina: (SF) increased incidence 20151031.3758370\nMumps - USA (08): (IL) college students 20150922.3662990\nMumps - USA (07): (IL) community college students, RFI 20150918.3654737\nMumps - USA (06): (IL) returning university students, further development 20150828.3608518\nMumps - USA (05): (IA) returning university students 20150821.3594465\nMumps - Ireland (02) 20150806.3563027\nMumps - USA (04): (IL, MO) university students 20150730.3546295\nMumps - USA (03): (IL) university students 20150616.3442934\nMumps - Canada (02): (ON) school children 20150624.3462267\nMumps - Canada (QC): school children, correction (ON) 20150529.3396108\nMumps - Canada (QC): school children 20150529.3395573\nMumps - Australia (WA) 20150426.3323826\nMumps - Ireland: football players 20150223.3185969\nMumps - USA (02): (ID) university students 20150209.3153606\nMumps - UK: (Scotland) 20150204.3142750\nMumps - USA: (PA) professional hockey team players 20150109.3080644\n.................................................sb/lk/mj/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-02-20 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "1135-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "QC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gallatin City - County Health Department", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Belgrade", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gallatin County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Montana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mumps -
