Crowded environments, such as college classes, organized sports, or dormitories, are a major contributing factor to the spread of mumps if the virus is introduced.\n\n80 to 90% of vaccinees will be fully protected, but those who do become infected following vaccination tend to have milder disease when exposed to the virus. If a community maintains a high vaccination rate, the risk of exposure declines too. - Mod.LK]\nSee Also\nMumps - USA (03): (MA) student cases 20160308.4078373\nMumps - USA (02): (NH) student cases, alert 20160229.4057550\nMumps - USA: (CO,KY) increased incidence 20160225.4050452\n2015\n----\nMumps - Norway: increased incidence 20151109.3776723\nMumps - Argentina: (SF) increased incidence 20151031.3758370\nMumps - USA (08): (IL) college students 20150922.3662990\nMumps - USA (07): (IL) community college students, RFI 20150918.3654737\nMumps - USA (06): (IL) returning university students, further development 20150828.3608518\nMumps - USA (05): (IA) returning university students 20150821.3594465\nMumps - Ireland (02) 20150806.3563027\nMumps - USA (04): (IL, MO) university students 20150730.3546295\nMumps - USA (03): (IL) university students 20150616.3442934\nMumps - Canada (02): (ON) school children 20150624.3462267\nMumps - Canada (QC): school children, correction (ON) 20150529.3396108\nMumps - Canada (QC): school children 20150529.3395573\nMumps - Australia (WA) 20150426.3323826\nMumps - Ireland: football players 20150223.3185969\nMumps - USA (02): (ID) university students 20150209.3153606\nMumps - UK: (Scotland) 20150204.3142750\nMumps - USA: (PA) professional hockey team players 20150109.3080644\n.................................................sb/lk/mj/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-02-20 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "1135-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "QC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gallatin City - County Health Department", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Belgrade", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gallatin County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Montana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mumps - Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SF", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Massachusetts", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4148390", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (09): (MN,ND,IN)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4148390", "date": "2016-03-11 09:06:43", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (04): (MASSACHUSETTS, MONTANA) STUDENT CASES\n********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Massachusetts: University of Massachusetts students\n[2] Montana: Belgrade schools\n\n******\n[1] Massachusetts: University of Massachusetts students\nDate: Wed 9 Mar 2016\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/umass-boston-reports-2nd-mumps-case-99723/\n\n\nFollowing reports of the 1st case of mumps in a UMass [University of Massachusetts] Boston (UMB) last week [week of 1 Mar 2016], school officials announced [Tue 8 Mar 2016] a 2nd confirmed case of the contagious viral disease.\n\nThe 1st on campus case occurred on 20 Feb 2016 during the UMB Men's hockey team match against University of Southern Maine (USM), according to a University Health Services release.\n\nUSM has previously reported a confirmed mumps case last week.\n\nMumps is a contagious disease. The most common symptom is swelling of the cheeks and jaw due to inflammation of one or both of the saliva glands near the ear and back of the jaw. However, up to half of the people with mumps may not have enough swelling to show. Other symptoms include fever, headache, stiff neck, and loss of appetite.\n\nCurrently, there is no specific treatment for mumps. Supportive care should be given as needed. If someone becomes very ill, they should seek medical attention. If someone seeks medical attention, they should call their healthcare provider in advance so that they do not have to sit in the waiting room for a long time and possibly infect other people.\n\nUMB student health asks that you seek medical care if you experience any of the symptoms noted above in the next 2 weeks. Please call or come to see us, or visit your own healthcare provider. Please be sure to tell your provider that there was a confirmed case of mumps on campus.\n\n[Byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The report stated the University of Massachusetts Boston hockey team was matched against Southern Maine University (SMU), and in the next line stated \"USM has previously reported a confirmed mumps case last week.\" Since SMU is Southern Methodist University, but the report names the University as Southern Maine University, I have taken the liberty of changing the name to University of Southern Maine, USM, which I suspect is correct.\n\nPlease see comments about mumps activity in the United States following item [2] below. - Mod.LK\n\nThe state of Massachusetts can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/16731. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[2] Montana: Belgrade schools\nDate: Wed 9 Mar 2016\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/mumps-reported-in-belgrade-montana-students-70542/\n\n\nHealth officials in Gallatin County, Montana are reporting on 4 mumps cases among students in Belgrade schools. All of the confirmed cases attend Belgrade High School or Belgrade Middle School.\n\nMumps is a viral disease characterized by swelling of the parotid or salivary glands along the face, neck, and jaw. The swelling can last from 2 to 10 days. The incubation period, (time from when you were infected to when you have symptoms) is 12-25 days. Other symptoms, in addition to the swelling around the neck and jaw, include fever, malaise (tiredness), muscle aches, and headache. Up to 25% of people with mumps may have few or no symptoms.\n\nMumps is spread by droplets of saliva or mucus from the mouth, nose, or throat of an infected person. Saliva can pass from one person to another when they share straws, spoons, forks, cups, cans, bottles, and even lip gloss. Mumps is also commonly spread when an infected person coughs or sneezes, and a non-infected person inhales respiratory droplets that contain the virus.\n\nIf you do have mumps, you should avoid prolonged, close contact with other people until at least 5 days after your salivary glands begin to swell because you are contagious during this time.\n\nParents of children who may be most susceptible to mumps will be notified by staff from Gallatin City-County Health Department who will provide information and health care guidance. In most cases, students who are most susceptible to mumps are those who have not been vaccinated against the disease.\n\nThe good news is that guidance from the American Academy of Pediatrics and the Centers for Disease Control has determined that unimmunized students can return to school immediately if they are vaccinated against mumps.\n\nStudents who have religious or medical exemptions for the MMR [measles, mumps, rubella] vaccine may be excluded from school for 25 days or more, depending on the course of the outbreak. But again, if students are vaccinated with the MMR vaccine they can return to school immediately.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Montana can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/35926. Gallatin County, in southern Montana, can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/montana-county-map.gif.\n\nFrom 2000 through 2012, an average of 1135 mumps cases (range: 229 to 6584) were reported annually in the United States. Large outbreaks occurred in 2006 (6584 cases) and in 2009 and 2010 (approximately 3500 cases). Outbreaks occurred primarily among previously vaccinated persons in densely populated settings (colleges and religious communities). A provisional total of 438 mumps cases were reported in 2013.\n\nMMR vaccine is recommended routinely for all children age 12 through 15 months, with a 2nd dose at age 4 through 6 years. The 2nd dose is not a booster, but rather is intended to produce immunity in the small number of people who fail to respond to the 1st dose. 2-5% of people do not develop measles immunity after the 1st dose of vaccine. This occurs for a variety of reasons.\n\nTo protect against mumps, adults with no evidence of immunity should get 1 dose of MMR unless the adult is in a high-risk group. High-risk people need 2 doses and include healthcare personnel, international travelers, and students at post-high school educational institutions, among others (excerpted/edited from http://www.immunize.org/askexperts/experts_mmr.asp).\n\nMumps is no longer common in the United States, but periodic mumps outbreaks occur, particularly in winter and spring, and cases may still occur despite prior vaccination. Crowded environments, such as college classes, organized sports, or dormitories, are a major contributing factor to the spread of mumps if the virus is introduced.\n\n80 to 90% of vaccinees will be fully protected, but those who do become infected following vaccination tend to have milder disease when exposed to the virus. If a community maintains a high vaccination rate, the risk of exposure declines too. - Mod.LK]\nSee Also\nMumps - USA (03): (MA) student cases 20160308.4078373\nMumps - USA (02): (NH) student cases, alert 20160229.4057550\nMumps - USA: (CO,KY) increased incidence 20160225.4050452\n2015\n----\nMumps - Norway: increased incidence 20151109.3776723\nMumps - Argentina: (SF) increased incidence 20151031.3758370\nMumps - USA (08): (IL) college students 20150922.3662990\nMumps - USA (07): (IL) community college students, RFI 20150918.3654737\nMumps - USA (06): (IL) returning university students, further development 20150828.3608518\nMumps - USA (05): (IA) returning university students 20150821.3594465\nMumps - Ireland (02) 20150806.3563027\nMumps - USA (04): (IL, MO) university students 20150730.3546295\nMumps - USA (03): (IL) university students 20150616.3442934\nMumps - Canada (02): (ON) school children 20150624.3462267\nMumps - Canada (QC): school children, correction (ON) 20150529.3396108\nMumps - Canada (QC): school children 20150529.3395573\nMumps - Australia (WA) 20150426.3323826\nMumps - Ireland: football players 20150223.3185969\nMumps - USA (02): (ID) university students 20150209.3153606\nMumps - UK: (Scotland) 20150204.3142750\nMumps - USA: (PA) professional hockey team players 20150109.3080644\n.................................................sb/lk/mj/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-02-20 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "1135-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "QC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gallatin City - USA (07): (MT) student cases", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4104627", "date": "2016-03-11 09:06:43", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (04): (MASSACHUSETTS, MONTANA) STUDENT CASES\n********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Massachusetts: University of Massachusetts students\n[2] Montana: Belgrade schools\n\n******\n[1] Massachusetts: University of Massachusetts students\nDate: Wed 9 Mar 2016\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/umass-boston-reports-2nd-mumps-case-99723/\n\n\nFollowing reports of the 1st case of mumps in a UMass [University of Massachusetts] Boston (UMB) last week [week of 1 Mar 2016], school officials announced [Tue 8 Mar 2016] a 2nd confirmed case of the contagious viral disease.\n\nThe 1st on campus case occurred on 20 Feb 2016 during the UMB Men's hockey team match against University of Southern Maine (USM), according to a University Health Services release.\n\nUSM has previously reported a confirmed mumps case last week.\n\nMumps is a contagious disease. This occurs for a variety of reasons.\n\nTo protect against mumps, adults with no evidence of immunity should get 1 dose of MMR unless the adult is in a high-risk group. High-risk people need 2 doses and include healthcare personnel, international travelers, and students at post-high school educational institutions, among others (excerpted/edited from http://www.immunize.org/askexperts/experts_mmr.asp).\n\nMumps is no longer common in the United States, but periodic mumps outbreaks occur, particularly in winter and spring, and cases may still occur despite prior vaccination. Crowded environments, such as college classes, organized sports, or dormitories, are a major contributing factor to the spread of mumps if the virus is introduced.\n\n80 to 90% of vaccinees will be fully protected, but those who do become infected following vaccination tend to have milder disease when exposed to the virus. If a community maintains a high vaccination rate, the risk of exposure declines too. - Mod.LK]\nSee Also\nMumps - USA (03): (MA) student cases 20160308.4078373\nMumps - USA (02): (NH) student cases, alert 20160229.4057550\nMumps - USA: (CO,KY) increased incidence 20160225.4050452\n2015\n----\nMumps - Norway: increased incidence 20151109.3776723\nMumps - Argentina: (SF) increased incidence 20151031.3758370\nMumps - USA (08): (IL) college students 20150922.3662990\nMumps - USA (07): (IL) community college students, RFI 20150918.3654737\nMumps - USA (06): (IL) returning university students, further development 20150828.3608518\nMumps - USA (05): (IA) returning university students 20150821.3594465\nMumps - Ireland (02) 20150806.3563027\nMumps - USA (04): (IL, MO) university students 20150730.3546295\nMumps - USA (03): (IL) university students 20150616.3442934\nMumps - Canada (02): (ON) school children 20150624.3462267\nMumps - Canada (QC): school children, correction (ON) 20150529.3396108\nMumps - Canada (QC): school children 20150529.3395573\nMumps - Australia (WA) 20150426.3323826\nMumps - Ireland: football players 20150223.3185969\nMumps - USA (02): (ID) university students 20150209.3153606\nMumps - UK: (Scotland) 20150204.3142750\nMumps - USA: (PA) professional hockey team players 20150109.3080644\n.................................................sb/lk/mj/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-02-20 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "1135-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "QC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gallatin City - County Health Department", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Belgrade", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gallatin County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Montana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mumps - Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SF", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Massachusetts", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4095024", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (06): (CA, NY) student cases", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4095024", "date": "2016-03-11 09:06:43", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (04): (MASSACHUSETTS, MONTANA) STUDENT CASES\n********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Massachusetts: University of Massachusetts students\n[2] Montana: Belgrade schools\n\n******\n[1] Massachusetts: University of Massachusetts students\nDate: Wed 9 Mar 2016\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/umass-boston-reports-2nd-mumps-case-99723/\n\n\nFollowing reports of the 1st case of mumps in a UMass [University of Massachusetts] Boston (UMB) last week [week of 1 Mar 2016], school officials announced [Tue 8 Mar 2016] a 2nd confirmed case of the contagious viral disease.\n\nThe 1st on campus case occurred on 20 Feb 2016 during the UMB Men's hockey team match against University of Southern Maine (USM), according to a University Health Services release.\n\nUSM has previously reported a confirmed mumps case last week.\n\nMumps is a contagious disease. The most common symptom is swelling of the cheeks and jaw due to inflammation of one or both of the saliva glands near the ear and back of the jaw. However, up to half of the people with mumps may not have enough swelling to show. Other symptoms include fever, headache, stiff neck, and loss of appetite.\n\nCurrently, there is no specific treatment for mumps. Supportive care should be given as needed. If someone becomes very ill, they should seek medical attention. If someone seeks medical attention, they should call their healthcare provider in advance so that they do not have to sit in the waiting room for a long time and possibly infect other people.\n\nUMB student health asks that you seek medical care if you experience any of the symptoms noted above in the next 2 weeks. Please call or come to see us, or visit your own healthcare provider. Please be sure to tell your provider that there was a confirmed case of mumps on campus.\n\n[Byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The report stated the University of Massachusetts Boston hockey team was matched against Southern Maine University (SMU), and in the next line stated \"USM has previously reported a confirmed mumps case last week.\" Since SMU is Southern Methodist University, but the report names the University as Southern Maine University, I have taken the liberty of changing the name to University of Southern Maine, USM, which I suspect is correct.\n\nPlease see comments about mumps activity in the United States following item [2] below. - Mod.LK\n\nThe state of Massachusetts can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/16731. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[2] Montana: Belgrade schools\nDate: Wed 9 Mar 2016\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/mumps-reported-in-belgrade-montana-students-70542/\n\n\nHealth officials in Gallatin County, Montana are reporting on 4 mumps cases among students in Belgrade schools. All of the confirmed cases attend Belgrade High School or Belgrade Middle School.\n\nMumps is a viral disease characterized by swelling of the parotid or salivary glands along the face, neck, and jaw. The swelling can last from 2 to 10 days. The incubation period, (time from when you were infected to when you have symptoms) is 12-25 days. Other symptoms, in addition to the swelling around the neck and jaw, include fever, malaise (tiredness), muscle aches, and headache. Up to 25% of people with mumps may have few or no symptoms.\n\nMumps is spread by droplets of saliva or mucus from the mouth, nose, or throat of an infected person. Saliva can pass from one person to another when they share straws, spoons, forks, cups, cans, bottles, and even lip gloss. Mumps is also commonly spread when an infected person coughs or sneezes, and a non-infected person inhales respiratory droplets that contain the virus.\n\nIf you do have mumps, you should avoid prolonged, close contact with other people until at least 5 days after your salivary glands begin to swell because you are contagious during this time.\n\nParents of children who may be most susceptible to mumps will be notified by staff from Gallatin City-County Health Department who will provide information and health care guidance. In most cases, students who are most susceptible to mumps are those who have not been vaccinated against the disease.\n\nThe good news is that guidance from the American Academy of Pediatrics and the Centers for Disease Control has determined that unimmunized students can return to school immediately if they are vaccinated against mumps.\n\nStudents who have religious or medical exemptions for the MMR [measles, mumps, rubella] vaccine may be excluded from school for 25 days or more, depending on the course of the outbreak. But again, if students are vaccinated with the MMR vaccine they can return to school immediately.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Montana can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/35926. Gallatin County, in southern Montana, can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/montana-county-map.gif.\n\nFrom 2000 through 2012, an average of 1135 mumps cases (range: 229 to 6584) were reported annually in the United States. Large outbreaks occurred in 2006 (6584 cases) and in 2009 and 2010 (approximately 3500 cases). Outbreaks occurred primarily among previously vaccinated persons in densely populated settings (colleges and religious communities). A provisional total of 438 mumps cases were reported in 2013.\n\nMMR vaccine is recommended routinely for all children age 12 through 15 months, with a 2nd dose at age 4 through 6 years. The 2nd dose is not a booster, but rather is intended to produce immunity in the small number of people who fail to respond to the 1st dose. 2-5% of people do not develop measles immunity after the 1st dose of vaccine. This occurs for a variety of reasons.\n\nTo protect against mumps, adults with no evidence of immunity should get 1 dose of MMR unless the adult is in a high-risk group. High-risk people need 2 doses and include healthcare personnel, international travelers, and students at post-high school educational institutions, among others (excerpted/edited from http://www.immunize.org/askexperts/experts_mmr.asp).\n\nMumps is no longer common in the United States, but periodic mumps outbreaks occur, particularly in winter and spring, and cases may still occur despite prior vaccination. Crowded environments, such as college classes, organized sports, or dormitories, are a major contributing factor to the spread of mumps if the virus is introduced.\n\n80 to 90% of vaccinees will be fully protected, but those who do become infected following vaccination tend to have milder disease when exposed to the virus. If a community maintains a high vaccination rate, the risk of exposure declines too. - Mod.LK]\nSee Also\nMumps - USA (03): (MA) student cases 20160308.4078373\nMumps - USA (02): (NH) student cases, alert 20160229.4057550\nMumps - USA: (CO,KY) increased incidence 20160225.4050452\n2015\n----\nMumps - Norway: increased incidence 20151109.3776723\nMumps - Argentina: (SF) increased incidence 20151031.3758370\nMumps - USA (08): (IL) college students 20150922.3662990\nMumps - USA (07): (IL) community college students, RFI 20150918.3654737\nMumps - USA (06): (IL) returning university students, further development 20150828.3608518\nMumps - USA (05): (IA) returning university students 20150821.3594465\nMumps - Ireland (02) 20150806.3563027\nMumps - USA (04): (IL, MO) university students 20150730.3546295\nMumps - USA (03): (IL) university students 20150616.3442934\nMumps - Canada (02): (ON) school children 20150624.3462267\nMumps - Canada (QC): school children, correction (ON) 20150529.3396108\nMumps - Canada (QC): school children 20150529.3395573\nMumps - Australia (WA) 20150426.3323826\nMumps - Ireland: football players 20150223.3185969\nMumps - USA (02): (ID) university students 20150209.3153606\nMumps - UK: (Scotland) 20150204.3142750\nMumps - USA: (PA) professional hockey team players 20150109.3080644\n.................................................sb/lk/mj/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-02-20 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "1135-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "QC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gallatin City - USA (04): (MA, MT) student cases", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4084267", "date": "2016-03-11 09:06:43", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (04): (MASSACHUSETTS, MONTANA) STUDENT CASES\n********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Massachusetts: University of Massachusetts students\n[2] Montana: Belgrade schools\n\n******\n[1] Massachusetts: University of Massachusetts students\nDate: Wed 9 Mar 2016\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/umass-boston-reports-2nd-mumps-case-99723/\n\n\nFollowing reports of the 1st case of mumps in a UMass [University of Massachusetts] Boston (UMB) last week [week of 1 Mar 2016], school officials announced [Tue 8 Mar 2016] a 2nd confirmed case of the contagious viral disease.\n\nThe 1st on campus case occurred on 20 Feb 2016 during the UMB Men's hockey team match against University of Southern Maine (USM), according to a University Health Services release.\n\nUSM has previously reported a confirmed mumps case last week.\n\nMumps is a contagious disease. The 2nd dose is not a booster, but rather is intended to produce immunity in the small number of people who fail to respond to the 1st dose. 2-5% of people do not develop measles immunity after the 1st dose of vaccine. This occurs for a variety of reasons.\n\nTo protect against mumps, adults with no evidence of immunity should get 1 dose of MMR unless the adult is in a high-risk group. High-risk people need 2 doses and include healthcare personnel, international travelers, and students at post-high school educational institutions, among others (excerpted/edited from http://www.immunize.org/askexperts/experts_mmr.asp).\n\nMumps is no longer common in the United States, but periodic mumps outbreaks occur, particularly in winter and spring, and cases may still occur despite prior vaccination. Crowded environments, such as college classes, organized sports, or dormitories, are a major contributing factor to the spread of mumps if the virus is introduced.\n\n80 to 90% of vaccinees will be fully protected, but those who do become infected following vaccination tend to have milder disease when exposed to the virus. If a community maintains a high vaccination rate, the risk of exposure declines too. - Mod.LK]\nSee Also\nMumps - USA (03): (MA) student cases 20160308.4078373\nMumps - USA (02): (NH) student cases, alert 20160229.4057550\nMumps - USA: (CO,KY) increased incidence 20160225.4050452\n2015\n----\nMumps - Norway: increased incidence 20151109.3776723\nMumps - Argentina: (SF) increased incidence 20151031.3758370\nMumps - USA (08): (IL) college students 20150922.3662990\nMumps - USA (07): (IL) community college students, RFI 20150918.3654737\nMumps - USA (06): (IL) returning university students, further development 20150828.3608518\nMumps - USA (05): (IA) returning university students 20150821.3594465\nMumps - Canada (QC): school children, correction (ON) 20150529.3396108\nMumps - Canada (QC): school children 20150529.3395573\nMumps - Australia (WA) 20150426.3323826\nMumps - Ireland: football players 20150223.3185969\nMumps - USA (02): (ID) university students 20150209.3153606\nMumps - UK: (Scotland) 20150204.3142750\nMumps - USA: (PA) professional hockey team players 20150109.3080644\n.................................................sb/lk/mj/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-02-20 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "1135-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "QC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gallatin City - Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SF", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Massachusetts", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4078373", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (03): (MA) student cases", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4078373", "date": "2015-09-18 17:34:08", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (07): (ILLINOIS) COMMUNITY COLLEGE STUDENTS, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n********************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 16 Sep 2015\nSource: WJBC [edited]\nhttp://www.wjbc.com/2015/09/16/mumps-outbreak-declared-at-heartland-community-college/\n\n\nMumps outbreak declared at Heartland Community College: Illinois\n----------------------------------------------------------------\nThe Illinois Department of Public Health [IDPH] has declared a mumps outbreak at Heartland Community College [Normal, McLean County, Illinois]. The IDPH says 4 cases have been found at the college. Letters are being sent out to students, faculty and staff the health department has determined were in close contact with those who were infected.\n\nAs of [16 Sep 2015], 6 cases of mumps have been identified in McLean County and more test results are pending.\n\nThe symptoms of mumps include fever, headache and swollen salivary glands, and malaise. Symptoms usually appear 12 to 25 days after [a person becomes] infected.\n\n[Byline: Joe Ragusa]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This outbreak appears to be part of the larger epidemic affecting students in more than one educational establishment in the state of Illinois. Further information would be appreciated regarding the source of the virus responsible for the initiation of the outbreak and the failure of vaccination to contain the spread of the outbreak. So far it has been reported [in ProMED-mail post 20150828.3608518] that: \"Champaign-Urbana [Illinois] is experiencing the largest outbreak of the mumps ever to hit the area with around 100 cases confirmed as of Wednesday morning [26 Aug 2015]. Researchers say the mass mumps outbreak began this spring [2015] on the University of Illinois campus. They attribute the spread of the infection to students living in close quarters and interacting in large social settings. The best protection against the mumps is the MMR [measles, mumps, rubella] vaccine, but the standard 2 doses only offer 85 percent protection. So the CDC and the Illinois Department of Public Health recommend everyone in the community get a 3rd booster shot, which increases that immunity level to 95 percent.\" - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/7999.]\nSee Also\nMumps - USA (07): (ILLINOIS) COMMUNITY COLLEGE STUDENTS, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n********************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 16 Sep 2015\nSource: WJBC [edited]\nhttp://www.wjbc.com/2015/09/16/mumps-outbreak-declared-at-heartland-community-college/\n\n\nMumps outbreak declared at Heartland Community College: Illinois\n----------------------------------------------------------------\nThe Illinois Department of Public Health [IDPH] has declared a mumps outbreak at Heartland Community College [Normal, McLean County, Illinois]. The IDPH says 4 cases have been found at the college. Letters are being sent out to students, faculty and staff the health department has determined were in close contact with those who were infected.\n\nAs of [16 Sep 2015], 6 cases of mumps have been identified in McLean County and more test results are pending.\n\nThe symptoms of mumps include fever, headache and swollen salivary glands, and malaise. Symptoms usually appear 12 to 25 days after [a person becomes] infected.\n\n[Byline: Joe Ragusa]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This outbreak appears to be part of the larger epidemic affecting students in more than one educational establishment in the state of Illinois. Further information would be appreciated regarding the source of the virus responsible for the initiation of the outbreak and the failure of vaccination to contain the spread of the outbreak. So far it has been reported [in ProMED-mail post 20150828.3608518] that: \"Champaign-Urbana [Illinois] is experiencing the largest outbreak of the mumps ever to hit the area with around 100 cases confirmed as of Wednesday morning [26 Aug 2015]. Researchers say the mass mumps outbreak began this spring [2015] on the University of Illinois campus. They attribute the spread of the infection to students living in close quarters and interacting in large social settings. The best protection against the mumps is the MMR [measles, mumps, rubella] vaccine, but the standard 2 doses only offer 85 percent protection. So the CDC and the Illinois Department of Public Health recommend everyone in the community get a 3rd booster shot, which increases that immunity level to 95 percent.\" - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/7999.]\nSee Also\nMumps - Symptoms usually appear 12 to 25 days after [a person becomes] infected.\n\n[Byline: Joe Ragusa]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This outbreak appears to be part of the larger epidemic affecting students in more than one educational establishment in the state of Illinois. Further information would be appreciated regarding the source of the virus responsible for the initiation of the outbreak and the failure of vaccination to contain the spread of the outbreak. So far it has been reported [in ProMED-mail post 20150828.3608518] that: \"Champaign-Urbana [Illinois] is experiencing the largest outbreak of the mumps ever to hit the area with around 100 cases confirmed as of Wednesday morning [26 Aug 2015]. Researchers say the mass mumps outbreak began this spring [2015] on the University of Illinois campus. They attribute the spread of the infection to students living in close quarters and interacting in large social settings. The best protection against the mumps is the MMR [measles, mumps, rubella] vaccine, but the standard 2 doses only offer 85 percent protection. So the CDC and the Illinois Department of Public Health recommend everyone in the community get a 3rd booster shot, which increases that immunity level to 95 percent.\" - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/7999.]\nSee Also\nMumps - USA (07): (ILLINOIS) COMMUNITY COLLEGE STUDENTS, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n********************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 16 Sep 2015\nSource: WJBC [edited]\nhttp://www.wjbc.com/2015/09/16/mumps-outbreak-declared-at-heartland-community-college/\n\n\nMumps outbreak declared at Heartland Community College: Illinois\n----------------------------------------------------------------\nThe Illinois Department of Public Health [IDPH] has declared a mumps outbreak at Heartland Community College [Normal, McLean County, Illinois]. The IDPH says 4 cases have been found at the college. Letters are being sent out to students, faculty and staff the health department has determined were in close contact with those who were infected.\n\nAs of [16 Sep 2015], 6 cases of mumps have been identified in McLean County and more test results are pending.\n\nThe symptoms of mumps include fever, headache and swollen salivary glands, and malaise. Symptoms usually appear 12 to 25 days after [a person becomes] infected.\n\n[Byline: Joe Ragusa]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This outbreak appears to be part of the larger epidemic affecting students in more than one educational establishment in the state of Illinois. Further information would be appreciated regarding the source of the virus responsible for the initiation of the outbreak and the failure of vaccination to contain the spread of the outbreak. So far it has been reported [in ProMED-mail post 20150828.3608518] that: \"Champaign-Urbana [Illinois] is experiencing the largest outbreak of the mumps ever to hit the area with around 100 cases confirmed as of Wednesday morning [26 Aug 2015]. Researchers say the mass mumps outbreak began this spring [2015] on the University of Illinois campus. They attribute the spread of the infection to students living in close quarters and interacting in large social settings. The best protection against the mumps is the MMR [measles, mumps, rubella] vaccine, but the standard 2 doses only offer 85 percent protection. So the CDC and the Illinois Department of Public Health recommend everyone in the community get a 3rd booster shot, which increases that immunity level to 95 percent.\" - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/7999.]\nSee Also\nMumps - Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "McLean County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3608518", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (06): (IL) returning university students, further development", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3608518", "date": "2015-05-29 18:41:31", "main_text": "MUMPS - CANADA (QUEBEC): SCHOOL CHILDREN\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[The original post of this erroneously put Guelph in Quebec rather than Ontario where it belongs. - Mod.MPP]\n\nDate: Fri 29 May 2015\nSource Guelph Mercury [edited]\nhttp://www.guelphmercury.com/news-story/5649727-public-health-investigating-mumps-outbreak-in-two-guelph-high-schools/\n\n\nWellington-Dufferin-Guelph Public Health is investigating an outbreak of mumps at 2 Guelph high schools, the 1st cases of the disease in the area since 2010.\n\nChuck Ferguson, spokesperson for the health unit, said there are 2 reported cases of mumps at 2 different Catholic high schools, Bishop Macdonell and Our Lady of Lourdes. \"We haven't determined a link between the cases, and there are 4 suspected cases in total that we're investigating,\" Ferguson said on Thursday [28 May 2015].\n\nPeople can protect themselves from getting mumps by getting the free vaccination, part of the measles, mumps rubella (MMR) childhood vaccine. Two doses are required.\n\nStudents at both schools who choose not to be vaccinated will be kept home from school for a minimum of 16 days or until the outbreak is over, Ferguson said. If a student who is missing a 2nd dose of the vaccine agrees to get it, they can return to school.\n\nFerguson said that keeping kids at home is not a measure that's taken lightly by the health unit. \"We work with parents; we work with schools; we work with doctors to make sure kids are protected, but if there's an outbreak and they're not vaccinated, there's nothing we can do but remove them from school for their own protection,\" he said.\n\nTamara Nugent, director of education for the Wellington Catholic District School Board, said the number of kids that will be affected is shifting. \"By the end of this week, I think we'll have a good sense of how many students there are,\" she said. \"We know that it's very few. It's just a matter of records and making sure that the public health unit has those on file; that's often the case.\"\n\nNugent said the board is working with the public health unit to take all of the \"preventative and precautionary measures\" they can, such as encouraging kids to wash their hands and not share water bottles or musical instruments with mouthpieces.\n\nMumps is very contagious and can be spread by coughing, sneezing, kissing or using an object an infected person has recently used. Ferguson said it's unclear where the mumps outbreak started, but there are sporadic cases in Ontario, and the 1st case may have been brought into the area through travel.\n\nThe symptoms of mumps include fever, swollen glands, and headache. It's caused by a virus, and antibiotics cannot treat it, so doctors often let it run its course. Mumps used to be a rare disease but is now making somewhat of a comeback.\n\nWhile people born before 1970 are supposed to have natural immunity to the mumps, those born in the 1980s and 1990s may have missed getting the 2nd dose of the vaccine, which was introduced in 1996.\n\n[Byline: May Warren]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Public health Agency of Canada (2014) states that: Outbreaks of mumps continue to occur in Canada, and the proportion of cases aged 20 years and older has increased. Complications such as orchitis and oophoritis are relatively frequent; permanent sequelae like deafness are rare. Mumps vaccine is available as measles-mumps-rubella (MMR) or measles-mumps-rubella-varicella (MMRV) vaccine. Mumps vaccine effectiveness has been estimated at 62-91 percent for one dose and 76-95 percent for 2 doses. Reactions to MMR and MMRV vaccine are generally mild and transient and include pain and redness at the injection site, low-grade fever, and rash.\n\nMumps-containing vaccine is recommended for routine immunization of children and for immunization of children and adolescents who missed mumps immunization on the routine schedule. Mumps-containing vaccine is recommended for susceptible adults born in 1970 or later. Adults born before 1970 can be presumed to have acquired natural immunity to mumps; however, susceptible health care workers, travellers, and military personnel should receive MMR vaccine, regardless of the year of birth. - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/268.]\nSee Also\nMumps Australia (WA) 20150426.33238\nMumps - Ireland: football players 20150223.3185969\nMumps - USA: (ID) university students 20150209.3153606\nMumps - UK: (Scotland) 20150204.3142750\nMumps - USA: (PA) professional hockey team players 20150109.3080644\n2014\n----\nMumps - USA (08): (ID) university students 20141122.2982582\nMumps - USA (03): (VA) university students 20130328.1608579\nMumps - USA (02): (VA) university students 20130319.1594231\nMumps - USA: (MD) university students 20130316.1589886\n2012\n----\nMumps, 2011 - USA: (CA) university students 20121206.1441071\n2011\n---\nMumps - USA (04): (CA) university students 20111011.3045\nMumps - USA (03): (CA) university students 20111007.3014\nMumps - USA (02): (CA) university students, alert 20111006.3008\nMumps - USA: (IL) university students 20110928.2936\n.................................................sb/cp/msp/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["measles", "mumps", "rubella", "varicella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-05-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2015-05-28 00:00:00", "1970-03-16 00:00:00", "1996-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "1970-03-16 00:00:00", "1970-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Quebec", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ontario", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mumps - Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3594465", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (05): (IA) returning university students", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3594465", "date": "2015-05-29 18:41:31", "main_text": "MUMPS - CANADA (QUEBEC): SCHOOL CHILDREN\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[The original post of this erroneously put Guelph in Quebec rather than Ontario where it belongs. - Mod.MPP]\n\nDate: Fri 29 May 2015\nSource Guelph Mercury [edited]\nhttp://www.guelphmercury.com/news-story/5649727-public-health-investigating-mumps-outbreak-in-two-guelph-high-schools/\n\n\nWellington-Dufferin-Guelph Public Health is investigating an outbreak of mumps at 2 Guelph high schools, the 1st cases of the disease in the area since 2010.\n\nChuck Ferguson, spokesperson for the health unit, said there are 2 reported cases of mumps at 2 different Catholic high schools, Bishop Macdonell and Our Lady of Lourdes. \"We haven't determined a link between the cases, and there are 4 suspected cases in total that we're investigating,\" Ferguson said on Thursday [28 May 2015].\n\nPeople can protect themselves from getting mumps by getting the free vaccination, part of the measles, mumps rubella (MMR) childhood vaccine. Two doses are required.\n\nStudents at both schools who choose not to be vaccinated will be kept home from school for a minimum of 16 days or until the outbreak is over, Ferguson said. If a student who is missing a 2nd dose of the vaccine agrees to get it, they can return to school.\n\nFerguson said that keeping kids at home is not a measure that's taken lightly by the health unit. \"We work with parents; we work with schools; we work with doctors to make sure kids are protected, but if there's an outbreak and they're not vaccinated, there's nothing we can do but remove them from school for their own protection,\" he said.\n\nTamara Nugent, director of education for the Wellington Catholic District School Board, said the number of kids that will be affected is shifting. \"By the end of this week, I think we'll have a good sense of how many students there are,\" she said. \"We know that it's very few. It's just a matter of records and making sure that the public health unit has those on file; that's often the case.\"\n\nNugent said the board is working with the public health unit to take all of the \"preventative and precautionary measures\" they can, such as encouraging kids to wash their hands and not share water bottles or musical instruments with mouthpieces.\n\nMumps is very contagious and can be spread by coughing, sneezing, kissing or using an object an infected person has recently used. Ferguson said it's unclear where the mumps outbreak started, but there are sporadic cases in Ontario, and the 1st case may have been brought into the area through travel.\n\nThe symptoms of mumps include fever, swollen glands, and headache. It's caused by a virus, and antibiotics cannot treat it, so doctors often let it run its course. Mumps used to be a rare disease but is now making somewhat of a comeback.\n\nWhile people born before 1970 are supposed to have natural immunity to the mumps, those born in the 1980s and 1990s may have missed getting the 2nd dose of the vaccine, which was introduced in 1996.\n\n[Byline: May Warren]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Public health Agency of Canada (2014) states that: Outbreaks of mumps continue to occur in Canada, and the proportion of cases aged 20 years and older has increased. Complications such as orchitis and oophoritis are relatively frequent; permanent sequelae like deafness are rare. Mumps vaccine is available as measles-mumps-rubella (MMR) or measles-mumps-rubella-varicella (MMRV) vaccine. Mumps vaccine effectiveness has been estimated at 62-91 percent for one dose and 76-95 percent for 2 doses. Reactions to MMR and MMRV vaccine are generally mild and transient and include pain and redness at the injection site, low-grade fever, and rash.\n\nMumps-containing vaccine is recommended for routine immunization of children and for immunization of children and adolescents who missed mumps immunization on the routine schedule. Mumps-containing vaccine is recommended for susceptible adults born in 1970 or later. Adults born before 1970 can be presumed to have acquired natural immunity to mumps; however, susceptible health care workers, travellers, and military personnel should receive MMR vaccine, regardless of the year of birth. - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/268.]\nSee Also\nMumps Australia (WA) 20150426.33238\nMumps - Ireland: football players 20150223.3185969\nMumps - USA: (ID) university students 20150209.3153606\nMumps - UK: (Scotland) 20150204.3142750\nMumps - USA: (PA) professional hockey team players 20150109.3080644\n2014\n----\nMumps - USA (08): (ID) university students 20141122.2982582\nMumps - USA: (OH) university students 20140308.2321285\n2013\n----\nMumps - USA (06): (NJ) bar & grill associated 20130908.1931146\nMumps - USA (05): (NJ) young adults, correction 20130719.1832549\nMumps - USA (04): (NJ) young adults 20130717.1830577\nMumps - USA (03): (VA) university students 20130328.1608579\nMumps - USA (02): (VA) university students 20130319.1594231\nMumps - USA: (MD) university students 20130316.1589886\n2012\n----\nMumps, 2011 - USA: (CA) university students 20121206.1441071\n2011\n---\nMumps - USA (04): (CA) university students 20111011.3045\nMumps - USA (03): (CA) university students 20111007.3014\nMumps - USA (02): (CA) university students, alert 20111006.3008\nMumps - USA: (IL) university students 20110928.2936\n.................................................sb/cp/msp/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["measles", "mumps", "rubella", "varicella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-05-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2015-05-28 00:00:00", "1970-03-16 00:00:00", "1996-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "1970-03-16 00:00:00", "1970-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Quebec", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ontario", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mumps - Mumps used to be a rare disease but is now making somewhat of a comeback.\n\nWhile people born before 1970 are supposed to have natural immunity to the mumps, those born in the 1980s and 1990s may have missed getting the 2nd dose of the vaccine, which was introduced in 1996.\n\n[Byline: May Warren]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Public health Agency of Canada (2014) states that: Outbreaks of mumps continue to occur in Canada, and the proportion of cases aged 20 years and older has increased. USA (04): (CA) university students 20111011.3045\nMumps - USA (03): (CA) university students 20111007.3014\nMumps - USA (02): (CA) university students, alert 20111006.3008\nMumps - USA: (IL) university students 20110928.2936\n.................................................sb/cp/msp/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["measles", "mumps", "rubella", "varicella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-05-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2015-05-28 00:00:00", "1970-03-16 00:00:00", "1996-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "1970-03-16 00:00:00", "1970-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Quebec", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ontario", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mumps - Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3442934", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (03): (IL) university students", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3442934", "date": "2015-05-29 18:41:31", "main_text": "MUMPS - CANADA (QUEBEC): SCHOOL CHILDREN\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[The original post of this erroneously put Guelph in Quebec rather than Ontario where it belongs. - Mod.MPP]\n\nDate: Fri 29 May 2015\nSource Guelph Mercury [edited]\nhttp://www.guelphmercury.com/news-story/5649727-public-health-investigating-mumps-outbreak-in-two-guelph-high-schools/\n\n\nWellington-Dufferin-Guelph Public Health is investigating an outbreak of mumps at 2 Guelph high schools, the 1st cases of the disease in the area since 2010.\n\nChuck Ferguson, spokesperson for the health unit, said there are 2 reported cases of mumps at 2 different Catholic high schools, Bishop Macdonell and Our Lady of Lourdes. \"We haven't determined a link between the cases, and there are 4 suspected cases in total that we're investigating,\" Ferguson said on Thursday [28 May 2015].\n\nPeople can protect themselves from getting mumps by getting the free vaccination, part of the measles, mumps rubella (MMR) childhood vaccine. Two doses are required.\n\nStudents at both schools who choose not to be vaccinated will be kept home from school for a minimum of 16 days or until the outbreak is over, Ferguson said. If a student who is missing a 2nd dose of the vaccine agrees to get it, they can return to school.\n\nFerguson said that keeping kids at home is not a measure that's taken lightly by the health unit. \"We work with parents; we work with schools; we work with doctors to make sure kids are protected, but if there's an outbreak and they're not vaccinated, there's nothing we can do but remove them from school for their own protection,\" he said.\n\nTamara Nugent, director of education for the Wellington Catholic District School Board, said the number of kids that will be affected is shifting. \"By the end of this week, I think we'll have a good sense of how many students there are,\" she said. \"We know that it's very few. It's just a matter of records and making sure that the public health unit has those on file; that's often the case.\"\n\nNugent said the board is working with the public health unit to take all of the \"preventative and precautionary measures\" they can, such as encouraging kids to wash their hands and not share water bottles or musical instruments with mouthpieces.\n\nMumps is very contagious and can be spread by coughing, sneezing, kissing or using an object an infected person has recently used. Ferguson said it's unclear where the mumps outbreak started, but there are sporadic cases in Ontario, and the 1st case may have been brought into the area through travel.\n\nThe symptoms of mumps include fever, swollen glands, and headache. It's caused by a virus, and antibiotics cannot treat it, so doctors often let it run its course. Mumps used to be a rare disease but is now making somewhat of a comeback.\n\nWhile people born before 1970 are supposed to have natural immunity to the mumps, those born in the 1980s and 1990s may have missed getting the 2nd dose of the vaccine, which was introduced in 1996.\n\n[Byline: May Warren]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Public health Agency of Canada (2014) states that: Outbreaks of mumps continue to occur in Canada, and the proportion of cases aged 20 years and older has increased. Complications such as orchitis and oophoritis are relatively frequent; permanent sequelae like deafness are rare. Mumps vaccine is available as measles-mumps-rubella (MMR) or measles-mumps-rubella-varicella (MMRV) vaccine. Mumps vaccine effectiveness has been estimated at 62-91 percent for one dose and 76-95 percent for 2 doses. Reactions to MMR and MMRV vaccine are generally mild and transient and include pain and redness at the injection site, low-grade fever, and rash.\n\nMumps-containing vaccine is recommended for routine immunization of children and for immunization of children and adolescents who missed mumps immunization on the routine schedule. Mumps-containing vaccine is recommended for susceptible adults born in 1970 or later. Adults born before 1970 can be presumed to have acquired natural immunity to mumps; however, susceptible health care workers, travellers, and military personnel should receive MMR vaccine, regardless of the year of birth. - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/268.]\nSee Also\nMumps Australia (WA) 20150426.33238\nMumps - Ireland: football players 20150223.3185969\nMumps - It's caused by a virus, and antibiotics cannot treat it, so doctors often let it run its course. Mumps used to be a rare disease but is now making somewhat of a comeback.\n\nWhile people born before 1970 are supposed to have natural immunity to the mumps, those born in the 1980s and 1990s may have missed getting the 2nd dose of the vaccine, which was introduced in 1996.\n\n[Byline: May Warren]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Public health Agency of Canada (2014) states that: Outbreaks of mumps continue to occur in Canada, and the proportion of cases aged 20 years and older has increased. Mumps used to be a rare disease but is now making somewhat of a comeback.\n\nWhile people born before 1970 are supposed to have natural immunity to the mumps, those born in the 1980s and 1990s may have missed getting the 2nd dose of the vaccine, which was introduced in 1996.\n\n[Byline: May Warren]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Public health Agency of Canada (2014) states that: Outbreaks of mumps continue to occur in Canada, and the proportion of cases aged 20 years and older has increased. Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3323826", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Australia (WA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3323826", "date": "2014-04-18 12:39:42", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (04): (WISCONSIN) UPDATE\n************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 17 Apr 2014\nFrom: Janet Welter <welter@rarc.wisc.edu> [edited]\n\n\nThe number of confirmed mumps cases at UW-Madison [University of Wisconsin, Madison] continues to increase. 5 student cases have been identified at this time and UHS [University Health Services] continues to work with public health officials to monitor the situation.\n\nMumps is a contagious viral illness that spreads by droplets of saliva or mucus from the mouth, nose, or throat of an infected person, usually when the person coughs, sneezes, or talks.\n\nWhile most people who have been given the measles-mumps-rubella (MMR) vaccine are usually protected for life against mumps infections, the illness can still occur in previously immunized persons.\n\nFaculty and staff should take the following steps to stay healthy and prevent spreading mumps:\n1. Watch for symptoms, even if you have been vaccinated, and stay home if you are sick. If you experience mumps symptoms (fever, headache, muscle aches, fatigue, and swelling of the cheek and jaw area) contact your private healthcare provider.\n\nIt's a campus expectation that anyone suspected of having mumps stays home from school, work, or similar activities for 5 days. We encourage faculty and staff to allow students with mumps symptoms to stay home from class and work, and to provide alternate arrangements.\n\nThere is no treatment for mumps, but you can soothe your symptoms by getting plenty of bed rest, taking over-the-counter pain killers such as ibuprofen or Tylenol to relieve any pain, and drinking plenty of fluids.\n\n2. Take a page from the flu playbook with preventive actions. Wash your hands regularly with soap and water; sneeze and cough into a tissue or your elbow; and avoid sharing drinks, food, and utensils.\n\n3. Check your immunization records to make sure you've had 2 doses of the MMR vaccine. See your private healthcare provider or local pharmacy if you need a 2nd dose.\n\nFor more information:\nMumps FAQs http://www.uhs.wisc.edu/health-topics/mumps/faq.pdf\nMumps (CDC) http://www.cdc.gov/mumps/\n\n--\nJanet Welter, DVM, MPH, PHD, DACLAM\nChief Campus Veterinarian\nUniversity of Wisconsin-Madison\n<welter@rarc.wisc.edu>\nhttp://www.rarc.wisc.edu\n\n[ProMED-mail appreciates this report from Dr Welter. Mumps outbreaks can be difficult to control on university campuses and unfortunately, immunity is sometimes incomplete, even after appropriate immunization. Another larger outbreak was recently reported in the Ohio State University campus. Most universities in the US require proof of immunity to mumps at the time of enrollment.\n\nMore complete comments by Moderator ML are found in ProMED-mail archive no 20140409.2391429. - Mod.LM\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6812.]\nSee Also\nMumps - USA (03): (OH) update 20140409.2391429\nMumps - USA (02): (OH) update 20140404.2380592\nMumps - USA: (OH) university students 20140308.2321285\n2013\n----\nMumps - USA (06): (NJ) bar & grill associated 20130908.1931146\nMumps - USA (05): (NJ) young adults, correction 20130719.1832549\nMumps - USA (04): (NJ) young adults 20130717.1830577\nMumps - USA (03): (VA) university students 20130328.1608579\nMumps - USA (02): (VA) university students 20130319.1594231\nMumps - USA: (MD) university students 20130316.1589886\n2012\n----\nMumps, 2011 - USA: (CA) university students 20121206.1441071\n.................................................lm/mj/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tylenol", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3080644", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA: (PA) professional hockey team players", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3080644", "date": "2014-04-18 12:39:42", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (04): (WISCONSIN) UPDATE\n************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 17 Apr 2014\nFrom: Janet Welter <welter@rarc.wisc.edu> [edited]\n\n\nThe number of confirmed mumps cases at UW-Madison [University of Wisconsin, Madison] continues to increase. 5 student cases have been identified at this time and UHS [University Health Services] continues to work with public health officials to monitor the situation.\n\nMumps is a contagious viral illness that spreads by droplets of saliva or mucus from the mouth, nose, or throat of an infected person, usually when the person coughs, sneezes, or talks.\n\nWhile most people who have been given the measles-mumps-rubella (MMR) vaccine are usually protected for life against mumps infections, the illness can still occur in previously immunized persons.\n\nFaculty and staff should take the following steps to stay healthy and prevent spreading mumps:\n1. Watch for symptoms, even if you have been vaccinated, and stay home if you are sick. If you experience mumps symptoms (fever, headache, muscle aches, fatigue, and swelling of the cheek and jaw area) contact your private healthcare provider.\n\nIt's a campus expectation that anyone suspected of having mumps stays home from school, work, or similar activities for 5 days. We encourage faculty and staff to allow students with mumps symptoms to stay home from class and work, and to provide alternate arrangements.\n\nThere is no treatment for mumps, but you can soothe your symptoms by getting plenty of bed rest, taking over-the-counter pain killers such as ibuprofen or Tylenol to relieve any pain, and drinking plenty of fluids.\n\n2. Take a page from the flu playbook with preventive actions. Wash your hands regularly with soap and water; sneeze and cough into a tissue or your elbow; and avoid sharing drinks, food, and utensils.\n\n3. Check your immunization records to make sure you've had 2 doses of the MMR vaccine. See your private healthcare provider or local pharmacy if you need a 2nd dose.\n\nFor more information:\nMumps FAQs http://www.uhs.wisc.edu/health-topics/mumps/faq.pdf\nMumps (CDC) http://www.cdc.gov/mumps/\n\n--\nJanet Welter, DVM, MPH, PHD, DACLAM\nChief Campus Veterinarian\nUniversity of Wisconsin-Madison\n<welter@rarc.wisc.edu>\nhttp://www.rarc.wisc.edu\n\n[ProMED-mail appreciates this report from Dr Welter. Mumps outbreaks can be difficult to control on university campuses and unfortunately, immunity is sometimes incomplete, even after appropriate immunization. Another larger outbreak was recently reported in the Ohio State University campus. Most universities in the US require proof of immunity to mumps at the time of enrollment.\n\nMore complete comments by Moderator ML are found in ProMED-mail archive no 20140409.2391429. - Mod.LM\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6812.]\nSee Also\nMumps - USA (08): (ID) university students", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2982582", "date": "2014-04-18 12:39:42", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (04): (WISCONSIN) UPDATE\n************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 17 Apr 2014\nFrom: Janet Welter <welter@rarc.wisc.edu> [edited]\n\n\nThe number of confirmed mumps cases at UW-Madison [University of Wisconsin, Madison] continues to increase. 5 student cases have been identified at this time and UHS [University Health Services] continues to work with public health officials to monitor the situation.\n\nMumps is a contagious viral illness that spreads by droplets of saliva or mucus from the mouth, nose, or throat of an infected person, usually when the person coughs, sneezes, or talks.\n\nWhile most people who have been given the measles-mumps-rubella (MMR) vaccine are usually protected for life against mumps infections, the illness can still occur in previously immunized persons.\n\nFaculty and staff should take the following steps to stay healthy and prevent spreading mumps:\n1. Watch for symptoms, even if you have been vaccinated, and stay home if you are sick. If you experience mumps symptoms (fever, headache, muscle aches, fatigue, and swelling of the cheek and jaw area) contact your private healthcare provider.\n\nIt's a campus expectation that anyone suspected of having mumps stays home from school, work, or similar activities for 5 days. We encourage faculty and staff to allow students with mumps symptoms to stay home from class and work, and to provide alternate arrangements.\n\nThere is no treatment for mumps, but you can soothe your symptoms by getting plenty of bed rest, taking over-the-counter pain killers such as ibuprofen or Tylenol to relieve any pain, and drinking plenty of fluids.\n\n2. Take a page from the flu playbook with preventive actions. Wash your hands regularly with soap and water; sneeze and cough into a tissue or your elbow; and avoid sharing drinks, food, and utensils.\n\n3. Check your immunization records to make sure you've had 2 doses of the MMR vaccine. See your private healthcare provider or local pharmacy if you need a 2nd dose.\n\nFor more information:\nMumps FAQs http://www.uhs.wisc.edu/health-topics/mumps/faq.pdf\nMumps (CDC) http://www.cdc.gov/mumps/\n\n--\nJanet Welter, DVM, MPH, PHD, DACLAM\nChief Campus Veterinarian\nUniversity of Wisconsin-Madison\n<welter@rarc.wisc.edu>\nhttp://www.rarc.wisc.edu\n\n[ProMED-mail appreciates this report from Dr Welter. Mumps outbreaks can be difficult to control on university campuses and unfortunately, immunity is sometimes incomplete, even after appropriate immunization. Another larger outbreak was recently reported in the Ohio State University campus. Most universities in the US require proof of immunity to mumps at the time of enrollment.\n\nMore complete comments by Moderator ML are found in ProMED-mail archive no 20140409.2391429. - Mod.LM\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6812.]\nSee Also\nMumps - USA (07): (OH) update", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2588034", "date": "2014-04-18 12:39:42", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (04): (WISCONSIN) UPDATE\n************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 17 Apr 2014\nFrom: Janet Welter <welter@rarc.wisc.edu> [edited]\n\n\nThe number of confirmed mumps cases at UW-Madison [University of Wisconsin, Madison] continues to increase. 5 student cases have been identified at this time and UHS [University Health Services] continues to work with public health officials to monitor the situation.\n\nMumps is a contagious viral illness that spreads by droplets of saliva or mucus from the mouth, nose, or throat of an infected person, usually when the person coughs, sneezes, or talks.\n\nWhile most people who have been given the measles-mumps-rubella (MMR) vaccine are usually protected for life against mumps infections, the illness can still occur in previously immunized persons.\n\nFaculty and staff should take the following steps to stay healthy and prevent spreading mumps:\n1. Watch for symptoms, even if you have been vaccinated, and stay home if you are sick. If you experience mumps symptoms (fever, headache, muscle aches, fatigue, and swelling of the cheek and jaw area) contact your private healthcare provider.\n\nIt's a campus expectation that anyone suspected of having mumps stays home from school, work, or similar activities for 5 days. We encourage faculty and staff to allow students with mumps symptoms to stay home from class and work, and to provide alternate arrangements.\n\nThere is no treatment for mumps, but you can soothe your symptoms by getting plenty of bed rest, taking over-the-counter pain killers such as ibuprofen or Tylenol to relieve any pain, and drinking plenty of fluids.\n\n2. Take a page from the flu playbook with preventive actions. Wash your hands regularly with soap and water; sneeze and cough into a tissue or your elbow; and avoid sharing drinks, food, and utensils.\n\n3. Check your immunization records to make sure you've had 2 doses of the MMR vaccine. See your private healthcare provider or local pharmacy if you need a 2nd dose.\n\nFor more information:\nMumps FAQs http://www.uhs.wisc.edu/health-topics/mumps/faq.pdf\nMumps (CDC) http://www.cdc.gov/mumps/\n\n--\nJanet Welter, DVM, MPH, PHD, DACLAM\nChief Campus Veterinarian\nUniversity of Wisconsin-Madison\n<welter@rarc.wisc.edu>\nhttp://www.rarc.wisc.edu\n\n[ProMED-mail appreciates this report from Dr Welter. Mumps outbreaks can be difficult to control on university campuses and unfortunately, immunity is sometimes incomplete, even after appropriate immunization. Another larger outbreak was recently reported in the Ohio State University campus. Most universities in the US require proof of immunity to mumps at the time of enrollment.\n\nMore complete comments by Moderator ML are found in ProMED-mail archive no 20140409.2391429. - Mod.LM\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6812.]\nSee Also\nMumps - Watch for symptoms, even if you have been vaccinated, and stay home if you are sick. If you experience mumps symptoms (fever, headache, muscle aches, fatigue, and swelling of the cheek and jaw area) contact your private healthcare provider.\n\nIt's a campus expectation that anyone suspected of having mumps stays home from school, work, or similar activities for 5 days. We encourage faculty and staff to allow students with mumps symptoms to stay home from class and work, and to provide alternate arrangements.\n\nThere is no treatment for mumps, but you can soothe your symptoms by getting plenty of bed rest, taking over-the-counter pain killers such as ibuprofen or Tylenol to relieve any pain, and drinking plenty of fluids.\n\n2. Watch for symptoms, even if you have been vaccinated, and stay home if you are sick. If you experience mumps symptoms (fever, headache, muscle aches, fatigue, and swelling of the cheek and jaw area) contact your private healthcare provider.\n\nIt's a campus expectation that anyone suspected of having mumps stays home from school, work, or similar activities for 5 days. We encourage faculty and staff to allow students with mumps symptoms to stay home from class and work, and to provide alternate arrangements.\n\nThere is no treatment for mumps, but you can soothe your symptoms by getting plenty of bed rest, taking over-the-counter pain killers such as ibuprofen or Tylenol to relieve any pain, and drinking plenty of fluids.\n\n2.
