USA: (MD) university students 20130316.1589886\n2012\n----\nMumps, 2011 - USA: (CA) university students 20121206.1441071\n.................................................lm/mj/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tylenol", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2413572", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (04): (WI) update", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2413572", "date": "2014-04-18 12:39:42", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (04): (WISCONSIN) UPDATE\n************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 17 Apr 2014\nFrom: Janet Welter <welter@rarc.wisc.edu> [edited]\n\n\nThe number of confirmed mumps cases at UW-Madison [University of Wisconsin, Madison] continues to increase. 5 student cases have been identified at this time and UHS [University Health Services] continues to work with public health officials to monitor the situation.\n\nMumps is a contagious viral illness that spreads by droplets of saliva or mucus from the mouth, nose, or throat of an infected person, usually when the person coughs, sneezes, or talks.\n\nWhile most people who have been given the measles-mumps-rubella (MMR) vaccine are usually protected for life against mumps infections, the illness can still occur in previously immunized persons.\n\nFaculty and staff should take the following steps to stay healthy and prevent spreading mumps:\n1. Watch for symptoms, even if you have been vaccinated, and stay home if you are sick. If you experience mumps symptoms (fever, headache, muscle aches, fatigue, and swelling of the cheek and jaw area) contact your private healthcare provider.\n\nIt's a campus expectation that anyone suspected of having mumps stays home from school, work, or similar activities for 5 days. We encourage faculty and staff to allow students with mumps symptoms to stay home from class and work, and to provide alternate arrangements.\n\nThere is no treatment for mumps, but you can soothe your symptoms by getting plenty of bed rest, taking over-the-counter pain killers such as ibuprofen or Tylenol to relieve any pain, and drinking plenty of fluids.\n\n2. Take a page from the flu playbook with preventive actions. Wash your hands regularly with soap and water; sneeze and cough into a tissue or your elbow; and avoid sharing drinks, food, and utensils.\n\n3. Check your immunization records to make sure you've had 2 doses of the MMR vaccine. See your private healthcare provider or local pharmacy if you need a 2nd dose.\n\nFor more information:\nMumps FAQs http://www.uhs.wisc.edu/health-topics/mumps/faq.pdf\nMumps (CDC) http://www.cdc.gov/mumps/\n\n--\nJanet Welter, DVM, MPH, PHD, DACLAM\nChief Campus Veterinarian\nUniversity of Wisconsin-Madison\n<welter@rarc.wisc.edu>\nhttp://www.rarc.wisc.edu\n\n[ProMED-mail appreciates this report from Dr Welter. Mumps outbreaks can be difficult to control on university campuses and unfortunately, immunity is sometimes incomplete, even after appropriate immunization. Another larger outbreak was recently reported in the Ohio State University campus. Most universities in the US require proof of immunity to mumps at the time of enrollment.\n\nMore complete comments by Moderator ML are found in ProMED-mail archive no 20140409.2391429. - Mod.LM\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6812.]\nSee Also\nMumps - USA (03): (OH) update 20140409.2391429\nMumps - USA (02): (OH) update 20140404.2380592\nMumps - USA: (OH) university students 20140308.2321285\n2013\n----\nMumps - USA (06): (NJ) bar & grill associated 20130908.1931146\nMumps - USA (05): (NJ) young adults, correction 20130719.1832549\nMumps - USA (04): (NJ) young adults 20130717.1830577\nMumps - USA (03): (VA) university students 20130328.1608579\nMumps - USA (02): (VA) university students 20130319.1594231\nMumps - USA (03): (OH) update", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2391429", "date": "2013-05-20 17:07:53", "main_text": "MUMPS - UK (02): (ENGLAND) UNIVERSITY STUDENTS, COMMENT\n*******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 20 May 2013\nFrom: Peter English <peter.english@phe.gov.uk> [edited]\n\n\nRe: ProMED-mail Mumps - UK: (England) university students 20130519.1723475\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------\nIn the post it was stated that: \"Scientists have linked the recent growth in mumps outbreaks to public opposition to the MMR jab, after a 1998 study linked the vaccination to autism. Its researcher, Andrew Wakefield, has since been struck off the medical register, and his conclusions are largely discredited. However, after his findings were reported globally, the number of children receiving the vaccination in the UK fell from 92 percent to below 80 percent. The last major outbreak was in 2008, when 1348 cases were confirmed, and 2 people died.\"\n\n[Dr Peter English points out at that:] \"The Wakefield scare started in 1998. That was 14 years ago. University students will be age 18 years or older, so they were not affected by this. Prior to the scare the uptake of MMR was better; but a catch-up vaccination campaign for children who had only had a single dose of MMR in the 1990s used an MR vaccine, protecting against measles and rubella only, so some of the students may have had only one dose of mumps containing (MMR) vaccine.\" There is more information about this at: 'Questions and answers about mumps and MMR' at http://www.ganfyd.org/index.php?title=Questions_and_answers_about_mumps_and_MMR. Interested readers are recommend to consult this document.\n\n--\nDr Peter M B English\nGMC No 3002861\nConsultant in Communicable Disease Control\nUK\n<peter.english@phe.gov.uk>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Peter English for drawing attention to this situation, which is relevant to the interpretation of this outbreak. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nMumps - USA (03): (VA) university students 20130328.1608579\nMumps - USA (02): (VA) university students 20130319.1594231\nMumps - USA: (MD) university students 20130316.1589886\n2012\n----\nMumps, 2011 - USA: (CA) university students 20121206.1441071\nMumps - UK: (Scotland) university students, alert 20120220.1047110\n2011\n----\nMumps - USA (04): (CA) university students 20111011.3045\nMumps - USA (03): (CA) university students 20111007.3014\nMumps - USA (02): (OH) update", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2380592", "date": "2013-05-20 17:07:53", "main_text": "MUMPS - UK (02): (ENGLAND) UNIVERSITY STUDENTS, COMMENT\n*******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 20 May 2013\nFrom: Peter English <peter.english@phe.gov.uk> [edited]\n\n\nRe: ProMED-mail Mumps - UK: (England) university students 20130519.1723475\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------\nIn the post it was stated that: \"Scientists have linked the recent growth in mumps outbreaks to public opposition to the MMR jab, after a 1998 study linked the vaccination to autism. Its researcher, Andrew Wakefield, has since been struck off the medical register, and his conclusions are largely discredited. However, after his findings were reported globally, the number of children receiving the vaccination in the UK fell from 92 percent to below 80 percent. The last major outbreak was in 2008, when 1348 cases were confirmed, and 2 people died.\"\n\n[Dr Peter English points out at that:] \"The Wakefield scare started in 1998. That was 14 years ago. University students will be age 18 years or older, so they were not affected by this. Prior to the scare the uptake of MMR was better; but a catch-up vaccination campaign for children who had only had a single dose of MMR in the 1990s used an MR vaccine, protecting against measles and rubella only, so some of the students may have had only one dose of mumps containing (MMR) vaccine.\" There is more information about this at: 'Questions and answers about mumps and MMR' at http://www.ganfyd.org/index.php?title=Questions_and_answers_about_mumps_and_MMR. Interested readers are recommend to consult this document.\n\n--\nDr Peter M B English\nGMC No 3002861\nConsultant in Communicable Disease Control\nUK\n<peter.english@phe.gov.uk>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Peter English for drawing attention to this situation, which is relevant to the interpretation of this outbreak. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nMumps - USA (03): (VA) university students 20130328.1608579\nMumps - USA (02): (VA) university students 20130319.1594231\nMumps - USA: (MD) university students 20130316.1589886\n2012\n----\nMumps, 2011 - USA: (OH) university students", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2321285", "date": "2013-05-20 17:07:53", "main_text": "MUMPS - UK (02): (ENGLAND) UNIVERSITY STUDENTS, COMMENT\n*******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 20 May 2013\nFrom: Peter English <peter.english@phe.gov.uk> [edited]\n\n\nRe: ProMED-mail Mumps - UK: (England) university students 20130519.1723475\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------\nIn the post it was stated that: \"Scientists have linked the recent growth in mumps outbreaks to public opposition to the MMR jab, after a 1998 study linked the vaccination to autism. Its researcher, Andrew Wakefield, has since been struck off the medical register, and his conclusions are largely discredited. However, after his findings were reported globally, the number of children receiving the vaccination in the UK fell from 92 percent to below 80 percent. The last major outbreak was in 2008, when 1348 cases were confirmed, and 2 people died.\"\n\n[Dr Peter English points out at that:] \"The Wakefield scare started in 1998. That was 14 years ago. University students will be age 18 years or older, so they were not affected by this. Prior to the scare the uptake of MMR was better; but a catch-up vaccination campaign for children who had only had a single dose of MMR in the 1990s used an MR vaccine, protecting against measles and rubella only, so some of the students may have had only one dose of mumps containing (MMR) vaccine.\" There is more information about this at: 'Questions and answers about mumps and MMR' at http://www.ganfyd.org/index.php?title=Questions_and_answers_about_mumps_and_MMR. Interested readers are recommend to consult this document.\n\n--\nDr Peter M B English\nGMC No 3002861\nConsultant in Communicable Disease Control\nUK\n<peter.english@phe.gov.uk>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Peter English for drawing attention to this situation, which is relevant to the interpretation of this outbreak. - USA (06): (NJ) bar & grill associated", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1931146", "date": "2013-05-20 17:07:53", "main_text": "MUMPS - UK (02): (ENGLAND) UNIVERSITY STUDENTS, COMMENT\n*******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 20 May 2013\nFrom: Peter English <peter.english@phe.gov.uk> [edited]\n\n\nRe: ProMED-mail Mumps - UK: (England) university students 20130519.1723475\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------\nIn the post it was stated that: \"Scientists have linked the recent growth in mumps outbreaks to public opposition to the MMR jab, after a 1998 study linked the vaccination to autism. Its researcher, Andrew Wakefield, has since been struck off the medical register, and his conclusions are largely discredited. However, after his findings were reported globally, the number of children receiving the vaccination in the UK fell from 92 percent to below 80 percent. The last major outbreak was in 2008, when 1348 cases were confirmed, and 2 people died.\"\n\n[Dr Peter English points out at that:] \"The Wakefield scare started in 1998. That was 14 years ago. University students will be age 18 years or older, so they were not affected by this. Prior to the scare the uptake of MMR was better; but a catch-up vaccination campaign for children who had only had a single dose of MMR in the 1990s used an MR vaccine, protecting against measles and rubella only, so some of the students may have had only one dose of mumps containing (MMR) vaccine.\" There is more information about this at: 'Questions and answers about mumps and MMR' at http://www.ganfyd.org/index.php?title=Questions_and_answers_about_mumps_and_MMR. Interested readers are recommend to consult this document.\n\n--\nDr Peter M B English\nGMC No 3002861\nConsultant in Communicable Disease Control\nUK\n<peter.english@phe.gov.uk>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Peter English for drawing attention to this situation, which is relevant to the interpretation of this outbreak. - UK: (England) university students 20130519.1723475\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------\nIn the post it was stated that: \"Scientists have linked the recent growth in mumps outbreaks to public opposition to the MMR jab, after a 1998 study linked the vaccination to autism. Its researcher, Andrew Wakefield, has since been struck off the medical register, and his conclusions are largely discredited. However, after his findings were reported globally, the number of children receiving the vaccination in the UK fell from 92 percent to below 80 percent. The last major outbreak was in 2008, when 1348 cases were confirmed, and 2 people died.\"\n\n[Dr Peter English points out at that:] \"The Wakefield scare started in 1998. That was 14 years ago. University students will be age 18 years or older, so they were not affected by this. Prior to the scare the uptake of MMR was better; but a catch-up vaccination campaign for children who had only had a single dose of MMR in the 1990s used an MR vaccine, protecting against measles and rubella only, so some of the students may have had only one dose of mumps containing (MMR) vaccine.\" There is more information about this at: 'Questions and answers about mumps and MMR' at http://www.ganfyd.org/index.php?title=Questions_and_answers_about_mumps_and_MMR. UK: (England) university students 20130519.1723475\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------\nIn the post it was stated that: \"Scientists have linked the recent growth in mumps outbreaks to public opposition to the MMR jab, after a 1998 study linked the vaccination to autism. Its researcher, Andrew Wakefield, has since been struck off the medical register, and his conclusions are largely discredited. However, after his findings were reported globally, the number of children receiving the vaccination in the UK fell from 92 percent to below 80 percent. The last major outbreak was in 2008, when 1348 cases were confirmed, and 2 people died.\"\n\n[Dr Peter English points out at that:] \"The Wakefield scare started in 1998. That was 14 years ago. University students will be age 18 years or older, so they were not affected by this. Prior to the scare the uptake of MMR was better; but a catch-up vaccination campaign for children who had only had a single dose of MMR in the 1990s used an MR vaccine, protecting against measles and rubella only, so some of the students may have had only one dose of mumps containing (MMR) vaccine.\" There is more information about this at: 'Questions and answers about mumps and MMR' at http://www.ganfyd.org/index.php?title=Questions_and_answers_about_mumps_and_MMR. Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nMumps - USA (03): (VA) university students 20130328.1608579\nMumps - USA (02): (VA) university students 20130319.1594231\nMumps - USA: (MD) university students 20130316.1589886\n2012\n----\nMumps, 2011 - USA: (CA) university students 20121206.1441071\nMumps - UK: (Scotland) university students, alert 20120220.1047110\n2011\n----\nMumps - USA (04): (CA) university students 20111011.3045\nMumps - USA (03): (CA) university students 20111007.3014\nMumps - USA (02): (CA) university students, alert 20111006.3008\nMumps - USA: (IL) university students 20110928.2936\nMumps - UK (03): (England) university students 20110506.1403\n.................................................cp/mj/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "1348-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Mumps", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MR", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wakefield", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1773439", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Australia (02): (NS) alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1773439", "date": "2013-05-20 17:07:53", "main_text": "MUMPS - UK (02): (ENGLAND) UNIVERSITY STUDENTS, COMMENT\n*******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 20 May 2013\nFrom: Peter English <peter.english@phe.gov.uk> [edited]\n\n\nRe: ProMED-mail Mumps - UK: (England) university students 20130519.1723475\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------\nIn the post it was stated that: \"Scientists have linked the recent growth in mumps outbreaks to public opposition to the MMR jab, after a 1998 study linked the vaccination to autism. Its researcher, Andrew Wakefield, has since been struck off the medical register, and his conclusions are largely discredited. However, after his findings were reported globally, the number of children receiving the vaccination in the UK fell from 92 percent to below 80 percent. The last major outbreak was in 2008, when 1348 cases were confirmed, and 2 people died.\"\n\n[Dr Peter English points out at that:] \"The Wakefield scare started in 1998. That was 14 years ago. University students will be age 18 years or older, so they were not affected by this. Prior to the scare the uptake of MMR was better; but a catch-up vaccination campaign for children who had only had a single dose of MMR in the 1990s used an MR vaccine, protecting against measles and rubella only, so some of the students may have had only one dose of mumps containing (MMR) vaccine.\" There is more information about this at: 'Questions and answers about mumps and MMR' at http://www.ganfyd.org/index.php?title=Questions_and_answers_about_mumps_and_MMR. Interested readers are recommend to consult this document.\n\n--\nDr Peter M B English\nGMC No 3002861\nConsultant in Communicable Disease Control\nUK\n<peter.english@phe.gov.uk>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Peter English for drawing attention to this situation, which is relevant to the interpretation of this outbreak. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nMumps - USA (03): (VA) university students 20130328.1608579\nMumps - USA (02): (VA) university students 20130319.1594231\nMumps - USA: (MD) university students 20130316.1589886\n2012\n----\nMumps, 2011 - USA: (CA) university students 20121206.1441071\nMumps - UK: (Scotland) university students, alert 20120220.1047110\n2011\n----\nMumps - USA (04): (CA) university students 20111011.3045\nMumps - USA (03): (CA) university students 20111007.3014\nMumps - USA (02): (CA) university students, alert 20111006.3008\nMumps - USA: (IL) university students 20110928.2936\nMumps - UK (03): (England) university students 20110506.1403\n.................................................cp/mj/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "1348-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Mumps", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MR", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wakefield", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1725865", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - UK (02): (England) university students, comment", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1725865", "date": "2013-05-20 17:07:53", "main_text": "MUMPS - UK (02): (ENGLAND) UNIVERSITY STUDENTS, COMMENT\n*******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 20 May 2013\nFrom: Peter English <peter.english@phe.gov.uk> [edited]\n\n\nRe: ProMED-mail Mumps - UK: (England) university students 20130519.1723475\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------\nIn the post it was stated that: \"Scientists have linked the recent growth in mumps outbreaks to public opposition to the MMR jab, after a 1998 study linked the vaccination to autism. Its researcher, Andrew Wakefield, has since been struck off the medical register, and his conclusions are largely discredited. However, after his findings were reported globally, the number of children receiving the vaccination in the UK fell from 92 percent to below 80 percent. The last major outbreak was in 2008, when 1348 cases were confirmed, and 2 people died.\"\n\n[Dr Peter English points out at that:] \"The Wakefield scare started in 1998. That was 14 years ago. University students will be age 18 years or older, so they were not affected by this. Prior to the scare the uptake of MMR was better; but a catch-up vaccination campaign for children who had only had a single dose of MMR in the 1990s used an MR vaccine, protecting against measles and rubella only, so some of the students may have had only one dose of mumps containing (MMR) vaccine.\" There is more information about this at: 'Questions and answers about mumps and MMR' at http://www.ganfyd.org/index.php?title=Questions_and_answers_about_mumps_and_MMR. Interested readers are recommend to consult this document.\n\n--\nDr Peter M B English\nGMC No 3002861\nConsultant in Communicable Disease Control\nUK\n<peter.english@phe.gov.uk>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Peter English for drawing attention to this situation, which is relevant to the interpretation of this outbreak. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nMumps - USA (03): (VA) university students 20130328.1608579\nMumps - USA (02): (VA) university students 20130319.1594231\nMumps - USA: (MD) university students 20130316.1589886\n2012\n----\nMumps, 2011 - USA: (CA) university students 20121206.1441071\nMumps - UK: (Scotland) university students, alert 20120220.1047110\n2011\n----\nMumps - USA (04): (CA) university students 20111011.3045\nMumps - USA (03): (CA) university students 20111007.3014\nMumps - USA (02): (CA) university students, alert 20111006.3008\nMumps - USA: (IL) university students 20110928.2936\nMumps - UK (03): (England) university students 20110506.1403\n.................................................cp/mj/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "1348-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Mumps", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MR", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wakefield", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1723475", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - UK: (England) university students", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1723475", "date": "2013-02-17 14:54:00", "main_text": "MUMPS - SPAIN: (MADRID)\n***********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 16 Feb 2013\nSource: Madridactual.es [in Spanish, trans. Mod.JG/CP, edited]\nhttp://www.madridactual.es/20130214494299/la-consejeria-de-sanidad-en-alerta-ante-el-aumento-del-brote-de-paperas\n\n\nThe mumps outbreak that is currently affecting some youngsters in Madrid may spread. Mumps is mild and not a \"severe\" disease, but there can be no room for complacency, said Dr. Antonio Alemany, Chief of Primary Care. Dr. Alemany stated that the outbreak had begun at the beginning of the month [February 2013] and that the outbreak is not restricted to Madrid. He stated that it represents a new cycle of the disease, which tends to occur every 3-6 years.\n\nHe said that people \"are more or less protected,\" depending on the immunogenic capability of the vaccines they might have received. Dr. Alemany explained that vaccines used in Spain before 1999 had a 50.5 percent antigen content [protective capacity?], whereas those vaccines used more recently, particularly those manufactured \"using more advanced technology,\" have a \"much higher protection capacity,\" between 88 and 90 percent. Dr. Alemany recognized that children vaccinated before 1999 have a 50.5 percent likelihood of being protected, meaning that \"they do not have a complete defense\" against the disease as a consequence of the characteristics of that particular vaccine they had received.\n\nDr. Alemany also stated that, from an epidemiological point of view, \"being that this disease is quite communicable, we can expect that the number of cases of mumps in Madrid may increase,\" but he pointed out that there is no [reason] for concern \"because of the typical characteristics of this condition.\" Dr Alemany also stated that: \"It depends on the characteristics of the virus and climatic conditions, since outbreaks may occur more frequently during the cold season.\" Dr. Alemany also indicated that cases of mumps are occurring in several autonomous communities, \"since viruses do not recognize borders or geographical limits.\"\n\nAccording to Dr Alemany, mumps is a common disease during infancy \"that usually does not necessitate hospitalisation and can be treated at home with plenty of rest, lots of non-acidic fluids, with use of analgesics for alleviating headache or for temperature control.\" He explained also that in many cases, a person may have the virus and not develop the disease, or he/she may develop a mild form of this condition.\n\nOn the other hand, Dr. Salvador Victoria, Counselor of the Presidency and Spokesman for the Madrid Community Local Government, stated last Thursday [14 Feb 2013] that the outbreak of mumps recorded in Madrid \"is similar to the situation occurring in other areas in Spain, and that it does not have a special significance.\"\n\nAccording to the General Direction for Primary Care, the present situation is not a general outbreak, but it consists of \"local outbreaks occurring in specific sites\" in which \"timely epidemiological investigations are being carried out.\" When asked about this situation in a press conference after the Government Council meeting, Dr. Victoria explained that the Madrid Health Council had changed the vaccine in 1999 that was provided at that time by the Spanish Ministry of Health; and he mentioned also that in 2007, a vaccination campaign was carried out in 9- to 12-year old children, \"so they may have complete immunity against mumps.\"\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Outbreaks of mumps have been frequent throughout Spain in recent years. The symptoms of mumps usually develop 14 to 25 days after a person is infected with mumps virus. The average incubation period is around 17 days. Swelling of the parotid glands is the most common symptom of mumps. Both glands are usually affected by the swelling, although only one gland can be affected. The swelling can cause pain, tenderness, and difficulty with swallowing. Other symptoms of the mumps include: headache, joint pain, sickness, abdominal pain and fever.\n\nMumps is spread in the same way as colds and flu: via infected droplets of saliva that can be inhaled or picked up from surfaces and passed into the mouth or nose. A person is most contagious 1-2 days before the onset of symptoms and for 5 days afterwards. During this time, it is important to try to prevent spreading the infection to others, particularly teenagers and young adults who have not been vaccinated. Normally, infection resolves without complications and provides life-long immunity.\n\nFor unvaccinated persons born before 1957 who lack laboratory evidence of measles, mumps and/or rubella immunity or laboratory confirmation of disease, healthcare facilities should consider vaccinating these individuals with 2 doses of MMR vaccine at the appropriate interval (for measles and mumps) and one dose of MMR vaccine (for rubella), respectively. For unvaccinated personnel born before 1957 who lack laboratory evidence of measles, mumps and/or rubella immunity or laboratory confirmation of disease, healthcare facilities should recommend 2 doses of MMR vaccine during an outbreak of measles or mumps and one dose during an outbreak of rubella.\n\nTwo doses of mumps vaccine are 88 percent (range: 66-95 percent) effective at preventing the disease; one dose is 78 percent (range: 49-92 percent) effective. The 1st vaccine against mumps was licensed in the United States in 1967, and by 2005, high 2-dose childhood vaccination coverage reduced disease rates by 99 percent. Adults at higher risk, such as university students, health care personnel, and international travelers, and persons with potential mumps outbreak exposure, should ensure that they have been vaccinated. (Further information can be obtained from the USCDC website at (http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/pubs/pinkbook/mumps.html#vaccines). - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1zJm.]\nSee Also\n2012\n----\nMumps - Spain (06): (AS) 20121206.1441128\nMumps - Spain (05): (PA) 20121121.1419241\nMumps - Spain (04): (AS) 20120808.1234954\nMumps - Spain (03): (Catalonia) Girona 20120621.1176218\nMumps - Spain (02): Background 20120402.1087523\nMumps - Spain: (Catalonia) Girona 20120331.1086759\n2007\n----\nMumps - Spain (Navarra) (02): 2006 - 2007 20070216.0577\n.................................................sb/jg/cp/msp/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2013-02-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-02-14 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "1957-03-16 00:00:00", "1957-03-16 00:00:00", "1967-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "MUMPS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SPAIN", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madrid", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Catalonia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mumps - Spain", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1608579", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (03): (VA) university students", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1608579", "date": "2013-02-17 14:54:00", "main_text": "MUMPS - SPAIN: (MADRID)\n***********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 16 Feb 2013\nSource: Madridactual.es [in Spanish, trans. (Further information can be obtained from the USCDC website at (http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/pubs/pinkbook/mumps.html#vaccines). - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1zJm.]\nSee Also\n2012\n----\nMumps - Spain (06): (AS) 20121206.1441128\nMumps - Spain (05): (PA) 20121121.1419241\nMumps - Spain (04): (AS) 20120808.1234954\nMumps - Spain (03): (Catalonia) Girona 20120621.1176218\nMumps - Spain (02): Background 20120402.1087523\nMumps - Spain: (Catalonia) Girona 20120331.1086759\n2007\n----\nMumps - Spain (Navarra) (02): 2006 - 2007 20070216.0577\n.................................................sb/jg/cp/msp/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2013-02-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-02-14 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "1957-03-16 00:00:00", "1957-03-16 00:00:00", "1967-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "MUMPS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SPAIN", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madrid", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Catalonia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mumps - Spain", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1604476", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Australia: (WA), alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1604476", "date": "2013-02-17 14:54:00", "main_text": "MUMPS - SPAIN: (MADRID)\n***********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 16 Feb 2013\nSource: Madridactual.es [in Spanish, trans. Mod.JG/CP, edited]\nhttp://www.madridactual.es/20130214494299/la-consejeria-de-sanidad-en-alerta-ante-el-aumento-del-brote-de-paperas\n\n\nThe mumps outbreak that is currently affecting some youngsters in Madrid may spread. Mumps is mild and not a \"severe\" disease, but there can be no room for complacency, said Dr. Antonio Alemany, Chief of Primary Care. He stated that it represents a new cycle of the disease, which tends to occur every 3-6 years.\n\nHe said that people \"are more or less protected,\" depending on the immunogenic capability of the vaccines they might have received. of the characteristics of that particular vaccine they had received.\n\nDr. Alemany also stated that, from an epidemiological point of view, \"being that this disease is quite communicable, we can expect that the number of cases of mumps in Madrid may increase,\" but he pointed out that there is no [reason] for concern \"because of the typical characteristics of this condition.\" Dr Alemany explained also that in many cases, a person may have the virus and not develop the disease, or he/she may develop a mild form of this condition.\n\nOn the other hand, Dr. Salvador Victoria, Counselor of the Presidency and Spokesman for the Madrid Community Local Government, stated last Thursday [14 Feb 2013] that the outbreak of mumps recorded in Madrid \"is similar to the situation occurring in other areas in Spain, and that it does not have a special significance.\"\n\nAccording to the General Direction for Primary Care, the present situation is not a general outbreak, but it consists of \"local outbreaks occurring in specific sites\" in which \"timely epidemiological investigations are being carried out.\" When asked about this situation in a press conference after the Government Council meeting, Dr. Victoria explained that the Madrid Health Council had changed the vaccine in 1999 that was provided at that time by the Spanish Ministry of Health; and he mentioned also that in 2007, a vaccination campaign was carried out in 9- to 12-year old children, \"so they may have complete immunity against mumps.\"\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Outbreaks of mumps have been frequent throughout Spain in recent years. The symptoms of mumps usually develop 14 to 25 days after a person is infected with mumps virus. The average incubation period is around 17 days. Swelling of the parotid glands is the most common symptom of mumps. Both glands are usually affected by the swelling, although only one gland can be affected. The swelling can cause pain, tenderness, and difficulty with swallowing. Other symptoms of the mumps include: headache, joint pain, sickness, abdominal pain and fever.\n\nMumps is spread in the same way as colds and flu: via infected droplets of saliva that can be inhaled or picked up from surfaces and passed into the mouth or nose. A person is most contagious 1-2 days before the onset of symptoms and for 5 days afterwards. During this time, it is important to try to prevent spreading the infection to others, particularly teenagers and young adults who have not been vaccinated. Normally, infection resolves without complications and provides life-long immunity.\n\nFor unvaccinated persons born before 1957 who lack laboratory evidence of measles, mumps and/or rubella immunity or laboratory confirmation of disease, healthcare facilities should consider vaccinating these individuals with 2 doses of MMR vaccine at the appropriate interval (for measles and mumps) and one dose of MMR vaccine (for rubella), respectively. For unvaccinated personnel born before 1957 who lack laboratory evidence of measles, mumps and/or rubella immunity or laboratory confirmation of disease, healthcare facilities should recommend 2 doses of MMR vaccine during an outbreak of measles or mumps and one dose during an outbreak of rubella.\n\nTwo doses of mumps vaccine are 88 percent (range: 66-95 percent) effective at preventing the disease; one dose is 78 percent (range: 49-92 percent) effective. The 1st vaccine against mumps was licensed in the United States in 1967, and by 2005, high 2-dose childhood vaccination coverage reduced disease rates by 99 percent. Adults at higher risk, such as university students, health care personnel, and international travelers, and persons with potential mumps outbreak exposure, should ensure that they have been vaccinated. (Further information can be obtained from the USCDC website at (http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/pubs/pinkbook/mumps.html#vaccines). - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1zJm.]\nSee Also\n2012\n----\nMumps - Spain (06): (AS) 20121206.1441128\nMumps - Spain (05): (PA) 20121121.1419241\nMumps - Spain (04): (AS) 20120808.1234954\nMumps - Spain (03): (Catalonia) Girona 20120621.1176218\nMumps - Spain (02): Background 20120402.1087523\nMumps - Spain: (Catalonia) Girona 20120331.1086759\n2007\n----\nMumps - Spain (Navarra) (02): 2006 - 2007 20070216.0577\n.................................................sb/jg/cp/msp/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2013-02-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-02-14 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "1957-03-16 00:00:00", "1957-03-16 00:00:00", "1967-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "MUMPS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SPAIN", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madrid", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Catalonia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mumps - Spain", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1595802", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Viet Nam: (LO)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1595802", "date": "2013-02-17 14:54:00", "main_text": "MUMPS - SPAIN: (MADRID)\n***********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 16 Feb 2013\nSource: Madridactual.es [in Spanish, trans. Mod.JG/CP, edited]\nhttp://www.madridactual.es/20130214494299/la-consejeria-de-sanidad-en-alerta-ante-el-aumento-del-brote-de-paperas\n\n\nThe mumps outbreak that is currently affecting some youngsters in Madrid may spread. Mumps is mild and not a \"severe\" disease, but there can be no room for complacency, said Dr. Antonio Alemany, Chief of Primary Care. Dr. Alemany stated that the outbreak had begun at the beginning of the month [February 2013] and that the outbreak is not restricted to Madrid. He stated that it represents a new cycle of the disease, which tends to occur every 3-6 years.\n\nHe said that people \"are more or less protected,\" depending on the immunogenic capability of the vaccines they might have received. Dr. Alemany explained that vaccines used in Spain before 1999 had a 50.5 percent antigen content [protective capacity?], whereas those vaccines used more recently, particularly those manufactured \"using more advanced technology,\" have a \"much higher protection capacity,\" between 88 and 90 percent. Dr. Alemany recognized that children vaccinated before 1999 have a 50.5 percent likelihood of being protected, meaning that \"they do not have a complete defense\" against the disease as a consequence of the characteristics of that particular vaccine they had received.\n\nDr. Alemany also stated that, from an epidemiological point of view, \"being that this disease is quite communicable, we can expect that the number of cases of mumps in Madrid may increase,\" but he pointed out that there is no [reason] for concern \"because of the typical characteristics of this condition.\" Dr Alemany also stated that: \"It depends on the characteristics of the virus and climatic conditions, since outbreaks may occur more frequently during the cold season.\" Dr. Alemany also indicated that cases of mumps are occurring in several autonomous communities, \"since viruses do not recognize borders or geographical limits.\"\n\nAccording to Dr Alemany, mumps is a common disease during infancy \"that usually does not necessitate hospitalisation and can be treated at home with plenty of rest, lots of non-acidic fluids, with use of analgesics for alleviating headache or for temperature control.\" He explained also that in many cases, a person may have the virus and not develop the disease, or he/she may develop a mild form of this condition.\n\nOn the other hand, Dr. Salvador Victoria, Counselor of the Presidency and Spokesman for the Madrid Community Local Government, stated last Thursday [14 Feb 2013] that the outbreak of mumps recorded in Madrid \"is similar to the situation occurring in other areas in Spain, and that it does not have a special significance.\"\n\nAccording to the General Direction for Primary Care, the present situation is not a general outbreak, but it consists of \"local outbreaks occurring in specific sites\" in which \"timely epidemiological investigations are being carried out.\" When asked about this situation in a press conference after the Government Council meeting, Dr. Victoria explained that the Madrid Health Council had changed the vaccine in 1999 that was provided at that time by the Spanish Ministry of Health; and he mentioned also that in 2007, a vaccination campaign was carried out in 9- to 12-year old children, \"so they may have complete immunity against mumps.\"\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Outbreaks of mumps have been frequent throughout Spain in recent years. The symptoms of mumps usually develop 14 to 25 days after a person is infected with mumps virus. The average incubation period is around 17 days. Swelling of the parotid glands is the most common symptom of mumps. Both glands are usually affected by the swelling, although only one gland can be affected. The swelling can cause pain, tenderness, and difficulty with swallowing. Other symptoms of the mumps include: headache, joint pain, sickness, abdominal pain and fever.\n\nMumps is spread in the same way as colds and flu: via infected droplets of saliva that can be inhaled or picked up from surfaces and passed into the mouth or nose. A person is most contagious 1-2 days before the onset of symptoms and for 5 days afterwards. During this time, it is important to try to prevent spreading the infection to others, particularly teenagers and young adults who have not been vaccinated. Normally, infection resolves without complications and provides life-long immunity.\n\nFor unvaccinated persons born before 1957 who lack laboratory evidence of measles, mumps and/or rubella immunity or laboratory confirmation of disease, healthcare facilities should consider vaccinating these individuals with 2 doses of MMR vaccine at the appropriate interval (for measles and mumps) and one dose of MMR vaccine (for rubella), respectively. For unvaccinated personnel born before 1957 who lack laboratory evidence of measles, mumps and/or rubella immunity or laboratory confirmation of disease, healthcare facilities should recommend 2 doses of MMR vaccine during an outbreak of measles or mumps and one dose during an outbreak of rubella.\n\nTwo doses of mumps vaccine are 88 percent (range: 66-95 percent) effective at preventing the disease; one dose is 78 percent (range: 49-92 percent) effective. The 1st vaccine against mumps was licensed in the United States in 1967, and by 2005, high 2-dose childhood vaccination coverage reduced disease rates by 99 percent. Adults at higher risk, such as university students, health care personnel, and international travelers, and persons with potential mumps outbreak exposure, should ensure that they have been vaccinated. (Further information can be obtained from the USCDC website at (http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/pubs/pinkbook/mumps.html#vaccines). - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1zJm.]\nSee Also\n2012\n----\nMumps - Spain (06): (AS) 20121206.1441128\nMumps - Spain (05): (PA) 20121121.1419241\nMumps - Spain (04): (AS) 20120808.1234954\nMumps - Spain (03): (Catalonia) Girona 20120621.1176218\nMumps - Spain (02): Background 20120402.1087523\nMumps - Spain: (Catalonia) Girona 20120331.1086759\n2007\n----\nMumps - Spain (Navarra) (02): 2006 - 2007 20070216.0577\n.................................................sb/jg/cp/msp/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2013-02-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-02-14 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "1957-03-16 00:00:00", "1957-03-16 00:00:00", "1967-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "MUMPS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SPAIN", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madrid", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Catalonia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mumps - Spain", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1594231", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (02): (VA) university students", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1594231", "date": "2013-02-17 14:54:00", "main_text": "MUMPS - SPAIN: (MADRID)\n***********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 16 Feb 2013\nSource: Madridactual.es [in Spanish, trans. Mumps is mild and not a \"severe\" disease, but there can be no room for complacency, said Dr. Antonio Alemany, Chief of Primary Care. Dr. Alemany stated that the outbreak had begun at the beginning of the month [February 2013] and that the outbreak is not restricted to Madrid. Dr. Alemany recognized that children vaccinated before 1999 have a 50.5 percent likelihood of being protected, meaning that \"they do not have a complete defense\" against the disease as a consequence of the characteristics of that particular vaccine they had received.\n\nDr. Alemany also stated that, from an epidemiological point of view, \"being that this disease is quite communicable, we can expect that the number of cases of mumps in Madrid may increase,\" but he pointed out that there is no [reason] for concern \"because of the typical characteristics of this condition.\" Dr Alemany also stated that: \"It depends on the characteristics of the virus and climatic conditions, since outbreaks may occur more frequently during the cold season.\" Dr. Alemany also indicated that cases of other areas in Spain, and that it does not have a special significance.\"\n\nAccording to the General Direction for Primary Care, the present situation is not a general outbreak, but it consists of \"local outbreaks occurring in specific sites\" in which \"timely epidemiological investigations are being carried out.\" When asked about this situation in a press conference after the Government Council meeting, Dr. Victoria explained that the Madrid Health Council had changed the vaccine in 1999 that was provided at that time by the Spanish Ministry of Health; and he mentioned also that in 2007, a vaccination campaign was carried out in 9- to 12-year old children, \"so they may have complete immunity against mumps.\"\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap The symptoms of mumps usually develop 14 to 25 days after a person is infected with mumps virus. The average incubation period is around 17 days. Swelling of the parotid glands is the most common symptom of mumps. Both glands are usually affected by the swelling, although only one gland can be affected. The swelling can cause pain, tenderness, and difficulty with swallowing. Other symptoms of the mumps include: headache, joint pain, sickness, abdominal pain and fever.\n\nMumps is spread in the same way as colds and flu: via infected droplets of saliva that can be inhaled or picked up from surfaces and passed into the mouth or nose. A person is most contagious 1-2 days before the onset of symptoms and for 5 days afterwards. During this time, it is important to try to prevent spreading the infection to others, particularly teenagers and young adults who have not been vaccinated. Normally, infection resolves without complications and provides life-long immunity.\n\nFor unvaccinated persons born before 1957 who lack laboratory evidence of measles, mumps and/or rubella immunity or laboratory confirmation of disease, healthcare facilities should consider vaccinating these individuals with 2 doses of MMR vaccine at the appropriate interval (for measles and mumps) and one dose of MMR vaccine (for rubella), respectively. For unvaccinated personnel born before 1957 who lack laboratory evidence of measles, mumps and/or rubella immunity or laboratory confirmation of disease, healthcare facilities should recommend 2 doses of MMR vaccine during an outbreak of measles or mumps and one dose during an outbreak of rubella.\n\nTwo doses of mumps vaccine are 88 percent (range: 66-95 percent) effective at preventing the disease; one dose is 78 percent (range: 49-92 percent) effective. The 1st vaccine against mumps was licensed in the United States in 1967, and by 2005, high 2-dose childhood vaccination coverage reduced disease rates by 99 percent. Adults at higher risk, such as university students, health care personnel, and international travelers, and persons with potential mumps outbreak exposure, should ensure that they have been vaccinated. (Further information can be obtained from the USCDC website at (http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/pubs/pinkbook/mumps.html#vaccines). - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1zJm.]\nSee Also\n2012\n----\nMumps - Spain (06): (AS) 20121206.1441128\nMumps - Spain (05): (PA) 20121121.1419241\nMumps - Spain (04): (AS) 20120808.1234954\nMumps - Spain (03): (Catalonia) Girona 20120621.1176218\nMumps - Spain (02): Background 20120402.1087523\nMumps - Spain: (Catalonia) Girona 20120331.1086759\n2007\n----\nMumps - Spain (Navarra) (02): 2006 - 2007 20070216.0577\n.................................................sb/jg/cp/msp/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2013-02-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-02-14 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "1957-03-16 00:00:00", "1957-03-16 00:00:00", "1967-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "MUMPS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SPAIN", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madrid", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Catalonia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mumps - Spain", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1546740", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Spain: (Madrid)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1546740", "date": "2013-02-17 14:54:00", "main_text": "MUMPS - SPAIN: (MADRID)\n***********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 16 Feb 2013\nSource: Madridactual.es [in Spanish, trans. Mod.JG/CP, edited]\nhttp://www.madridactual.es/20130214494299/la-consejeria-de-sanidad-en-alerta-ante-el-aumento-del-brote-de-paperas\n\n\nThe mumps outbreak that is currently affecting some youngsters in Madrid may spread. Mumps is mild and not a \"severe\" disease, but there can be no room for complacency, said Dr. Antonio Alemany, Chief of Primary Care. Dr. Alemany stated that the outbreak had begun at the beginning of the month [February 2013] and that the outbreak is not restricted to Madrid. He stated that it represents a new cycle of the disease, which tends to occur every 3-6 years.\n\nHe said that people \"are more or less protected,\" depending on the immunogenic capability of the vaccines they might have received. Dr. Alemany explained that vaccines used in Spain before 1999 had a 50.5 percent antigen content [protective capacity?], whereas those vaccines used more recently, particularly those manufactured \"using more advanced technology,\" have a \"much higher protection capacity,\" between 88 and 90 percent. Dr. Alemany recognized that children vaccinated before 1999 have a 50.5 percent likelihood of being protected, meaning that \"they do not have a complete defense\" against the disease as a consequence of the characteristics of that particular vaccine they had received.\n\nDr. Alemany also stated that, from an epidemiological point of view, \"being that this disease is quite communicable, we can expect that the number of cases of mumps in Madrid may increase,\" but he pointed out that there is no [reason] for concern \"because of the typical characteristics of this condition.\" Dr Alemany also stated that: \"It depends on the characteristics of the virus and climatic conditions, since outbreaks may occur more frequently during the cold season.\" Dr. Alemany also indicated that cases of mumps are occurring in several autonomous communities, \"since viruses do not recognize borders or geographical limits.\"\n\nAccording to Dr Alemany, mumps is a common disease during infancy \"that usually does not necessitate hospitalisation and can be treated at home with plenty of rest, lots of non-acidic fluids, with use of analgesics for alleviating headache or for temperature control.\" He explained also that in many cases, a person may have the virus and not develop the disease, or he/she may develop a mild form of this condition.\n\nOn the other hand, Dr. Salvador Victoria, Counselor of the Presidency and Spokesman for the Madrid Community Local Government, stated last Thursday [14 Feb 2013] that the outbreak of mumps recorded in Madrid \"is similar to the situation occurring in other areas in Spain, and that it does not have a special significance.\"\n\nAccording to the General Direction for Primary Care, the present situation is not a general outbreak, but it consists of \"local outbreaks occurring in specific sites\" in which \"timely epidemiological investigations are being carried out.\" When asked about this situation in a press conference after the Government Council meeting, Dr. Victoria explained that the Madrid Health Council had changed the vaccine in 1999 that was provided at that time by the Spanish Ministry of Health; and he mentioned also that in 2007, a vaccination campaign was carried out in 9- to 12-year old children, \"so they may have complete immunity against mumps.\"\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Outbreaks of mumps have been frequent throughout Spain in recent years. The symptoms of mumps usually develop 14 to 25 days after a person is infected with mumps virus. The average incubation period is around 17 days. Swelling of the parotid glands is the most common symptom of mumps. Both glands are usually affected by the swelling, although only one gland can be affected. The swelling can cause pain, tenderness, and difficulty with swallowing. Other symptoms of the mumps include: headache, joint pain, sickness, abdominal pain and fever.\n\nMumps is spread in the same way as colds and flu: via infected droplets of saliva that can be inhaled or picked up from surfaces and passed into the mouth or nose. A person is most contagious 1-2 days before the onset of symptoms and for 5 days afterwards. During this time, it is important to try to prevent spreading the infection to others, particularly teenagers and young adults who have not been vaccinated. Normally, infection resolves without complications and provides life-long immunity.\n\nFor unvaccinated persons born before 1957 who lack laboratory evidence of measles, mumps and/or rubella immunity or laboratory confirmation of disease, healthcare facilities should consider vaccinating these individuals with 2 doses of MMR vaccine at the appropriate interval (for measles and mumps) and one dose of MMR vaccine (for rubella), respectively. For unvaccinated personnel born before 1957 who lack laboratory evidence of measles, mumps and/or rubella immunity or laboratory confirmation of disease, healthcare facilities should recommend 2 doses of MMR vaccine during an outbreak of measles or mumps and one dose during an outbreak of rubella.\n\nTwo doses of mumps vaccine are 88 percent (range: 66-95 percent) effective at preventing the disease; one dose is 78 percent (range: 49-92 percent) effective. The 1st vaccine against mumps was licensed in the United States in 1967, and by 2005, high 2-dose childhood vaccination coverage reduced disease rates by 99 percent. Adults at higher risk, such as university students, health care personnel, and international travelers, and persons with potential mumps outbreak exposure, should ensure that they have been vaccinated. (Further information can be obtained from the USCDC website at (http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/pubs/pinkbook/mumps.html#vaccines). - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1zJm.]\nSee Also\n2012\n----\nMumps - Spain (06): (AS) 20121206.1441128\nMumps - Spain (05): (PA) 20121121.1419241\nMumps - Spain (04): (AS) 20120808.1234954\nMumps - Spain (03): (Catalonia) Girona 20120621.1176218\nMumps - Spain (02): Background 20120402.1087523\nMumps - Spain: (Catalonia) Girona 20120331.1086759\n2007\n----\nMumps - Spain (Navarra) (02): 2006 - 2007 20070216.0577\n.................................................sb/jg/cp/msp/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2013-02-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-02-14 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "1957-03-16 00:00:00", "1957-03-16 00:00:00", "1967-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "MUMPS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SPAIN", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madrid", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Catalonia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mumps - Spain", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1494583", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Pakistan: (SD), fatalites, NOT", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1494583", "date": "2012-10-02 16:18:45", "main_text": "MUMPS - EGYPT: VACCINE SHORTAGE\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 1 Oct 2012\nSource: The Disease Daily [edited]\nhttp://www.healthmap.org/news/over-100-egyptian-children-face-mumps-outbreak-10112\n\n\nEgyptian Children Face Mumps Outbreak\n-------------------------------------\nMore than 100 children have been affected by a mumps outbreak in Marashda [official name Al Mar\u0101shidah located in Qina governorate], Egypt, with 43 cases and 70 infections reported. Officials at the Ministry of Health insist that this is not a serious outbreak. However, many children are not attending school out of fear of infection.\n\nMumps is caused by mumps virus and is spread when a person comes into contact with infected droplets of saliva or mucus, usually through coughing, sneezing, or sharing dishes. Symptoms of the disease include fever, headache, and fatigue, along with serious complications such as inflammation of the brain and deafness.\n\nEgyptian officials are working to provide treatment for infected youth. However, vaccination is considered the best strategy for avoiding mumps infection. The vaccination for mumps is a combination vaccine for measles, mumps, and rubella, (MMR). It is recommended that children receive 2 doses: one at age 12-15 months and another at age 4-6 years. The 1st MMR vaccine became available in 1967 and has reduced mumps prevalence by 99 percent.\n\nThis outbreak has occurred alongside news that Egypt is facing a nationwide vaccine shortage. Administrative delays have prevented the health ministry from replacing expired vaccines. While vaccines are available in private clinics, their costs make them unattainable to most patients. \"The longer the government fails to immunize these children, the more vulnerable to disease they are,\" explained Eman Masoud, head of the Pediatrics Section at Abul Riesh University Hospital in Cairo.\n\nExperts recommend that people experiencing symptoms of mumps contact a provider immediately and avoid situations where they might infect others, such as in a clinic waiting room.\n\n[Byline: Lauren Edmundson]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It is likely that this large outbreak of mumps virus infection is a consequence of disruption of the routine programme of immunisation of children with the combined MMR (mumps, measles and rubella) vaccine due to a temporary shortage of vaccine in Egypt.\n\nMumps virus was isolated in 1945, and an inactivated vaccine was developed in 1948. This vaccine produced only short-lasting immunity, and its use was discontinued in the mid-1970s. Most vaccines contain the Jeryl Lynn strain of live attenuated mumps virus vaccine. Mumps vaccine produces an inapparent, or mild, noncommunicable infection. More than 97 percent of recipients of a single dose develop measurable antibody. Seroconversion rates are similar for single antigen mumps vaccine or the combined MMR vaccine. A study in the United Kingdom documented vaccine effectiveness of 88 percent with 2 doses. The duration of vaccine-induced immunity is believed to be greater than 25 years, and is probably lifelong in most vaccine recipients. - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/3BOS.]\nSee Also\nMumps - EGYPT: VACCINE SHORTAGE\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 1 Oct 2012\nSource: The Disease Daily [edited]\nhttp://www.healthmap.org/news/over-100-egyptian-children-face-mumps-outbreak-10112\n\n\nEgyptian Children Face Mumps Outbreak\n-------------------------------------\nMore than 100 children have been affected by a mumps outbreak in Marashda [official name Al Mar\u0101shidah located in Qina governorate], Egypt, with 43 cases and 70 infections reported. Officials at the Ministry of Health insist that this is not a serious outbreak. However, many children are not attending school out of fear of infection.\n\nMumps is caused by mumps virus and is spread when a person comes into contact with infected droplets of saliva or mucus, usually through coughing, sneezing, or sharing dishes. Symptoms of the disease include fever, headache, and fatigue, along with serious complications such as inflammation of the brain and deafness.\n\nEgyptian officials are working to provide treatment for infected youth. However, vaccination is considered the best strategy for avoiding mumps infection. The vaccination for mumps is a combination vaccine for measles, mumps, and rubella, (MMR). It is recommended that children receive 2 doses: one at age 12-15 months and another at age 4-6 years. The 1st MMR vaccine became available in 1967 and has reduced mumps prevalence by 99 percent.\n\nThis outbreak has occurred alongside news that Egypt is facing a nationwide vaccine shortage. Administrative delays have prevented the health ministry from replacing expired vaccines. While vaccines are available in private clinics, their costs make them unattainable to most patients. \"The longer the government fails to immunize these children, the more vulnerable to disease they are,\" explained Eman Masoud, head of the Pediatrics Section at Abul Riesh University Hospital in Cairo.\n\nExperts recommend that people experiencing symptoms of mumps contact a provider immediately and avoid situations where they might infect others, such as in a clinic waiting room.\n\n[Byline: Lauren Edmundson]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It is likely that this large outbreak of mumps virus infection is a consequence of disruption of the routine programme of immunisation of children with the combined MMR (mumps, measles and rubella) vaccine due to a temporary shortage of vaccine in Egypt.\n\nMumps virus was isolated in 1945, and an inactivated vaccine was developed in 1948. This vaccine produced only short-lasting immunity, and its use was discontinued in the mid-1970s. Most vaccines contain the Jeryl Lynn strain of live attenuated mumps virus vaccine. Mumps vaccine produces an inapparent, or mild, noncommunicable infection. More than 97 percent of recipients of a single dose develop measurable antibody. Seroconversion rates are similar for single antigen mumps vaccine or the combined MMR vaccine. A study in the United Kingdom documented vaccine effectiveness of 88 percent with 2 doses. Spain (02): Background 20120402.1087523\nMumps - Spain: (Catalonia) Girona 20120331.1086759\nMumps - UK: (Scotland) university students, alert 20120220.1047110\n.................................................sb/cp/ejp/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1967-03-16 00:00:00", "1945-03-16 00:00:00", "1948-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Cairo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Catalonia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mumps - Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Qina", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1441071", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps, 2011 - USA: (CA) university students", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1441071", "date": "2012-10-02 16:18:45", "main_text": "MUMPS - EGYPT: VACCINE SHORTAGE\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 1 Oct 2012\nSource: The Disease Daily [edited]\nhttp://www.healthmap.org/news/over-100-egyptian-children-face-mumps-outbreak-10112\n\n\nEgyptian Children Face Mumps Outbreak\n-------------------------------------\nMore than 100 children have been affected by a mumps outbreak in Marashda [official name Al Mar\u0101shidah located in Qina governorate], Egypt, with 43 cases and 70 infections reported. Officials at the Ministry of Health insist that this is not a serious outbreak. However, many children are not attending school out of fear of infection.\n\nMumps is caused by mumps virus and is spread when a person comes into contact with infected droplets of saliva or mucus, usually through coughing, sneezing, or sharing dishes. Symptoms of the disease include fever, headache, and fatigue, along with serious complications such as inflammation of the brain and deafness.\n\nEgyptian officials are working to provide treatment for infected youth. However, vaccination is considered the best strategy for avoiding mumps infection. The vaccination for mumps is a combination vaccine for measles, mumps, and rubella, (MMR). It is recommended that children receive 2 doses: one at age 12-15 months and another at age 4-6 years. The 1st MMR vaccine became available in 1967 and has reduced mumps prevalence by 99 percent.\n\nThis outbreak has occurred alongside news that Egypt is facing a nationwide vaccine shortage. Administrative delays have prevented the health ministry from replacing expired vaccines. While vaccines are available in private clinics, their costs make them unattainable to most patients. \"The longer the government fails to immunize these children, the more vulnerable to disease they are,\" explained Eman Masoud, head of the Pediatrics Section at Abul Riesh University Hospital in Cairo.\n\nExperts recommend that people experiencing symptoms of mumps contact a provider immediately and avoid situations where they might infect others, such as in a clinic waiting room.\n\n[Byline: Lauren Edmundson]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It is likely that this large outbreak of mumps virus infection is a consequence of disruption of the routine programme of immunisation of children with the combined MMR (mumps, measles and rubella) vaccine due to a temporary shortage of vaccine in Egypt.\n\nMumps virus was isolated in 1945, and an inactivated vaccine was developed in 1948. This vaccine produced only short-lasting immunity, and its use was discontinued in the mid-1970s. Most vaccines contain the Jeryl Lynn strain of live attenuated mumps virus vaccine. Mumps vaccine produces an inapparent, or mild, noncommunicable infection. More than 97 percent of recipients of a single dose develop measurable antibody. Seroconversion rates are similar for single antigen mumps vaccine or the combined MMR vaccine. A study in the United Kingdom documented vaccine effectiveness of 88 percent with 2 doses. The duration of vaccine-induced immunity is believed to be greater than 25 years, and is probably lifelong in most vaccine recipients. - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/3BOS.]\nSee Also\nMumps - Spain: (AS) 20120808.1234954\nMumps - Australia: (QL) Gold Coast, adult 20120706.1192457\nMumps - Spain (03): (Catalonia) Girona 20120621.1176218\nMumps - Serbia: (VO) 20120511.1129263\nMumps - Canada: (MB), school outbreak 20120421.1109536\nMumps - Spain (02): Background 20120402.1087523\nMumps - Spain: (Catalonia) Girona 20120331.1086759\nMumps - UK: (Scotland) university students, alert 20120220.1047110\n.................................................sb/cp/ejp/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1967-03-16 00:00:00", "1945-03-16 00:00:00", "1948-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Cairo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Catalonia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mumps - EGYPT: VACCINE SHORTAGE\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 1 Oct 2012\nSource: The Disease Daily [edited]\nhttp://www.healthmap.org/news/over-100-egyptian-children-face-mumps-outbreak-10112\n\n\nEgyptian Children Face Mumps Outbreak\n-------------------------------------\nMore than 100 children have been affected by a mumps outbreak in Marashda [official name Al Mar\u0101shidah located in Qina governorate], Egypt, with 43 cases and 70 infections reported. Officials at the Ministry of Health insist that this is not a serious outbreak. However, many children are not attending school out of fear of infection.\n\nMumps is caused by mumps virus and is spread when a person comes into contact with infected droplets of saliva or mucus, usually through coughing, sneezing, or sharing dishes. Symptoms of the disease include fever, headache, and fatigue, along with serious complications such as inflammation of the brain and deafness.\n\nEgyptian officials are working to provide treatment for infected youth. However, vaccination is considered the best strategy for avoiding mumps infection. The vaccination for mumps is a combination vaccine for measles, mumps, and rubella, (MMR). It is recommended that children receive 2 doses: one at age 12-15 months and another at age 4-6 years. The 1st MMR vaccine became available in 1967 and has reduced mumps prevalence by 99 percent.\n\nThis outbreak has occurred alongside news that Egypt is facing a nationwide vaccine shortage. Administrative delays have prevented the health ministry from replacing expired vaccines. While vaccines are available in private clinics, their costs make them unattainable to most patients. \"The longer the government fails to immunize these children, the more vulnerable to disease they are,\" explained Eman Masoud, head of the Pediatrics Section at Abul Riesh University Hospital in Cairo.\n\nExperts recommend that people experiencing symptoms of mumps contact a provider immediately and avoid situations where they might infect others, such as in a clinic waiting room.\n\n[Byline: Lauren Edmundson]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It is likely that this large outbreak of mumps virus infection is a consequence of disruption of the routine programme of immunisation of children with the combined MMR (mumps, measles and rubella) vaccine due to a temporary shortage of vaccine in Egypt.\n\nMumps virus was isolated in 1945, and an inactivated vaccine was developed in 1948. This vaccine produced only short-lasting immunity, and its use was discontinued in the mid-1970s. Most vaccines contain the Jeryl Lynn strain of live attenuated mumps virus vaccine. Mumps vaccine produces an inapparent, or mild, noncommunicable infection. More than 97 percent of recipients of a single dose develop measurable antibody. Seroconversion rates are similar for single antigen mumps vaccine or the combined MMR vaccine. A study in the United Kingdom documented vaccine effectiveness of 88 percent with 2 doses. The duration of vaccine-induced immunity is believed to be greater than 25 years, and is probably lifelong in most vaccine recipients. - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/3BOS.]\nSee Also\nMumps -
