UK: (SCOTLAND) UNIVERSITY STUDENTS, ALERT\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 16 Feb 2012\nSource: Evening Times [edited]\nhttp://www.eveningtimes.co.uk/news/alert-as-more-students-are-hit-by-mumps-30-university-students-now-have-mumps-1.1148192\n\n\nA health warning has been reissued to students after 15 more cases of mumps were reported at Glasgow University. It brings the total number of students infected since the start of the month [February 2012] to 30 although university officials had claimed the outbreak was leveling off.\n\nNHS Greater Glasgow and Clyde's Public Health Protection Unit is liaising closely with the university and health officials said none of the students were giving cause for concern.\n\n[Byline: Carol Wilson]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Previously the HPS (Health Protection Scotland) Weekly Report dated 15 Feb 2012 indicated that since 7 Feb 2012, the Glasgow University Medical Centre has seen 26 cases of mumps in students attending Glasgow University. The students are between 18 and 22 years old, both male and female, attending different courses, and staying in different places.\n\nGlasgow University has asked all students to contact their GP for MMR vaccine if they have not already had 2 doses. MMR vaccine protects against measles, mumps, and rubella and is usually given at the ages of 13/14 months and around 4 years. Those who have missed doses of vaccine should get MMR vaccine from their GP. NHS [National Health Service] Greater Glasgow and Clyde has contacted all universities and colleges within its area to advise of the outbreak at Glasgow University and urge a reminder to all students in all institutions to obtain vaccine from their GP if they are under-immunized (see http://www.documents.hps.scot.nhs.uk/ewr/pdf2012/1207.pdf).\n\nOf the students who have contracted mumps virus infection it would be relevant to determine if any had received 2 doses of the MMR vaccine and were not protected. There are continuing doubts about the effectiveness of the mumps component of the MMR vaccine.\n\nGlasgow can be located in the interactive HealthMap/ProMED-mail map at http://healthmap.org/r/1OwW. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\n2011\n----\nMumps - UK (02): (Scotland) young people 20110224.0612\nMumps - UK: (Scotland) young people 20110115.0169\n2009\n----\nMumps: USA (MA); UK (Scotland) 20090419.1482\n2004\n----\nMumps - UK (Scotland) (03) 20040223.0575\nMumps - UK (Scotland) (02): background 20040221.0554\nMumps - UK (Scotland) 20040220.0545\n.................................................sb/cp/mj/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2012-02-16 00:00:00", "2012-02-15 00:00:00", "2012-02-07 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Clyde", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1192457", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Australia: (QL) Gold Coast, adult", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1192457", "date": "2012-02-20 12:35:15", "main_text": "MUMPS - UK: (SCOTLAND) UNIVERSITY STUDENTS, ALERT\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 16 Feb 2012\nSource: Evening Times [edited]\nhttp://www.eveningtimes.co.uk/news/alert-as-more-students-are-hit-by-mumps-30-university-students-now-have-mumps-1.1148192\n\n\nA health warning has been reissued to students after 15 more cases of mumps were reported at Glasgow University. It brings the total number of students infected since the start of the month [February 2012] to 30 although university officials had claimed the outbreak was leveling off.\n\nNHS Greater Glasgow and Clyde's Public Health Protection Unit is liaising closely with the university and health officials said none of the students were giving cause for concern.\n\n[Byline: Carol Wilson]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Previously the HPS (Health Protection Scotland) Weekly Report dated 15 Feb 2012 indicated that since 7 Feb 2012, the Glasgow University Medical Centre has seen 26 cases of mumps in students attending Glasgow University. The students are between 18 and 22 years old, both male and female, attending different courses, and staying in different places.\n\nGlasgow University has asked all students to contact their GP for MMR vaccine if they have not already had 2 doses. MMR vaccine protects against measles, mumps, and rubella and is usually given at the ages of 13/14 months and around 4 years. Those who have missed doses of vaccine should get MMR vaccine from their GP. NHS [National Health Service] Greater Glasgow and Clyde has contacted all universities and colleges within its area to advise of the outbreak at Glasgow University and urge a reminder to all students in all institutions to obtain vaccine from their GP if they are under-immunized (see http://www.documents.hps.scot.nhs.uk/ewr/pdf2012/1207.pdf).\n\nOf the students who have contracted mumps virus infection it would be relevant to determine if any had received 2 doses of the MMR vaccine and were not protected. There are continuing doubts about the effectiveness of the mumps component of the MMR vaccine.\n\nGlasgow can be located in the interactive HealthMap/ProMED-mail map at http://healthmap.org/r/1OwW. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\n2011\n----\nMumps - UK (02): (Scotland) young people 20110224.0612\nMumps - UK: (Scotland) young people 20110115.0169\n2009\n----\nMumps: USA (MA); UK (Scotland) 20090419.1482\n2004\n----\nMumps - UK (Scotland) (03) 20040223.0575\nMumps - UK (Scotland) (02): background 20040221.0554\nMumps - UK (Scotland) 20040220.0545\n.................................................sb/cp/mj/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2012-02-16 00:00:00", "2012-02-15 00:00:00", "2012-02-07 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Clyde", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1176218", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Spain (03): (Catalonia) Girona", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1176218", "date": "2012-02-20 12:35:15", "main_text": "MUMPS - UK: (SCOTLAND) UNIVERSITY STUDENTS, ALERT\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 16 Feb 2012\nSource: Evening Times [edited]\nhttp://www.eveningtimes.co.uk/news/alert-as-more-students-are-hit-by-mumps-30-university-students-now-have-mumps-1.1148192\n\n\nA health warning has been reissued to students after 15 more cases of mumps were reported at Glasgow University. It brings the total number of students infected since the start of the month [February 2012] to 30 although university officials had claimed the outbreak was leveling off.\n\nNHS Greater Glasgow and Clyde's Public Health Protection Unit is liaising closely with the university and health officials said none of the students were giving cause for concern.\n\n[Byline: Carol Wilson]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Previously the HPS (Health Protection Scotland) Weekly Report dated 15 Feb 2012 indicated that since 7 Feb 2012, the Glasgow University Medical Centre has seen 26 cases of mumps in students attending Glasgow University. The students are between 18 and 22 years old, both male and female, attending different courses, and staying in different places.\n\nGlasgow University has asked all students to contact their GP for MMR vaccine if they have not already had 2 doses. MMR vaccine protects against measles, mumps, and rubella and is usually given at the ages of 13/14 months and around 4 years. Those who have missed doses of vaccine should get MMR vaccine from their GP. NHS [National Health Service] Greater Glasgow and Clyde has contacted all universities and colleges within its area to advise of the outbreak at Glasgow University and urge a reminder to all students in all institutions to obtain vaccine from their GP if they are under-immunized (see http://www.documents.hps.scot.nhs.uk/ewr/pdf2012/1207.pdf).\n\nOf the students who have contracted mumps virus infection it would be relevant to determine if any had received 2 doses of the MMR vaccine and were not protected. There are continuing doubts about the effectiveness of the mumps component of the MMR vaccine.\n\nGlasgow can be located in the interactive HealthMap/ProMED-mail map at http://healthmap.org/r/1OwW. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\n2011\n----\nMumps - UK (02): (Scotland) young people 20110224.0612\nMumps - UK: (Scotland) young people 20110115.0169\n2009\n----\nMumps: USA (MA); UK (Scotland) 20090419.1482\n2004\n----\nMumps - UK (Scotland) (03) 20040223.0575\nMumps - UK (Scotland) (02): background 20040221.0554\nMumps - UK (Scotland) 20040220.0545\n.................................................sb/cp/mj/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2012-02-16 00:00:00", "2012-02-15 00:00:00", "2012-02-07 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Clyde", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1129263", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Serbia: (VO)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1129263", "date": "2012-02-20 12:35:15", "main_text": "MUMPS - UK: (SCOTLAND) UNIVERSITY STUDENTS, ALERT\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 16 Feb 2012\nSource: Evening Times [edited]\nhttp://www.eveningtimes.co.uk/news/alert-as-more-students-are-hit-by-mumps-30-university-students-now-have-mumps-1.1148192\n\n\nA health warning has been reissued to students after 15 more cases of mumps were reported at Glasgow University. It brings the total number of students infected since the start of the month [February 2012] to 30 although university officials had claimed the outbreak was leveling off.\n\nNHS Greater Glasgow and Clyde's Public Health Protection Unit is liaising closely with the university and health officials said none of the students were giving cause for concern.\n\n[Byline: Carol Wilson]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Previously the HPS (Health Protection Scotland) Weekly Report dated 15 Feb 2012 indicated that since 7 Feb 2012, the Glasgow University Medical Centre has seen 26 cases of mumps in students attending Glasgow University. The students are between 18 and 22 years old, both male and female, attending different courses, and staying in different places.\n\nGlasgow University has asked all students to contact their GP for MMR vaccine if they have not already had 2 doses. MMR vaccine protects against measles, mumps, and rubella and is usually given at the ages of 13/14 months and around 4 years. Those who have missed doses of vaccine should get MMR vaccine from their GP. NHS [National Health Service] Greater Glasgow and Clyde has contacted all universities and colleges within its area to advise of the outbreak at Glasgow University and urge a reminder to all students in all institutions to obtain vaccine from their GP if they are under-immunized (see http://www.documents.hps.scot.nhs.uk/ewr/pdf2012/1207.pdf).\n\nOf the students who have contracted mumps virus infection it would be relevant to determine if any had received 2 doses of the MMR vaccine and were not protected. It brings the total number of students infected since the start of the month [February 2012] to 30 although university officials had claimed the outbreak was leveling off.\n\nNHS Greater Glasgow and Clyde's Public Health Protection Unit is liaising closely with the university and health officials said none of the students were giving cause for concern.\n\n[Byline: Carol Wilson]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Previously the HPS (Health Protection Scotland) Weekly Report dated 15 Feb 2012 indicated that since 7 Feb 2012, the Glasgow University Medical Centre has seen 26 cases of mumps in students attending Glasgow University. MMR vaccine protects against measles, mumps, and rubella and is usually given at the ages of 13/14 months and around 4 years. Those who have missed doses of vaccine should get MMR vaccine from their GP. NHS [National Health Service] Greater Glasgow and Clyde has contacted all universities and colleges within its area to advise of the outbreak at Glasgow University and urge a reminder to all students in all institutions to obtain vaccine from their GP if they are under-immunized (see http://www.documents.hps.scot.nhs.uk/ewr/pdf2012/1207.pdf).\n\nOf the students who have contracted mumps virus infection it would be relevant to determine if any had received 2 doses of the MMR vaccine and were not protected. MMR vaccine protects against measles, mumps, and rubella and is usually given at the ages of 13/14 months and around 4 years. Those who have missed doses of vaccine should get MMR vaccine from their GP. NHS [National Health Service] Greater Glasgow and Clyde has contacted all universities and colleges within its area to advise of the outbreak at Glasgow University and urge a reminder to all students in all institutions to obtain vaccine from their GP if they are under-immunized (see http://www.documents.hps.scot.nhs.uk/ewr/pdf2012/1207.pdf).\n\nOf the students who have contracted mumps virus infection it would be relevant to determine if any had received 2 doses of the MMR vaccine and were not protected. So far 31\ncases have been reported in Ontario, including 2 in Ottawa.\n\n\"There were 2 cases ... they have completely recovered and they have\npassed the stage where they could pass the virus on to anyone else,\"\nsays Brenda MacLean of Ottawa Communicable Disease Prevention.\n\nMumps used to be a common childhood disease, but has been under\ncontrol since the development of a vaccine. Mumps is a viral infection\ntransmitted through direct contact. Signs of the infection include:\nFever, swelling or tenderness in the throat glands, and pain while\nchewing.\n\nOttawa typically sees 3 or 4 cases of mumps per year. Public Health\nofficials say the recent cases are not cause for alarm.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n****\n[2]\nDate: 29 Sep 2011\nFrom: John P. Maher, MD\nWest Chester, PA 19382\n<jmaher@chesco.org>\n\n\n[ProMED-mail received the following comment subsequent to the post\nentitled: \"Mumps - USA: (IL) university students, archive number\n20110928.2936,\" about a mumps outbreak in Illinois, USA, which is\nequally applicable to the preceding Canadian post. - Mod.CP]\n\nOne can't help but wonder from the reassuring tone of the news release\nwhether the health department and/or the University health officials\ndidn't miss a \"teachable moment\" with this outbreak, considering there\nis no mention therein about the potential (although perhaps uncommon)\ncomplications of preventable mumps infections, including orchitis,\naseptic meningitis, pancreatitis, hearing loss, etc.\n\n--\nJohn P. So far 31\ncases have been reported in Ontario, including 2 in Ottawa.\n\n\"There were 2 cases ... they have completely recovered and they have\npassed the stage where they could pass the virus on to anyone else,\"\nsays Brenda MacLean of Ottawa Communicable Disease Prevention.\n\nMumps used to be a common childhood disease, but has been under\ncontrol since the development of a vaccine. Mumps is a viral infection\ntransmitted through direct contact. Signs of the infection include:\nFever, swelling or tenderness in the throat glands, and pain while\nchewing.\n\nOttawa typically sees 3 or 4 cases of mumps per year. Public Health\nofficials say the recent cases are not cause for alarm.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n****\n[2]\nDate: 29 Sep 2011\nFrom: John P. Maher, MD\nWest Chester, PA 19382\n<jmaher@chesco.org>\n\n\n[ProMED-mail received the following comment subsequent to the post\nentitled: \"Mumps - USA: (IL) university students, archive number\n20110928.2936,\" about a mumps outbreak in Illinois, USA, which is\nequally applicable to the preceding Canadian post. - Mod.CP]\n\nOne can't help but wonder from the reassuring tone of the news release\nwhether the health department and/or the University health officials\ndidn't miss a \"teachable moment\" with this outbreak, considering there\nis no mention therein about the potential (although perhaps uncommon)\ncomplications of preventable mumps infections, including orchitis,\naseptic meningitis, pancreatitis, hearing loss, etc.\n\n--\nJohn P. So far 31\ncases have been reported in Ontario, including 2 in Ottawa.\n\n\"There were 2 cases ... they have completely recovered and they have\npassed the stage where they could pass the virus on to anyone else,\"\nsays Brenda MacLean of Ottawa Communicable Disease Prevention.\n\nMumps used to be a common childhood disease, but has been under\ncontrol since the development of a vaccine. Signs of the infection include:\nFever, swelling or tenderness in the throat glands, and pain while\nchewing.\n\nOttawa typically sees 3 or 4 cases of mumps per year. Public Health\nofficials say the recent cases are not cause for alarm.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n****\n[2]\nDate: 29 Sep 2011\nFrom: John P. Maher, MD\nWest Chester, PA 19382\n<jmaher@chesco.org>\n\n\n[ProMED-mail received the following comment subsequent to the post\nentitled: \"Mumps - USA: (IL) university students, archive number\n20110928.2936,\" about a mumps outbreak in Illinois, USA, which is\nequally applicable to the preceding Canadian post. - Mod.CP]\n\nOne can't help but wonder from the reassuring tone of the news release\nwhether the health department and/or the University health officials\ndidn't miss a \"teachable moment\" with this outbreak, considering there\nis no mention therein about the potential (although perhaps uncommon)\ncomplications of preventable mumps infections, including orchitis,\naseptic meningitis, pancreatitis, hearing loss, etc.\n\n--\nJohn P. So far 31\ncases have been reported in Ontario, including 2 in Ottawa.\n\n\"There were 2 cases ... they have completely recovered and they have\npassed the stage where they could pass the virus on to anyone else,\"\nsays Brenda MacLean of Ottawa Communicable Disease Prevention.\n\nMumps used to be a common childhood disease, but has been under\ncontrol since the development of a vaccine. Mumps is a viral infection\ntransmitted through direct contact. Signs of the infection include:\nFever, swelling or tenderness in the throat glands, and pain while\nchewing.\n\nOttawa typically sees 3 or 4 cases of mumps per year. Public Health\nofficials say the recent cases are not cause for alarm.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n****\n[2]\nDate: 29 Sep 2011\nFrom: John P. Maher, MD\nWest Chester, PA 19382\n<jmaher@chesco.org>\n\n\n[ProMED-mail received the following comment subsequent to the post\nentitled: \"Mumps - USA: (IL) university students, archive number\n20110928.2936,\" about a mumps outbreak in Illinois, USA, which is\nequally applicable to the preceding Canadian post. - Mod.CP]\n\nOne can't help but wonder from the reassuring tone of the news release\nwhether the health department and/or the University health officials\ndidn't miss a \"teachable moment\" with this outbreak, considering there\nis no mention therein about the potential (although perhaps uncommon)\ncomplications of preventable mumps infections, including orchitis,\naseptic meningitis, pancreatitis, hearing loss, etc.\n\n--\nJohn P. Maher, MD\nPublic Health Physician\nChester County Health Department\n601 Westtown Road, Ste 295\nWest Chester, PA 19382\n<jmaher@chesco.org>\n\n[The interactive HealthMap/ProMED map for Ottawa, Ontario, Canada, is\navailable at:\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/1i3l - CopyEd.EJP]\nSee Also\nMumps - USA: (IL) university students 20110928\nMumps - Canada (05): (ON) 20110817.2492\nMumps - Canada (04): (ON) 20110809.2418\nMumps - Canada (03): (BC) 20110707.2057\nMumps - Canada (02): (BC) alert 20110622.1912\nMumps - Canada: (BC) 20110415.1188\n.................................................sb/cp/ejp/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["mumps", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ottawa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Illinois , USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ontario", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "889629", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA: (IL) university students", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=889629", "date": "2011-07-07 17:23:03", "main_text": "MUMPS - CANADA (03): (BRITISH COLUMBIA)\n***************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 7 Jul 2011\nFrom: Jat Sandhu <Jat.Sandhu@vch.ca>\n\n\n[Submitted in response to the ProMED-mail post archived as: Mumps -\nCanada (02): (BC) alert 20110622.1912. - Mod.CP]\n\nBackground:\nVancouver Coastal Health Authority has been investigating an outbreak\nof mumps occurring initially in Whistler and spreading more recently\nto surrounding municipalities. Mumps is a viral illness characterized\nby swollen salivary glands, fever, and headache. In severe cases,\nmeningitis, orchitis (testicular swelling) and hearing loss can\noccur.\n\nSince February 2011, a total of 90 cases have been reported, mostly\nin young adults.\n\nSetting:\nWhistler is a popular ski and outdoor activities destination north of\nVancouver that attracts visitors and seasonal employees from all over\nthe world. The permanent population of Whistler is estimated to be\napproximately 10 500, although the area attracts over 2700 seasonal\nemployees and 14 800 visitors each year. An additional estimated 3700\nemployees commute to Whistler on a daily basis from surrounding\ncommunities, increasing the daily average population to approximately\n32 000. The entire region of Vancouver Coastal Health, which includes\nWhistler, has a population of 1.1 million.\n\nEpidemiology:\nMumps is spread by direct contact with the saliva of an infected\nperson. Current case definition includes individuals having symptoms\nconsistent with mumps illness and:\n(a) laboratory confirmation of mumps RNA; or\n(b) epidemiological links to a laboratory confirmed case; or\n(c) recent travel to Whistler.\n\nThe earliest date of symptom onset was 22 Feb 2011 in a Whistler\nresident, and while cases continue to reside predominantly in the\nWhistler region, increasing numbers of cases in surrounding cities,\nincluding Vancouver and Richmond, have been reported. Several of these\nrecent cases have no known links to Whistler; though many are\nclustered among the same household or social network.\n\nThe disease is primarily affecting young adults; the median age of\nall cases is 27.0 years (age range: 1-54 years), and 54 cases (60.0\nper cent) are male.\n\nTransmission among initial Whistler-linked cases was primarily by\nsharing marijuana joints, cigarettes, drinks, and utensils.\n\nNearly 60 per cent of cases with links to Whistler are employed\neither by the mountain resort or in the hospitality and retail sector.\nThese sectors employ a largely seasonal workforce arising from many\ndifferent countries across the globe.\n\nClinical presentation:\nNearly all cases presented with unilateral or bilateral parotitis\n(97.8 per cent). 22 per cent of male cases presented with orchitis.\nOther symptoms included fever (58.9 per cent), myalgia (34.4 per\ncent), headache (24.4 per cent), pharyngitis (22.2 per cent),\narthralgia (7.8 per cent), fatigue (7.8 per cent), and nausea (5.6 per\ncent).\n\nIdentified cases have been encouraged to self-isolate for 9 days\nfollowing symptom onset.\n\nImmunization history:\nThe majority of cases have not received the 2 doses of\nmumps-containing vaccine needed for full protection. As Whistler hosts\na largely transient (and international) population, immunization\nhistories of residents vary greatly.\n\nIn our health region, most children and youth born between 1970 and\n1995 will not have had 2 doses of MMR, as the 2nd dose was not\nincluded in the routine immunization schedule for this age group. A\n2nd MMR at 18 months of age became part of routine infant immunization\nin 1996.\n\nGenotype:\n16 cases to date have been confirmed as Genotype G, a common genotype\nof mumps that was observed in several other recent North American\noutbreaks.\n\nPublic health response to date:\n- Notification has been given to all primary care providers and\nemergency physicians in the health region to be vigilant for patients\npresenting with swelling of the parotid gland, or other\nmumps-compatible illness.\n\n- Collection of laboratory specimens including blood for serology and\nbuccal swabs and/or urine for detection of mumps virus RNA.\n\n- Recommendation of 2 doses of mumps containing vaccine for all\nindividuals born on or after 1 Jan 1970. One dose is recommended for\nall individuals born between 1 Jan 1957 and 31 Dec 1969 who do not\nhave evidence of immunity to mumps.\n\n- Notification to all health jurisdictions across Canada through the\nCNPHI (Canadian Network for Public Health Intelligence) web platform.\n\n- Media advisory in Whistler (March and April 2011) on outbreak and\ninformation on where to access vaccine and messaging for those without\nhealth insurance.\n\n- Drop-in immunization clinics have been held at the Whistler Health\nCare Centre since March 2011.\n\n- A targeted immunization campaign was launched in Whistler to\ncoincide with the 10-day Telus Ski & Snowboard Festival (15-24 Apr\n2011), the largest annual winter sports and music festival in North\nAmerica. Over 600 doses of MMR were given to contacts of cases and\nindividuals who live and work in Whistler through vaccination at\nworksites and a drop-in clinic at a centrally located community\npharmacy. Approximately 50 per cent of those taking up vaccination\nwere overseas nationals of Australia, New Zealand, United Kingdom,\nSouth Africa, and smaller numbers from other European and Asian\ncountries.\n\nFurther planned public health response:\n- Continued messaging and immunization to target post-secondary\neducational institutions in the region with a particular focus on new\nstudents arriving in August 2011 for the start of the new academic\nyear.\n\n- Targeted immunization at staff orientations to be held by major\nemployers in the resort municipality of Whistler in anticipation of\nnew international staff arriving in the fall [2011].\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nPaul Martiquet MD\nMedical Health Officer\n\nReka Gustafson MD\nMedical Health Officer and Medical Director Communicable Disease\nControl\n\nEmily Laflamme MPH\nRegional Epidemiologist, Public Health Surveillance Unit\n\nJat Sandhu PhD\nRegional Director, Public Health Surveillance Unit\nOffice of the Chief Medical Health Officer\nVancouver Coastal Health Authority\n800 601 West Broadway\nVancouver, British Columbia\nCanada V5Z 4C2\nhttp:www.vch.ca\n<phsu@vch.ca>\n\n[Contact <phsu@vch.ca> at Vancouver Coastal Health Authority\nhttp:www.vch.ca for further information.\n\nFor the VCH Health Watch monthly public health bulletin (with map of\nregion), see\nhttp://www.vch.ca/your_health/disease_surveillance/health_watch/.\n\nSince the previous report, the number of confirmed cases of mumps\nvirus infection has increased from 77 to 90, indicating that the\noutbreak has not yet been contained. ProMED-mail thanks Dr Jat Sandu\nand colleagues for provision of this detailed account of the current\nsituation regarding the mumps outbreak centered on the Whistler resort\narea of British Columbia and the response of the local health\nauthority.\n\nA map of British Columbia, showing the locations of Whistler and\nVancouver, can be found at\nhttp://www.jnweb.com/british-columbia/map-bc.html. The\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Canada can be accessed at\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/007x. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nMumps - Canada (02): (BC) alert 20110622.1912\nMumps - Canada: (BC) 20110415.1188\n2008\n---\nMumps - Canada (05): (BC) 20080827.2683\nMumps - Canada (03): (BC) 20080615.1890\nMumps - Canada: (BC) 20080311.0983\n.................................................cp/msp/sh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "mumps", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2011-02-16 00:00:00", "2700-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-02-22 00:00:00", "1995-03-16 00:00:00", "1996-03-16 00:00:00", "1970-01-01 00:00:00", "1969-12-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-04-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-08-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Vancouver", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Whistler", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "British Columbia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Richmond", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "853060", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Bosnia & Herzegovina: ongoing outbreak", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=853060", "date": "2011-07-07 17:23:03", "main_text": "MUMPS - CANADA (03): (BRITISH COLUMBIA)\n***************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 7 Jul 2011\nFrom: Jat Sandhu <Jat.Sandhu@vch.ca>\n\n\n[Submitted in response to the ProMED-mail post archived as: Mumps -\nCanada (02): (BC) alert 20110622.1912. - Mod.CP]\n\nBackground:\nVancouver Coastal Health Authority has been investigating an outbreak\nof mumps occurring initially in Whistler and spreading more recently\nto surrounding municipalities. Mumps is a viral illness characterized\nby swollen salivary glands, fever, and headache. In severe cases,\nmeningitis, orchitis (testicular swelling) and hearing loss can\noccur.\n\nSince February 2011, a total of 90 cases have been reported, mostly\nin young adults.\n\nSetting:\nWhistler is a popular ski and outdoor activities destination north of\nVancouver that attracts visitors and seasonal employees from all over\nthe world. The permanent population of Whistler is estimated to be\napproximately 10 500, although the area attracts over 2700 seasonal\nemployees and 14 800 visitors each year. An additional estimated 3700\nemployees commute to Whistler on a daily basis from surrounding\ncommunities, increasing the daily average population to approximately\n32 000. The entire region of Vancouver Coastal Health, which includes\nWhistler, has a population of 1.1 million.\n\nEpidemiology:\nMumps is spread by direct contact with the saliva of an infected\nperson. Current case definition includes individuals having symptoms\nconsistent with mumps illness and:\n(a) laboratory confirmation of mumps RNA; or\n(b) epidemiological links to a laboratory confirmed case; or\n(c) recent travel to Whistler.\n\nThe earliest date of symptom onset was 22 Feb 2011 in a Whistler\nresident, and while cases continue to reside predominantly in the\nWhistler region, increasing numbers of cases in surrounding cities,\nincluding Vancouver and Richmond, have been reported. Several of these\nrecent cases have no known links to Whistler; though many are\nclustered among the same household or social network.\n\nThe disease is primarily affecting young adults; the median age of\nall cases is 27.0 years (age range: 1-54 years), and 54 cases (60.0\nper cent) are male.\n\nTransmission among initial Whistler-linked cases was primarily by\nsharing marijuana joints, cigarettes, drinks, and utensils.\n\nNearly 60 per cent of cases with links to Whistler are employed\neither by the mountain resort or in the hospitality and retail sector.\nThese sectors employ a largely seasonal workforce arising from many\ndifferent countries across the globe.\n\nClinical presentation:\nNearly all cases presented with unilateral or bilateral parotitis\n(97.8 per cent). 22 per cent of male cases presented with orchitis.\nOther symptoms included fever (58.9 per cent), myalgia (34.4 per\ncent), headache (24.4 per cent), pharyngitis (22.2 per cent),\narthralgia (7.8 per cent), fatigue (7.8 per cent), and nausea (5.6 per\ncent).\n\nIdentified cases have been encouraged to self-isolate for 9 days\nfollowing symptom onset.\n\nImmunization history:\nThe majority of cases have not received the 2 doses of\nmumps-containing vaccine needed for full protection. As Whistler hosts\na largely transient (and international) population, immunization\nhistories of residents vary greatly.\n\nIn our health region, most children and youth born between 1970 and\n1995 will not have had 2 doses of MMR, as the 2nd dose was not\nincluded in the routine immunization schedule for this age group. A\n2nd MMR at 18 months of age became part of routine infant immunization\nin 1996.\n\nGenotype:\n16 cases to date have been confirmed as Genotype G, a common genotype\nof mumps that was observed in several other recent North American\noutbreaks.\n\nPublic health response to date:\n- Notification has been given to all primary care providers and\nemergency physicians in the health region to be vigilant for patients\npresenting with swelling of the parotid gland, or other\nmumps-compatible illness.\n\n- Collection of laboratory specimens including blood for serology and\nbuccal swabs and/or urine for detection of mumps virus RNA.\n\n- Recommendation of 2 doses of mumps containing vaccine for all\nindividuals born on or after 1 Jan 1970. One dose is recommended for\nall individuals born between 1 Jan 1957 and 31 Dec 1969 who do not\nhave evidence of immunity to mumps.\n\n- Notification to all health jurisdictions across Canada through the\nCNPHI (Canadian Network for Public Health Intelligence) web platform.\n\n- Media advisory in Whistler (March and April 2011) on outbreak and\ninformation on where to access vaccine and messaging for those without\nhealth insurance.\n\n- Drop-in immunization clinics have been held at the Whistler Health\nCare Centre since March 2011.\n\n- A targeted immunization campaign was launched in Whistler to\ncoincide with the 10-day Telus Ski & Snowboard Festival (15-24 Apr\n2011), the largest annual winter sports and music festival in North\nAmerica. Over 600 doses of MMR were given to contacts of cases and\nindividuals who live and work in Whistler through vaccination at\nworksites and a drop-in clinic at a centrally located community\npharmacy. Approximately 50 per cent of those taking up vaccination\nwere overseas nationals of Australia, New Zealand, United Kingdom,\nSouth Africa, and smaller numbers from other European and Asian\ncountries.\n\nFurther planned public health response:\n- Continued messaging and immunization to target post-secondary\neducational institutions in the region with a particular focus on new\nstudents arriving in August 2011 for the start of the new academic\nyear.\n\n- Targeted immunization at staff orientations to be held by major\nemployers in the resort municipality of Whistler in anticipation of\nnew international staff arriving in the fall [2011].\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nPaul Martiquet MD\nMedical Health Officer\n\nReka Gustafson MD\nMedical Health Officer and Medical Director Communicable Disease\nControl\n\nEmily Laflamme MPH\nRegional Epidemiologist, Public Health Surveillance Unit\n\nJat Sandhu PhD\nRegional Director, Public Health Surveillance Unit\nOffice of the Chief Medical Health Officer\nVancouver Coastal Health Authority\n800 601 West Broadway\nVancouver, British Columbia\nCanada V5Z 4C2\nhttp:www.vch.ca\n<phsu@vch.ca>\n\n[Contact <phsu@vch.ca> at Vancouver Coastal Health Authority\nhttp:www.vch.ca for further information.\n\nFor the VCH Health Watch monthly public health bulletin (with map of\nregion), see\nhttp://www.vch.ca/your_health/disease_surveillance/health_watch/.\n\nSince the previous report, the number of confirmed cases of mumps\nvirus infection has increased from 77 to 90, indicating that the\noutbreak has not yet been contained. ProMED-mail thanks Dr Jat Sandu\nand colleagues for provision of this detailed account of the current\nsituation regarding the mumps outbreak centered on the Whistler resort\narea of British Columbia and the response of the local health\nauthority.\n\nA map of British Columbia, showing the locations of Whistler and\nVancouver, can be found at\nhttp://www.jnweb.com/british-columbia/map-bc.html. The\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Canada can be accessed at\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/007x. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nMumps - Canada (02): (BC) alert 20110622.1912\nMumps - Canada: (BC) 20110415.1188\n2008\n---\nMumps - Canada (05): (BC) 20080827.2683\nMumps - Canada (03): (BC) 20080615.1890\nMumps - Canada: (BC) 20080311.0983\n.................................................cp/msp/sh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "mumps", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2011-02-16 00:00:00", "2700-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-02-22 00:00:00", "1995-03-16 00:00:00", "1996-03-16 00:00:00", "1970-01-01 00:00:00", "1969-12-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-04-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-08-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Vancouver", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Whistler", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "British Columbia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Richmond", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "832443", "headline": "PRO> Mumps - Bermuda", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=832442", "date": "2011-07-07 17:23:03", "main_text": "MUMPS - CANADA (03): (BRITISH COLUMBIA)\n***************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 7 Jul 2011\nFrom: Jat Sandhu <Jat.Sandhu@vch.ca>\n\n\n[Submitted in response to the ProMED-mail post archived as: Mumps -\nCanada (02): (BC) alert 20110622.1912. - Mod.CP]\n\nBackground:\nVancouver Coastal Health Authority has been investigating an outbreak\nof mumps occurring initially in Whistler and spreading more recently\nto surrounding municipalities. Mumps is a viral illness characterized\nby swollen salivary glands, fever, and headache. In severe cases,\nmeningitis, orchitis (testicular swelling) and hearing loss can\noccur.\n\nSince February 2011, a total of 90 cases have been reported, mostly\nin young adults.\n\nSetting:\nWhistler is a popular ski and outdoor activities destination north of\nVancouver that attracts visitors and seasonal employees from all over\nthe world. The permanent population of Whistler is estimated to be\napproximately 10 500, although the area attracts over 2700 seasonal\nemployees and 14 800 visitors each year. An additional estimated 3700\nemployees commute to Whistler on a daily basis from surrounding\ncommunities, increasing the daily average population to approximately\n32 000. The entire region of Vancouver Coastal Health, which includes\nWhistler, has a population of 1.1 million.\n\nEpidemiology:\nMumps is spread by direct contact with the saliva of an infected\nperson. Current case definition includes individuals having symptoms\nconsistent with mumps illness and:\n(a) laboratory confirmation of mumps RNA; or\n(b) epidemiological links to a laboratory confirmed case; or\n(c) recent travel to Whistler.\n\nThe earliest date of symptom onset was 22 Feb 2011 in a Whistler\nresident, and while cases continue to reside predominantly in the\nWhistler region, increasing numbers of cases in surrounding cities,\nincluding Vancouver and Richmond, have been reported. Several of these\nrecent cases have no known links to Whistler; though many are\nclustered among the same household or social network.\n\nThe disease is primarily affecting young adults; the median age of\nall cases is 27.0 years (age range: 1-54 years), and 54 cases (60.0\nper cent) are male.\n\nTransmission among initial Whistler-linked cases was primarily by\nsharing marijuana joints, cigarettes, drinks, and utensils.\n\nNearly 60 per cent of cases with links to Whistler are employed\neither by the mountain resort or in the hospitality and retail sector.\nThese sectors employ a largely seasonal workforce arising from many\ndifferent countries across the globe.\n\nClinical presentation:\nNearly all cases presented with unilateral or bilateral parotitis\n(97.8 per cent). 22 per cent of male cases presented with orchitis.\nOther symptoms included fever (58.9 per cent), myalgia (34.4 per\ncent), headache (24.4 per cent), pharyngitis (22.2 per cent),\narthralgia (7.8 per cent), fatigue (7.8 per cent), and nausea (5.6 per\ncent).\n\nIdentified cases have been encouraged to self-isolate for 9 days\nfollowing symptom onset.\n\nImmunization history:\nThe majority of cases have not received the 2 doses of\nmumps-containing vaccine needed for full protection. As Whistler hosts\na largely transient (and international) population, immunization\nhistories of residents vary greatly.\n\nIn our health region, most children and youth born between 1970 and\n1995 will not have had 2 doses of MMR, as the 2nd dose was not\nincluded in the routine immunization schedule for this age group. A\n2nd MMR at 18 months of age became part of routine infant immunization\nin 1996.\n\nGenotype:\n16 cases to date have been confirmed as Genotype G, a common genotype\nof mumps that was observed in several other recent North American\noutbreaks.\n\nPublic health response to date:\n- Notification has been given to all primary care providers and\nemergency physicians in the health region to be vigilant for patients\npresenting with swelling of the parotid gland, or other\nmumps-compatible illness.\n\n- Collection of laboratory specimens including blood for serology and\nbuccal swabs and/or urine for detection of mumps virus RNA.\n\n- Recommendation of 2 doses of mumps containing vaccine for all\nindividuals born on or after 1 Jan 1970. One dose is recommended for\nall individuals born between 1 Jan 1957 and 31 Dec 1969 who do not\nhave evidence of immunity to mumps.\n\n- Notification to all health jurisdictions across Canada through the\nCNPHI (Canadian Network for Public Health Intelligence) web platform.\n\n- Media advisory in Whistler (March and April 2011) on outbreak and\ninformation on where to access vaccine and messaging for those without\nhealth insurance.\n\n- Drop-in immunization clinics have been held at the Whistler Health\nCare Centre since March 2011.\n\n- A targeted immunization campaign was launched in Whistler to\ncoincide with the 10-day Telus Ski & Snowboard Festival (15-24 Apr\n2011), the largest annual winter sports and music festival in North\nAmerica. Over 600 doses of MMR were given to contacts of cases and\nindividuals who live and work in Whistler through vaccination at\nworksites and a drop-in clinic at a centrally located community\npharmacy. Approximately 50 per cent of those taking up vaccination\nwere overseas nationals of Australia, New Zealand, United Kingdom,\nSouth Africa, and smaller numbers from other European and Asian\ncountries.\n\nFurther planned public health response:\n- Continued messaging and immunization to target post-secondary\neducational institutions in the region with a particular focus on new\nstudents arriving in August 2011 for the start of the new academic\nyear.\n\n- Targeted immunization at staff orientations to be held by major\nemployers in the resort municipality of Whistler in anticipation of\nnew international staff arriving in the fall [2011].\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nPaul Martiquet MD\nMedical Health Officer\n\nReka Gustafson MD\nMedical Health Officer and Medical Director Communicable Disease\nControl\n\nEmily Laflamme MPH\nRegional Epidemiologist, Public Health Surveillance Unit\n\nJat Sandhu PhD\nRegional Director, Public Health Surveillance Unit\nOffice of the Chief Medical Health Officer\nVancouver Coastal Health Authority\n800 601 West Broadway\nVancouver, British Columbia\nCanada V5Z 4C2\nhttp:www.vch.ca\n<phsu@vch.ca>\n\n[Contact <phsu@vch.ca> at Vancouver Coastal Health Authority\nhttp:www.vch.ca for further information.\n\nFor the VCH Health Watch monthly public health bulletin (with map of\nregion), see\nhttp://www.vch.ca/your_health/disease_surveillance/health_watch/.\n\nSince the previous report, the number of confirmed cases of mumps\nvirus infection has increased from 77 to 90, indicating that the\noutbreak has not yet been contained. The\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Canada can be accessed at\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/007x. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nMumps - Canada (02): (BC) alert 20110622.1912\nMumps - Canada: (BC) 20110415.1188\n2008\n---\nMumps - Canada (05): (BC) 20080827.2683\nMumps - Canada (03): (BC) 20080615.1890\nMumps - Canada: (BC) 20080311.0983\n.................................................cp/msp/sh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "mumps", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2011-02-16 00:00:00", "2700-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-02-22 00:00:00", "1995-03-16 00:00:00", "1996-03-16 00:00:00", "1970-01-01 00:00:00", "1969-12-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-04-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-08-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Vancouver", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Whistler", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "British Columbia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Richmond", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "830856", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Czech Republic: (SK) supplementary vaccination?", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=830856", "date": "2011-07-07 17:23:03", "main_text": "MUMPS - CANADA (03): (BRITISH COLUMBIA)\n***************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 7 Jul 2011\nFrom: Jat Sandhu <Jat.Sandhu@vch.ca>\n\n\n[Submitted in response to the ProMED-mail post archived as: Mumps -\nCanada (02): (BC) alert 20110622.1912. - Mod.CP]\n\nBackground:\nVancouver Coastal Health Authority has been investigating an outbreak\nof mumps occurring initially in Whistler and spreading more recently\nto surrounding municipalities. Mumps is a viral illness characterized\nby swollen salivary glands, fever, and headache. In severe cases,\nmeningitis, orchitis (testicular swelling) and hearing loss can\noccur.\n\nSince February 2011, a total of 90 cases have been reported, mostly\nin young adults.\n\nSetting:\nWhistler is a popular ski and outdoor activities destination north of\nVancouver that attracts visitors and seasonal employees from all over\nthe world. The permanent population of Whistler is estimated to be\napproximately 10 500, although the area attracts over 2700 seasonal\nemployees and 14 800 visitors each year. An additional estimated 3700\nemployees commute to Whistler on a daily basis from surrounding\ncommunities, increasing the daily average population to approximately\n32 000. The entire region of Vancouver Coastal Health, which includes\nWhistler, has a population of 1.1 million.\n\nEpidemiology:\nMumps is spread by direct contact with the saliva of an infected\nperson. Current case definition includes individuals having symptoms\nconsistent with mumps illness and:\n(a) laboratory confirmation of mumps RNA; or\n(b) epidemiological links to a laboratory confirmed case; or\n(c) recent travel to Whistler.\n\nThe earliest date of symptom onset was 22 Feb 2011 in a Whistler\nresident, and while cases continue to reside predominantly in the\nWhistler region, increasing numbers of cases in surrounding cities,\nincluding Vancouver and Richmond, have been reported. Several of these\nrecent cases have no known links to Whistler; though many are\nclustered among the same household or social network.\n\nThe disease is primarily affecting young adults; the median age of\nall cases is 27.0 years (age range: 1-54 years), and 54 cases (60.0\nper cent) are male.\n\nTransmission among initial Whistler-linked cases was primarily by\nsharing marijuana joints, cigarettes, drinks, and utensils.\n\nNearly 60 per cent of cases with links to Whistler are employed\neither by the mountain resort or in the hospitality and retail sector.\nThese sectors employ a largely seasonal workforce arising from many\ndifferent countries across the globe.\n\nClinical presentation:\nNearly all cases presented with unilateral or bilateral parotitis\n(97.8 per cent). 22 per cent of male cases presented with orchitis.\nOther symptoms included fever (58.9 per cent), myalgia (34.4 per\ncent), headache (24.4 per cent), pharyngitis (22.2 per cent),\narthralgia (7.8 per cent), fatigue (7.8 per cent), and nausea (5.6 per\ncent).\n\nIdentified cases have been encouraged to self-isolate for 9 days\nfollowing symptom onset.\n\nImmunization history:\nThe majority of cases have not received the 2 doses of\nmumps-containing vaccine needed for full protection. As Whistler hosts\na largely transient (and international) population, immunization\nhistories of residents vary greatly.\n\nIn our health region, most children and youth born between 1970 and\n1995 will not have had 2 doses of MMR, as the 2nd dose was not\nincluded in the routine immunization schedule for this age group. A\n2nd MMR at 18 months of age became part of routine infant immunization\nin 1996.\n\nGenotype:\n16 cases to date have been confirmed as Genotype G, a common genotype\nof mumps that was observed in several other recent North American\noutbreaks.\n\nPublic health response to date:\n- Notification has been given to all primary care providers and\nemergency physicians in the health region to be vigilant for patients\npresenting with swelling of the parotid gland, or other\nmumps-compatible illness.\n\n- Collection of laboratory specimens including blood for serology and\nbuccal swabs and/or urine for detection of mumps virus RNA.\n\n- Recommendation of 2 doses of mumps containing vaccine for all\nindividuals born on or after 1 Jan 1970. One dose is recommended for\nall individuals born between 1 Jan 1957 and 31 Dec 1969 who do not\nhave evidence of immunity to mumps.\n\n- Notification to all health jurisdictions across Canada through the\nCNPHI (Canadian Network for Public Health Intelligence) web platform.\n\n- Media advisory in Whistler (March and April 2011) on outbreak and\ninformation on where to access vaccine and messaging for those without\nhealth insurance.\n\n- Drop-in immunization clinics have been held at the Whistler Health\nCare Centre since March 2011.\n\n- A targeted immunization campaign was launched in Whistler to\ncoincide with the 10-day Telus Ski & Snowboard Festival (15-24 Apr\n2011), the largest annual winter sports and music festival in North\nAmerica. Over 600 doses of MMR were given to contacts of cases and\nindividuals who live and work in Whistler through vaccination at\nworksites and a drop-in clinic at a centrally located community\npharmacy. Approximately 50 per cent of those taking up vaccination\nwere overseas nationals of Australia, New Zealand, United Kingdom,\nSouth Africa, and smaller numbers from other European and Asian\ncountries.\n\nFurther planned public health response:\n- Continued messaging and immunization to target post-secondary\neducational institutions in the region with a particular focus on new\nstudents arriving in August 2011 for the start of the new academic\nyear.\n\n- Targeted immunization at staff orientations to be held by major\nemployers in the resort municipality of Whistler in anticipation of\nnew international staff arriving in the fall [2011].\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nPaul Martiquet MD\nMedical Health Officer\n\nReka Gustafson MD\nMedical Health Officer and Medical Director Communicable Disease\nControl\n\nEmily Laflamme MPH\nRegional Epidemiologist, Public Health Surveillance Unit\n\nJat Sandhu PhD\nRegional Director, Public Health Surveillance Unit\nOffice of the Chief Medical Health Officer\nVancouver Coastal Health Authority\n800 601 West Broadway\nVancouver, British Columbia\nCanada V5Z 4C2\nhttp:www.vch.ca\n<phsu@vch.ca>\n\n[Contact <phsu@vch.ca> at Vancouver Coastal Health Authority\nhttp:www.vch.ca for further information.\n\nFor the VCH Health Watch monthly public health bulletin (with map of\nregion), see\nhttp://www.vch.ca/your_health/disease_surveillance/health_watch/.\n\nSince the previous report, the number of confirmed cases of mumps\nvirus infection has increased from 77 to 90, indicating that the\noutbreak has not yet been contained. ProMED-mail thanks Dr Jat Sandu\nand colleagues for provision of this detailed account of the current\nsituation regarding the mumps outbreak centered on the Whistler resort\narea of British Columbia and the response of the local health\nauthority.\n\nA map of British Columbia, showing the locations of Whistler and\nVancouver, can be found at\nhttp://www.jnweb.com/british-columbia/map-bc.html. The\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Canada can be accessed at\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/007x. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nMumps - Canada (02): (BC) alert 20110622.1912\nMumps - Canada: (BC) 20110415.1188\n2008\n---\nMumps - Canada (05): (BC) 20080827.2683\nMumps - Canada (03): (BC) 20080615.1890\nMumps - Canada: (BC) 20080311.0983\n.................................................cp/msp/sh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "mumps", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2011-02-16 00:00:00", "2700-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-02-22 00:00:00", "1995-03-16 00:00:00", "1996-03-16 00:00:00", "1970-01-01 00:00:00", "1969-12-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-04-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-08-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Vancouver", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Whistler", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "British Columbia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Richmond", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "824022", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Approximately 50 per cent of those taking up vaccination\nwere overseas nationals of Australia, New Zealand, United Kingdom,\nSouth Africa, and smaller numbers from other European and Asian\ncountries.\n\nFurther planned public health response:\n- Continued messaging and immunization to target post-secondary\neducational institutions in the region with a particular focus on new\nstudents arriving in August 2011 for the start of the new academic\nyear.\n\n- Targeted immunization at staff orientations to be held by major\nemployers in the resort municipality of Whistler in anticipation of\nnew international staff arriving in the fall [2011].\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nPaul Martiquet MD\nMedical Health Officer\n\nReka Gustafson MD\nMedical Health Officer and Medical Director Communicable Disease\nControl\n\nEmily Laflamme MPH\nRegional Epidemiologist, Public Health Surveillance Unit\n\nJat Sandhu PhD\nRegional Director, Public Health Surveillance Unit\nOffice of the Chief Medical Health Officer\nVancouver Coastal Health Authority\n800 601 West Broadway\nVancouver, British Columbia\nCanada V5Z 4C2\nhttp:www.vch.ca\n<phsu@vch.ca>\n\n[Contact <phsu@vch.ca> at Vancouver Coastal Health Authority\nhttp:www.vch.ca for further information.\n\nFor the VCH Health Watch monthly public health bulletin (with map of\nregion), see\nhttp://www.vch.ca/your_health/disease_surveillance/health_watch/.\n\nSince the previous report, the number of confirmed cases of mumps\nvirus infection has increased from 77 to 90, indicating that the\noutbreak has not yet been contained. Canada (04): (ON)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=813559", "date": "2011-07-07 17:23:03", "main_text": "MUMPS - CANADA (03): (BRITISH COLUMBIA)\n***************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 7 Jul 2011\nFrom: Jat Sandhu <Jat.Sandhu@vch.ca>\n\n\n[Submitted in response to the ProMED-mail post archived as: Mumps -\nCanada (02): (BC) alert 20110622.1912. - Mod.CP]\n\nBackground:\nVancouver Coastal Health Authority has been investigating an outbreak\nof mumps occurring initially in Whistler and spreading more recently\nto surrounding municipalities. Mumps is a viral illness characterized\nby swollen salivary glands, fever, and headache. In severe cases,\nmeningitis, orchitis (testicular swelling) and hearing loss can\noccur.\n\nSince February 2011, a total of 90 cases have been reported, mostly\nin young adults.\n\nSetting:\nWhistler is a popular ski and outdoor activities destination north of\nVancouver that attracts visitors and seasonal employees from all over\nthe world. The permanent population of Whistler is estimated to be\napproximately 10 500, although the area attracts over 2700 seasonal\nemployees and 14 800 visitors each year. An additional estimated 3700\nemployees commute to Whistler on a daily basis from surrounding\ncommunities, increasing the daily average population to approximately\n32 000. The entire region of Vancouver Coastal Health, which includes\nWhistler, has a population of 1.1 million.\n\nEpidemiology:\nMumps is spread by direct contact with the saliva of an infected\nperson. Current case definition includes individuals having symptoms\nconsistent with mumps illness and:\n(a) laboratory confirmation of mumps RNA; or\n(b) epidemiological links to a laboratory confirmed case; or\n(c) recent travel to Whistler.\n\nThe earliest date of symptom onset was 22 Feb 2011 in a Whistler\nresident, and while cases continue to reside predominantly in the\nWhistler region, increasing numbers of cases in surrounding cities,\nincluding Vancouver and Richmond, have been reported. Several of these\nrecent cases have no known links to Whistler; though many are\nclustered among the same household or social network.\n\nThe disease is primarily affecting young adults; the median age of\nall cases is 27.0 years (age range: 1-54 years), and 54 cases (60.0\nper cent) are male.\n\nTransmission among initial Whistler-linked cases was primarily by\nsharing marijuana joints, cigarettes, drinks, and utensils.\n\nNearly 60 per cent of cases with links to Whistler are employed\neither by the mountain resort or in the hospitality and retail sector.\nThese sectors employ a largely seasonal workforce arising from many\ndifferent countries across the globe.\n\nClinical presentation:\nNearly all cases presented with unilateral or bilateral parotitis\n(97.8 per cent). 22 per cent of male cases presented with orchitis.\nOther symptoms included fever (58.9 per cent), myalgia (34.4 per\ncent), headache (24.4 per cent), pharyngitis (22.2 per cent),\narthralgia (7.8 per cent), fatigue (7.8 per cent), and nausea (5.6 per\ncent).\n\nIdentified cases have been encouraged to self-isolate for 9 days\nfollowing symptom onset.\n\nImmunization history:\nThe majority of cases have not received the 2 doses of\nmumps-containing vaccine needed for full protection. As Whistler hosts\na largely transient (and international) population, immunization\nhistories of residents vary greatly.\n\nIn our health region, most children and youth born between 1970 and\n1995 will not have had 2 doses of MMR, as the 2nd dose was not\nincluded in the routine immunization schedule for this age group. A\n2nd MMR at 18 months of age became part of routine infant immunization\nin 1996.\n\nGenotype:\n16 cases to date have been confirmed as Genotype G, a common genotype\nof mumps that was observed in several other recent North American\noutbreaks.\n\nPublic health response to date:\n- Notification has been given to all primary care providers and\nemergency physicians in the health region to be vigilant for patients\npresenting with swelling of the parotid gland, or other\nmumps-compatible illness.\n\n- Collection of laboratory specimens including blood for serology and\nbuccal swabs and/or urine for detection of mumps virus RNA.\n\n- Recommendation of 2 doses of mumps containing vaccine for all\nindividuals born on or after 1 Jan 1970. One dose is recommended for\nall individuals born between 1 Jan 1957 and 31 Dec 1969 who do not\nhave evidence of immunity to mumps.\n\n- Notification to all health jurisdictions across Canada through the\nCNPHI (Canadian Network for Public Health Intelligence) web platform.\n\n- Media advisory in Whistler (March and April 2011) on outbreak and\ninformation on where to access vaccine and messaging for those without\nhealth insurance.\n\n- Drop-in immunization clinics have been held at the Whistler Health\nCare Centre since March 2011.\n\n- A targeted immunization campaign was launched in Whistler to\ncoincide with the 10-day Telus Ski & Snowboard Festival (15-24 Apr\n2011), the largest annual winter sports and music festival in North\nAmerica. Over 600 doses of MMR were given to contacts of cases and\nindividuals who live and work in Whistler through vaccination at\nworksites and a drop-in clinic at a centrally located community\npharmacy. Approximately 50 per cent of those taking up vaccination\nwere overseas nationals of Australia, New Zealand, United Kingdom,\nSouth Africa, and smaller numbers from other European and Asian\ncountries.\n\nFurther planned public health response:\n- Continued messaging and immunization to target post-secondary\neducational institutions in the region with a particular focus on new\nstudents arriving in August 2011 for the start of the new academic\nyear.\n\n- Targeted immunization at staff orientations to be held by major\nemployers in the resort municipality of Whistler in anticipation of\nnew international staff arriving in the fall [2011].\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nPaul Martiquet MD\nMedical Health Officer\n\nReka Gustafson MD\nMedical Health Officer and Medical Director Communicable Disease\nControl\n\nEmily Laflamme MPH\nRegional Epidemiologist, Public Health Surveillance Unit\n\nJat Sandhu PhD\nRegional Director, Public Health Surveillance Unit\nOffice of the Chief Medical Health Officer\nVancouver Coastal Health Authority\n800 601 West Broadway\nVancouver, British Columbia\nCanada V5Z 4C2\nhttp:www.vch.ca\n<phsu@vch.ca>\n\n[Contact <phsu@vch.ca> at Vancouver Coastal Health Authority\nhttp:www.vch.ca for further information.\n\nFor the VCH Health Watch monthly public health bulletin (with map of\nregion), see\nhttp://www.vch.ca/your_health/disease_surveillance/health_watch/.\n\nSince the previous report, the number of confirmed cases of mumps\nvirus infection has increased from 77 to 90, indicating that the\noutbreak has not yet been contained. Mod.CP]\n\nBackground:\nVancouver Coastal Health Authority has been investigating an outbreak\nof mumps occurring initially in Whistler and spreading more recently\nto surrounding municipalities. Mumps is a viral illness characterized\nby swollen salivary glands, fever, and headache. In severe cases,\nmeningitis, orchitis (testicular swelling) and hearing loss can\noccur.\n\nSince February 2011, a total of 90 cases have been reported, mostly\nin young adults.\n\nSetting:\nWhistler is a popular ski and outdoor activities destination north of\nVancouver that attracts visitors and seasonal employees from all over\nthe world. The permanent population of Whistler is estimated to be\napproximately 10 500, although the area attracts over 2700 seasonal\nemployees and 14 800 visitors each year. An additional estimated 3700\nemployees commute to Whistler on a daily basis from surrounding\ncommunities, increasing the daily average population to approximately\n32 000. The entire region of Vancouver Coastal Health, which includes\nWhistler, has a population of 1.1 million.\n\nEpidemiology:\nMumps is spread by direct contact with the saliva of an infected\nperson. Current case definition includes individuals having symptoms\nconsistent with mumps illness and:\n(a) laboratory confirmation of mumps RNA; or\n(b) epidemiological links to a laboratory confirmed case; or\n(c) recent travel to Whistler.\n\nThe earliest date of symptom onset was 22 Feb 2011 in a Whistler\nresident, and while cases continue to reside predominantly in the\nWhistler region, increasing numbers of cases in surrounding cities,\nincluding Vancouver and Richmond, have been reported. Several of these\nrecent cases have no known links to Whistler; though many are\nclustered among the same household or social network.\n\nThe disease is primarily affecting young adults; the median age of\nall cases is 27.0 years (age range: 1-54 years), and 54 cases (60.0\nper cent) are male.\n\nTransmission among initial Whistler-linked cases was primarily by\nsharing marijuana joints, cigarettes, drinks, and utensils.\n\nNearly 60 per cent of cases with links to Whistler are employed\neither by the mountain resort or in the hospitality and retail sector.\nThese sectors employ a largely seasonal workforce arising from many\ndifferent countries across the globe.\n\nClinical presentation:\nNearly all cases presented with unilateral or bilateral parotitis\n(97.8 per cent). 22 per cent of male cases presented with orchitis.\nOther symptoms included fever (58.9 per cent), myalgia (34.4 per\ncent), headache (24.4 per cent), pharyngitis (22.2 per cent),\narthralgia (7.8 per cent), fatigue (7.8 per cent), and nausea (5.6 per\ncent).\n\nIdentified cases have been encouraged to self-isolate for 9 days\nfollowing symptom onset.\n\nImmunization history:\nThe majority of cases have not received the 2 doses of\nmumps-containing vaccine needed for full protection. As Whistler hosts\na largely transient (and international) population, immunization\nhistories of residents vary greatly.\n\nIn our health region, most children and youth born between 1970 and\n1995 will not have had 2 doses of MMR, as the 2nd dose was not\nincluded in the routine immunization schedule for this age group. A\n2nd MMR at 18 months of age became part of routine infant immunization\nin 1996.\n\nGenotype:\n16 cases to date have been confirmed as Genotype G, a common genotype\nof mumps that was observed in several other recent North American\noutbreaks.\n\nPublic health response to date:\n- Notification has been given to all primary care providers and\nemergency physicians in the health region to be vigilant for patients\npresenting with swelling of the parotid gland, or other\nmumps-compatible illness.\n\n- Collection of laboratory specimens including blood for serology and\nbuccal swabs and/or urine for detection of mumps virus RNA.\n\n- Recommendation of 2 doses of mumps containing vaccine for all\nindividuals born on or after 1 Jan 1970. One dose is recommended for\nall individuals born between 1 Jan 1957 and 31 Dec 1969 who do not\nhave evidence of immunity to mumps.\n\n- Notification to all health jurisdictions across Canada through the\nCNPHI (Canadian Network for Public Health Intelligence) web platform.\n\n- Media advisory in Whistler (March and April 2011) on outbreak and\ninformation on where to access vaccine and messaging for those without\nhealth insurance.\n\n- Drop-in immunization clinics have been held at the Whistler Health\nCare Centre since March 2011.\n\n- A targeted immunization campaign was launched in Whistler to\ncoincide with the 10-day Telus Ski & Snowboard Festival (15-24 Apr\n2011), the largest annual winter sports and music festival in North\nAmerica. Over 600 doses of MMR were given to contacts of cases and\nindividuals who live and work in Whistler through vaccination at\nworksites and a drop-in clinic at a centrally located community\npharmacy. Approximately 50 per cent of those taking up vaccination\nwere overseas nationals of Australia, New Zealand, United Kingdom,\nSouth Africa, and smaller numbers from other European and Asian\ncountries.\n\nFurther planned public health response:\n- Continued messaging and immunization to target post-secondary\neducational institutions in the region with a particular focus on new\nstudents arriving in August 2011 for the start of the new academic\nyear.\n\n- Targeted immunization at staff orientations to be held by major\nemployers in the resort municipality of Whistler in anticipation of\nnew international staff arriving in the fall [2011].\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nPaul Martiquet MD\nMedical Health Officer\n\nReka Gustafson MD\nMedical Health Officer and Medical Director Communicable Disease\nControl\n\nEmily Laflamme MPH\nRegional Epidemiologist, Public Health Surveillance Unit\n\nJat Sandhu PhD\nRegional Director, Public Health Surveillance Unit\nOffice of the Chief Medical Health Officer\nVancouver Coastal Health Authority\n800 601 West Broadway\nVancouver, British Columbia\nCanada V5Z 4C2\nhttp:www.vch.ca\n<phsu@vch.ca>\n\n[Contact <phsu@vch.ca> at Vancouver Coastal Health Authority\nhttp:www.vch.ca for further information.\n\nFor the VCH Health Watch monthly public health bulletin (with map of\nregion), see\nhttp://www.vch.ca/your_health/disease_surveillance/health_watch/.\n\nSince the previous report, the number of confirmed cases of mumps\nvirus infection has increased from 77 to 90, indicating that the\noutbreak has not yet been contained. ProMED-mail thanks Dr Jat Sandu\nand colleagues for provision of this detailed account of the current\nsituation regarding the mumps outbreak centered on the Whistler resort\narea of British Columbia and the response of the local health\nauthority.\n\nA map of British Columbia, showing the locations of Whistler and\nVancouver, can be found at\nhttp://www.jnweb.com/british-columbia/map-bc.html. The\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Canada can be accessed at\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/007x. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nMumps - Canada (02): (BC) alert 20110622.1912\nMumps - Canada: (BC) 20110415.1188\n2008\n---\nMumps - Canada (05): (BC) 20080827.2683\nMumps - Canada (03): (BC) 20080615.1890\nMumps - Canada: (BC) 20080311.0983\n.................................................cp/msp/sh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "mumps", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2011-02-16 00:00:00", "2700-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-02-22 00:00:00", "1995-03-16 00:00:00", "1996-03-16 00:00:00", "1970-01-01 00:00:00", "1969-12-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-04-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-08-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Vancouver", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Whistler", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "British Columbia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Richmond", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "764567", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Canada (02): (BC) alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=764567", "date": "2010-08-16 14:00:03", "main_text": "MUMPS - ISRAEL (05): CORRECTION\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[This posting replaces ProMED-mail Mumps - Israel (05) 20100814.2799,\ndated 7 Aug 2010, in which item [1] is a text that should have been\ndiscarded following discussions with Israel's MOH.\n\nProMED-mail regrets the error. - Mods.AS/DK]\n\n******\n[1]\nDate: Sun 8 Aug 2010\nSource: a correspondent who has requested anonymity [edited]\n\n\nWith respect to the ongoing outbreak of mumps in Israel, it seems\nthat the disease has become more widely spread, apparently affecting\nadditional sectors of the population [see prior ProMED-mail posting\n'Mumps - Israel (04): Yeshiva students 20100723.2472']. As of 10 Jul\n2010 (the most recent available weekly epidemiological report), the\ntotal number of reported confirmed cases this year is 4185 (compared\nwith 6 confirmed cases during the same period last year - 2009).\nThere is spread of disease in kindergartens and elementary schools in\ncentral/coastal Israel, in addition to Jerusalem. This includes\nchildren who have been MMR vaccinated, as well as some of those duly\nboosted (with the Jeryl Lynn mumps vaccine) at the age of 6-8.\n\nGenotyping of the prevailing G5 virus strain, reportedly revealed a\nsingle nucleotide difference, initially in Jerusalem and later on in\nBnei-Brak. The possibility that this nucleotide difference has had\nany impact on vaccine efficacy in the country has been a matter for\n(inconclusive) discussion.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\na correspondent who has requested anonymity\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Mon 2 Aug 2010\nSource: Haaretz [edited]\n<http://www.haaretz.com/print-edition/news/west-nile-fever-hits-12-people-in-israel-leaving-one-dead-1.305379>\n\n\n[The following information is the last paragraph in a newswire on the\nWest Nile virus outbreak in Israel. - Mod.MPP]\n\nThe Ministry has also noted a rise in the incidence of mumps in\nrecent months, with 4190 cases since the beginning of the year\n[January 2010]. A ministry advisory committee has recommended a\nprogram of mumps vaccinations, particularly in areas where the\noutbreaks have occurred, notably in ultra-Orthodox communities.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following response to the 2 items above has been kindly provided\nby the Israeli Ministry of Health and is gratefully acknowledged:\n\n\"In January 2010 the Ministry of Health noted a rise in the incidence\nof mumps. A ministry advisory committee has recommended a program of\nmumps vaccinations, particularly in areas where the outbreaks have\noccurred, notably in ultra-Orthodox communities. In recent months\nincidence has decreased, but the outbreak is still ongoing after it\npeaked on April 2009, with a total of 4190 cases since the beginning\nof the year. It should be noted that the spread of the disease to the\ngeneral population is limited: case incidence is highest in the\nultra-orthodox community\". - Mods.AS/CP\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Israel can be accessed\nat <http://healthmap.org/r/00JC>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\nMumps - Israel (05) 20100814.2799\nMumps - Israel (04): Yeshiva students 20100723.2472\nMumps - Israel (03): (JM) RFI 20100126.0287\nMumps - Israel (02): Yeshiva students, 2009 20100123.0258\nMumps - Israel: Yeshiva students, 2009 20100106.0059\n2009\n----\nMumps - Israel (02) 20091120.3996\nMumps - Israel: Yeshiva students - RFI 20091119.3990\n...................................mpp/arn/cp/mj/mpp/arn/mj/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
