As of 10 Jul\n2010 (the most recent available weekly epidemiological report), the\ntotal number of reported confirmed cases this year is 4185 (compared\nwith 6 confirmed cases during the same period last year - 2009).\nThere is spread of disease in kindergartens and elementary schools in\ncentral/coastal Israel, in addition to Jerusalem. This includes\nchildren who have been MMR vaccinated, as well as some of those duly\nboosted (with the Jeryl Lynn mumps vaccine) at the age of 6-8.\n\nGenotyping of the prevailing G5 virus strain, reportedly revealed a\nsingle nucleotide difference, initially in Jerusalem and later on in\nBnei-Brak. The possibility that this nucleotide difference has had\nany impact on vaccine efficacy in the country has been a matter for\n(inconclusive) discussion.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\na correspondent who has requested anonymity\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Mon 2 Aug 2010\nSource: Haaretz [edited]\n<http://www.haaretz.com/print-edition/news/west-nile-fever-hits-12-people-in-israel-leaving-one-dead-1.305379>\n\n\n[The following information is the last paragraph in a newswire on the\nWest Nile virus outbreak in Israel. - Mod.MPP]\n\nThe Ministry has also noted a rise in the incidence of mumps in\nrecent months, with 4190 cases since the beginning of the year\n[January 2010]. A ministry advisory committee has recommended a\nprogram of mumps vaccinations, particularly in areas where the\noutbreaks have occurred, notably in ultra-Orthodox communities.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following response to the 2 items above has been kindly provided\nby the Israeli Ministry of Health and is gratefully acknowledged:\n\n\"In January 2010 the Ministry of Health noted a rise in the incidence\nof mumps. A ministry advisory committee has recommended a program of\nmumps vaccinations, particularly in areas where the outbreaks have\noccurred, notably in ultra-Orthodox communities. In recent months\nincidence has decreased, but the outbreak is still ongoing after it\npeaked on April 2009, with a total of 4190 cases since the beginning\nof the year. It should be noted that the spread of the disease to the\ngeneral population is limited: case incidence is highest in the\nultra-orthodox community\". - Mods.AS/CP\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Israel can be accessed\nat <http://healthmap.org/r/00JC>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\nMumps - Israel (05) 20100814.2799\nMumps - Israel (04): Yeshiva students 20100723.2472\nMumps - Israel (03): (JM) RFI 20100126.0287\nMumps - Israel (02): Yeshiva students, 2009 20100123.0258\nMumps - Israel: Yeshiva students, 2009 20100106.0059\n2009\n----\nMumps - Israel (02) 20091120.3996\nMumps - Israel: Yeshiva students - RFI 20091119.3990\n...................................mpp/arn/cp/mj/mpp/arn/mj/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. A ministry advisory committee has recommended a\nprogram of mumps vaccinations, particularly in areas where the\noutbreaks have occurred, notably in ultra-Orthodox communities.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following response to the 2 items above has been kindly provided\nby the Israeli Ministry of Health and is gratefully acknowledged:\n\n\"In January 2010 the Ministry of Health noted a rise in the incidence\nof mumps. A ministry advisory committee has recommended a program of\nmumps vaccinations, particularly in areas where the outbreaks have\noccurred, notably in ultra-Orthodox communities. In recent months\nincidence has decreased, but the outbreak is still ongoing after it\npeaked on April 2009, with a total of 4190 cases since the beginning\nof the year. It should be noted that the spread of the disease to the\ngeneral population is limited: case incidence is highest in the\nultra-orthodox community\". - Mods.AS/CP\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Israel can be accessed\nat <http://healthmap.org/r/00JC>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\nMumps - Israel (05) 20100814.2799\nMumps - Israel (04): Yeshiva students 20100723.2472\nMumps - Israel (03): (JM) RFI 20100126.0287\nMumps - Israel (02): Yeshiva students, 2009 20100123.0258\nMumps - Israel: Yeshiva students, 2009 20100106.0059\n2009\n----\nMumps - Israel (02) 20091120.3996\nMumps - Israel: Yeshiva students - RFI 20091119.3990\n...................................mpp/arn/cp/mj/mpp/arn/mj/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. As of 10 Jul\n2010 (the most recent available weekly epidemiological report), the\ntotal number of reported confirmed cases this year is 4185 (compared\nwith 6 confirmed cases during the same period last year - 2009).\nThere is spread of disease in kindergartens and elementary schools in\ncentral/coastal Israel, in addition to Jerusalem. This includes\nchildren who have been MMR vaccinated, as well as some of those duly\nboosted (with the Jeryl Lynn mumps vaccine) at the age of 6-8.\n\nGenotyping of the prevailing G5 virus strain, reportedly revealed a\nsingle nucleotide difference, initially in Jerusalem and later on in\nBnei-Brak. The possibility that this nucleotide difference has had\nany impact on vaccine efficacy in the country has been a matter for\n(inconclusive) discussion.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\na correspondent who has requested anonymity\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Mon 2 Aug 2010\nSource: Haaretz [edited]\n<http://www.haaretz.com/print-edition/news/west-nile-fever-hits-12-people-in-israel-leaving-one-dead-1.305379>\n\n\n[The following information is the last paragraph in a newswire on the\nWest Nile virus outbreak in Israel. - Mod.MPP]\n\nThe Ministry has also noted a rise in the incidence of mumps in\nrecent months, with 4190 cases since the beginning of the year\n[January 2010]. A ministry advisory committee has recommended a\nprogram of mumps vaccinations, particularly in areas where the\noutbreaks have occurred, notably in ultra-Orthodox communities.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following response to the 2 items above has been kindly provided\nby the Israeli Ministry of Health and is gratefully acknowledged:\n\n\"In January 2010 the Ministry of Health noted a rise in the incidence\nof mumps. As of 10 Jul\n2010 (the most recent available weekly epidemiological report), the\ntotal number of reported confirmed cases this year is 4185 (compared\nwith 6 confirmed cases during the same period last year - 2009).\nThere is spread of disease in kindergartens and elementary schools in\ncentral/coastal Israel, in addition to Jerusalem. This includes\nchildren who have been MMR vaccinated, as well as some of those duly\nboosted (with the Jeryl Lynn mumps vaccine) at the age of 6-8.\n\nGenotyping of the prevailing G5 virus strain, reportedly revealed a\nsingle nucleotide difference, initially in Jerusalem and later on in\nBnei-Brak. In recent months\nincidence has decreased, but the outbreak is still ongoing after it\npeaked on April 2009, with a total of 4190 cases since the beginning\nof the year. (17) [edited]\n\n\nGuam mumps outbreak update\n--------------------------\nAs of Mon 3 May 2010, there have been 142 confirmed or probable mumps cases\nrecorded on Guam as a result of the current ongoing outbreak, with 71\nadditional suspect cases still under investigation.\n\nOnly 2 cases have required hospitalization (both had co-morbidities) and\nthere have been no mumps-related deaths thus far.\n\n83 per cent of confirmed and probable cases have been in children under 18\nyears of age, the highest number of cases (44) occurring in the age group\n11-13.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nAlice E Hadley, MLS, AHIP(D)\n<Alice.Hadley@med.navy.mil>\n\n[The mumps epidemic continues to spread. The number of confirmed or\nprobable cases of mumps on the island of Guam has increased to more than a\n142 cases from the 5 cases reported initially on 25 Mar 2010.\n\nThe majority of cases have been children, which is unexpected since Guam\nlaw requires all students entering school to submit proof of immunization\nthat includes 2 doses of the measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) vaccine. It\nmay be that the mumps component of the MMR vaccine is less immunogenic that\nthe measles and rubella components and 2 doses are not sufficient to\nprovide complete protection. Alternatively perhaps the law is not being\nenforced.\n\nGuam is located in the western north Pacific Ocean, and is the largest and\nsouthernmost island in the Mariana Islands archipelago. A map of Guam can\nbe accessed at\n<http://www.picresorts.com/en/Guam/Background/Map-Of-Guam.jpg>. The\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Guam is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/01gu>. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nMumps - Guam (02) 20100424.1322\nMumps - Guam: school children 20100328.0976\n\n.................cp/mj/sh\n\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The number of confirmed or\nprobable cases of mumps on the island of Guam has increased to more than a\n142 cases from the 5 cases reported initially on 25 Mar 2010.\n\nThe majority of cases have been children, which is unexpected since Guam\nlaw requires all students entering school to submit proof of immunization\nthat includes 2 doses of the measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) vaccine. It\nmay be that the mumps component of the MMR vaccine is less immunogenic that\nthe measles and rubella components and 2 doses are not sufficient to\nprovide complete protection. Alternatively perhaps the law is not being\nenforced.\n\nGuam is located in the western north Pacific Ocean, and is the largest and\nsouthernmost island in the Mariana Islands archipelago. A map of Guam can\nbe accessed at\n<http://www.picresorts.com/en/Guam/Background/Map-Of-Guam.jpg>. The\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Guam is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/01gu>. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nMumps - Guam (02) 20100424.1322\nMumps - Guam: school children 20100328.0976\n\n.................cp/mj/sh\n\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The number of confirmed or\nprobable cases of mumps on the island of Guam has increased to more than a\n142 cases from the 5 cases reported initially on 25 Mar 2010.\n\nThe majority of cases have been children, which is unexpected since Guam\nlaw requires all students entering school to submit proof of immunization\nthat includes 2 doses of the measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) vaccine. It\nmay be that the mumps component of the MMR vaccine is less immunogenic that\nthe measles and rubella components and 2 doses are not sufficient to\nprovide complete protection. Alternatively perhaps the law is not being\nenforced.\n\nGuam is located in the western north Pacific Ocean, and is the largest and\nsouthernmost island in the Mariana Islands archipelago. A map of Guam can\nbe accessed at\n<http://www.picresorts.com/en/Guam/Background/Map-Of-Guam.jpg>. The number of confirmed or\nprobable cases of mumps on the island of Guam has increased to more than a\n142 cases from the 5 cases reported initially on 25 Mar 2010.\n\nThe majority of cases have been children, which is unexpected since Guam\nlaw requires all students entering school to submit proof of immunization\nthat includes 2 doses of the measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) vaccine. It\nmay be that the mumps component of the MMR vaccine is less immunogenic that\nthe measles and rubella components and 2 doses are not sufficient to\nprovide complete protection. Alternatively perhaps the law is not being\nenforced.\n\nGuam is located in the western north Pacific Ocean, and is the largest and\nsouthernmost island in the Mariana Islands archipelago. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-05-03 00:00:00", "2044-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-11-13 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Guam", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "422521", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Guam (03)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=422521", "date": "2010-05-06 16:00:10", "main_text": "MUMPS - GUAM (03)\n*****************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 6 May 2010\nSource: Guam Epidemiology Newsletter 2010; (17) [edited]\n\n\nGuam mumps outbreak update\n--------------------------\nAs of Mon 3 May 2010, there have been 142 confirmed or probable mumps cases\nrecorded on Guam as a result of the current ongoing outbreak, with 71\nadditional suspect cases still under investigation.\n\nOnly 2 cases have required hospitalization (both had co-morbidities) and\nthere have been no mumps-related deaths thus far.\n\n83 per cent of confirmed and probable cases have been in children under 18\nyears of age, the highest number of cases (44) occurring in the age group\n11-13.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nAlice E Hadley, MLS, AHIP(D)\n<Alice.Hadley@med.navy.mil>\n\n[The mumps epidemic continues to spread. The number of confirmed or\nprobable cases of mumps on the island of Guam has increased to more than a\n142 cases from the 5 cases reported initially on 25 Mar 2010.\n\nThe majority of cases have been children, which is unexpected since Guam\nlaw requires all students entering school to submit proof of immunization\nthat includes 2 doses of the measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) vaccine. It\nmay be that the mumps component of the MMR vaccine is less immunogenic that\nthe measles and rubella components and 2 doses are not sufficient to\nprovide complete protection. Alternatively perhaps the law is not being\nenforced.\n\nGuam is located in the western north Pacific Ocean, and is the largest and\nsouthernmost island in the Mariana Islands archipelago. A map of Guam can\nbe accessed at\n<http://www.picresorts.com/en/Guam/Background/Map-Of-Guam.jpg>. The\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Guam is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/01gu>. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nMumps - Guam (02) 20100424.1322\nMumps - Guam: school children 20100328.0976\n\n.................cp/mj/sh\n\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-05-03 00:00:00", "2044-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-11-13 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Guam", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "420197", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (08): (NC) ex UK", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=420197", "date": "2010-02-26 23:50:00", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (04)\n****************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 25 Feb 2010\nSource: The Pediatric SuperSite [edited]\n<http://www.pediatricsupersite.com/view.aspx?rid=61325>\n\n\nACIP discusses factors leading to mumps outbreak in the north east\n------------------------------------------------------------------\nThe number of cases linked to a June [2009] mumps outbreak at a New York\nsummer camp has climbed to 2336, CDC [Centers for Disease Control and\nPrevention] officials reported during the Advisory Committee on\nImmunization Practices [ACIP] meeting this week [24-25 Feb 2010]. After\ninitial spread into other populations throughout the state and areas of New\nJersey, CDC epidemiologist Kathleen Gallagher said the disease has now been\nexported to Connecticut, Quebec, and Israel.\n\nIncidence remains highest among boys in the Hasidic community because they\nusually spend longer hours at private schools, Gallagher said, mostly\naround other people belonging to this population. In addition to day\nstudents, these schools also board students from a variety of other regions\nand states. Therefore, boys potentially exposed to mumps may inadvertently\nspread the disease among other communities when they return home for\nholidays, emphasizing the importance of up-to-date, 2-dose vaccinations in\nthis age group.\n\nThe potential for a 3-dose measles, mumps, and rubella vaccine (MMR II,\nMerck) was also a focal point at the meeting. Currently, officials in\nOrange County, New York have tried administering a 3rd dose to children in\nefforts to control the outbreak. Although little data are available,\nGallagher said studies to evaluate the efficacy of a 3-dose vaccine regimen\nare ongoing.\n\nAdditional discussion addressed the genotype responsible for the outbreak,\nas well as the current vaccine's ability to effectively prevent the spread\nof disease. Officials have identified genotype G from the United Kingdom,\nwhich was also present in the 2006 mumps outbreak, as the culprit for the\ncurrent outbreak. Gallagher noted that there was \"nothing special\" about\ngenotype G, and the MMR vaccine may [induce] antibodies to this strain.\n\nNevertheless, other committee members said the mumps component of the MMRV\n[measles, mumps, rubella, varicella] has always been less effective than\nthe measles and rubella components, and some attributed this to the strain\ncontained in the vaccine. \"It's a complex situation that we have, but as\nI've said to my colleagues from Merck, we do need a better mumps strain\nthan we currently have,\" Stanley A Plotkin, MD, of Sanofi-Pasteur, said.\n\"Even though we have a number of [mumps strains], none of them are perfect.\"\n\n[byline: Melissa Foster]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The number of cases in this outbreak has increased from the 1521 reported\non 29 Jan 2010 to the current figure of 2336. This outbreak is still far\nfrom contained and now has spread in the USA to the state of Connecticut,\nas well as to Quebec, Canada, and Israel.\n\nThe mumps component of the current MMR triple vaccine may be less effective\nthan the other components of the triple vaccine. The potential value of\ngiving 3 doses of MMR vaccine was discussed at the ACIP meeting, in efforts\nto control the outbreak. Results are awaited. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nMumps - USA (03): (NY, NJ) 20100211.0481\nMumps - USA (02): NYC 20100210.0462\nMumps - USA: (NY) 20100209.0436\n2009\n---\nMumps - USA (07): (NY) 20091220.4297\nMumps - USA (06): (NY,NJ,CT) alert 20091219.4289\nMumps - USA (NY, NJ), Canada (QC) 20091113.3934\nMumps - USA (04): (NY) 20091106.3835\nMumps - USA (03): (NY) 20091023.3655\n\n.................cp/mj/sh\n\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. After\ninitial spread into other populations throughout the state and areas of New\nJersey, CDC epidemiologist Kathleen Gallagher said the disease has now been\nexported to Connecticut, Quebec, and Israel.\n\nIncidence remains highest among boys in the Hasidic community because they\nusually spend longer hours at private schools, Gallagher said, mostly\naround other people belonging to this population. In addition to day\nstudents, these schools also board students from a variety of other regions\nand states. Therefore, boys potentially exposed to mumps may inadvertently\nspread the disease among other communities when they return home for\nholidays, emphasizing the importance of up-to-date, 2-dose vaccinations in\nthis age group.\n\nThe potential for a 3-dose measles, mumps, and rubella vaccine (MMR II,\nMerck) was also a focal point at the meeting. Although little data are available,\nGallagher said studies to evaluate the efficacy of a 3-dose vaccine regimen\nare ongoing.\n\nAdditional discussion addressed the genotype responsible for the outbreak,\nas well as the current vaccine's ability to effectively prevent the spread\nof disease. Officials have identified genotype G from the United Kingdom,\nwhich was also present in the 2006 mumps outbreak, as the culprit for the\ncurrent outbreak. Gallagher noted that there was \"nothing special\" about\ngenotype G, and the MMR vaccine may [induce] antibodies to this strain.\n\nNevertheless, other committee members said the mumps component of the MMRV\n[measles, mumps, rubella, varicella] has always been less effective than\nthe measles and rubella components, and some attributed this to the strain\ncontained in the vaccine. \"It's a complex situation that we have, but as\nI've said to my colleagues from Merck, we do need a better mumps strain\nthan we currently have,\" Stanley A Plotkin, MD, of Sanofi-Pasteur, said.\n\"Even though we have a number of [mumps strains], none of them are perfect.\"\n\n[byline: Melissa Foster]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The number of cases in this outbreak has increased from the 1521 reported\non 29 Jan 2010 to the current figure of 2336. After\ninitial spread into other populations throughout the state and areas of New\nJersey, CDC epidemiologist Kathleen Gallagher said the disease has now been\nexported to Connecticut, Quebec, and Israel.\n\nIncidence remains highest among boys in the Hasidic community because they\nusually spend longer hours at private schools, Gallagher said, mostly\naround other people belonging to this population. In addition to day\nstudents, these schools also board students from a variety of other regions\nand states. Therefore, boys potentially exposed to mumps may inadvertently\nspread the disease among other communities when they return home for\nholidays, emphasizing the importance of up-to-date, 2-dose vaccinations in\nthis age group.\n\nThe potential for a 3-dose measles, mumps, and rubella vaccine (MMR II,\nMerck) was also a focal point at the meeting. Currently, officials in\nOrange County, New York have tried administering a 3rd dose to children in\nefforts to control the outbreak. Although little data are available,\nGallagher said studies to evaluate the efficacy of a 3-dose vaccine regimen\nare ongoing.\n\nAdditional discussion addressed the genotype responsible for the outbreak,\nas well as the current vaccine's ability to effectively prevent the spread\nof disease. Officials have identified genotype G from the United Kingdom,\nwhich was also present in the 2006 mumps outbreak, as the culprit for the\ncurrent outbreak. Gallagher noted that there was \"nothing special\" about\ngenotype G, and the MMR vaccine may [induce] antibodies to this strain.\n\nNevertheless, other committee members said the mumps component of the MMRV\n[measles, mumps, rubella, varicella] has always been less effective than\nthe measles and rubella components, and some attributed this to the strain\ncontained in the vaccine. \"It's a complex situation that we have, but as\nI've said to my colleagues from Merck, we do need a better mumps strain\nthan we currently have,\" Stanley A Plotkin, MD, of Sanofi-Pasteur, said.\n\"Even though we have a number of [mumps strains], none of them are perfect.\"\n\n[byline: Melissa Foster]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The number of cases in this outbreak has increased from the 1521 reported\non 29 Jan 2010 to the current figure of 2336. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella", "varicella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2010-02-25 00:00:00", "2021-06-16 00:00:00", "2336-03-16 00:00:00", "2024-02-25 20:10:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "1521-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-01-29 00:00:00", "2336-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "QC", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "New \n Jersey", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Quebec", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Orange County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Connecticut", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "the United Kingdom", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "Israel", "country": "Israel"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "406034", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (06): (NY, PA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=406034", "date": "2010-02-26 23:50:00", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (04)\n****************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 25 Feb 2010\nSource: The Pediatric SuperSite [edited]\n<http://www.pediatricsupersite.com/view.aspx?rid=61325>\n\n\nACIP discusses factors leading to mumps outbreak in the north east\n------------------------------------------------------------------\nThe number of cases linked to a June [2009] mumps outbreak at a New York\nsummer camp has climbed to 2336, CDC [Centers for Disease Control and\nPrevention] officials reported during the Advisory Committee on\nImmunization Practices [ACIP] meeting this week [24-25 Feb 2010]. After\ninitial spread into other populations throughout the state and areas of New\nJersey, CDC epidemiologist Kathleen Gallagher said the disease has now been\nexported to Connecticut, Quebec, and Israel.\n\nIncidence remains highest among boys in the Hasidic community because they\nusually spend longer hours at private schools, Gallagher said, mostly\naround other people belonging to this population. In addition to day\nstudents, these schools also board students from a variety of other regions\nand states. Therefore, boys potentially exposed to mumps may inadvertently\nspread the disease among other communities when they return home for\nholidays, emphasizing the importance of up-to-date, 2-dose vaccinations in\nthis age group.\n\nThe potential for a 3-dose measles, mumps, and rubella vaccine (MMR II,\nMerck) was also a focal point at the meeting. Currently, officials in\nOrange County, New York have tried administering a 3rd dose to children in\nefforts to control the outbreak. Although little data are available,\nGallagher said studies to evaluate the efficacy of a 3-dose vaccine regimen\nare ongoing.\n\nAdditional discussion addressed the genotype responsible for the outbreak,\nas well as the current vaccine's ability to effectively prevent the spread\nof disease. Officials have identified genotype G from the United Kingdom,\nwhich was also present in the 2006 mumps outbreak, as the culprit for the\ncurrent outbreak. Gallagher noted that there was \"nothing special\" about\ngenotype G, and the MMR vaccine may [induce] antibodies to this strain.\n\nNevertheless, other committee members said the mumps component of the MMRV\n[measles, mumps, rubella, varicella] has always been less effective than\nthe measles and rubella components, and some attributed this to the strain\ncontained in the vaccine. \"It's a complex situation that we have, but as\nI've said to my colleagues from Merck, we do need a better mumps strain\nthan we currently have,\" Stanley A Plotkin, MD, of Sanofi-Pasteur, said.\n\"Even though we have a number of [mumps strains], none of them are perfect.\"\n\n[byline: Melissa Foster]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The number of cases in this outbreak has increased from the 1521 reported\non 29 Jan 2010 to the current figure of 2336. This outbreak is still far\nfrom contained and now has spread in the USA to the state of Connecticut,\nas well as to Quebec, Canada, and Israel.\n\nThe mumps component of the current MMR triple vaccine may be less effective\nthan the other components of the triple vaccine. The potential value of\ngiving 3 doses of MMR vaccine was discussed at the ACIP meeting, in efforts\nto control the outbreak. Results are awaited. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nMumps - USA (03): (NY, NJ) 20100211.0481\nMumps - USA (02): NYC 20100210.0462\nMumps - USA: (NY) 20100209.0436\n2009\n---\nMumps - USA (07): (NY) 20091220.4297\nMumps - USA (06): (NY,NJ,CT) alert 20091219.4289\nMumps - USA (NY, NJ), Canada (QC) 20091113.3934\nMumps - USA (04): (NY) 20091106.3835\nMumps - USA (03): (NY) 20091023.3655\n\n.................cp/mj/sh\n\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella", "varicella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2010-02-25 00:00:00", "2021-06-16 00:00:00", "2336-03-16 00:00:00", "2024-02-25 20:10:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "1521-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-01-29 00:00:00", "2336-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "QC", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "New \n Jersey", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Quebec", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Orange County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Connecticut", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "the United Kingdom", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "Israel", "country": "Israel"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "379854", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (03): (NY, NJ)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=379854", "date": "2009-12-19 19:00:04", "main_text": "MUMPS - UNITED STATES OF AMERICA (06): (NEW YORK, NEW JERSEY, CONNECTICUT)\nALERT\n********************************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n******\n[1]\nDate: Fri 18 Dec 2009\nSource: myfox.com, New York [edited]\n<http://www.myfoxny.com/dpp/health/091218-brooklyn-mumps-outbreak-continues>\n\n\nBrooklyn mumps outbreak continues\n---------------------------------\nA mumps outbreak in Brooklyn that has lasted for months has prompted health\nofficials to issue a multistate mumps outbreak alert, warning health care\nproviders in New York, New Jersey, and Connecticut to be aware of the\nproblem. New York City is dealing with nearly 600 confirmed and suspected\ncases. Most of the patients have one thing in common: religion. The cases\nstarted turning up in late August [2009].\n\nMumps is an illness characterized by acute swelling of the salivary gland\nlasting 2 or more days. The illness can cause deafness and encephalitis. A\nperson can be infected for 2 days before symptoms appear. The health\ndepartment is telling people who suspect they have mumps to stay home for 5\ndays. Children who are not fully vaccinated against mumps are the highest\nrisk of infection.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Sat 19 Dec 2009\nSource: The Jewish Week [edited]\n<http://www.thejewishweek.com/viewArticle/c36_a17351/News/New_York.html>\n\n\nNot immune from mumps\n---------------------\nStemming from an initial mumps outbreak that wreaked havoc at a Jewish camp\nthis summer [summer of 2009], 247 New York City residents plus 131 other\nstate residents [as of 1 Dec 2009] have since contracted the disease, which\nremains mostly contained among fervently Orthodox adolescent boys in\npockets of New York, New Jersey, and Quebec, according to official reports\nfrom the New York City and State Departments of Health.\n\nThe trigger case occurred back in June [2009], when an 11 year old boy\nreturned to his Sullivan County summer camp after traveling in the United\nKingdom, where an ongoing outbreak has now reached about 4000 cases [see\n<http://www.hpa.org.uk/hpr/infections/immunisation.htm>, the Centers for\nDisease Control and Prevention (CDC) reported. From there, the mumps spread\nto 24 other boys at the camp and continued to plague their local\ncommunities when they returned home, and the median age of patients remains\naround 14.\n\nBut perhaps the most frustrating news to some parents is that most of the\naffected patients had received their proper 2-dose vaccination as children\n-- 83 per cent, according to CDC.\n\n\"This is a very confusing issue not only for ourselves but for providers\nand parents,\" said Cindy Schulte, vaccine-preventable disease surveillance\nofficer at the New York State Department of Health. \"If you have a\npopulation that's fairly well but unevenly vaccinated, by logic, you're\ngoing to end up having some disease in the effective population.\" The\nmeasles, mumps and rubella (MMR) vaccine has an 85 to 91 per cent efficacy\nrate among those who take the proper doses, she said.\n\nThe commonest symptoms of this viral disease are fever, muscle aches, and\nparotitis -- the signature inflammation of the salivary glands below the\near. Though no deaths have occurred thus far and symptoms may often be\nsubtle, there have been several hospitalizations and one potential case of\nmeningoencephalitis (inflammation of the brain), according to Dr Debra\nBlog, medical director at the Bureau of Immunization Program in the New\nYork State Department of Health.\n\nMumps can be particularly dangerous to pubescent boys, doctors say, because\na small number will develop orchitis, a swelling of the testicles that can\npotentially (though rarely) lead to infertility. The same goes for girls,\nwho can develop swelling of the ovaries that can lead to sterility. While\nmumps cases among women have certainly increased since the summer, New York\nCity infections remain around 79 per cent male, Blog explained.\n\n\"These communities tend to have social contact with themselves and tend to\nbe a bit isolated from the outside community,\" she said. \"In New York City\nespecially it's going through their schools.\"\n\nAs of 30 Oct 2009, CDC had only reported a total of 179 cases in New York\nand New Jersey and another 15 in Canada, but New York City health officials\nsay that the numbers have increased so dramatically in the past month\nsimply because doctors are taking more care to report their ill patients to\nthe government.\n\n\"We're still getting cases reported virtually every day,\" said Dr Chris\nZimmerman, medical director at the Bureau of Immunization in the New York\nCity Department of Health and Mental Hygiene. \"There was a substantial\nincrease just from the week before the alert to when the alert came out.\"\nIt is difficult to maintain an exact number of cases, Schulte added,\nbecause disease spread is a \"fluid number\".\n\nA mumps outbreak of this size has not occurred since 2006, when the United\nStates experienced over 6500 cases that were particularly hard-hitting\namong college dormitory residents in Iowa. But the current wave largely\nremains within pocketed chasidic communities, all linked back to that one\nsummer camp flare-up. \"There have been less than a handful of cases outside\nthe community,\" Zimmerman said. \"The population is segregated -- these kids\nare not going to public schools, they're going to yeshivas,\" he continued.\n\"They only have the opportunity to interact with other boys in their\ncommunity.\"\n\nAnd while statistics show that an overwhelming majority of the kids in\nthese neighborhoods are in fact properly vaccinated, the few outliers are\nprobably the ones perpetuating the disease spread, he added. \"Overall,\nimmunization coverage is good, but this is a community that has had\nresistance to MMR vaccines -- their parents have claimed religious\nexemptions,\" Zimmerman said.\n\nYet despite outbreaks that have resurfaced from time to time, state medical\nofficials still maintain the mumps vaccine is a successful product,\nparticularly in what Blog calls \"evenly vaccinated communities\" -- those\nwho pretty much unanimously undergo the immunization.\n\nRegarding the disease spread, another crucial element worth considering\namong the allegedly vaccinated patients is whether or not their dosages\nwere properly refrigerated speculated Dr Michael Augenbraun, a professor of\nepidemiology at Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn. \"Breaks in the 'cold\nchain' are a serious problem for vaccine efficacy if, for example, an\noffice allowed for a vaccine to sit out on countertops overnight,\"\nAugenbraun said, noting that we have no way of knowing this after so many\nyears, however.\n\nThus far, despite the one hospitalization and some cases of orchitis,\ncomplications from this outbreak have generally been minimal. About 56 per\ncent of the confirmed cases exhibited the parotitis, according to Schulte.\n\"We're not seeing the same rate of complications that we saw in the\npre-vaccine era,\" Zimmerman said, noting that before the vaccine, another\ndangerous side effect of the mumps was permanent deafness. But the subtle\nnature of so many of these current cases may be yet another reason that the\ndisease is spreading, because parents neglect to see a doctor about their\nchildren's illnesses. So what can parents do to protect their families from\ncatching the mumps?\n\nThey should make sure that their children have received the 2 dosages of\nthe vaccine on time, ideally before their 1st birthday, Schulte said. If an\nolder child has not yet received the vaccine but hasn't yet been exposed to\nthe illness, this child too should be immunized. And if a child or adult\nbecomes sick, the best thing to do, as always, is to stay home from school\nor work, wash hands frequently and see a doctor. Blog added, \"Isolation and\nvaccination are the most effective things along with common sense.\"\n\n[byline: Sharon Udasin]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is now a very large outbreak in a population that is considered to be\nwell vaccinated. This is perhaps a consequence of maintenance of an\nimported infection in a sub-set of the population which has declined\nvaccination on the basis of religious convictions. Additionally, or\nalternatively, it may reflect an inherent lower immunogencity of the mumps\nvirus component of the triple MMR vaccine.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the United States of America\ncan be accessed at <http://healthmap.org/r/009V>. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nMumps - USA (NY, NJ), Canada (QC) 20091113.3934\nMumps - USA (04): (NY) 20091106.3835\nMumps - USA (03): (NY) 20091023.3655\nMumps - USA (02): (MA), students 20090917.3265\nMumps: USA (MA); UK (Scotland) 20090419.1482\nMumps - USA: (MA) ex Ireland 20090417.1455\n\n....................cp/ejp/sh\n\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "plague", "rubella", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-06-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "NEW JERSEY", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "QC", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "CONNECTICUT", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Quebec", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brooklyn", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sullivan County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "New York City", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Iowa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NEW YORK", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "the United States of America", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Connecticut", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "United", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "New Jersey", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "379294", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "plague", "rubella", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-06-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "NEW JERSEY", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "QC", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "CONNECTICUT", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Quebec", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brooklyn", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sullivan County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "New York City", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Iowa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NEW YORK", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "the United States of America", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Connecticut", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "United", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "New Jersey", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "378646", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA: (NY)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=378646", "date": "2009-12-19 19:00:04", "main_text": "MUMPS - UNITED STATES OF AMERICA (06): (NEW YORK, NEW JERSEY, CONNECTICUT)\nALERT\n********************************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n******\n[1]\nDate: Fri 18 Dec 2009\nSource: myfox.com, New York [edited]\n<http://www.myfoxny.com/dpp/health/091218-brooklyn-mumps-outbreak-continues>\n\n\nBrooklyn mumps outbreak continues\n---------------------------------\nA mumps outbreak in Brooklyn that has lasted for months has prompted health\nofficials to issue a multistate mumps outbreak alert, warning health care\nproviders in New York, New Jersey, and Connecticut to be aware of the\nproblem. The same goes for girls,\nwho can develop swelling of the ovaries that can lead to sterility. While\nmumps cases among women have certainly increased since the summer, New York\nCity infections remain around 79 per cent male, Blog explained.\n\n\"These communities tend to have social contact with themselves and tend to\nbe a bit isolated from the outside community,\" she said. \"In New York City\nespecially it's going through their schools.\"\n\nAs of 30 Oct 2009, CDC had only reported a total of 179 cases in New York\nand New Jersey and another 15 in Canada, but New York City health officials\nsay that the numbers have increased so dramatically in the past month\nsimply because doctors are taking more care to report their ill patients to\nthe government.\n\n\"We're still getting cases reported virtually every day,\" said Dr Chris\nZimmerman, medical director at the Bureau of Immunization in the New York\nCity Department of Health and Mental Hygiene. \"There was a substantial\nincrease just from the week before the alert to when the alert came out.\"\nIt is difficult to maintain an exact number of cases, Schulte added,\nbecause disease spread is a \"fluid number\".\n\nA mumps outbreak of this size has not occurred since 2006, when the United\nStates experienced over 6500 cases that were particularly hard-hitting\namong college dormitory residents in Iowa. But the current wave largely\nremains within pocketed chasidic communities, all linked back to that one\nsummer camp flare-up. \"There have been less than a handful of cases outside\nthe community,\" Zimmerman said. \"The population is segregated -- these kids\nare not going to public schools, they're going to yeshivas,\" he continued.\n\"They only have the opportunity to interact with other boys in their\ncommunity.\"\n\nAnd while statistics show that an overwhelming majority of the kids in\nthese neighborhoods are in fact properly vaccinated, the few outliers are\nprobably the ones perpetuating the disease spread, he added. \"Overall,\nimmunization coverage is good, but this is a community that has had\nresistance to MMR vaccines -- their parents have claimed religious\nexemptions,\" Zimmerman said.\n\nYet despite outbreaks that have resurfaced from time to time, state medical\nofficials still maintain the mumps vaccine is a successful product,\nparticularly in what Blog calls \"evenly vaccinated communities\" -- those\nwho pretty much unanimously undergo the immunization.\n\nRegarding the disease spread, another crucial element worth considering\namong the allegedly vaccinated patients is whether or not their dosages\nwere properly refrigerated speculated Dr Michael Augenbraun, a professor of\nepidemiology at Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn. \"Breaks in the 'cold\nchain' are a serious problem for vaccine efficacy if, for example, an\noffice allowed for a vaccine to sit out on countertops overnight,\"\nAugenbraun said, noting that we have no way of knowing this after so many\nyears, however.\n\nThus far, despite the one hospitalization and some cases of orchitis,\ncomplications from this outbreak have generally been minimal. About 56 per\ncent of the confirmed cases exhibited the parotitis, according to Schulte.\n\"We're not seeing the same rate of complications that we saw in the\npre-vaccine era,\" Zimmerman said, noting that before the vaccine, another\ndangerous side effect of the mumps was permanent deafness. But the subtle\nnature of so many of these current cases may be yet another reason that the\ndisease is spreading, because parents neglect to see a doctor about their\nchildren's illnesses. So what can parents do to protect their families from\ncatching the mumps?\n\nThey should make sure that their children have received the 2 dosages of\nthe vaccine on time, ideally before their 1st birthday, Schulte said. If an\nolder child has not yet received the vaccine but hasn't yet been exposed to\nthe illness, this child too should be immunized. And if a child or adult\nbecomes sick, the best thing to do, as always, is to stay home from school\nor work, wash hands frequently and see a doctor. Blog added, \"Isolation and\nvaccination are the most effective things along with common sense.\"\n\n[byline: Sharon Udasin]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is now a very large outbreak in a population that is considered to be\nwell vaccinated. This is perhaps a consequence of maintenance of an\nimported infection in a sub-set of the population which has declined\nvaccination on the basis of religious convictions. Additionally, or\nalternatively, it may reflect an inherent lower immunogencity of the mumps\nvirus component of the triple MMR vaccine.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the United States of America\ncan be accessed at <http://healthmap.org/r/009V>. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nMumps - USA (NY, NJ), Canada (QC) 20091113.3934\nMumps - USA (04): (NY) 20091106.3835\nMumps - USA (03): (NY) 20091023.3655\nMumps - USA (02): (MA), students 20090917.3265\nMumps: USA (MA); UK (Scotland) 20090419.1482\nMumps - USA: (MA) ex Ireland 20090417.1455\n\n....................cp/ejp/sh\n\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "plague", "rubella", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-06-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "NEW JERSEY", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "QC", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "CONNECTICUT", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Quebec", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brooklyn", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sullivan County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "New York City", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Iowa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NEW YORK", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "the United States of America", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Connecticut", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "United", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "New Jersey", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "371331", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Israel (03): (JM) RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=371331", "date": "2009-12-19 19:00:04", "main_text": "MUMPS - UNITED STATES OF AMERICA (06): (NEW YORK, NEW JERSEY, CONNECTICUT)\nALERT\n********************************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n******\n[1]\nDate: Fri 18 Dec 2009\nSource: myfox.com, New York [edited]\n<http://www.myfoxny.com/dpp/health/091218-brooklyn-mumps-outbreak-continues>\n\n\nBrooklyn mumps outbreak continues\n---------------------------------\nA mumps outbreak in Brooklyn that has lasted for months has prompted health\nofficials to issue a multistate mumps outbreak alert, warning health care\nproviders in New York, New Jersey, and Connecticut to be aware of the\nproblem. New York City is dealing with nearly 600 confirmed and suspected\ncases. Most of the patients have one thing in common: religion. The cases\nstarted turning up in late August [2009].\n\nMumps is an illness characterized by acute swelling of the salivary gland\nlasting 2 or more days. The illness can cause deafness and encephalitis. A\nperson can be infected for 2 days before symptoms appear. The health\ndepartment is telling people who suspect they have mumps to stay home for 5\ndays. Children who are not fully vaccinated against mumps are the highest\nrisk of infection.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Sat 19 Dec 2009\nSource: The Jewish Week [edited]\n<http://www.thejewishweek.com/viewArticle/c36_a17351/News/New_York.html>\n\n\nNot immune from mumps\n---------------------\nStemming from an initial mumps outbreak that wreaked havoc at a Jewish camp\nthis summer [summer of 2009], 247 New York City residents plus 131 other\nstate residents [as of 1 Dec 2009] have since contracted the disease, which\nremains mostly contained among fervently Orthodox adolescent boys in\npockets of New York, New Jersey, and Quebec, according to official reports\nfrom the New York City and State Departments of Health.\n\nThe trigger case occurred back in June [2009], when an 11 year old boy\nreturned to his Sullivan County summer camp after traveling in the United\nKingdom, where an ongoing outbreak has now reached about 4000 cases [see\n<http://www.hpa.org.uk/hpr/infections/immunisation.htm>, the Centers for\nDisease Control and Prevention (CDC) reported. From there, the mumps spread\nto 24 other boys at the camp and continued to plague their local\ncommunities when they returned home, and the median age of patients remains\naround 14.\n\nBut perhaps the most frustrating news to some parents is that most of the\naffected patients had received their proper 2-dose vaccination as children\n-- 83 per cent, according to CDC.\n\n\"This is a very confusing issue not only for ourselves but for providers\nand parents,\" said Cindy Schulte, vaccine-preventable disease surveillance\nofficer at the New York State Department of Health. \"If you have a\npopulation that's fairly well but unevenly vaccinated, by logic, you're\ngoing to end up having some disease in the effective population.\" The\nmeasles, mumps and rubella (MMR) vaccine has an 85 to 91 per cent efficacy\nrate among those who take the proper doses, she said.\n\nThe commonest symptoms of this viral disease are fever, muscle aches, and\nparotitis -- the signature inflammation of the salivary glands below the\near. Though no deaths have occurred thus far and symptoms may often be\nsubtle, there have been several hospitalizations and one potential case of\nmeningoencephalitis (inflammation of the brain), according to Dr Debra\nBlog, medical director at the Bureau of Immunization Program in the New\nYork State Department of Health.\n\nMumps can be particularly dangerous to pubescent boys, doctors say, because\na small number will develop orchitis, a swelling of the testicles that can\npotentially (though rarely) lead to infertility. The same goes for girls,\nwho can develop swelling of the ovaries that can lead to sterility. While\nmumps cases among women have certainly increased since the summer, New York\nCity infections remain around 79 per cent male, Blog explained.\n\n\"These communities tend to have social contact with themselves and tend to\nbe a bit isolated from the outside community,\" she said. \"In New York City\nespecially it's going through their schools.\"\n\nAs of 30 Oct 2009, CDC had only reported a total of 179 cases in New York\nand New Jersey and another 15 in Canada, but New York City health officials\nsay that the numbers have increased so dramatically in the past month\nsimply because doctors are taking more care to report their ill patients to\nthe government.\n\n\"We're still getting cases reported virtually every day,\" said Dr Chris\nZimmerman, medical director at the Bureau of Immunization in the New York\nCity Department of Health and Mental Hygiene. \"There was a substantial\nincrease just from the week before the alert to when the alert came out.\"\nIt is difficult to maintain an exact number of cases, Schulte added,\nbecause disease spread is a \"fluid number\".\n\nA mumps outbreak of this size has not occurred since 2006, when the United\nStates experienced over 6500 cases that were particularly hard-hitting\namong college dormitory residents in Iowa. But the current wave largely\nremains within pocketed chasidic communities, all linked back to that one\nsummer camp flare-up. \"There have been less than a handful of cases outside\nthe community,\" Zimmerman said. \"The population is segregated -- these kids\nare not going to public schools, they're going to yeshivas,\" he continued.\n\"They only have the opportunity to interact with other boys in their\ncommunity.\"\n\nAnd while statistics show that an overwhelming majority of the kids in\nthese neighborhoods are in fact properly vaccinated, the few outliers are\nprobably the ones perpetuating the disease spread, he added. \"Overall,\nimmunization coverage is good, but this is a community that has had\nresistance to MMR vaccines -- their parents have claimed religious\nexemptions,\" Zimmerman said.\n\nYet despite outbreaks that have resurfaced from time to time, state medical\nofficials still maintain the mumps vaccine is a successful product,\nparticularly in what Blog calls \"evenly vaccinated communities\" -- those\nwho pretty much unanimously undergo the immunization.\n\nRegarding the disease spread, another crucial element worth considering\namong the allegedly vaccinated patients is whether or not their dosages\nwere properly refrigerated speculated Dr Michael Augenbraun, a professor of\nepidemiology at Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn. \"Breaks in the 'cold\nchain' are a serious problem for vaccine efficacy if, for example, an\noffice allowed for a vaccine to sit out on countertops overnight,\"\nAugenbraun said, noting that we have no way of knowing this after so many\nyears, however.\n\nThus far, despite the one hospitalization and some cases of orchitis,\ncomplications from this outbreak have generally been minimal. About 56 per\ncent of the confirmed cases exhibited the parotitis, according to Schulte.\n\"We're not seeing the same rate of complications that we saw in the\npre-vaccine era,\" Zimmerman said, noting that before the vaccine, another\ndangerous side effect of the mumps was permanent deafness. But the subtle\nnature of so many of these current cases may be yet another reason that the\ndisease is spreading, because parents neglect to see a doctor about their\nchildren's illnesses. So what can parents do to protect their families from\ncatching the mumps?\n\nThey should make sure that their children have received the 2 dosages of\nthe vaccine on time, ideally before their 1st birthday, Schulte said. If an\nolder child has not yet received the vaccine but hasn't yet been exposed to\nthe illness, this child too should be immunized. And if a child or adult\nbecomes sick, the best thing to do, as always, is to stay home from school\nor work, wash hands frequently and see a doctor. Blog added, \"Isolation and\nvaccination are the most effective things along with common sense.\"\n\n[byline: Sharon Udasin]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is now a very large outbreak in a population that is considered to be\nwell vaccinated. This is perhaps a consequence of maintenance of an\nimported infection in a sub-set of the population which has declined\nvaccination on the basis of religious convictions. Additionally, or\nalternatively, it may reflect an inherent lower immunogencity of the mumps\nvirus component of the triple MMR vaccine.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the United States of America\ncan be accessed at <http://healthmap.org/r/009V>. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nMumps - USA (NY, NJ), Canada (QC) 20091113.3934\nMumps - USA (04): (NY) 20091106.3835\nMumps - USA (03): (NY) 20091023.3655\nMumps - USA (02): (MA), students 20090917.3265\nMumps: USA (MA); UK (Scotland) 20090419.1482\nMumps - USA: (MA) ex Ireland 20090417.1455\n\n....................cp/ejp/sh\n\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "plague", "rubella", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-06-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "NEW JERSEY", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "QC", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "CONNECTICUT", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Quebec", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brooklyn", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sullivan County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "New York City", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Iowa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NEW YORK", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "the United States of America", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Connecticut", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "United", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "New Jersey", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "370574", "headline": "PRO> Mumps - Israel (02): Yeshiva students, 2009", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=370574", "date": "2009-12-19 19:00:04", "main_text": "MUMPS - UNITED STATES OF AMERICA (06): (NEW YORK, NEW JERSEY, CONNECTICUT)\nALERT\n********************************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n******\n[1]\nDate: Fri 18 Dec 2009\nSource: myfox.com, New York [edited]\n<http://www.myfoxny.com/dpp/health/091218-brooklyn-mumps-outbreak-continues>\n\n\nBrooklyn mumps outbreak continues\n---------------------------------\nA mumps outbreak in Brooklyn that has lasted for months has prompted health\nofficials to issue a multistate mumps outbreak alert, warning health care\nproviders in New York, New Jersey, and Connecticut to be aware of the\nproblem. New York City is dealing with nearly 600 confirmed and suspected\ncases. Most of the patients have one thing in common: religion. The cases\nstarted turning up in late August [2009].\n\nMumps is an illness characterized by acute swelling of the salivary gland\nlasting 2 or more days. The illness can cause deafness and encephalitis. A\nperson can be infected for 2 days before symptoms appear. The health\ndepartment is telling people who suspect they have mumps to stay home for 5\ndays. Children who are not fully vaccinated against mumps are the highest\nrisk of infection.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Sat 19 Dec 2009\nSource: The Jewish Week [edited]\n<http://www.thejewishweek.com/viewArticle/c36_a17351/News/New_York.html>\n\n\nNot immune from mumps\n---------------------\nStemming from an initial mumps outbreak that wreaked havoc at a Jewish camp\nthis summer [summer of 2009], 247 New York City residents plus 131 other\nstate residents [as of 1 Dec 2009] have since contracted the disease, which\nremains mostly contained among fervently Orthodox adolescent boys in\npockets of New York, New Jersey, and Quebec, according to official reports\nfrom the New York City and State Departments of Health.\n\nThe trigger case occurred back in June [2009], when an 11 year old boy\nreturned to his Sullivan County summer camp after traveling in the United\nKingdom, where an ongoing outbreak has now reached about 4000 cases [see\n<http://www.hpa.org.uk/hpr/infections/immunisation.htm>, the Centers for\nDisease Control and Prevention (CDC) reported. From there, the mumps spread\nto 24 other boys at the camp and continued to plague their local\ncommunities when they returned home, and the median age of patients remains\naround 14.\n\nBut perhaps the most frustrating news to some parents is that most of the\naffected patients had received their proper 2-dose vaccination as children\n-- 83 per cent, according to CDC.\n\n\"This is a very confusing issue not only for ourselves but for providers\nand parents,\" said Cindy Schulte, vaccine-preventable disease surveillance\nofficer at the New York State Department of Health. \"If you have a\npopulation that's fairly well but unevenly vaccinated, by logic, you're\ngoing to end up having some disease in the effective population.\" The\nmeasles, mumps and rubella (MMR) vaccine has an 85 to 91 per cent efficacy\nrate among those who take the proper doses, she said.\n\nThe commonest symptoms of this viral disease are fever, muscle aches, and\nparotitis -- the signature inflammation of the salivary glands below the\near. Though no deaths have occurred thus far and symptoms may often be\nsubtle, there have been several hospitalizations and one potential case of\nmeningoencephalitis (inflammation of the brain), according to Dr Debra\nBlog, medical director at the Bureau of Immunization Program in the New\nYork State Department of Health.\n\nMumps can be particularly dangerous to pubescent boys, doctors say, because\na small number will develop orchitis, a swelling of the testicles that can\npotentially (though rarely) lead to infertility. The same goes for girls,\nwho can develop swelling of the ovaries that can lead to sterility. While\nmumps cases among women have certainly increased since the summer, New York\nCity infections remain around 79 per cent male, Blog explained.\n\n\"These communities tend to have social contact with themselves and tend to\nbe a bit isolated from the outside community,\" she said. \"In New York City\nespecially it's going through their schools.\"\n\nAs of 30 Oct 2009, CDC had only reported a total of 179 cases in New York\nand New Jersey and another 15 in Canada, but New York City health officials\nsay that the numbers have increased so dramatically in the past month\nsimply because doctors are taking more care to report their ill patients to\nthe government.\n\n\"We're still getting cases reported virtually every day,\" said Dr Chris\nZimmerman, medical director at the Bureau of Immunization in the New York\nCity Department of Health and Mental Hygiene. \"There was a substantial\nincrease just from the week before the alert to when the alert came out.\"\nIt is difficult to maintain an exact number of cases, Schulte added,\nbecause disease spread is a \"fluid number\".\n\nA mumps outbreak of this size has not occurred since 2006, when the United\nStates experienced over 6500 cases that were particularly hard-hitting\namong college dormitory residents in Iowa. But the current wave largely\nremains within pocketed chasidic communities, all linked back to that one\nsummer camp flare-up. \"There have been less than a handful of cases outside\nthe community,\" Zimmerman said. \"The population is segregated -- these kids\nare not going to public schools, they're going to yeshivas,\" he continued.\n\"They only have the opportunity to interact with other boys in their\ncommunity.\"\n\nAnd while statistics show that an overwhelming majority of the kids in\nthese neighborhoods are in fact properly vaccinated, the few outliers are\nprobably the ones perpetuating the disease spread, he added. \"Overall,\nimmunization coverage is good, but this is a community that has had\nresistance to MMR vaccines -- their parents have claimed religious\nexemptions,\" Zimmerman said.\n\nYet despite outbreaks that have resurfaced from time to time, state medical\nofficials still maintain the mumps vaccine is a successful product,\nparticularly in what Blog calls \"evenly vaccinated communities\" -- those\nwho pretty much unanimously undergo the immunization.\n\nRegarding the disease spread, another crucial element worth considering\namong the allegedly vaccinated patients is whether or not their dosages\nwere properly refrigerated speculated Dr Michael Augenbraun, a professor of\nepidemiology at Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn. \"Breaks in the 'cold\nchain' are a serious problem for vaccine efficacy if, for example, an\noffice allowed for a vaccine to sit out on countertops overnight,\"\nAugenbraun said, noting that we have no way of knowing this after so many\nyears, however.\n\nThus far, despite the one hospitalization and some cases of orchitis,\ncomplications from this outbreak have generally been minimal. About 56 per\ncent of the confirmed cases exhibited the parotitis, according to Schulte.\n\"We're not seeing the same rate of complications that we saw in the\npre-vaccine era,\" Zimmerman said, noting that before the vaccine, another\ndangerous side effect of the mumps was permanent deafness. But the subtle\nnature of so many of these current cases may be yet another reason that the\ndisease is spreading, because parents neglect to see a doctor about their\nchildren's illnesses. So what can parents do to protect their families from\ncatching the mumps?\n\nThey should make sure that their children have received the 2 dosages of\nthe vaccine on time, ideally before their 1st birthday, Schulte said. If an\nolder child has not yet received the vaccine but hasn't yet been exposed to\nthe illness, this child too should be immunized. And if a child or adult\nbecomes sick, the best thing to do, as always, is to stay home from school\nor work, wash hands frequently and see a doctor. Blog added, \"Isolation and\nvaccination are the most effective things along with common sense.\"\n\n[byline: Sharon Udasin]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is now a very large outbreak in a population that is considered to be\nwell vaccinated.
