If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "plague", "rubella", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-06-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "NEW JERSEY", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "QC", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "CONNECTICUT", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Quebec", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brooklyn", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sullivan County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "New York City", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Iowa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NEW YORK", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "the United States of America", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Connecticut", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "United", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "New Jersey", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "360999", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Israel: Yeshiva students, 2009", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=360999", "date": "2009-12-19 19:00:04", "main_text": "MUMPS - UNITED STATES OF AMERICA (06): (NEW YORK, NEW JERSEY, CONNECTICUT)\nALERT\n********************************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n******\n[1]\nDate: Fri 18 Dec 2009\nSource: myfox.com, New York [edited]\n<http://www.myfoxny.com/dpp/health/091218-brooklyn-mumps-outbreak-continues>\n\n\nBrooklyn mumps outbreak continues\n---------------------------------\nA mumps outbreak in Brooklyn that has lasted for months has prompted health\nofficials to issue a multistate mumps outbreak alert, warning health care\nproviders in New York, New Jersey, and Connecticut to be aware of the\nproblem. New York City is dealing with nearly 600 confirmed and suspected\ncases. Most of the patients have one thing in common: religion. The cases\nstarted turning up in late August [2009].\n\nMumps is an illness characterized by acute swelling of the salivary gland\nlasting 2 or more days. The illness can cause deafness and encephalitis. A\nperson can be infected for 2 days before symptoms appear. The health\ndepartment is telling people who suspect they have mumps to stay home for 5\ndays. Children who are not fully vaccinated against mumps are the highest\nrisk of infection.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Sat 19 Dec 2009\nSource: The Jewish Week [edited]\n<http://www.thejewishweek.com/viewArticle/c36_a17351/News/New_York.html>\n\n\nNot immune from mumps\n---------------------\nStemming from an initial mumps outbreak that wreaked havoc at a Jewish camp\nthis summer [summer of 2009], 247 New York City residents plus 131 other\nstate residents [as of 1 Dec 2009] have since contracted the disease, which\nremains mostly contained among fervently Orthodox adolescent boys in\npockets of New York, New Jersey, and Quebec, according to official reports\nfrom the New York City and State Departments of Health.\n\nThe trigger case occurred back in June [2009], when an 11 year old boy\nreturned to his Sullivan County summer camp after traveling in the United\nKingdom, where an ongoing outbreak has now reached about 4000 cases [see\n<http://www.hpa.org.uk/hpr/infections/immunisation.htm>, the Centers for\nDisease Control and Prevention (CDC) reported. From there, the mumps spread\nto 24 other boys at the camp and continued to plague their local\ncommunities when they returned home, and the median age of patients remains\naround 14.\n\nBut perhaps the most frustrating news to some parents is that most of the\naffected patients had received their proper 2-dose vaccination as children\n-- 83 per cent, according to CDC.\n\n\"This is a very confusing issue not only for ourselves but for providers\nand parents,\" said Cindy Schulte, vaccine-preventable disease surveillance\nofficer at the New York State Department of Health. \"If you have a\npopulation that's fairly well but unevenly vaccinated, by logic, you're\ngoing to end up having some disease in the effective population.\" The\nmeasles, mumps and rubella (MMR) vaccine has an 85 to 91 per cent efficacy\nrate among those who take the proper doses, she said.\n\nThe commonest symptoms of this viral disease are fever, muscle aches, and\nparotitis -- the signature inflammation of the salivary glands below the\near. Though no deaths have occurred thus far and symptoms may often be\nsubtle, there have been several hospitalizations and one potential case of\nmeningoencephalitis (inflammation of the brain), according to Dr Debra\nBlog, medical director at the Bureau of Immunization Program in the New\nYork State Department of Health.\n\nMumps can be particularly dangerous to pubescent boys, doctors say, because\na small number will develop orchitis, a swelling of the testicles that can\npotentially (though rarely) lead to infertility. The same goes for girls,\nwho can develop swelling of the ovaries that can lead to sterility. While\nmumps cases among women have certainly increased since the summer, New York\nCity infections remain around 79 per cent male, Blog explained.\n\n\"These communities tend to have social contact with themselves and tend to\nbe a bit isolated from the outside community,\" she said. \"In New York City\nespecially it's going through their schools.\"\n\nAs of 30 Oct 2009, CDC had only reported a total of 179 cases in New York\nand New Jersey and another 15 in Canada, but New York City health officials\nsay that the numbers have increased so dramatically in the past month\nsimply because doctors are taking more care to report their ill patients to\nthe government.\n\n\"We're still getting cases reported virtually every day,\" said Dr Chris\nZimmerman, medical director at the Bureau of Immunization in the New York\nCity Department of Health and Mental Hygiene. \"There was a substantial\nincrease just from the week before the alert to when the alert came out.\"\nIt is difficult to maintain an exact number of cases, Schulte added,\nbecause disease spread is a \"fluid number\".\n\nA mumps outbreak of this size has not occurred since 2006, when the United\nStates experienced over 6500 cases that were particularly hard-hitting\namong college dormitory residents in Iowa. But the current wave largely\nremains within pocketed chasidic communities, all linked back to that one\nsummer camp flare-up. \"There have been less than a handful of cases outside\nthe community,\" Zimmerman said. \"The population is segregated -- these kids\nare not going to public schools, they're going to yeshivas,\" he continued.\n\"They only have the opportunity to interact with other boys in their\ncommunity.\"\n\nAnd while statistics show that an overwhelming majority of the kids in\nthese neighborhoods are in fact properly vaccinated, the few outliers are\nprobably the ones perpetuating the disease spread, he added. \"Overall,\nimmunization coverage is good, but this is a community that has had\nresistance to MMR vaccines -- their parents have claimed religious\nexemptions,\" Zimmerman said.\n\nYet despite outbreaks that have resurfaced from time to time, state medical\nofficials still maintain the mumps vaccine is a successful product,\nparticularly in what Blog calls \"evenly vaccinated communities\" -- those\nwho pretty much unanimously undergo the immunization.\n\nRegarding the disease spread, another crucial element worth considering\namong the allegedly vaccinated patients is whether or not their dosages\nwere properly refrigerated speculated Dr Michael Augenbraun, a professor of\nepidemiology at Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn. \"Breaks in the 'cold\nchain' are a serious problem for vaccine efficacy if, for example, an\noffice allowed for a vaccine to sit out on countertops overnight,\"\nAugenbraun said, noting that we have no way of knowing this after so many\nyears, however.\n\nThus far, despite the one hospitalization and some cases of orchitis,\ncomplications from this outbreak have generally been minimal. About 56 per\ncent of the confirmed cases exhibited the parotitis, according to Schulte.\n\"We're not seeing the same rate of complications that we saw in the\npre-vaccine era,\" Zimmerman said, noting that before the vaccine, another\ndangerous side effect of the mumps was permanent deafness. But the subtle\nnature of so many of these current cases may be yet another reason that the\ndisease is spreading, because parents neglect to see a doctor about their\nchildren's illnesses. So what can parents do to protect their families from\ncatching the mumps?\n\nThey should make sure that their children have received the 2 dosages of\nthe vaccine on time, ideally before their 1st birthday, Schulte said. If an\nolder child has not yet received the vaccine but hasn't yet been exposed to\nthe illness, this child too should be immunized. And if a child or adult\nbecomes sick, the best thing to do, as always, is to stay home from school\nor work, wash hands frequently and see a doctor. Blog added, \"Isolation and\nvaccination are the most effective things along with common sense.\"\n\n[byline: Sharon Udasin]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is now a very large outbreak in a population that is considered to be\nwell vaccinated. This is perhaps a consequence of maintenance of an\nimported infection in a sub-set of the population which has declined\nvaccination on the basis of religious convictions. Additionally, or\nalternatively, it may reflect an inherent lower immunogencity of the mumps\nvirus component of the triple MMR vaccine.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the United States of America\ncan be accessed at <http://healthmap.org/r/009V>. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nMumps - USA (NY, NJ), Canada (QC) 20091113.3934\nMumps - USA (04): (NY) 20091106.3835\nMumps - USA (03): (NY) 20091023.3655\nMumps - USA (02): (MA), students 20090917.3265\nMumps: USA (MA); UK (Scotland) 20090419.1482\nMumps - USA: (MA) ex Ireland 20090417.1455\n\n....................cp/ejp/sh\n\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "plague", "rubella", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-06-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "NEW JERSEY", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "QC", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "CONNECTICUT", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Quebec", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brooklyn", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sullivan County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "New York City", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Iowa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NEW YORK", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "the United States of America", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Connecticut", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "United", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "New Jersey", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "353958", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "plague", "rubella", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-06-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "NEW JERSEY", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "QC", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "CONNECTICUT", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Quebec", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brooklyn", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sullivan County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "New York City", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Iowa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NEW YORK", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "the United States of America", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Connecticut", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "United", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "New Jersey", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "353691", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (06): (NY,NJ,CT) alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=353691", "date": "2009-12-19 19:00:04", "main_text": "MUMPS - UNITED STATES OF AMERICA (06): (NEW YORK, NEW JERSEY, CONNECTICUT)\nALERT\n********************************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n******\n[1]\nDate: Fri 18 Dec 2009\nSource: myfox.com, New York [edited]\n<http://www.myfoxny.com/dpp/health/091218-brooklyn-mumps-outbreak-continues>\n\n\nBrooklyn mumps outbreak continues\n---------------------------------\nA mumps outbreak in Brooklyn that has lasted for months has prompted health\nofficials to issue a multistate mumps outbreak alert, warning health care\nproviders in New York, New Jersey, and Connecticut to be aware of the\nproblem. Though no deaths have occurred thus far and symptoms may often be\nsubtle, there have been several hospitalizations and one potential case of\nmeningoencephalitis (inflammation of the brain), according to Dr Debra\nBlog, medical director at the Bureau of Immunization Program in the New\nYork State Department of Health.\n\nMumps can be particularly dangerous to pubescent boys, doctors say, because\na small number will develop orchitis, a swelling of the testicles that can\npotentially (though rarely) lead to infertility. The same goes for girls,\nwho can develop swelling of the ovaries that can lead to sterility. While\nmumps cases among women have certainly increased since the summer, New York\nCity infections remain around 79 per cent male, Blog explained.\n\n\"These communities tend to have social contact with themselves and tend to\nbe a bit isolated from the outside community,\" she said. \"In New York City\nespecially it's going through their schools.\"\n\nAs of 30 Oct 2009, CDC had only reported a total of 179 cases in New York\nand New Jersey and another 15 in Canada, but New York City health officials\nsay that the numbers have increased so dramatically in the past month\nsimply because doctors are taking more care to report their ill patients to\nthe government.\n\n\"We're still getting cases reported virtually every day,\" said Dr Chris\nZimmerman, medical director at the Bureau of Immunization in the New York\nCity Department of Health and Mental Hygiene. \"There was a substantial\nincrease just from the week before the alert to when the alert came out.\"\nIt is difficult to maintain an exact number of cases, Schulte added,\nbecause disease spread is a \"fluid number\".\n\nA mumps outbreak of this size has not occurred since 2006, when the United\nStates experienced over 6500 cases that were particularly hard-hitting\namong college dormitory residents in Iowa. But the current wave largely\nremains within pocketed chasidic communities, all linked back to that one\nsummer camp flare-up. \"There have been less than a handful of cases outside\nthe community,\" Zimmerman said. \"The population is segregated -- these kids\nare not going to public schools, they're going to yeshivas,\" he continued.\n\"They only have the opportunity to interact with other boys in their\ncommunity.\"\n\nAnd while statistics show that an overwhelming majority of the kids in\nthese neighborhoods are in fact properly vaccinated, the few outliers are\nprobably the ones perpetuating the disease spread, he added. \"Overall,\nimmunization coverage is good, but this is a community that has had\nresistance to MMR vaccines -- their parents have claimed religious\nexemptions,\" Zimmerman said.\n\nYet despite outbreaks that have resurfaced from time to time, state medical\nofficials still maintain the mumps vaccine is a successful product,\nparticularly in what Blog calls \"evenly vaccinated communities\" -- those\nwho pretty much unanimously undergo the immunization.\n\nRegarding the disease spread, another crucial element worth considering\namong the allegedly vaccinated patients is whether or not their dosages\nwere properly refrigerated speculated Dr Michael Augenbraun, a professor of\nepidemiology at Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn. \"Breaks in the 'cold\nchain' are a serious problem for vaccine efficacy if, for example, an\noffice allowed for a vaccine to sit out on countertops overnight,\"\nAugenbraun said, noting that we have no way of knowing this after so many\nyears, however.\n\nThus far, despite the one hospitalization and some cases of orchitis,\ncomplications from this outbreak have generally been minimal. About 56 per\ncent of the confirmed cases exhibited the parotitis, according to Schulte.\n\"We're not seeing the same rate of complications that we saw in the\npre-vaccine era,\" Zimmerman said, noting that before the vaccine, another\ndangerous side effect of the mumps was permanent deafness. But the subtle\nnature of so many of these current cases may be yet another reason that the\ndisease is spreading, because parents neglect to see a doctor about their\nchildren's illnesses. So what can parents do to protect their families from\ncatching the mumps?\n\nThey should make sure that their children have received the 2 dosages of\nthe vaccine on time, ideally before their 1st birthday, Schulte said. If an\nolder child has not yet received the vaccine but hasn't yet been exposed to\nthe illness, this child too should be immunized. And if a child or adult\nbecomes sick, the best thing to do, as always, is to stay home from school\nor work, wash hands frequently and see a doctor. Blog added, \"Isolation and\nvaccination are the most effective things along with common sense.\"\n\n[byline: Sharon Udasin]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is now a very large outbreak in a population that is considered to be\nwell vaccinated. This is perhaps a consequence of maintenance of an\nimported infection in a sub-set of the population which has declined\nvaccination on the basis of religious convictions. Additionally, or\nalternatively, it may reflect an inherent lower immunogencity of the mumps\nvirus component of the triple MMR vaccine.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the United States of America\ncan be accessed at <http://healthmap.org/r/009V>. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nMumps - USA (NY, NJ), Canada (QC) 20091113.3934\nMumps - USA (04): (NY) 20091106.3835\nMumps - USA (03): (NY) 20091023.3655\nMumps - USA (02): (MA), students 20090917.3265\nMumps: USA (MA); UK (Scotland) 20090419.1482\nMumps - USA: (MA) ex Ireland 20090417.1455\n\n....................cp/ejp/sh\n\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. UK (11): (England)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=352735", "date": "2009-10-23 19:00:03", "main_text": "MUMPS - UNITED STATES OF AMERICA (03): (NEW YORK)\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 23 Oct 2009\nSorce: All Headline News (AHN) [edited]\n<http://www.allheadlinenews.com/articles/7016779670>\n\n\nNew York Mumps Outbreak Strikes 57 People\n-----------------------------------------\nThe New York Department of Health has confirmed an outbreak of old\nfashioned mumps in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn where at\nleast 57 confirmed or probable cases have been reported since 21 Aug 2009.\n\nOfficials say the outbreak was traced back to a child who went to\nBritain, then attended summer camp in upper New York state and\ninfected fellow campers there who brought the disease back with them\nto Brooklyn where it has continued to spread. Most of the victims\nhave been between the ages of 10 to 15, but the youngest patient so\nfar was a 1-year-old, while the oldest victim was 42.\n\nHealth officials are puzzled over why it is spreading though. While\nvaccination rates are low in Britain, at least 75 percent of the\nBrooklyn victims had received the normal 2 doses of mumps vaccine.\nHowever, the vaccine only has a 90 percent effective rate.\n\nThere is no treatment for the disease that causes painful swelling of\nthe salivary glands. Mumps usually runs its course in about 10 days.\nComplications can lead to deafness or even death and was a childhood\nscourge until vaccination largely ended the disease in developed nations.\n\nMumps is spread by large respiratory droplets of the virus spread\nthrough coughs and sneezes.\n\n[Byline: Linda Young]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It is likely that this outbreak was initiated by a child (presumably\nunvaccinated) who had returned to New York from the United Kingdom\nwhere mumps infection is still widespread due to deficiencies vaccine\ncoverage (as documented by the ProMED-mail archived reports for 2009\nlisted below). Subsequent transmission of mumps infection in New York\nhas embraced 57 people ranging in age from 1 to 42 years. While it is\naccepted that the mumps component of the MMR vaccine is less\nimmunogenic than the other 2 components, and that 2 doses are\nrecommended, the large number of cases and the wide age range suggest\nthat there may be a higher proportion of unvaccinated individuals in\nthe Brooklyn area than elsewhere in the city. This may be a\nconsequence of negligence or avoidance of vaccination on grounds of\nreligious or other beliefs. - Mod.CP]\n\n[ProMED-mail would like to thank Dr. George Robertson for submitting\na similar article. - Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\nMumps - UK (10): (England) 20091014.3545\nMumps - USA (02): (MA), students 20090917.3265\nMumps - UK (09): (England) 20090704.2407\nMumps - UK (08): (England) 20090630.2370\nMumps, students - UK (07): (England, Wales) 20090524.1943\nMumps: USA (MA); UK (Scotland) 20090419.1482\nMumps - USA: (MA) ex Ireland 20090417.1455\nMumps, students - UK (06): (England, Wales) 20090410.1379\nMumps, students - UK (05): (ENG) 20090221.0728\nMumps - UK (04): (England, Wales) 20090212.0634\nMumps - UK (03): (England) 20090211.0619\nMumps - UK (02): (Wales) 20090206.0544\nMumps - UK (WALES) 20090130.0418\n..................mpp/cp/ejp/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Canada: (ON)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=349758", "date": "2009-10-23 19:00:03", "main_text": "MUMPS - UNITED STATES OF AMERICA (03): (NEW YORK)\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 23 Oct 2009\nSorce: All Headline News (AHN) [edited]\n<http://www.allheadlinenews.com/articles/7016779670>\n\n\nNew York Mumps Outbreak Strikes 57 People\n-----------------------------------------\nThe New York Department of Health has confirmed an outbreak of old\nfashioned mumps in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn where at\nleast 57 confirmed or probable cases have been reported since 21 Aug 2009.\n\nOfficials say the outbreak was traced back to a child who went to\nBritain, then attended summer camp in upper New York state and\ninfected fellow campers there who brought the disease back with them\nto Brooklyn where it has continued to spread. Most of the victims\nhave been between the ages of 10 to 15, but the youngest patient so\nfar was a 1-year-old, while the oldest victim was 42.\n\nHealth officials are puzzled over why it is spreading though. While\nvaccination rates are low in Britain, at least 75 percent of the\nBrooklyn victims had received the normal 2 doses of mumps vaccine.\nHowever, the vaccine only has a 90 percent effective rate.\n\nThere is no treatment for the disease that causes painful swelling of\nthe salivary glands. Mumps usually runs its course in about 10 days.\nComplications can lead to deafness or even death and was a childhood\nscourge until vaccination largely ended the disease in developed nations.\n\nMumps is spread by large respiratory droplets of the virus spread\nthrough coughs and sneezes.\n\n[Byline: Linda Young]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It is likely that this outbreak was initiated by a child (presumably\nunvaccinated) who had returned to New York from the United Kingdom\nwhere mumps infection is still widespread due to deficiencies vaccine\ncoverage (as documented by the ProMED-mail archived reports for 2009\nlisted below). Subsequent transmission of mumps infection in New York\nhas embraced 57 people ranging in age from 1 to 42 years. While it is\naccepted that the mumps component of the MMR vaccine is less\nimmunogenic than the other 2 components, and that 2 doses are\nrecommended, the large number of cases and the wide age range suggest\nthat there may be a higher proportion of unvaccinated individuals in\nthe Brooklyn area than elsewhere in the city. This may be a\nconsequence of negligence or avoidance of vaccination on grounds of\nreligious or other beliefs. - Mod.CP]\n\n[ProMED-mail would like to thank Dr. George Robertson for submitting\na similar article. - Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\nMumps - UK (10): (England) 20091014.3545\nMumps - USA (02): (MA), students 20090917.3265\nMumps - UK (09): (England) 20090704.2407\nMumps - UK (08): (England) 20090630.2370\nMumps, students - UK (07): (England, Wales) 20090524.1943\nMumps: USA (MA); UK (Scotland) 20090419.1482\nMumps - USA: (MA) ex Ireland 20090417.1455\nMumps, students - UK (06): (England, Wales) 20090410.1379\nMumps, students - UK (05): (ENG) 20090221.0728\nMumps - UK (04): (England, Wales) 20090212.0634\nMumps - UK (03): (England) 20090211.0619\nMumps - UK (02): (Wales) 20090206.0544\nMumps - UK (WALES) 20090130.0418\n..................mpp/cp/ejp/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Israel (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=336029", "date": "2009-10-23 19:00:03", "main_text": "MUMPS - UNITED STATES OF AMERICA (03): (NEW YORK)\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 23 Oct 2009\nSorce: All Headline News (AHN) [edited]\n<http://www.allheadlinenews.com/articles/7016779670>\n\n\nNew York Mumps Outbreak Strikes 57 People\n-----------------------------------------\nThe New York Department of Health has confirmed an outbreak of old\nfashioned mumps in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn where at\nleast 57 confirmed or probable cases have been reported since 21 Aug 2009.\n\nOfficials say the outbreak was traced back to a child who went to\nBritain, then attended summer camp in upper New York state and\ninfected fellow campers there who brought the disease back with them\nto Brooklyn where it has continued to spread. Most of the victims\nhave been between the ages of 10 to 15, but the youngest patient so\nfar was a 1-year-old, while the oldest victim was 42.\n\nHealth officials are puzzled over why it is spreading though. While\nvaccination rates are low in Britain, at least 75 percent of the\nBrooklyn victims had received the normal 2 doses of mumps vaccine.\nHowever, the vaccine only has a 90 percent effective rate.\n\nThere is no treatment for the disease that causes painful swelling of\nthe salivary glands. Mumps usually runs its course in about 10 days.\nComplications can lead to deafness or even death and was a childhood\nscourge until vaccination largely ended the disease in developed nations.\n\nMumps is spread by large respiratory droplets of the virus spread\nthrough coughs and sneezes.\n\n[Byline: Linda Young]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It is likely that this outbreak was initiated by a child (presumably\nunvaccinated) who had returned to New York from the United Kingdom\nwhere mumps infection is still widespread due to deficiencies vaccine\ncoverage (as documented by the ProMED-mail archived reports for 2009\nlisted below). Subsequent transmission of mumps infection in New York\nhas embraced 57 people ranging in age from 1 to 42 years. While it is\naccepted that the mumps component of the MMR vaccine is less\nimmunogenic than the other 2 components, and that 2 doses are\nrecommended, the large number of cases and the wide age range suggest\nthat there may be a higher proportion of unvaccinated individuals in\nthe Brooklyn area than elsewhere in the city. This may be a\nconsequence of negligence or avoidance of vaccination on grounds of\nreligious or other beliefs. - Mod.CP]\n\n[ProMED-mail would like to thank Dr. George Robertson for submitting\na similar article. - Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\nMumps - UK (10): (England) 20091014.3545\nMumps - USA (02): (MA), students 20090917.3265\nMumps - UK (09): (England) 20090704.2407\nMumps - UK (08): (England) 20090630.2370\nMumps, students - UK (07): (England, Wales) 20090524.1943\nMumps: USA (MA); UK (Scotland) 20090419.1482\nMumps - USA: (MA) ex Ireland 20090417.1455\nMumps, students - UK (06): (England, Wales) 20090410.1379\nMumps, students - UK (05): (ENG) 20090221.0728\nMumps - UK (04): (England, Wales) 20090212.0634\nMumps - UK (03): (England) 20090211.0619\nMumps - UK (02): (Wales) 20090206.0544\nMumps - UK (WALES) 20090130.0418\n..................mpp/cp/ejp/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "mumps"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-08-21 00:00:00", "2042-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Britain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Borough Park", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brooklyn", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "NEW YORK", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United Kingdom", "country": "United Kingdom"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "335300", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps, Yeshiva students - Israel, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=335300", "date": "2009-10-23 19:00:03", "main_text": "MUMPS - UNITED STATES OF AMERICA (03): (NEW YORK)\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 23 Oct 2009\nSorce: All Headline News (AHN) [edited]\n<http://www.allheadlinenews.com/articles/7016779670>\n\n\nNew York Mumps Outbreak Strikes 57 People\n-----------------------------------------\nThe New York Department of Health has confirmed an outbreak of old\nfashioned mumps in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn where at\nleast 57 confirmed or probable cases have been reported since 21 Aug 2009.\n\nOfficials say the outbreak was traced back to a child who went to\nBritain, then attended summer camp in upper New York state and\ninfected fellow campers there who brought the disease back with them\nto Brooklyn where it has continued to spread. Most of the victims\nhave been between the ages of 10 to 15, but the youngest patient so\nfar was a 1-year-old, while the oldest victim was 42.\n\nHealth officials are puzzled over why it is spreading though. While\nvaccination rates are low in Britain, at least 75 percent of the\nBrooklyn victims had received the normal 2 doses of mumps vaccine.\nHowever, the vaccine only has a 90 percent effective rate.\n\nThere is no treatment for the disease that causes painful swelling of\nthe salivary glands. Mumps usually runs its course in about 10 days.\nComplications can lead to deafness or even death and was a childhood\nscourge until vaccination largely ended the disease in developed nations.\n\nMumps is spread by large respiratory droplets of the virus spread\nthrough coughs and sneezes.\n\n[Byline: Linda Young]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It is likely that this outbreak was initiated by a child (presumably\nunvaccinated) who had returned to New York from the United Kingdom\nwhere mumps infection is still widespread due to deficiencies vaccine\ncoverage (as documented by the ProMED-mail archived reports for 2009\nlisted below). Subsequent transmission of mumps infection in New York\nhas embraced 57 people ranging in age from 1 to 42 years. While it is\naccepted that the mumps component of the MMR vaccine is less\nimmunogenic than the other 2 components, and that 2 doses are\nrecommended, the large number of cases and the wide age range suggest\nthat there may be a higher proportion of unvaccinated individuals in\nthe Brooklyn area than elsewhere in the city. This may be a\nconsequence of negligence or avoidance of vaccination on grounds of\nreligious or other beliefs. - Mod.CP]\n\n[ProMED-mail would like to thank Dr. George Robertson for submitting\na similar article. - Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\nMumps - UK (10): (England) 20091014.3545\nMumps - USA (02): (MA), students 20090917.3265\nMumps - UK (09): (England) 20090704.2407\nMumps - UK (08): (England) 20090630.2370\nMumps, students - UK (07): (England, Wales) 20090524.1943\nMumps: USA (MA); UK (Scotland) 20090419.1482\nMumps - USA: (MA) ex Ireland 20090417.1455\nMumps, students - UK (06): (England, Wales) 20090410.1379\nMumps, students - UK (05): (ENG) 20090221.0728\nMumps - UK (04): (England, Wales) 20090212.0634\nMumps - UK (03): (England) 20090211.0619\nMumps - UK (02): (Wales) 20090206.0544\nMumps - UK (WALES) 20090130.0418\n..................mpp/cp/ejp/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Israel: Yeshiva students - RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=336089", "date": "2009-10-23 19:00:03", "main_text": "MUMPS - UNITED STATES OF AMERICA (03): (NEW YORK)\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 23 Oct 2009\nSorce: All Headline News (AHN) [edited]\n<http://www.allheadlinenews.com/articles/7016779670>\n\n\nNew York Mumps Outbreak Strikes 57 People\n-----------------------------------------\nThe New York Department of Health has confirmed an outbreak of old\nfashioned mumps in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn where at\nleast 57 confirmed or probable cases have been reported since 21 Aug 2009.\n\nOfficials say the outbreak was traced back to a child who went to\nBritain, then attended summer camp in upper New York state and\ninfected fellow campers there who brought the disease back with them\nto Brooklyn where it has continued to spread. Most of the victims\nhave been between the ages of 10 to 15, but the youngest patient so\nfar was a 1-year-old, while the oldest victim was 42.\n\nHealth officials are puzzled over why it is spreading though. While\nvaccination rates are low in Britain, at least 75 percent of the\nBrooklyn victims had received the normal 2 doses of mumps vaccine.\nHowever, the vaccine only has a 90 percent effective rate.\n\nThere is no treatment for the disease that causes painful swelling of\nthe salivary glands. Mumps usually runs its course in about 10 days.\nComplications can lead to deafness or even death and was a childhood\nscourge until vaccination largely ended the disease in developed nations.\n\nMumps is spread by large respiratory droplets of the virus spread\nthrough coughs and sneezes.\n\n[Byline: Linda Young]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It is likely that this outbreak was initiated by a child (presumably\nunvaccinated) who had returned to New York from the United Kingdom\nwhere mumps infection is still widespread due to deficiencies vaccine\ncoverage (as documented by the ProMED-mail archived reports for 2009\nlisted below). Subsequent transmission of mumps infection in New York\nhas embraced 57 people ranging in age from 1 to 42 years. While it is\naccepted that the mumps component of the MMR vaccine is less\nimmunogenic than the other 2 components, and that 2 doses are\nrecommended, the large number of cases and the wide age range suggest\nthat there may be a higher proportion of unvaccinated individuals in\nthe Brooklyn area than elsewhere in the city. This may be a\nconsequence of negligence or avoidance of vaccination on grounds of\nreligious or other beliefs. - Mod.CP]\n\n[ProMED-mail would like to thank Dr. George Robertson for submitting\na similar article. - Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\nMumps - UK (10): (England) 20091014.3545\nMumps - USA (02): (MA), students 20090917.3265\nMumps - UK (09): (England) 20090704.2407\nMumps - UK (08): (England) 20090630.2370\nMumps, students - UK (07): (England, Wales) 20090524.1943\nMumps: USA (MA); UK (Scotland) 20090419.1482\nMumps - USA: (MA) ex Ireland 20090417.1455\nMumps, students - UK (06): (England, Wales) 20090410.1379\nMumps, students - UK (05): (ENG) 20090221.0728\nMumps - UK (04): (England, Wales) 20090212.0634\nMumps - UK (03): (England) 20090211.0619\nMumps - UK (02): (Wales) 20090206.0544\nMumps - UK (WALES) 20090130.0418\n..................mpp/cp/ejp/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. UK (10): (England)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=309502", "date": "2009-04-10 18:01:01", "main_text": "MUMPS, STUDENTS - UNITED KINGDOM (06): (ENGLAND, WALES)\n*******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org\n\n\nDate: Thu 9 Apr 2009\nSource: Health Protection Report, Volume 3, No 14, 2009 [edited]\n<http://www.hpa.org.uk/hpr/archives/2009/news1409.htm#mumps0809>\n\n\nContinued increase in mumps in universities 2008/2009\n-----------------------------------------------------\nAs reported previously [1], the number of mumps cases notified in\nEngland and Wales increased in early 2009 and has continued to\nincrease during March. Outbreaks have been reported from several\nuniversities and colleges. A similar increase has been reported from\nthe Republic of Ireland [2].\n\nA large epidemic of mumps affecting university students 1st occurred\nin the academic year 2004/5 [3] and continued into 2005/6, declining\nin 2006/7 and 2007/8. During the final quarter of 2008, 695 cases of\nmumps were confirmed compared to 447 in the previous quarter [4]. So\nfar in 2009, 998 cases of mumps with onset in January or February\nhave been confirmed mumps IgM or RNA positive in England and Wales.\nThis compares to 322, 274, and 1173 cases in the same periods of\n2008, 2007, and 2006 respectively. During 2009, cases have been\nconfirmed in all English regions and Wales with high numbers from the\nSouth West (204), South East (180), and North West (162) regions. For\nthe remaining regions the number of cases confirmed was as follows:\nYorkshire and Humberside (115), London (86), East of England (81),\nWest Midlands (64), East Midlands (48), North East (30), and Wales\n(27). The genotype currently circulating is a G5, the same strain\nthat has been circulating over the past 5 years and responsible for\noutbreaks in other parts of Europe [5,6].\n\n[These data are illustrated in the original text by a figure showing\nthe 5 week moving average of mumps notifications, England and Wales\n2003-2009. - Mod.CP]\n\nReason for the increase\n-----------------------\nThe previous epidemic was attributed to a cohort of young adults,\nborn between 1981 and 1990, who were at increased risk of mumps.\nThese individuals were born before the implementation of the routine\n2-dose MMR programme and had therefore either received no MMR\nvaccine, or only one dose. As control of mumps was excellent after\n1990, this group remained susceptible until they entered the\nuniversity or college setting, when transmission of mumps was\nfacilitated. During 2008, 1403 (57 percent) of the confirmed cases\nwere in those born between 1981 and 1990 . [Data illustrated by a\nfigure in the original text. - Mod.CP]\n\nDespite this clear picture, the reason why the numbers of cases have\nincreased in this academic year, after remaining lower in both 2006/7\nand 2007/8 is not entirely clear. One explanation may be that, since\nthe widespread transmission in 2005/6, 3 new cohorts of students have\nentered college and therefore another susceptible pool has been\nre-established in this setting.\n\nIn the previous epidemic, although the vaccinated cohorts were\nlargely protected from mumps, cases were confirmed in vaccinated\nindividuals. By the 2008/9 academic year, most students would have\nbeen eligible for one or 2 doses of MMR (measles, mumps, rubella),\nand so a higher proportion of vaccine failures are expected amongst\nthe cases. Initial reports are consistent with this observation.\n\nIn 2004-5, analysis of protection from vaccination showed that,\nalthough individual protection from vaccination was high, there was\nevidence of declining protection over time, particularly in those who\nhad only received one dose of vaccine [7]. Investigations during\nuniversity outbreaks in the United States, where vaccine coverage for\n2 doses has been in place for longer, also suggested that waning\nprotection may have contributed [8]. Secondary vaccine failure may\ntherefore also explain a proportion of cases.\n\nSurveillance and control\n------------------------\nContinued surveillance, including confirmation of the diagnosis, is\nimportant for ensuring accurate epidemiological data. In persons who\nhave been previously vaccinated, the serological diagnosis of mumps\ncan be difficult as the IgM response may be delayed and reach lower\nlevels. For rapid diagnosis, an oral fluid taken in the 1st 14 days\nof illness is preferred as this can be tested for both IgM\n(Immunoglobulin M) and viral RNA (ribonucleic acid). If this is not\npossible then parallel serum and throat swab or paired serum samples\ncan be collected.\n\nIn 2005 and 2006, the incident team for the national mumps outbreak\nrecommended that the priorities were to ensure that systems were in\nplace to ensure that those entering university were fully vaccinated\nwith MMR in the future. This included ensuring that pupils attending\nfor the Year 10 booster and university entrants from 2005 onwards had\nreceived 2 doses of MMR.\n\nThe team also concluded that university vaccination campaigns in\nparticular are likely to achieve low uptake and are unlikely to stop\noutbreaks. The offer of individual vaccination, however, should be\navailable to students who are unvaccinated or have received only one\ndose of MMR. Approaches being taken in individual universities this\nyear have included using text messaging and university computer\nnetworks to alert students to these recommendations.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. HPA. Mumps increase in university students, Health Protection\nReport [serial online] 2009; 3(10): News. Available at\n<http://www.hpa.org.uk/hpr/archives/2009/news1009.htm#mumps>.\n\n2. Continued increase in mumps cases in 2009. Health Protection\nSurveillance Centre (Republic of Ireland). [online] [10 March 2009]\n<http://www.hpsc.ie/hpsc/News/MainBody,3484,en.html>.\n\n3. Savage E, Ramsay M, White J, Beard S, Lawson H, Hunjan R, et al.\nMumps outbreaks across England and Wales in 2004: observational\nstudy. BMJ. 2005 14; 330(7500):1119-20.\n\n4. HPA. Laboratory confirmed cases of mumps, England and Wales:\nOctober to December 2008.Health Protection Report [serial online]\n2009;3(14)news.\n<http://www.hpa.org.uk/hpr/infections/immunisation.htm>.\n\n5. Cui A, Myers R, Xu W, Jin L. Analysis of the genetic variability\nof the mumps SH gene in viruses circulating in the UK between 1996\nand 2005. Infect Genet Evol. 2009; 9(1):71-80\n\n6. Mumps outbreak among the military in Luxembourg in 2008:\nepidemiology and evaluation of control measures. Mossong J, Bonert C,\nWeicherding P, Opp M, Reichert P, Even J, Schneider F.Euro Surveill\n[serial online] 2009 19; 14(7). pii: 19121\n\n7. Cohen C, White JM, Savage EJ, Glynn JR, Choi Y, Andrews N, et al.\nVaccine effectiveness estimates, 2004-2005 mumps outbreak, England.\nEmerg Infect Dis 2007 Jan;13(1):12-7.\n\n8. Date AA, Kyaw MH, Rue AM, Klahn J, Obrecht L, Krohn T, et al.\nLong-term persistence of mumps antibody after receipt of 2\nmeasles-mumps- rubella (MMR) vaccinations and antibody response after\na third MMR vaccination among a university population. J Infect Dis.\n2008 15;197(12): 1662-8.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The extent and intensity of the mumps epidemic in the current\nacademic year is surprising in view of the decline of mumps in\nuniversity students during both 2006/2007 and 2007/2008, subsequent to\nthe major outbreak in 2005/2006. As suggested above, it may be that\nsince 2005/2006 3 new cohorts of students have entered colleges and\nuniversities and established a new pool of susceptibles.\n\nEfforts to increase awareness of the risk of exposure to mumps\ninfection among university students must be continued. - Mod.CP]\n\n[Mumps in male college students may lead to orchitis (inflammation of\nthe testes) and sterility, a good selling point for taking the\nvaccine. - Mod.JW]\nSee Also\nMumps, students - UK (05): (ENG) 20090221.0728\nMumps - UK (04): (England, Wales) 20090212.0634\nMumps - UK (03): (England) 20090211.0619\nMumps - UK (02): (Wales) 20090206.0544\nMumps - UK (WALES) 20090130.0418\n2008\n----\nMumps, students - UK: (England) 20081108.3513\nMumps, students - UK: (London) 20080508.1575\n2004\n-----\nMumps, students - UK (02) 20041126.3166\nMumps, students - UK & Ireland (03) 20041117.3089\nMumps, students - UK & Ireland (02) 20041112.3055\nMumps, students - UK & Ireland 20041110.3039\nMumps, students - UK 20041103.2974\n2003\n----\nMumps, increase - UK (02) 20031123.2910\nMumps, increase - UK 20030524.1284\n2001\n----\nMumps, consequence of reduced MMRV uptake - UK (02) 20010831.2069\nMumps, consequence of reduced MMRV uptake 20010806.1858\n1999\n----\nMumps, imported - UK: RFI 19990223.0241\n...........................cp/ejp/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-06-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-01-16 00:00:00", "1173-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "1990-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-06-16 00:00:00", "2004-05-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-10 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "1662-08-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "North West", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Luxembourg", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "London", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "East midland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Republic of Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Opp M", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "293703", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (02): (MA), students", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=293703", "date": "2009-04-10 18:01:01", "main_text": "MUMPS, STUDENTS - UNITED KINGDOM (06): (ENGLAND, WALES)\n*******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org\n\n\nDate: Thu 9 Apr 2009\nSource: Health Protection Report, Volume 3, No 14, 2009 [edited]\n<http://www.hpa.org.uk/hpr/archives/2009/news1409.htm#mumps0809>\n\n\nContinued increase in mumps in universities 2008/2009\n-----------------------------------------------------\nAs reported previously [1], the number of mumps cases notified in\nEngland and Wales increased in early 2009 and has continued to\nincrease during March. Outbreaks have been reported from several\nuniversities and colleges. A similar increase has been reported from\nthe Republic of Ireland [2].\n\nA large epidemic of mumps affecting university students 1st occurred\nin the academic year 2004/5 [3] and continued into 2005/6, declining\nin 2006/7 and 2007/8. During the final quarter of 2008, 695 cases of\nmumps were confirmed compared to 447 in the previous quarter [4]. So\nfar in 2009, 998 cases of mumps with onset in January or February\nhave been confirmed mumps IgM or RNA positive in England and Wales.\nThis compares to 322, 274, and 1173 cases in the same periods of\n2008, 2007, and 2006 respectively. During 2009, cases have been\nconfirmed in all English regions and Wales with high numbers from the\nSouth West (204), South East (180), and North West (162) regions. For\nthe remaining regions the number of cases confirmed was as follows:\nYorkshire and Humberside (115), London (86), East of England (81),\nWest Midlands (64), East Midlands (48), North East (30), and Wales\n(27). The genotype currently circulating is a G5, the same strain\nthat has been circulating over the past 5 years and responsible for\noutbreaks in other parts of Europe [5,6].\n\n[These data are illustrated in the original text by a figure showing\nthe 5 week moving average of mumps notifications, England and Wales\n2003-2009. - Mod.CP]\n\nReason for the increase\n-----------------------\nThe previous epidemic was attributed to a cohort of young adults,\nborn between 1981 and 1990, who were at increased risk of mumps.\nThese individuals were born before the implementation of the routine\n2-dose MMR programme and had therefore either received no MMR\nvaccine, or only one dose. As control of mumps was excellent after\n1990, this group remained susceptible until they entered the\nuniversity or college setting, when transmission of mumps was\nfacilitated. During 2008, 1403 (57 percent) of the confirmed cases\nwere in those born between 1981 and 1990 . [Data illustrated by a\nfigure in the original text. - Mod.CP]\n\nDespite this clear picture, the reason why the numbers of cases have\nincreased in this academic year, after remaining lower in both 2006/7\nand 2007/8 is not entirely clear. One explanation may be that, since\nthe widespread transmission in 2005/6, 3 new cohorts of students have\nentered college and therefore another susceptible pool has been\nre-established in this setting.\n\nIn the previous epidemic, although the vaccinated cohorts were\nlargely protected from mumps, cases were confirmed in vaccinated\nindividuals. By the 2008/9 academic year, most students would have\nbeen eligible for one or 2 doses of MMR (measles, mumps, rubella),\nand so a higher proportion of vaccine failures are expected amongst\nthe cases. Initial reports are consistent with this observation.\n\nIn 2004-5, analysis of protection from vaccination showed that,\nalthough individual protection from vaccination was high, there was\nevidence of declining protection over time, particularly in those who\nhad only received one dose of vaccine [7]. Investigations during\nuniversity outbreaks in the United States, where vaccine coverage for\n2 doses has been in place for longer, also suggested that waning\nprotection may have contributed [8]. Secondary vaccine failure may\ntherefore also explain a proportion of cases.\n\nSurveillance and control\n------------------------\nContinued surveillance, including confirmation of the diagnosis, is\nimportant for ensuring accurate epidemiological data. In persons who\nhave been previously vaccinated, the serological diagnosis of mumps\ncan be difficult as the IgM response may be delayed and reach lower\nlevels. For rapid diagnosis, an oral fluid taken in the 1st 14 days\nof illness is preferred as this can be tested for both IgM\n(Immunoglobulin M) and viral RNA (ribonucleic acid). If this is not\npossible then parallel serum and throat swab or paired serum samples\ncan be collected.\n\nIn 2005 and 2006, the incident team for the national mumps outbreak\nrecommended that the priorities were to ensure that systems were in\nplace to ensure that those entering university were fully vaccinated\nwith MMR in the future. This included ensuring that pupils attending\nfor the Year 10 booster and university entrants from 2005 onwards had\nreceived 2 doses of MMR.\n\nThe team also concluded that university vaccination campaigns in\nparticular are likely to achieve low uptake and are unlikely to stop\noutbreaks. The offer of individual vaccination, however, should be\navailable to students who are unvaccinated or have received only one\ndose of MMR. Approaches being taken in individual universities this\nyear have included using text messaging and university computer\nnetworks to alert students to these recommendations.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. HPA. Mumps increase in university students, Health Protection\nReport [serial online] 2009; 3(10): News. Available at\n<http://www.hpa.org.uk/hpr/archives/2009/news1009.htm#mumps>.\n\n2. Continued increase in mumps cases in 2009. Health Protection\nSurveillance Centre (Republic of Ireland). [online] [10 March 2009]\n<http://www.hpsc.ie/hpsc/News/MainBody,3484,en.html>.\n\n3. Savage E, Ramsay M, White J, Beard S, Lawson H, Hunjan R, et al.\nMumps outbreaks across England and Wales in 2004: observational\nstudy. BMJ. 2005 14; 330(7500):1119-20.\n\n4. HPA. Laboratory confirmed cases of mumps, England and Wales:\nOctober to December 2008.Health Protection Report [serial online]\n2009;3(14)news.\n<http://www.hpa.org.uk/hpr/infections/immunisation.htm>.\n\n5. Cui A, Myers R, Xu W, Jin L. Analysis of the genetic variability\nof the mumps SH gene in viruses circulating in the UK between 1996\nand 2005. Infect Genet Evol. 2009; 9(1):71-80\n\n6. During 2008, 1403 (57 percent) of the confirmed cases\nwere in those born between 1981 and 1990 . [Data illustrated by a\nfigure in the original text. - Mod.CP]\n\nDespite this clear picture, the reason why the numbers of cases have\nincreased in this academic year, after remaining lower in both 2006/7\nand 2007/8 is not entirely clear. One explanation may be that, since\nthe widespread transmission in 2005/6, 3 new cohorts of students have\nentered college and therefore another susceptible pool has been\nre-established in this setting.\n\nIn the previous epidemic, although the vaccinated cohorts were\nlargely protected from mumps, cases were confirmed in vaccinated\nindividuals. By the 2008/9 academic year, most students would have\nbeen eligible for one or 2 doses of MMR (measles, mumps, rubella),\nand so a higher proportion of vaccine failures are expected amongst\nthe cases. Initial reports are consistent with this observation.\n\nIn 2004-5, analysis of protection from vaccination showed that,\nalthough individual protection from vaccination was high, there was\nevidence of declining protection over time, particularly in those who\nhad only received one dose of vaccine [7]. Investigations during\nuniversity outbreaks in the United States, where vaccine coverage for\n2 doses has been in place for longer, also suggested that waning\nprotection may have contributed [8]. Secondary vaccine failure may\ntherefore also explain a proportion of cases.\n\nSurveillance and control\n------------------------\nContinued surveillance, including confirmation of the diagnosis, is\nimportant for ensuring accurate epidemiological data. In persons who\nhave been previously vaccinated, the serological diagnosis of mumps\ncan be difficult as the IgM response may be delayed and reach lower\nlevels. For rapid diagnosis, an oral fluid taken in the 1st 14 days\nof illness is preferred as this can be tested for both IgM\n(Immunoglobulin M) and viral RNA (ribonucleic acid). If this is not\npossible then parallel serum and throat swab or paired serum samples\ncan be collected.\n\nIn 2005 and 2006, the incident team for the national mumps outbreak\nrecommended that the priorities were to ensure that systems were in\nplace to ensure that those entering university were fully vaccinated\nwith MMR in the future. This included ensuring that pupils attending\nfor the Year 10 booster and university entrants from 2005 onwards had\nreceived 2 doses of MMR.\n\nThe team also concluded that university vaccination campaigns in\nparticular are likely to achieve low uptake and are unlikely to stop\noutbreaks. The offer of individual vaccination, however, should be\navailable to students who are unvaccinated or have received only one\ndose of MMR. Approaches being taken in individual universities this\nyear have included using text messaging and university computer\nnetworks to alert students to these recommendations.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. HPA. Mumps increase in university students, Health Protection\nReport [serial online] 2009; 3(10): News. Available at\n<http://www.hpa.org.uk/hpr/archives/2009/news1009.htm#mumps>.\n\n2. Continued increase in mumps cases in 2009. Health Protection\nSurveillance Centre (Republic of Ireland). [online] [10 March 2009]\n<http://www.hpsc.ie/hpsc/News/MainBody,3484,en.html>.\n\n3. Savage E, Ramsay M, White J, Beard S, Lawson H, Hunjan R, et al.\nMumps outbreaks across England and Wales in 2004: observational\nstudy. BMJ. 2005 14; 330(7500):1119-20.\n\n4. HPA. Laboratory confirmed cases of mumps, England and Wales:\nOctober to December 2008.Health Protection Report [serial online]\n2009;3(14)news.\n<http://www.hpa.org.uk/hpr/infections/immunisation.htm>.\n\n5. Cui A, Myers R, Xu W, Jin L. Analysis of the genetic variability\nof the mumps SH gene in viruses circulating in the UK between 1996\nand 2005. Infect Genet Evol. 2009; 9(1):71-80\n\n6. Mumps outbreak among the military in Luxembourg in 2008:\nepidemiology and evaluation of control measures. Mossong J, Bonert C,\nWeicherding P, Opp M, Reichert P, Even J, Schneider F.Euro Surveill\n[serial online] 2009 19; 14(7). pii: 19121\n\n7. Cohen C, White JM, Savage EJ, Glynn JR, Choi Y, Andrews N, et al.\nVaccine effectiveness estimates, 2004-2005 mumps outbreak, England.\nEmerg Infect Dis 2007 Jan;13(1):12-7.\n\n8. J Infect Dis.\n2008 15;197(12): 1662-8.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The extent and intensity of the mumps epidemic in the current\nacademic year is surprising in view of the decline of mumps in\nuniversity students during both 2006/2007 and 2007/2008, subsequent to\nthe major outbreak in 2005/2006. As suggested above, it may be that\nsince 2005/2006 3 new cohorts of students have entered colleges and\nuniversities and established a new pool of susceptibles.\n\nEfforts to increase awareness of the risk of exposure to mumps\ninfection among university students must be continued. - Mod.CP]\n\n[Mumps in male college students may lead to orchitis (inflammation of\nthe testes) and sterility, a good selling point for taking the\nvaccine. - Mod.JW]\nSee Also\nMumps, students - UK (05): (ENG) 20090221.0728\nMumps - UK (04): (England, Wales) 20090212.0634\nMumps - UK (03): (England) 20090211.0619\nMumps - UK (02): (Wales) 20090206.0544\nMumps - UK (WALES) 20090130.0418\n2008\n----\nMumps, students - UK: (England) 20081108.3513\nMumps, students - UK: (London) 20080508.1575\n2004\n-----\nMumps, students - UK (02) 20041126.3166\nMumps, students - UK & Ireland (03) 20041117.3089\nMumps, students - UK & Ireland (02) 20041112.3055\nMumps, students - UK & Ireland 20041110.3039\nMumps, students - UK 20041103.2974\n2003\n----\nMumps, increase - UK (02) 20031123.2910\nMumps, increase - UK 20030524.1284\n2001\n----\nMumps, consequence of reduced MMRV uptake - UK (02) 20010831.2069\nMumps, consequence of reduced MMRV uptake 20010806.1858\n1999\n----\nMumps, imported - UK: RFI 19990223.0241\n...........................cp/ejp/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-06-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-01-16 00:00:00", "1173-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "1990-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-06-16 00:00:00", "2004-05-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-10 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "1662-08-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "North West", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Luxembourg", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "London", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "East midland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Republic of Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Opp M", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "230391", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - UK (08): (England)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=230391", "date": "2009-04-10 18:01:01", "main_text": "MUMPS, STUDENTS - UNITED KINGDOM (06): (ENGLAND, WALES)\n*******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org\n\n\nDate: Thu 9 Apr 2009\nSource: Health Protection Report, Volume 3, No 14, 2009 [edited]\n<http://www.hpa.org.uk/hpr/archives/2009/news1409.htm#mumps0809>\n\n\nContinued increase in mumps in universities 2008/2009\n-----------------------------------------------------\nAs reported previously [1], the number of mumps cases notified in\nEngland and Wales increased in early 2009 and has continued to\nincrease during March. Outbreaks have been reported from several\nuniversities and colleges. A similar increase has been reported from\nthe Republic of Ireland [2].\n\nA large epidemic of mumps affecting university students 1st occurred\nin the academic year 2004/5 [3] and continued into 2005/6, declining\nin 2006/7 and 2007/8. During the final quarter of 2008, 695 cases of\nmumps were confirmed compared to 447 in the previous quarter [4]. So\nfar in 2009, 998 cases of mumps with onset in January or February\nhave been confirmed mumps IgM or RNA positive in England and Wales.\nThis compares to 322, 274, and 1173 cases in the same periods of\n2008, 2007, and 2006 respectively. During 2009, cases have been\nconfirmed in all English regions and Wales with high numbers from the\nSouth West (204), South East (180), and North West (162) regions. For\nthe remaining regions the number of cases confirmed was as follows:\nYorkshire and Humberside (115), London (86), East of England (81),\nWest Midlands (64), East Midlands (48), North East (30), and Wales\n(27). The genotype currently circulating is a G5, the same strain\nthat has been circulating over the past 5 years and responsible for\noutbreaks in other parts of Europe [5,6].\n\n[These data are illustrated in the original text by a figure showing\nthe 5 week moving average of mumps notifications, England and Wales\n2003-2009. - Mod.CP]\n\nReason for the increase\n-----------------------\nThe previous epidemic was attributed to a cohort of young adults,\nborn between 1981 and 1990, who were at increased risk of mumps.\nThese individuals were born before the implementation of the routine\n2-dose MMR programme and had therefore either received no MMR\nvaccine, or only one dose. As control of mumps was excellent after\n1990, this group remained susceptible until they entered the\nuniversity or college setting, when transmission of mumps was\nfacilitated. During 2008, 1403 (57 percent) of the confirmed cases\nwere in those born between 1981 and 1990 . [Data illustrated by a\nfigure in the original text. - Mod.CP]\n\nDespite this clear picture, the reason why the numbers of cases have\nincreased in this academic year, after remaining lower in both 2006/7\nand 2007/8 is not entirely clear. One explanation may be that, since\nthe widespread transmission in 2005/6, 3 new cohorts of students have\nentered college and therefore another susceptible pool has been\nre-established in this setting.\n\nIn the previous epidemic, although the vaccinated cohorts were\nlargely protected from mumps, cases were confirmed in vaccinated\nindividuals. By the 2008/9 academic year, most students would have\nbeen eligible for one or 2 doses of MMR (measles, mumps, rubella),\nand so a higher proportion of vaccine failures are expected amongst\nthe cases. Initial reports are consistent with this observation.\n\nIn 2004-5, analysis of protection from vaccination showed that,\nalthough individual protection from vaccination was high, there was\nevidence of declining protection over time, particularly in those who\nhad only received one dose of vaccine [7]. Investigations during\nuniversity outbreaks in the United States, where vaccine coverage for\n2 doses has been in place for longer, also suggested that waning\nprotection may have contributed [8]. Secondary vaccine failure may\ntherefore also explain a proportion of cases.\n\nSurveillance and control\n------------------------\nContinued surveillance, including confirmation of the diagnosis, is\nimportant for ensuring accurate epidemiological data. In persons who\nhave been previously vaccinated, the serological diagnosis of mumps\ncan be difficult as the IgM response may be delayed and reach lower\nlevels. For rapid diagnosis, an oral fluid taken in the 1st 14 days\nof illness is preferred as this can be tested for both IgM\n(Immunoglobulin M) and viral RNA (ribonucleic acid). If this is not\npossible then parallel serum and throat swab or paired serum samples\ncan be collected.\n\nIn 2005 and 2006, the incident team for the national mumps outbreak\nrecommended that the priorities were to ensure that systems were in\nplace to ensure that those entering university were fully vaccinated\nwith MMR in the future. This included ensuring that pupils attending\nfor the Year 10 booster and university entrants from 2005 onwards had\nreceived 2 doses of MMR.\n\nThe team also concluded that university vaccination campaigns in\nparticular are likely to achieve low uptake and are unlikely to stop\noutbreaks. The offer of individual vaccination, however, should be\navailable to students who are unvaccinated or have received only one\ndose of MMR. Approaches being taken in individual universities this\nyear have included using text messaging and university computer\nnetworks to alert students to these recommendations.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. HPA. Mumps increase in university students, Health Protection\nReport [serial online] 2009; 3(10): News. Available at\n<http://www.hpa.org.uk/hpr/archives/2009/news1009.htm#mumps>.\n\n2. Continued increase in mumps cases in 2009. Health Protection\nSurveillance Centre (Republic of Ireland). [online] [10 March 2009]\n<http://www.hpsc.ie/hpsc/News/MainBody,3484,en.html>.\n\n3. Savage E, Ramsay M, White J, Beard S, Lawson H, Hunjan R, et al.\nMumps outbreaks across England and Wales in 2004: observational\nstudy. BMJ. 2005 14; 330(7500):1119-20.\n\n4. HPA. Laboratory confirmed cases of mumps, England and Wales:\nOctober to December 2008.Health Protection Report [serial online]\n2009;3(14)news.\n<http://www.hpa.org.uk/hpr/infections/immunisation.htm>.\n\n5. Cui A, Myers R, Xu W, Jin L. Analysis of the genetic variability\nof the mumps SH gene in viruses circulating in the UK between 1996\nand 2005. Infect Genet Evol. 2009; 9(1):71-80\n\n6. Mumps outbreak among the military in Luxembourg in 2008:\nepidemiology and evaluation of control measures. Mossong J, Bonert C,\nWeicherding P, Opp M, Reichert P, Even J, Schneider F.Euro Surveill\n[serial online] 2009 19; 14(7). pii: 19121\n\n7. Cohen C, White JM, Savage EJ, Glynn JR, Choi Y, Andrews N, et al.\nVaccine effectiveness estimates, 2004-2005 mumps outbreak, England.\nEmerg Infect Dis 2007 Jan;13(1):12-7.\n\n8. Date AA, Kyaw MH, Rue AM, Klahn J, Obrecht L, Krohn T, et al.\nLong-term persistence of mumps antibody after receipt of 2\nmeasles-mumps- rubella (MMR) vaccinations and antibody response after\na third MMR vaccination among a university population. J Infect Dis.\n2008 15;197(12): 1662-8.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The extent and intensity of the mumps epidemic in the current\nacademic year is surprising in view of the decline of mumps in\nuniversity students during both 2006/2007 and 2007/2008, subsequent to\nthe major outbreak in 2005/2006. As suggested above, it may be that\nsince 2005/2006 3 new cohorts of students have entered colleges and\nuniversities and established a new pool of susceptibles.\n\nEfforts to increase awareness of the risk of exposure to mumps\ninfection among university students must be continued. - Mod.CP]\n\n[Mumps in male college students may lead to orchitis (inflammation of\nthe testes) and sterility, a good selling point for taking the\nvaccine. - Mod.JW]\nSee Also\nMumps, students - UK (05): (ENG) 20090221.0728\nMumps - UK (04): (England, Wales) 20090212.0634\nMumps - UK (03): (England) 20090211.0619\nMumps - UK (02): (Wales) 20090206.0544\nMumps - UK (WALES) 20090130.0418\n2008\n----\nMumps, students - UK: (England) 20081108.3513\nMumps, students - UK: (London) 20080508.1575\n2004\n-----\nMumps, students - UK (02) 20041126.3166\nMumps, students - UK & Ireland (03) 20041117.3089\nMumps, students - UK & Ireland (02) 20041112.3055\nMumps, students - UK & Ireland 20041110.3039\nMumps, students - UK 20041103.2974\n2003\n----\nMumps, increase - UK (02) 20031123.2910\nMumps, increase - UK 20030524.1284\n2001\n----\nMumps, consequence of reduced MMRV uptake - UK (02) 20010831.2069\nMumps, consequence of reduced MMRV uptake 20010806.1858\n1999\n----\nMumps, imported - UK: RFI 19990223.0241\n...........................cp/ejp/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
