UK (07): (England, Wales)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=204704", "date": "2009-04-10 18:01:01", "main_text": "MUMPS, STUDENTS - UNITED KINGDOM (06): (ENGLAND, WALES)\n*******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org\n\n\nDate: Thu 9 Apr 2009\nSource: Health Protection Report, Volume 3, No 14, 2009 [edited]\n<http://www.hpa.org.uk/hpr/archives/2009/news1409.htm#mumps0809>\n\n\nContinued increase in mumps in universities 2008/2009\n-----------------------------------------------------\nAs reported previously [1], the number of mumps cases notified in\nEngland and Wales increased in early 2009 and has continued to\nincrease during March. Outbreaks have been reported from several\nuniversities and colleges. A similar increase has been reported from\nthe Republic of Ireland [2].\n\nA large epidemic of mumps affecting university students 1st occurred\nin the academic year 2004/5 [3] and continued into 2005/6, declining\nin 2006/7 and 2007/8. During the final quarter of 2008, 695 cases of\nmumps were confirmed compared to 447 in the previous quarter [4]. So\nfar in 2009, 998 cases of mumps with onset in January or February\nhave been confirmed mumps IgM or RNA positive in England and Wales.\nThis compares to 322, 274, and 1173 cases in the same periods of\n2008, 2007, and 2006 respectively. During 2009, cases have been\nconfirmed in all English regions and Wales with high numbers from the\nSouth West (204), South East (180), and North West (162) regions. For\nthe remaining regions the number of cases confirmed was as follows:\nYorkshire and Humberside (115), London (86), East of England (81),\nWest Midlands (64), East Midlands (48), North East (30), and Wales\n(27). The genotype currently circulating is a G5, the same strain\nthat has been circulating over the past 5 years and responsible for\noutbreaks in other parts of Europe [5,6].\n\n[These data are illustrated in the original text by a figure showing\nthe 5 week moving average of mumps notifications, England and Wales\n2003-2009. - Mod.CP]\n\nReason for the increase\n-----------------------\nThe previous epidemic was attributed to a cohort of young adults,\nborn between 1981 and 1990, who were at increased risk of mumps.\nThese individuals were born before the implementation of the routine\n2-dose MMR programme and had therefore either received no MMR\nvaccine, or only one dose. As control of mumps was excellent after\n1990, this group remained susceptible until they entered the\nuniversity or college setting, when transmission of mumps was\nfacilitated. During 2008, 1403 (57 percent) of the confirmed cases\nwere in those born between 1981 and 1990 . [Data illustrated by a\nfigure in the original text. - Mod.CP]\n\nDespite this clear picture, the reason why the numbers of cases have\nincreased in this academic year, after remaining lower in both 2006/7\nand 2007/8 is not entirely clear. One explanation may be that, since\nthe widespread transmission in 2005/6, 3 new cohorts of students have\nentered college and therefore another susceptible pool has been\nre-established in this setting.\n\nIn the previous epidemic, although the vaccinated cohorts were\nlargely protected from mumps, cases were confirmed in vaccinated\nindividuals. By the 2008/9 academic year, most students would have\nbeen eligible for one or 2 doses of MMR (measles, mumps, rubella),\nand so a higher proportion of vaccine failures are expected amongst\nthe cases. Initial reports are consistent with this observation.\n\nIn 2004-5, analysis of protection from vaccination showed that,\nalthough individual protection from vaccination was high, there was\nevidence of declining protection over time, particularly in those who\nhad only received one dose of vaccine [7]. Investigations during\nuniversity outbreaks in the United States, where vaccine coverage for\n2 doses has been in place for longer, also suggested that waning\nprotection may have contributed [8]. Secondary vaccine failure may\ntherefore also explain a proportion of cases.\n\nSurveillance and control\n------------------------\nContinued surveillance, including confirmation of the diagnosis, is\nimportant for ensuring accurate epidemiological data. In persons who\nhave been previously vaccinated, the serological diagnosis of mumps\ncan be difficult as the IgM response may be delayed and reach lower\nlevels. For rapid diagnosis, an oral fluid taken in the 1st 14 days\nof illness is preferred as this can be tested for both IgM\n(Immunoglobulin M) and viral RNA (ribonucleic acid). If this is not\npossible then parallel serum and throat swab or paired serum samples\ncan be collected.\n\nIn 2005 and 2006, the incident team for the national mumps outbreak\nrecommended that the priorities were to ensure that systems were in\nplace to ensure that those entering university were fully vaccinated\nwith MMR in the future. This included ensuring that pupils attending\nfor the Year 10 booster and university entrants from 2005 onwards had\nreceived 2 doses of MMR.\n\nThe team also concluded that university vaccination campaigns in\nparticular are likely to achieve low uptake and are unlikely to stop\noutbreaks. The offer of individual vaccination, however, should be\navailable to students who are unvaccinated or have received only one\ndose of MMR. Approaches being taken in individual universities this\nyear have included using text messaging and university computer\nnetworks to alert students to these recommendations.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. HPA. Mumps increase in university students, Health Protection\nReport [serial online] 2009; 3(10): News. Available at\n<http://www.hpa.org.uk/hpr/archives/2009/news1009.htm#mumps>.\n\n2. Date AA, Kyaw MH, Rue AM, Klahn J, Obrecht L, Krohn T, et al.\nLong-term persistence of mumps antibody after receipt of 2\nmeasles-mumps- rubella (MMR) vaccinations and antibody response after\na third MMR vaccination among a university population. J Infect Dis.\n2008 15;197(12): 1662-8.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The extent and intensity of the mumps epidemic in the current\nacademic year is surprising in view of the decline of mumps in\nuniversity students during both 2006/2007 and 2007/2008, subsequent to\nthe major outbreak in 2005/2006. As suggested above, it may be that\nsince 2005/2006 3 new cohorts of students have entered colleges and\nuniversities and established a new pool of susceptibles.\n\nEfforts to increase awareness of the risk of exposure to mumps\ninfection among university students must be continued. - Mod.CP]\n\n[Mumps in male college students may lead to orchitis (inflammation of\nthe testes) and sterility, a good selling point for taking the\nvaccine. - Mod.JW]\nSee Also\nMumps, students - UK (05): (ENG) 20090221.0728\nMumps - UK (04): (England, Wales) 20090212.0634\nMumps - UK (03): (England) 20090211.0619\nMumps - UK (02): (Wales) 20090206.0544\nMumps - UK (WALES) 20090130.0418\n2008\n----\nMumps, students - UK: (England) 20081108.3513\nMumps, students - UK: (London) 20080508.1575\n2004\n-----\nMumps, students - UK (02) 20041126.3166\nMumps, students - UK & Ireland (03) 20041117.3089\nMumps, students - UK & Ireland (02) 20041112.3055\nMumps, students - UK & Ireland 20041110.3039\nMumps, students - UK 20041103.2974\n2003\n----\nMumps, increase - UK (02) 20031123.2910\nMumps, increase - UK 20030524.1284\n2001\n----\nMumps, consequence of reduced MMRV uptake - UK (02) 20010831.2069\nMumps, consequence of reduced MMRV uptake 20010806.1858\n1999\n----\nMumps, imported - UK: RFI 19990223.0241\n...........................cp/ejp/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-06-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-01-16 00:00:00", "1173-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "1990-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-06-16 00:00:00", "2004-05-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-10 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "1662-08-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "North West", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Luxembourg", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "London", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "East midland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Republic of Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Opp M", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "175697", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps: USA (MA); UK (Scotland)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=175697", "date": "2009-04-10 18:01:01", "main_text": "MUMPS, STUDENTS - UNITED KINGDOM (06): (ENGLAND, WALES)\n*******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org\n\n\nDate: Thu 9 Apr 2009\nSource: Health Protection Report, Volume 3, No 14, 2009 [edited]\n<http://www.hpa.org.uk/hpr/archives/2009/news1409.htm#mumps0809>\n\n\nContinued increase in mumps in universities 2008/2009\n-----------------------------------------------------\nAs reported previously [1], the number of mumps cases notified in\nEngland and Wales increased in early 2009 and has continued to\nincrease during March. Outbreaks have been reported from several\nuniversities and colleges. A similar increase has been reported from\nthe Republic of Ireland [2].\n\nA large epidemic of mumps affecting university students 1st occurred\nin the academic year 2004/5 [3] and continued into 2005/6, declining\nin 2006/7 and 2007/8. During the final quarter of 2008, 695 cases of\nmumps were confirmed compared to 447 in the previous quarter [4]. So\nfar in 2009, 998 cases of mumps with onset in January or February\nhave been confirmed mumps IgM or RNA positive in England and Wales.\nThis compares to 322, 274, and 1173 cases in the same periods of\n2008, 2007, and 2006 respectively. During 2009, cases have been\nconfirmed in all English regions and Wales with high numbers from the\nSouth West (204), South East (180), and North West (162) regions. For\nthe remaining regions the number of cases confirmed was as follows:\nYorkshire and Humberside (115), London (86), East of England (81),\nWest Midlands (64), East Midlands (48), North East (30), and Wales\n(27). The genotype currently circulating is a G5, the same strain\nthat has been circulating over the past 5 years and responsible for\noutbreaks in other parts of Europe [5,6].\n\n[These data are illustrated in the original text by a figure showing\nthe 5 week moving average of mumps notifications, England and Wales\n2003-2009. - Mod.CP]\n\nReason for the increase\n-----------------------\nThe previous epidemic was attributed to a cohort of young adults,\nborn between 1981 and 1990, who were at increased risk of mumps.\nThese individuals were born before the implementation of the routine\n2-dose MMR programme and had therefore either received no MMR\nvaccine, or only one dose. As control of mumps was excellent after\n1990, this group remained susceptible until they entered the\nuniversity or college setting, when transmission of mumps was\nfacilitated. During 2008, 1403 (57 percent) of the confirmed cases\nwere in those born between 1981 and 1990 . [Data illustrated by a\nfigure in the original text. - Mod.CP]\n\nDespite this clear picture, the reason why the numbers of cases have\nincreased in this academic year, after remaining lower in both 2006/7\nand 2007/8 is not entirely clear. One explanation may be that, since\nthe widespread transmission in 2005/6, 3 new cohorts of students have\nentered college and therefore another susceptible pool has been\nre-established in this setting.\n\nIn the previous epidemic, although the vaccinated cohorts were\nlargely protected from mumps, cases were confirmed in vaccinated\nindividuals. By the 2008/9 academic year, most students would have\nbeen eligible for one or 2 doses of MMR (measles, mumps, rubella),\nand so a higher proportion of vaccine failures are expected amongst\nthe cases. Initial reports are consistent with this observation.\n\nIn 2004-5, analysis of protection from vaccination showed that,\nalthough individual protection from vaccination was high, there was\nevidence of declining protection over time, particularly in those who\nhad only received one dose of vaccine [7]. Investigations during\nuniversity outbreaks in the United States, where vaccine coverage for\n2 doses has been in place for longer, also suggested that waning\nprotection may have contributed [8]. Secondary vaccine failure may\ntherefore also explain a proportion of cases.\n\nSurveillance and control\n------------------------\nContinued surveillance, including confirmation of the diagnosis, is\nimportant for ensuring accurate epidemiological data. In persons who\nhave been previously vaccinated, the serological diagnosis of mumps\ncan be difficult as the IgM response may be delayed and reach lower\nlevels. For rapid diagnosis, an oral fluid taken in the 1st 14 days\nof illness is preferred as this can be tested for both IgM\n(Immunoglobulin M) and viral RNA (ribonucleic acid). If this is not\npossible then parallel serum and throat swab or paired serum samples\ncan be collected.\n\nIn 2005 and 2006, the incident team for the national mumps outbreak\nrecommended that the priorities were to ensure that systems were in\nplace to ensure that those entering university were fully vaccinated\nwith MMR in the future. This included ensuring that pupils attending\nfor the Year 10 booster and university entrants from 2005 onwards had\nreceived 2 doses of MMR.\n\nThe team also concluded that university vaccination campaigns in\nparticular are likely to achieve low uptake and are unlikely to stop\noutbreaks. The offer of individual vaccination, however, should be\navailable to students who are unvaccinated or have received only one\ndose of MMR. Approaches being taken in individual universities this\nyear have included using text messaging and university computer\nnetworks to alert students to these recommendations.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. HPA. Mumps increase in university students, Health Protection\nReport [serial online] 2009; 3(10): News. Available at\n<http://www.hpa.org.uk/hpr/archives/2009/news1009.htm#mumps>.\n\n2. Continued increase in mumps cases in 2009. Health Protection\nSurveillance Centre (Republic of Ireland). [online] [10 March 2009]\n<http://www.hpsc.ie/hpsc/News/MainBody,3484,en.html>.\n\n3. Savage E, Ramsay M, White J, Beard S, Lawson H, Hunjan R, et al.\nMumps outbreaks across England and Wales in 2004: observational\nstudy. BMJ. 2005 14; 330(7500):1119-20.\n\n4. HPA. Laboratory confirmed cases of mumps, England and Wales:\nOctober to December 2008.Health Protection Report [serial online]\n2009;3(14)news.\n<http://www.hpa.org.uk/hpr/infections/immunisation.htm>.\n\n5. Cui A, Myers R, Xu W, Jin L. Analysis of the genetic variability\nof the mumps SH gene in viruses circulating in the UK between 1996\nand 2005. Infect Genet Evol. 2009; 9(1):71-80\n\n6. Mumps outbreak among the military in Luxembourg in 2008:\nepidemiology and evaluation of control measures. Mossong J, Bonert C,\nWeicherding P, Opp M, Reichert P, Even J, Schneider F.Euro Surveill\n[serial online] 2009 19; 14(7). pii: 19121\n\n7. Cohen C, White JM, Savage EJ, Glynn JR, Choi Y, Andrews N, et al.\nVaccine effectiveness estimates, 2004-2005 mumps outbreak, England.\nEmerg Infect Dis 2007 Jan;13(1):12-7.\n\n8. Date AA, Kyaw MH, Rue AM, Klahn J, Obrecht L, Krohn T, et al.\nLong-term persistence of mumps antibody after receipt of 2\nmeasles-mumps- rubella (MMR) vaccinations and antibody response after\na third MMR vaccination among a university population. J Infect Dis.\n2008 15;197(12): 1662-8.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The extent and intensity of the mumps epidemic in the current\nacademic year is surprising in view of the decline of mumps in\nuniversity students during both 2006/2007 and 2007/2008, subsequent to\nthe major outbreak in 2005/2006. As suggested above, it may be that\nsince 2005/2006 3 new cohorts of students have entered colleges and\nuniversities and established a new pool of susceptibles.\n\nEfforts to increase awareness of the risk of exposure to mumps\ninfection among university students must be continued. - Mod.CP]\n\n[Mumps in male college students may lead to orchitis (inflammation of\nthe testes) and sterility, a good selling point for taking the\nvaccine. - Mod.JW]\nSee Also\nMumps, students - UK (05): (ENG) 20090221.0728\nMumps - UK (04): (England, Wales) 20090212.0634\nMumps - UK (03): (England) 20090211.0619\nMumps - UK (02): (Wales) 20090206.0544\nMumps - UK (WALES) 20090130.0418\n2008\n----\nMumps, students - UK: (England) 20081108.3513\nMumps, students - UK: (London) 20080508.1575\n2004\n-----\nMumps, students - UK (02) 20041126.3166\nMumps, students - UK & Ireland (03) 20041117.3089\nMumps, students - UK & Ireland (02) 20041112.3055\nMumps, students - UK & Ireland 20041110.3039\nMumps, students - UK 20041103.2974\n2003\n----\nMumps, increase - UK (02) 20031123.2910\nMumps, increase - UK 20030524.1284\n2001\n----\nMumps, consequence of reduced MMRV uptake - UK (02) 20010831.2069\nMumps, consequence of reduced MMRV uptake 20010806.1858\n1999\n----\nMumps, imported - UK: RFI 19990223.0241\n...........................cp/ejp/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-06-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-01-16 00:00:00", "1173-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "1990-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-06-16 00:00:00", "2004-05-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-10 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "1662-08-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "North West", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Luxembourg", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "London", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "East midland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Republic of Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Opp M", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "175211", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA: (MA) ex Ireland", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=175211", "date": "2009-04-10 18:01:01", "main_text": "MUMPS, STUDENTS - UNITED KINGDOM (06): (ENGLAND, WALES)\n*******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org\n\n\nDate: Thu 9 Apr 2009\nSource: Health Protection Report, Volume 3, No 14, 2009 [edited]\n<http://www.hpa.org.uk/hpr/archives/2009/news1409.htm#mumps0809>\n\n\nContinued increase in mumps in universities 2008/2009\n-----------------------------------------------------\nAs reported previously [1], the number of mumps cases notified in\nEngland and Wales increased in early 2009 and has continued to\nincrease during March. Outbreaks have been reported from several\nuniversities and colleges. A similar increase has been reported from\nthe Republic of Ireland [2].\n\nA large epidemic of mumps affecting university students 1st occurred\nin the academic year 2004/5 [3] and continued into 2005/6, declining\nin 2006/7 and 2007/8. During the final quarter of 2008, 695 cases of\nmumps were confirmed compared to 447 in the previous quarter [4]. So\nfar in 2009, 998 cases of mumps with onset in January or February\nhave been confirmed mumps IgM or RNA positive in England and Wales.\nThis compares to 322, 274, and 1173 cases in the same periods of\n2008, 2007, and 2006 respectively. During 2009, cases have been\nconfirmed in all English regions and Wales with high numbers from the\nSouth West (204), South East (180), and North West (162) regions. For\nthe remaining regions the number of cases confirmed was as follows:\nYorkshire and Humberside (115), London (86), East of England (81),\nWest Midlands (64), East Midlands (48), North East (30), and Wales\n(27). The genotype currently circulating is a G5, the same strain\nthat has been circulating over the past 5 years and responsible for\noutbreaks in other parts of Europe [5,6].\n\n[These data are illustrated in the original text by a figure showing\nthe 5 week moving average of mumps notifications, England and Wales\n2003-2009. - Mod.CP]\n\nReason for the increase\n-----------------------\nThe previous epidemic was attributed to a cohort of young adults,\nborn between 1981 and 1990, who were at increased risk of mumps.\nThese individuals were born before the implementation of the routine\n2-dose MMR programme and had therefore either received no MMR\nvaccine, or only one dose. As control of mumps was excellent after\n1990, this group remained susceptible until they entered the\nuniversity or college setting, when transmission of mumps was\nfacilitated. During 2008, 1403 (57 percent) of the confirmed cases\nwere in those born between 1981 and 1990 . [Data illustrated by a\nfigure in the original text. - Mod.CP]\n\nDespite this clear picture, the reason why the numbers of cases have\nincreased in this academic year, after remaining lower in both 2006/7\nand 2007/8 is not entirely clear. One explanation may be that, since\nthe widespread transmission in 2005/6, 3 new cohorts of students have\nentered college and therefore another susceptible pool has been\nre-established in this setting.\n\nIn the previous epidemic, although the vaccinated cohorts were\nlargely protected from mumps, cases were confirmed in vaccinated\nindividuals. By the 2008/9 academic year, most students would have\nbeen eligible for one or 2 doses of MMR (measles, mumps, rubella),\nand so a higher proportion of vaccine failures are expected amongst\nthe cases. Initial reports are consistent with this observation.\n\nIn 2004-5, analysis of protection from vaccination showed that,\nalthough individual protection from vaccination was high, there was\nevidence of declining protection over time, particularly in those who\nhad only received one dose of vaccine [7]. Investigations during\nuniversity outbreaks in the United States, where vaccine coverage for\n2 doses has been in place for longer, also suggested that waning\nprotection may have contributed [8]. Secondary vaccine failure may\ntherefore also explain a proportion of cases.\n\nSurveillance and control\n------------------------\nContinued surveillance, including confirmation of the diagnosis, is\nimportant for ensuring accurate epidemiological data. In persons who\nhave been previously vaccinated, the serological diagnosis of mumps\ncan be difficult as the IgM response may be delayed and reach lower\nlevels. For rapid diagnosis, an oral fluid taken in the 1st 14 days\nof illness is preferred as this can be tested for both IgM\n(Immunoglobulin M) and viral RNA (ribonucleic acid). If this is not\npossible then parallel serum and throat swab or paired serum samples\ncan be collected.\n\nIn 2005 and 2006, the incident team for the national mumps outbreak\nrecommended that the priorities were to ensure that systems were in\nplace to ensure that those entering university were fully vaccinated\nwith MMR in the future. This included ensuring that pupils attending\nfor the Year 10 booster and university entrants from 2005 onwards had\nreceived 2 doses of MMR.\n\nThe team also concluded that university vaccination campaigns in\nparticular are likely to achieve low uptake and are unlikely to stop\noutbreaks. The offer of individual vaccination, however, should be\navailable to students who are unvaccinated or have received only one\ndose of MMR. Approaches being taken in individual universities this\nyear have included using text messaging and university computer\nnetworks to alert students to these recommendations.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-06-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-01-16 00:00:00", "1173-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "1990-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-06-16 00:00:00", "2004-05-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-10 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "1662-08-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "North West", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Luxembourg", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "London", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "East midland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Republic of Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Opp M", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "173341", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps, students - UK (06): (England, Wales)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=173341", "date": "2009-04-10 18:01:01", "main_text": "MUMPS, STUDENTS - UNITED KINGDOM (06): (ENGLAND, WALES)\n*******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org\n\n\nDate: Thu 9 Apr 2009\nSource: Health Protection Report, Volume 3, No 14, 2009 [edited]\n<http://www.hpa.org.uk/hpr/archives/2009/news1409.htm#mumps0809>\n\n\nContinued increase in mumps in universities 2008/2009\n-----------------------------------------------------\nAs reported previously [1], the number of mumps cases notified in\nEngland and Wales increased in early 2009 and has continued to\nincrease during March. Outbreaks have been reported from several\nuniversities and colleges. A similar increase has been reported from\nthe Republic of Ireland [2].\n\nA large epidemic of mumps affecting university students 1st occurred\nin the academic year 2004/5 [3] and continued into 2005/6, declining\nin 2006/7 and 2007/8. During the final quarter of 2008, 695 cases of\nmumps were confirmed compared to 447 in the previous quarter [4]. So\nfar in 2009, 998 cases of mumps with onset in January or February\nhave been confirmed mumps IgM or RNA positive in England and Wales.\nThis compares to 322, 274, and 1173 cases in the same periods of\n2008, 2007, and 2006 respectively. During 2009, cases have been\nconfirmed in all English regions and Wales with high numbers from the\nSouth West (204), South East (180), and North West (162) regions. For\nthe remaining regions the number of cases confirmed was as follows:\nYorkshire and Humberside (115), London (86), East of England (81),\nWest Midlands (64), East Midlands (48), North East (30), and Wales\n(27). The genotype currently circulating is a G5, the same strain\nthat has been circulating over the past 5 years and responsible for\noutbreaks in other parts of Europe [5,6].\n\n[These data are illustrated in the original text by a figure showing\nthe 5 week moving average of mumps notifications, England and Wales\n2003-2009. - Mod.CP]\n\nReason for the increase\n-----------------------\nThe previous epidemic was attributed to a cohort of young adults,\nborn between 1981 and 1990, who were at increased risk of mumps.\nThese individuals were born before the implementation of the routine\n2-dose MMR programme and had therefore either received no MMR\nvaccine, or only one dose. As control of mumps was excellent after\n1990, this group remained susceptible until they entered the\nuniversity or college setting, when transmission of mumps was\nfacilitated. During 2008, 1403 (57 percent) of the confirmed cases\nwere in those born between 1981 and 1990 . [Data illustrated by a\nfigure in the original text. - Mod.CP]\n\nDespite this clear picture, the reason why the numbers of cases have\nincreased in this academic year, after remaining lower in both 2006/7\nand 2007/8 is not entirely clear. One explanation may be that, since\nthe widespread transmission in 2005/6, 3 new cohorts of students have\nentered college and therefore another susceptible pool has been\nre-established in this setting.\n\nIn the previous epidemic, although the vaccinated cohorts were\nlargely protected from mumps, cases were confirmed in vaccinated\nindividuals. By the 2008/9 academic year, most students would have\nbeen eligible for one or 2 doses of MMR (measles, mumps, rubella),\nand so a higher proportion of vaccine failures are expected amongst\nthe cases. Initial reports are consistent with this observation.\n\nIn 2004-5, analysis of protection from vaccination showed that,\nalthough individual protection from vaccination was high, there was\nevidence of declining protection over time, particularly in those who\nhad only received one dose of vaccine [7]. Investigations during\nuniversity outbreaks in the United States, where vaccine coverage for\n2 doses has been in place for longer, also suggested that waning\nprotection may have contributed [8]. Secondary vaccine failure may\ntherefore also explain a proportion of cases.\n\nSurveillance and control\n------------------------\nContinued surveillance, including confirmation of the diagnosis, is\nimportant for ensuring accurate epidemiological data. In persons who\nhave been previously vaccinated, the serological diagnosis of mumps\ncan be difficult as the IgM response may be delayed and reach lower\nlevels. For rapid diagnosis, an oral fluid taken in the 1st 14 days\nof illness is preferred as this can be tested for both IgM\n(Immunoglobulin M) and viral RNA (ribonucleic acid). If this is not\npossible then parallel serum and throat swab or paired serum samples\ncan be collected.\n\nIn 2005 and 2006, the incident team for the national mumps outbreak\nrecommended that the priorities were to ensure that systems were in\nplace to ensure that those entering university were fully vaccinated\nwith MMR in the future. This included ensuring that pupils attending\nfor the Year 10 booster and university entrants from 2005 onwards had\nreceived 2 doses of MMR.\n\nThe team also concluded that university vaccination campaigns in\nparticular are likely to achieve low uptake and are unlikely to stop\noutbreaks. The offer of individual vaccination, however, should be\navailable to students who are unvaccinated or have received only one\ndose of MMR. Approaches being taken in individual universities this\nyear have included using text messaging and university computer\nnetworks to alert students to these recommendations.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. HPA. Mumps increase in university students, Health Protection\nReport [serial online] 2009; 3(10): News. Available at\n<http://www.hpa.org.uk/hpr/archives/2009/news1009.htm#mumps>.\n\n2. Continued increase in mumps cases in 2009. Health Protection\nSurveillance Centre (Republic of Ireland). [online] [10 March 2009]\n<http://www.hpsc.ie/hpsc/News/MainBody,3484,en.html>.\n\n3. Savage E, Ramsay M, White J, Beard S, Lawson H, Hunjan R, et al.\nMumps outbreaks across England and Wales in 2004: observational\nstudy. BMJ. 2005 14; 330(7500):1119-20.\n\n4. HPA. Laboratory confirmed cases of mumps, England and Wales:\nOctober to December 2008.Health Protection Report [serial online]\n2009;3(14)news.\n<http://www.hpa.org.uk/hpr/infections/immunisation.htm>.\n\n5. Cui A, Myers R, Xu W, Jin L. Analysis of the genetic variability\nof the mumps SH gene in viruses circulating in the UK between 1996\nand 2005. Infect Genet Evol. 2009; 9(1):71-80\n\n6. Mumps outbreak among the military in Luxembourg in 2008:\nepidemiology and evaluation of control measures. Mossong J, Bonert C,\nWeicherding P, Opp M, Reichert P, Even J, Schneider F.Euro Surveill\n[serial online] 2009 19; 14(7). pii: 19121\n\n7. Cohen C, White JM, Savage EJ, Glynn JR, Choi Y, Andrews N, et al.\nVaccine effectiveness estimates, 2004-2005 mumps outbreak, England.\nEmerg Infect Dis 2007 Jan;13(1):12-7.\n\n8. Date AA, Kyaw MH, Rue AM, Klahn J, Obrecht L, Krohn T, et al.\nLong-term persistence of mumps antibody after receipt of 2\nmeasles-mumps- rubella (MMR) vaccinations and antibody response after\na third MMR vaccination among a university population. J Infect Dis.\n2008 15;197(12): 1662-8.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The extent and intensity of the mumps epidemic in the current\nacademic year is surprising in view of the decline of mumps in\nuniversity students during both 2006/2007 and 2007/2008, subsequent to\nthe major outbreak in 2005/2006. As suggested above, it may be that\nsince 2005/2006 3 new cohorts of students have entered colleges and\nuniversities and established a new pool of susceptibles.\n\nEfforts to increase awareness of the risk of exposure to mumps\ninfection among university students must be continued. - Mod.CP]\n\n[Mumps in male college students may lead to orchitis (inflammation of\nthe testes) and sterility, a good selling point for taking the\nvaccine. - Mod.JW]\nSee Also\nMumps, students - UK (05): (ENG) 20090221.0728\nMumps - UK (04): (England, Wales) 20090212.0634\nMumps - UK (03): (England) 20090211.0619\nMumps - UK (02): (Wales) 20090206.0544\nMumps - UK (WALES) 20090130.0418\n2008\n----\nMumps, students - UK: (England) 20081108.3513\nMumps, students - UK: (London) 20080508.1575\n2004\n-----\nMumps, students - UK (02) 20041126.3166\nMumps, students - UK & Ireland (03) 20041117.3089\nMumps, students - UK & Ireland (02) 20041112.3055\nMumps, students - UK & Ireland 20041110.3039\nMumps, students - UK 20041103.2974\n2003\n----\nMumps, increase - UK (02) 20031123.2910\nMumps, increase - UK 20030524.1284\n2001\n----\nMumps, consequence of reduced MMRV uptake - UK (02) 20010831.2069\nMumps, consequence of reduced MMRV uptake 20010806.1858\n1999\n----\nMumps, imported - UK: RFI 19990223.0241\n...........................cp/ejp/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-06-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-01-16 00:00:00", "1173-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "1990-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-06-16 00:00:00", "2004-05-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-10 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "1662-08-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "North West", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Luxembourg", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "London", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "East midland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Republic of Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Opp M", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "158941", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps, students - UK (05): (ENG)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=158941", "date": "2009-01-31 22:00:44", "main_text": "MUMPS - MACEDONIA\n*****************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Sat 31 Jan 2009\nFrom: Marija PopStefanija\n<marija_popstefanija@yahoo.com>\nSource: Dnevnik\n<http://www.dnevnik.com.mk/?ItemID=11B0C9E112E25E448739E96DF7A7AAAA>\n& Nova Makedonia\n\n[in Macedonian, trans. by submitter, edited]\n\n\nMumps outbreak in the Republic of Macedonia\n-------------------------------------------\nAn increase of cases of mumps has been reported in the Republic of\nMacedonia since last year [2008], including outbreaks in 12 different\ntowns. In the Clinic of Infectious Diseases (Medical Faculty,\nUniversity of Skopje) in January 2009 alone, there were 234 cases of\nmumps reported, including 50 who were hospitalized, 20 with a\ncomplication of orchitis [inflammation of the testes] and 18 with\nmeningitis. In the State Institute of Health, they are reporting 16\npercent of the mumps cases have complications, and more than half are\nteenagers between 15-19.\n\nAbout one third of the cases have received one mumps vaccination and\nsome have received 2 doses. The vaccine was introduced as a school\nrequirement in 1982. Until 1997, only one dose of the vaccine was\nrequired. The World Health Organization is now recommending 2 doses\nof the vaccine. The vaccine was not available due to a shortage in\nMacedonia from 1990-1994 and a lot of children at that time were not\nvaccinated. In December of 2008, the vaccine recommendation was\nextended to the age group 15-19.\n\nThe director of the Clinic of Infectious Diseases in Skopje, Zvonko\nMilenkovic, said that government has requested that the WHO help them\nwith tests to determine if the vaccine is protective against the virus\nthat is circulating. What is happening in Macedonia, he said, is\nsimilar to what happened to Western European countries like\nSwitzerland and England, and in the United States as well. In 1993,\nUNICEF donated mumps vaccines to Macedonia, but in the past 6 years\nall of the vaccines have been purchased from 2 companies, Pasteur and\nGlaxoSmithKline.\n\n--\nMarija PopStefanija, MPH, MS\nEpidemiologist\nMass Department of Public Health\nWestern Mass Public Health Center\nN424 Morril Bld. UMass\nAmherst, MA 01002\n<marija.popstefanija@state.ma.us>\n\n[These reports reflect continuing problems in achieving eradication\nof mumps by vaccination. The HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of\nMacedonia is available at:\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en? v=41.6,21.7,5> - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nMumps - UK (WLS) 20090130.0418\n2008\n----\nMumps, students - UK: (England) 20081108.3513\nMumps - Canada (05): (BC) 20080827.2683\nMumps - Canada (04): (ON) 20080810.2457\nMumps - Netherlands: increased incidence 20080627.1981\nMumps - Canada (03): (BC) 20080615.1890\nMumps, students - UK: (London) 20080508.1575\nMumps - Ireland: (Limerick) 20080416.1365\nMumps - Canada (02): 2007 review 20080403.1224\nMumps - Australia: (WA) 20080331.1190\nMumps - Moldova, Pridnestrovye (04) 20080330.1183\nMumps - Moldova, Pridnestrovye (03) 20080328.1167\nMumps - Canada: (BC) 20080311.0983\nMumps - Moldova, Pridnestrovye (02): background 20080131.0392\nMumps - Moldova, Pridnestrovye 20080130.0385\n.........................cp/ejp/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Macedonia (03)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=157945", "date": "2009-01-31 22:00:44", "main_text": "MUMPS - MACEDONIA\n*****************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Sat 31 Jan 2009\nFrom: Marija PopStefanija\n<marija_popstefanija@yahoo.com>\nSource: Dnevnik\n<http://www.dnevnik.com.mk/?ItemID=11B0C9E112E25E448739E96DF7A7AAAA>\n& Nova Makedonia\n\n[in Macedonian, trans. by submitter, edited]\n\n\nMumps outbreak in the Republic of Macedonia\n-------------------------------------------\nAn increase of cases of mumps has been reported in the Republic of\nMacedonia since last year [2008], including outbreaks in 12 different\ntowns. In the Clinic of Infectious Diseases (Medical Faculty,\nUniversity of Skopje) in January 2009 alone, there were 234 cases of\nmumps reported, including 50 who were hospitalized, 20 with a\ncomplication of orchitis [inflammation of the testes] and 18 with\nmeningitis. In the State Institute of Health, they are reporting 16\npercent of the mumps cases have complications, and more than half are\nteenagers between 15-19.\n\nAbout one third of the cases have received one mumps vaccination and\nsome have received 2 doses. The vaccine was introduced as a school\nrequirement in 1982. Until 1997, only one dose of the vaccine was\nrequired. The World Health Organization is now recommending 2 doses\nof the vaccine. The vaccine was not available due to a shortage in\nMacedonia from 1990-1994 and a lot of children at that time were not\nvaccinated. In December of 2008, the vaccine recommendation was\nextended to the age group 15-19.\n\nThe director of the Clinic of Infectious Diseases in Skopje, Zvonko\nMilenkovic, said that government has requested that the WHO help them\nwith tests to determine if the vaccine is protective against the virus\nthat is circulating. What is happening in Macedonia, he said, is\nsimilar to what happened to Western European countries like\nSwitzerland and England, and in the United States as well. In 1993,\nUNICEF donated mumps vaccines to Macedonia, but in the past 6 years\nall of the vaccines have been purchased from 2 companies, Pasteur and\nGlaxoSmithKline.\n\n--\nMarija PopStefanija, MPH, MS\nEpidemiologist\nMass Department of Public Health\nWestern Mass Public Health Center\nN424 Morril Bld. UMass\nAmherst, MA 01002\n<marija.popstefanija@state.ma.us>\n\n[These reports reflect continuing problems in achieving eradication\nof mumps by vaccination. The HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of\nMacedonia is available at:\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en? v=41.6,21.7,5> - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nMumps - UK (WLS) 20090130.0418\n2008\n----\nMumps, students - UK: (England) 20081108.3513\nMumps - Canada (05): (BC) 20080827.2683\nMumps - Canada (04): (ON) 20080810.2457\nMumps - Netherlands: increased incidence 20080627.1981\nMumps - Canada (03): (BC) 20080615.1890\nMumps, students - UK: (London) 20080508.1575\nMumps - Ireland: (Limerick) 20080416.1365\nMumps - Canada (02): 2007 review 20080403.1224\nMumps - Australia: (WA) 20080331.1190\nMumps - Moldova, Pridnestrovye (04) 20080330.1183\nMumps - Moldova, Pridnestrovye (03) 20080328.1167\nMumps - Canada: (BC) 20080311.0983\nMumps - Moldova, Pridnestrovye (02): background 20080131.0392\nMumps - Moldova, Pridnestrovye 20080130.0385\n.........................cp/ejp/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "156274", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - UK (04): (England, Wales)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=156274", "date": "2009-01-31 22:00:44", "main_text": "MUMPS - MACEDONIA\n*****************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Sat 31 Jan 2009\nFrom: Marija PopStefanija\n<marija_popstefanija@yahoo.com>\nSource: Dnevnik\n<http://www.dnevnik.com.mk/?ItemID=11B0C9E112E25E448739E96DF7A7AAAA>\n& Nova Makedonia\n\n[in Macedonian, trans. by submitter, edited]\n\n\nMumps outbreak in the Republic of Macedonia\n-------------------------------------------\nAn increase of cases of mumps has been reported in the Republic of\nMacedonia since last year [2008], including outbreaks in 12 different\ntowns. In the Clinic of Infectious Diseases (Medical Faculty,\nUniversity of Skopje) in January 2009 alone, there were 234 cases of\nmumps reported, including 50 who were hospitalized, 20 with a\ncomplication of orchitis [inflammation of the testes] and 18 with\nmeningitis. In the State Institute of Health, they are reporting 16\npercent of the mumps cases have complications, and more than half are\nteenagers between 15-19.\n\nAbout one third of the cases have received one mumps vaccination and\nsome have received 2 doses. The vaccine was introduced as a school\nrequirement in 1982. Until 1997, only one dose of the vaccine was\nrequired. The World Health Organization is now recommending 2 doses\nof the vaccine. The vaccine was not available due to a shortage in\nMacedonia from 1990-1994 and a lot of children at that time were not\nvaccinated. In December of 2008, the vaccine recommendation was\nextended to the age group 15-19.\n\nThe director of the Clinic of Infectious Diseases in Skopje, Zvonko\nMilenkovic, said that government has requested that the WHO help them\nwith tests to determine if the vaccine is protective against the virus\nthat is circulating. What is happening in Macedonia, he said, is\nsimilar to what happened to Western European countries like\nSwitzerland and England, and in the United States as well. In 1993,\nUNICEF donated mumps vaccines to Macedonia, but in the past 6 years\nall of the vaccines have been purchased from 2 companies, Pasteur and\nGlaxoSmithKline.\n\n--\nMarija PopStefanija, MPH, MS\nEpidemiologist\nMass Department of Public Health\nWestern Mass Public Health Center\nN424 Morril Bld. UMass\nAmherst, MA 01002\n<marija.popstefanija@state.ma.us>\n\n[These reports reflect continuing problems in achieving eradication\nof mumps by vaccination. The HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of\nMacedonia is available at:\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en? v=41.6,21.7,5> - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nMumps - UK (WLS) 20090130.0418\n2008\n----\nMumps, students - UK: (England) 20081108.3513\nMumps - Canada (05): (BC) 20080827.2683\nMumps - Canada (04): (ON) 20080810.2457\nMumps - Netherlands: increased incidence 20080627.1981\nMumps - Canada (03): (BC) 20080615.1890\nMumps, students - UK: (London) 20080508.1575\nMumps - Ireland: (Limerick) 20080416.1365\nMumps - Canada (02): 2007 review 20080403.1224\nMumps - Australia: (WA) 20080331.1190\nMumps - Moldova, Pridnestrovye (04) 20080330.1183\nMumps - Moldova, Pridnestrovye (03) 20080328.1167\nMumps - Canada: (BC) 20080311.0983\nMumps - Moldova, Pridnestrovye (02): background 20080131.0392\nMumps - Moldova, Pridnestrovye 20080130.0385\n.........................cp/ejp/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. In the Clinic of Infectious Diseases (Medical Faculty,\nUniversity of Skopje) in January 2009 alone, there were 234 cases of\nmumps reported, including 50 who were hospitalized, 20 with a\ncomplication of orchitis [inflammation of the testes] and 18 with\nmeningitis. In the State Institute of Health, they are reporting 16\npercent of the mumps cases have complications, and more than half are\nteenagers between 15-19.\n\nAbout one third of the cases have received one mumps vaccination and\nsome have received 2 doses. The vaccine was introduced as a school\nrequirement in 1982. Until 1997, only one dose of the vaccine was\nrequired. The World Health Organization is now recommending 2 doses\nof the vaccine. The vaccine was not available due to a shortage in\nMacedonia from 1990-1994 and a lot of children at that time were not\nvaccinated. In December of 2008, the vaccine recommendation was\nextended to the age group 15-19.\n\nThe director of the Clinic of Infectious Diseases in Skopje, Zvonko\nMilenkovic, said that government has requested that the WHO help them\nwith tests to determine if the vaccine is protective against the virus\nthat is circulating. What is happening in Macedonia, he said, is\nsimilar to what happened to Western European countries like\nSwitzerland and England, and in the United States as well. In 1993,\nUNICEF donated mumps vaccines to Macedonia, but in the past 6 years\nall of the vaccines have been purchased from 2 companies, Pasteur and\nGlaxoSmithKline.\n\n--\nMarija PopStefanija, MPH, MS\nEpidemiologist\nMass Department of Public Health\nWestern Mass Public Health Center\nN424 Morril Bld. UMass\nAmherst, MA 01002\n<marija.popstefanija@state.ma.us>\n\n[These reports reflect continuing problems in achieving eradication\nof mumps by vaccination. In the Clinic of Infectious Diseases (Medical Faculty,\nUniversity of Skopje) in January 2009 alone, there were 234 cases of\nmumps reported, including 50 who were hospitalized, 20 with a\ncomplication of orchitis [inflammation of the testes] and 18 with\nmeningitis. The vaccine was introduced as a school\nrequirement in 1982. Until 1997, only one dose of the vaccine was\nrequired. The World Health Organization is now recommending 2 doses\nof the vaccine. The vaccine was not available due to a shortage in\nMacedonia from 1990-1994 and a lot of children at that time were not\nvaccinated. In December of 2008, the vaccine recommendation was\nextended to the age group 15-19.\n\nThe director of the Clinic of Infectious Diseases in Skopje, Zvonko\nMilenkovic, said that government has requested that the WHO help them\nwith tests to determine if the vaccine is protective against the virus\nthat is circulating. What is happening in Macedonia, he said, is\nsimilar to what happened to Western European countries like\nSwitzerland and England, and in the United States as well. In the Clinic of Infectious Diseases (Medical Faculty,\nUniversity of Skopje) in January 2009 alone, there were 234 cases of\nmumps reported, including 50 who were hospitalized, 20 with a\ncomplication of orchitis [inflammation of the testes] and 18 with\nmeningitis. The vaccine was introduced as a school\nrequirement in 1982. Until 1997, only one dose of the vaccine was\nrequired. The World Health Organization is now recommending 2 doses\nof the vaccine. The vaccine was not available due to a shortage in\nMacedonia from 1990-1994 and a lot of children at that time were not\nvaccinated. In December of 2008, the vaccine recommendation was\nextended to the age group 15-19.\n\nThe director of the Clinic of Infectious Diseases in Skopje, Zvonko\nMilenkovic, said that government has requested that the WHO help them\nwith tests to determine if the vaccine is protective against the virus\nthat is circulating. What is happening in Macedonia, he said, is\nsimilar to what happened to Western European countries like\nSwitzerland and England, and in the United States as well. In the Clinic of Infectious Diseases (Medical Faculty,\nUniversity of Skopje) in January 2009 alone, there were 234 cases of\nmumps reported, including 50 who were hospitalized, 20 with a\ncomplication of orchitis [inflammation of the testes] and 18 with\nmeningitis. In the State Institute of Health, they are reporting 16\npercent of the mumps cases have complications, and more than half are\nteenagers between 15-19.\n\nAbout one third of the cases have received one mumps vaccination and\nsome have received 2 doses. The vaccine was introduced as a school\nrequirement in 1982. Until 1997, only one dose of the vaccine was\nrequired. The World Health Organization is now recommending 2 doses\nof the vaccine. The vaccine was not available due to a shortage in\nMacedonia from 1990-1994 and a lot of children at that time were not\nvaccinated. In December of 2008, the vaccine recommendation was\nextended to the age group 15-19.\n\nThe director of the Clinic of Infectious Diseases in Skopje, Zvonko\nMilenkovic, said that government has requested that the WHO help them\nwith tests to determine if the vaccine is protective against the virus\nthat is circulating. What is happening in Macedonia, he said, is\nsimilar to what happened to Western European countries like\nSwitzerland and England, and in the United States as well. In 1993,\nUNICEF donated mumps vaccines to Macedonia, but in the past 6 years\nall of the vaccines have been purchased from 2 companies, Pasteur and\nGlaxoSmithKline.\n\n--\nMarija PopStefanija, MPH, MS\nEpidemiologist\nMass Department of Public Health\nWestern Mass Public Health Center\nN424 Morril Bld. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["mumps", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2009-01-16 00:00:00", "1982-03-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-12-16 00:00:00", "1993-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Macedonian", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "London", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Republic of Macedonia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Republic of", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Macedonia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mumps - Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Switzerland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WLS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mumps - Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "151992", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Macedonia", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=151992", "date": "2009-01-31 22:00:44", "main_text": "MUMPS - MACEDONIA\n*****************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Sat 31 Jan 2009\nFrom: Marija PopStefanija\n<marija_popstefanija@yahoo.com>\nSource: Dnevnik\n<http://www.dnevnik.com.mk/?ItemID=11B0C9E112E25E448739E96DF7A7AAAA>\n& Nova Makedonia\n\n[in Macedonian, trans. by submitter, edited]\n\n\nMumps outbreak in the Republic of Macedonia\n-------------------------------------------\nAn increase of cases of mumps has been reported in the Republic of\nMacedonia since last year [2008], including outbreaks in 12 different\ntowns. In the Clinic of Infectious Diseases (Medical Faculty,\nUniversity of Skopje) in January 2009 alone, there were 234 cases of\nmumps reported, including 50 who were hospitalized, 20 with a\ncomplication of orchitis [inflammation of the testes] and 18 with\nmeningitis. In the State Institute of Health, they are reporting 16\npercent of the mumps cases have complications, and more than half are\nteenagers between 15-19.\n\nAbout one third of the cases have received one mumps vaccination and\nsome have received 2 doses. The vaccine was introduced as a school\nrequirement in 1982. Until 1997, only one dose of the vaccine was\nrequired. The World Health Organization is now recommending 2 doses\nof the vaccine. The vaccine was not available due to a shortage in\nMacedonia from 1990-1994 and a lot of children at that time were not\nvaccinated. In December of 2008, the vaccine recommendation was\nextended to the age group 15-19.\n\nThe director of the Clinic of Infectious Diseases in Skopje, Zvonko\nMilenkovic, said that government has requested that the WHO help them\nwith tests to determine if the vaccine is protective against the virus\nthat is circulating. What is happening in Macedonia, he said, is\nsimilar to what happened to Western European countries like\nSwitzerland and England, and in the United States as well. In 1993,\nUNICEF donated mumps vaccines to Macedonia, but in the past 6 years\nall of the vaccines have been purchased from 2 companies, Pasteur and\nGlaxoSmithKline.\n\n--\nMarija PopStefanija, MPH, MS\nEpidemiologist\nMass Department of Public Health\nWestern Mass Public Health Center\nN424 Morril Bld. UMass\nAmherst, MA 01002\n<marija.popstefanija@state.ma.us>\n\n[These reports reflect continuing problems in achieving eradication\nof mumps by vaccination. The HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of\nMacedonia is available at:\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en? v=41.6,21.7,5> - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nMumps - UK (WLS) 20090130.0418\n2008\n----\nMumps, students - UK: (England) 20081108.3513\nMumps - Canada (05): (BC) 20080827.2683\nMumps - Canada (04): (ON) 20080810.2457\nMumps - Netherlands: increased incidence 20080627.1981\nMumps - Canada (03): (BC) 20080615.1890\nMumps, students - UK: (London) 20080508.1575\nMumps - Ireland: (Limerick) 20080416.1365\nMumps - Canada (02): 2007 review 20080403.1224\nMumps - Australia: (WA) 20080331.1190\nMumps - Moldova, Pridnestrovye (04) 20080330.1183\nMumps - Moldova, Pridnestrovye (03) 20080328.1167\nMumps - Canada: (BC) 20080311.0983\nMumps - Moldova, Pridnestrovye (02): background 20080131.0392\nMumps - Moldova, Pridnestrovye 20080130.0385\n.........................cp/ejp/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["mumps", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2009-01-16 00:00:00", "1982-03-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-12-16 00:00:00", "1993-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Macedonian", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "London", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Republic of Macedonia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Republic of", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Macedonia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mumps - Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Switzerland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WLS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mumps - Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "151701", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - UK (WLS)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=151701", "date": "2008-04-16 12:00:22", "main_text": "MUMPS - IRELAND: (LIMERICK)\n***************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 15 Apr 2008\nSource: Limerick Post [edited]\n<http://www.limerickpost.ie/dailynews.elive?id=8747&category=Daily-Tue>\n\n\nMumps and measles alert\n-----------------------\nThe Department of Public Health in Limerick [province of Munster] has\nrecently been notified of 18 cases of mumps across the Mid-West area,\nwith over half of these amongst students at the University of\nLimerick (UL). GPs (general practitioners) in Limerick have been\nalerted to the increased cases, which comes at a time when Ireland\nhas also been shown to have one of the worst records in Europe at\nfighting measles.\n\nLow uptake of the MMR [mumps, measles, and rubella] vaccination,\nwhich currently stands at 77 per cent, makes Ireland one of 4\ncountries named and shamed in a World Health Organisation (WHO)\nsurvey as having particularly low immunity to measles, mumps, and\nrubella among adults and children.\n\nIn the University of Limerick, close contacts have been offered\nimmunisation through the Student Health Service and GPs across the\nMid-West have been put on the alert for symptoms. The HSE [Health\nService Executive] is advising students on the UL campus to ensure\nthat they are protected against mumps unless they are already immune.\nImmunity to mumps will result from having either received 2 doses of\nthe MMR vaccine in the past; been immunised during the outbreak of\nmumps that occurred at UL in March 2005, or already have had clinical\nmumps. According to a spokesperson from the HSE, most of those born\nsince 1988 have had 2 doses of MMR vaccine.\n\n\"If people are definitely not immune nor certain, they should seek\nmedical advice through their GP or Student Health Centre as to\nwhether they need a dose of the MMR vaccine to protect them at this\ntime. University staff who think that they are not immune have been\nadvised to attend their own general practitioner for this vaccine,\"\nhe advised.\n\nMeanwhile, deputy Jan O'Sullivan, is calling for an urgent campaign\nto encourage parents to immunise their children, to prevent a measles\nepidemic.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[A vaccination coverage rate of 77 per cent is considered\nunsatisfactory from a public health standpoint as the pool of\nsusceptibles remains at a level that will support continued\ntransmission of the measles virus, and the mumps virus as well.\n\nProMED-mail has had numerous postings mentioning the challenges faced\nin several countries as a result of the anti-vaccine lobby that has\nresulted in lower coverages with measles-containing vaccines. It is a\npity that the anti-vaccine lobby hasn't been reviewing the data and\nliterature to see the actual impact of measles seen in the\npre-vaccine era, with immediate complications (primary measles\npneumonia, encephalitis, severe diarrhea with dehydration, and death\nrelated to these complications) and subacute to delayed\ncomplications, such as sub-acute sclerosing panencephalitis. - Mod.MPP\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Ireland can be accessed at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=53.2,-8.2,5>.\nLimerick is located in the mid-western part of the country. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nMumps - Canada: 2007 review 20080403.1224\nMumps - Australia: (WA) 20080331.1190\nMumps - Moldova, Pridnestrovye (04) 20080330.1183\nMumps - Moldova, Pridnestrovye (03) 20080328.1167\nMumps - Canada: (BC) 20080311.0983\nMumps - Moldova, Pridnestrovye (02): background 20080131.0392\n...................................mpp/cp/mj/lm\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. GPs (general practitioners) in Limerick have been\nalerted to the increased cases, which comes at a time when Ireland\nhas also been shown to have one of the worst records in Europe at\nfighting measles.\n\nLow uptake of the MMR [mumps, measles, and rubella] vaccination,\nwhich currently stands at 77 per cent, makes Ireland one of 4\ncountries named and shamed in a World Health Organisation (WHO)\nsurvey as having particularly low immunity to measles, mumps, and\nrubella among adults and children.\n\nIn the University of Limerick, close contacts have been offered\nimmunisation through the Student Health Service and GPs across the\nMid-West have been put on the alert for symptoms. The HSE [Health\nService Executive] is advising students on the UL campus to ensure\nthat they are protected against mumps unless they are already immune.\nImmunity to mumps will result from having either received 2 doses of\nthe MMR vaccine in the past; been immunised during the outbreak of\nmumps that occurred at UL in March 2005, or already have had clinical\nmumps. According to a spokesperson from the HSE, most of those born\nsince 1988 have had 2 doses of MMR vaccine.\n\n\"If people are definitely not immune nor certain, they should seek\nmedical advice through their GP or Student Health Centre as to\nwhether they need a dose of the MMR vaccine to protect them at this\ntime. University staff who think that they are not immune have been\nadvised to attend their own general practitioner for this vaccine,\"\nhe advised.\n\nMeanwhile, deputy Jan O'Sullivan, is calling for an urgent campaign\nto encourage parents to immunise their children, to prevent a measles\nepidemic.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[A vaccination coverage rate of 77 per cent is considered\nunsatisfactory from a public health standpoint as the pool of\nsusceptibles remains at a level that will support continued\ntransmission of the measles virus, and the mumps virus as well.\n\nProMED-mail has had numerous postings mentioning the challenges faced\nin several countries as a result of the anti-vaccine lobby that has\nresulted in lower coverages with measles-containing vaccines. It is a\npity that the anti-vaccine lobby hasn't been reviewing the data and\nliterature to see the actual impact of measles seen in the\npre-vaccine era, with immediate complications (primary measles\npneumonia, encephalitis, severe diarrhea with dehydration, and death\nrelated to these complications) and subacute to delayed\ncomplications, such as sub-acute sclerosing panencephalitis. - Mod.MPP\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Ireland can be accessed at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=53.2,-8.2,5>.\nLimerick is located in the mid-western part of the country. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nMumps - Canada: 2007 review 20080403.1224\nMumps - Australia: (WA) 20080331.1190\nMumps - Moldova, Pridnestrovye (04) 20080330.1183\nMumps - Moldova, Pridnestrovye (03) 20080328.1167\nMumps - Canada: (BC) 20080311.0983\nMumps - Moldova, Pridnestrovye (02): background 20080131.0392\n...................................mpp/cp/mj/lm\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. GPs (general practitioners) in Limerick have been\nalerted to the increased cases, which comes at a time when Ireland\nhas also been shown to have one of the worst records in Europe at\nfighting measles.\n\nLow uptake of the MMR [mumps, measles, and rubella] vaccination,\nwhich currently stands at 77 per cent, makes Ireland one of 4\ncountries named and shamed in a World Health Organisation (WHO)\nsurvey as having particularly low immunity to measles, mumps, and\nrubella among adults and children.\n\nIn the University of Limerick, close contacts have been offered\nimmunisation through the Student Health Service and GPs across the\nMid-West have been put on the alert for symptoms. The HSE [Health\nService Executive] is advising students on the UL campus to ensure\nthat they are protected against mumps unless they are already immune.\nImmunity to mumps will result from having either received 2 doses of\nthe MMR vaccine in the past; been immunised during the outbreak of\nmumps that occurred at UL in March 2005, or already have had clinical\nmumps. According to a spokesperson from the HSE, most of those born\nsince 1988 have had 2 doses of MMR vaccine.\n\n\"If people are definitely not immune nor certain, they should seek\nmedical advice through their GP or Student Health Centre as to\nwhether they need a dose of the MMR vaccine to protect them at this\ntime. University staff who think that they are not immune have been\nadvised to attend their own general practitioner for this vaccine,\"\nhe advised.\n\nMeanwhile, deputy Jan O'Sullivan, is calling for an urgent campaign\nto encourage parents to immunise their children, to prevent a measles\nepidemic.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[A vaccination coverage rate of 77 per cent is considered\nunsatisfactory from a public health standpoint as the pool of\nsusceptibles remains at a level that will support continued\ntransmission of the measles virus, and the mumps virus as well.\n\nProMED-mail has had numerous postings mentioning the challenges faced\nin several countries as a result of the anti-vaccine lobby that has\nresulted in lower coverages with measles-containing vaccines. It is a\npity that the anti-vaccine lobby hasn't been reviewing the data and\nliterature to see the actual impact of measles seen in the\npre-vaccine era, with immediate complications (primary measles\npneumonia, encephalitis, severe diarrhea with dehydration, and death\nrelated to these complications) and subacute to delayed\ncomplications, such as sub-acute sclerosing panencephalitis. - Mod.MPP\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Ireland can be accessed at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=53.2,-8.2,5>.\nLimerick is located in the mid-western part of the country. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nMumps - Canada: 2007 review 20080403.1224\nMumps - Australia: (WA) 20080331.1190\nMumps - Moldova, Pridnestrovye (04) 20080330.1183\nMumps - Moldova, Pridnestrovye (03) 20080328.1167\nMumps - Canada: (BC) 20080311.0983\nMumps - Moldova, Pridnestrovye (02): background 20080131.0392\n...................................mpp/cp/mj/lm\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. GPs (general practitioners) in Limerick have been\nalerted to the increased cases, which comes at a time when Ireland\nhas also been shown to have one of the worst records in Europe at\nfighting measles.\n\nLow uptake of the MMR [mumps, measles, and rubella] vaccination,\nwhich currently stands at 77 per cent, makes Ireland one of 4\ncountries named and shamed in a World Health Organisation (WHO)\nsurvey as having particularly low immunity to measles, mumps, and\nrubella among adults and children.\n\nIn the University of Limerick, close contacts have been offered\nimmunisation through the Student Health Service and GPs across the\nMid-West have been put on the alert for symptoms. The HSE [Health\nService Executive] is advising students on the UL campus to ensure\nthat they are protected against mumps unless they are already immune.\nImmunity to mumps will result from having either received 2 doses of\nthe MMR vaccine in the past; been immunised during the outbreak of\nmumps that occurred at UL in March 2005, or already have had clinical\nmumps. According to a spokesperson from the HSE, most of those born\nsince 1988 have had 2 doses of MMR vaccine.\n\n\"If people are definitely not immune nor certain, they should seek\nmedical advice through their GP or Student Health Centre as to\nwhether they need a dose of the MMR vaccine to protect them at this\ntime. University staff who think that they are not immune have been\nadvised to attend their own general practitioner for this vaccine,\"\nhe advised.\n\nMeanwhile, deputy Jan O'Sullivan, is calling for an urgent campaign\nto encourage parents to immunise their children, to prevent a measles\nepidemic.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[A vaccination coverage rate of 77 per cent is considered\nunsatisfactory from a public health standpoint as the pool of\nsusceptibles remains at a level that will support continued\ntransmission of the measles virus, and the mumps virus as well.\n\nProMED-mail has had numerous postings mentioning the challenges faced\nin several countries as a result of the anti-vaccine lobby that has\nresulted in lower coverages with measles-containing vaccines. It is a\npity that the anti-vaccine lobby hasn't been reviewing the data and\nliterature to see the actual impact of measles seen in the\npre-vaccine era, with immediate complications (primary measles\npneumonia, encephalitis, severe diarrhea with dehydration, and death\nrelated to these complications) and subacute to delayed\ncomplications, such as sub-acute sclerosing panencephalitis. - Mod.MPP\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Ireland can be accessed at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=53.2,-8.2,5>.\nLimerick is located in the mid-western part of the country. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nMumps - Canada: 2007 review 20080403.1224\nMumps - Australia: (WA) 20080331.1190\nMumps - Moldova, Pridnestrovye (04) 20080330.1183\nMumps - Moldova, Pridnestrovye (03) 20080328.1167\nMumps - Canada: (BC) 20080311.0983\nMumps - Moldova, Pridnestrovye (02): background 20080131.0392\n...................................mpp/cp/mj/lm\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
