For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["measles", "mumps", "rubella", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2005-03-16 00:00:00", "1988-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Limerick", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "90968", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Netherlands: increased incidence", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=90968", "date": "2008-04-16 12:00:22", "main_text": "MUMPS - IRELAND: (LIMERICK)\n***************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 15 Apr 2008\nSource: Limerick Post [edited]\n<http://www.limerickpost.ie/dailynews.elive?id=8747&category=Daily-Tue>\n\n\nMumps and measles alert\n-----------------------\nThe Department of Public Health in Limerick [province of Munster] has\nrecently been notified of 18 cases of mumps across the Mid-West area,\nwith over half of these amongst students at the University of\nLimerick (UL). GPs (general practitioners) in Limerick have been\nalerted to the increased cases, which comes at a time when Ireland\nhas also been shown to have one of the worst records in Europe at\nfighting measles.\n\nLow uptake of the MMR [mumps, measles, and rubella] vaccination,\nwhich currently stands at 77 per cent, makes Ireland one of 4\ncountries named and shamed in a World Health Organisation (WHO)\nsurvey as having particularly low immunity to measles, mumps, and\nrubella among adults and children.\n\nIn the University of Limerick, close contacts have been offered\nimmunisation through the Student Health Service and GPs across the\nMid-West have been put on the alert for symptoms. The HSE [Health\nService Executive] is advising students on the UL campus to ensure\nthat they are protected against mumps unless they are already immune.\nImmunity to mumps will result from having either received 2 doses of\nthe MMR vaccine in the past; been immunised during the outbreak of\nmumps that occurred at UL in March 2005, or already have had clinical\nmumps. According to a spokesperson from the HSE, most of those born\nsince 1988 have had 2 doses of MMR vaccine.\n\n\"If people are definitely not immune nor certain, they should seek\nmedical advice through their GP or Student Health Centre as to\nwhether they need a dose of the MMR vaccine to protect them at this\ntime. University staff who think that they are not immune have been\nadvised to attend their own general practitioner for this vaccine,\"\nhe advised.\n\nMeanwhile, deputy Jan O'Sullivan, is calling for an urgent campaign\nto encourage parents to immunise their children, to prevent a measles\nepidemic.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[A vaccination coverage rate of 77 per cent is considered\nunsatisfactory from a public health standpoint as the pool of\nsusceptibles remains at a level that will support continued\ntransmission of the measles virus, and the mumps virus as well.\n\nProMED-mail has had numerous postings mentioning the challenges faced\nin several countries as a result of the anti-vaccine lobby that has\nresulted in lower coverages with measles-containing vaccines. It is a\npity that the anti-vaccine lobby hasn't been reviewing the data and\nliterature to see the actual impact of measles seen in the\npre-vaccine era, with immediate complications (primary measles\npneumonia, encephalitis, severe diarrhea with dehydration, and death\nrelated to these complications) and subacute to delayed\ncomplications, such as sub-acute sclerosing panencephalitis. - Mod.MPP\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Ireland can be accessed at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=53.2,-8.2,5>.\nLimerick is located in the mid-western part of the country. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nMumps - Canada: 2007 review 20080403.1224\nMumps - Australia: (WA) 20080331.1190\nMumps - Moldova, Pridnestrovye (04) 20080330.1183\nMumps - Moldova, Pridnestrovye (03) 20080328.1167\nMumps - Canada: (BC) 20080311.0983\nMumps - Moldova, Pridnestrovye (02): background 20080131.0392\n...................................mpp/cp/mj/lm\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["measles", "mumps", "rubella", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2005-03-16 00:00:00", "1988-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Limerick", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "87754", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Canada (03): (BC)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=87754", "date": "2008-04-16 12:00:22", "main_text": "MUMPS - IRELAND: (LIMERICK)\n***************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 15 Apr 2008\nSource: Limerick Post [edited]\n<http://www.limerickpost.ie/dailynews.elive?id=8747&category=Daily-Tue>\n\n\nMumps and measles alert\n-----------------------\nThe Department of Public Health in Limerick [province of Munster] has\nrecently been notified of 18 cases of mumps across the Mid-West area,\nwith over half of these amongst students at the University of\nLimerick (UL). GPs (general practitioners) in Limerick have been\nalerted to the increased cases, which comes at a time when Ireland\nhas also been shown to have one of the worst records in Europe at\nfighting measles.\n\nLow uptake of the MMR [mumps, measles, and rubella] vaccination,\nwhich currently stands at 77 per cent, makes Ireland one of 4\ncountries named and shamed in a World Health Organisation (WHO)\nsurvey as having particularly low immunity to measles, mumps, and\nrubella among adults and children.\n\nIn the University of Limerick, close contacts have been offered\nimmunisation through the Student Health Service and GPs across the\nMid-West have been put on the alert for symptoms. The HSE [Health\nService Executive] is advising students on the UL campus to ensure\nthat they are protected against mumps unless they are already immune.\nImmunity to mumps will result from having either received 2 doses of\nthe MMR vaccine in the past; been immunised during the outbreak of\nmumps that occurred at UL in March 2005, or already have had clinical\nmumps. According to a spokesperson from the HSE, most of those born\nsince 1988 have had 2 doses of MMR vaccine.\n\n\"If people are definitely not immune nor certain, they should seek\nmedical advice through their GP or Student Health Centre as to\nwhether they need a dose of the MMR vaccine to protect them at this\ntime. University staff who think that they are not immune have been\nadvised to attend their own general practitioner for this vaccine,\"\nhe advised.\n\nMeanwhile, deputy Jan O'Sullivan, is calling for an urgent campaign\nto encourage parents to immunise their children, to prevent a measles\nepidemic.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[A vaccination coverage rate of 77 per cent is considered\nunsatisfactory from a public health standpoint as the pool of\nsusceptibles remains at a level that will support continued\ntransmission of the measles virus, and the mumps virus as well.\n\nProMED-mail has had numerous postings mentioning the challenges faced\nin several countries as a result of the anti-vaccine lobby that has\nresulted in lower coverages with measles-containing vaccines. It is a\npity that the anti-vaccine lobby hasn't been reviewing the data and\nliterature to see the actual impact of measles seen in the\npre-vaccine era, with immediate complications (primary measles\npneumonia, encephalitis, severe diarrhea with dehydration, and death\nrelated to these complications) and subacute to delayed\ncomplications, such as sub-acute sclerosing panencephalitis. - Mod.MPP\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Ireland can be accessed at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=53.2,-8.2,5>.\nLimerick is located in the mid-western part of the country. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nMumps - Canada: 2007 review 20080403.1224\nMumps - Australia: (WA) 20080331.1190\nMumps - Moldova, Pridnestrovye (04) 20080330.1183\nMumps - Moldova, Pridnestrovye (03) 20080328.1167\nMumps - Canada: (BC) 20080311.0983\nMumps - Moldova, Pridnestrovye (02): background 20080131.0392\n...................................mpp/cp/mj/lm\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. GPs (general practitioners) in Limerick have been\nalerted to the increased cases, which comes at a time when Ireland\nhas also been shown to have one of the worst records in Europe at\nfighting measles.\n\nLow uptake of the MMR [mumps, measles, and rubella] vaccination,\nwhich currently stands at 77 per cent, makes Ireland one of 4\ncountries named and shamed in a World Health Organisation (WHO)\nsurvey as having particularly low immunity to measles, mumps, and\nrubella among adults and children.\n\nIn the University of Limerick, close contacts have been offered\nimmunisation through the Student Health Service and GPs across the\nMid-West have been put on the alert for symptoms. The HSE [Health\nService Executive] is advising students on the UL campus to ensure\nthat they are protected against mumps unless they are already immune.\nImmunity to mumps will result from having either received 2 doses of\nthe MMR vaccine in the past; been immunised during the outbreak of\nmumps that occurred at UL in March 2005, or already have had clinical\nmumps. According to a spokesperson from the HSE, most of those born\nsince 1988 have had 2 doses of MMR vaccine.\n\n\"If people are definitely not immune nor certain, they should seek\nmedical advice through their GP or Student Health Centre as to\nwhether they need a dose of the MMR vaccine to protect them at this\ntime. University staff who think that they are not immune have been\nadvised to attend their own general practitioner for this vaccine,\"\nhe advised.\n\nMeanwhile, deputy Jan O'Sullivan, is calling for an urgent campaign\nto encourage parents to immunise their children, to prevent a measles\nepidemic.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[A vaccination coverage rate of 77 per cent is considered\nunsatisfactory from a public health standpoint as the pool of\nsusceptibles remains at a level that will support continued\ntransmission of the measles virus, and the mumps virus as well.\n\nProMED-mail has had numerous postings mentioning the challenges faced\nin several countries as a result of the anti-vaccine lobby that has\nresulted in lower coverages with measles-containing vaccines. It is a\npity that the anti-vaccine lobby hasn't been reviewing the data and\nliterature to see the actual impact of measles seen in the\npre-vaccine era, with immediate complications (primary measles\npneumonia, encephalitis, severe diarrhea with dehydration, and death\nrelated to these complications) and subacute to delayed\ncomplications, such as sub-acute sclerosing panencephalitis. - Mod.MPP\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Ireland can be accessed at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=53.2,-8.2,5>.\nLimerick is located in the mid-western part of the country. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nMumps - Canada: 2007 review 20080403.1224\nMumps - Australia: (WA) 20080331.1190\nMumps - Moldova, Pridnestrovye (04) 20080330.1183\nMumps - Moldova, Pridnestrovye (03) 20080328.1167\nMumps - Canada: (BC) 20080311.0983\nMumps - Moldova, Pridnestrovye (02): background 20080131.0392\n...................................mpp/cp/mj/lm\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. GPs (general practitioners) in Limerick have been\nalerted to the increased cases, which comes at a time when Ireland\nhas also been shown to have one of the worst records in Europe at\nfighting measles.\n\nLow uptake of the MMR [mumps, measles, and rubella] vaccination,\nwhich currently stands at 77 per cent, makes Ireland one of 4\ncountries named and shamed in a World Health Organisation (WHO)\nsurvey as having particularly low immunity to measles, mumps, and\nrubella among adults and children.\n\nIn the University of Limerick, close contacts have been offered\nimmunisation through the Student Health Service and GPs across the\nMid-West have been put on the alert for symptoms. The HSE [Health\nService Executive] is advising students on the UL campus to ensure\nthat they are protected against mumps unless they are already immune.\nImmunity to mumps will result from having either received 2 doses of\nthe MMR vaccine in the past; been immunised during the outbreak of\nmumps that occurred at UL in March 2005, or already have had clinical\nmumps. According to a spokesperson from the HSE, most of those born\nsince 1988 have had 2 doses of MMR vaccine.\n\n\"If people are definitely not immune nor certain, they should seek\nmedical advice through their GP or Student Health Centre as to\nwhether they need a dose of the MMR vaccine to protect them at this\ntime. University staff who think that they are not immune have been\nadvised to attend their own general practitioner for this vaccine,\"\nhe advised.\n\nMeanwhile, deputy Jan O'Sullivan, is calling for an urgent campaign\nto encourage parents to immunise their children, to prevent a measles\nepidemic.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[A vaccination coverage rate of 77 per cent is considered\nunsatisfactory from a public health standpoint as the pool of\nsusceptibles remains at a level that will support continued\ntransmission of the measles virus, and the mumps virus as well.\n\nProMED-mail has had numerous postings mentioning the challenges faced\nin several countries as a result of the anti-vaccine lobby that has\nresulted in lower coverages with measles-containing vaccines. It is a\npity that the anti-vaccine lobby hasn't been reviewing the data and\nliterature to see the actual impact of measles seen in the\npre-vaccine era, with immediate complications (primary measles\npneumonia, encephalitis, severe diarrhea with dehydration, and death\nrelated to these complications) and subacute to delayed\ncomplications, such as sub-acute sclerosing panencephalitis. - Mod.MPP\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Ireland can be accessed at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=53.2,-8.2,5>.\nLimerick is located in the mid-western part of the country. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nMumps - Canada: 2007 review 20080403.1224\nMumps - Australia: (WA) 20080331.1190\nMumps - Moldova, Pridnestrovye (04) 20080330.1183\nMumps - Moldova, Pridnestrovye (03) 20080328.1167\nMumps - Canada: (BC) 20080311.0983\nMumps - Moldova, Pridnestrovye (02): background 20080131.0392\n...................................mpp/cp/mj/lm\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["measles", "mumps", "rubella", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2005-03-16 00:00:00", "1988-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Limerick", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "69980", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Canada: 2007 review", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=69980", "date": "2007-12-21 03:00:27", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (02): (MAINE)\n*************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu 20 Dec 2007\nSource: The Boston Globe online [edited]\n<http://www.boston.com/news/local/articles/2007/12/20/\nmumps_outbreak_worries_mass_officials/>\n\nMumps outbreak worries Massachusetts officials\n----------------------------------------------\nMassachusetts health authorities are on high alert for cases of mumps, the\npainful viral illness that has reemerged in Maine and Maritime Canada in\nrecent months, despite decades of vaccinations. Before the outbreak, Maine\nhad not reported a case in at least 20 years. Now mumps has spread across\nthe state, reaching its southernmost county and making nearly 75 children\nand adults sick statewide since September [2007].\nDisease trackers suspect that the Maine outbreak was imported from Canada,\nwhere 1140 people have fallen ill this year [2007], 14 times the average\nfor recent years. Most of the cases have been reported by 3 eastern\nprovinces -- Nova Scotia, New Brunswick, and Prince Edward Island.\nSpecialists in Massachusetts are watching the migration of mumps with\nincreasing concern, knowing that many of the patients in Maine and Canada\nare college students, a group particularly susceptible because they are\nmobile and live in tight quarters, an ideal combination for disease\ntransmission.\n\"We are exploring every possible mumps case,\" said Dr Alfred DeMaria,\ndirector of communicable disease control for the Department of Public\nHealth in Massachusetts, where only 3 cases have been reported this year.\n\"We're going to be especially vigilant after the holidays,\" he said,\nbecause Boston students may have contact with students from Maine schools\nduring the break.\nThe resurgence of mumps illustrates the hardiness of a virus, the\nlimitations of a vaccine, and the realities of a world so hooked on air\ntravel that germs can spread from one country to another in a matter of\nhours. Specialists said they believe that is exactly what happened with\nmumps. Like measles, it was a common childhood scourge that appeared headed\nfor extinction in the United States. But in 2005, a strain widely\ncirculating [not terribly common, clinically. - Mod.SH] in the United\nKingdom, where vaccination rates are significantly lower than in North\nAmerica, was imported to a New York state summer camp. Within a year, that\nsame strain was identified as the culprit in a Midwest outbreak. And it is\nbeing blamed for the cases in Canada this year.\n\"Mumps is essentially endemic in the rest of the world,\" said Dr James\nAlexander, a medical epidemiologist at the US Centers for Disease Control\nand Prevention (CDC). \"Canada and the United States were the 2 countries\nwhere mumps was close to being eliminated.\"\nThe virus is transmitted by direct contact with an infected person's\nsaliva, meaning it can travel through a kiss or on utensils, towels, or\ntissues. It causes severe swelling of salivary glands and is heralded by\nfever, headache, body aches, and glandular tenderness where the jaw forms\nan angle. Rarely fatal, it can result in significant complications,\nincluding inflammation of the testes, brain swelling, meningitis, and\nsterility. A vaccine introduced in 1967 led to a steep decline in mumps in\nthe United States, but within 2 decades, the virus had reemerged.\n\"Mumps has undoubtedly been with us for millennia, and it's not likely to\ndisappear just because we develop an effective vaccine,\" said Dr Kenneth\nMcIntosh, a disease specialist at Children's Hospital Boston. One pivotal\nlesson derived from the return of the mumps in the late 1980s: a single\ndose of vaccine did not provide enough of a shield. It was then that\ndisease specialists began recommending that children receive 2 doses and\nthat schools bar students who were not vaccinated.\nAs Canadian specialists began investigating this year's outbreak, they\nquickly homed in on the vaccination history of patients, unearthing\nimportant clues. Nearly 73 per cent had received only a single dose of\nvaccine, while 19 per cent had no vaccination at all. Those who received at\nleast one dose generally had milder cases. \"I like to compare this disease\nto a heat-seeking missile,\" said Jeannette Macey, an epidemiologist with\nthe epidemiologist with the Public Health Agency of Canada. \"If there are\npeople in the population who are not protected, it's going to find them.\"\nIn Maine, authorities are collecting comparable data, but they know already\nthat many of the adults who became infected probably only got a single dose\nearlier in life. At the University of Southern Maine, where many of the\nstudents are older, at least 10 people have fallen ill, a spokeswoman said.\nDisease specialists from Maine and the federal CDC are also continuing to\ninvestigate exactly where the virus came from, running sophisticated\ngenetic testing and conducting extensive interviews. \"It's not surprising\nthat Maine would have cases,\" said Dr Dora Mills, director of Maine's CDC.\n\"New Brunswick is adjacent to Maine, and Nova Scotia might as well be,\nbecause there are several boats that go back and forth every day.\"\n[byline: Stephen Smith]\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Brent Barrett\n[There has been a considerable increase in the number of mumps cases\nreported in Maine since the initial report on 20 Nov 2007. The case count\nof 7 confirmed and 24 suspected cases of mumps has risen to at least 75\nconfirmed cases. It may be that as time progresses the State of Maine will\nbe required to instigate a comprehensive vaccination campaign to provide\nprotective immunity to those in the population who have previously received\na single vaccinations or none, to contain this outbreak - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nMumps - Canada (11): (AB) 20071202.3881\nMumps - USA: (ME) 20071121.3777\nMumps - Canada (10): (AB) 20071118.3736\nMumps - Canada (09) (NS) 20071105.3598\nMumps - Canada (08) (multi-province, PEI) 20071025.3473\nMumps - Canada (multi-province) (02) 20070510.1501\nMumps - Canada (NS) (06) 20070501.1411\nMumps - Canada (NS) (02) 20070406.1162\nMumps - Canada (NS): RFI 20070331.1104\n..................cp/ejp/sh\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-09-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "1967-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Maine", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Boston", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Prince Edward Island", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "the State of Maine", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Massachusetts", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "69587", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Australia: (WA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=69587", "date": "2007-12-21 03:00:27", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (02): (MAINE)\n*************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu 20 Dec 2007\nSource: The Boston Globe online [edited]\n<http://www.boston.com/news/local/articles/2007/12/20/\nmumps_outbreak_worries_mass_officials/>\n\nMumps outbreak worries Massachusetts officials\n----------------------------------------------\nMassachusetts health authorities are on high alert for cases of mumps, the\npainful viral illness that has reemerged in Maine and Maritime Canada in\nrecent months, despite decades of vaccinations. Before the outbreak, Maine\nhad not reported a case in at least 20 years. Now mumps has spread across\nthe state, reaching its southernmost county and making nearly 75 children\nand adults sick statewide since September [2007].\nDisease trackers suspect that the Maine outbreak was imported from Canada,\nwhere 1140 people have fallen ill this year [2007], 14 times the average\nfor recent years. Most of the cases have been reported by 3 eastern\nprovinces -- Nova Scotia, New Brunswick, and Prince Edward Island.\nSpecialists in Massachusetts are watching the migration of mumps with\nincreasing concern, knowing that many of the patients in Maine and Canada\nare college students, a group particularly susceptible because they are\nmobile and live in tight quarters, an ideal combination for disease\ntransmission.\n\"We are exploring every possible mumps case,\" said Dr Alfred DeMaria,\ndirector of communicable disease control for the Department of Public\nHealth in Massachusetts, where only 3 cases have been reported this year.\n\"We're going to be especially vigilant after the holidays,\" he said,\nbecause Boston students may have contact with students from Maine schools\nduring the break.\nThe resurgence of mumps illustrates the hardiness of a virus, the\nlimitations of a vaccine, and the realities of a world so hooked on air\ntravel that germs can spread from one country to another in a matter of\nhours. Specialists said they believe that is exactly what happened with\nmumps. Like measles, it was a common childhood scourge that appeared headed\nfor extinction in the United States. But in 2005, a strain widely\ncirculating [not terribly common, clinically. - Mod.SH] in the United\nKingdom, where vaccination rates are significantly lower than in North\nAmerica, was imported to a New York state summer camp. Within a year, that\nsame strain was identified as the culprit in a Midwest outbreak. And it is\nbeing blamed for the cases in Canada this year.\n\"Mumps is essentially endemic in the rest of the world,\" said Dr James\nAlexander, a medical epidemiologist at the US Centers for Disease Control\nand Prevention (CDC). \"Canada and the United States were the 2 countries\nwhere mumps was close to being eliminated.\"\nThe virus is transmitted by direct contact with an infected person's\nsaliva, meaning it can travel through a kiss or on utensils, towels, or\ntissues. It causes severe swelling of salivary glands and is heralded by\nfever, headache, body aches, and glandular tenderness where the jaw forms\nan angle. Rarely fatal, it can result in significant complications,\nincluding inflammation of the testes, brain swelling, meningitis, and\nsterility. A vaccine introduced in 1967 led to a steep decline in mumps in\nthe United States, but within 2 decades, the virus had reemerged.\n\"Mumps has undoubtedly been with us for millennia, and it's not likely to\ndisappear just because we develop an effective vaccine,\" said Dr Kenneth\nMcIntosh, a disease specialist at Children's Hospital Boston. One pivotal\nlesson derived from the return of the mumps in the late 1980s: a single\ndose of vaccine did not provide enough of a shield. It was then that\ndisease specialists began recommending that children receive 2 doses and\nthat schools bar students who were not vaccinated.\nAs Canadian specialists began investigating this year's outbreak, they\nquickly homed in on the vaccination history of patients, unearthing\nimportant clues. Nearly 73 per cent had received only a single dose of\nvaccine, while 19 per cent had no vaccination at all. Those who received at\nleast one dose generally had milder cases. \"I like to compare this disease\nto a heat-seeking missile,\" said Jeannette Macey, an epidemiologist with\nthe epidemiologist with the Public Health Agency of Canada. \"If there are\npeople in the population who are not protected, it's going to find them.\"\nIn Maine, authorities are collecting comparable data, but they know already\nthat many of the adults who became infected probably only got a single dose\nearlier in life. At the University of Southern Maine, where many of the\nstudents are older, at least 10 people have fallen ill, a spokeswoman said.\nDisease specialists from Maine and the federal CDC are also continuing to\ninvestigate exactly where the virus came from, running sophisticated\ngenetic testing and conducting extensive interviews. \"It's not surprising\nthat Maine would have cases,\" said Dr Dora Mills, director of Maine's CDC.\n\"New Brunswick is adjacent to Maine, and Nova Scotia might as well be,\nbecause there are several boats that go back and forth every day.\"\n[byline: Stephen Smith]\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Brent Barrett\n[There has been a considerable increase in the number of mumps cases\nreported in Maine since the initial report on 20 Nov 2007. The case count\nof 7 confirmed and 24 suspected cases of mumps has risen to at least 75\nconfirmed cases. It may be that as time progresses the State of Maine will\nbe required to instigate a comprehensive vaccination campaign to provide\nprotective immunity to those in the population who have previously received\na single vaccinations or none, to contain this outbreak - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nMumps - Canada (11): (AB) 20071202.3881\nMumps - USA: (ME) 20071121.3777\nMumps - Canada (10): (AB) 20071118.3736\nMumps - Canada (09) (NS) 20071105.3598\nMumps - Canada (08) (multi-province, PEI) 20071025.3473\nMumps - Canada (multi-province) (02) 20070510.1501\nMumps - Canada (NS) (06) 20070501.1411\nMumps - Canada (NS) (02) 20070406.1162\nMumps - Canada (NS): RFI 20070331.1104\n..................cp/ejp/sh\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Before the outbreak, Maine\nhad not reported a case in at least 20 years. Now mumps has spread across\nthe state, reaching its southernmost county and making nearly 75 children\nand adults sick statewide since September [2007].\nDisease trackers suspect that the Maine outbreak was imported from Canada,\nwhere 1140 people have fallen ill this year [2007], 14 times the average\nfor recent years. Most of the cases have been reported by 3 eastern\nprovinces -- Nova Scotia, New Brunswick, and Prince Edward Island.\nSpecialists in Massachusetts are watching the migration of mumps with\nincreasing concern, knowing that many of the patients in Maine and Canada\nare college students, a group particularly susceptible because they are\nmobile and live in tight quarters, an ideal combination for disease\ntransmission.\n\"We are exploring every possible mumps case,\" said Dr Alfred DeMaria,\ndirector of communicable disease control for the Department of Public\nHealth in Massachusetts, where only 3 cases have been reported this year.\n\"We're going to be especially vigilant after the holidays,\" he said,\nbecause Boston students may have contact with students from Maine schools\nduring the break.\nThe resurgence of mumps illustrates the hardiness of a virus, the\nlimitations of a vaccine, and the realities of a world so hooked on air\ntravel that germs can spread from one country to another in a matter of\nhours. Specialists said they believe that is exactly what happened with\nmumps. Like measles, it was a common childhood scourge that appeared headed\nfor extinction in the United States. But in 2005, a strain widely\ncirculating [not terribly common, clinically. - Mod.SH] in the United\nKingdom, where vaccination rates are significantly lower than in North\nAmerica, was imported to a New York state summer camp. Within a year, that\nsame strain was identified as the culprit in a Midwest outbreak. And it is\nbeing blamed for the cases in Canada this year.\n\"Mumps is essentially endemic in the rest of the world,\" said Dr James\nAlexander, a medical epidemiologist at the US Centers for Disease Control\nand Prevention (CDC). \"Canada and the United States were the 2 countries\nwhere mumps was close to being eliminated.\"\nThe virus is transmitted by direct contact with an infected person's\nsaliva, meaning it can travel through a kiss or on utensils, towels, or\ntissues. It causes severe swelling of salivary glands and is heralded by\nfever, headache, body aches, and glandular tenderness where the jaw forms\nan angle. Rarely fatal, it can result in significant complications,\nincluding inflammation of the testes, brain swelling, meningitis, and\nsterility. A vaccine introduced in 1967 led to a steep decline in mumps in\nthe United States, but within 2 decades, the virus had reemerged.\n\"Mumps has undoubtedly been with us for millennia, and it's not likely to\ndisappear just because we develop an effective vaccine,\" said Dr Kenneth\nMcIntosh, a disease specialist at Children's Hospital Boston. One pivotal\nlesson derived from the return of the mumps in the late 1980s: a single\ndose of vaccine did not provide enough of a shield. It was then that\ndisease specialists began recommending that children receive 2 doses and\nthat schools bar students who were not vaccinated.\nAs Canadian specialists began investigating this year's outbreak, they\nquickly homed in on the vaccination history of patients, unearthing\nimportant clues. Nearly 73 per cent had received only a single dose of\nvaccine, while 19 per cent had no vaccination at all. Those who received at\nleast one dose generally had milder cases. \"I like to compare this disease\nto a heat-seeking missile,\" said Jeannette Macey, an epidemiologist with\nthe epidemiologist with the Public Health Agency of Canada. \"If there are\npeople in the population who are not protected, it's going to find them.\"\nIn Maine, authorities are collecting comparable data, but they know already\nthat many of the adults who became infected probably only got a single dose\nearlier in life. At the University of Southern Maine, where many of the\nstudents are older, at least 10 people have fallen ill, a spokeswoman said.\nDisease specialists from Maine and the federal CDC are also continuing to\ninvestigate exactly where the virus came from, running sophisticated\ngenetic testing and conducting extensive interviews. \"It's not surprising\nthat Maine would have cases,\" said Dr Dora Mills, director of Maine's CDC.\n\"New Brunswick is adjacent to Maine, and Nova Scotia might as well be,\nbecause there are several boats that go back and forth every day.\"\n[byline: Stephen Smith]\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Brent Barrett\n[There has been a considerable increase in the number of mumps cases\nreported in Maine since the initial report on 20 Nov 2007. The case count\nof 7 confirmed and 24 suspected cases of mumps has risen to at least 75\nconfirmed cases. It may be that as time progresses the State of Maine will\nbe required to instigate a comprehensive vaccination campaign to provide\nprotective immunity to those in the population who have previously received\na single vaccinations or none, to contain this outbreak - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nMumps - Canada (11): (AB) 20071202.3881\nMumps - USA: (ME) 20071121.3777\nMumps - Canada (10): (AB) 20071118.3736\nMumps - Canada (09) (NS) 20071105.3598\nMumps - Canada (08) (multi-province, PEI) 20071025.3473\nMumps - Canada (multi-province) (02) 20070510.1501\nMumps - Canada (NS) (06) 20070501.1411\nMumps - Canada (NS) (02) 20070406.1162\nMumps - Canada (NS): RFI 20070331.1104\n..................cp/ejp/sh\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Before the outbreak, Maine\nhad not reported a case in at least 20 years. Now mumps has spread across\nthe state, reaching its southernmost county and making nearly 75 children\nand adults sick statewide since September [2007].\nDisease trackers suspect that the Maine outbreak was imported from Canada,\nwhere 1140 people have fallen ill this year [2007], 14 times the average\nfor recent years. Specialists said they believe that is exactly what happened with\nmumps. Like measles, it was a common childhood scourge that appeared headed\nfor extinction in the United States. But in 2005, a strain widely\ncirculating [not terribly common, clinically. - Mod.SH] in the United\nKingdom, where vaccination rates are significantly lower than in North\nAmerica, was imported to a New York state summer camp. Within a year, that\nsame strain was identified as the culprit in a Midwest outbreak. And it is\nbeing blamed for the cases in Canada this year.\n\"Mumps is essentially endemic in the rest of the world,\" said Dr James\nAlexander, a medical epidemiologist at the US Centers for Disease Control\nand Prevention (CDC). \"Canada and the United States were the 2 countries\nwhere mumps was close to being eliminated.\"\nThe virus is transmitted by direct contact with an infected person's\nsaliva, meaning it can travel through a kiss or on utensils, towels, or\ntissues. It causes severe swelling of salivary glands and is heralded by\nfever, headache, body aches, and glandular tenderness where the jaw forms\nan angle. Rarely fatal, it can result in significant complications,\nincluding inflammation of the testes, brain swelling, meningitis, and\nsterility. A vaccine introduced in 1967 led to a steep decline in mumps in\nthe United States, but within 2 decades, the virus had reemerged.\n\"Mumps has undoubtedly been with us for millennia, and it's not likely to\ndisappear just because we develop an effective vaccine,\" said Dr Kenneth\nMcIntosh, a disease specialist at Children's Hospital Boston. One pivotal\nlesson derived from the return of the mumps in the late 1980s: a single\ndose of vaccine did not provide enough of a shield. It was then that\ndisease specialists began recommending that children receive 2 doses and\nthat schools bar students who were not vaccinated.\nAs Canadian specialists began investigating this year's outbreak, they\nquickly homed in on the vaccination history of patients, unearthing\nimportant clues. Nearly 73 per cent had received only a single dose of\nvaccine, while 19 per cent had no vaccination at all. Those who received at\nleast one dose generally had milder cases. \"I like to compare this disease\nto a heat-seeking missile,\" said Jeannette Macey, an epidemiologist with\nthe epidemiologist with the Public Health Agency of Canada. \"If there are\npeople in the population who are not protected, it's going to find them.\"\nIn Maine, authorities are collecting comparable data, but they know already\nthat many of the adults who became infected probably only got a single dose\nearlier in life. At the University of Southern Maine, where many of the\nstudents are older, at least 10 people have fallen ill, a spokeswoman said.\nDisease specialists from Maine and the federal CDC are also continuing to\ninvestigate exactly where the virus came from, running sophisticated\ngenetic testing and conducting extensive interviews. \"It's not surprising\nthat Maine would have cases,\" said Dr Dora Mills, director of Maine's CDC.\n\"New Brunswick is adjacent to Maine, and Nova Scotia might as well be,\nbecause there are several boats that go back and forth every day.\"\n[byline: Stephen Smith]\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Brent Barrett\n[There has been a considerable increase in the number of mumps cases\nreported in Maine since the initial report on 20 Nov 2007. Most of the cases have been reported by 3 eastern\nprovinces -- Nova Scotia, New Brunswick, and Prince Edward Island.\nSpecialists in Massachusetts are watching the migration of mumps with\nincreasing concern, knowing that many of the patients in Maine and Canada\nare college students, a group particularly susceptible because they are\nmobile and live in tight quarters, an ideal combination for disease\ntransmission.\n\"We are exploring every possible mumps case,\" said Dr Alfred DeMaria,\ndirector of communicable disease control for the Department of Public\nHealth in Massachusetts, where only 3 cases have been reported this year.\n\"We're going to be especially vigilant after the holidays,\" he said,\nbecause Boston students may have contact with students from Maine schools\nduring the break.\nThe resurgence of mumps illustrates the hardiness of a virus, the\nlimitations of a vaccine, and the realities of a world so hooked on air\ntravel that germs can spread from one country to another in a matter of\nhours. Specialists said they believe that is exactly what happened with\nmumps. Like measles, it was a common childhood scourge that appeared headed\nfor extinction in the United States. But in 2005, a strain widely\ncirculating [not terribly common, clinically. - Mod.SH] in the United\nKingdom, where vaccination rates are significantly lower than in North\nAmerica, was imported to a New York state summer camp. Within a year, that\nsame strain was identified as the culprit in a Midwest outbreak. And it is\nbeing blamed for the cases in Canada this year.\n\"Mumps is essentially endemic in the rest of the world,\" said Dr James\nAlexander, a medical epidemiologist at the US Centers for Disease Control\nand Prevention (CDC). \"Canada and the United States were the 2 countries\nwhere mumps was close to being eliminated.\"\nThe virus is transmitted by direct contact with an infected person's\nsaliva, meaning it can travel through a kiss or on utensils, towels, or\ntissues. It causes severe swelling of salivary glands and is heralded by\nfever, headache, body aches, and glandular tenderness where the jaw forms\nan angle. Rarely fatal, it can result in significant complications,\nincluding inflammation of the testes, brain swelling, meningitis, and\nsterility. A vaccine introduced in 1967 led to a steep decline in mumps in\nthe United States, but within 2 decades, the virus had reemerged.\n\"Mumps has undoubtedly been with us for millennia, and it's not likely to\ndisappear just because we develop an effective vaccine,\" said Dr Kenneth\nMcIntosh, a disease specialist at Children's Hospital Boston. One pivotal\nlesson derived from the return of the mumps in the late 1980s: a single\ndose of vaccine did not provide enough of a shield. It was then that\ndisease specialists began recommending that children receive 2 doses and\nthat schools bar students who were not vaccinated.\nAs Canadian specialists began investigating this year's outbreak, they\nquickly homed in on the vaccination history of patients, unearthing\nimportant clues. Nearly 73 per cent had received only a single dose of\nvaccine, while 19 per cent had no vaccination at all. Those who received at\nleast one dose generally had milder cases. \"I like to compare this disease\nto a heat-seeking missile,\" said Jeannette Macey, an epidemiologist with\nthe epidemiologist with the Public Health Agency of Canada. \"If there are\npeople in the population who are not protected, it's going to find them.\"\nIn Maine, authorities are collecting comparable data, but they know already\nthat many of the adults who became infected probably only got a single dose\nearlier in life. At the University of Southern Maine, where many of the\nstudents are older, at least 10 people have fallen ill, a spokeswoman said.\nDisease specialists from Maine and the federal CDC are also continuing to\ninvestigate exactly where the virus came from, running sophisticated\ngenetic testing and conducting extensive interviews. \"It's not surprising\nthat Maine would have cases,\" said Dr Dora Mills, director of Maine's CDC.\n\"New Brunswick is adjacent to Maine, and Nova Scotia might as well be,\nbecause there are several boats that go back and forth every day.\"\n[byline: Stephen Smith]\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Brent Barrett\n[There has been a considerable increase in the number of mumps cases\nreported in Maine since the initial report on 20 Nov 2007. The case count\nof 7 confirmed and 24 suspected cases of mumps has risen to at least 75\nconfirmed cases. It may be that as time progresses the State of Maine will\nbe required to instigate a comprehensive vaccination campaign to provide\nprotective immunity to those in the population who have previously received\na single vaccinations or none, to contain this outbreak - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nMumps - Canada (11): (AB) 20071202.3881\nMumps - USA: (ME) 20071121.3777\nMumps - Canada (10): (AB) 20071118.3736\nMumps - Canada (09) (NS) 20071105.3598\nMumps - Canada (08) (multi-province, PEI) 20071025.3473\nMumps - Canada (multi-province) (02) 20070510.1501\nMumps - Canada (NS) (06) 20070501.1411\nMumps - Canada (NS) (02) 20070406.1162\nMumps - Canada (NS): RFI 20070331.1104\n..................cp/ejp/sh\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-09-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "1967-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Maine", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Boston", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Prince Edward Island", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "the State of Maine", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Massachusetts", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "54265", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Moldova, Pridnestrovye (02): background", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=54265", "date": "2007-12-21 03:00:27", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (02): (MAINE)\n*************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu 20 Dec 2007\nSource: The Boston Globe online [edited]\n<http://www.boston.com/news/local/articles/2007/12/20/\nmumps_outbreak_worries_mass_officials/>\n\nMumps outbreak worries Massachusetts officials\n----------------------------------------------\nMassachusetts health authorities are on high alert for cases of mumps, the\npainful viral illness that has reemerged in Maine and Maritime Canada in\nrecent months, despite decades of vaccinations. Before the outbreak, Maine\nhad not reported a case in at least 20 years. Now mumps has spread across\nthe state, reaching its southernmost county and making nearly 75 children\nand adults sick statewide since September [2007].\nDisease trackers suspect that the Maine outbreak was imported from Canada,\nwhere 1140 people have fallen ill this year [2007], 14 times the average\nfor recent years. Most of the cases have been reported by 3 eastern\nprovinces -- Nova Scotia, New Brunswick, and Prince Edward Island.\nSpecialists in Massachusetts are watching the migration of mumps with\nincreasing concern, knowing that many of the patients in Maine and Canada\nare college students, a group particularly susceptible because they are\nmobile and live in tight quarters, an ideal combination for disease\ntransmission.\n\"We are exploring every possible mumps case,\" said Dr Alfred DeMaria,\ndirector of communicable disease control for the Department of Public\nHealth in Massachusetts, where only 3 cases have been reported this year.\n\"We're going to be especially vigilant after the holidays,\" he said,\nbecause Boston students may have contact with students from Maine schools\nduring the break.\nThe resurgence of mumps illustrates the hardiness of a virus, the\nlimitations of a vaccine, and the realities of a world so hooked on air\ntravel that germs can spread from one country to another in a matter of\nhours. Specialists said they believe that is exactly what happened with\nmumps. Like measles, it was a common childhood scourge that appeared headed\nfor extinction in the United States. But in 2005, a strain widely\ncirculating [not terribly common, clinically. - Mod.SH] in the United\nKingdom, where vaccination rates are significantly lower than in North\nAmerica, was imported to a New York state summer camp. Within a year, that\nsame strain was identified as the culprit in a Midwest outbreak. And it is\nbeing blamed for the cases in Canada this year.\n\"Mumps is essentially endemic in the rest of the world,\" said Dr James\nAlexander, a medical epidemiologist at the US Centers for Disease Control\nand Prevention (CDC). \"Canada and the United States were the 2 countries\nwhere mumps was close to being eliminated.\"\nThe virus is transmitted by direct contact with an infected person's\nsaliva, meaning it can travel through a kiss or on utensils, towels, or\ntissues. It causes severe swelling of salivary glands and is heralded by\nfever, headache, body aches, and glandular tenderness where the jaw forms\nan angle. Rarely fatal, it can result in significant complications,\nincluding inflammation of the testes, brain swelling, meningitis, and\nsterility. A vaccine introduced in 1967 led to a steep decline in mumps in\nthe United States, but within 2 decades, the virus had reemerged.\n\"Mumps has undoubtedly been with us for millennia, and it's not likely to\ndisappear just because we develop an effective vaccine,\" said Dr Kenneth\nMcIntosh, a disease specialist at Children's Hospital Boston. One pivotal\nlesson derived from the return of the mumps in the late 1980s: a single\ndose of vaccine did not provide enough of a shield. It was then that\ndisease specialists began recommending that children receive 2 doses and\nthat schools bar students who were not vaccinated.\nAs Canadian specialists began investigating this year's outbreak, they\nquickly homed in on the vaccination history of patients, unearthing\nimportant clues. Nearly 73 per cent had received only a single dose of\nvaccine, while 19 per cent had no vaccination at all. Those who received at\nleast one dose generally had milder cases. \"I like to compare this disease\nto a heat-seeking missile,\" said Jeannette Macey, an epidemiologist with\nthe epidemiologist with the Public Health Agency of Canada. \"If there are\npeople in the population who are not protected, it's going to find them.\"\nIn Maine, authorities are collecting comparable data, but they know already\nthat many of the adults who became infected probably only got a single dose\nearlier in life. At the University of Southern Maine, where many of the\nstudents are older, at least 10 people have fallen ill, a spokeswoman said.\nDisease specialists from Maine and the federal CDC are also continuing to\ninvestigate exactly where the virus came from, running sophisticated\ngenetic testing and conducting extensive interviews. \"It's not surprising\nthat Maine would have cases,\" said Dr Dora Mills, director of Maine's CDC.\n\"New Brunswick is adjacent to Maine, and Nova Scotia might as well be,\nbecause there are several boats that go back and forth every day.\"\n[byline: Stephen Smith]\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Brent Barrett\n[There has been a considerable increase in the number of mumps cases\nreported in Maine since the initial report on 20 Nov 2007. The case count\nof 7 confirmed and 24 suspected cases of mumps has risen to at least 75\nconfirmed cases. It may be that as time progresses the State of Maine will\nbe required to instigate a comprehensive vaccination campaign to provide\nprotective immunity to those in the population who have previously received\na single vaccinations or none, to contain this outbreak - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nMumps - Canada (11): (AB) 20071202.3881\nMumps - USA: (ME) 20071121.3777\nMumps - Canada (10): (AB) 20071118.3736\nMumps - Canada (09) (NS) 20071105.3598\nMumps - Canada (08) (multi-province, PEI) 20071025.3473\nMumps - Canada (multi-province) (02) 20070510.1501\nMumps - Canada (NS) (06) 20070501.1411\nMumps - Canada (NS) (02) 20070406.1162\nMumps - Canada (NS): RFI 20070331.1104\n..................cp/ejp/sh\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Before the outbreak, Maine\nhad not reported a case in at least 20 years. Now mumps has spread across\nthe state, reaching its southernmost county and making nearly 75 children\nand adults sick statewide since September [2007].\nDisease trackers suspect that the Maine outbreak was imported from Canada,\nwhere 1140 people have fallen ill this year [2007], 14 times the average\nfor recent years. Most of the cases have been reported by 3 eastern\nprovinces -- Nova Scotia, New Brunswick, and Prince Edward Island.\nSpecialists in Massachusetts are watching the migration of mumps with\nincreasing concern, knowing that many of the patients in Maine and Canada\nare college students, a group particularly susceptible because they are\nmobile and live in tight quarters, an ideal combination for disease\ntransmission.\n\"We are exploring every possible mumps case,\" said Dr Alfred DeMaria,\ndirector of communicable disease control for the Department of Public\nHealth in Massachusetts, where only 3 cases have been reported this year.\n\"We're going to be especially vigilant after the holidays,\" he said,\nbecause Boston students may have contact with students from Maine schools\nduring the break.\nThe resurgence of mumps illustrates the hardiness of a virus, the\nlimitations of a vaccine, and the realities of a world so hooked on air\ntravel that germs can spread from one country to another in a matter of\nhours. Specialists said they believe that is exactly what happened with\nmumps. Like measles, it was a common childhood scourge that appeared headed\nfor extinction in the United States. But in 2005, a strain widely\ncirculating [not terribly common, clinically. - Mod.SH] in the United\nKingdom, where vaccination rates are significantly lower than in North\nAmerica, was imported to a New York state summer camp. Within a year, that\nsame strain was identified as the culprit in a Midwest outbreak. And it is\nbeing blamed for the cases in Canada this year.\n\"Mumps is essentially endemic in the rest of the world,\" said Dr James\nAlexander, a medical epidemiologist at the US Centers for Disease Control\nand Prevention (CDC). \"Canada and the United States were the 2 countries\nwhere mumps was close to being eliminated.\"\nThe virus is transmitted by direct contact with an infected person's\nsaliva, meaning it can travel through a kiss or on utensils, towels, or\ntissues. It causes severe swelling of salivary glands and is heralded by\nfever, headache, body aches, and glandular tenderness where the jaw forms\nan angle. Rarely fatal, it can result in significant complications,\nincluding inflammation of the testes, brain swelling, meningitis, and\nsterility. A vaccine introduced in 1967 led to a steep decline in mumps in\nthe United States, but within 2 decades, the virus had reemerged.\n\"Mumps has undoubtedly been with us for millennia, and it's not likely to\ndisappear just because we develop an effective vaccine,\" said Dr Kenneth\nMcIntosh, a disease specialist at Children's Hospital Boston. One pivotal\nlesson derived from the return of the mumps in the late 1980s: a single\ndose of vaccine did not provide enough of a shield. It was then that\ndisease specialists began recommending that children receive 2 doses and\nthat schools bar students who were not vaccinated.\nAs Canadian specialists began investigating this year's outbreak, they\nquickly homed in on the vaccination history of patients, unearthing\nimportant clues. Nearly 73 per cent had received only a single dose of\nvaccine, while 19 per cent had no vaccination at all. Those who received at\nleast one dose generally had milder cases. \"I like to compare this disease\nto a heat-seeking missile,\" said Jeannette Macey, an epidemiologist with\nthe epidemiologist with the Public Health Agency of Canada. \"If there are\npeople in the population who are not protected, it's going to find them.\"\nIn Maine, authorities are collecting comparable data, but they know already\nthat many of the adults who became infected probably only got a single dose\nearlier in life. At the University of Southern Maine, where many of the\nstudents are older, at least 10 people have fallen ill, a spokeswoman said.\nDisease specialists from Maine and the federal CDC are also continuing to\ninvestigate exactly where the virus came from, running sophisticated\ngenetic testing and conducting extensive interviews. \"It's not surprising\nthat Maine would have cases,\" said Dr Dora Mills, director of Maine's CDC.\n\"New Brunswick is adjacent to Maine, and Nova Scotia might as well be,\nbecause there are several boats that go back and forth every day.\"\n[byline: Stephen Smith]\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Brent Barrett\n[There has been a considerable increase in the number of mumps cases\nreported in Maine since the initial report on 20 Nov 2007. The case count\nof 7 confirmed and 24 suspected cases of mumps has risen to at least 75\nconfirmed cases. It may be that as time progresses the State of Maine will\nbe required to instigate a comprehensive vaccination campaign to provide\nprotective immunity to those in the population who have previously received\na single vaccinations or none, to contain this outbreak - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nMumps - Canada (11): (AB) 20071202.3881\nMumps - USA: (ME) 20071121.3777\nMumps - Canada (10): (AB) 20071118.3736\nMumps - Canada (09) (NS) 20071105.3598\nMumps - Canada (08) (multi-province, PEI) 20071025.3473\nMumps - Canada (multi-province) (02) 20070510.1501\nMumps - Canada (NS) (06) 20070501.1411\nMumps - Canada (NS) (02) 20070406.1162\nMumps - Canada (NS): RFI 20070331.1104\n..................cp/ejp/sh\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Before the outbreak, Maine\nhad not reported a case in at least 20 years. Now mumps has spread across\nthe state, reaching its southernmost county and making nearly 75 children\nand adults sick statewide since September [2007].\nDisease trackers suspect that the Maine outbreak was imported from Canada,\nwhere 1140 people have fallen ill this year [2007], 14 times the average\nfor recent years. Most of the cases have been reported by 3 eastern\nprovinces -- Nova Scotia, New Brunswick, and Prince Edward Island.\nSpecialists in Massachusetts are watching the migration of mumps with\nincreasing concern, knowing that many of the patients in Maine and Canada\nare college students, a group particularly susceptible because they are\nmobile and live in tight quarters, an ideal combination for disease\ntransmission.\n\"We are exploring every possible mumps case,\" said Dr Alfred DeMaria,\ndirector of communicable disease control for the Department of Public\nHealth in Massachusetts, where only 3 cases have been reported this year.\n\"We're going to be especially vigilant after the holidays,\" he said,\nbecause Boston students may have contact with students from Maine schools\nduring the break.\nThe resurgence of mumps illustrates the hardiness of a virus, the\nlimitations of a vaccine, and the realities of a world so hooked on air\ntravel that germs can spread from one country to another in a matter of\nhours. Specialists said they believe that is exactly what happened with\nmumps. Like measles, it was a common childhood scourge that appeared headed\nfor extinction in the United States. But in 2005, a strain widely\ncirculating [not terribly common, clinically. - Mod.SH] in the United\nKingdom, where vaccination rates are significantly lower than in North\nAmerica, was imported to a New York state summer camp. Within a year, that\nsame strain was identified as the culprit in a Midwest outbreak. And it is\nbeing blamed for the cases in Canada this year.\n\"Mumps is essentially endemic in the rest of the world,\" said Dr James\nAlexander, a medical epidemiologist at the US Centers for Disease Control\nand Prevention (CDC). \"Canada and the United States were the 2 countries\nwhere mumps was close to being eliminated.\"\nThe virus is transmitted by direct contact with an infected person's\nsaliva, meaning it can travel through a kiss or on utensils, towels, or\ntissues. It causes severe swelling of salivary glands and is heralded by\nfever, headache, body aches, and glandular tenderness where the jaw forms\nan angle. Rarely fatal, it can result in significant complications,\nincluding inflammation of the testes, brain swelling, meningitis, and\nsterility. A vaccine introduced in 1967 led to a steep decline in mumps in\nthe United States, but within 2 decades, the virus had reemerged.\n\"Mumps has undoubtedly been with us for millennia, and it's not likely to\ndisappear just because we develop an effective vaccine,\" said Dr Kenneth\nMcIntosh, a disease specialist at Children's Hospital Boston. One pivotal\nlesson derived from the return of the mumps in the late 1980s: a single\ndose of vaccine did not provide enough of a shield. It was then that\ndisease specialists began recommending that children receive 2 doses and\nthat schools bar students who were not vaccinated.\nAs Canadian specialists began investigating this year's outbreak, they\nquickly homed in on the vaccination history of patients, unearthing\nimportant clues. Nearly 73 per cent had received only a single dose of\nvaccine, while 19 per cent had no vaccination at all. Those who received at\nleast one dose generally had milder cases. \"I like to compare this disease\nto a heat-seeking missile,\" said Jeannette Macey, an epidemiologist with\nthe epidemiologist with the Public Health Agency of Canada. \"If there are\npeople in the population who are not protected, it's going to find them.\"\nIn Maine, authorities are collecting comparable data, but they know already\nthat many of the adults who became infected probably only got a single dose\nearlier in life. At the University of Southern Maine, where many of the\nstudents are older, at least 10 people have fallen ill, a spokeswoman said.\nDisease specialists from Maine and the federal CDC are also continuing to\ninvestigate exactly where the virus came from, running sophisticated\ngenetic testing and conducting extensive interviews. \"It's not surprising\nthat Maine would have cases,\" said Dr Dora Mills, director of Maine's CDC.\n\"New Brunswick is adjacent to Maine, and Nova Scotia might as well be,\nbecause there are several boats that go back and forth every day.\"\n[byline: Stephen Smith]\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Brent Barrett\n[There has been a considerable increase in the number of mumps cases\nreported in Maine since the initial report on 20 Nov 2007. It may be that as time progresses the State of Maine will\nbe required to instigate a comprehensive vaccination campaign to provide\nprotective immunity to those in the population who have previously received\na single vaccinations or none, to contain this outbreak - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nMumps - Canada (11): (AB) 20071202.3881\nMumps - USA: (ME) 20071121.3777\nMumps - Canada (10): (AB) 20071118.3736\nMumps - Canada (09) (NS) 20071105.3598\nMumps - Canada (08) (multi-province, PEI) 20071025.3473\nMumps - Canada (multi-province) (02) 20070510.1501\nMumps - Canada (NS) (06) 20070501.1411\nMumps - Canada (NS) (02) 20070406.1162\nMumps - Canada (NS): RFI 20070331.1104\n..................cp/ejp/sh\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Medical officer of health, Dr. Robert Strang, has already\nsaid the peak of the outbreak is over but, as part of the normal\ncycle, more cases can be expected for weeks or months to come. And\nStrang says there's the possibility of an \"upswing\" in mumps cases in\nSeptember [2007], when university students return to classes.\nStrang says a vaccination program is being considered for students\nand a meeting has been scheduled for next week with the presidents of\nthe province's universities.\nThe majority of cases have occurred in people between the ages of 20\nand 25. The outbreak in Nova Scotia has also been linked to cases in\nother provinces. In New Brunswick, there have been dozens of cases.\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n[Previously, it was corrected on ProMED-mail that the Canadian mumps\noutbreak originated in the province of New Brunswick (see, \"Mumps -\nCanada (multi-province) (05): corr. 20070529.1720\").\nAs of 25 May 2007, the number of confirmed cases were: Nova Scotia\n302 (now 326), New Brunswick 56, Prince Edward Island 2, Ontario 12,\nAlberta 2, Manitoba 2, and British Columbia 2 (see:\n<http://www.phac-aspc.gc.ca/mumps-oreillons/prof_e.html>. - Medical officer of health, Dr. Robert Strang, has already\nsaid the peak of the outbreak is over but, as part of the normal\ncycle, more cases can be expected for weeks or months to come. And\nStrang says there's the possibility of an \"upswing\" in mumps cases in\nSeptember [2007], when university students return to classes.\nStrang says a vaccination program is being considered for students\nand a meeting has been scheduled for next week with the presidents of\nthe province's universities.\nThe majority of cases have occurred in people between the ages of 20\nand 25. The outbreak in Nova Scotia has also been linked to cases in\nother provinces. In New Brunswick, there have been dozens of cases.\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n[Previously, it was corrected on ProMED-mail that the Canadian mumps\noutbreak originated in the province of New Brunswick (see, \"Mumps -\nCanada (multi-province) (05): corr. 20070529.1720\").\nAs of 25 May 2007, the number of confirmed cases were: Nova Scotia\n302 (now 326), New Brunswick 56, Prince Edward Island 2, Ontario 12,\nAlberta 2, Manitoba 2, and British Columbia 2 (see:\n<http://www.phac-aspc.gc.ca/mumps-oreillons/prof_e.html>. - The outbreak in Nova Scotia has also been linked to cases in\nother provinces. In New Brunswick, there have been dozens of cases.\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n[Previously, it was corrected on ProMED-mail that the Canadian mumps\noutbreak originated in the province of New Brunswick (see, \"Mumps -\nCanada (multi-province) (05): corr. 20070529.1720\").\nAs of 25 May 2007, the number of confirmed cases were: Nova Scotia\n302 (now 326), New Brunswick 56, Prince Edward Island 2, Ontario 12,\nAlberta 2, Manitoba 2, and British Columbia 2 (see:\n<http://www.phac-aspc.gc.ca/mumps-oreillons/prof_e.html>. - For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "mumps"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-02-16 00:00:00", "2021-09-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2007-05-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "NS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Brunswick", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "British Columbia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ukraine", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nanjing", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NE", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "IA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Prince Edward Island", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Mumps - Spain", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2209634", "headline": "PRO/ERR> Mumps - Canada (multi-province) (05): corr.", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2209634", "date": "2007-05-05 21:00:01", "main_text": "MUMPS, CANADA (MULTI-PROVINCE)\n************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mailis a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: Sat 5 May 2007\nSource: Canadian Broadcasting Corporation News, Fri 4 May 2007 [edited]\n\nMumps in Ontario\n----------------\nThere are now several mumps cases in Ontario. Given that the original\nNova Scotia outbreak was largely focussed on college students, it is\nnot surprising that the disease has spread to other provinces as\nclasses have ended and students are travelling back to their home towns.\nCBS News reported in a Fri 4 May [2007] update that health officials\nare considering a re-vaccination campaign for mumps. The province of\nNova Scotia and the Public Health Agency of Canada are looking at\nre-immunizing people against mumps.\nNova Scotia has experienced 203 cases of mumps since February [2007],\nincluding about 50 new cases that have surfaced since last week\n[23-27 Apr 2007], public health officials said on Fri 4 May 2007. New\nBrunswick and Prince Edward Island have also reported cases, mainly\namong young adults in their 20s. Half a dozen cases of mumps have\nspread as far as Ontario.\nMumps is a highly infectious disease that is spread by coughing,\nsneezing, sharing drinks or kissing. Many of the cases spread through\ndowntown bars in Halifax and on the campus of Dalhousie University,\nhealth officials said.\nSince exams wrapped up about 2 weeks ago [20 Apr 2007], most students\nhave left campus and the disease seems to be receding, said Marla\nCranston, a Dalhousie spokeswoman. The province is talking about a\nnew immunization program for university-aged students and health-care\nworkers, said Dr. Shelly Sarwal, a medical officer of health with the\nNova Scotia health department. \"Right now, we're going to start\ndiscussion with the universities and the district health authorities\nto figure out how to make this happen,\" Sarwal said, adding plans\nshould be in place by next week [7-11 May 2007].\n--\nCommunicated by:\nDavid N. Fisman, MD MPH FRCP(C)\nScientist, Child Health Evaluative Sciences\nResearch Institute of the Hospital for Sick Children\nMedical Epidemiologist\nOntario Public Health Laboratories Branch\nRoom 428, 123 Edward Street\nToronto, Ontario, Canada M5G 1E2\n<david.fisman@sickkids.ca>\n******\n[2]\nDate: Sat 5 May 2007\nSource: Toronto Star, Sat 5 May 2007 [edited]\n<http://www.thestar.com/article/210743>\n\nMumps outbreak enters Ontario from Maritimes\n--------------------------------------------\nCanada's mumps outbreak has moved out of the Maritimes and into\nOntario, with 3 confirmed and 5 suspected cases, officials confirmed\nyesterday [4 May 2007].\nIn Nova Scotia, the centre of the outbreak, public health officials\nadmitted they are considering a catch-up vaccination campaign for\nuniversity students and health-care workers, several of whom have\nbecome infected while caring for mumps cases. Previously, officials\nin the province had said that any catch-up campaign -- designed to\ngive a 2nd dose of the combined measles, mumps and rubella vaccine to\nyoung adults who only received one in childhood -- would need to be\ndone in conjunction with other provinces and territories.\n\"Ideally, we'd have the whole country moving together. And we're\nstill working with the other provinces and with the Public Health\nAgency (of Canada),\" said Dr. Shelly Sarwal, a medical officer of\nhealth for the province. \"But, Nova Scotia's going to have to take\nsome steps to protect Nova Scotians.\"\nThis week, there was a significant jump in cases in Nova Scotia, to\n203 from 157, with mumps now being reported in all 9 health regions\nin the province. As of yesterday [4 May 2007], New Brunswick reported\n34 cases and Prince Edward Island remains at one confirmed case. For\nthe 1st time the outbreak has moved out of the Maritimes to Central\nCanada, a development public health officials had warned might occur\nas the university year ended and Halifax students dispersed to their\nhomes throughout the Maritimes and beyond.\nDavid Jensen, a spokesperson with Ontario's Ministry of Health and\nLong-term Care, said the province's 3 confirmed cases -- in the\nOttawa, York and Waterloo public health units -- can all be linked to\nthe Nova Scotia outbreak. Test results are still pending on 5\nsuspected cases. Jensen said physicians and public health officials\nin the province should keep mumps in mind if they see patients who\nhave mumps-like symptoms. These include aches, pains, fever, loss of\nappetite and, in about 40 percent of cases, the hugely swollen saliva\nglands that give mumps its characteristic chipmunk-cheek look.\nThe Nova Scotia outbreak, which began in the 3rd week of February\n[2007], is the province's 3rd in 2 years. It is by far the largest;\nthe earlier outbreaks, in 2005, involved 13 and 19 cases\nrespectively. It is fuelled by a pool of susceptible young adults.\nSarwal said authorities believe many of the province's cases were\nvaccinated with MMR [measles, mumps, rubella vaccine] in childhood,\nbut received only one dose. The one-dose schedule for the MMR vaccine\nwas adequate to protect many people. If it had not been, this\noutbreak would be much larger. But it's now known one dose doesn't\nprotect everyone; MMR is now given in two doses. Nova Scotia is\nleaning heavily towards topping up those it considers susceptible to the virus.\n\"We are looking more seriously at instituting our vaccination\nprograms. An extra dose of MMR for the at-risk groups, which in this\ncase is 2: university students and health-care workers,\" Sarwal said.\nThe vaccination campaign likely can't be mounted quickly enough to\nstamp out this outbreak, but could help prevent additional epidemics, she said.\nThe incubation period for mumps is 12 to 25 days. University\ndormitories and crowded student apartments make for easy spread of\nthe virus among susceptible young adults.\n[Byline: Helen Branswell]\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail copy editor Ed Prucha <edprucha@midcoast.com>\n[These reports record a significant increase in number of mumps cases\namong students in the Maritime provinces of Canada; and more\nsignificantly, the geographical spread of the outbreak to Central\nCanada is noted. Catch-up vaccination of students and healthcare\nworkers is fast becoming a priority. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nMumps - Canada (NS) (06) 20070501.1411\nMumps - Canada (NS) (05) 20070427.1378\nMumps - Canada (NS) (04) 20070422.1312\nMumps - Bulgaria (Plovdiv) 20070306.0793\nMumps - Spain (Navarra) (02): 2006 - 2007 20070216.0577\nMumps - Spain (Navarra) 20070111.0123\n2006\n----\nMumps - Ukraine (Zakarpatye): RFI 20061213.3507\nMumps, village festival - Spain (Navarra) 20061109.3220\nMumps - USA (multistate) (03) 20061027.3079\nMumps - USA (IL) 20061003.2834\nMumps - Fiji 20060913.2596\nMumps - Austria (03) 20060706.1853\nMumps - Austria (Carinthia) 20060608.1598\nMumps - USA: multistate (02) 20060520.1432\nMumps - China (Nanjing) 20060515.1371\nMumps - USA (multistate) 20060421.1163\nMumps - USA (NE, IA) (05) 20060414.1113\nMumps - USA (NE, IA) (04): air travel exposure 20060414.1112\nMumps - UK & Ireland 20041110.3039\nMumps, students - UK 20041103.2974\nMumps - UK (Scotland) (03) 20040223.0575\nMumps - UK (Scotland) 20040220.0545\n2003\n----\nMumps, increase - UK (02) 20031123.2910\nMumps, increase - UK 20030524.1284\n2001\n----\nMumps, consequence of reduced MMRV uptake - UK (02) 20010831.2069\nMumps, consequence of reduced MMRV uptake - UK 20010806.1858\n1999\n----\nMumps & Rubini vaccine - Singapore 19991025.1937\nMumps, imported -
