For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-02-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-05-04 00:00:00", "2021-07-11 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "British Columbia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CANADA", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Ottawa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Brunswick", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ukraine", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nanjing", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Prince Edward Island", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ontario", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Toronto", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NE", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "IA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "mumps", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mumps - Spain", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "10629", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Canada (multi-province)(06)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=10629", "date": "2007-05-05 21:00:01", "main_text": "MUMPS, CANADA (MULTI-PROVINCE)\n************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mailis a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: Sat 5 May 2007\nSource: Canadian Broadcasting Corporation News, Fri 4 May 2007 [edited]\n\nMumps in Ontario\n----------------\nThere are now several mumps cases in Ontario. Given that the original\nNova Scotia outbreak was largely focussed on college students, it is\nnot surprising that the disease has spread to other provinces as\nclasses have ended and students are travelling back to their home towns.\nCBS News reported in a Fri 4 May [2007] update that health officials\nare considering a re-vaccination campaign for mumps. The province of\nNova Scotia and the Public Health Agency of Canada are looking at\nre-immunizing people against mumps.\nNova Scotia has experienced 203 cases of mumps since February [2007],\nincluding about 50 new cases that have surfaced since last week\n[23-27 Apr 2007], public health officials said on Fri 4 May 2007. New\nBrunswick and Prince Edward Island have also reported cases, mainly\namong young adults in their 20s. Half a dozen cases of mumps have\nspread as far as Ontario.\nMumps is a highly infectious disease that is spread by coughing,\nsneezing, sharing drinks or kissing. Many of the cases spread through\ndowntown bars in Halifax and on the campus of Dalhousie University,\nhealth officials said.\nSince exams wrapped up about 2 weeks ago [20 Apr 2007], most students\nhave left campus and the disease seems to be receding, said Marla\nCranston, a Dalhousie spokeswoman. The province is talking about a\nnew immunization program for university-aged students and health-care\nworkers, said Dr. Shelly Sarwal, a medical officer of health with the\nNova Scotia health department. \"Right now, we're going to start\ndiscussion with the universities and the district health authorities\nto figure out how to make this happen,\" Sarwal said, adding plans\nshould be in place by next week [7-11 May 2007].\n--\nCommunicated by:\nDavid N. Fisman, MD MPH FRCP(C)\nScientist, Child Health Evaluative Sciences\nResearch Institute of the Hospital for Sick Children\nMedical Epidemiologist\nOntario Public Health Laboratories Branch\nRoom 428, 123 Edward Street\nToronto, Ontario, Canada M5G 1E2\n<david.fisman@sickkids.ca>\n******\n[2]\nDate: Sat 5 May 2007\nSource: Toronto Star, Sat 5 May 2007 [edited]\n<http://www.thestar.com/article/210743>\n\nMumps outbreak enters Ontario from Maritimes\n--------------------------------------------\nCanada's mumps outbreak has moved out of the Maritimes and into\nOntario, with 3 confirmed and 5 suspected cases, officials confirmed\nyesterday [4 May 2007].\nIn Nova Scotia, the centre of the outbreak, public health officials\nadmitted they are considering a catch-up vaccination campaign for\nuniversity students and health-care workers, several of whom have\nbecome infected while caring for mumps cases. Previously, officials\nin the province had said that any catch-up campaign -- designed to\ngive a 2nd dose of the combined measles, mumps and rubella vaccine to\nyoung adults who only received one in childhood -- would need to be\ndone in conjunction with other provinces and territories.\n\"Ideally, we'd have the whole country moving together. And we're\nstill working with the other provinces and with the Public Health\nAgency (of Canada),\" said Dr. Shelly Sarwal, a medical officer of\nhealth for the province. \"But, Nova Scotia's going to have to take\nsome steps to protect Nova Scotians.\"\nThis week, there was a significant jump in cases in Nova Scotia, to\n203 from 157, with mumps now being reported in all 9 health regions\nin the province. As of yesterday [4 May 2007], New Brunswick reported\n34 cases and Prince Edward Island remains at one confirmed case. For\nthe 1st time the outbreak has moved out of the Maritimes to Central\nCanada, a development public health officials had warned might occur\nas the university year ended and Halifax students dispersed to their\nhomes throughout the Maritimes and beyond.\nDavid Jensen, a spokesperson with Ontario's Ministry of Health and\nLong-term Care, said the province's 3 confirmed cases -- in the\nOttawa, York and Waterloo public health units -- can all be linked to\nthe Nova Scotia outbreak. Test results are still pending on 5\nsuspected cases. Jensen said physicians and public health officials\nin the province should keep mumps in mind if they see patients who\nhave mumps-like symptoms. These include aches, pains, fever, loss of\nappetite and, in about 40 percent of cases, the hugely swollen saliva\nglands that give mumps its characteristic chipmunk-cheek look.\nThe Nova Scotia outbreak, which began in the 3rd week of February\n[2007], is the province's 3rd in 2 years. It is by far the largest;\nthe earlier outbreaks, in 2005, involved 13 and 19 cases\nrespectively. It is fuelled by a pool of susceptible young adults.\nSarwal said authorities believe many of the province's cases were\nvaccinated with MMR [measles, mumps, rubella vaccine] in childhood,\nbut received only one dose. The one-dose schedule for the MMR vaccine\nwas adequate to protect many people. If it had not been, this\noutbreak would be much larger. But it's now known one dose doesn't\nprotect everyone; MMR is now given in two doses. Nova Scotia is\nleaning heavily towards topping up those it considers susceptible to the virus.\n\"We are looking more seriously at instituting our vaccination\nprograms. An extra dose of MMR for the at-risk groups, which in this\ncase is 2: university students and health-care workers,\" Sarwal said.\nThe vaccination campaign likely can't be mounted quickly enough to\nstamp out this outbreak, but could help prevent additional epidemics, she said.\nThe incubation period for mumps is 12 to 25 days. University\ndormitories and crowded student apartments make for easy spread of\nthe virus among susceptible young adults.\n[Byline: Helen Branswell]\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail copy editor Ed Prucha <edprucha@midcoast.com>\n[These reports record a significant increase in number of mumps cases\namong students in the Maritime provinces of Canada; and more\nsignificantly, the geographical spread of the outbreak to Central\nCanada is noted. Catch-up vaccination of students and healthcare\nworkers is fast becoming a priority. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nMumps - Canada (NS) (06) 20070501.1411\nMumps - Canada (NS) (05) 20070427.1378\nMumps - Canada (NS) (04) 20070422.1312\nMumps - Canada (NS) (03) 20070409.1189\nMumps - Canada (NS) (02) 20070406.1162\nMumps - Canada (NS): RFI 20070331.1104\nMumps - Bulgaria: supplementary vaccination 20070322.1007\nMumps - Hungary (Heves) ex Ukraine 20070329.1087\nMumps - Bulgaria (Plovdiv) 20070306.0793\nMumps - Spain (Navarra) (02): 2006 - 2007 20070216.0577\nMumps - Spain (Navarra) 20070111.0123\n2006\n----\nMumps - Ukraine (Zakarpatye): RFI 20061213.3507\nMumps, village festival - USA: multistate (02) 20060520.1432\nMumps - China (Nanjing) 20060515.1371\nMumps - USA (multistate) 20060421.1163\nMumps - USA (NE, IA) (05) 20060414.1113\nMumps - USA (NE, IA) (04): air travel exposure 20060414.1112\nMumps - USA (NE, IA) 20060403.1000\nMumps virus, genotype G - USA (IA) 20060315.0809\n2004\n----\nMumps, students - UK (02) 20041126.3166\nMumps, students - UK & Ireland (03) 20041117.3089\nMumps, students - UK & Ireland 20041110.3039\nMumps, students - UK 20041103.2974\nMumps - UK (Scotland) (03) 20040223.0575\nMumps - UK (Scotland) 20040220.0545\n2003\n----\nMumps, increase - UK (02) 20031123.2910\nMumps, increase - UK 20030524.1284\n2001\n----\nMumps, consequence of reduced MMRV uptake - UK (02) 20010831.2069\nMumps, consequence of reduced MMRV uptake - UK 20010806.1858\n1999\n----\nMumps & Rubini vaccine - Singapore 19991025.1937\nMumps, imported - UK: RFI 19990223.0241\n1997\n----\nMumps - Canada (British Columbia) (02) 19971123.2351\nMumps - Canada (British Columbia) 19971119.2336\n1995\n----\nMumps surveillance - US (MMWR Supplement SS-3) 19950811.0672\n.......................cp/ejp/dk\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-02-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-05-04 00:00:00", "2021-07-11 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "British Columbia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CANADA", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Ottawa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Brunswick", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ukraine", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nanjing", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Prince Edward Island", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ontario", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Toronto", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NE", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "IA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "mumps", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mumps - Spain", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "10616", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Canada (multi-province) (05)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=10616", "date": "2007-05-05 21:00:01", "main_text": "MUMPS, CANADA (MULTI-PROVINCE)\n************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mailis a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: Sat 5 May 2007\nSource: Canadian Broadcasting Corporation News, Fri 4 May 2007 [edited]\n\nMumps in Ontario\n----------------\nThere are now several mumps cases in Ontario. Given that the original\nNova Scotia outbreak was largely focussed on college students, it is\nnot surprising that the disease has spread to other provinces as\nclasses have ended and students are travelling back to their home towns.\nCBS News reported in a Fri 4 May [2007] update that health officials\nare considering a re-vaccination campaign for mumps. The province of\nNova Scotia and the Public Health Agency of Canada are looking at\nre-immunizing people against mumps.\nNova Scotia has experienced 203 cases of mumps since February [2007],\nincluding about 50 new cases that have surfaced since last week\n[23-27 Apr 2007], public health officials said on Fri 4 May 2007. New\nBrunswick and Prince Edward Island have also reported cases, mainly\namong young adults in their 20s. Half a dozen cases of mumps have\nspread as far as Ontario.\nMumps is a highly infectious disease that is spread by coughing,\nsneezing, sharing drinks or kissing. Many of the cases spread through\ndowntown bars in Halifax and on the campus of Dalhousie University,\nhealth officials said.\nSince exams wrapped up about 2 weeks ago [20 Apr 2007], most students\nhave left campus and the disease seems to be receding, said Marla\nCranston, a Dalhousie spokeswoman. The province is talking about a\nnew immunization program for university-aged students and health-care\nworkers, said Dr. Shelly Sarwal, a medical officer of health with the\nNova Scotia health department. \"Right now, we're going to start\ndiscussion with the universities and the district health authorities\nto figure out how to make this happen,\" Sarwal said, adding plans\nshould be in place by next week [7-11 May 2007].\n--\nCommunicated by:\nDavid N. Fisman, MD MPH FRCP(C)\nScientist, Child Health Evaluative Sciences\nResearch Institute of the Hospital for Sick Children\nMedical Epidemiologist\nOntario Public Health Laboratories Branch\nRoom 428, 123 Edward Street\nToronto, Ontario, Canada M5G 1E2\n<david.fisman@sickkids.ca>\n******\n[2]\nDate: Sat 5 May 2007\nSource: Toronto Star, Sat 5 May 2007 [edited]\n<http://www.thestar.com/article/210743>\n\nMumps outbreak enters Ontario from Maritimes\n--------------------------------------------\nCanada's mumps outbreak has moved out of the Maritimes and into\nOntario, with 3 confirmed and 5 suspected cases, officials confirmed\nyesterday [4 May 2007].\nIn Nova Scotia, the centre of the outbreak, public health officials\nadmitted they are considering a catch-up vaccination campaign for\nuniversity students and health-care workers, several of whom have\nbecome infected while caring for mumps cases. Previously, officials\nin the province had said that any catch-up campaign -- designed to\ngive a 2nd dose of the combined measles, mumps and rubella vaccine to\nyoung adults who only received one in childhood -- would need to be\ndone in conjunction with other provinces and territories.\n\"Ideally, we'd have the whole country moving together. And we're\nstill working with the other provinces and with the Public Health\nAgency (of Canada),\" said Dr. Shelly Sarwal, a medical officer of\nhealth for the province. \"But, Nova Scotia's going to have to take\nsome steps to protect Nova Scotians.\"\nThis week, there was a significant jump in cases in Nova Scotia, to\n203 from 157, with mumps now being reported in all 9 health regions\nin the province. As of yesterday [4 May 2007], New Brunswick reported\n34 cases and Prince Edward Island remains at one confirmed case. For\nthe 1st time the outbreak has moved out of the Maritimes to Central\nCanada, a development public health officials had warned might occur\nas the university year ended and Halifax students dispersed to their\nhomes throughout the Maritimes and beyond.\nDavid Jensen, a spokesperson with Ontario's Ministry of Health and\nLong-term Care, said the province's 3 confirmed cases -- in the\nOttawa, York and Waterloo public health units -- can all be linked to\nthe Nova Scotia outbreak. Test results are still pending on 5\nsuspected cases. Jensen said physicians and public health officials\nin the province should keep mumps in mind if they see patients who\nhave mumps-like symptoms. These include aches, pains, fever, loss of\nappetite and, in about 40 percent of cases, the hugely swollen saliva\nglands that give mumps its characteristic chipmunk-cheek look.\nThe Nova Scotia outbreak, which began in the 3rd week of February\n[2007], is the province's 3rd in 2 years. It is by far the largest;\nthe earlier outbreaks, in 2005, involved 13 and 19 cases\nrespectively. It is fuelled by a pool of susceptible young adults.\nSarwal said authorities believe many of the province's cases were\nvaccinated with MMR [measles, mumps, rubella vaccine] in childhood,\nbut received only one dose. The one-dose schedule for the MMR vaccine\nwas adequate to protect many people. If it had not been, this\noutbreak would be much larger. But it's now known one dose doesn't\nprotect everyone; MMR is now given in two doses. Nova Scotia is\nleaning heavily towards topping up those it considers susceptible to the virus.\n\"We are looking more seriously at instituting our vaccination\nprograms. An extra dose of MMR for the at-risk groups, which in this\ncase is 2: university students and health-care workers,\" Sarwal said.\nThe vaccination campaign likely can't be mounted quickly enough to\nstamp out this outbreak, but could help prevent additional epidemics, she said.\nThe incubation period for mumps is 12 to 25 days. University\ndormitories and crowded student apartments make for easy spread of\nthe virus among susceptible young adults.\n[Byline: Helen Branswell]\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail copy editor Ed Prucha <edprucha@midcoast.com>\n[These reports record a significant increase in number of mumps cases\namong students in the Maritime provinces of Canada; and more\nsignificantly, the geographical spread of the outbreak to Central\nCanada is noted. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-02-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-05-04 00:00:00", "2021-07-11 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "British Columbia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CANADA", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Ottawa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Brunswick", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ukraine", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nanjing", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Prince Edward Island", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ontario", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Toronto", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NE", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "IA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "mumps", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mumps - Given that the original\nNova Scotia outbreak was largely focussed on college students, it is\nnot surprising that the disease has spread to other provinces as\nclasses have ended and students are travelling back to their home towns.\nCBS News reported in a Fri 4 May [2007] update that health officials\nare considering a re-vaccination campaign for mumps. The province of\nNova Scotia and the Public Health Agency of Canada are looking at\nre-immunizing people against mumps.\nNova Scotia has experienced 203 cases of mumps since February [2007],\nincluding about 50 new cases that have surfaced since last week\n[23-27 Apr 2007], public health officials said on Fri 4 May 2007. New\nBrunswick and Prince Edward Island have also reported cases, mainly\namong young adults in their 20s. Half a dozen cases of mumps have\nspread as far as Ontario.\nMumps is a highly infectious disease that is spread by coughing,\nsneezing, sharing drinks or kissing. Many of the cases spread through\ndowntown bars in Halifax and on the campus of Dalhousie University,\nhealth officials said.\nSince exams wrapped up about 2 weeks ago [20 Apr 2007], most students\nhave left campus and the disease seems to be receding, said Marla\nCranston, a Dalhousie spokeswoman. The province is talking about a\nnew immunization program for university-aged students and health-care\nworkers, said Dr. Shelly Sarwal, a medical officer of health with the\nNova Scotia health department. \"Right now, we're going to start\ndiscussion with the universities and the district health authorities\nto figure out how to make this happen,\" Sarwal said, adding plans\nshould be in place by next week [7-11 May 2007].\n--\nCommunicated by:\nDavid N. Fisman, MD MPH FRCP(C)\nScientist, Child Health Evaluative Sciences\nResearch Institute of the Hospital for Sick Children\nMedical Epidemiologist\nOntario Public Health Laboratories Branch\nRoom 428, 123 Edward Street\nToronto, Ontario, Canada M5G 1E2\n<david.fisman@sickkids.ca>\n******\n[2]\nDate: Sat 5 May 2007\nSource: Toronto Star, Sat 5 May 2007 [edited]\n<http://www.thestar.com/article/210743>\n\nMumps outbreak enters Ontario from Maritimes\n--------------------------------------------\nCanada's mumps outbreak has moved out of the Maritimes and into\nOntario, with 3 confirmed and 5 suspected cases, officials confirmed\nyesterday [4 May 2007].\nIn Nova Scotia, the centre of the outbreak, public health officials\nadmitted they are considering a catch-up vaccination campaign for\nuniversity students and health-care workers, several of whom have\nbecome infected while caring for mumps cases. Previously, officials\nin the province had said that any catch-up campaign -- designed to\ngive a 2nd dose of the combined measles, mumps and rubella vaccine to\nyoung adults who only received one in childhood -- would need to be\ndone in conjunction with other provinces and territories.\n\"Ideally, we'd have the whole country moving together. And we're\nstill working with the other provinces and with the Public Health\nAgency (of Canada),\" said Dr. Shelly Sarwal, a medical officer of\nhealth for the province. \"But, Nova Scotia's going to have to take\nsome steps to protect Nova Scotians.\"\nThis week, there was a significant jump in cases in Nova Scotia, to\n203 from 157, with mumps now being reported in all 9 health regions\nin the province. As of yesterday [4 May 2007], New Brunswick reported\n34 cases and Prince Edward Island remains at one confirmed case. For\nthe 1st time the outbreak has moved out of the Maritimes to Central\nCanada, a development public health officials had warned might occur\nas the university year ended and Halifax students dispersed to their\nhomes throughout the Maritimes and beyond.\nDavid Jensen, a spokesperson with Ontario's Ministry of Health and\nLong-term Care, said the province's 3 confirmed cases -- in the\nOttawa, York and Waterloo public health units -- can all be linked to\nthe Nova Scotia outbreak. Test results are still pending on 5\nsuspected cases. Jensen said physicians and public health officials\nin the province should keep mumps in mind if they see patients who\nhave mumps-like symptoms. These include aches, pains, fever, loss of\nappetite and, in about 40 percent of cases, the hugely swollen saliva\nglands that give mumps its characteristic chipmunk-cheek look.\nThe Nova Scotia outbreak, which began in the 3rd week of February\n[2007], is the province's 3rd in 2 years. It is by far the largest;\nthe earlier outbreaks, in 2005, involved 13 and 19 cases\nrespectively. It is fuelled by a pool of susceptible young adults.\nSarwal said authorities believe many of the province's cases were\nvaccinated with MMR [measles, mumps, rubella vaccine] in childhood,\nbut received only one dose. The one-dose schedule for the MMR vaccine\nwas adequate to protect many people. If it had not been, this\noutbreak would be much larger. But it's now known one dose doesn't\nprotect everyone; MMR is now given in two doses. Nova Scotia is\nleaning heavily towards topping up those it considers susceptible to the virus.\n\"We are looking more seriously at instituting our vaccination\nprograms. An extra dose of MMR for the at-risk groups, which in this\ncase is 2: university students and health-care workers,\" Sarwal said.\nThe vaccination campaign likely can't be mounted quickly enough to\nstamp out this outbreak, but could help prevent additional epidemics, she said.\nThe incubation period for mumps is 12 to 25 days. University\ndormitories and crowded student apartments make for easy spread of\nthe virus among susceptible young adults.\n[Byline: Helen Branswell]\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail copy editor Ed Prucha <edprucha@midcoast.com>\n[These reports record a significant increase in number of mumps cases\namong students in the Maritime provinces of Canada; and more\nsignificantly, the geographical spread of the outbreak to Central\nCanada is noted. Catch-up vaccination of students and healthcare\nworkers is fast becoming a priority. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nMumps - Canada (NS) (06) 20070501.1411\nMumps - Canada (NS) (05) 20070427.1378\nMumps - Canada (NS) (04) 20070422.1312\nMumps - Bulgaria (Plovdiv) 20070306.0793\nMumps - Spain (Navarra) (02): 2006 - 2007 20070216.0577\nMumps - Spain (Navarra) 20070111.0123\n2006\n----\nMumps - Ukraine (Zakarpatye): RFI 20061213.3507\nMumps, village festival - For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-02-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-05-04 00:00:00", "2021-07-11 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "British Columbia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CANADA", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Ottawa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Brunswick", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ukraine", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nanjing", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Prince Edward Island", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ontario", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Toronto", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NE", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "IA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "mumps", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mumps - Spain", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "10326", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Canada (multi-province) (03)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=10326", "date": "2007-05-05 21:00:01", "main_text": "MUMPS, CANADA (MULTI-PROVINCE)\n************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mailis a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: Sat 5 May 2007\nSource: Canadian Broadcasting Corporation News, Fri 4 May 2007 [edited]\n\nMumps in Ontario\n----------------\nThere are now several mumps cases in Ontario. Given that the original\nNova Scotia outbreak was largely focussed on college students, it is\nnot surprising that the disease has spread to other provinces as\nclasses have ended and students are travelling back to their home towns.\nCBS News reported in a Fri 4 May [2007] update that health officials\nare considering a re-vaccination campaign for mumps. The province of\nNova Scotia and the Public Health Agency of Canada are looking at\nre-immunizing people against mumps.\nNova Scotia has experienced 203 cases of mumps since February [2007],\nincluding about 50 new cases that have surfaced since last week\n[23-27 Apr 2007], public health officials said on Fri 4 May 2007. New\nBrunswick and Prince Edward Island have also reported cases, mainly\namong young adults in their 20s. Half a dozen cases of mumps have\nspread as far as Ontario.\nMumps is a highly infectious disease that is spread by coughing,\nsneezing, sharing drinks or kissing. Many of the cases spread through\ndowntown bars in Halifax and on the campus of Dalhousie University,\nhealth officials said.\nSince exams wrapped up about 2 weeks ago [20 Apr 2007], most students\nhave left campus and the disease seems to be receding, said Marla\nCranston, a Dalhousie spokeswoman. The province is talking about a\nnew immunization program for university-aged students and health-care\nworkers, said Dr. Shelly Sarwal, a medical officer of health with the\nNova Scotia health department. \"Right now, we're going to start\ndiscussion with the universities and the district health authorities\nto figure out how to make this happen,\" Sarwal said, adding plans\nshould be in place by next week [7-11 May 2007].\n--\nCommunicated by:\nDavid N. Fisman, MD MPH FRCP(C)\nScientist, Child Health Evaluative Sciences\nResearch Institute of the Hospital for Sick Children\nMedical Epidemiologist\nOntario Public Health Laboratories Branch\nRoom 428, 123 Edward Street\nToronto, Ontario, Canada M5G 1E2\n<david.fisman@sickkids.ca>\n******\n[2]\nDate: Sat 5 May 2007\nSource: Toronto Star, Sat 5 May 2007 [edited]\n<http://www.thestar.com/article/210743>\n\nMumps outbreak enters Ontario from Maritimes\n--------------------------------------------\nCanada's mumps outbreak has moved out of the Maritimes and into\nOntario, with 3 confirmed and 5 suspected cases, officials confirmed\nyesterday [4 May 2007].\nIn Nova Scotia, the centre of the outbreak, public health officials\nadmitted they are considering a catch-up vaccination campaign for\nuniversity students and health-care workers, several of whom have\nbecome infected while caring for mumps cases. Previously, officials\nin the province had said that any catch-up campaign -- designed to\ngive a 2nd dose of the combined measles, mumps and rubella vaccine to\nyoung adults who only received one in childhood -- would need to be\ndone in conjunction with other provinces and territories.\n\"Ideally, we'd have the whole country moving together. And we're\nstill working with the other provinces and with the Public Health\nAgency (of Canada),\" said Dr. Shelly Sarwal, a medical officer of\nhealth for the province. \"But, Nova Scotia's going to have to take\nsome steps to protect Nova Scotians.\"\nThis week, there was a significant jump in cases in Nova Scotia, to\n203 from 157, with mumps now being reported in all 9 health regions\nin the province. As of yesterday [4 May 2007], New Brunswick reported\n34 cases and Prince Edward Island remains at one confirmed case. For\nthe 1st time the outbreak has moved out of the Maritimes to Central\nCanada, a development public health officials had warned might occur\nas the university year ended and Halifax students dispersed to their\nhomes throughout the Maritimes and beyond.\nDavid Jensen, a spokesperson with Ontario's Ministry of Health and\nLong-term Care, said the province's 3 confirmed cases -- in the\nOttawa, York and Waterloo public health units -- can all be linked to\nthe Nova Scotia outbreak. Test results are still pending on 5\nsuspected cases. Jensen said physicians and public health officials\nin the province should keep mumps in mind if they see patients who\nhave mumps-like symptoms. These include aches, pains, fever, loss of\nappetite and, in about 40 percent of cases, the hugely swollen saliva\nglands that give mumps its characteristic chipmunk-cheek look.\nThe Nova Scotia outbreak, which began in the 3rd week of February\n[2007], is the province's 3rd in 2 years. It is by far the largest;\nthe earlier outbreaks, in 2005, involved 13 and 19 cases\nrespectively. It is fuelled by a pool of susceptible young adults.\nSarwal said authorities believe many of the province's cases were\nvaccinated with MMR [measles, mumps, rubella vaccine] in childhood,\nbut received only one dose. The one-dose schedule for the MMR vaccine\nwas adequate to protect many people. If it had not been, this\noutbreak would be much larger. But it's now known one dose doesn't\nprotect everyone; MMR is now given in two doses. Nova Scotia is\nleaning heavily towards topping up those it considers susceptible to the virus.\n\"We are looking more seriously at instituting our vaccination\nprograms. An extra dose of MMR for the at-risk groups, which in this\ncase is 2: university students and health-care workers,\" Sarwal said.\nThe vaccination campaign likely can't be mounted quickly enough to\nstamp out this outbreak, but could help prevent additional epidemics, she said.\nThe incubation period for mumps is 12 to 25 days. University\ndormitories and crowded student apartments make for easy spread of\nthe virus among susceptible young adults.\n[Byline: Helen Branswell]\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail copy editor Ed Prucha <edprucha@midcoast.com>\n[These reports record a significant increase in number of mumps cases\namong students in the Maritime provinces of Canada; and more\nsignificantly, the geographical spread of the outbreak to Central\nCanada is noted. Catch-up vaccination of students and healthcare\nworkers is fast becoming a priority. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nMumps - Canada (NS) (06) 20070501.1411\nMumps - Canada (NS) (05) 20070427.1378\nMumps - Canada (NS) (04) 20070422.1312\nMumps - Bulgaria (Plovdiv) 20070306.0793\nMumps - Spain (Navarra) (02): 2006 - 2007 20070216.0577\nMumps - Spain (Navarra) 20070111.0123\n2006\n----\nMumps - Ukraine (Zakarpatye): RFI 20061213.3507\nMumps, village festival - UK 20030524.1284\n2001\n----\nMumps, consequence of reduced MMRV uptake - UK (02) 20010831.2069\nMumps, consequence of reduced MMRV uptake - UK 20010806.1858\n1999\n----\nMumps & Rubini vaccine - Singapore 19991025.1937\nMumps, imported - UK: RFI 19990223.0241\n1997\n----\nMumps - Canada (British Columbia) (02) 19971123.2351\nMumps - Canada (British Columbia) 19971119.2336\n1995\n----\nMumps surveillance - US (MMWR Supplement SS-3) 19950811.0672\n.......................cp/ejp/dk\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The province of\nNova Scotia and the Public Health Agency of Canada are looking at\nre-immunizing people against mumps.\nNova Scotia has experienced 203 cases of mumps since February [2007],\nincluding about 50 new cases that have surfaced since last week\n[23-27 Apr 2007], public health officials said on Fri 4 May 2007. New\nBrunswick and Prince Edward Island have also reported cases, mainly\namong young adults in their 20s. Half a dozen cases of mumps have\nspread as far as Ontario.\nMumps is a highly infectious disease that is spread by coughing,\nsneezing, sharing drinks or kissing. Many of the cases spread through\ndowntown bars in Halifax and on the campus of Dalhousie University,\nhealth officials said.\nSince exams wrapped up about 2 weeks ago [20 Apr 2007], most students\nhave left campus and the disease seems to be receding, said Marla\nCranston, a Dalhousie spokeswoman. It is fuelled by a pool of susceptible young adults.\nSarwal said authorities believe many of the province's cases were\nvaccinated with MMR [measles, mumps, rubella vaccine] in childhood,\nbut received only one dose. The one-dose schedule for the MMR vaccine\nwas adequate to protect many people. If it had not been, this\noutbreak would be much larger. But it's now known one dose doesn't\nprotect everyone; MMR is now given in two doses. Nova Scotia is\nleaning heavily towards topping up those it considers susceptible to the virus.\n\"We are looking more seriously at instituting our vaccination\nprograms. An extra dose of MMR for the at-risk groups, which in this\ncase is 2: university students and health-care workers,\" Sarwal said.\nThe vaccination campaign likely can't be mounted quickly enough to\nstamp out this outbreak, but could help prevent additional epidemics, she said.\nThe incubation period for mumps is 12 to 25 days. University\ndormitories and crowded student apartments make for easy spread of\nthe virus among susceptible young adults.\n[Byline: Helen Branswell]\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail copy editor Ed Prucha <edprucha@midcoast.com>\n[These reports record a significant increase in number of mumps cases\namong students in the Maritime provinces of Canada; and more\nsignificantly, the geographical spread of the outbreak to Central\nCanada is noted. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-02-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-05-04 00:00:00", "2021-07-11 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "British Columbia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CANADA", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Ottawa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Brunswick", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ukraine", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nanjing", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Prince Edward Island", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ontario", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Toronto", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NE", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "IA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "mumps", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mumps - Spain", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "10158", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps, Canada (multi-province)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=10158", "date": "2007-05-05 21:00:01", "main_text": "MUMPS, CANADA (MULTI-PROVINCE)\n************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mailis a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: Sat 5 May 2007\nSource: Canadian Broadcasting Corporation News, Fri 4 May 2007 [edited]\n\nMumps in Ontario\n----------------\nThere are now several mumps cases in Ontario. Given that the original\nNova Scotia outbreak was largely focussed on college students, it is\nnot surprising that the disease has spread to other provinces as\nclasses have ended and students are travelling back to their home towns.\nCBS News reported in a Fri 4 May [2007] update that health officials\nare considering a re-vaccination campaign for mumps. The province of\nNova Scotia and the Public Health Agency of Canada are looking at\nre-immunizing people against mumps.\nNova Scotia has experienced 203 cases of mumps since February [2007],\nincluding about 50 new cases that have surfaced since last week\n[23-27 Apr 2007], public health officials said on Fri 4 May 2007. New\nBrunswick and Prince Edward Island have also reported cases, mainly\namong young adults in their 20s. Half a dozen cases of mumps have\nspread as far as Ontario.\nMumps is a highly infectious disease that is spread by coughing,\nsneezing, sharing drinks or kissing. Many of the cases spread through\ndowntown bars in Halifax and on the campus of Dalhousie University,\nhealth officials said.\nSince exams wrapped up about 2 weeks ago [20 Apr 2007], most students\nhave left campus and the disease seems to be receding, said Marla\nCranston, a Dalhousie spokeswoman. The province is talking about a\nnew immunization program for university-aged students and health-care\nworkers, said Dr. Shelly Sarwal, a medical officer of health with the\nNova Scotia health department. \"Right now, we're going to start\ndiscussion with the universities and the district health authorities\nto figure out how to make this happen,\" Sarwal said, adding plans\nshould be in place by next week [7-11 May 2007].\n--\nCommunicated by:\nDavid N. Fisman, MD MPH FRCP(C)\nScientist, Child Health Evaluative Sciences\nResearch Institute of the Hospital for Sick Children\nMedical Epidemiologist\nOntario Public Health Laboratories Branch\nRoom 428, 123 Edward Street\nToronto, Ontario, Canada M5G 1E2\n<david.fisman@sickkids.ca>\n******\n[2]\nDate: Sat 5 May 2007\nSource: Toronto Star, Sat 5 May 2007 [edited]\n<http://www.thestar.com/article/210743>\n\nMumps outbreak enters Ontario from Maritimes\n--------------------------------------------\nCanada's mumps outbreak has moved out of the Maritimes and into\nOntario, with 3 confirmed and 5 suspected cases, officials confirmed\nyesterday [4 May 2007].\nIn Nova Scotia, the centre of the outbreak, public health officials\nadmitted they are considering a catch-up vaccination campaign for\nuniversity students and health-care workers, several of whom have\nbecome infected while caring for mumps cases. Previously, officials\nin the province had said that any catch-up campaign -- designed to\ngive a 2nd dose of the combined measles, mumps and rubella vaccine to\nyoung adults who only received one in childhood -- would need to be\ndone in conjunction with other provinces and territories.\n\"Ideally, we'd have the whole country moving together. And we're\nstill working with the other provinces and with the Public Health\nAgency (of Canada),\" said Dr. Shelly Sarwal, a medical officer of\nhealth for the province. \"But, Nova Scotia's going to have to take\nsome steps to protect Nova Scotians.\"\nThis week, there was a significant jump in cases in Nova Scotia, to\n203 from 157, with mumps now being reported in all 9 health regions\nin the province. As of yesterday [4 May 2007], New Brunswick reported\n34 cases and Prince Edward Island remains at one confirmed case. For\nthe 1st time the outbreak has moved out of the Maritimes to Central\nCanada, a development public health officials had warned might occur\nas the university year ended and Halifax students dispersed to their\nhomes throughout the Maritimes and beyond.\nDavid Jensen, a spokesperson with Ontario's Ministry of Health and\nLong-term Care, said the province's 3 confirmed cases -- in the\nOttawa, York and Waterloo public health units -- can all be linked to\nthe Nova Scotia outbreak. Test results are still pending on 5\nsuspected cases. Jensen said physicians and public health officials\nin the province should keep mumps in mind if they see patients who\nhave mumps-like symptoms. These include aches, pains, fever, loss of\nappetite and, in about 40 percent of cases, the hugely swollen saliva\nglands that give mumps its characteristic chipmunk-cheek look.\nThe Nova Scotia outbreak, which began in the 3rd week of February\n[2007], is the province's 3rd in 2 years. It is by far the largest;\nthe earlier outbreaks, in 2005, involved 13 and 19 cases\nrespectively. It is fuelled by a pool of susceptible young adults.\nSarwal said authorities believe many of the province's cases were\nvaccinated with MMR [measles, mumps, rubella vaccine] in childhood,\nbut received only one dose. The one-dose schedule for the MMR vaccine\nwas adequate to protect many people. If it had not been, this\noutbreak would be much larger. But it's now known one dose doesn't\nprotect everyone; MMR is now given in two doses. Nova Scotia is\nleaning heavily towards topping up those it considers susceptible to the virus.\n\"We are looking more seriously at instituting our vaccination\nprograms. An extra dose of MMR for the at-risk groups, which in this\ncase is 2: university students and health-care workers,\" Sarwal said.\nThe vaccination campaign likely can't be mounted quickly enough to\nstamp out this outbreak, but could help prevent additional epidemics, she said.\nThe incubation period for mumps is 12 to 25 days. University\ndormitories and crowded student apartments make for easy spread of\nthe virus among susceptible young adults.\n[Byline: Helen Branswell]\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail copy editor Ed Prucha <edprucha@midcoast.com>\n[These reports record a significant increase in number of mumps cases\namong students in the Maritime provinces of Canada; and more\nsignificantly, the geographical spread of the outbreak to Central\nCanada is noted. Catch-up vaccination of students and healthcare\nworkers is fast becoming a priority. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nMumps - Canada (NS) (06) 20070501.1411\nMumps - Canada (NS) (05) 20070427.1378\nMumps - Canada (NS) (04) 20070422.1312\nMumps - For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-02-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-05-04 00:00:00", "2021-07-11 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "British Columbia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CANADA", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Ottawa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Brunswick", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ukraine", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nanjing", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Prince Edward Island", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ontario", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Toronto", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NE", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "IA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "mumps", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mumps - Spain", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "10058", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Canada (NS) (06)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=10058", "date": "2007-03-22 20:00:02", "main_text": "MUMPS - BULGARIA: SUPPLEMENTARY VACCINATION\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu 22 Mar 2007\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Eurosurveillance weekly release Vol. 12, Issue 3 [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/2007/070322.asp#4>\n\nMumps outbreak in Bulgaria, 2007: a preliminary report\n-----------------------------------------------\nThere is an ongoing mumps outbreak in Bulgaria, with a total of 997\ncases notified between 1 Jan and 18 Mar 2007. This number includes\nlaboratory-confirmed and probable epidemiologically-linked clinical\ncases in line with the EU case definition and case classification\nthat have been adopted for mumps surveillance purposes in Bulgaria\nsince 2005 [1].\nFor comparison, only 22 cases were reported in the 1st 11 weeks of\n2005, and 311 cases were registered in the same period in 2006.\nAltogether, 608 cases were notified in 2005, and 919 cases were\nreported during 2006. An increase of the number of reported cases was\nnoted already in 2006, and since the beginning of 2007, the number of\ncases has continued to rise. [The text at this point is supplemented\nby a figure plotting reported mumps cases during weeks 1 to 11 in\n2005 (n=22), 2006 (n=311) and 2007 (n=997)].\nThe present mumps epidemic affects mostly teenagers and young adults.\nMore than 60 percent of the cases reported in 2007 occurred in\npatients aged 15 to 19 years, and about 20 percent in patients aged\n20 to 24 years. To date, 112 out of 997 cases (11.2 percent) have\nbeen laboratory-confirmed.\nConclusion\n----------\nThe outbreak investigation is still ongoing, but preliminary data\nindicate that the predominance of patients in age groups 15-19 and\n20-24 years may be a result of poor immunisation of these birth\ncohorts in general. About 1/3rd of patients aged 15 to 19 years have\nnot been vaccinated at all, whereas more than half have received only\none dose of monovalent mumps vaccine strain Leningrad 3, which has\nbeen shown to have a lower effectiveness [2]. Among the 20- to\n24-year-old patients, over 90 percent have never been immunised against mumps.\nVaccination against mumps in Bulgaria started in 1972, and a routine\nmumps immunisation program was launched in 1976. However, different\nvaccine strains and vaccines have been used, and different\nimmunisation strategies implemented, including a suspension of mumps\nimmunisation for almost 4 years during the period 1982 to 1986.\nDue to the past changes in the immunisation program and occasionally\nincomplete immunisation coverage, the conditions in which outbreaks\ncan occur still exist, despite the current up-to-date mumps\nimmunisation strategy.\nControl measures\n----------------\nA risk assessment carried out following the outbreak concluded that\nbirth cohorts 1982 to 1992 that are at higher risk of mumps infection\nshould be offered supplementary mumps immunisation.\nAs a result, the Bulgarian Ministry of Health decided to provide\nsupplementary doses of MMR vaccine and to conduct immunisation\ncampaigns targeted at these cohorts. In early March 2007, the\nMinistry of Health organized a meeting to inform regional\nepidemiologists about the situation and to discuss with them the need\nfor strengthening disease surveillance and undertaking control\nmeasures to prevent further spread of mumps. Furthermore,\ncommunication aimed at the general public, conveying information\nabout the risks related to mumps infection and the preventive\nmeasures, including immunisation, has been intensified through the\nparticipation of national experts in a series of briefings, TV and\nradio broadcasts.\nA longer article on the epidemiology of mumps in Bulgaria, including\na detailed risk assessment, is planned for publication in the monthly\nrelease of Eurosurveillance.\nReferences\n----------\n(1.) Commission decision of 19 Mar 2002 laying down case definitions\nfor reporting communicable diseases to the Community network under\nDecision No 2119/98/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council\n(2002/253/EC), Official Journal of the European Communities\n03.04.2002. Available from:\n<http://europa.eu.int/eur-lex/pri/en/oj/dat/2002/l_086/l_08620020403en00440062.pdf>.\n(2.) Gatcheva N, Tchakov B, Vladimirova N. Analysis of immunisations\nperformed in 1991. NCIPD Information Journal, 5, 1992; 50-62. (In Bulgarian).\n[Reported by: M Kojouharova <mkojouharova@ncipd.org>, A Kurchatova, L\nMarinova, and T Georgieva; National Center of Infectious and\nParasitic Diseases, Sofia, Bulgaria]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Outbreaks of mumps still occur sporadically throughout Europe as a\nresult of incomplete vaccine coverage in the past, particularly in\ncountries with significant migrant Roma populations that may escape\nroutine immunisation programs. The inclusion of a sub-optimal mump\ncomponent in triple MMR vaccine in the past may be another factor\naffecting the efficacy of vaccination. (E.g. Higher rates of aseptic\nmeningitis have been attributed to the Urabe, Leningrad-Zagreb and\nLeningrad-3 strain vaccines compared with the current Jeryl-Lynn strain vaccine\n<http://www.who.int/vaccine_safety/topics/mumps/statement/en/>.)\nA map of Bulgaria can be viewed at:\n<http://education.yahoo.com/reference/factbook/bu/map.html;_ylt=AtDijegFEGPd.km6_uIUY864ecYF>.\n- Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nMumps - Bulgaria (Plovdiv) 20070306.0793\nMumps - Spain (Navarra) (02): 2006 - 2007 20070216.0577\nMumps - Spain (Navarra) 20070111.0123\n2006\n----\nMumps - Ukraine (Zakarpatye): RFI 20061213.3507\nMumps, village festival - Spain (Navarra) 20061109.3220\nMumps - Austria (03) 20060706.1853\nMumps - Austria (02) 20060616.1666\nMumps - Austria (Carinthia) 20060608.1598\n..................mpp/cp/msp/mpp\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "mumps", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "1972-03-16 00:00:00", "1976-03-16 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "1991-03-16 00:00:00", "1992-05-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "L \n Marinova", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bulgaria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "eurosurveillance", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sofia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kurchatova", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mumps - Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Leningrad", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "9998", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Canada (NS) (05)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=9998", "date": "2007-03-22 20:00:02", "main_text": "MUMPS - BULGARIA: SUPPLEMENTARY VACCINATION\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu 22 Mar 2007\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Eurosurveillance weekly release Vol. 12, Issue 3 [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/2007/070322.asp#4>\n\nMumps outbreak in Bulgaria, 2007: a preliminary report\n-----------------------------------------------\nThere is an ongoing mumps outbreak in Bulgaria, with a total of 997\ncases notified between 1 Jan and 18 Mar 2007. This number includes\nlaboratory-confirmed and probable epidemiologically-linked clinical\ncases in line with the EU case definition and case classification\nthat have been adopted for mumps surveillance purposes in Bulgaria\nsince 2005 [1].\nFor comparison, only 22 cases were reported in the 1st 11 weeks of\n2005, and 311 cases were registered in the same period in 2006.\nAltogether, 608 cases were notified in 2005, and 919 cases were\nreported during 2006. An increase of the number of reported cases was\nnoted already in 2006, and since the beginning of 2007, the number of\ncases has continued to rise. [The text at this point is supplemented\nby a figure plotting reported mumps cases during weeks 1 to 11 in\n2005 (n=22), 2006 (n=311) and 2007 (n=997)].\nThe present mumps epidemic affects mostly teenagers and young adults.\nMore than 60 percent of the cases reported in 2007 occurred in\npatients aged 15 to 19 years, and about 20 percent in patients aged\n20 to 24 years. To date, 112 out of 997 cases (11.2 percent) have\nbeen laboratory-confirmed.\nConclusion\n----------\nThe outbreak investigation is still ongoing, but preliminary data\nindicate that the predominance of patients in age groups 15-19 and\n20-24 years may be a result of poor immunisation of these birth\ncohorts in general. About 1/3rd of patients aged 15 to 19 years have\nnot been vaccinated at all, whereas more than half have received only\none dose of monovalent mumps vaccine strain Leningrad 3, which has\nbeen shown to have a lower effectiveness [2]. Among the 20- to\n24-year-old patients, over 90 percent have never been immunised against mumps.\nVaccination against mumps in Bulgaria started in 1972, and a routine\nmumps immunisation program was launched in 1976. However, different\nvaccine strains and vaccines have been used, and different\nimmunisation strategies implemented, including a suspension of mumps\nimmunisation for almost 4 years during the period 1982 to 1986.\nDue to the past changes in the immunisation program and occasionally\nincomplete immunisation coverage, the conditions in which outbreaks\ncan occur still exist, despite the current up-to-date mumps\nimmunisation strategy.\nControl measures\n----------------\nA risk assessment carried out following the outbreak concluded that\nbirth cohorts 1982 to 1992 that are at higher risk of mumps infection\nshould be offered supplementary mumps immunisation.\nAs a result, the Bulgarian Ministry of Health decided to provide\nsupplementary doses of MMR vaccine and to conduct immunisation\ncampaigns targeted at these cohorts. In early March 2007, the\nMinistry of Health organized a meeting to inform regional\nepidemiologists about the situation and to discuss with them the need\nfor strengthening disease surveillance and undertaking control\nmeasures to prevent further spread of mumps. Furthermore,\ncommunication aimed at the general public, conveying information\nabout the risks related to mumps infection and the preventive\nmeasures, including immunisation, has been intensified through the\nparticipation of national experts in a series of briefings, TV and\nradio broadcasts.\nA longer article on the epidemiology of mumps in Bulgaria, including\na detailed risk assessment, is planned for publication in the monthly\nrelease of Eurosurveillance.\nReferences\n----------\n(1.) Commission decision of 19 Mar 2002 laying down case definitions\nfor reporting communicable diseases to the Community network under\nDecision No 2119/98/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council\n(2002/253/EC), Official Journal of the European Communities\n03.04.2002. Available from:\n<http://europa.eu.int/eur-lex/pri/en/oj/dat/2002/l_086/l_08620020403en00440062.pdf>.\n(2.) Gatcheva N, Tchakov B, Vladimirova N. Analysis of immunisations\nperformed in 1991. NCIPD Information Journal, 5, 1992; 50-62. (In Bulgarian).\n[Reported by: M Kojouharova <mkojouharova@ncipd.org>, A Kurchatova, L\nMarinova, and T Georgieva; National Center of Infectious and\nParasitic Diseases, Sofia, Bulgaria]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Outbreaks of mumps still occur sporadically throughout Europe as a\nresult of incomplete vaccine coverage in the past, particularly in\ncountries with significant migrant Roma populations that may escape\nroutine immunisation programs. The inclusion of a sub-optimal mump\ncomponent in triple MMR vaccine in the past may be another factor\naffecting the efficacy of vaccination. (E.g. Higher rates of aseptic\nmeningitis have been attributed to the Urabe, Leningrad-Zagreb and\nLeningrad-3 strain vaccines compared with the current Jeryl-Lynn strain vaccine\n<http://www.who.int/vaccine_safety/topics/mumps/statement/en/>.)\nA map of Bulgaria can be viewed at:\n<http://education.yahoo.com/reference/factbook/bu/map.html;_ylt=AtDijegFEGPd.km6_uIUY864ecYF>.\n- Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nMumps - Bulgaria (Plovdiv) 20070306.0793\nMumps - Spain (Navarra) (02): 2006 - 2007 20070216.0577\nMumps - Spain (Navarra) 20070111.0123\n2006\n----\nMumps - Ukraine (Zakarpatye): RFI 20061213.3507\nMumps, village festival - Spain (Navarra) 20061109.3220\nMumps - Austria (03) 20060706.1853\nMumps - Austria (02) 20060616.1666\nMumps - Austria (Carinthia) 20060608.1598\n..................mpp/cp/msp/mpp\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "mumps", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "1972-03-16 00:00:00", "1976-03-16 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "1991-03-16 00:00:00", "1992-05-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "L \n Marinova", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bulgaria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "eurosurveillance", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sofia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kurchatova", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mumps - Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Leningrad", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "9869", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Canada (NS)(04)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=9869", "date": "2007-03-22 20:00:02", "main_text": "MUMPS - BULGARIA: SUPPLEMENTARY VACCINATION\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu 22 Mar 2007\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Eurosurveillance weekly release Vol. 12, Issue 3 [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/2007/070322.asp#4>\n\nMumps outbreak in Bulgaria, 2007: a preliminary report\n-----------------------------------------------\nThere is an ongoing mumps outbreak in Bulgaria, with a total of 997\ncases notified between 1 Jan and 18 Mar 2007. This number includes\nlaboratory-confirmed and probable epidemiologically-linked clinical\ncases in line with the EU case definition and case classification\nthat have been adopted for mumps surveillance purposes in Bulgaria\nsince 2005 [1].\nFor comparison, only 22 cases were reported in the 1st 11 weeks of\n2005, and 311 cases were registered in the same period in 2006.\nAltogether, 608 cases were notified in 2005, and 919 cases were\nreported during 2006. An increase of the number of reported cases was\nnoted already in 2006, and since the beginning of 2007, the number of\ncases has continued to rise. [The text at this point is supplemented\nby a figure plotting reported mumps cases during weeks 1 to 11 in\n2005 (n=22), 2006 (n=311) and 2007 (n=997)].\nThe present mumps epidemic affects mostly teenagers and young adults.\nMore than 60 percent of the cases reported in 2007 occurred in\npatients aged 15 to 19 years, and about 20 percent in patients aged\n20 to 24 years. To date, 112 out of 997 cases (11.2 percent) have\nbeen laboratory-confirmed.\nConclusion\n----------\nThe outbreak investigation is still ongoing, but preliminary data\nindicate that the predominance of patients in age groups 15-19 and\n20-24 years may be a result of poor immunisation of these birth\ncohorts in general. About 1/3rd of patients aged 15 to 19 years have\nnot been vaccinated at all, whereas more than half have received only\none dose of monovalent mumps vaccine strain Leningrad 3, which has\nbeen shown to have a lower effectiveness [2]. Among the 20- to\n24-year-old patients, over 90 percent have never been immunised against mumps.\nVaccination against mumps in Bulgaria started in 1972, and a routine\nmumps immunisation program was launched in 1976. However, different\nvaccine strains and vaccines have been used, and different\nimmunisation strategies implemented, including a suspension of mumps\nimmunisation for almost 4 years during the period 1982 to 1986.\nDue to the past changes in the immunisation program and occasionally\nincomplete immunisation coverage, the conditions in which outbreaks\ncan occur still exist, despite the current up-to-date mumps\nimmunisation strategy.\nControl measures\n----------------\nA risk assessment carried out following the outbreak concluded that\nbirth cohorts 1982 to 1992 that are at higher risk of mumps infection\nshould be offered supplementary mumps immunisation.\nAs a result, the Bulgarian Ministry of Health decided to provide\nsupplementary doses of MMR vaccine and to conduct immunisation\ncampaigns targeted at these cohorts. In early March 2007, the\nMinistry of Health organized a meeting to inform regional\nepidemiologists about the situation and to discuss with them the need\nfor strengthening disease surveillance and undertaking control\nmeasures to prevent further spread of mumps. Furthermore,\ncommunication aimed at the general public, conveying information\nabout the risks related to mumps infection and the preventive\nmeasures, including immunisation, has been intensified through the\nparticipation of national experts in a series of briefings, TV and\nradio broadcasts.\nA longer article on the epidemiology of mumps in Bulgaria, including\na detailed risk assessment, is planned for publication in the monthly\nrelease of Eurosurveillance.\nReferences\n----------\n(1.) Commission decision of 19 Mar 2002 laying down case definitions\nfor reporting communicable diseases to the Community network under\nDecision No 2119/98/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council\n(2002/253/EC), Official Journal of the European Communities\n03.04.2002. Available from:\n<http://europa.eu.int/eur-lex/pri/en/oj/dat/2002/l_086/l_08620020403en00440062.pdf>.\n(2.) Gatcheva N, Tchakov B, Vladimirova N. Analysis of immunisations\nperformed in 1991. NCIPD Information Journal, 5, 1992; 50-62. (In Bulgarian).\n[Reported by: M Kojouharova <mkojouharova@ncipd.org>, A Kurchatova, L\nMarinova, and T Georgieva; National Center of Infectious and\nParasitic Diseases, Sofia, Bulgaria]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Outbreaks of mumps still occur sporadically throughout Europe as a\nresult of incomplete vaccine coverage in the past, particularly in\ncountries with significant migrant Roma populations that may escape\nroutine immunisation programs. The inclusion of a sub-optimal mump\ncomponent in triple MMR vaccine in the past may be another factor\naffecting the efficacy of vaccination. (E.g. Higher rates of aseptic\nmeningitis have been attributed to the Urabe, Leningrad-Zagreb and\nLeningrad-3 strain vaccines compared with the current Jeryl-Lynn strain vaccine\n<http://www.who.int/vaccine_safety/topics/mumps/statement/en/>.)\nA map of Bulgaria can be viewed at:\n<http://education.yahoo.com/reference/factbook/bu/map.html;_ylt=AtDijegFEGPd.km6_uIUY864ecYF>.\n- Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nMumps - Bulgaria (Plovdiv) 20070306.0793\nMumps - Spain (Navarra) (02): 2006 - 2007 20070216.0577\nMumps - Spain (Navarra) 20070111.0123\n2006\n----\nMumps - Ukraine (Zakarpatye): RFI 20061213.3507\nMumps, village festival - Spain (Navarra) 20061109.3220\nMumps - Austria (03) 20060706.1853\nMumps - Austria (02) 20060616.1666\nMumps - Austria (Carinthia) 20060608.1598\n..................mpp/cp/msp/mpp\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "mumps", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "1972-03-16 00:00:00", "1976-03-16 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "1991-03-16 00:00:00", "1992-05-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "L \n Marinova", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bulgaria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "eurosurveillance", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sofia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kurchatova", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mumps - Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Leningrad", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "9569", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Canada (NS) (03)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=9569", "date": "2007-03-22 20:00:02", "main_text": "MUMPS - BULGARIA: SUPPLEMENTARY VACCINATION\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu 22 Mar 2007\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Eurosurveillance weekly release Vol. 12, Issue 3 [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/2007/070322.asp#4>\n\nMumps outbreak in Bulgaria, 2007: a preliminary report\n-----------------------------------------------\nThere is an ongoing mumps outbreak in Bulgaria, with a total of 997\ncases notified between 1 Jan and 18 Mar 2007. This number includes\nlaboratory-confirmed and probable epidemiologically-linked clinical\ncases in line with the EU case definition and case classification\nthat have been adopted for mumps surveillance purposes in Bulgaria\nsince 2005 [1].\nFor comparison, only 22 cases were reported in the 1st 11 weeks of\n2005, and 311 cases were registered in the same period in 2006.\nAltogether, 608 cases were notified in 2005, and 919 cases were\nreported during 2006. An increase of the number of reported cases was\nnoted already in 2006, and since the beginning of 2007, the number of\ncases has continued to rise. [The text at this point is supplemented\nby a figure plotting reported mumps cases during weeks 1 to 11 in\n2005 (n=22), 2006 (n=311) and 2007 (n=997)].\nThe present mumps epidemic affects mostly teenagers and young adults.\nMore than 60 percent of the cases reported in 2007 occurred in\npatients aged 15 to 19 years, and about 20 percent in patients aged\n20 to 24 years. To date, 112 out of 997 cases (11.2 percent) have\nbeen laboratory-confirmed.\nConclusion\n----------\nThe outbreak investigation is still ongoing, but preliminary data\nindicate that the predominance of patients in age groups 15-19 and\n20-24 years may be a result of poor immunisation of these birth\ncohorts in general. About 1/3rd of patients aged 15 to 19 years have\nnot been vaccinated at all, whereas more than half have received only\none dose of monovalent mumps vaccine strain Leningrad 3, which has\nbeen shown to have a lower effectiveness [2]. Among the 20- to\n24-year-old patients, over 90 percent have never been immunised against mumps.\nVaccination against mumps in Bulgaria started in 1972, and a routine\nmumps immunisation program was launched in 1976. However, different\nvaccine strains and vaccines have been used, and different\nimmunisation strategies implemented, including a suspension of mumps\nimmunisation for almost 4 years during the period 1982 to 1986.\nDue to the past changes in the immunisation program and occasionally\nincomplete immunisation coverage, the conditions in which outbreaks\ncan occur still exist, despite the current up-to-date mumps\nimmunisation strategy.\nControl measures\n----------------\nA risk assessment carried out following the outbreak concluded that\nbirth cohorts 1982 to 1992 that are at higher risk of mumps infection\nshould be offered supplementary mumps immunisation.\nAs a result, the Bulgarian Ministry of Health decided to provide\nsupplementary doses of MMR vaccine and to conduct immunisation\ncampaigns targeted at these cohorts. In early March 2007, the\nMinistry of Health organized a meeting to inform regional\nepidemiologists about the situation and to discuss with them the need\nfor strengthening disease surveillance and undertaking control\nmeasures to prevent further spread of mumps. Furthermore,\ncommunication aimed at the general public, conveying information\nabout the risks related to mumps infection and the preventive\nmeasures, including immunisation, has been intensified through the\nparticipation of national experts in a series of briefings, TV and\nradio broadcasts.\nA longer article on the epidemiology of mumps in Bulgaria, including\na detailed risk assessment, is planned for publication in the monthly\nrelease of Eurosurveillance.\nReferences\n----------\n(1.) Commission decision of 19 Mar 2002 laying down case definitions\nfor reporting communicable diseases to the Community network under\nDecision No 2119/98/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council\n(2002/253/EC), Official Journal of the European Communities\n03.04.2002. Available from:\n<http://europa.eu.int/eur-lex/pri/en/oj/dat/2002/l_086/l_08620020403en00440062.pdf>.\n(2.) Gatcheva N, Tchakov B, Vladimirova N. Analysis of immunisations\nperformed in 1991. NCIPD Information Journal, 5, 1992; 50-62. (In Bulgarian).\n[Reported by: M Kojouharova <mkojouharova@ncipd.org>, A Kurchatova, L\nMarinova, and T Georgieva; National Center of Infectious and\nParasitic Diseases, Sofia, Bulgaria]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Outbreaks of mumps still occur sporadically throughout Europe as a\nresult of incomplete vaccine coverage in the past, particularly in\ncountries with significant migrant Roma populations that may escape\nroutine immunisation programs. The inclusion of a sub-optimal mump\ncomponent in triple MMR vaccine in the past may be another factor\naffecting the efficacy of vaccination. (E.g. Higher rates of aseptic\nmeningitis have been attributed to the Urabe, Leningrad-Zagreb and\nLeningrad-3 strain vaccines compared with the current Jeryl-Lynn strain vaccine\n<http://www.who.int/vaccine_safety/topics/mumps/statement/en/>.)\nA map of Bulgaria can be viewed at:\n<http://education.yahoo.com/reference/factbook/bu/map.html;_ylt=AtDijegFEGPd.km6_uIUY864ecYF>.\n- Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nMumps - Bulgaria (Plovdiv) 20070306.0793\nMumps - Spain (Navarra) (02): 2006 - 2007 20070216.0577\nMumps - Spain (Navarra) 20070111.0123\n2006\n----\nMumps - Ukraine (Zakarpatye): RFI 20061213.3507\nMumps, village festival - Spain (Navarra) 20061109.3220\nMumps - Austria (03) 20060706.1853\nMumps - Austria (02) 20060616.1666\nMumps - Austria (Carinthia) 20060608.1598\n..................mpp/cp/msp/mpp\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
