This number includes\nlaboratory-confirmed and probable epidemiologically-linked clinical\ncases in line with the EU case definition and case classification\nthat have been adopted for mumps surveillance purposes in Bulgaria\nsince 2005 [1].\nFor comparison, only 22 cases were reported in the 1st 11 weeks of\n2005, and 311 cases were registered in the same period in 2006.\nAltogether, 608 cases were notified in 2005, and 919 cases were\nreported during 2006. An increase of the number of reported cases was\nnoted already in 2006, and since the beginning of 2007, the number of\ncases has continued to rise. [The text at this point is supplemented\nby a figure plotting reported mumps cases during weeks 1 to 11 in\n2005 (n=22), 2006 (n=311) and 2007 (n=997)].\nThe present mumps epidemic affects mostly teenagers and young adults.\nMore than 60 percent of the cases reported in 2007 occurred in\npatients aged 15 to 19 years, and about 20 percent in patients aged\n20 to 24 years. To date, 112 out of 997 cases (11.2 percent) have\nbeen laboratory-confirmed.\nConclusion\n----------\nThe outbreak investigation is still ongoing, but preliminary data\nindicate that the predominance of patients in age groups 15-19 and\n20-24 years may be a result of poor immunisation of these birth\ncohorts in general. About 1/3rd of patients aged 15 to 19 years have\nnot been vaccinated at all, whereas more than half have received only\none dose of monovalent mumps vaccine strain Leningrad 3, which has\nbeen shown to have a lower effectiveness [2]. Among the 20- to\n24-year-old patients, over 90 percent have never been immunised against mumps.\nVaccination against mumps in Bulgaria started in 1972, and a routine\nmumps immunisation program was launched in 1976. However, different\nvaccine strains and vaccines have been used, and different\nimmunisation strategies implemented, including a suspension of mumps\nimmunisation for almost 4 years during the period 1982 to 1986.\nDue to the past changes in the immunisation program and occasionally\nincomplete immunisation coverage, the conditions in which outbreaks\ncan occur still exist, despite the current up-to-date mumps\nimmunisation strategy.\nControl measures\n----------------\nA risk assessment carried out following the outbreak concluded that\nbirth cohorts 1982 to 1992 that are at higher risk of mumps infection\nshould be offered supplementary mumps immunisation.\nAs a result, the Bulgarian Ministry of Health decided to provide\nsupplementary doses of MMR vaccine and to conduct immunisation\ncampaigns targeted at these cohorts. In early March 2007, the\nMinistry of Health organized a meeting to inform regional\nepidemiologists about the situation and to discuss with them the need\nfor strengthening disease surveillance and undertaking control\nmeasures to prevent further spread of mumps. Furthermore,\ncommunication aimed at the general public, conveying information\nabout the risks related to mumps infection and the preventive\nmeasures, including immunisation, has been intensified through the\nparticipation of national experts in a series of briefings, TV and\nradio broadcasts.\nA longer article on the epidemiology of mumps in Bulgaria, including\na detailed risk assessment, is planned for publication in the monthly\nrelease of Eurosurveillance.\nReferences\n----------\n(1.) Commission decision of 19 Mar 2002 laying down case definitions\nfor reporting communicable diseases to the Community network under\nDecision No 2119/98/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council\n(2002/253/EC), Official Journal of the European Communities\n03.04.2002. This number includes\nlaboratory-confirmed and probable epidemiologically-linked clinical\ncases in line with the EU case definition and case classification\nthat have been adopted for mumps surveillance purposes in Bulgaria\nsince 2005 [1].\nFor comparison, only 22 cases were reported in the 1st 11 weeks of\n2005, and 311 cases were registered in the same period in 2006.\nAltogether, 608 cases were notified in 2005, and 919 cases were\nreported during 2006. An increase of the number of reported cases was\nnoted already in 2006, and since the beginning of 2007, the number of\ncases has continued to rise. [The text at this point is supplemented\nby a figure plotting reported mumps cases during weeks 1 to 11 in\n2005 (n=22), 2006 (n=311) and 2007 (n=997)].\nThe present mumps epidemic affects mostly teenagers and young adults.\nMore than 60 percent of the cases reported in 2007 occurred in\npatients aged 15 to 19 years, and about 20 percent in patients aged\n20 to 24 years. To date, 112 out of 997 cases (11.2 percent) have\nbeen laboratory-confirmed.\nConclusion\n----------\nThe outbreak investigation is still ongoing, but preliminary data\nindicate that the predominance of patients in age groups 15-19 and\n20-24 years may be a result of poor immunisation of these birth\ncohorts in general. About 1/3rd of patients aged 15 to 19 years have\nnot been vaccinated at all, whereas more than half have received only\none dose of monovalent mumps vaccine strain Leningrad 3, which has\nbeen shown to have a lower effectiveness [2]. Among the 20- to\n24-year-old patients, over 90 percent have never been immunised against mumps.\nVaccination against mumps in Bulgaria started in 1972, and a routine\nmumps immunisation program was launched in 1976. However, different\nvaccine strains and vaccines have been used, and different\nimmunisation strategies implemented, including a suspension of mumps\nimmunisation for almost 4 years during the period 1982 to 1986.\nDue to the past changes in the immunisation program and occasionally\nincomplete immunisation coverage, the conditions in which outbreaks\ncan occur still exist, despite the current up-to-date mumps\nimmunisation strategy.\nControl measures\n----------------\nA risk assessment carried out following the outbreak concluded that\nbirth cohorts 1982 to 1992 that are at higher risk of mumps infection\nshould be offered supplementary mumps immunisation.\nAs a result, the Bulgarian Ministry of Health decided to provide\nsupplementary doses of MMR vaccine and to conduct immunisation\ncampaigns targeted at these cohorts. In early March 2007, the\nMinistry of Health organized a meeting to inform regional\nepidemiologists about the situation and to discuss with them the need\nfor strengthening disease surveillance and undertaking control\nmeasures to prevent further spread of mumps. Furthermore,\ncommunication aimed at the general public, conveying information\nabout the risks related to mumps infection and the preventive\nmeasures, including immunisation, has been intensified through the\nparticipation of national experts in a series of briefings, TV and\nradio broadcasts.\nA longer article on the epidemiology of mumps in Bulgaria, including\na detailed risk assessment, is planned for publication in the monthly\nrelease of Eurosurveillance.\nReferences\n----------\n(1.) Commission decision of 19 Mar 2002 laying down case definitions\nfor reporting communicable diseases to the Community network under\nDecision No 2119/98/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council\n(2002/253/EC), Official Journal of the European Communities\n03.04.2002. Available from:\n<http://europa.eu.int/eur-lex/pri/en/oj/dat/2002/l_086/l_08620020403en00440062.pdf>.\n(2.) Gatcheva N, Tchakov B, Vladimirova N. Analysis of immunisations\nperformed in 1991. NCIPD Information Journal, 5, 1992; 50-62. (In Bulgarian).\n[Reported by: M Kojouharova <mkojouharova@ncipd.org>, A Kurchatova, L\nMarinova, and T Georgieva; National Center of Infectious and\nParasitic Diseases, Sofia, Bulgaria]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Outbreaks of mumps still occur sporadically throughout Europe as a\nresult of incomplete vaccine coverage in the past, particularly in\ncountries with significant migrant Roma populations that may escape\nroutine immunisation programs. The inclusion of a sub-optimal mump\ncomponent in triple MMR vaccine in the past may be another factor\naffecting the efficacy of vaccination. (E.g. Higher rates of aseptic\nmeningitis have been attributed to the Urabe, Leningrad-Zagreb and\nLeningrad-3 strain vaccines compared with the current Jeryl-Lynn strain vaccine\n<http://www.who.int/vaccine_safety/topics/mumps/statement/en/>.)\nA map of Bulgaria can be viewed at:\n<http://education.yahoo.com/reference/factbook/bu/map.html;_ylt=AtDijegFEGPd.km6_uIUY864ecYF>.\n- Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nMumps - Bulgaria (Plovdiv) 20070306.0793\nMumps - Spain (Navarra) (02): 2006 - 2007 20070216.0577\nMumps - Spain (Navarra) 20070111.0123\n2006\n----\nMumps - Ukraine (Zakarpatye): RFI 20061213.3507\nMumps, village festival - Spain (Navarra) 20061109.3220\nMumps - Austria (03) 20060706.1853\nMumps - Austria (02) 20060616.1666\nMumps - Austria (Carinthia) 20060608.1598\n..................mpp/cp/msp/mpp\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "mumps", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "1972-03-16 00:00:00", "1976-03-16 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "1991-03-16 00:00:00", "1992-05-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "L \n Marinova", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bulgaria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "eurosurveillance", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sofia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kurchatova", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mumps - Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Leningrad", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "9320", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Hungary (Heves) ex Ukraine", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=9320", "date": "2007-03-22 20:00:02", "main_text": "MUMPS - BULGARIA: SUPPLEMENTARY VACCINATION\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu 22 Mar 2007\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Eurosurveillance weekly release Vol. 12, Issue 3 [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/2007/070322.asp#4>\n\nMumps outbreak in Bulgaria, 2007: a preliminary report\n-----------------------------------------------\nThere is an ongoing mumps outbreak in Bulgaria, with a total of 997\ncases notified between 1 Jan and 18 Mar 2007. This number includes\nlaboratory-confirmed and probable epidemiologically-linked clinical\ncases in line with the EU case definition and case classification\nthat have been adopted for mumps surveillance purposes in Bulgaria\nsince 2005 [1].\nFor comparison, only 22 cases were reported in the 1st 11 weeks of\n2005, and 311 cases were registered in the same period in 2006.\nAltogether, 608 cases were notified in 2005, and 919 cases were\nreported during 2006. An increase of the number of reported cases was\nnoted already in 2006, and since the beginning of 2007, the number of\ncases has continued to rise. [The text at this point is supplemented\nby a figure plotting reported mumps cases during weeks 1 to 11 in\n2005 (n=22), 2006 (n=311) and 2007 (n=997)].\nThe present mumps epidemic affects mostly teenagers and young adults.\nMore than 60 percent of the cases reported in 2007 occurred in\npatients aged 15 to 19 years, and about 20 percent in patients aged\n20 to 24 years. To date, 112 out of 997 cases (11.2 percent) have\nbeen laboratory-confirmed.\nConclusion\n----------\nThe outbreak investigation is still ongoing, but preliminary data\nindicate that the predominance of patients in age groups 15-19 and\n20-24 years may be a result of poor immunisation of these birth\ncohorts in general. About 1/3rd of patients aged 15 to 19 years have\nnot been vaccinated at all, whereas more than half have received only\none dose of monovalent mumps vaccine strain Leningrad 3, which has\nbeen shown to have a lower effectiveness [2]. Among the 20- to\n24-year-old patients, over 90 percent have never been immunised against mumps.\nVaccination against mumps in Bulgaria started in 1972, and a routine\nmumps immunisation program was launched in 1976. However, different\nvaccine strains and vaccines have been used, and different\nimmunisation strategies implemented, including a suspension of mumps\nimmunisation for almost 4 years during the period 1982 to 1986.\nDue to the past changes in the immunisation program and occasionally\nincomplete immunisation coverage, the conditions in which outbreaks\ncan occur still exist, despite the current up-to-date mumps\nimmunisation strategy.\nControl measures\n----------------\nA risk assessment carried out following the outbreak concluded that\nbirth cohorts 1982 to 1992 that are at higher risk of mumps infection\nshould be offered supplementary mumps immunisation.\nAs a result, the Bulgarian Ministry of Health decided to provide\nsupplementary doses of MMR vaccine and to conduct immunisation\ncampaigns targeted at these cohorts. In early March 2007, the\nMinistry of Health organized a meeting to inform regional\nepidemiologists about the situation and to discuss with them the need\nfor strengthening disease surveillance and undertaking control\nmeasures to prevent further spread of mumps. Furthermore,\ncommunication aimed at the general public, conveying information\nabout the risks related to mumps infection and the preventive\nmeasures, including immunisation, has been intensified through the\nparticipation of national experts in a series of briefings, TV and\nradio broadcasts.\nA longer article on the epidemiology of mumps in Bulgaria, including\na detailed risk assessment, is planned for publication in the monthly\nrelease of Eurosurveillance.\nReferences\n----------\n(1.) Commission decision of 19 Mar 2002 laying down case definitions\nfor reporting communicable diseases to the Community network under\nDecision No 2119/98/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council\n(2002/253/EC), Official Journal of the European Communities\n03.04.2002. Available from:\n<http://europa.eu.int/eur-lex/pri/en/oj/dat/2002/l_086/l_08620020403en00440062.pdf>.\n(2.) Gatcheva N, Tchakov B, Vladimirova N. Analysis of immunisations\nperformed in 1991. NCIPD Information Journal, 5, 1992; 50-62. (In Bulgarian).\n[Reported by: M Kojouharova <mkojouharova@ncipd.org>, A Kurchatova, L\nMarinova, and T Georgieva; National Center of Infectious and\nParasitic Diseases, Sofia, Bulgaria]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Outbreaks of mumps still occur sporadically throughout Europe as a\nresult of incomplete vaccine coverage in the past, particularly in\ncountries with significant migrant Roma populations that may escape\nroutine immunisation programs. The inclusion of a sub-optimal mump\ncomponent in triple MMR vaccine in the past may be another factor\naffecting the efficacy of vaccination. (E.g. Higher rates of aseptic\nmeningitis have been attributed to the Urabe, Leningrad-Zagreb and\nLeningrad-3 strain vaccines compared with the current Jeryl-Lynn strain vaccine\n<http://www.who.int/vaccine_safety/topics/mumps/statement/en/>.)\nA map of Bulgaria can be viewed at:\n<http://education.yahoo.com/reference/factbook/bu/map.html;_ylt=AtDijegFEGPd.km6_uIUY864ecYF>.\n- Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nMumps - Bulgaria (Plovdiv) 20070306.0793\nMumps - Spain (Navarra) (02): 2006 - 2007 20070216.0577\nMumps - Spain (Navarra) 20070111.0123\n2006\n----\nMumps - Ukraine (Zakarpatye): RFI 20061213.3507\nMumps, village festival - Spain (Navarra) 20061109.3220\nMumps - Austria (03) 20060706.1853\nMumps - Austria (02) 20060616.1666\nMumps - Austria (Carinthia) 20060608.1598\n..................mpp/cp/msp/mpp\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "mumps", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "1972-03-16 00:00:00", "1976-03-16 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "1991-03-16 00:00:00", "1992-05-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "L \n Marinova", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bulgaria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "eurosurveillance", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sofia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kurchatova", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mumps - Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Leningrad", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "9100", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Bulgaria: supplementary vaccination", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=9100", "date": "2007-03-22 20:00:02", "main_text": "MUMPS - BULGARIA: SUPPLEMENTARY VACCINATION\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu 22 Mar 2007\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Eurosurveillance weekly release Vol. 12, Issue 3 [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/2007/070322.asp#4>\n\nMumps outbreak in Bulgaria, 2007: a preliminary report\n-----------------------------------------------\nThere is an ongoing mumps outbreak in Bulgaria, with a total of 997\ncases notified between 1 Jan and 18 Mar 2007. This number includes\nlaboratory-confirmed and probable epidemiologically-linked clinical\ncases in line with the EU case definition and case classification\nthat have been adopted for mumps surveillance purposes in Bulgaria\nsince 2005 [1].\nFor comparison, only 22 cases were reported in the 1st 11 weeks of\n2005, and 311 cases were registered in the same period in 2006.\nAltogether, 608 cases were notified in 2005, and 919 cases were\nreported during 2006. An increase of the number of reported cases was\nnoted already in 2006, and since the beginning of 2007, the number of\ncases has continued to rise. [The text at this point is supplemented\nby a figure plotting reported mumps cases during weeks 1 to 11 in\n2005 (n=22), 2006 (n=311) and 2007 (n=997)].\nThe present mumps epidemic affects mostly teenagers and young adults.\nMore than 60 percent of the cases reported in 2007 occurred in\npatients aged 15 to 19 years, and about 20 percent in patients aged\n20 to 24 years. To date, 112 out of 997 cases (11.2 percent) have\nbeen laboratory-confirmed.\nConclusion\n----------\nThe outbreak investigation is still ongoing, but preliminary data\nindicate that the predominance of patients in age groups 15-19 and\n20-24 years may be a result of poor immunisation of these birth\ncohorts in general. About 1/3rd of patients aged 15 to 19 years have\nnot been vaccinated at all, whereas more than half have received only\none dose of monovalent mumps vaccine strain Leningrad 3, which has\nbeen shown to have a lower effectiveness [2]. Among the 20- to\n24-year-old patients, over 90 percent have never been immunised against mumps.\nVaccination against mumps in Bulgaria started in 1972, and a routine\nmumps immunisation program was launched in 1976. However, different\nvaccine strains and vaccines have been used, and different\nimmunisation strategies implemented, including a suspension of mumps\nimmunisation for almost 4 years during the period 1982 to 1986.\nDue to the past changes in the immunisation program and occasionally\nincomplete immunisation coverage, the conditions in which outbreaks\ncan occur still exist, despite the current up-to-date mumps\nimmunisation strategy.\nControl measures\n----------------\nA risk assessment carried out following the outbreak concluded that\nbirth cohorts 1982 to 1992 that are at higher risk of mumps infection\nshould be offered supplementary mumps immunisation.\nAs a result, the Bulgarian Ministry of Health decided to provide\nsupplementary doses of MMR vaccine and to conduct immunisation\ncampaigns targeted at these cohorts. In early March 2007, the\nMinistry of Health organized a meeting to inform regional\nepidemiologists about the situation and to discuss with them the need\nfor strengthening disease surveillance and undertaking control\nmeasures to prevent further spread of mumps. Furthermore,\ncommunication aimed at the general public, conveying information\nabout the risks related to mumps infection and the preventive\nmeasures, including immunisation, has been intensified through the\nparticipation of national experts in a series of briefings, TV and\nradio broadcasts.\nA longer article on the epidemiology of mumps in Bulgaria, including\na detailed risk assessment, is planned for publication in the monthly\nrelease of Eurosurveillance.\nReferences\n----------\n(1.) Commission decision of 19 Mar 2002 laying down case definitions\nfor reporting communicable diseases to the Community network under\nDecision No 2119/98/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council\n(2002/253/EC), Official Journal of the European Communities\n03.04.2002. Available from:\n<http://europa.eu.int/eur-lex/pri/en/oj/dat/2002/l_086/l_08620020403en00440062.pdf>.\n(2.) Gatcheva N, Tchakov B, Vladimirova N. Analysis of immunisations\nperformed in 1991. NCIPD Information Journal, 5, 1992; 50-62. (In Bulgarian).\n[Reported by: M Kojouharova <mkojouharova@ncipd.org>, A Kurchatova, L\nMarinova, and T Georgieva; National Center of Infectious and\nParasitic Diseases, Sofia, Bulgaria]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Outbreaks of mumps still occur sporadically throughout Europe as a\nresult of incomplete vaccine coverage in the past, particularly in\ncountries with significant migrant Roma populations that may escape\nroutine immunisation programs. The inclusion of a sub-optimal mump\ncomponent in triple MMR vaccine in the past may be another factor\naffecting the efficacy of vaccination. (E.g. Higher rates of aseptic\nmeningitis have been attributed to the Urabe, Leningrad-Zagreb and\nLeningrad-3 strain vaccines compared with the current Jeryl-Lynn strain vaccine\n<http://www.who.int/vaccine_safety/topics/mumps/statement/en/>.)\nA map of Bulgaria can be viewed at:\n<http://education.yahoo.com/reference/factbook/bu/map.html;_ylt=AtDijegFEGPd.km6_uIUY864ecYF>.\n- Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nMumps - Bulgaria (Plovdiv) 20070306.0793\nMumps - Spain (Navarra) (02): 2006 - 2007 20070216.0577\nMumps - Spain (Navarra) 20070111.0123\n2006\n----\nMumps - Ukraine (Zakarpatye): RFI 20061213.3507\nMumps, village festival - Spain (Navarra) 20061109.3220\nMumps - Austria (03) 20060706.1853\nMumps - Austria (02) 20060616.1666\nMumps - Austria (Carinthia) 20060608.1598\n..................mpp/cp/msp/mpp\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "mumps", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "1972-03-16 00:00:00", "1976-03-16 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "1991-03-16 00:00:00", "1992-05-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "L \n Marinova", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bulgaria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "eurosurveillance", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sofia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kurchatova", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mumps - Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Leningrad", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "8665", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Bulgaria (Plovdiv)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=8665", "date": "2006-09-13 00:00:00", "main_text": "MUMPS - FIJI\n***********\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 13 Sep 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Fiji Times Online [edited]\n<http://www.fijitimes.com/story.aspx?id=48194>\n\nHealth ministry warns of mumps outbreak\n-----------------------------------------------\nThere is an outbreak of mumps in the Labasa and Suva areas, says\nHealth Ministry officer Doctor Josaia Samuela.\nHe said there had been an increasing number of mumps cases,\nespecially in the Labasa area, for the past 2 months.\n\"This has been evident from the reported number of cases seen at the\nLabasa Hospital for the past 2 months. For the Suva area, there have\nbeen anecdotal reports of increasing number of mump cases occurring\nin various schools in Suva for the past 2 months.\n\"Labasa Hospital has [had] an average of 120 cases for the past 12\nmonths. Lautoka Hospital reported about 30 cases in total for the\npast 2 months, and the Suva Private Hospital reported 15 cases last\nmonth [August 2006],\" he said.\nHe said the reported mumps cases were based solely on clinical\nsymptoms of the patients since no blood test had been sent to Suva\nfor laboratory confirmation.\nDr. Samuela said mumps was the commonest cause of painful and swollen\nsalivary glands. \"The most prominent symptoms are the presence of\npainful swelling or lumps at the angle of the jaw. These swellings of\nthe salivary glands could be on one or both sides. Associated\nsymptoms include body aches, loss of appetite, generalized weakness,\nheadache and low grade fever,\" he said. He said that panadol was a\nsuitable and effective medicine for both fever and pain relief and\nthat soft food should be given to the affected child, as chewing made\nthe pain worse.\nDr. Samuela said the child infected with mumps should be stopped from\ngoing to school until symptoms subside.\nLast week, Fiji College of General Practitioners president Doctor\nWahid Khan said children suffering from mumps should be allowed a lot\nof bed rest and not sent to school. He said that more than 50\npatients had visited his general practice seeking treatment for mumps\nand that proper care should be taken by the parents on the issue.\n\"If there are more than one child living in a household whose member\nhas the virus, the sick child's utensils should be kept separately\nfrom the rest of the family, because it is a contagious disease that\ncould be passed easily from one member to another,\" he said.\nHe said children suffering from mumps should wear warm clothing and\ndrink a lot of fluids with paracetamol, panadeine and codeine.\n\"I have seen some boys who come with mumps and complain of pain in\nthe scrotum, and this was not good, so extra care should be taken at\nall times,\" he said.\nHe said those infected with mumps should not be given orange or any\ncitrus drink to take while being infected because it could worsen the pain.\nMeanwhile, Health Ministry chief executive officer Doctor Lepani\nWaqatakirewa said the current outbreak was viral in origin and\nantibiotics such as amoxycillin are for bacterial infections.\nIn a statement reacting to the current outbreak of mumps among\nchildren, Dr. Waqatakirewa said virus and bacteria were different and\ngiving antibiotics for viral infection was a waste of medicine.\nSome parents had shown concern that their children with virus-related\ninfectious were in fact given antibiotics.\n\"However, do note that in some children, there could be co-exiting\nbacterial infection in the chest or elsewhere in the body. In such\ncases, antibiotics such as amoxycillin could be prescribed,\" he said.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[This is the 1st ProMED report of mumps in Fiji and the 2nd in\nSoutheast Asia. The previous report was of mumps infection associated\nwith use of the Rubini vaccine. - Mod.TY]\n[Mumps is a vaccine preventible disease. In a recent posting on\nmeasles in Fiji, the information on vaccination program activities\nmentioned that measles-rubella vaccine is used for routine\nimmunizations in Fiji. Hence, in the absence of a major vaccination\nprogram, periodic outbreaks of mumps would be expected. - Mod.MPP]\n[see also\nMeasles - Fiji 20060908.2551\n1999\n----\nMumps & Rubini vaccine - Singapore 19991025.1937]\n...................mpp/ty/msp/mpp\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n************************************************************\nBecome a ProMED-mail Premium Subscriber at\n<http://www.isid.org/ProMEDMail_Premium.shtml>\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org\n(NOT to an individual moderator). If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-08-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Suva", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Labasa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Fiji", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "8069", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Spain (Navarra) (02): 2006 - 2007", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=8069", "date": "2006-09-13 00:00:00", "main_text": "MUMPS - FIJI\n***********\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 13 Sep 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Fiji Times Online [edited]\n<http://www.fijitimes.com/story.aspx?id=48194>\n\nHealth ministry warns of mumps outbreak\n-----------------------------------------------\nThere is an outbreak of mumps in the Labasa and Suva areas, says\nHealth Ministry officer Doctor Josaia Samuela.\nHe said there had been an increasing number of mumps cases,\nespecially in the Labasa area, for the past 2 months.\n\"This has been evident from the reported number of cases seen at the\nLabasa Hospital for the past 2 months. For the Suva area, there have\nbeen anecdotal reports of increasing number of mump cases occurring\nin various schools in Suva for the past 2 months.\n\"Labasa Hospital has [had] an average of 120 cases for the past 12\nmonths. Lautoka Hospital reported about 30 cases in total for the\npast 2 months, and the Suva Private Hospital reported 15 cases last\nmonth [August 2006],\" he said.\nHe said the reported mumps cases were based solely on clinical\nsymptoms of the patients since no blood test had been sent to Suva\nfor laboratory confirmation.\nDr. Samuela said mumps was the commonest cause of painful and swollen\nsalivary glands. \"The most prominent symptoms are the presence of\npainful swelling or lumps at the angle of the jaw. These swellings of\nthe salivary glands could be on one or both sides. Associated\nsymptoms include body aches, loss of appetite, generalized weakness,\nheadache and low grade fever,\" he said. He said that panadol was a\nsuitable and effective medicine for both fever and pain relief and\nthat soft food should be given to the affected child, as chewing made\nthe pain worse.\nDr. Samuela said the child infected with mumps should be stopped from\ngoing to school until symptoms subside.\nLast week, Fiji College of General Practitioners president Doctor\nWahid Khan said children suffering from mumps should be allowed a lot\nof bed rest and not sent to school. He said that more than 50\npatients had visited his general practice seeking treatment for mumps\nand that proper care should be taken by the parents on the issue.\n\"If there are more than one child living in a household whose member\nhas the virus, the sick child's utensils should be kept separately\nfrom the rest of the family, because it is a contagious disease that\ncould be passed easily from one member to another,\" he said.\nHe said children suffering from mumps should wear warm clothing and\ndrink a lot of fluids with paracetamol, panadeine and codeine.\n\"I have seen some boys who come with mumps and complain of pain in\nthe scrotum, and this was not good, so extra care should be taken at\nall times,\" he said.\nHe said those infected with mumps should not be given orange or any\ncitrus drink to take while being infected because it could worsen the pain.\nMeanwhile, Health Ministry chief executive officer Doctor Lepani\nWaqatakirewa said the current outbreak was viral in origin and\nantibiotics such as amoxycillin are for bacterial infections.\nIn a statement reacting to the current outbreak of mumps among\nchildren, Dr. Waqatakirewa said virus and bacteria were different and\ngiving antibiotics for viral infection was a waste of medicine.\nSome parents had shown concern that their children with virus-related\ninfectious were in fact given antibiotics.\n\"However, do note that in some children, there could be co-exiting\nbacterial infection in the chest or elsewhere in the body. In such\ncases, antibiotics such as amoxycillin could be prescribed,\" he said.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[This is the 1st ProMED report of mumps in Fiji and the 2nd in\nSoutheast Asia. The previous report was of mumps infection associated\nwith use of the Rubini vaccine. - Mod.TY]\n[Mumps is a vaccine preventible disease. In a recent posting on\nmeasles in Fiji, the information on vaccination program activities\nmentioned that measles-rubella vaccine is used for routine\nimmunizations in Fiji. Hence, in the absence of a major vaccination\nprogram, periodic outbreaks of mumps would be expected. - Mod.MPP]\n[see also\nMeasles - Fiji 20060908.2551\n1999\n----\nMumps & Rubini vaccine - Singapore 19991025.1937]\n...................mpp/ty/msp/mpp\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n************************************************************\nBecome a ProMED-mail Premium Subscriber at\n<http://www.isid.org/ProMEDMail_Premium.shtml>\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org\n(NOT to an individual moderator). If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-08-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Suva", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Labasa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Fiji", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6516", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Spain (Navarra)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6516", "date": "2006-09-13 00:00:00", "main_text": "MUMPS - FIJI\n***********\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 13 Sep 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Fiji Times Online [edited]\n<http://www.fijitimes.com/story.aspx?id=48194>\n\nHealth ministry warns of mumps outbreak\n-----------------------------------------------\nThere is an outbreak of mumps in the Labasa and Suva areas, says\nHealth Ministry officer Doctor Josaia Samuela.\nHe said there had been an increasing number of mumps cases,\nespecially in the Labasa area, for the past 2 months.\n\"This has been evident from the reported number of cases seen at the\nLabasa Hospital for the past 2 months. For the Suva area, there have\nbeen anecdotal reports of increasing number of mump cases occurring\nin various schools in Suva for the past 2 months.\n\"Labasa Hospital has [had] an average of 120 cases for the past 12\nmonths. Lautoka Hospital reported about 30 cases in total for the\npast 2 months, and the Suva Private Hospital reported 15 cases last\nmonth [August 2006],\" he said.\nHe said the reported mumps cases were based solely on clinical\nsymptoms of the patients since no blood test had been sent to Suva\nfor laboratory confirmation.\nDr. Samuela said mumps was the commonest cause of painful and swollen\nsalivary glands. \"The most prominent symptoms are the presence of\npainful swelling or lumps at the angle of the jaw. These swellings of\nthe salivary glands could be on one or both sides. Associated\nsymptoms include body aches, loss of appetite, generalized weakness,\nheadache and low grade fever,\" he said. He said that panadol was a\nsuitable and effective medicine for both fever and pain relief and\nthat soft food should be given to the affected child, as chewing made\nthe pain worse.\nDr. Samuela said the child infected with mumps should be stopped from\ngoing to school until symptoms subside.\nLast week, Fiji College of General Practitioners president Doctor\nWahid Khan said children suffering from mumps should be allowed a lot\nof bed rest and not sent to school. He said that more than 50\npatients had visited his general practice seeking treatment for mumps\nand that proper care should be taken by the parents on the issue.\n\"If there are more than one child living in a household whose member\nhas the virus, the sick child's utensils should be kept separately\nfrom the rest of the family, because it is a contagious disease that\ncould be passed easily from one member to another,\" he said.\nHe said children suffering from mumps should wear warm clothing and\ndrink a lot of fluids with paracetamol, panadeine and codeine.\n\"I have seen some boys who come with mumps and complain of pain in\nthe scrotum, and this was not good, so extra care should be taken at\nall times,\" he said.\nHe said those infected with mumps should not be given orange or any\ncitrus drink to take while being infected because it could worsen the pain.\nMeanwhile, Health Ministry chief executive officer Doctor Lepani\nWaqatakirewa said the current outbreak was viral in origin and\nantibiotics such as amoxycillin are for bacterial infections.\nIn a statement reacting to the current outbreak of mumps among\nchildren, Dr. Waqatakirewa said virus and bacteria were different and\ngiving antibiotics for viral infection was a waste of medicine.\nSome parents had shown concern that their children with virus-related\ninfectious were in fact given antibiotics.\n\"However, do note that in some children, there could be co-exiting\nbacterial infection in the chest or elsewhere in the body. In such\ncases, antibiotics such as amoxycillin could be prescribed,\" he said.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[This is the 1st ProMED report of mumps in Fiji and the 2nd in\nSoutheast Asia. The previous report was of mumps infection associated\nwith use of the Rubini vaccine. - Mod.TY]\n[Mumps is a vaccine preventible disease. In a recent posting on\nmeasles in Fiji, the information on vaccination program activities\nmentioned that measles-rubella vaccine is used for routine\nimmunizations in Fiji. Hence, in the absence of a major vaccination\nprogram, periodic outbreaks of mumps would be expected. - Mod.MPP]\n[see also\nMeasles - Fiji 20060908.2551\n1999\n----\nMumps & Rubini vaccine - Singapore 19991025.1937]\n...................mpp/ty/msp/mpp\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For the Suva area, there have\nbeen anecdotal reports of increasing number of mump cases occurring\nin various schools in Suva for the past 2 months.\n\"Labasa Hospital has [had] an average of 120 cases for the past 12\nmonths. Lautoka Hospital reported about 30 cases in total for the\npast 2 months, and the Suva Private Hospital reported 15 cases last\nmonth [August 2006],\" he said.\nHe said the reported mumps cases were based solely on clinical\nsymptoms of the patients since no blood test had been sent to Suva\nfor laboratory confirmation.\nDr. Samuela said mumps was the commonest cause of painful and swollen\nsalivary glands. \"The most prominent symptoms are the presence of\npainful swelling or lumps at the angle of the jaw. These swellings of\nthe salivary glands could be on one or both sides. Associated\nsymptoms include body aches, loss of appetite, generalized weakness,\nheadache and low grade fever,\" he said. He said that panadol was a\nsuitable and effective medicine for both fever and pain relief and\nthat soft food should be given to the affected child, as chewing made\nthe pain worse.\nDr. Samuela said the child infected with mumps should be stopped from\ngoing to school until symptoms subside.\nLast week, Fiji College of General Practitioners president Doctor\nWahid Khan said children suffering from mumps should be allowed a lot\nof bed rest and not sent to school. He said that more than 50\npatients had visited his general practice seeking treatment for mumps\nand that proper care should be taken by the parents on the issue.\n\"If there are more than one child living in a household whose member\nhas the virus, the sick child's utensils should be kept separately\nfrom the rest of the family, because it is a contagious disease that\ncould be passed easily from one member to another,\" he said.\nHe said children suffering from mumps should wear warm clothing and\ndrink a lot of fluids with paracetamol, panadeine and codeine.\n\"I have seen some boys who come with mumps and complain of pain in\nthe scrotum, and this was not good, so extra care should be taken at\nall times,\" he said.\nHe said those infected with mumps should not be given orange or any\ncitrus drink to take while being infected because it could worsen the pain.\nMeanwhile, Health Ministry chief executive officer Doctor Lepani\nWaqatakirewa said the current outbreak was viral in origin and\nantibiotics such as amoxycillin are for bacterial infections.\nIn a statement reacting to the current outbreak of mumps among\nchildren, Dr. Waqatakirewa said virus and bacteria were different and\ngiving antibiotics for viral infection was a waste of medicine.\nSome parents had shown concern that their children with virus-related\ninfectious were in fact given antibiotics.\n\"However, do note that in some children, there could be co-exiting\nbacterial infection in the chest or elsewhere in the body. In such\ncases, antibiotics such as amoxycillin could be prescribed,\" he said.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[This is the 1st ProMED report of mumps in Fiji and the 2nd in\nSoutheast Asia. The previous report was of mumps infection associated\nwith use of the Rubini vaccine. - Mod.TY]\n[Mumps is a vaccine preventible disease. In a recent posting on\nmeasles in Fiji, the information on vaccination program activities\nmentioned that measles-rubella vaccine is used for routine\nimmunizations in Fiji. Hence, in the absence of a major vaccination\nprogram, periodic outbreaks of mumps would be expected. - Mod.MPP]\n[see also\nMeasles - Fiji 20060908.2551\n1999\n----\nMumps & Rubini vaccine - Singapore 19991025.1937]\n...................mpp/ty/msp/mpp\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For the Suva area, there have\nbeen anecdotal reports of increasing number of mump cases occurring\nin various schools in Suva for the past 2 months.\n\"Labasa Hospital has [had] an average of 120 cases for the past 12\nmonths. Lautoka Hospital reported about 30 cases in total for the\npast 2 months, and the Suva Private Hospital reported 15 cases last\nmonth [August 2006],\" he said.\nHe said the reported mumps cases were based solely on clinical\nsymptoms of the patients since no blood test had been sent to Suva\nfor laboratory confirmation.\nDr. Samuela said mumps was the commonest cause of painful and swollen\nsalivary glands. \"The most prominent symptoms are the presence of\npainful swelling or lumps at the angle of the jaw. These swellings of\nthe salivary glands could be on one or both sides. Associated\nsymptoms include body aches, loss of appetite, generalized weakness,\nheadache and low grade fever,\" he said. He said that panadol was a\nsuitable and effective medicine for both fever and pain relief and\nthat soft food should be given to the affected child, as chewing made\nthe pain worse.\nDr. Samuela said the child infected with mumps should be stopped from\ngoing to school until symptoms subside.\nLast week, Fiji College of General Practitioners president Doctor\nWahid Khan said children suffering from mumps should be allowed a lot\nof bed rest and not sent to school. He said that more than 50\npatients had visited his general practice seeking treatment for mumps\nand that proper care should be taken by the parents on the issue.\n\"If there are more than one child living in a household whose member\nhas the virus, the sick child's utensils should be kept separately\nfrom the rest of the family, because it is a contagious disease that\ncould be passed easily from one member to another,\" he said.\nHe said children suffering from mumps should wear warm clothing and\ndrink a lot of fluids with paracetamol, panadeine and codeine.\n\"I have seen some boys who come with mumps and complain of pain in\nthe scrotum, and this was not good, so extra care should be taken at\nall times,\" he said.\nHe said those infected with mumps should not be given orange or any\ncitrus drink to take while being infected because it could worsen the pain.\nMeanwhile, Health Ministry chief executive officer Doctor Lepani\nWaqatakirewa said the current outbreak was viral in origin and\nantibiotics such as amoxycillin are for bacterial infections.\nIn a statement reacting to the current outbreak of mumps among\nchildren, Dr. Waqatakirewa said virus and bacteria were different and\ngiving antibiotics for viral infection was a waste of medicine.\nSome parents had shown concern that their children with virus-related\ninfectious were in fact given antibiotics.\n\"However, do note that in some children, there could be co-exiting\nbacterial infection in the chest or elsewhere in the body. In such\ncases, antibiotics such as amoxycillin could be prescribed,\" he said.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[This is the 1st ProMED report of mumps in Fiji and the 2nd in\nSoutheast Asia. The previous report was of mumps infection associated\nwith use of the Rubini vaccine. - Mod.TY]\n[Mumps is a vaccine preventible disease. In a recent posting on\nmeasles in Fiji, the information on vaccination program activities\nmentioned that measles-rubella vaccine is used for routine\nimmunizations in Fiji. Hence, in the absence of a major vaccination\nprogram, periodic outbreaks of mumps would be expected. - Mod.MPP]\n[see also\nMeasles - Fiji 20060908.2551\n1999\n----\nMumps & Rubini vaccine - Singapore 19991025.1937]\n...................mpp/ty/msp/mpp\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For the Suva area, there have\nbeen anecdotal reports of increasing number of mump cases occurring\nin various schools in Suva for the past 2 months.\n\"Labasa Hospital has [had] an average of 120 cases for the past 12\nmonths. Lautoka Hospital reported about 30 cases in total for the\npast 2 months, and the Suva Private Hospital reported 15 cases last\nmonth [August 2006],\" he said.\nHe said the reported mumps cases were based solely on clinical\nsymptoms of the patients since no blood test had been sent to Suva\nfor laboratory confirmation.\nDr. Samuela said mumps was the commonest cause of painful and swollen\nsalivary glands. \"The most prominent symptoms are the presence of\npainful swelling or lumps at the angle of the jaw. These swellings of\nthe salivary glands could be on one or both sides. Associated\nsymptoms include body aches, loss of appetite, generalized weakness,\nheadache and low grade fever,\" he said. He said that panadol was a\nsuitable and effective medicine for both fever and pain relief and\nthat soft food should be given to the affected child, as chewing made\nthe pain worse.\nDr. Samuela said the child infected with mumps should be stopped from\ngoing to school until symptoms subside.\nLast week, Fiji College of General Practitioners president Doctor\nWahid Khan said children suffering from mumps should be allowed a lot\nof bed rest and not sent to school. He said that more than 50\npatients had visited his general practice seeking treatment for mumps\nand that proper care should be taken by the parents on the issue.\n\"If there are more than one child living in a household whose member\nhas the virus, the sick child's utensils should be kept separately\nfrom the rest of the family, because it is a contagious disease that\ncould be passed easily from one member to another,\" he said.\nHe said children suffering from mumps should wear warm clothing and\ndrink a lot of fluids with paracetamol, panadeine and codeine.\n\"I have seen some boys who come with mumps and complain of pain in\nthe scrotum, and this was not good, so extra care should be taken at\nall times,\" he said.\nHe said those infected with mumps should not be given orange or any\ncitrus drink to take while being infected because it could worsen the pain.\nMeanwhile, Health Ministry chief executive officer Doctor Lepani\nWaqatakirewa said the current outbreak was viral in origin and\nantibiotics such as amoxycillin are for bacterial infections.\nIn a statement reacting to the current outbreak of mumps among\nchildren, Dr. Waqatakirewa said virus and bacteria were different and\ngiving antibiotics for viral infection was a waste of medicine.\nSome parents had shown concern that their children with virus-related\ninfectious were in fact given antibiotics.\n\"However, do note that in some children, there could be co-exiting\nbacterial infection in the chest or elsewhere in the body. In such\ncases, antibiotics such as amoxycillin could be prescribed,\" he said.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[This is the 1st ProMED report of mumps in Fiji and the 2nd in\nSoutheast Asia. The previous report was of mumps infection associated\nwith use of the Rubini vaccine. - Mod.TY]\n[Mumps is a vaccine preventible disease. In a recent posting on\nmeasles in Fiji, the information on vaccination program activities\nmentioned that measles-rubella vaccine is used for routine\nimmunizations in Fiji. Hence, in the absence of a major vaccination\nprogram, periodic outbreaks of mumps would be expected. - Mod.MPP]\n[see also\nMeasles - Fiji 20060908.2551\n1999\n----\nMumps & Rubini vaccine - Singapore 19991025.1937]\n...................mpp/ty/msp/mpp\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-08-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Suva", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Labasa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Fiji", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3129", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (IL)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3129", "date": "2006-09-13 00:00:00", "main_text": "MUMPS - FIJI\n***********\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 13 Sep 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Fiji Times Online [edited]\n<http://www.fijitimes.com/story.aspx?id=48194>\n\nHealth ministry warns of mumps outbreak\n-----------------------------------------------\nThere is an outbreak of mumps in the Labasa and Suva areas, says\nHealth Ministry officer Doctor Josaia Samuela.\nHe said there had been an increasing number of mumps cases,\nespecially in the Labasa area, for the past 2 months.\n\"This has been evident from the reported number of cases seen at the\nLabasa Hospital for the past 2 months. For the Suva area, there have\nbeen anecdotal reports of increasing number of mump cases occurring\nin various schools in Suva for the past 2 months.\n\"Labasa Hospital has [had] an average of 120 cases for the past 12\nmonths. Lautoka Hospital reported about 30 cases in total for the\npast 2 months, and the Suva Private Hospital reported 15 cases last\nmonth [August 2006],\" he said.\nHe said the reported mumps cases were based solely on clinical\nsymptoms of the patients since no blood test had been sent to Suva\nfor laboratory confirmation.\nDr. Samuela said mumps was the commonest cause of painful and swollen\nsalivary glands. \"The most prominent symptoms are the presence of\npainful swelling or lumps at the angle of the jaw. These swellings of\nthe salivary glands could be on one or both sides. Associated\nsymptoms include body aches, loss of appetite, generalized weakness,\nheadache and low grade fever,\" he said. He said that panadol was a\nsuitable and effective medicine for both fever and pain relief and\nthat soft food should be given to the affected child, as chewing made\nthe pain worse.\nDr. Samuela said the child infected with mumps should be stopped from\ngoing to school until symptoms subside.\nLast week, Fiji College of General Practitioners president Doctor\nWahid Khan said children suffering from mumps should be allowed a lot\nof bed rest and not sent to school. He said that more than 50\npatients had visited his general practice seeking treatment for mumps\nand that proper care should be taken by the parents on the issue.\n\"If there are more than one child living in a household whose member\nhas the virus, the sick child's utensils should be kept separately\nfrom the rest of the family, because it is a contagious disease that\ncould be passed easily from one member to another,\" he said.\nHe said children suffering from mumps should wear warm clothing and\ndrink a lot of fluids with paracetamol, panadeine and codeine.\n\"I have seen some boys who come with mumps and complain of pain in\nthe scrotum, and this was not good, so extra care should be taken at\nall times,\" he said.\nHe said those infected with mumps should not be given orange or any\ncitrus drink to take while being infected because it could worsen the pain.\nMeanwhile, Health Ministry chief executive officer Doctor Lepani\nWaqatakirewa said the current outbreak was viral in origin and\nantibiotics such as amoxycillin are for bacterial infections.\nIn a statement reacting to the current outbreak of mumps among\nchildren, Dr. Waqatakirewa said virus and bacteria were different and\ngiving antibiotics for viral infection was a waste of medicine.\nSome parents had shown concern that their children with virus-related\ninfectious were in fact given antibiotics.\n\"However, do note that in some children, there could be co-exiting\nbacterial infection in the chest or elsewhere in the body. In such\ncases, antibiotics such as amoxycillin could be prescribed,\" he said.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[This is the 1st ProMED report of mumps in Fiji and the 2nd in\nSoutheast Asia. The previous report was of mumps infection associated\nwith use of the Rubini vaccine. - Mod.TY]\n[Mumps is a vaccine preventible disease. In a recent posting on\nmeasles in Fiji, the information on vaccination program activities\nmentioned that measles-rubella vaccine is used for routine\nimmunizations in Fiji. Hence, in the absence of a major vaccination\nprogram, periodic outbreaks of mumps would be expected. - Mod.MPP]\n[see also\nMeasles - Fiji 20060908.2551\n1999\n----\nMumps & Rubini vaccine - Singapore 19991025.1937]\n...................mpp/ty/msp/mpp\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For the Suva area, there have\nbeen anecdotal reports of increasing number of mump cases occurring\nin various schools in Suva for the past 2 months.\n\"Labasa Hospital has [had] an average of 120 cases for the past 12\nmonths. Lautoka Hospital reported about 30 cases in total for the\npast 2 months, and the Suva Private Hospital reported 15 cases last\nmonth [August 2006],\" he said.\nHe said the reported mumps cases were based solely on clinical\nsymptoms of the patients since no blood test had been sent to Suva\nfor laboratory confirmation.\nDr. Samuela said mumps was the commonest cause of painful and swollen\nsalivary glands. \"The most prominent symptoms are the presence of\npainful swelling or lumps at the angle of the jaw. These swellings of\nthe salivary glands could be on one or both sides. Associated\nsymptoms include body aches, loss of appetite, generalized weakness,\nheadache and low grade fever,\" he said. He said that panadol was a\nsuitable and effective medicine for both fever and pain relief and\nthat soft food should be given to the affected child, as chewing made\nthe pain worse.\nDr. Samuela said the child infected with mumps should be stopped from\ngoing to school until symptoms subside.\nLast week, Fiji College of General Practitioners president Doctor\nWahid Khan said children suffering from mumps should be allowed a lot\nof bed rest and not sent to school. He said that more than 50\npatients had visited his general practice seeking treatment for mumps\nand that proper care should be taken by the parents on the issue.\n\"If there are more than one child living in a household whose member\nhas the virus, the sick child's utensils should be kept separately\nfrom the rest of the family, because it is a contagious disease that\ncould be passed easily from one member to another,\" he said.\nHe said children suffering from mumps should wear warm clothing and\ndrink a lot of fluids with paracetamol, panadeine and codeine.\n\"I have seen some boys who come with mumps and complain of pain in\nthe scrotum, and this was not good, so extra care should be taken at\nall times,\" he said.\nHe said those infected with mumps should not be given orange or any\ncitrus drink to take while being infected because it could worsen the pain.\nMeanwhile, Health Ministry chief executive officer Doctor Lepani\nWaqatakirewa said the current outbreak was viral in origin and\nantibiotics such as amoxycillin are for bacterial infections.\nIn a statement reacting to the current outbreak of mumps among\nchildren, Dr. Waqatakirewa said virus and bacteria were different and\ngiving antibiotics for viral infection was a waste of medicine.\nSome parents had shown concern that their children with virus-related\ninfectious were in fact given antibiotics.\n\"However, do note that in some children, there could be co-exiting\nbacterial infection in the chest or elsewhere in the body. In such\ncases, antibiotics such as amoxycillin could be prescribed,\" he said.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[This is the 1st ProMED report of mumps in Fiji and the 2nd in\nSoutheast Asia. The previous report was of mumps infection associated\nwith use of the Rubini vaccine. - Mod.TY]\n[Mumps is a vaccine preventible disease. In a recent posting on\nmeasles in Fiji, the information on vaccination program activities\nmentioned that measles-rubella vaccine is used for routine\nimmunizations in Fiji. Hence, in the absence of a major vaccination\nprogram, periodic outbreaks of mumps would be expected. - Mod.MPP]\n[see also\nMeasles - Fiji 20060908.2551\n1999\n----\nMumps & Rubini vaccine - Singapore 19991025.1937]\n...................mpp/ty/msp/mpp\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-08-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Suva", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Labasa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Fiji", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1892", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Austria (03)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1892", "date": "2006-04-14 23:50:00", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (NEBRASKA, IOWA) (04): AIR TRAVEL EXPOSURE\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 11 Apr 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: MMWR, 11 Apr 2006 / 55(Dispatch); 1-2 [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm55d411a1.htm?s_cid=mm55d411a1_e>\n\nExposure to Mumps During Air Travel - United States, April 2006\n-----------------------------------------------\nThe state of Iowa has been experiencing a large mumps outbreak that\nbegan in December 2005 (1). As of 10 Apr 2006, a total of 515\npossible mumps cases have been reported to the Iowa Department of\nPublic Health (IDPH) during 2006 (2). This outbreak has spread across\nIowa, and mumps activity, possibly linked to the Iowa outbreak, is\nunder investigation in 6 neighboring states, including Illinois (n =\n4), Kansas (n = 33), Minnesota (n = one), Missouri (n = 4), Nebraska\n(n = 43), and Wisconsin (n = 4) (CDC, unpublished data, 10 Apr 2006).\nThe reasons for this outbreak are under investigation.\nMumps is an acute viral infection characterized by a nonspecific\nprodrome, including myalgia, anorexia, malaise, headache, and fever,\nfollowed by acute onset of unilateral or bilateral tender swelling of\nparotid or other salivary glands (2). An estimated 60 percent to 70\npercent of mumps infections produce typical acute parotitis (3).\nApproximately 20 percent of infections are asymptomatic, and nearly\n50 percent are associated with nonspecific or primarily respiratory\nsymptoms. Complications include orchitis, oophoritis, or mastitis\n(inflammation of the testicles, ovaries, or breasts, respectively),\nmeningitis/encephalitis, spontaneous abortion, and deafness.\nTransmission occurs by direct contact with respiratory droplets or\nsaliva. The incubation period is 14-18 days (range: 14-25 days) from\nexposure to onset of symptoms. The infectious period is from 3 days\nbefore symptom onset until 9 days after onset of symptoms.\nIDPH has identified 2 persons who had mumps diagnosed and were\npotentially infectious during travel on 9 different commercial\nflights involving 2 airlines during 26 Mar-2 Apr 2006. The commercial\nairline flights identified with a potentially infectious traveler are\nlisted below by date, carrier, and flight number:\nNorthwest Airline (NWA) flights:\n26 Mar 2006 - NWA (Mesaba) #3025 from Waterloo, Iowa to Minneapolis, Minnesota\n26 Mar 2006 - NWA #760 from Minneapolis, Minnesota, to Detroit, Michigan\n27 Mar 2006 - NWA #0260 from Detroit, Michigan, to Washington,\nDC--Reagan National\n29 Mar 2006 - NWA #1705 from Washington, DC--Reagan National to\nMinneapolis, Minnesota\n29 Mar 2006 - NWA (Mesaba) #3026 from Minneapolis, Minnesota, to Waterloo, Iowa\nAmerican Airlines (AA) flights:\n2 Apr 2006 - AA #1216 from Tucson, Arizona, to Dallas, Texas (DFW)\n2 Apr 2006 - AA #3617 from DFW to Lafayette, Arkansas (Northwest\nArkansas Regional [NAR])\n2 Apr 2006 - AA #5399 from NAR to St. Louis, Missouri\n2 Apr 2006 - AA #5498 from St. Louis, Missouri, to Cedar Rapids, Iowa\nPersons on these flights who have symptoms consistent with mumps\nwithin 21 days of travel should be evaluated for mumps by an\nhealth-care provider. Health-care providers should remain vigilant\nfor mumps among persons with parotitis or other salivary gland\ninflammation. Cases of suspected mumps should be reported immediately\nto public health officials.\nA multistate investigation has been initiated by CDC and the state\nhealth departments in affected states to notify potentially exposed\npassengers (i.e., those seated in close proximity to the index\ncases). This investigation is using a new software application,\neManifest, developed by the CDC Division of Global Migration and\nQuarantine (DGMQ) to securely import, sort, and assign\npassenger-locating information to jurisdictions to facilitate timely\nidentification of exposed persons. These data are securely\ntransmitted to state and territorial health departments via the\nEpidemic Information Exchange (Epi-X) Forum (available at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/epix/epix.html>) for notification of\npotentially exposed passengers.\nIncidence of mumps in the United States began to decrease after\nvaccine introduction in 1967 and recommendations for routine\nvaccination of children in 1977. Since the 1990s, a further decrease\nin the reported incidence of mumps has occurred, which is thought to\nbe attributable to the implementation of the 2nd dose of measles,\nmumps, and rubella vaccine (3). The risk for transmission of\nrespiratory infectious diseases during air travel might depend on\nseveral factors, including 1) immunity of passengers; 2)\ninfectiousness of the organism; 3) degree of shedding of the pathogen\nby infected passengers; 4) hygienic practices of infectious\npassengers; 5) proximity of others to infectious passengers; 6)\nhygienic practices of the other passengers/crew; 7) flight duration;\nand 8) cabin environment of the aircraft (4). Transmission of other\nrespiratory pathogens during air travel has been reported (5-9).\nExposure and transmission of mumps during commercial air travel has\nnot been described previously.\n[Reported by: P Quinlisk, MD, Iowa Dept of Public Health. S Redd, G\nDayan, MD, National Center for Immunization and Respiratory Diseases;\nN Gallagher, Geographic Medicine and Health Promotion Br, P Lutz, K\nMarienau, MD, F Averhoff, MD, Quarantine and Border Health Svcs Br,\nDiv of Global Migration and Quarantine, National Center for\nInfectious Diseases, CDC.]\nReferences:\n1. CDC. Mumps epidemic, Iowa, 2006. MMWR 2006;55:366-8.\n2. Iowa Department of Public Health, Center for Acute Disease\nEpidemiology. Iowa mumps update. Des Moines, Iowa: Iowa Department of\nPublic Health; 2006. Available at\n<http://www.idph.state.ia.us/adper/common/pdf/mumps/mumps_update_041106.pdf>.\n3. Plotkin SA, Orenstein WA, eds. Vaccines. 4th ed. Philadelphia, PA:\nWB Saunders; 2003:441-69.\n4. Mangili A, Glendreau M. Transmission of infectious diseases during\ncommercial air travel. Lancet 2005;365:989-96.\n5. World Health Organization. Tuberculosis and air travel: guidelines\nfor prevention and control. 2nd ed. Geneva, Switzerland: World Health\nOrganization; 2006:5-7. Available at:\n<http://www.who.int/docstore/gtb/publications/aircraft/PDF/98_256.pdf>\n6. CDC. Postexposure prophylaxis, isolation, and quarantine to\ncontrol an import-associated measles outbreak - Iowa, 2004. MMWR\n2004; 53:969-71.\n7. Moser MR, Bend TR, Margolis HS, et al. An outbreak of influenza\naboard a commercial airline. Am J Epidemiol 1979;110:1-6.\n8. Klonz KC, Hynes NA, Gunn RA, et al. An outbreak of influenza\nA/Taiwan/1/86 infections at a naval base and its association with\nairplane travel. Am J Epidemiol 1989;129:341-8.\n9. Marsden AG. Influenza outbreak related to air travel. Med J\nAustral 2003;179:172-3.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[ProMED-mail has been covering this unusual outbreak due to the size\nof the outbreak, the genotype involved (genotype G, most recently\nassociated with outbreaks in the United Kingdom) and now the\nadditional information that there may be spread to neighboring states\nand the possibility of exposure during airline travel. The mention of\na new software application \"eManifest\" is interesting, and one\nwonders whether it shortens the time necessary to identify passengers\nat risk of exposure to diseases while traveling. We look forward to\nhearing more about this tool. - Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\nMumps - USA (NE, IA) (03) 20060406.1037\nMumps - USA (NE, IA)(02) 20060405.1023\nMumps - USA (NE, IA) 20060403.1000\nMumps virus, genotype G - USA (IA) 20060315.0809\n2004\n----\nMumps, students - UK (02) 20041126.3166\nMumps, students - UK & Ireland (03) 20041117.3089\nMumps, students - UK & Ireland (02) 20041112.3055\nMumps, students - UK & Ireland 20041110.3039\nMumps, students - UK 20041103.2974\nMumps - UK (Scotland) (03) 20040223.0575\nMumps - UK (Scotland) (02): background 20040221.0554\nMumps - UK (Scotland) 20040220.0545\n2003\n----\nMumps, increase - UK (02) 20031123.2910\nMumps, increase - UK 20030524.1284\n2001\n----\nMumps, consequence of reduced MMRV uptake - UK (02) 20010831.2069\nMumps, consequence of reduced MMRV uptake - UK 20010806.1858\n1999\n----\nMumps & Rubini vaccine - Singapore 19991025.1937\nMumps, imported - UK: RFI 19990223.0241\n1997\n----\nMumps - Canada (British Columbia) (02) 19971123.2351\nMumps - Canada (British Columbia) 19971119.2336\n1995\n----\nMumps surveillance - US (MMWR Supplement SS-3) 19950811.0672\n...........................mpp/msp/lm\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail.
