"https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1748", "date": "2006-04-14 23:50:00", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (NEBRASKA, IOWA) (04): AIR TRAVEL EXPOSURE\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 11 Apr 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: MMWR, 11 Apr 2006 / 55(Dispatch); 1-2 [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm55d411a1.htm?s_cid=mm55d411a1_e>\n\nExposure to Mumps During Air Travel - United States, April 2006\n-----------------------------------------------\nThe state of Iowa has been experiencing a large mumps outbreak that\nbegan in December 2005 (1). As of 10 Apr 2006, a total of 515\npossible mumps cases have been reported to the Iowa Department of\nPublic Health (IDPH) during 2006 (2). This outbreak has spread across\nIowa, and mumps activity, possibly linked to the Iowa outbreak, is\nunder investigation in 6 neighboring states, including Illinois (n =\n4), Kansas (n = 33), Minnesota (n = one), Missouri (n = 4), Nebraska\n(n = 43), and Wisconsin (n = 4) (CDC, unpublished data, 10 Apr 2006).\nThe reasons for this outbreak are under investigation.\nMumps is an acute viral infection characterized by a nonspecific\nprodrome, including myalgia, anorexia, malaise, headache, and fever,\nfollowed by acute onset of unilateral or bilateral tender swelling of\nparotid or other salivary glands (2). An estimated 60 percent to 70\npercent of mumps infections produce typical acute parotitis (3).\nApproximately 20 percent of infections are asymptomatic, and nearly\n50 percent are associated with nonspecific or primarily respiratory\nsymptoms. Complications include orchitis, oophoritis, or mastitis\n(inflammation of the testicles, ovaries, or breasts, respectively),\nmeningitis/encephalitis, spontaneous abortion, and deafness.\nTransmission occurs by direct contact with respiratory droplets or\nsaliva. The incubation period is 14-18 days (range: 14-25 days) from\nexposure to onset of symptoms. The infectious period is from 3 days\nbefore symptom onset until 9 days after onset of symptoms.\nIDPH has identified 2 persons who had mumps diagnosed and were\npotentially infectious during travel on 9 different commercial\nflights involving 2 airlines during 26 Mar-2 Apr 2006. The commercial\nairline flights identified with a potentially infectious traveler are\nlisted below by date, carrier, and flight number:\nNorthwest Airline (NWA) flights:\n26 Mar 2006 - NWA (Mesaba) #3025 from Waterloo, Iowa to Minneapolis, Minnesota\n26 Mar 2006 - NWA #760 from Minneapolis, Minnesota, to Detroit, Michigan\n27 Mar 2006 - NWA #0260 from Detroit, Michigan, to Washington,\nDC--Reagan National\n29 Mar 2006 - NWA #1705 from Washington, DC--Reagan National to\nMinneapolis, Minnesota\n29 Mar 2006 - NWA (Mesaba) #3026 from Minneapolis, Minnesota, to Waterloo, Iowa\nAmerican Airlines (AA) flights:\n2 Apr 2006 - AA #1216 from Tucson, Arizona, to Dallas, Texas (DFW)\n2 Apr 2006 - AA #3617 from DFW to Lafayette, Arkansas (Northwest\nArkansas Regional [NAR])\n2 Apr 2006 - AA #5399 from NAR to St. Louis, Missouri\n2 Apr 2006 - AA #5498 from St. Louis, Missouri, to Cedar Rapids, Iowa\nPersons on these flights who have symptoms consistent with mumps\nwithin 21 days of travel should be evaluated for mumps by an\nhealth-care provider. Health-care providers should remain vigilant\nfor mumps among persons with parotitis or other salivary gland\ninflammation. Cases of suspected mumps should be reported immediately\nto public health officials.\nA multistate investigation has been initiated by CDC and the state\nhealth departments in affected states to notify potentially exposed\npassengers (i.e., those seated in close proximity to the index\ncases). This investigation is using a new software application,\neManifest, developed by the CDC Division of Global Migration and\nQuarantine (DGMQ) to securely import, sort, and assign\npassenger-locating information to jurisdictions to facilitate timely\nidentification of exposed persons. These data are securely\ntransmitted to state and territorial health departments via the\nEpidemic Information Exchange (Epi-X) Forum (available at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/epix/epix.html>) for notification of\npotentially exposed passengers.\nIncidence of mumps in the United States began to decrease after\nvaccine introduction in 1967 and recommendations for routine\nvaccination of children in 1977. Since the 1990s, a further decrease\nin the reported incidence of mumps has occurred, which is thought to\nbe attributable to the implementation of the 2nd dose of measles,\nmumps, and rubella vaccine (3). The risk for transmission of\nrespiratory infectious diseases during air travel might depend on\nseveral factors, including 1) immunity of passengers; 2)\ninfectiousness of the organism; 3) degree of shedding of the pathogen\nby infected passengers; 4) hygienic practices of infectious\npassengers; 5) proximity of others to infectious passengers; 6)\nhygienic practices of the other passengers/crew; 7) flight duration;\nand 8) cabin environment of the aircraft (4). Transmission of other\nrespiratory pathogens during air travel has been reported (5-9).\nExposure and transmission of mumps during commercial air travel has\nnot been described previously.\n[Reported by: P Quinlisk, MD, Iowa Dept of Public Health. S Redd, G\nDayan, MD, National Center for Immunization and Respiratory Diseases;\nN Gallagher, Geographic Medicine and Health Promotion Br, P Lutz, K\nMarienau, MD, F Averhoff, MD, Quarantine and Border Health Svcs Br,\nDiv of Global Migration and Quarantine, National Center for\nInfectious Diseases, CDC.]\nReferences:\n1. CDC. Mumps epidemic, Iowa, 2006. MMWR 2006;55:366-8.\n2. Iowa Department of Public Health, Center for Acute Disease\nEpidemiology. Iowa mumps update. Des Moines, Iowa: Iowa Department of\nPublic Health; 2006. Available at\n<http://www.idph.state.ia.us/adper/common/pdf/mumps/mumps_update_041106.pdf>.\n3. Plotkin SA, Orenstein WA, eds. Vaccines. 4th ed. Philadelphia, PA:\nWB Saunders; 2003:441-69.\n4. Mangili A, Glendreau M. Transmission of infectious diseases during\ncommercial air travel. Lancet 2005;365:989-96.\n5. World Health Organization. Tuberculosis and air travel: guidelines\nfor prevention and control. 2nd ed. Geneva, Switzerland: World Health\nOrganization; 2006:5-7. Available at:\n<http://www.who.int/docstore/gtb/publications/aircraft/PDF/98_256.pdf>\n6. CDC. Postexposure prophylaxis, isolation, and quarantine to\ncontrol an import-associated measles outbreak - Iowa, 2004. MMWR\n2004; 53:969-71.\n7. Moser MR, Bend TR, Margolis HS, et al. An outbreak of influenza\naboard a commercial airline. Am J Epidemiol 1979;110:1-6.\n8. Klonz KC, Hynes NA, Gunn RA, et al. An outbreak of influenza\nA/Taiwan/1/86 infections at a naval base and its association with\nairplane travel. Am J Epidemiol 1989;129:341-8.\n9. Marsden AG. Influenza outbreak related to air travel. Med J\nAustral 2003;179:172-3.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[ProMED-mail has been covering this unusual outbreak due to the size\nof the outbreak, the genotype involved (genotype G, most recently\nassociated with outbreaks in the United Kingdom) and now the\nadditional information that there may be spread to neighboring states\nand the possibility of exposure during airline travel. The mention of\na new software application \"eManifest\" is interesting, and one\nwonders whether it shortens the time necessary to identify passengers\nat risk of exposure to diseases while traveling. We look forward to\nhearing more about this tool. - Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\nMumps - USA (NE, IA) (03) 20060406.1037\nMumps - USA (NE, IA)(02) 20060405.1023\nMumps - USA (NE, IA) 20060403.1000\nMumps virus, genotype G - USA (IA) 20060315.0809\n2004\n----\nMumps, students - UK (02) 20041126.3166\nMumps, students - UK & Ireland (03) 20041117.3089\nMumps, students - UK & Ireland (02) 20041112.3055\nMumps, students - UK & Ireland 20041110.3039\nMumps, students - UK 20041103.2974\nMumps - UK (Scotland) (03) 20040223.0575\nMumps - UK (Scotland) (02): background 20040221.0554\nMumps - UK (Scotland) 20040220.0545\n2003\n----\nMumps, increase - UK (02) 20031123.2910\nMumps, increase - UK 20030524.1284\n2001\n----\nMumps, consequence of reduced MMRV uptake - UK (02) 20010831.2069\nMumps, consequence of reduced MMRV uptake - UK 20010806.1858\n1999\n----\nMumps & Rubini vaccine - Singapore 19991025.1937\nMumps, imported - UK: RFI 19990223.0241\n1997\n----\nMumps - Canada (British Columbia) (02) 19971123.2351\nMumps - Canada (British Columbia) 19971119.2336\n1995\n----\nMumps surveillance - US (MMWR Supplement SS-3) 19950811.0672\n...........................mpp/msp/lm\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. "mumps", "rubella", "tuberculosis", "encephalitis", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2006-04-16 00:00:00", "2005-12-16 00:00:00", "Lafayette", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Minneapolis", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "British Columbia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Waterloo", "country": "unknown"}, States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mesaba", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1692", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Austria (Carinthia)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1692", "date": "2006-04-14 23:50:00", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (NEBRASKA, IOWA) (04): AIR TRAVEL EXPOSURE\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 11 Apr 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: MMWR, 11 Apr 2006 / 55(Dispatch); 1-2 [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm55d411a1.htm?s_cid=mm55d411a1_e>\n\nExposure to Mumps During Air Travel - United States, April 2006\n-----------------------------------------------\nThe state of Iowa has been experiencing a large mumps outbreak that\nbegan in December 2005 (1). As of 10 Apr 2006, a total of 515\npossible mumps cases have been reported to the Iowa Department of\nPublic Health (IDPH) during 2006 (2). This outbreak has spread across\nIowa, and mumps activity, possibly linked to the Iowa outbreak, is\nunder investigation in 6 neighboring states, including Illinois (n =\n4), Kansas (n = 33), Minnesota (n = one), Missouri (n = 4), Nebraska\n(n = 43), and Wisconsin (n = 4) (CDC, unpublished data, 10 Apr 2006).\nThe reasons for this outbreak are under investigation.\nMumps is an acute viral infection characterized by a nonspecific\nprodrome, including myalgia, anorexia, malaise, headache, and fever,\nfollowed by acute onset of unilateral or bilateral tender swelling of\nparotid or other salivary glands (2). An estimated 60 percent to 70\npercent of mumps infections produce typical acute parotitis (3).\nApproximately 20 percent of infections are asymptomatic, and nearly\n50 percent are associated with nonspecific or primarily respiratory\nsymptoms. Complications include orchitis, oophoritis, or mastitis\n(inflammation of the testicles, ovaries, or breasts, respectively),\nmeningitis/encephalitis, spontaneous abortion, and deafness.\nTransmission occurs by direct contact with respiratory droplets or\nsaliva. The incubation period is 14-18 days (range: 14-25 days) from\nexposure to onset of symptoms. The infectious period is from 3 days\nbefore symptom onset until 9 days after onset of symptoms.\nIDPH has identified 2 persons who had mumps diagnosed and were\npotentially infectious during travel on 9 different commercial\nflights involving 2 airlines during 26 Mar-2 Apr 2006. The commercial\nairline flights identified with a potentially infectious traveler are\nlisted below by date, carrier, and flight number:\nNorthwest Airline (NWA) flights:\n26 Mar 2006 - NWA (Mesaba) #3025 from Waterloo, Iowa to Minneapolis, Minnesota\n26 Mar 2006 - NWA #760 from Minneapolis, Minnesota, to Detroit, Michigan\n27 Mar 2006 - NWA #0260 from Detroit, Michigan, to Washington,\nDC--Reagan National\n29 Mar 2006 - NWA #1705 from Washington, DC--Reagan National to\nMinneapolis, Minnesota\n29 Mar 2006 - NWA (Mesaba) #3026 from Minneapolis, Minnesota, to Waterloo, Iowa\nAmerican Airlines (AA) flights:\n2 Apr 2006 - AA #1216 from Tucson, Arizona, to Dallas, Texas (DFW)\n2 Apr 2006 - AA #3617 from DFW to Lafayette, Arkansas (Northwest\nArkansas Regional [NAR])\n2 Apr 2006 - AA #5399 from NAR to St. Louis, Missouri\n2 Apr 2006 - AA #5498 from St. Louis, Missouri, to Cedar Rapids, Iowa\nPersons on these flights who have symptoms consistent with mumps\nwithin 21 days of travel should be evaluated for mumps by an\nhealth-care provider. Health-care providers should remain vigilant\nfor mumps among persons with parotitis or other salivary gland\ninflammation. Cases of suspected mumps should be reported immediately\nto public health officials.\nA multistate investigation has been initiated by CDC and the state\nhealth departments in affected states to notify potentially exposed\npassengers (i.e., those seated in close proximity to the index\ncases). This investigation is using a new software application,\neManifest, developed by the CDC Division of Global Migration and\nQuarantine (DGMQ) to securely import, sort, and assign\npassenger-locating information to jurisdictions to facilitate timely\nidentification of exposed persons. These data are securely\ntransmitted to state and territorial health departments via the\nEpidemic Information Exchange (Epi-X) Forum (available at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/epix/epix.html>) for notification of\npotentially exposed passengers.\nIncidence of mumps in the United States began to decrease after\nvaccine introduction in 1967 and recommendations for routine\nvaccination of children in 1977. Since the 1990s, a further decrease\nin the reported incidence of mumps has occurred, which is thought to\nbe attributable to the implementation of the 2nd dose of measles,\nmumps, and rubella vaccine (3). The risk for transmission of\nrespiratory infectious diseases during air travel might depend on\nseveral factors, including 1) immunity of passengers; 2)\ninfectiousness of the organism; 3) degree of shedding of the pathogen\nby infected passengers; 4) hygienic practices of infectious\npassengers; 5) proximity of others to infectious passengers; 6)\nhygienic practices of the other passengers/crew; 7) flight duration;\nand 8) cabin environment of the aircraft (4). Transmission of other\nrespiratory pathogens during air travel has been reported (5-9).\nExposure and transmission of mumps during commercial air travel has\nnot been described previously.\n[Reported by: P Quinlisk, MD, Iowa Dept of Public Health. S Redd, G\nDayan, MD, National Center for Immunization and Respiratory Diseases;\nN Gallagher, Geographic Medicine and Health Promotion Br, P Lutz, K\nMarienau, MD, F Averhoff, MD, Quarantine and Border Health Svcs Br,\nDiv of Global Migration and Quarantine, National Center for\nInfectious Diseases, CDC.]\nReferences:\n1. CDC. Mumps epidemic, Iowa, 2006. MMWR 2006;55:366-8.\n2. Iowa Department of Public Health, Center for Acute Disease\nEpidemiology. Iowa mumps update. Des Moines, Iowa: Iowa Department of\nPublic Health; 2006. Available at\n<http://www.idph.state.ia.us/adper/common/pdf/mumps/mumps_update_041106.pdf>.\n3. Plotkin SA, Orenstein WA, eds. Vaccines. 4th ed. Philadelphia, PA:\nWB Saunders; 2003:441-69.\n4. Mangili A, Glendreau M. Transmission of infectious diseases during\ncommercial air travel. Lancet 2005;365:989-96.\n5. World Health Organization. Tuberculosis and air travel: guidelines\nfor prevention and control. 2nd ed. Geneva, Switzerland: World Health\nOrganization; 2006:5-7. Available at:\n<http://www.who.int/docstore/gtb/publications/aircraft/PDF/98_256.pdf>\n6. CDC. Postexposure prophylaxis, isolation, and quarantine to\ncontrol an import-associated measles outbreak - Iowa, 2004. MMWR\n2004; 53:969-71.\n7. Moser MR, Bend TR, Margolis HS, et al. An outbreak of influenza\naboard a commercial airline. Am J Epidemiol 1979;110:1-6.\n8. Klonz KC, Hynes NA, Gunn RA, et al. An outbreak of influenza\nA/Taiwan/1/86 infections at a naval base and its association with\nairplane travel. Am J Epidemiol 1989;129:341-8.\n9. Marsden AG. Influenza outbreak related to air travel. Med J\nAustral 2003;179:172-3.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[ProMED-mail has been covering this unusual outbreak due to the size\nof the outbreak, the genotype involved (genotype G, most recently\nassociated with outbreaks in the United Kingdom) and now the\nadditional information that there may be spread to neighboring states\nand the possibility of exposure during airline travel. The mention of\na new software application \"eManifest\" is interesting, and one\nwonders whether it shortens the time necessary to identify passengers\nat risk of exposure to diseases while traveling. We look forward to\nhearing more about this tool. - Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\nMumps - USA (NE, IA) (03) 20060406.1037\nMumps - USA (NE, IA)(02) 20060405.1023\nMumps - USA (NE, IA) 20060403.1000\nMumps virus, genotype G - USA (IA) 20060315.0809\n2004\n----\nMumps, students - UK (02) 20041126.3166\nMumps, students - UK & Ireland (03) 20041117.3089\nMumps, students - UK & Ireland (02) 20041112.3055\nMumps, students - UK & Ireland 20041110.3039\nMumps, students - UK 20041103.2974\nMumps - UK (Scotland) (03) 20040223.0575\nMumps - UK (Scotland) (02): background 20040221.0554\nMumps - UK (Scotland) 20040220.0545\n2003\n----\nMumps, increase - UK (02) 20031123.2910\nMumps, increase - UK 20030524.1284\n2001\n----\nMumps, consequence of reduced MMRV uptake - UK (02) 20010831.2069\nMumps, consequence of reduced MMRV uptake - UK 20010806.1858\n1999\n----\nMumps & Rubini vaccine - Singapore 19991025.1937\nMumps, imported - UK: RFI 19990223.0241\n1997\n----\nMumps - Canada (British Columbia) (02) 19971123.2351\nMumps - Canada (British Columbia) 19971119.2336\n1995\n----\nMumps surveillance - US (MMWR Supplement SS-3) 19950811.0672\n...........................mpp/msp/lm\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1391", "date": "2006-04-14 23:50:00", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (NEBRASKA, IOWA) (04): AIR TRAVEL EXPOSURE\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 11 Apr 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: MMWR, 11 Apr 2006 / 55(Dispatch); 1-2 [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm55d411a1.htm?s_cid=mm55d411a1_e>\n\nExposure to Mumps During Air Travel - United States, April 2006\n-----------------------------------------------\nThe state of Iowa has been experiencing a large mumps outbreak that\nbegan in December 2005 (1). As of 10 Apr 2006, a total of 515\npossible mumps cases have been reported to the Iowa Department of\nPublic Health (IDPH) during 2006 (2). This outbreak has spread across\nIowa, and mumps activity, possibly linked to the Iowa outbreak, is\nunder investigation in 6 neighboring states, including Illinois (n =\n4), Kansas (n = 33), Minnesota (n = one), Missouri (n = 4), Nebraska\n(n = 43), and Wisconsin (n = 4) (CDC, unpublished data, 10 Apr 2006).\nThe reasons for this outbreak are under investigation.\nMumps is an acute viral infection characterized by a nonspecific\nprodrome, including myalgia, anorexia, malaise, headache, and fever,\nfollowed by acute onset of unilateral or bilateral tender swelling of\nparotid or other salivary glands (2). An estimated 60 percent to 70\npercent of mumps infections produce typical acute parotitis (3).\nApproximately 20 percent of infections are asymptomatic, and nearly\n50 percent are associated with nonspecific or primarily respiratory\nsymptoms. Complications include orchitis, oophoritis, or mastitis\n(inflammation of the testicles, ovaries, or breasts, respectively),\nmeningitis/encephalitis, spontaneous abortion, and deafness.\nTransmission occurs by direct contact with respiratory droplets or\nsaliva. The incubation period is 14-18 days (range: 14-25 days) from\nexposure to onset of symptoms. The infectious period is from 3 days\nbefore symptom onset until 9 days after onset of symptoms.\nIDPH has identified 2 persons who had mumps diagnosed and were\npotentially infectious during travel on 9 different commercial\nflights involving 2 airlines during 26 Mar-2 Apr 2006. The commercial\nairline flights identified with a potentially infectious traveler are\nlisted below by date, carrier, and flight number:\nNorthwest Airline (NWA) flights:\n26 Mar 2006 - NWA (Mesaba) #3025 from Waterloo, Iowa to Minneapolis, Minnesota\n26 Mar 2006 - NWA #760 from Minneapolis, Minnesota, to Detroit, Michigan\n27 Mar 2006 - NWA #0260 from Detroit, Michigan, to Washington,\nDC--Reagan National\n29 Mar 2006 - NWA #1705 from Washington, DC--Reagan National to\nMinneapolis, Minnesota\n29 Mar 2006 - NWA (Mesaba) #3026 from Minneapolis, Minnesota, to Waterloo, Iowa\nAmerican Airlines (AA) flights:\n2 Apr 2006 - AA #1216 from Tucson, Arizona, to Dallas, Texas (DFW)\n2 Apr 2006 - AA #3617 from DFW to Lafayette, Arkansas (Northwest\nArkansas Regional [NAR])\n2 Apr 2006 - AA #5399 from NAR to St. Louis, Missouri\n2 Apr 2006 - AA #5498 from St. Louis, Missouri, to Cedar Rapids, Iowa\nPersons on these flights who have symptoms consistent with mumps\nwithin 21 days of travel should be evaluated for mumps by an\nhealth-care provider. Health-care providers should remain vigilant\nfor mumps among persons with parotitis or other salivary gland\ninflammation. Cases of suspected mumps should be reported immediately\nto public health officials.\nA multistate investigation has been initiated by CDC and the state\nhealth departments in affected states to notify potentially exposed\npassengers (i.e., those seated in close proximity to the index\ncases). This investigation is using a new software application,\neManifest, developed by the CDC Division of Global Migration and\nQuarantine (DGMQ) to securely import, sort, and assign\npassenger-locating information to jurisdictions to facilitate timely\nidentification of exposed persons. These data are securely\ntransmitted to state and territorial health departments via the\nEpidemic Information Exchange (Epi-X) Forum (available at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/epix/epix.html>) for notification of\npotentially exposed passengers.\nIncidence of mumps in the United States began to decrease after\nvaccine introduction in 1967 and recommendations for routine\nvaccination of children in 1977. Since the 1990s, a further decrease\nin the reported incidence of mumps has occurred, which is thought to\nbe attributable to the implementation of the 2nd dose of measles,\nmumps, and rubella vaccine (3). The risk for transmission of\nrespiratory infectious diseases during air travel might depend on\nseveral factors, including 1) immunity of passengers; 2)\ninfectiousness of the organism; 3) degree of shedding of the pathogen\nby infected passengers; 4) hygienic practices of infectious\npassengers; 5) proximity of others to infectious passengers; 6)\nhygienic practices of the other passengers/crew; 7) flight duration;\nand 8) cabin environment of the aircraft (4). Transmission of other\nrespiratory pathogens during air travel has been reported (5-9).\nExposure and transmission of mumps during commercial air travel has\nnot been described previously.\n[Reported by: P Quinlisk, MD, Iowa Dept of Public Health. S Redd, G\nDayan, MD, National Center for Immunization and Respiratory Diseases;\nN Gallagher, Geographic Medicine and Health Promotion Br, P Lutz, K\nMarienau, MD, F Averhoff, MD, Quarantine and Border Health Svcs Br,\nDiv of Global Migration and Quarantine, National Center for\nInfectious Diseases, CDC.]\nReferences:\n1. CDC. Mumps epidemic, Iowa, 2006. MMWR 2006;55:366-8.\n2. Iowa Department of Public Health, Center for Acute Disease\nEpidemiology. Iowa mumps update. Des Moines, Iowa: Iowa Department of\nPublic Health; 2006. Available at\n<http://www.idph.state.ia.us/adper/common/pdf/mumps/mumps_update_041106.pdf>.\n3. Plotkin SA, Orenstein WA, eds. Vaccines. 4th ed. Philadelphia, PA:\nWB Saunders; 2003:441-69.\n4. Mangili A, Glendreau M. Transmission of infectious diseases during\ncommercial air travel. Lancet 2005;365:989-96.\n5. World Health Organization. Tuberculosis and air travel: guidelines\nfor prevention and control. 2nd ed. Geneva, Switzerland: World Health\nOrganization; 2006:5-7. Available at:\n<http://www.who.int/docstore/gtb/publications/aircraft/PDF/98_256.pdf>\n6. CDC. Postexposure prophylaxis, isolation, and quarantine to\ncontrol an import-associated measles outbreak - Iowa, 2004. MMWR\n2004; 53:969-71.\n7. Moser MR, Bend TR, Margolis HS, et al. An outbreak of influenza\naboard a commercial airline. Am J Epidemiol 1979;110:1-6.\n8. Klonz KC, Hynes NA, Gunn RA, et al. An outbreak of influenza\nA/Taiwan/1/86 infections at a naval base and its association with\nairplane travel. Am J Epidemiol 1989;129:341-8.\n9. Marsden AG. Influenza outbreak related to air travel. Med J\nAustral 2003;179:172-3.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[ProMED-mail has been covering this unusual outbreak due to the size\nof the outbreak, the genotype involved (genotype G, most recently\nassociated with outbreaks in the United Kingdom) and now the\nadditional information that there may be spread to neighboring states\nand the possibility of exposure during airline travel. The mention of\na new software application \"eManifest\" is interesting, and one\nwonders whether it shortens the time necessary to identify passengers\nat risk of exposure to diseases while traveling. We look forward to\nhearing more about this tool. - Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\nMumps - USA (NE, IA) (03) 20060406.1037\nMumps - USA (NE, IA)(02) 20060405.1023\nMumps - USA (NE, IA) 20060403.1000\nMumps virus, genotype G - USA (IA) 20060315.0809\n2004\n----\nMumps, students - UK (02) 20041126.3166\nMumps, students - UK & Ireland (03) 20041117.3089\nMumps, students - UK & Ireland (02) 20041112.3055\nMumps, students - UK & Ireland 20041110.3039\nMumps, students - UK 20041103.2974\nMumps - UK (Scotland) (03) 20040223.0575\nMumps - UK (Scotland) (02): background 20040221.0554\nMumps - UK (Scotland) 20040220.0545\n2003\n----\nMumps, increase - UK (02) 20031123.2910\nMumps, increase - UK 20030524.1284\n2001\n----\nMumps, consequence of reduced MMRV uptake - UK (02) 20010831.2069\nMumps, consequence of reduced MMRV uptake - UK 20010806.1858\n1999\n----\nMumps & Rubini vaccine - Singapore 19991025.1937\nMumps, imported - UK: RFI 19990223.0241\n1997\n----\nMumps - Canada (British Columbia) (02) 19971123.2351\nMumps - Canada (British Columbia) 19971119.2336\n1995\n----\nMumps surveillance - US (MMWR Supplement SS-3) 19950811.0672\n...........................mpp/msp/lm\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella", "tuberculosis", "encephalitis", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2006-04-16 00:00:00", "2005-12-16 00:00:00", "2006-04-10 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2043-03-16 00:00:00", "5399-03-16 00:00:00", "1967-03-16 00:00:00", "1977-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-05-09 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Lafayette", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Minneapolis", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "British Columbia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Waterloo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Northwest", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Iowa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington ,", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "- United States", "country": "unknown"}, States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mesaba", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1225", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - China (Nanjing)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1225", "date": "2006-04-14 23:50:00", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (NEBRASKA, IOWA) (04): AIR TRAVEL EXPOSURE\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 11 Apr 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: MMWR, 11 Apr 2006 / 55(Dispatch); 1-2 [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm55d411a1.htm?s_cid=mm55d411a1_e>\n\nExposure to Mumps During Air Travel - United States, April 2006\n-----------------------------------------------\nThe state of Iowa has been experiencing a large mumps outbreak that\nbegan in December 2005 (1). As of 10 Apr 2006, a total of 515\npossible mumps cases have been reported to the Iowa Department of\nPublic Health (IDPH) during 2006 (2). This outbreak has spread across\nIowa, and mumps activity, possibly linked to the Iowa outbreak, is\nunder investigation in 6 neighboring states, including Illinois (n =\n4), Kansas (n = 33), Minnesota (n = one), Missouri (n = 4), Nebraska\n(n = 43), and Wisconsin (n = 4) (CDC, unpublished data, 10 Apr 2006).\nThe reasons for this outbreak are under investigation.\nMumps is an acute viral infection characterized by a nonspecific\nprodrome, including myalgia, anorexia, malaise, headache, and fever,\nfollowed by acute onset of unilateral or bilateral tender swelling of\nparotid or other salivary glands (2). An estimated 60 percent to 70\npercent of mumps infections produce typical acute parotitis (3).\nApproximately 20 percent of infections are asymptomatic, and nearly\n50 percent are associated with nonspecific or primarily respiratory\nsymptoms. Complications include orchitis, oophoritis, or mastitis\n(inflammation of the testicles, ovaries, or breasts, respectively),\nmeningitis/encephalitis, spontaneous abortion, and deafness.\nTransmission occurs by direct contact with respiratory droplets or\nsaliva. The incubation period is 14-18 days (range: 14-25 days) from\nexposure to onset of symptoms. The infectious period is from 3 days\nbefore symptom onset until 9 days after onset of symptoms.\nIDPH has identified 2 persons who had mumps diagnosed and were\npotentially infectious during travel on 9 different commercial\nflights involving 2 airlines during 26 Mar-2 Apr 2006. The commercial\nairline flights identified with a potentially infectious traveler are\nlisted below by date, carrier, and flight number:\nNorthwest Airline (NWA) flights:\n26 Mar 2006 - NWA (Mesaba) #3025 from Waterloo, Iowa to Minneapolis, Minnesota\n26 Mar 2006 - NWA #760 from Minneapolis, Minnesota, to Detroit, Michigan\n27 Mar 2006 - NWA #0260 from Detroit, Michigan, to Washington,\nDC--Reagan National\n29 Mar 2006 - NWA #1705 from Washington, DC--Reagan National to\nMinneapolis, Minnesota\n29 Mar 2006 - NWA (Mesaba) #3026 from Minneapolis, Minnesota, to Waterloo, Iowa\nAmerican Airlines (AA) flights:\n2 Apr 2006 - AA #1216 from Tucson, Arizona, to Dallas, Texas (DFW)\n2 Apr 2006 - AA #3617 from DFW to Lafayette, Arkansas (Northwest\nArkansas Regional [NAR])\n2 Apr 2006 - AA #5399 from NAR to St. Louis, Missouri\n2 Apr 2006 - AA #5498 from St. Louis, Missouri, to Cedar Rapids, Iowa\nPersons on these flights who have symptoms consistent with mumps\nwithin 21 days of travel should be evaluated for mumps by an\nhealth-care provider. Health-care providers should remain vigilant\nfor mumps among persons with parotitis or other salivary gland\ninflammation. Cases of suspected mumps should be reported immediately\nto public health officials.\nA multistate investigation has been initiated by CDC and the state\nhealth departments in affected states to notify potentially exposed\npassengers (i.e., those seated in close proximity to the index\ncases). This investigation is using a new software application,\neManifest, developed by the CDC Division of Global Migration and\nQuarantine (DGMQ) to securely import, sort, and assign\npassenger-locating information to jurisdictions to facilitate timely\nidentification of exposed persons. These data are securely\ntransmitted to state and territorial health departments via the\nEpidemic Information Exchange (Epi-X) Forum (available at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/epix/epix.html>) for notification of\npotentially exposed passengers.\nIncidence of mumps in the United States began to decrease after\nvaccine introduction in 1967 and recommendations for routine\nvaccination of children in 1977. Since the 1990s, a further decrease\nin the reported incidence of mumps has occurred, which is thought to\nbe attributable to the implementation of the 2nd dose of measles,\nmumps, and rubella vaccine (3). The risk for transmission of\nrespiratory infectious diseases during air travel might depend on\nseveral factors, including 1) immunity of passengers; 2)\ninfectiousness of the organism; 3) degree of shedding of the pathogen\nby infected passengers; 4) hygienic practices of infectious\npassengers; 5) proximity of others to infectious passengers; 6)\nhygienic practices of the other passengers/crew; 7) flight duration;\nand 8) cabin environment of the aircraft (4). Transmission of other\nrespiratory pathogens during air travel has been reported (5-9).\nExposure and transmission of mumps during commercial air travel has\nnot been described previously.\n[Reported by: P Quinlisk, MD, Iowa Dept of Public Health. S Redd, G\nDayan, MD, National Center for Immunization and Respiratory Diseases;\nN Gallagher, Geographic Medicine and Health Promotion Br, P Lutz, K\nMarienau, MD, F Averhoff, MD, Quarantine and Border Health Svcs Br,\nDiv of Global Migration and Quarantine, National Center for\nInfectious Diseases, CDC.]\nReferences:\n1. CDC. Mumps epidemic, Iowa, 2006. MMWR 2006;55:366-8.\n2. Iowa Department of Public Health, Center for Acute Disease\nEpidemiology. Iowa mumps update. Des Moines, Iowa: Iowa Department of\nPublic Health; 2006. Available at\n<http://www.idph.state.ia.us/adper/common/pdf/mumps/mumps_update_041106.pdf>.\n3. Plotkin SA, Orenstein WA, eds. Vaccines. 4th ed. Philadelphia, PA:\nWB Saunders; 2003:441-69.\n4. Mangili A, Glendreau M. Transmission of infectious diseases during\ncommercial air travel. Lancet 2005;365:989-96.\n5. World Health Organization. Tuberculosis and air travel: guidelines\nfor prevention and control. 2nd ed. Geneva, Switzerland: World Health\nOrganization; 2006:5-7. Available at:\n<http://www.who.int/docstore/gtb/publications/aircraft/PDF/98_256.pdf>\n6. CDC. Postexposure prophylaxis, isolation, and quarantine to\ncontrol an import-associated measles outbreak - Iowa, 2004. MMWR\n2004; 53:969-71.\n7. Moser MR, Bend TR, Margolis HS, et al. An outbreak of influenza\naboard a commercial airline. Am J Epidemiol 1979;110:1-6.\n8. Klonz KC, Hynes NA, Gunn RA, et al. An outbreak of influenza\nA/Taiwan/1/86 infections at a naval base and its association with\nairplane travel. Am J Epidemiol 1989;129:341-8.\n9. Marsden AG. Influenza outbreak related to air travel. Med J\nAustral 2003;179:172-3.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[ProMED-mail has been covering this unusual outbreak due to the size\nof the outbreak, the genotype involved (genotype G, most recently\nassociated with outbreaks in the United Kingdom) and now the\nadditional information that there may be spread to neighboring states\nand the possibility of exposure during airline travel. The mention of\na new software application \"eManifest\" is interesting, and one\nwonders whether it shortens the time necessary to identify passengers\nat risk of exposure to diseases while traveling. We look forward to\nhearing more about this tool. - Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\nMumps - USA (NE, IA) (03) 20060406.1037\nMumps - USA (NE, IA)(02) 20060405.1023\nMumps - USA (NE, IA) 20060403.1000\nMumps virus, genotype G - USA (IA) 20060315.0809\n2004\n----\nMumps, students - UK (02) 20041126.3166\nMumps, students - UK & Ireland (03) 20041117.3089\nMumps, students - UK & Ireland (02) 20041112.3055\nMumps, students - UK & Ireland 20041110.3039\nMumps, students - UK 20041103.2974\nMumps - UK (Scotland) (03) 20040223.0575\nMumps - UK (Scotland) (02): background 20040221.0554\nMumps - UK (Scotland) 20040220.0545\n2003\n----\nMumps, increase - UK (02) 20031123.2910\nMumps, increase - UK 20030524.1284\n2001\n----\nMumps, consequence of reduced MMRV uptake - UK (02) 20010831.2069\nMumps, consequence of reduced MMRV uptake - UK 20010806.1858\n1999\n----\nMumps & Rubini vaccine - Singapore 19991025.1937\nMumps, imported - UK: RFI 19990223.0241\n1997\n----\nMumps - Canada (British Columbia) (02) 19971123.2351\nMumps - Canada (British Columbia) 19971119.2336\n1995\n----\nMumps surveillance - US (MMWR Supplement SS-3) 19950811.0672\n...........................mpp/msp/lm\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. EXPOSURE\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm55d411a1.htm?s_cid=mm55d411a1_e>\n\nExposure to Mumps During Air Travel - United States, April 2006\n-----------------------------------------------\nThe state of Iowa has been experiencing a large mumps outbreak that\nbegan in December 2005 (1). As of 10 Apr 2006, a total of 515\npossible mumps cases have been reported to the Iowa Department of\nPublic Health (IDPH) during 2006 (2). This outbreak has spread across\nIowa, and mumps activity, possibly linked to the Iowa outbreak, is\nunder investigation in 6 neighboring states, including Illinois (n =\n4), Kansas (n = 33), Minnesota (n = one), Missouri (n = 4), Nebraska\n(n = 43), and Wisconsin (n = 4) (CDC, unpublished data, 10 Apr 2006).\nThe reasons for this outbreak are under investigation.\nMumps is an acute viral infection characterized by a nonspecific\nprodrome, including myalgia, anorexia, malaise, headache, and fever,\nfollowed by acute onset of unilateral or bilateral tender swelling of\nparotid or other salivary glands (2). An estimated 60 percent to 70\npercent of mumps infections produce typical acute parotitis (3).\nApproximately 20 percent of infections are asymptomatic, and nearly\n50 percent are associated with nonspecific or primarily respiratory\nsymptoms. Complications include orchitis, oophoritis, or mastitis\n(inflammation of the testicles, ovaries, or breasts, respectively),\nmeningitis/encephalitis, spontaneous abortion, and deafness.\nTransmission occurs by direct contact with respiratory droplets or\nsaliva. The incubation period is 14-18 days (range: 14-25 days) from\nexposure to onset of symptoms. The infectious period is from 3 days\nbefore symptom onset until 9 days after onset of symptoms.\nIDPH has identified 2 persons who had mumps diagnosed and were\npotentially infectious during travel on 9 different commercial\nflights involving 2 airlines during 26 Mar-2 Apr 2006. The commercial\nairline flights identified with a potentially infectious traveler are\nlisted below by date, carrier, and flight number:\nNorthwest Airline (NWA) flights:\n26 Mar 2006 - NWA (Mesaba) #3025 from Waterloo, Iowa to Minneapolis, Minnesota\n26 Mar 2006 - NWA #760 from Minneapolis, Minnesota, to Detroit, Michigan\n27 Mar 2006 - NWA #0260 from Detroit, Michigan, to Washington,\nDC--Reagan National\n29 Mar 2006 - NWA #1705 from Washington, DC--Reagan National to\nMinneapolis, Minnesota\n29 Mar 2006 - NWA (Mesaba) #3026 from Minneapolis, Minnesota, to Waterloo, Iowa\nAmerican Airlines (AA) flights:\n2 Apr 2006 - AA #1216 from Tucson, Arizona, to Dallas, Texas (DFW)\n2 Apr 2006 - AA #3617 from DFW to Lafayette, Arkansas (Northwest\nArkansas Regional [NAR])\n2 Apr 2006 - AA #5399 from NAR to St. Louis, Missouri\n2 Apr 2006 - AA #5498 from St. Louis, Missouri, to Cedar Rapids, Iowa\nPersons on these flights who have symptoms consistent with mumps\nwithin 21 days of travel should be evaluated for mumps by an\nhealth-care provider. Health-care providers should remain vigilant\nfor mumps among persons with parotitis or other salivary gland\ninflammation. Cases of suspected mumps should be reported immediately\nto public health officials.\nA multistate investigation has been initiated by CDC and the state\nhealth departments in affected states to notify potentially exposed\npassengers (i.e., those seated in close proximity to the index\ncases). This investigation is using a new software application,\neManifest, developed by the CDC Division of Global Migration and\nQuarantine (DGMQ) to securely import, sort, and assign\npassenger-locating information to jurisdictions to facilitate timely\nidentification of exposed persons. These data are securely\ntransmitted to state and territorial health departments via the\nEpidemic Information Exchange (Epi-X) Forum (available at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/epix/epix.html>) for notification of\npotentially exposed passengers.\nIncidence of mumps in the United States began to decrease after\nvaccine introduction in 1967 and recommendations for routine\nvaccination of children in 1977. Since the 1990s, a further decrease\nin the reported incidence of mumps has occurred, which is thought to\nbe attributable to the implementation of the 2nd dose of measles,\nmumps, and rubella vaccine (3). The risk for transmission of\nrespiratory infectious diseases during air travel might depend on\nseveral factors, including 1) immunity of passengers; 2)\ninfectiousness of the organism; 3) degree of shedding of the pathogen\nby infected passengers; 4) hygienic practices of infectious\npassengers; 5) proximity of others to infectious passengers; 6)\nhygienic practices of the other passengers/crew; 7) flight duration;\nand 8) cabin environment of the aircraft (4). Transmission of other\nrespiratory pathogens during air travel has been reported (5-9).\nExposure and transmission of mumps during commercial air travel has\nnot been described previously.\n[Reported by: P Quinlisk, MD, Iowa Dept of Public Health. S Redd, G\nDayan, MD, National Center for Immunization and Respiratory Diseases;\nN Gallagher, Geographic Medicine and Health Promotion Br, P Lutz, K\nMarienau, MD, F Averhoff, MD, Quarantine and Border Health Svcs Br,\nDiv of Global Migration and Quarantine, National Center for\nInfectious Diseases, CDC.]\nReferences:\n1. Postexposure prophylaxis, isolation, and quarantine to\ncontrol an import-associated measles outbreak - Iowa, 2004. MMWR\n2004; 53:969-71.\n7. Moser MR, Bend TR, Margolis HS, et al. An outbreak of influenza\naboard a commercial airline. Am J Epidemiol 1979;110:1-6.\n8. Klonz KC, Hynes NA, Gunn RA, et al. An outbreak of influenza\nA/Taiwan/1/86 infections at a naval base and its association with\nairplane travel. Am J Epidemiol 1989;129:341-8.\n9. Marsden AG. Influenza outbreak related to air travel. Med J\nAustral 2003;179:172-3.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[ProMED-mail has been covering this unusual outbreak due to the size\nof the outbreak, the genotype involved (genotype G, most recently\nassociated with outbreaks in the United Kingdom) and now the\nadditional information that there may be spread to neighboring states\nand the possibility of exposure during airline travel. The mention of\na new software application \"eManifest\" is interesting, and one\nwonders whether it shortens the time necessary to identify passengers\nat risk of exposure to diseases while traveling. We look forward to\nhearing more about this tool. - Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\nMumps - USA (NE, IA) (03) 20060406.1037\nMumps - USA (NE, IA)(02) 20060405.1023\nMumps - USA (NE, IA) 20060403.1000\nMumps virus, genotype G - USA (IA) 20060315.0809\n2004\n----\nMumps, students - UK (02) 20041126.3166\nMumps, students - UK & Ireland (03) 20041117.3089\nMumps, students - UK & Ireland (02) 20041112.3055\nMumps, students - UK & Ireland 20041110.3039\nMumps, students - UK 20041103.2974\nMumps - UK (Scotland) (03) 20040223.0575\nMumps - UK (Scotland) (02): background 20040221.0554\nMumps - UK (Scotland) 20040220.0545\n2003\n----\nMumps, increase - UK (02) 20031123.2910\nMumps, increase - UK 20030524.1284\n2001\n----\nMumps, consequence of reduced MMRV uptake - UK (02) 20010831.2069\nMumps, consequence of reduced MMRV uptake - UK 20010806.1858\n1999\n----\nMumps & Rubini vaccine - Singapore 19991025.1937\nMumps, imported - UK: RFI 19990223.0241\n1997\n----\nMumps - Canada (British Columbia) (02) 19971123.2351\nMumps - Canada (British Columbia) 19971119.2336\n1995\n----\nMumps surveillance - US (MMWR Supplement SS-3) 19950811.0672\n...........................mpp/msp/lm\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella", "tuberculosis", "encephalitis", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2006-04-16 00:00:00", "2005-12-16 00:00:00", "2006-04-10 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2043-03-16 00:00:00", "5399-03-16 00:00:00", "1967-03-16 00:00:00", "1977-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-05-09 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Lafayette", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Minneapolis", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "British Columbia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Waterloo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Northwest", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Iowa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington ,", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "- United States", "country": "unknown"}, States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mesaba", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2209547", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - USA (NE, IA) (05)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2209547", "date": "2006-04-14 23:50:00", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (NEBRASKA, IOWA) (04): AIR TRAVEL EXPOSURE\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 11 Apr 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: MMWR, 11 Apr 2006 / 55(Dispatch); 1-2 [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm55d411a1.htm?s_cid=mm55d411a1_e>\n\nExposure to Mumps During Air Travel - United States, April 2006\n-----------------------------------------------\nThe state of Iowa has been experiencing a large mumps outbreak that\nbegan in December 2005 (1). As of 10 Apr 2006, a total of 515\npossible mumps cases have been reported to the Iowa Department of\nPublic Health (IDPH) during 2006 (2). This outbreak has spread across\nIowa, and mumps activity, possibly linked to the Iowa outbreak, is\nunder investigation in 6 neighboring states, including Illinois (n =\n4), Kansas (n = 33), Minnesota (n = one), Missouri (n = 4), Nebraska\n(n = 43), and Wisconsin (n = 4) (CDC, unpublished data, 10 Apr 2006).\nThe reasons for this outbreak are under investigation.\nMumps is an acute viral infection characterized by a nonspecific\nprodrome, including myalgia, anorexia, malaise, headache, and fever,\nfollowed by acute onset of unilateral or bilateral tender swelling of\nparotid or other salivary glands (2). An estimated 60 percent to 70\npercent of mumps infections produce typical acute parotitis (3).\nApproximately 20 percent of infections are asymptomatic, and nearly\n50 percent are associated with nonspecific or primarily respiratory\nsymptoms. Complications include orchitis, oophoritis, or mastitis\n(inflammation of the testicles, ovaries, or breasts, respectively),\nmeningitis/encephalitis, spontaneous abortion, and deafness.\nTransmission occurs by direct contact with respiratory droplets or\nsaliva. The incubation period is 14-18 days (range: 14-25 days) from\nexposure to onset of symptoms. The infectious period is from 3 days\nbefore symptom onset until 9 days after onset of symptoms.\nIDPH has identified 2 persons who had mumps diagnosed and were\npotentially infectious during travel on 9 different commercial\nflights involving 2 airlines during 26 Mar-2 Apr 2006. The commercial\nairline flights identified with a potentially infectious traveler are\nlisted below by date, carrier, and flight number:\nNorthwest Airline (NWA) flights:\n26 Mar 2006 - NWA (Mesaba) #3025 from Waterloo, Iowa to Minneapolis, Minnesota\n26 Mar 2006 - NWA #760 from Minneapolis, Minnesota, to Detroit, Michigan\n27 Mar 2006 - NWA #0260 from Detroit, Michigan, to Washington,\nDC--Reagan National\n29 Mar 2006 - NWA #1705 from Washington, DC--Reagan National to\nMinneapolis, Minnesota\n29 Mar 2006 - NWA (Mesaba) #3026 from Minneapolis, Minnesota, to Waterloo, Iowa\nAmerican Airlines (AA) flights:\n2 Apr 2006 - AA #1216 from Tucson, Arizona, to Dallas, Texas (DFW)\n2 Apr 2006 - AA #3617 from DFW to Lafayette, Arkansas (Northwest\nArkansas Regional [NAR])\n2 Apr 2006 - AA #5399 from NAR to St. Louis, Missouri\n2 Apr 2006 - AA #5498 from St. Louis, Missouri, to Cedar Rapids, Iowa\nPersons on these flights who have symptoms consistent with mumps\nwithin 21 days of travel should be evaluated for mumps by an\nhealth-care provider. Health-care providers should remain vigilant\nfor mumps among persons with parotitis or other salivary gland\ninflammation. Cases of suspected mumps should be reported immediately\nto public health officials.\nA multistate investigation has been initiated by CDC and the state\nhealth departments in affected states to notify potentially exposed\npassengers (i.e., those seated in close proximity to the index\ncases). This investigation is using a new software application,\neManifest, developed by the CDC Division of Global Migration and\nQuarantine (DGMQ) to securely import, sort, and assign\npassenger-locating information to jurisdictions to facilitate timely\nidentification of exposed persons. These data are securely\ntransmitted to state and territorial health departments via the\nEpidemic Information Exchange (Epi-X) Forum (available at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/epix/epix.html>) for notification of\npotentially exposed passengers.\nIncidence of mumps in the United States began to decrease after\nvaccine introduction in 1967 and recommendations for routine\nvaccination of children in 1977. Since the 1990s, a further decrease\nin the reported incidence of mumps has occurred, which is thought to\nbe attributable to the implementation of the 2nd dose of measles,\nmumps, and rubella vaccine (3). The risk for transmission of\nrespiratory infectious diseases during air travel might depend on\nseveral factors, including 1) immunity of passengers; 2)\ninfectiousness of the organism; 3) degree of shedding of the pathogen\nby infected passengers; 4) hygienic practices of infectious\npassengers; 5) proximity of others to infectious passengers; 6)\nhygienic practices of the other passengers/crew; 7) flight duration;\nand 8) cabin environment of the aircraft (4). Transmission of other\nrespiratory pathogens during air travel has been reported (5-9).\nExposure and transmission of mumps during commercial air travel has\nnot been described previously.\n[Reported by: P Quinlisk, MD, Iowa Dept of Public Health. S Redd, G\nDayan, MD, National Center for Immunization and Respiratory Diseases;\nN Gallagher, Geographic Medicine and Health Promotion Br, P Lutz, K\nMarienau, MD, F Averhoff, MD, Quarantine and Border Health Svcs Br,\nDiv of Global Migration and Quarantine, National Center for\nInfectious Diseases, CDC.]\nReferences:\n1. CDC. Mumps epidemic, Iowa, 2006. MMWR 2006;55:366-8.\n2. Iowa Department of Public Health, Center for Acute Disease\nEpidemiology. Iowa mumps update. Des Moines, Iowa: Iowa Department of\nPublic Health; 2006. Available at\n<http://www.idph.state.ia.us/adper/common/pdf/mumps/mumps_update_041106.pdf>.\n3. Plotkin SA, Orenstein WA, eds. Vaccines. 4th ed. Philadelphia, PA:\nWB Saunders; 2003:441-69.\n4. Mangili A, Glendreau M. Transmission of infectious diseases during\ncommercial air travel. Lancet 2005;365:989-96.\n5. World Health Organization. Tuberculosis and air travel: guidelines\nfor prevention and control. 2nd ed. Geneva, Switzerland: World Health\nOrganization; 2006:5-7. Available at:\n<http://www.who.int/docstore/gtb/publications/aircraft/PDF/98_256.pdf>\n6. CDC. Postexposure prophylaxis, isolation, and quarantine to\ncontrol an import-associated measles outbreak - Iowa, 2004. MMWR\n2004; 53:969-71.\n7. Moser MR, Bend TR, Margolis HS, et al. An outbreak of influenza\naboard a commercial airline. Am J Epidemiol 1979;110:1-6.\n8. Klonz KC, Hynes NA, Gunn RA, et al. An outbreak of influenza\nA/Taiwan/1/86 infections at a naval base and its association with\nairplane travel. Am J Epidemiol 1989;129:341-8.\n9. Marsden AG. Influenza outbreak related to air travel. Med J\nAustral 2003;179:172-3.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[ProMED-mail has been covering this unusual outbreak due to the size\nof the outbreak, the genotype involved (genotype G, most recently\nassociated with outbreaks in the United Kingdom) and now the\nadditional information that there may be spread to neighboring states\nand the possibility of exposure during airline travel. The mention of\na new software application \"eManifest\" is interesting, and one\nwonders whether it shortens the time necessary to identify passengers\nat risk of exposure to diseases while traveling. We look forward to\nhearing more about this tool. - Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\nMumps - USA (NE, IA) (03) 20060406.1037\nMumps - USA (NE, IA)(02) 20060405.1023\nMumps - USA (NE, IA) 20060403.1000\nMumps virus, genotype G - USA (IA) 20060315.0809\n2004\n----\nMumps, students - UK (02) 20041126.3166\nMumps, students - UK & Ireland (03) 20041117.3089\nMumps, students - UK & Ireland (02) 20041112.3055\nMumps, students - UK & Ireland 20041110.3039\nMumps, students - UK 20041103.2974\nMumps - UK (Scotland) (03) 20040223.0575\nMumps - UK (Scotland) (02): background 20040221.0554\nMumps - UK (Scotland) 20040220.0545\n2003\n----\nMumps, increase - UK (02) 20031123.2910\nMumps, increase - UK 20030524.1284\n2001\n----\nMumps, consequence of reduced MMRV uptake - UK (02) 20010831.2069\nMumps, consequence of reduced MMRV uptake - UK 20010806.1858\n1999\n----\nMumps & Rubini vaccine - Singapore 19991025.1937\nMumps, imported - UK: RFI 19990223.0241\n1997\n----\nMumps - Canada (British Columbia) (02) 19971123.2351\nMumps - Canada (British Columbia) 19971119.2336\n1995\n----\nMumps surveillance - US (MMWR Supplement SS-3) 19950811.0672\n...........................mpp/msp/lm\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2209546", "date": "2006-04-14 23:50:00", "main_text": "MUMPS - USA (NEBRASKA, IOWA) (04): AIR TRAVEL EXPOSURE\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 11 Apr 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: MMWR, 11 Apr 2006 / 55(Dispatch); 1-2 [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm55d411a1.htm?s_cid=mm55d411a1_e>\n\nExposure to Mumps During Air Travel - United States, April 2006\n-----------------------------------------------\nThe state of Iowa has been experiencing a large mumps outbreak that\nbegan in December 2005 (1). As of 10 Apr 2006, a total of 515\npossible mumps cases have been reported to the Iowa Department of\nPublic Health (IDPH) during 2006 (2). This outbreak has spread across\nIowa, and mumps activity, possibly linked to the Iowa outbreak, is\nunder investigation in 6 neighboring states, including Illinois (n =\n4), Kansas (n = 33), Minnesota (n = one), Missouri (n = 4), Nebraska\n(n = 43), and Wisconsin (n = 4) (CDC, unpublished data, 10 Apr 2006).\nThe reasons for this outbreak are under investigation.\nMumps is an acute viral infection characterized by a nonspecific\nprodrome, including myalgia, anorexia, malaise, headache, and fever,\nfollowed by acute onset of unilateral or bilateral tender swelling of\nparotid or other salivary glands (2). An estimated 60 percent to 70\npercent of mumps infections produce typical acute parotitis (3).\nApproximately 20 percent of infections are asymptomatic, and nearly\n50 percent are associated with nonspecific or primarily respiratory\nsymptoms. Complications include orchitis, oophoritis, or mastitis\n(inflammation of the testicles, ovaries, or breasts, respectively),\nmeningitis/encephalitis, spontaneous abortion, and deafness.\nTransmission occurs by direct contact with respiratory droplets or\nsaliva. The incubation period is 14-18 days (range: 14-25 days) from\nexposure to onset of symptoms. The infectious period is from 3 days\nbefore symptom onset until 9 days after onset of symptoms.\nIDPH has identified 2 persons who had mumps diagnosed and were\npotentially infectious during travel on 9 different commercial\nflights involving 2 airlines during 26 Mar-2 Apr 2006. The commercial\nairline flights identified with a potentially infectious traveler are\nlisted below by date, carrier, and flight number:\nNorthwest Airline (NWA) flights:\n26 Mar 2006 - NWA (Mesaba) #3025 from Waterloo, Iowa to Minneapolis, Minnesota\n26 Mar 2006 - NWA #760 from Minneapolis, Minnesota, to Detroit, Michigan\n27 Mar 2006 - NWA #0260 from Detroit, Michigan, to Washington,\nDC--Reagan National\n29 Mar 2006 - NWA #1705 from Washington, DC--Reagan National to\nMinneapolis, Minnesota\n29 Mar 2006 - NWA (Mesaba) #3026 from Minneapolis, Minnesota, to Waterloo, Iowa\nAmerican Airlines (AA) flights:\n2 Apr 2006 - AA #1216 from Tucson, Arizona, to Dallas, Texas (DFW)\n2 Apr 2006 - AA #3617 from DFW to Lafayette, Arkansas (Northwest\nArkansas Regional [NAR])\n2 Apr 2006 - AA #5399 from NAR to St. Louis, Missouri\n2 Apr 2006 - AA #5498 from St. Louis, Missouri, to Cedar Rapids, Iowa\nPersons on these flights who have symptoms consistent with mumps\nwithin 21 days of travel should be evaluated for mumps by an\nhealth-care provider. Health-care providers should remain vigilant\nfor mumps among persons with parotitis or other salivary gland\ninflammation. Cases of suspected mumps should be reported immediately\nto public health officials.\nA multistate investigation has been initiated by CDC and the state\nhealth departments in affected states to notify potentially exposed\npassengers (i.e., those seated in close proximity to the index\ncases). This investigation is using a new software application,\neManifest, developed by the CDC Division of Global Migration and\nQuarantine (DGMQ) to securely import, sort, and assign\npassenger-locating information to jurisdictions to facilitate timely\nidentification of exposed persons. These data are securely\ntransmitted to state and territorial health departments via the\nEpidemic Information Exchange (Epi-X) Forum (available at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/epix/epix.html>) for notification of\npotentially exposed passengers.\nIncidence of mumps in the United States began to decrease after\nvaccine introduction in 1967 and recommendations for routine\nvaccination of children in 1977. Since the 1990s, a further decrease\nin the reported incidence of mumps has occurred, which is thought to\nbe attributable to the implementation of the 2nd dose of measles,\nmumps, and rubella vaccine (3). The risk for transmission of\nrespiratory infectious diseases during air travel might depend on\nseveral factors, including 1) immunity of passengers; 2)\ninfectiousness of the organism; 3) degree of shedding of the pathogen\nby infected passengers; 4) hygienic practices of infectious\npassengers; 5) proximity of others to infectious passengers; 6)\nhygienic practices of the other passengers/crew; 7) flight duration;\nand 8) cabin environment of the aircraft (4). Transmission of other\nrespiratory pathogens during air travel has been reported (5-9).\nExposure and transmission of mumps during commercial air travel has\nnot been described previously.\n[Reported by: P Quinlisk, MD, Iowa Dept of Public Health. S Redd, G\nDayan, MD, National Center for Immunization and Respiratory Diseases;\nN Gallagher, Geographic Medicine and Health Promotion Br, P Lutz, K\nMarienau, MD, F Averhoff, MD, Quarantine and Border Health Svcs Br,\nDiv of Global Migration and Quarantine, National Center for\nInfectious Diseases, CDC.]\nReferences:\n1. CDC. Mumps epidemic, Iowa, 2006. MMWR 2006;55:366-8.\n2. Iowa Department of Public Health, Center for Acute Disease\nEpidemiology. Iowa mumps update. Des Moines, Iowa: Iowa Department of\nPublic Health; 2006. Available at\n<http://www.idph.state.ia.us/adper/common/pdf/mumps/mumps_update_041106.pdf>.\n3. Plotkin SA, Orenstein WA, eds. Vaccines. 4th ed. Philadelphia, PA:\nWB Saunders; 2003:441-69.\n4. Mangili A, Glendreau M. Transmission of infectious diseases during\ncommercial air travel. Lancet 2005;365:989-96.\n5. World Health Organization. Tuberculosis and air travel: guidelines\nfor prevention and control. 2nd ed. Geneva, Switzerland: World Health\nOrganization; 2006:5-7. Available at:\n<http://www.who.int/docstore/gtb/publications/aircraft/PDF/98_256.pdf>\n6. CDC. Postexposure prophylaxis, isolation, and quarantine to\ncontrol an import-associated measles outbreak - Iowa, 2004. MMWR\n2004; 53:969-71.\n7. Moser MR, Bend TR, Margolis HS, et al. Med J\nAustral 2003;179:172-3.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[ProMED-mail has been covering this unusual outbreak due to the size\nof the outbreak, the genotype involved (genotype G, most recently\nassociated with outbreaks in the United Kingdom) and now the\nadditional information that there may be spread to neighboring states\nand the possibility of exposure during airline travel. The mention of\na new software application \"eManifest\" is interesting, and one\nwonders whether it shortens the time necessary to identify passengers\nat risk of exposure to diseases while traveling. We look forward to\nhearing more about this tool. - Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\nMumps - USA (NE, IA) (03) 20060406.1037\nMumps - USA (NE, IA)(02) 20060405.1023\nMumps - USA (NE, IA) 20060403.1000\nMumps virus, genotype G - USA (IA) 20060315.0809\n2004\n----\nMumps, students - UK (02) 20041126.3166\nMumps, students - UK & Ireland (03) 20041117.3089\nMumps, students - UK & Ireland (02) 20041112.3055\nMumps, students - UK & Ireland 20041110.3039\nMumps, students - UK 20041103.2974\nMumps - UK (Scotland) (03) 20040223.0575\nMumps - UK (Scotland) (02): background 20040221.0554\nMumps - UK (Scotland) 20040220.0545\n2003\n----\nMumps, increase - UK (02) 20031123.2910\nMumps, increase - UK 20030524.1284\n2001\n----\nMumps, consequence of reduced MMRV uptake - UK (02) 20010831.2069\nMumps, consequence of reduced MMRV uptake - UK 20010806.1858\n1999\n----\nMumps & Rubini vaccine - Singapore 19991025.1937\nMumps, imported - UK: RFI 19990223.0241\n1997\n----\nMumps - Canada (British Columbia) (02) 19971123.2351\nMumps - Canada (British Columbia) 19971119.2336\n1995\n----\nMumps surveillance - US (MMWR Supplement SS-3) 19950811.0672\n...........................mpp/msp/lm\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2209506", "date": "2004-11-10 23:50:00", "main_text": "MUMPS, STUDENTS - UK & IRELAND\n*****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: Wed 10 Nov 2004\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: The Scotsman newspaper, Press Association report, Tue 9 Nov 2004\n[edited]\n<http://news.scotsman.com/latest.cfm?id=3737362>\n\nUK: mumps outbreak hits Cambridge University\n-----------------------------------------------\nStudents at Cambridge are among the latest to be affected by a mumps\nepidemic striking British universities. University officials said today\n[Tue 9 Nov 2004 ] that 38 students had been diagnosed with the disease\nsince the autumn term began. Students under the age of 25 were being\noffered vaccinations, said a spokeswoman. Affected colleges include Jesus,\nEmmanuel, Pembroke, St. Catharine's, Peterhouse, Corpus Christi, Churchill,\nand Trinity Hall.\n\"The university published advice in the student handbook. We advised all\nstudents to check if they had been immunized, and if not, to arrange for\nimmunization through their GP,\" she said. \"1st-year students were offered\nthe opportunity to be vaccinated free of charge through their GP, once they\narrived in the city.\"\nUniversities across the UK have been setting up vaccination programs in\nrecent weeks. Experts believe that around 3000 students and young people --\nborn before the infant MMR triple vaccine program began -- could be\ninfected with the virus by the end of the year [2004] if trends continue.\n[Byline: Brian Farmer]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: Wed 10 Nov 2004\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: News, Tue 9 Nov 2004 [edited]\n<http://212.2.162.45/news/story.asp?j=123501286&p=yz35xy99z&n=123502046>\n\nIreland: mumps outbreak hits 3 colleges\n-------------------------------------------\nThe National Disease Surveillance Centre is investigating an outbreak of\nmumps at 3 colleges in Westmeath, Donegal, and Kildare. Around 75 cases of\nthe viral infection have been reported in Athlone Institute of Technology,\nLetterkenny Institute of Technology, and St. Patrick College in Maynooth.\nThis is more than double the total number of mumps cases reported for this\ntime last year [2003]. Mumps can be potentially serious for children and\nyoung adults, and any students with symptoms, such as fever and headaches,\nhave been advised to stay at home.\n--\nProMED-mail\n@promedmail.org>\nSee Also\nMumps, students - UK 20041103.2974\nMumps - UK (Scotland) 20040220.0545\nMumps - UK (Scotland) (02): background 20040221.0554\nMumps - UK (Scotland) (03) 20040223.0575\n2003\n----\nMumps, increase - UK 20030524.1284\nMumps, increase - UK (02) 20031123.2910\n......................cp/msp/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\n* *\n* Please support the 2004 ProMED-mail Internet-a-thon! *\n* http://www.isid.org/netathon2004.shtml *\n* *\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. University officials said today\n[Tue 9 Nov 2004 ] that 38 students had been diagnosed with the disease\nsince the autumn term began. Students under the age of 25 were being\noffered vaccinations, said a spokeswoman. Affected colleges include Jesus,\nEmmanuel, Pembroke, St. Catharine's, Peterhouse, Corpus Christi, Churchill,\nand Trinity Hall.\n\"The university published advice in the student handbook. We advised all\nstudents to check if they had been immunized, and if not, to arrange for\nimmunization through their GP,\" she said. \"1st-year students were offered\nthe opportunity to be vaccinated free of charge through their GP, once they\narrived in the city.\"\nUniversities across the UK have been setting up vaccination programs in\nrecent weeks. Experts believe that around 3000 students and young people --\nborn before the infant MMR triple vaccine program began -- could be\ninfected with the virus by the end of the year [2004] if trends continue.\n[Byline: Brian Farmer]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: Wed 10 Nov 2004\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: News, Tue 9 Nov 2004 [edited]\n<http://212.2.162.45/news/story.asp?j=123501286&p=yz35xy99z&n=123502046>\n\nIreland: mumps outbreak hits 3 colleges\n-------------------------------------------\nThe National Disease Surveillance Centre is investigating an outbreak of\nmumps at 3 colleges in Westmeath, Donegal, and Kildare. Around 75 cases of\nthe viral infection have been reported in Athlone Institute of Technology,\nLetterkenny Institute of Technology, and St. Patrick College in Maynooth.\nThis is more than double the total number of mumps cases reported for this\ntime last year [2003]. Mumps can be potentially serious for children and\nyoung adults, and any students with symptoms, such as fever and headaches,\nhave been advised to stay at home.\n--\nProMED-mail\n@promedmail.org>\nSee Also\nMumps, students - UK 20041103.2974\nMumps - UK (Scotland) 20040220.0545\nMumps - UK (Scotland) (02): background 20040221.0554\nMumps - UK (Scotland) (03) 20040223.0575\n2003\n----\nMumps, increase - UK 20030524.1284\nMumps, increase - UK (02) 20031123.2910\n......................cp/msp/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\n* *\n* Please support the 2004 ProMED-mail Internet-a-thon! *\n* http://www.isid.org/netathon2004.shtml *\n* *\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["mumps"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Westmeath", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cambridge", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Donegal", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2206807", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps, students - UK", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2206807", "date": "1999-10-25 23:50:00", "main_text": "MUMPS & RUBINI VACCINE - SINGAPORE\n**********************************\nA ProMED post\n<http://www.healthnet.org/programs/promed.html>\nDate: Fri, 22 Oct 1999\nFrom: Chan Yow Cheong mailto:chanyowcheong@pacific.net.sg\nProMED Regional Moderator for Asia\nSource: Eurosurveillance Weekly, issue 43, 21 Oct 1999\n<http://www.eurosurv.org/update/>\n\nResurgence of mumps in Singapore associated with Rubini vaccine\n---------------------------------------------------------------\nThe incidence of mumps has increased in Singapore since the measles, mumps,\nand rubella (MMR) vaccine was introduced into the national childhood\nimmunisation programme in 1990, while the incidence of measles and rubella\nhas declined (1). Since 1990 three strains of mumps virus - Urabe,\nJeryl-Lynn, and Rubini - have been used in MMR vaccines. The Urabe strain\nwas withdrawn in 1992 after an increased risk of aseptic meninigitis was\nreported in other countries and the Rubini strain was purchased between\n1993 and 1995. In more recent years the Jeryl-Lynn strain (vaccine efficacy\n75%) has also been used (KT Goh, personal communication). The incidence of\nmumps increased from 674 cases in 1997 to 1183 cases in 1998, 2586 cases\nwere reported in the first seven months of 1999, and it is estimated that\nthe incidence will reach 200 per 100 000 population by the end of 1999.\nForty-four per cent (258) of 592 cases that arose in the last four months\nof 1998 had received MMR vaccine. Of 195 whose mumps vaccine strain was\nknown, 144 (74%) had received the Rubini strain, 42 (22%) the Jeryl-Lynn\nstrain, and nine (5%) the Urabe strain. About 75% of cases had received MMR\nvaccine between one and four years before developing mumps.\nEpidemiological evidence suggested that the Rubini vaccine strain offered\nno protection. One hundred and forty of 1546 children who had been\nvaccinated with the Rubini strain developed mumps - an attack rate of 9%.\nThe short interval between vaccination and illness indicated primary rather\nthan secondary vaccine failure due waning immunity over time.\nSeroepidemiological evidence showed that the prevalence of mumps antibody\nin children aged under 5 years of age was 22% in 1989 before MMR was\nintroduced. It increased to 72% in 1993 after mumps vaccination with the\nUrabe and Jeryl-Lynn strains was introduced, but it fell to 26% in 1998.\nThe Ministry of Health in Singapore deregistered the MMR vaccine containing\nthe Rubini strain in May 1999.\nThe poor protection of the Rubini strain in mumps vaccine has been noted in\nother countries (2-4). In Portugal, Rubini replaced the Urabe strain in MMR\nvaccine in October 1992 and resulted in a large increase in the incidence\nof mumps in children (5). The highest rates of mumps occurred in children\naged 1 to 4 years during a mumps epidemic in 1995/96. By January 1998 all\nPortuguese health centres had begun to use MMR vaccine containing the Jeryl\nLynn strain in place of the Rubini strain (6).\nReferences:\nGoh KT. Resurgence of mumps in Singapore caused by the Rubini mumps virus\nvaccine strain. Lancet 1999; 354: 1355-6. (http://www.thelancet.com/)\nGalazka AM, Robinson SE, Kraigher A. Mumps and mumps vaccine: a global\nreview. Bull World Health Organ 1999; 77: 3-14. (http://www.who.int/bulletin/)\nToscani L, Batou M, Bouvier P, Schlanepfer A. Comparaison de l'efficacit\u00e9\nde diff\u00e9rentes souches de vaccin ourlien: une enqu\u00eate en milieu scolare. Soz\nPraventivmed 1996; 41: 341-7.\nGermann D, Strohle A. Eggenberger K. Steiner CA. Matter I. An outbreak of\nmumps in a population partially vaccinated with the Rubini strain. Scand J\nInfect Dis 1996; 28: 235-8.\nDias JA, Cordeiro M, Freitas MG, Morgado MR, Silva JL, Nunes LM, et al.\nMumps outbreak in Portugal despite high vaccine coverage - preliminary\nreport. Eurosurveillance 1996; 1: 25-8. (http://www.ceses.org/eurosurv)\nGon\u00e7alves G, de Ara\u00fajo A, Monteiro Cardoso ML. Outbreak of mumps associated\nwith poor vaccine efficacy - Oporto, Portugal, 1996. Eurosurveillance 1998;\n3: 119-21. (http://www.ceses.org/eurosurv)\n(Reported by Caroline Akehurst, (cakehurs@phls.nhs.uk), PHLS Communicable\nDisease Surveillance Centre, London, England.)\n--\nProMED\ne-mail: promed@promedmail.org\n......................................jw/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2043-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "1990-03-16 00:00:00", "1990-03-16 00:00:00", "1992-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "2586-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "2042-03-16 00:00:00", "1546-03-16 00:00:00", "1989-03-16 00:00:00", "1993-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-05-16 00:00:00", "2021-02-04 00:00:00", "1992-10-16 00:00:00", "1998-01-16 00:00:00", "1355-06-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "1996-03-16 00:00:00", "1996-03-16 00:00:00", "1996-03-16 00:00:00", "1996-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Portugal", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "London", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Singapore", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oporto", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Batou M", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2205323", "headline": "PRO> Mumps - The Urabe strain\nwas withdrawn in 1992 after an increased risk of aseptic meninigitis was\nreported in other countries and the Rubini strain was purchased between\n1993 and 1995. In more recent years the Jeryl-Lynn strain (vaccine efficacy\n75%) has also been used (KT Goh, personal communication). The incidence of\nmumps increased from 674 cases in 1997 to 1183 cases in 1998, 2586 cases\nwere reported in the first seven months of 1999, and it is estimated that\nthe incidence will reach 200 per 100 000 population by the end of 1999.\nForty-four per cent (258) of 592 cases that arose in the last four months\nof 1998 had received MMR vaccine.
