It increased to 72% in 1993 after mumps vaccination with the\nUrabe and Jeryl-Lynn strains was introduced, but it fell to 26% in 1998.\nThe Ministry of Health in Singapore deregistered the MMR vaccine containing\nthe Rubini strain in May 1999.\nThe poor protection of the Rubini strain in mumps vaccine has been noted in\nother countries (2-4). In Portugal, Rubini replaced the Urabe strain in MMR\nvaccine in October 1992 and resulted in a large increase in the incidence\nof mumps in children (5). The highest rates of mumps occurred in children\naged 1 to 4 years during a mumps epidemic in 1995/96. By January 1998 all\nPortuguese health centres had begun to use MMR vaccine containing the Jeryl\nLynn strain in place of the Rubini strain (6).\nReferences:\nGoh KT. (http://www.ceses.org/eurosurv)\n(Reported by Caroline Akehurst, (cakehurs@phls.nhs.uk), PHLS Communicable\nDisease Surveillance Centre, London, England.)\n--\nProMED\ne-mail: promed@promedmail.org\n......................................jw/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2043-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "1990-03-16 00:00:00", "1990-03-16 00:00:00", "1992-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "2586-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "2042-03-16 00:00:00", "1546-03-16 00:00:00", "1989-03-16 00:00:00", "1993-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-05-16 00:00:00", "2021-02-04 00:00:00", "1992-10-16 00:00:00", "1998-01-16 00:00:00", "1355-06-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "1996-03-16 00:00:00", "1996-03-16 00:00:00", "1996-03-16 00:00:00", "1996-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Portugal", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "London", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Singapore", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oporto", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Batou M", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2205316", "headline": "PRO> Mumps - UK (Scotland) (02): background", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2205316", "date": "1999-10-25 23:50:00", "main_text": "MUMPS & RUBINI VACCINE - SINGAPORE\n**********************************\nA ProMED post\n<http://www.healthnet.org/programs/promed.html>\nDate: Fri, 22 Oct 1999\nFrom: Chan Yow Cheong mailto:chanyowcheong@pacific.net.sg\nProMED Regional Moderator for Asia\nSource: Eurosurveillance Weekly, issue 43, 21 Oct 1999\n<http://www.eurosurv.org/update/>\n\nResurgence of mumps in Singapore associated with Rubini vaccine\n---------------------------------------------------------------\nThe incidence of mumps has increased in Singapore since the measles, mumps,\nand rubella (MMR) vaccine was introduced into the national childhood\nimmunisation programme in 1990, while the incidence of measles and rubella\nhas declined (1). Since 1990 three strains of mumps virus - Urabe,\nJeryl-Lynn, and Rubini - have been used in MMR vaccines. The Urabe strain\nwas withdrawn in 1992 after an increased risk of aseptic meninigitis was\nreported in other countries and the Rubini strain was purchased between\n1993 and 1995. In more recent years the Jeryl-Lynn strain (vaccine efficacy\n75%) has also been used (KT Goh, personal communication). The incidence of\nmumps increased from 674 cases in 1997 to 1183 cases in 1998, 2586 cases\nwere reported in the first seven months of 1999, and it is estimated that\nthe incidence will reach 200 per 100 000 population by the end of 1999.\nForty-four per cent (258) of 592 cases that arose in the last four months\nof 1998 had received MMR vaccine. Of 195 whose mumps vaccine strain was\nknown, 144 (74%) had received the Rubini strain, 42 (22%) the Jeryl-Lynn\nstrain, and nine (5%) the Urabe strain. About 75% of cases had received MMR\nvaccine between one and four years before developing mumps.\nEpidemiological evidence suggested that the Rubini vaccine strain offered\nno protection. One hundred and forty of 1546 children who had been\nvaccinated with the Rubini strain developed mumps - an attack rate of 9%.\nThe short interval between vaccination and illness indicated primary rather\nthan secondary vaccine failure due waning immunity over time.\nSeroepidemiological evidence showed that the prevalence of mumps antibody\nin children aged under 5 years of age was 22% in 1989 before MMR was\nintroduced. It increased to 72% in 1993 after mumps vaccination with the\nUrabe and Jeryl-Lynn strains was introduced, but it fell to 26% in 1998.\nThe Ministry of Health in Singapore deregistered the MMR vaccine containing\nthe Rubini strain in May 1999.\nThe poor protection of the Rubini strain in mumps vaccine has been noted in\nother countries (2-4). In Portugal, Rubini replaced the Urabe strain in MMR\nvaccine in October 1992 and resulted in a large increase in the incidence\nof mumps in children (5). The highest rates of mumps occurred in children\naged 1 to 4 years during a mumps epidemic in 1995/96. By January 1998 all\nPortuguese health centres had begun to use MMR vaccine containing the Jeryl\nLynn strain in place of the Rubini strain (6).\nReferences:\nGoh KT. Resurgence of mumps in Singapore caused by the Rubini mumps virus\nvaccine strain. Lancet 1999; 354: 1355-6. (http://www.thelancet.com/)\nGalazka AM, Robinson SE, Kraigher A. Mumps and mumps vaccine: a global\nreview. Bull World Health Organ 1999; 77: 3-14. (http://www.who.int/bulletin/)\nToscani L, Batou M, Bouvier P, Schlanepfer A. Comparaison de l'efficacit\u00e9\nde diff\u00e9rentes souches de vaccin ourlien: une enqu\u00eate en milieu scolare. Soz\nPraventivmed 1996; 41: 341-7.\nGermann D, Strohle A. Eggenberger K. Steiner CA. Matter I. An outbreak of\nmumps in a population partially vaccinated with the Rubini strain. Scand J\nInfect Dis 1996; 28: 235-8.\nDias JA, Cordeiro M, Freitas MG, Morgado MR, Silva JL, Nunes LM, et al.\nMumps outbreak in Portugal despite high vaccine coverage - preliminary\nreport. Eurosurveillance 1996; 1: 25-8. (http://www.ceses.org/eurosurv)\nGon\u00e7alves G, de Ara\u00fajo A, Monteiro Cardoso ML. Outbreak of mumps associated\nwith poor vaccine efficacy - Oporto, Portugal, 1996. Eurosurveillance 1998;\n3: 119-21. (http://www.ceses.org/eurosurv)\n(Reported by Caroline Akehurst, (cakehurs@phls.nhs.uk), PHLS Communicable\nDisease Surveillance Centre, London, England.)\n--\nProMED\ne-mail: promed@promedmail.org\n......................................jw/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. (http://www.ceses.org/eurosurv)\n(Reported by Caroline Akehurst, (cakehurs@phls.nhs.uk), PHLS Communicable\nDisease Surveillance Centre, London, England.)\n--\nProMED\ne-mail: promed@promedmail.org\n......................................jw/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2043-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "1990-03-16 00:00:00", "1990-03-16 00:00:00", "1992-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "2586-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "2042-03-16 00:00:00", "1546-03-16 00:00:00", "1989-03-16 00:00:00", "1993-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-05-16 00:00:00", "2021-02-04 00:00:00", "1992-10-16 00:00:00", "1998-01-16 00:00:00", "1355-06-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "1996-03-16 00:00:00", "1996-03-16 00:00:00", "1996-03-16 00:00:00", "1996-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Portugal", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "London", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Singapore", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oporto", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Batou M", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2200369", "headline": "PRO> Mumps, consequence of reduced MMRV uptake - UK", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2200369", "date": "1999-10-25 23:50:00", "main_text": "MUMPS & RUBINI VACCINE - SINGAPORE\n**********************************\nA ProMED post\n<http://www.healthnet.org/programs/promed.html>\nDate: Fri, 22 Oct 1999\nFrom: Chan Yow Cheong mailto:chanyowcheong@pacific.net.sg\nProMED Regional Moderator for Asia\nSource: Eurosurveillance Weekly, issue 43, 21 Oct 1999\n<http://www.eurosurv.org/update/>\n\nResurgence of mumps in Singapore associated with Rubini vaccine\n---------------------------------------------------------------\nThe incidence of mumps has increased in Singapore since the measles, mumps,\nand rubella (MMR) vaccine was introduced into the national childhood\nimmunisation programme in 1990, while the incidence of measles and rubella\nhas declined (1). Since 1990 three strains of mumps virus - Urabe,\nJeryl-Lynn, and Rubini - have been used in MMR vaccines. The Urabe strain\nwas withdrawn in 1992 after an increased risk of aseptic meninigitis was\nreported in other countries and the Rubini strain was purchased between\n1993 and 1995. In more recent years the Jeryl-Lynn strain (vaccine efficacy\n75%) has also been used (KT Goh, personal communication). The incidence of\nmumps increased from 674 cases in 1997 to 1183 cases in 1998, 2586 cases\nwere reported in the first seven months of 1999, and it is estimated that\nthe incidence will reach 200 per 100 000 population by the end of 1999.\nForty-four per cent (258) of 592 cases that arose in the last four months\nof 1998 had received MMR vaccine. Of 195 whose mumps vaccine strain was\nknown, 144 (74%) had received the Rubini strain, 42 (22%) the Jeryl-Lynn\nstrain, and nine (5%) the Urabe strain. About 75% of cases had received MMR\nvaccine between one and four years before developing mumps.\nEpidemiological evidence suggested that the Rubini vaccine strain offered\nno protection. One hundred and forty of 1546 children who had been\nvaccinated with the Rubini strain developed mumps - an attack rate of 9%.\nThe short interval between vaccination and illness indicated primary rather\nthan secondary vaccine failure due waning immunity over time.\nSeroepidemiological evidence showed that the prevalence of mumps antibody\nin children aged under 5 years of age was 22% in 1989 before MMR was\nintroduced. It increased to 72% in 1993 after mumps vaccination with the\nUrabe and Jeryl-Lynn strains was introduced, but it fell to 26% in 1998.\nThe Ministry of Health in Singapore deregistered the MMR vaccine containing\nthe Rubini strain in May 1999.\nThe poor protection of the Rubini strain in mumps vaccine has been noted in\nother countries (2-4). In Portugal, Rubini replaced the Urabe strain in MMR\nvaccine in October 1992 and resulted in a large increase in the incidence\nof mumps in children (5). The highest rates of mumps occurred in children\naged 1 to 4 years during a mumps epidemic in 1995/96. By January 1998 all\nPortuguese health centres had begun to use MMR vaccine containing the Jeryl\nLynn strain in place of the Rubini strain (6).\nReferences:\nGoh KT. Resurgence of mumps in Singapore caused by the Rubini mumps virus\nvaccine strain. Lancet 1999; 354: 1355-6. (http://www.thelancet.com/)\nGalazka AM, Robinson SE, Kraigher A. Mumps and mumps vaccine: a global\nreview. Bull World Health Organ 1999; 77: 3-14. (http://www.who.int/bulletin/)\nToscani L, Batou M, Bouvier P, Schlanepfer A. Comparaison de l'efficacit\u00e9\nde diff\u00e9rentes souches de vaccin ourlien: une enqu\u00eate en milieu scolare. Soz\nPraventivmed 1996; 41: 341-7.\nGermann D, Strohle A. Eggenberger K. Steiner CA. Matter I. An outbreak of\nmumps in a population partially vaccinated with the Rubini strain. Scand J\nInfect Dis 1996; 28: 235-8.\nDias JA, Cordeiro M, Freitas MG, Morgado MR, Silva JL, Nunes LM, et al.\nMumps outbreak in Portugal despite high vaccine coverage - preliminary\nreport. Eurosurveillance 1996; 1: 25-8. (http://www.ceses.org/eurosurv)\nGon\u00e7alves G, de Ara\u00fajo A, Monteiro Cardoso ML. Outbreak of mumps associated\nwith poor vaccine efficacy - Oporto, Portugal, 1996. Eurosurveillance 1998;\n3: 119-21. (http://www.ceses.org/eurosurv)\n(Reported by Caroline Akehurst, (cakehurs@phls.nhs.uk), PHLS Communicable\nDisease Surveillance Centre, London, England.)\n--\nProMED\ne-mail: promed@promedmail.org\n......................................jw/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2043-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "1990-03-16 00:00:00", "1990-03-16 00:00:00", "1992-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "2586-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "2042-03-16 00:00:00", "1546-03-16 00:00:00", "1989-03-16 00:00:00", "1993-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-05-16 00:00:00", "2021-02-04 00:00:00", "1992-10-16 00:00:00", "1998-01-16 00:00:00", "1355-06-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "1996-03-16 00:00:00", "1996-03-16 00:00:00", "1996-03-16 00:00:00", "1996-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Portugal", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "London", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Singapore", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oporto", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Batou M", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2195121", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps, imported - UK: RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2195121", "date": "1997-11-19 23:50:00", "main_text": "MUMPS - CANADA (BRITISH COLUMBIA)\n*********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nDate: Mon, 17 Nov 1997 10:21:31 -0800\nFrom: James Chin, MD, MPH, CDPC-mail and Canada Communicable Disease\nReport:23(22),\nNovember 15, 1997.\n\nMumps, an acute viral disease caused by mumps virus (family\n_Paramyxoviridae_, genus _Rubulavirus_), is defined for surveillance\npurposes as an illness characterized by fever and tender, self-limited\nswelling of the salivary gland(s), lasting about 2 days without other\napparent cause.\nIn January and February 1997, an unexpected number of cases of mumps were\nreported to the Vancouver/Richmond Health Board (V/RHB). An investigation\nwas initiated with the British Columbia Centre for Disease Control (BCCDC).\nBetween 1 January 1997 and 31 March 1997, a total of 83 cases of mumps were\nreported via the BC Communicable Disease Surveillance System.\nA universal combined measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) immunization program\nwas introduced in BC in 1981 for children aged >12 months.\nInitial case follow-ups by the V/RHB suggested that public social events\nwere risk factors for acquiring mumps in the young adult age group. A\ncase-control study was initiated to examine this hypothesis and to further\nexplore the outcomes of mumps illness. Vaccine effectiveness, ascertained\nby self-reported immunization status, was estimated to be 80% (95%\nconfidence interval [CI] = 29% to 96%).\nEighty-eight percent (45/51) of the cases reported being in the Greater\nVancouver area during the exposure period. Among the 47 matched\ncase-control pairs, contact with a person with mumps was significantly\nassociated with illness (odds ratio = 13, 95% CI = 1.95 to 552). Sixteen\nof the 40 cases aged 17 to 40 years, and one of the nine cases aged <17\nyears reported attending a \"rave\" party during the exposure period.\n\"Raves\" are very large gatherings of teenagers and young adults who listen\nand dance to electronic music in warehouse type venues. Of the risk\nfactors examined, exposure to rave parties was the most strongly associated\nwith illness (odds ratio = 17, 95% CI = 2.7 to 710). All \"rave\" attendees\nreported sharing drinks and dancing in close proximity to others.\nAttending educational institutions, having contact with >50 persons per day\nat work, being a health-care professional, attending dance clubs, bars, or\nother social events, and playing group sports were not associated with\nillness.\nThe increased incidence rates in this outbreak suggest that the 1957 to\n1980 birth cohorts were most at risk. These incompletely vaccinated birth\ncohorts sustain an adult population susceptible to outbreaks of mumps in\nthe future. This investigation highlights, as previously described, the\nhigh proportion of extra-salivary symptoms of mumps experienced by an adult\npopulation.\nThis is the second communicable disease outbreak reported to be associated\nwith \"rave\" parties in Canada, the first being a 1996 meningitis outbreak\nin Quebec. These social events, characterized by close contact and sharing\nof drinks, should be considered as a risk factor for mumps and other\nillnesses transmissible by person-to-person droplet spread.\nIn response to the outbreak and this investigation, the V/RHB released a\npublic notice about \"raves\" as a risk factor for acquiring mumps and a\nreminder about MMR vaccinations.\nSource: A Bell, MDCM, MHSc, M Fyfe, MD, MSc, Communicable Disease\nEpidemiology Services, BCCDC, M Bigham, MD, MHSc, P Daly, MD, V/RHB, J\nBuxton, MBBS, MHSc, Community Residency Program, Department of Health Care\nand Epidemiology, UBC, Vancouver, BC; C Craig, DVM, BSc, Field Epidemiology\nTraining Program, LCDC, Ottawa, ON.\n--\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: <promed@usa.healthnet.org>\n[This report comes long after the epidemic occurrence but serves as a\nreminder that mumps virus has not yet been eradicated and that appropriate\nvaccination levels must be maintained. - Mod.CHC]\n......................................chc/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org\n(NOT to an individual moderator). If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["1997-11-17 00:00:00", "1997-11-15 00:00:00", "1981-03-16 00:00:00", "1957-03-16 00:00:00", "1980-03-16 00:00:00", "1996-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Vancouver", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ottawa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Quebec", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2192269", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Canada (British Columbia) (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2192269", "date": "1997-11-19 23:50:00", "main_text": "MUMPS - CANADA (BRITISH COLUMBIA)\n*********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nDate: Mon, 17 Nov 1997 10:21:31 -0800\nFrom: James Chin, MD, MPH, CDPC-mail and Canada Communicable Disease\nReport:23(22),\nNovember 15, 1997.\n\nMumps, an acute viral disease caused by mumps virus (family\n_Paramyxoviridae_, genus _Rubulavirus_), is defined for surveillance\npurposes as an illness characterized by fever and tender, self-limited\nswelling of the salivary gland(s), lasting about 2 days without other\napparent cause.\nIn January and February 1997, an unexpected number of cases of mumps were\nreported to the Vancouver/Richmond Health Board (V/RHB). An investigation\nwas initiated with the British Columbia Centre for Disease Control (BCCDC).\nBetween 1 January 1997 and 31 March 1997, a total of 83 cases of mumps were\nreported via the BC Communicable Disease Surveillance System.\nA universal combined measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) immunization program\nwas introduced in BC in 1981 for children aged >12 months.\nInitial case follow-ups by the V/RHB suggested that public social events\nwere risk factors for acquiring mumps in the young adult age group. A\ncase-control study was initiated to examine this hypothesis and to further\nexplore the outcomes of mumps illness. Vaccine effectiveness, ascertained\nby self-reported immunization status, was estimated to be 80% (95%\nconfidence interval [CI] = 29% to 96%).\nEighty-eight percent (45/51) of the cases reported being in the Greater\nVancouver area during the exposure period. Among the 47 matched\ncase-control pairs, contact with a person with mumps was significantly\nassociated with illness (odds ratio = 13, 95% CI = 1.95 to 552). Sixteen\nof the 40 cases aged 17 to 40 years, and one of the nine cases aged <17\nyears reported attending a \"rave\" party during the exposure period.\n\"Raves\" are very large gatherings of teenagers and young adults who listen\nand dance to electronic music in warehouse type venues. Of the risk\nfactors examined, exposure to rave parties was the most strongly associated\nwith illness (odds ratio = 17, 95% CI = 2.7 to 710). All \"rave\" attendees\nreported sharing drinks and dancing in close proximity to others.\nAttending educational institutions, having contact with >50 persons per day\nat work, being a health-care professional, attending dance clubs, bars, or\nother social events, and playing group sports were not associated with\nillness.\nThe increased incidence rates in this outbreak suggest that the 1957 to\n1980 birth cohorts were most at risk. These incompletely vaccinated birth\ncohorts sustain an adult population susceptible to outbreaks of mumps in\nthe future. This investigation highlights, as previously described, the\nhigh proportion of extra-salivary symptoms of mumps experienced by an adult\npopulation.\nThis is the second communicable disease outbreak reported to be associated\nwith \"rave\" parties in Canada, the first being a 1996 meningitis outbreak\nin Quebec. These social events, characterized by close contact and sharing\nof drinks, should be considered as a risk factor for mumps and other\nillnesses transmissible by person-to-person droplet spread.\nIn response to the outbreak and this investigation, the V/RHB released a\npublic notice about \"raves\" as a risk factor for acquiring mumps and a\nreminder about MMR vaccinations.\nSource: A Bell, MDCM, MHSc, M Fyfe, MD, MSc, Communicable Disease\nEpidemiology Services, BCCDC, M Bigham, MD, MHSc, P Daly, MD, V/RHB, J\nBuxton, MBBS, MHSc, Community Residency Program, Department of Health Care\nand Epidemiology, UBC, Vancouver, BC; C Craig, DVM, BSc, Field Epidemiology\nTraining Program, LCDC, Ottawa, ON.\n--\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: <promed@usa.healthnet.org>\n[This report comes long after the epidemic occurrence but serves as a\nreminder that mumps virus has not yet been eradicated and that appropriate\nvaccination levels must be maintained. - Mod.CHC]\n......................................chc/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["1997-11-17 00:00:00", "1997-11-15 00:00:00", "1981-03-16 00:00:00", "1957-03-16 00:00:00", "1980-03-16 00:00:00", "1996-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Vancouver", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ottawa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Quebec", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2192254", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Mumps - Canada (British Columbia)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2192254", "date": "1997-11-19 23:50:00", "main_text": "MUMPS - CANADA (BRITISH COLUMBIA)\n*********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nDate: Mon, 17 Nov 1997 10:21:31 -0800\nFrom: James Chin, MD, MPH, CDPC-mail and Canada Communicable Disease\nReport:23(22),\nNovember 15, 1997.\n\nMumps, an acute viral disease caused by mumps virus (family\n_Paramyxoviridae_, genus _Rubulavirus_), is defined for surveillance\npurposes as an illness characterized by fever and tender, self-limited\nswelling of the salivary gland(s), lasting about 2 days without other\napparent cause.\nIn January and February 1997, an unexpected number of cases of mumps were\nreported to the Vancouver/Richmond Health Board (V/RHB). An investigation\nwas initiated with the British Columbia Centre for Disease Control (BCCDC).\nBetween 1 January 1997 and 31 March 1997, a total of 83 cases of mumps were\nreported via the BC Communicable Disease Surveillance System.\nA universal combined measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) immunization program\nwas introduced in BC in 1981 for children aged >12 months.\nInitial case follow-ups by the V/RHB suggested that public social events\nwere risk factors for acquiring mumps in the young adult age group. A\ncase-control study was initiated to examine this hypothesis and to further\nexplore the outcomes of mumps illness. Vaccine effectiveness, ascertained\nby self-reported immunization status, was estimated to be 80% (95%\nconfidence interval [CI] = 29% to 96%).\nEighty-eight percent (45/51) of the cases reported being in the Greater\nVancouver area during the exposure period. Among the 47 matched\ncase-control pairs, contact with a person with mumps was significantly\nassociated with illness (odds ratio = 13, 95% CI = 1.95 to 552). Sixteen\nof the 40 cases aged 17 to 40 years, and one of the nine cases aged <17\nyears reported attending a \"rave\" party during the exposure period.\n\"Raves\" are very large gatherings of teenagers and young adults who listen\nand dance to electronic music in warehouse type venues. Of the risk\nfactors examined, exposure to rave parties was the most strongly associated\nwith illness (odds ratio = 17, 95% CI = 2.7 to 710). All \"rave\" attendees\nreported sharing drinks and dancing in close proximity to others.\nAttending educational institutions, having contact with >50 persons per day\nat work, being a health-care professional, attending dance clubs, bars, or\nother social events, and playing group sports were not associated with\nillness.\nThe increased incidence rates in this outbreak suggest that the 1957 to\n1980 birth cohorts were most at risk. These incompletely vaccinated birth\ncohorts sustain an adult population susceptible to outbreaks of mumps in\nthe future. This investigation highlights, as previously described, the\nhigh proportion of extra-salivary symptoms of mumps experienced by an adult\npopulation.\nThis is the second communicable disease outbreak reported to be associated\nwith \"rave\" parties in Canada, the first being a 1996 meningitis outbreak\nin Quebec. These social events, characterized by close contact and sharing\nof drinks, should be considered as a risk factor for mumps and other\nillnesses transmissible by person-to-person droplet spread.\nIn response to the outbreak and this investigation, the V/RHB released a\npublic notice about \"raves\" as a risk factor for acquiring mumps and a\nreminder about MMR vaccinations.\nSource: A Bell, MDCM, MHSc, M Fyfe, MD, MSc, Communicable Disease\nEpidemiology Services, BCCDC, M Bigham, MD, MHSc, P Daly, MD, V/RHB, J\nBuxton, MBBS, MHSc, Community Residency Program, Department of Health Care\nand Epidemiology, UBC, Vancouver, BC; C Craig, DVM, BSc, Field Epidemiology\nTraining Program, LCDC, Ottawa, ON.\n--\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: <promed@usa.healthnet.org>\n[This report comes long after the epidemic occurrence but serves as a\nreminder that mumps virus has not yet been eradicated and that appropriate\nvaccination levels must be maintained. - Mod.CHC]\n......................................chc/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "rubella", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["1997-11-17 00:00:00", "1997-11-15 00:00:00", "1981-03-16 00:00:00", "1957-03-16 00:00:00", "1980-03-16 00:00:00", "1996-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Vancouver", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ottawa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Quebec", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}]}]}]}
